"Crooked gates" are like winding paths, a kind of convolution. "Uneven thresholds" are not level. "Crooked" is read as *lián*, like the *lián* in *línglóng* (intricate); "thresholds" is read as *liè*, like the *liè* in *lièliè* (uneven). And he stumbles into filthy ravines and bottomless pits. "Filthy ravines" are great chasms; "ravines" is read as *hè*, like the *hè* in *hèhè* (bright).

Though born equal to others, he cannot escape being mocked and ridiculed. Why? Because form and spirit have parted ways. Thus, those who take spirit as their master find their form following to their benefit; those who take form as their ruler find their spirit following to their harm. Spirit is clear and still, hence beneficial; form is moved by passions and desires, hence harmful.

The greedy and covetous, obsessed with power and profit, lured and enticed by fame and rank—"obsessed" is like being dull and unaware, as if their feet were led astray; "lured" means to covet; "obsessed" is read as *mò*, like the *mò* in *mònì* (drowning). *Mò* is read as *zhī*, like the *zhī* in *juàn* (silk), dense and without gaps—hoping with their superior wisdom to stand above the world, "hoping" means to aspire; "stand" means to establish, aspiring to establish a lofty name in the world. Yet their spirit daily wanes and drifts ever farther. "Wanes" means to diminish; "drifts" means to depart without return. When the form is blocked and obstructed within, the spirit has no way to enter. "Spirit" means the essence of spirit; its clear and still nature has no path to return.

Thus, the world often suffers from blindness, delusion, and self-loss—like the case of a candle: the brighter the flame, the swifter its consumption. "Brighter" means to increase; "swifter" means to hasten.

The essence of spirit, qi, and will—when still, daily grows full and thus strengthens; when restless, daily depletes and thus ages. Therefore, the sage, in nurturing their spirit, harmonizes and softens their qi, levels and pacifies their form, and moves with the Dao in rise and fall, bow and lift. Rise and fall are like flourishing and decline; bow and lift are like ascent and descent.

In tranquility, they let it flow freely; in urgency, they employ it. When flowing freely, it is like a discarded robe; when employed, it is like the release of a crossbow’s trigger. The trigger is the mechanism of the crossbow, speaking of its swiftness.

Thus, the transformations of the myriad things are all met in due time—"met" means at the proper moment—and the changes of the hundred affairs are all responded to—"responded" means appropriately addressed.

*End of the Second Scroll of the* Huainanzi Honglie Jie

*Colophon: Recorded by the Grand Commandant and Libationer, Your Servant Xu Shen*

**The Inaugural Truth, Part One**

*Chu* means "beginning." *Zhen* means the true reality of the spoken Dao. Beginning from Non-Being, it transforms and nurtures into Being—thus it is called "embracing truth." This is why the chapter is so titled.

There is a beginning: the inception of Heaven and Earth. There is that which precedes the beginning of the beginning: the first stirrings of the myriad things before any inception. There is a beginning: the formation of shapes. There is that which precedes the beginning of what precedes the beginning: when Heaven and Earth conjoined their qi, silent and desolate, before any inception existed. What precedes the beginning of the beginning is but a faint semblance.

There is Being: the first signs and shapes of the myriad things. There is Non-Being: the vastness of Heaven and Earth, beyond naming. There is that which precedes the existence of Being and Non-Being, and that which precedes the beginning of what precedes the existence of Being and Non-Being.

The so-called "beginning" refers to when the teeming masses had not yet dispersed, when sprouts and shoots had not yet taken form, when no boundaries or edges existed, when the formless writhed and squirmed—about to arise but not yet manifest as distinct kinds. *Fanfen* describes the appearance of accumulated masses; *fa* means "to burst forth."

There is that which precedes the beginning of the beginning: when the qi of Heaven first descended and the qi of Earth first ascended, when yin and yang intermingled, freely roaming and vying in harmony within the cosmos. Clothed in virtue and containing harmony, they gathered in profusion like tangled vines, desiring to engage with things yet leaving no trace or sign. *Jing* means "to pursue"; *chang*, "to extend." *He* is qi. *Binfan* means "intermixed." *Longcong* means "to assemble." *Zhaozhen* refers to strange forms.

There is that which precedes the beginning of what precedes the beginning of the beginning: when Heaven contained harmony but had not yet sent it down, when Earth held qi but had not yet raised it—void and silent, desolate and boundless, with no semblance to be found, when qi flowed unimpeded into the great obscurity. *Xiao* is read as the *xiao* in *ganxiao* ("deep blue silk"). *Diao* is the *di* in the surname *Dishi*.

There is Being: when the myriad things scatter and fall, their roots, stems, branches, and leaves verdant and lush, their colors resplendent and dazzling, when winged creatures fly and wriggling things move, when crawling things creep and panting things breathe—all tangible, graspable, and measurable. *Can* is read as the *can* in *canxing* ("the three stars"). *Guanhuo xuanghuang* describes the appearance of colors. *Qi* is read as the *qi* in *cheqi zhe* ("wheel tracks"). *Kuai* is read as the *kuai* in *bu shuo ze wai* ("unwilling to choose the outer"). *Qie* means "to rub"; *xun*, "to follow." *Guan* is read as *wei* ("only"); *huo* is read as *hu* ("to guard").

There is Non-Being: invisible in form, inaudible in sound, untouchable to the hand, unbounded to the gaze—vast and boundless, beyond containment or governance, immeasurably vast. *Haohao hanhan* describes boundless expanse. *Guangyao* is formless.

There is that which precedes the existence of Being and Non-Being: it envelops Heaven and Earth, shapes the myriad things, and flows unimpeded through the great obscurity. Profound and expansive, it has no exterior; minute and precise, it has no interior. Without walls or enclosures, it gives rise to the root of Being and Non-Being. *Hun* refers to the state of the perfected person in profound obscurity—this is the Dao.

There is that which precedes the beginning of what precedes the existence of Being and Non-Being: when Heaven and Earth had not yet split, when yin and yang had not yet divided, when separation and distinction were undifferentiated. When the four seasons had not yet emerged, when the myriad things had not yet arisen—all was vast, still, and limpid, with no form to be seen. *Wang* is read as in *chuan shi zhu Zhou shi zhi wang* ("the vastness of the Zhou clan’s ancestral transmissions"). Like light shining between Non-Being, it recedes and vanishes from sight. To vanish is to be unseen.

The Master said: "I can grasp Being and Non-Being, yet I cannot grasp Non-Being of Non-Being. To grasp Being and Non-Being is action, but to be fundamentally non-active in one’s inherent nature—this I have not yet attained. Thus it is said I cannot grasp Non-Being. When one attains Non-Being of Non-Being, how could such supreme subtlety be reached?

The great clod burdens me with form, wearies me with life—the great clod being the space between Heaven and Earth. It grants me ease in old age, repose in death. As Zhuangzi said: 'Life is corvée labor; death is rest.' Thus it is said to grant me repose in death. To treat my life well is to treat my death well. To delight in the goodness of my life is to desire the goodness of my death. Understanding the transformations of death and the awareness therein, one seeks to reconcile life and death as one.

Hiding a boat in a ravine, concealing a mountain in a marsh—people call this secure. Yet in the dead of night, a strong man may bear them away in flight. The sleeper knows nothing; still, they have slipped away. If one hides the world within the world, then no form can escape. The great person takes the world as their chamber, storing all things within. How could one say there is no vast upheaval? *Yanghuo*—a term for boundless magnitude—*huo* is read as in *Gaojing* (the capital of Zhou).

A single encounter with human form brings joy—*fan* means 'to meet' or 'to suffer,' but here it signifies 'to mold' or 'to pattern.' Even when things imitate human form, they are deemed good. Yet for humans, there are ten thousand transformations without end. Life and death shift like dreams; thus it is said there is no ultimate limit. Worn out and then renewed—how could the joy therein be measured?

It is like one who becomes a bird and soars in the sky, or becomes a fish and plunges into the depths. While in that state, one does not know it; only upon waking does one recognize it. Now, when the great awakening comes, only then will we know that this present state is the great dream. Before I was born, how could I have known the joy of life? Now that I have not yet died, how could I know that death is not joy?

Long ago, Gongniu Ai suffered a transforming illness. After seven days, he became a tiger. *Zhuanbing* means 'changing illness.' In the region between the Yangtze and Huai rivers, the Gongniu clan had a condition where one would transform into a tiger—like those in the Central States who suffer from madness, with outbreaks at certain times. Those who became tigers would then eat people, and those who ate people became true tigers. Those who did not eat people would transform back into humans.

Gongniu was a man of Han, from the Huai-Nan region. Because cattle eat grass, they are called *chuhuan* ('grass-fed'), and this case serves as proof. His brother peered through the door to observe him, but the tiger pounced and killed him."

Yan means "sudden." *Chan* means "to observe." Thus, when the body becomes that of a beast, claws and fangs transform—this transformation means human claws and fangs become those of a tiger. Will and heart change; spirit and form shift. Will and heart both alter; spirit and form both transform. When one is a tiger, one does not recall having been human; when one is human, one does not foresee becoming a tiger. These two states alternate and diverge, each delighting in its formed shape. *Dai* means "to replace"; *xie*, "to unfold"; *chuan*, "to clash." *Xing* refers to the formed shape of tiger or human. *Chuan* is read as in *chuanmai*. Cunning or dull, kind or cruel, right or wrong—none knows whence these arise. *Meng* means "to arise."

Water, when winter comes, congeals into ice; ice, when spring arrives, melts and becomes water. Ice and water transform before and after, like a millstone turning in haste—who has leisure to know what brings suffering or joy? *Pan* means "to dissolve"; *qu*, "to return." Thus, when form is harmed by the ravages of cold, heat, dryness, or dampness, the form withers while the spirit remains strong. *Yuan* means "withered and ailing"; *zhuang*, "harmed." *Yuan* is read as in Nanyang *Yuan*. When the spirit is harmed by the afflictions of joy, anger, thought, or worry, the spirit is exhausted while the form lingers. Thus, when an old horse dies, flaying it reveals dryness like withered wood. *Pi* means "aged." Its qi and strength are spent, hence it resembles withered wood. When a young dog dies, flaying it remains moist. *Jiao* means "young"; *ru*, "moist." Its qi and strength are not yet exhausted. Therefore, those who die from harm have ghosts that are restless—*rao* means "vexing and restless," prone to inflicting illness upon people. Those who die in their time have spirits that are serene. *Ji* means "exhausted."

When one reaches the proper time of old age, the spirit becomes serene and still. *Mo* means "settled." In all these cases, form and spirit do not perish together. Daoists cultivate both form and spirit to achieve death in old age. When form and spirit perish together, it is not merely that both become still.

Laozi said: "One who governs the world with the Dao—its ghosts possess no numinous power." This is what is meant by "perishing together." The sage’s mind relies on nature and leans upon the spirit, the two supporting each other to complete the cycle of beginning and end. Thus, in sleep, they are not [disturbed]; in wakefulness, they are not anxious. Their essence and spirit harbor no thoughts or worries, hence no [disturbance]. Their will abides in benevolence and righteousness, and no calamity befalls them, hence no anxiety.

In ancient times, there were those who dwelled in primordial chaos, their spirit and qi undispersed outwardly. All things were tranquil and still, delighting in quietude. The baleful qi of comets and the handle of the Northern Dipper could not inflict harm. In that age, the people roamed wildly, knowing neither east nor west, wandering with food in their mouths, striking their bellies in play. *Gu* means "to strike"; *xi*, "to frolic." They were enveloped by the harmony of heaven and nourished by the virtue of earth. *Jiao* means "both"; *he*, "qi"; *de* of earth, "the five grains." Without cunning schemes, they did not blame one another for faults. In boundless vastness, this was called Great Governance. *Qugu* means "crafty contrivance"; *you*, "fault." *Mangmang chenchen* describes a state of abundance. *Mang* is read as in Wang Mang; *chen*, as in the phrase "water flows *chenchen* from Shenbai."

Thus, those in positions of authority guided and employed the people without corrupting their nature; they pacified and governed them without altering their virtue.

Thus, benevolence and righteousness were not spread abroad, yet the myriad things flourished and multiplied. In ancient times, those who embraced abundant virtue, dwelling in primal simplicity, did not rely on benevolence and righteousness for the myriad things to flourish and multiply.

Rewards and punishments were not applied, yet the world submitted in reverence—submitting to their virtue. Their Way could give rise to great beauty, yet it could not be grasped through calculation or enumeration. It is said that the great nature of the myriad things may be nurtured through great beauty, but it cannot be fully accounted for by reckoning. Therefore, to tally by the day is insufficient, while to tally by the year is more than enough—measured by limits, it thus abounds.

It is like the plum: a hundred plums suffice to make a hundred people taste sourness, but one plum cannot make a hundred people taste sourness. Fish forget one another in rivers and lakes; men forget one another in the arts of the Dao. Each attains their aspiration and thus forgets the other.

The True Person of old stood at the root of heaven and earth, dwelling in utmost ease, embracing virtue and warming themselves in harmonious qi, so that the myriad things ripened in abundance. *Yang* means "to warm"; they held fast to their virtuous aspiration and warmed themselves in harmonious qi, so the myriad things ripened, meaning they came to fruition. *Yang* is read as in "to nourish" (*yang* of *gongyang*).

Who would deign to entangle themselves in the affairs of the human world, thereby troubling their nature and destiny with external things? *Jiegou* means "to assemble" or "to engage"; *fan* means "to defile."

The Dao has its warp and weft, its branches and connections. The Way of attaining the One links a thousand boughs and ten thousand leaves. The One is the root of the Dao. Grasping the root, one may order a thousand branches and ten thousand leaves, governing the many through the few.

Thus, the noble have means to enact commands; the base have means to forget their lowliness. The poor have means to delight in their work; the distressed have means to endure peril. Only when bitter cold arrives and frost and snow descend does one recognize the flourishing of the pine and cypress. When peril is trodden and danger confronted, with profit and harm arrayed before them—*chen* means "to array"—only then does one recognize that the sage does not lose the Dao.

Therefore, those who can bear the great circle of heaven tread the great square of earth. Those who mirror the Great Purity gaze upon the great brightness. Those who establish Great Peace dwell in the Great Hall. Great Peace is the peace of all under heaven; the Great Hall is the Bright Hall, where the first day of the month is announced and commands are issued.

Those who wander in the obscure shine with the same light as the sun and moon—*guang* means "brightness." Those who discourse on the virtue of the Dao can shine with the brightness of the sun and moon. Thus, take the Dao as your pole, virtue as your line, ritual and music as your hook, benevolence and righteousness as your bait. Cast them into the rivers, float them upon the seas, and the myriad things, teeming and swarming—what is not yours?

Yet those who rely on the arts of *qiyue*—*qiyue* means "limping" or "uneven," the crooked Way—drag and haul the affairs of the human world, stirring and shaking the customs of the age. *Dan* means "to draw"; *shan* means "profit"; *tingnuo* means "up and down," seeking advantage and convenience. Groping and probing the subtleties of things—*mosu* means "to grope," and "subtleties" means "minute details"—they still indulge their ambitions and sate their desires. How much more so for those who embrace the Way of *xiangzhang*, forgetting their liver and gall, leaving behind their ears and eyes, drifting alone beyond all bounds, not entangled with things in wearisome toil—*bisa* means "to mix and grind." *Bi* is read as in "to trudge" (*ba* of *qishe*); *sa* is read as in the Chu word for "to kill."

They wander in the formless realm, harmonizing with heaven and earth. Such as these lay aside their keen perception and embrace their primal simplicity—*su* means "primal nature." They regard profit and harm as dust and grime—dust and grime are metaphors for the trivial. They regard life and death as day and night.

Thus, the sight of jade chariots adorned with *wanyan* and ivory, the sound of *Baixue* and *Qingjiao* in their ears, cannot disturb their spirit. *Yulu* is the chariot of kings, adorned with *wanyan* (fine jade) and ivory. *Baixue* is the melody played by Shi Kuang on the five-stringed zither of Taiyi, a divine instrument whose music summons the descent of spirits. *Qingjiao* is the note of the Shang mode.

Ascending a thousand-fathom gorge, standing at the edge of a dizzying precipice, is not enough to disrupt their harmony—monkeys at such a height grow dizzy, and *hua* means "to disturb." *He* means "harmony" or "ease." It is like the jade of Zhongshan, smelted with furnace and charcoal for three days and nights, yet its luster remains unchanged. Such is the essence of utmost virtue and the essence of heaven and earth. Zhongshan is Kunlun.

Therefore, life is not enough to employ them; how could profit move them? Death is not enough to restrain them; how could harm frighten them? Understanding the distinction between life and death, comprehending the changes of profit and harm, even if all under heaven were exchanged for a single hair on their shin, it would not sway their resolve. *Gan* refers to the part of the leg from the knee to the ankle; *gan* is read as in "to close" (*bi* of *bishou*).

The noble and base in relation to the self are like the timely passing of the *tiaofeng*—*tiaofeng* whistles through the branches, swift in its passage. *Li* means "to pass." Praise and blame in relation to the self are like the passing of a single mosquito. Those who hold fast to purity and do not darken it, who act with integrity and do not adulterate it, who dwell in the dark and obscure yet are not benighted, who rest in the harmony of heaven yet do not falter—*wei* means "to fail." The *Tianjun* is the land of the North Pole, a wild expanse of accumulated cold; resting there leads to ruin, but those who embody the Dao do not fail.

Mengmen and Zhonglong cannot bar their way—Mengmen is a mountain name, a pass of Taihang. Zhonglong is Zhongnan Mountain in Fufeng, both perilous strongholds. Only those who embody the Dao remain unobstructed. Rushing rapids, swirling abysses, the depths of Lüliang cannot detain them—*tuanlai* are swift currents; *xuanyuan* are deep whirlpools; Lüliang is a river in Pengcheng, all treacherous waters that cause stagnation. The perils of Taihang, Shijian, Feihu, and Juwang cannot hinder them—Taihang lies north of Yewang, a pass of Shangdang. Shijian are deep gorges; Feihu is in Daijun; Juwang is in Yanmen, all narrow and treacherous defiles.

Thus, their bodies may dwell upon rivers and seas, yet their spirits wander beneath the towering gates of the royal court—*Weique* are the outer gates of the royal palace.

Thus the teachings of the symbolic images are displayed upon the *Xiangwei*—towering and vast. Called *Weique*, it signifies that though the perfected person may dwell in distant lands, their heart remains with the king. Another interpretation: the heart’s *Juque* is where the spirit inwardly guards. Without attaining the One Origin, who could reach such a state? The One Origin is the source of the Dao.

Therefore, dwelling with the utmost person causes families to forget poverty, kings and lords to set aside their wealth and nobility and delight in humility, the bold to temper their vigor, and the greedy to dissolve their desires. Seated, they do not instruct; standing, they do not debate. Empty, they go forth; full, they return. Thus, without speaking, they nourish others with harmony. The Dao’s instruction flows like a river, silently quenching thirst with harmonious ease.

The supreme Dao is non-action, now a dragon, now a serpent—dragons transform, serpents shed their skins, hence the Dao uses them as metaphors. Expanding and contracting, coiling and unfurling, it changes with the times. Outwardly, it follows the wind; inwardly, it preserves its nature. Eyes and ears do not dazzle; thoughts do not stray. *Stray* here means to wander. Those who abide in the spirit hold simplicity and roam the Great Clarity. *Hold* means to grasp; *simplicity* means vastness. They draw forth and elevate the ten thousand things, causing all virtues to sprout. *Draw forth* means to promote; *elevate* is read like *yun* in *yungong*. Thus, those who govern the spirit drive it away; *govern* means to manage. Those who rest the spirit cause it to reside. Without disturbance or agitation.

The Dao emerges from the One Origin, passes through the Nine Gates—the gates of heaven—and disperses along the Six Thoroughfares, spreading through the six directions. It is established in the boundless expanse, *established* meaning to extend. *Gaidian* are the limits of the horizon. *Gai* is read as when one’s food and drink are so abundant that thoughts turn downward. *Dian* is read like the *fan* in *Guan Shi’s fan dian*. Serene and empty, it is not active toward things, nor do things act upon it. *Not active toward things* means it does not act upon them; *things act upon it* means things act upon themselves.

Thus, when actions accord with the Dao, it is not that the Dao acts, but that the Dao extends. All that heaven covers, earth bears, the six directions encompass, yin and yang exhale, rain and dew moisten, and the Dao and virtue uphold—these all share one father and mother and are gathered into one harmony. *Father and mother* are heaven and earth; *gathered* means to assemble; *harmony* is qi, what the Dao values. *Exhale* is read like the *xu* in *xiang xu*.

Therefore, the scholar tree and the orange tree become brothers, for the Dao unites disparate things. The Youmiao and Sanwei become one family. The Youmiao were a southern state near Pengli, who resisted in the time of Shun. Sanwei is a mountain at the western extremity, in Chenzhou. Their union is the Dao’s transformation. Though the eye gazes at swans and geese and the ear listens to the zither’s sound, the heart may be in Yanmen. Within a single body, the spirit divides and scatters; within the six directions, a single movement spans a thousand miles.

Thus, viewed from their differences, liver and gallbladder are as distant as Hu and Yue—liver and gallbladder are near, Hu and Yue are far apart. Viewed from their sameness, the ten thousand things are one corner. *Corner* means a nook. The hundred schools diverge in their doctrines, each with its own origin. As for Mo, Yang, Shen, and Shang in relation to the governance of the Dao: Mo is Mo Di, whose methods embraced universal love, rejected music, and wore oneself from head to heel for the benefit of the state. Yang is Yang Zhu, whose methods preserved one’s nature and integrity, and who would not pluck a single hair from his shin to benefit the world. Shen is Shen Buhai, minister to the Marquis of Han, who composed the *Three Mandates* and favored harsh governance. Shang is Gongsun Yang of Wei, who for Duke Xiao of Qin established laws of mutual responsibility, known for their severity, and was enfeoffed as Lord of Shang, hence called Shang Yang.

They are like a canopy without a single rafter or a wheel without a single spoke: their presence may complete the number, but their absence does no harm to function. Yet each claims exclusive possession, failing to comprehend the nature of heaven and earth. Now, when a smith casts vessels, the metal leaps within the furnace, and there must be spillage and waste. Some congeal unevenly, taking on shapes resembling things. Though their forms may be somewhat complete, they cannot compare to the Nine Tripods of the Zhou. How much less can they match those shaped by the compass? They are far removed from the Dao.

Now, the branching and scattering of the ten thousand things, the stems and leaves of the hundred affairs—all arise from one root and extend into a thousand strands. *Scattering* means to spread; *stems* is read like *san* in *baoyou sanye*. Like this, they have a receiver but no giver. The receiver has no giver, yet nothing is not received. That nothing is not received is like the dense clouds of Zhou, gathering and amassing, swelling and surging, to become rain. *Zhou clouds* are thick rain clouds; *gathering* means to assemble. *Swelling and surging* describe accumulation. The rain soaks the ten thousand things yet does not share their wetness. It does not become wet with them.

Now, the skilled archer possesses the measures of sights and markers, just as the craftsman has the calculations of compass and square—these are what they attain to reach mastery. They attain the skill of sights, markers, compass, and square. Yet Xi Zhong cannot become Peng Meng. Xi Zhong was skilled in making chariots; Peng Meng was skilled in archery. This shows they cannot be combined. Zaofu cannot become Bo Le. Zaofu was skilled in driving horses and served King Mu of Zhou; Bo Le was skilled in judging horses and served Duke Mu of Qin. This illustrates mastery of one aspect but failure to comprehend the connections of ten thousand directions.

Now, when black dye soaks into silk, it becomes blacker than the dye; when indigo soaks into silk, it becomes bluer than the indigo. The silk is not the dye, nor is the blue the indigo. Though it meets its source, it can no longer revert. The dye is alum stone; the source is the origin. What does this show? It illustrates how transformation grows ever more distant. How much more so for that which has never been shaped by dye or indigo? Its transformations, though carved into metal and stone or written on bamboo and silk, cannot fully express their number. *Carved* is read like *lou* in *loushu*.

From this we see: all things are born from *having*. *Having* means abiding. Great and small flourish abundantly. This speaks of their abundance. The tip of an autumn hair, though it sinks into the spaceless, returns to the great. The autumn hair is subtle and wondrous, thus it enters the spaceless. *Spaceless* means aperture. This speaks of the formless Dao: though compared to the tip of a hair, it still becomes great. The thickness of a reed’s membrane, though it passes through the boundless, returns to the substantial. *Thickness* here means thinness. *Reed* is the rush. The white membrane within the reed stalk, when pared to its thinnest, reverts to the rush—thus it is said to return to the substantial. *Membrane* is read like *fu* in *mianfu*.

As for that which has no autumn hair’s subtlety, no reed membrane’s thinness, which extends in all four directions without boundary, passing through the limitless—where the Dao pervades the formless (for the autumn hair and reed membrane already have form), thus it is said: “no autumn hair’s subtlety, no reed membrane’s thinness, extending in all four directions without boundary, passing through the limitless.” *Limitless* is the same as *frontier*. Yet nothing can restrain, intercept, or obstruct it. Its subtle and profound mystery gives rise to the ten thousand things, shaping and transforming them like a ball of clay. Such is the power of the Dao. Between heaven and earth, how could this be fully discussed? This speaks of the greatness of the Dao’s transformations.

A fierce wind may uproot trees yet cannot pluck a single hair. *Pluck* also means *uproot*. On a cloud-reaching tower, those who fall break their spines and shatter their skulls, yet mosquitoes and gnats can soar unharmed. The tower’s height touches the clouds, hence it is called a cloud-reaching tower. Mosquitoes and gnats are minute, thus they soar without fear of injury or destruction—this is what the Dao values. Those who ride the celestial mechanism with the crawling and wriggling—*crawling* and *wriggling* illustrate the minute; *celestial mechanism* is the divine steed—even the lightest and most subtle of flying things can escape with their lives. How much more so for that which has no form? *Form* means shape. Having no shape is what the Dao esteems.

From this we see: the birth of form from the formless is clear. Therefore, the sage entrusts his spirit to the numinous storehouse and returns to the origin of the ten thousand things. He sees in the darkness and hears in the silence. Within the darkness, he alone perceives the dawn. *Dawn* means clarity. Within the stillness, he alone has illumination. He employs it by not employing it; only by not employing it can he truly employ it. He knows by not knowing; only by not knowing can he truly know.

If heaven were not stable, the sun and moon would have no path. *Path* means course. If earth were not stable, grasses and trees would have no place to stand. *Stand* means take root. If what is established in the self is not secure, right and wrong have no manifestation. *Manifestation* means appearance. Thus, only with the true person does true knowledge arise. Knowledge is not false, hence it is called true. What he holds is not evident—how could the foolish know that what I call knowledge is not ignorance?

Now, those who accumulate kindness and heap up generosity, who layer love and pile on favor, using fame and splendor to envelop the common people, making them joyful and content in their natures—this is *ren*. Those who achieve great deeds, establish illustrious names, embody the relationship between ruler and minister, rectify high and low, clarify close and distant, rank noble and base, preserve endangered states, restore broken lineages, resolve entanglements and govern disorder, revive ruined clans, and establish heirs where there are none—this is *yi*. Those who close the nine apertures, conceal the heart and will, discard wisdom and intelligence, return to unknowing, wander aimlessly beyond the dust, and roam in the realm of no-affairs, inhaling yin and exhaling yang so that the ten thousand things harmonize—this is *de*.

Thus, the Dao scatters to become *de*, *de* overflows to become *ren* and *yi*. When *ren* and *yi* are established, the Dao and *de* are abandoned. A tree of a hundred spans, when felled and carved into a sacrificial vessel—*sacrificial* is read like *xi* in *xizun*, an intricately carved vessel—is engraved with patterns, adorned with blue and yellow, using tools like the *ji* (a hooked knife) and *ju* (a marking tool for carving). *Ji* is a skilled artisan’s carving knife; *ju* is the compass and square for marking and outlining. These are the tools for carving. Blue and yellow are decorative colors. *Ji* is read like *zhi* in *zhiji*; *ju* is read like *jue* in *juejiao*.

With splendid ornamentation and gleaming brilliance, dragons, snakes, tigers, and leopards curve into patterns. *Splendid ornamentation* means elaborate designs; *gleaming* refers to the vessel’s brightness. Dragons, snakes, tigers, and leopards are carved into the sacrificial vessels in coiling and crouching forms—hence it is said to curve into patterns. Yet when its fragments lie discarded in the ditch, compared to the sacrificial vessel, the difference in beauty is vast. *Vast* means distant. In their beauty and ugliness, they are far apart. Yet they have equally lost the nature of the wood. *Equally* means the same.

Thus, when the spirit scatters, words become flowery. *Scatters* means disperses.

Words fail to hold fast—thus they bloom with emptiness. *Virtue* scatters, and conduct becomes false. *Scatters* means to stray into deceit without fulfillment.

When the purest *qi* perishes within, yet speech and action are displayed without, this is to enslave the self to things—*to be enslaved by things.* Those who chase and abandon, who act with falsity, seek *qi* in externals. When *qi* dwindles to exhaustion while conduct knows no bounds, the heart is disturbed, the spirit muddied, and the root confounded.

What they cling to is unstable, *and* they stray into the winds of worldly custom. *Winds* means transformation. What they sever stumbles and falters, inwardly clouding their clarity. Thus they vacillate to the end, never attaining a moment of tranquility.

Therefore, the sage cultivates the arts of the *Dao* within and does not adorn the outside with benevolence and righteousness. They do not know the *proper* bounds of ears and eyes, *but* wander in the harmony of spirit and *qi.* Such is the sage’s wandering: below, they fathom the Three Springs; above, they traverse the Nine Heavens; horizontally, they embrace the Six Directions; they thread through the ten thousand things. This is the sage’s wandering.

As for the *zhenren*, they move dissolved in perfect emptiness and wander in the wilderness of annihilation. They ride *Feilian* and follow *Dunyu*—*Feilian* is a beast with long fur and wings; *Dunyu* is a small tiger, or the name of an immortal. They gallop beyond the bounds, resting within the cosmos. They illuminate the ten suns and command wind and rain, command *Leigong*, employ *Kua Fu*—*Kua Fu* was an immortal who cast aside his staff and became the Deng Forest. They take *Fufei* as concubine, wed *Shinü*, and how could heaven and earth suffice to confine their will?

Thus, emptiness and nothingness are the abode of the *Dao*; plainness and ease are the *Dao*’s essence. *Essence* means nature.

*Huainanzi Honglie Jie*, Scroll Three, concludes.
*Huainanzi Honglie Jie*, Scroll Four, recorded by Minister of the Grand Commandant, Xu Shen.

**The Lower "Initiating the Real"**

When people serve their spirits yet vex their essence, pursuing cleverness and seeking externally—all this is to lose their numinous clarity and abandon their true abode. *Serve* means to cultivate; *vex* means to trouble; *pursuing cleverness* refers to those who chase fame and profit. Thus it is said they seek externally. *Abandon their abode* means to forsake the dwelling of spirit and essence.

Therefore, the frozen borrow layered robes in spring, while the sweltering long for cool winds in autumn. Those afflicted within must show signs without. The *cen* tree bears a greenish film—*cen* is the bitter *li*, a tree by name. It grows in the mountains; its bark is stripped, soaked in water to yield a pure green, then used to wash the eyes, curing the membrane that clouds vision. Thus it is said to bear a greenish film. *Green* is the color, the sign. And the *luo* fly cures *wo huan*—*luo meng* is the slender horsefly; *wo huan* is an eye ailment. These are all remedies for the eyes. If one seeks such things without cause, they must have something obscuring their sight.

What startles the world about the sage, the perfected never deign to emulate. *Startles* means to move. What the worthy use to correct世俗, the sage never observes. *Correct* means to oppose. The puddle in a cow’s hoofprint holds no carp a foot long; *cen* is stagnant water. *Cen* is pronounced like *yan he*, with a sharp intake of breath. The mound of a clod bears no timber ten feet tall. This is a small hill in Chenliu. Why is this so? Because their dwelling is too narrow to contain anything great—how much less could that which has no enclosure do so? *No enclosure* means no form. This is how far the potential of mountains and abysses extends. Here, none debate greatness or magnitude.

When people are constrained by the world, their form is battered and their spirit leaks, so they cannot escape emptiness. *Form bound* means the body is afflicted and the spirit scatters, failing to remain in its proper guard. Thus it is said they cannot escape the illness of emptiness. If I can be tethered, it must be that my fate lies outside.

In the age of utmost virtue, one sweetly slumbers in the murky marshes—*yan* is read like *leisurely*. It describes the boundless and vacant. And one wanders in the vast expanse of the infinite. *Wanders* is like *boundless*. Without life, form arises; primordial *qi* is the root of spirit. Thus Lu Ao, meeting the *ruoshi*, said, "I have an appointment with the boundless at the summit of the nine heavens." *Abode* means dwelling. Lifting heaven and earth, one discards the myriad things, taking the primal chaos as a pillar of light, drifting and floating at the edge of no boundary. *Lifting* is with one hand; *na* means to raise; *discard* means to cast aside. This speaks of not allowing the self to be enslaved by things.

Primal chaos, the wilds of the eastern frontier, where the sun emerges—thus it is made the pillar of light. *Floating and drifting* is like soaring and roaming. *Without boundary or shore* describes its limitless expanse, hence the name.

Thus the sage inhales and exhales the *qi* of yin and yang, and all living beings gaze upward in reverence, their virtue harmonized in obedience. At this time, none preside over governance, yet separation and concealment resolve themselves, and all things come to be. Vast and boundless, primordial and undivided—*vast and boundless* describes the great form of chaos. Thus it is said: "primordial simplicity remains undispersed." All things merge as one, and the myriad beings flourish in abundance. *Flourish* means to thrive.

Therefore, even one with the wisdom of Yi would have no use for it. This speaks of the age of high antiquity, when one could sweetly slumber and governance would unfold of itself. Thus it is said: "even with the wisdom of Yi, there would be no use for it." This refers to Yi of Yao’s time, who could shoot down ten suns, ensnare the great wind, slay the *Yayu*, behead the nine-headed serpent, and shoot the River Lord—his cunning and skill were unmatched. It does not refer to Hou Yi of the Youqiong clan.

As the world declined, even under Fuxi, the Dao grew dim and indistinct. Yet he chanted of virtue and embraced harmony. Fuxi ruled all under heaven by the power of wood, and was called the Great Bright One. *Dim* means pure and thick; *indistinct* describes its vastness. He chanted of virtue and embraced harmony, though his *qi* had not yet fully spread. His influence was far-reaching—*far-reaching* is read as the *bi* in "illuminating the four directions." His virtue and grace were powerfully bestowed upon the people, and thus knowledge began to stir.

Dim and obscure, all sought to cast off their childlike innocence. *Dim* means desiring clarity but not yet attaining it; *obscure* describes the state of seeking knowledge. *Cast off* means to depart. And they awakened to observe the space between heaven and earth. Thus their virtue grew disordered and could not be unified. *Disordered* means excessive; *unified* means aligned.

By the time of Shennong and the Yellow Emperor, the great origin was divided, and the principles of heaven and earth were penetrated. They followed the nine heavens and doubled the nine forms—*penetrated* means to connect; *principles* means to order. *Followed* means to adhere to; *forms* refers to structure. This speaks of adhering to the forms and laws of the nine heavens and nine earths to establish order. They grasped yin and yang, harmonized hardness and softness, branched and resolved, threaded and arranged the ten thousand things and the hundred clans. *Harmonized* means to blend; *clans* means categories. They ensured each had its proper sequence and position. *Position* means place.

At this, the people gazed in wide-eyed wonder, yet none failed to stand in awe and lend their ears and eyes. *Gazing in wide-eyed wonder* describes their attentive listening and watching. Thus governance was achieved, but harmony was not. *Harmony* means accord.

From the decline of the Xia to the age of Kunwu and the Xia Hou clan—Kunwu was a lord of Xia in the time of Jie—desires became entangled with things, and keen perception was lured outward, so that nature and destiny lost their proper attainment. *Nature* is the root of destiny.

By the decline of the Zhou, purity thinned and simplicity scattered—*scattered* is read as the *yi* in "difficult and easy." The Dao was adulterated with falsity, and virtue was practiced with restraint. *Adulterated* means mixed. And cunning and deceit began to sprout. *Cunning* refers to deceptive speech.

As the Zhou declined and the royal Dao was abandoned, the Confucians and Mohists began to array their teachings and debate, dividing into factions and disputing. *Confucians* refers to the Dao of Confucius; *Mohists* to the techniques of Mo Di. *Factions* means parties; *disputing* means contesting right and wrong.

Thus they amassed learning to cast doubt upon the sages, and embellished falsehoods to coerce the masses. They studied the ways of Yang Zhu and Mo Di to sow doubt in the teachings of Confucius. They fabricated flowery words to slander the sages and intimidate their followers. They strummed strings, sang, danced, and adorned the *Odes* and *Documents* to purchase fame and reputation in the world. *Purchase* means to seek.

They multiplied the rites of ascent and descent, adorned their robes and caps, gathered crowds insufficient to exhaust their variations, and amassed wealth insufficient to meet their expenses. Thus the people began to swell with restless ambition, each desiring to deploy their cunning and deceit to carve a niche in the world, and to select and pursue fame and profit. *Deploy* means to apply; *select* means to choose; *pursue* means to seek. This speaks of applying their craft and seeking glory and gain.

Thus the common people sprawled across the fields of excess and dissipation, losing the root of the great origin. *Fields* may also be written as *wilds*.

The loss of nature and destiny in the world arises from gradual decline, and its origins are long-standing. Thus the learning of the sage aims to return nature to its beginning and to wander the mind in emptiness. Humans receive the center of heaven and earth at birth—Mencius said: "Nature is without flaw, but emotions and desires harm it." Thus the sage can return nature to its beginning. *Wandering the mind in emptiness* means to be without desire.

The learning of the enlightened aims to extend nature to the farthest reaches and to awaken to stillness and desolation. But the learning of the vulgar world is not so. They pluck at virtue and *xiao* their nature, inwardly distressing the five organs and outwardly exhausting their ears and eyes. *Pluck* means to seize; *xiao* means to strip. Neither follows principle, thus their thoughts are troubled. Their ears listen recklessly, their eyes gaze recklessly—excess leads to exhaustion.

They begin by grasping at the finest details of things, shaking and sweeping away benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music. They violently display their cunning and intelligence in the world to summon fame and reputation. *Shaking and sweeping away* means they cannot practice benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music. *Violently* means suddenly; *display* means to flaunt. They flaunt their deceitful intelligence to seize fame and reputation. This is what I find shameful and will not do.

Thus, rather than possess all under heaven, it is better to possess joy. *Joy* means delight—better to have others delight in you. Rather than possess joy, it is better to wander the beginnings and ends of things, and to comprehend the boundaries between being and non-being.

Therefore, though the whole world praises me, I am not encouraged; though the whole world blames me, I am not deterred.

Establishing oneself at the boundary between life and death, one penetrates the principle of honor and disgrace. Though raging fires and vast floods spread across the world, the spirit suffers no loss or lack within the breast. Such a one regards all under heaven as but a floating feather or drifting mustard seed—*mustard seed* meaning the center. Who would willingly divide their attention, *divided* denoting the appearance of scattered thoughts, to make external things their concern?

The nature of water is truly clear, yet soil muddies it; the nature of man is tranquil, yet cravings and desires disturb it. What humans receive from heaven—the ears and eyes for sounds and sights, the mouth and nose for fragrances and odors, the skin for cold and warmth—all share the same essence. Yet some attain communion with spirit and illumination, while others fall into delusion and madness—why? The constraints they impose differ.

Thus, spirit is the abyss of wisdom; when the abyss is clear, wisdom is bright. Wisdom is the storehouse of the heart; when wisdom is impartial, the heart is level. No one gazes at their reflection in flowing foam, but rather in still water, for its tranquility. *Foam* refers to the froth stirred up by rain, obscuring the vessel and rendering the human form unseen. No one peers at their form in unpolished iron, but rather in a bright mirror, for its clarity—*clarity* as in the *Changes* of Hejian. Only through clarity and stillness can one perceive the nature of things. From this, we see that utility must borrow from what is not used.

Therefore, an empty chamber generates brightness; auspiciousness comes to rest. *Empty* refers to the heart; *chamber* to the body; *brightness* to the Dao. By emptying the heart to generate the Dao, the nature of the Dao is desireless, and auspiciousness comes to dwell. A clear mirror cannot be obscured by dust and grime—*obscured* meaning defiled, pronounced like the *wo* in the Wo dialect. A pure spirit cannot be disordered by cravings and desires. A pure spirit guards the essence within, and the passions of craving and desire cannot disturb or confuse it.

When the spirit scatters outward, one must return and govern it—*scatters* meaning disperses; *govern* meaning to regulate. This is to lose the root and seek it in the branches. When inner and outer fail to correspond and one desires to engage with things, exhausting their mysterious radiance while seeking knowledge through the ears and eyes—*mysterious radiance* being inner illumination, also called the *Mysterious*, the Heavenly—this is to abandon the luminous and pursue the obscure. This is called losing the Dao.

When the heart reaches a certain point, the spirit sighs in response. Returning to emptiness, all dissipation and disturbance vanish—this is the wandering of the sage. Returning to emptiness, the nature of craving and desire dissipates and vanishes; thus it is called the wandering of the sage. *Wandering* means to act.

Therefore, those of old who governed all under heaven first penetrated the conditions of nature and destiny. Their actions were not necessarily the same, yet their alignment with the Dao was one. One does not don fur in summer not out of frugality, but because warmth suffices. One does not use a fan in winter not out of disdain, but because coolness suffices—*fan* pronounced like the *sha* in the quacking of a goose; *disdain* meaning to belittle.

The sage measures their belly to eat, gauges their form to clothe, and regulates only themselves. How could greed and corruption arise? Thus, one who can possess all under heaven must not treat it as a possession; one who can possess fame and reputation must not seek it through contrived conduct—*treat* meaning to employ. The sage attains a certain understanding, and with that attainment, the heart of craving and desire is cast aside—*cast aside* meaning discarded.

The disciples of Confucius and Mozi all taught the arts of benevolence and righteousness to the world, yet they could not avoid rendering themselves useless, let alone practice what they preached—*rendering themselves useless* meaning their persons went unutilized; *useless* pronounced like the *lei* in "echoing thunder." Why is this? Their Dao was external.

To seek the root through its branches—even Xu You could not practice this, let alone the common people? *Common people* refers to the ordinary folk, those leveled with the masses. Truly comprehending the essence of one’s nature and destiny, benevolence and righteousness naturally adhere; what need is there for deliberate pursuit or rejection to disturb the heart?

When the spirit remains unobscured and the mind bears no burden, all flows freely and unimpeded, serene and untroubled. With nothing congealed or stagnant, one abides in emptiness and stillness, awaiting all things. Then, neither power nor profit can entice—*entice* meaning to delude or lure. Sophists cannot persuade—*persuade* meaning to dispel. Sensual pleasures cannot seduce, beauty cannot lead astray—*lead astray* meaning to covet or overindulge. The wise cannot sway, the brave cannot frighten. This is the Dao of the perfected person.

One who embodies this tempers and cools the myriad things, serving as the companion of the Creator. Between heaven and earth, within the cosmos, nothing can obstruct or restrain. That which engenders life does not die, while that which transforms things does not itself transform—*that which engenders life* refers to heaven; *that which transforms things* refers to virtue. Though traversing the Li Mountains and Mount Taihang, it meets no difficulty. Though entering the Four Seas and the Nine Rivers, it does not become drenched. Dwelling in narrow confines, it is not constricted; spanning the expanse between heaven and earth, it does not yawn—*spanning* meaning to enclose.

One who fails to comprehend this—though their eyes may count the thousands in a flock of sheep, their ears discern the harmonies of the eight winds (the winds of the eight trigrams, *feng* meaning harmony), though their feet tread the dances of Yang’e and their hands keep time with the rhythms of *Green Waters* (*Yang’e* being a renowned performer of antiquity; *Green Waters*, a dance melody—or, by another account, an ancient poem; *qu* meaning to follow the beat)—though their wisdom spans heaven and earth, their illumination rivals sun and moon, their eloquence unravels linked rings, and their beneficence moistens jade and stone, it is still of no avail in governing the world.

Stillness and tranquility nurture one’s nature; harmony, joy, and emptiness nurture one’s virtue. When the external does not disturb the internal, one’s nature finds its proper place; when nature remains unagitated and harmonious, one’s virtue rests securely in its position. Nurturing life to order the world, embracing virtue to live out one’s years—this may be called embodying the Dao.

Those who attain this have blood and qi free from stagnation, the five viscera free from pathogenic qi (*wei* meaning illness). Neither fortune nor misfortune can unsettle them, neither praise nor blame can defile them, and thus they reach the ultimate. *Ultimate* meaning the highest point. Yet without the right era, who can bring it to fruition? Even one who possesses such ability, if they do not encounter the right time, may not even free themselves—how much less so one without the Dao, whose Way cannot be put into practice?

Now, human nature is such that the ears and eyes respond to stimuli, the heart and mind know sorrow and joy, and the hands and feet—shielding from cold and heat—engage with the world. A bee or scorpion stings a finger, and the spirit cannot remain composed (*shi* read as *release*; *dan* meaning settled). A mosquito or horsefly bites the skin, and the mind cannot stay at peace (*zan* meaning to bite, like piercing). The onset of cares and troubles assails the human heart (*ying* meaning to press upon)—not merely the venom of bees and scorpions or the torment of mosquitoes and horseflies. How, then, can one hope to remain in stillness, emptiness, and tranquility?

The eye may discern the tip of an autumn hair, yet fail to hear the crash of thunder; the ear may attune to the sound of jade and stone, yet fail to see the height of Mount Tai. Why? Because the small occupies the mind, and the great is forgotten.

Now, the myriad things assail us, plucking at our understanding, seizing our emotions like a spring’s unceasing flow. Even if one wished not to be moved, how could it be possible? *Bing* meaning to be stirred into action.

Consider a tree: watered with fresh streams, nurtured in fertile soil (*chou* meaning to heap; *rang* may also be written as *liao*), tended by one person yet uprooted by ten—it will surely leave no sprouts (*nie* meaning shoots). How much more so when an entire state joins in the uprooting? Though one may wish for long life, how can it be attained?

A basin of water in the courtyard, though cleared all day, cannot reflect one’s brows and lashes; yet a single stir renders it too turbid to discern a square or circle. *Cha* meaning to perceive. The human spirit is easily muddied and difficult to clarify—like the basin of water. How, then, can one hope for even a moment’s peace when the world stirs and unsettles it?

In the age of utmost virtue, merchants thrived in their markets, farmers delighted in their work, ministers rested in their duties (*zhi* meaning affairs), and recluses cultivated their Way (the Way of the former kings). In that time, wind and rain did not break or uproot, plants and trees did not wither prematurely, the Nine Tripods bore rich patina, pearls and jade gleamed with luster (*Nine Tripods* cast from the tribute metal of the nine provinces—or, by another account, symbolizing the nine virtues; *zhong* meaning thick; *runze* meaning radiant). The Luo River yielded its cinnabar script, the Yellow River its green diagrams. Thus, Xu You, Fang Hui, Shan Juan, and Pi Yi were able to realize their Way (*Xu You* of Yangcheng, whom Yao sought but who declined; *Fang Hui*, *Shan Juan*, and *Pi Yi*, all recluses of Yao’s time whose names cannot now be known—*Fang Hui* named for his upright and circling demeanor, *Pi Yi* for his habit of going about in a draped robe). They attained joy in what they cultivated—the Way of the former kings. Why was this so?

When rulers of an age possess the intent to benefit all under heaven, the people are thus able to find joy within it—joy in their own Way amid heaven and earth. Some cultivate civil virtue and take delight in their midst, which is the Way of the former kings. The talents of the Four Masters were not wholly perfect, for they belonged to the present age; yet none could share their radiance, for they met with the era of Tang and Yu.

*Radiance* here means *renown*.

But when the time of Jie of Xia and Zhou of Yin arrived, they burned living men, executed those who offered remonstrance, devised the roasting pillar, and cast the bronze column—setting fire beneath it and placing men atop it, laughing as they fell into the flames. They carved out the hearts of worthy men and split the shins of talented scholars.

*The worthy man* refers to Bi Gan.
*Split* means *to dissect*.
They flayed and examined the legs of gifted scholars to see if they possessed any marvels.
*Shin* here means *leg*.

They minced the daughter of the Ghost Marquis into meat paste and pickled the bones of Mei Bo.

The Ghost Marquis and Mei Bo were feudal lords of Zhou’s time. Mei Bo had praised the beauty of the Ghost Marquis’s daughter, prompting Zhou to take her as a consort. When she arrived, Zhou found her unpleasing and thus minced the daughter of the Ghost Marquis and pickled the bones of Mei Bo.
Another account states that Zhou, being without the Way, had Mei Bo repeatedly admonish him, so he pickled his bones.

At that time, Mount Yao collapsed, and the Three Rivers ran dry.

Mount Yao is said to lie in Nanyang.
The Three Rivers are the Jing, Wei, and Qian.
*Dry* means *exhausted*.

The tradition states: “When mountains collapse and rivers run dry, it is an omen of a state’s demise.”

Birds singed their wings in flight, and beasts broke their legs in haste. This speaks of Zhou’s ceaseless hunting and indulgence in game, so that flying birds snapped their wings and running beasts shattered their limbs—none escaped harm.

At such a time, how could there have been no sages? Yet they could not make their Way prevail, for they did not meet with their era. This means that sages could not bring their Way to fruition or enact their will because they did not encounter the right age.

When birds soar a thousand fathoms high and beasts run through dense thickets, disaster still befalls them—how much more so for the common folk bound to their households?

*Thicket* refers to a cluster of trees; *dense growth* to deep grass. *Still befalls them* refers to untimely hunting.

From this we see that embodying the Way does not depend solely on oneself; it may also be struck down by the age.

Consider the city of Liyang, which in a single night turned into a lake. The strong and wise shared the same fate as the weary and cowardly.

Liyang was a county in the state of Huainan, now part of Jiangdu.

Long ago, an old woman there constantly practiced benevolence and righteousness. Two scholars passed by and told her: “This land is fated to sink into a lake. When you see blood at the threshold of the eastern gate, flee at once to the northern mountain—do not look back.” From then on, the woman went to check the gate’s threshold. The gatekeeper asked her why, and she told him what had been said. That evening, the gatekeeper deliberately smeared chicken blood on the threshold. The next morning, the old woman hurried to the gate, saw the blood, and fled to the northern mountain. The land sank into a lake. When she spoke of this to the gatekeeper, barely a night had passed—yet by dawn, the city had become a lake. The brave and the cowardly met the same fate, with none escaping.

Atop Mount Wu, fire set with the wind spreads—fat summer trees and purple mushrooms perish alongside mugwort and wormwood. Mount Wu lies in Nan Commandery. "Fat summer" refers to great trees, their grain dense and white as lard, hence the name. Purple mushrooms symbolize the wise and virtuous; mugwort and wormwood, lowly weeds, symbolize the unworthy. Thus, fish of the Yellow River cannot see clearly, and young crops cannot ripen in season—such is the nature of their birth. The river’s waters are turbid, so their eyes cannot see; young crops wither under frost, so they cannot await their natural ripening. Thus it is said: such is the nature of their birth.

When the world is well-ordered, the foolish cannot alone cause chaos; when the world is in turmoil, the wise cannot alone bring order. To stride through a corrupt age and demand the Dao not be obstructed is like hobbling a fine steed with double fetters and expecting it to gallop a thousand *li*. To place an ape in a cage is to make it no different from a pig—not because it lacks skill or agility, but because it has no scope to exercise its abilities. When Shun tilled the soil and fired pottery, he could not bring prosperity to his village. Yet when he ruled as king, his virtue extended to the four seas. It is not that benevolence itself increased, but that his position afforded advantage and influence.

The sages of old were harmonious, joyful, and serene by nature; their aspirations fulfilled and the Dao realized by fate. Only when nature meets fate can action proceed; only when fate aligns with nature can clarity arise. A bow of *niao-hao* wood and a crossbow of *Xizi* make cannot shoot without their strings. *Niao-hao* refers to *zhe* mulberry; *Xizi* is either the name of a state producing crossbows or a skilled crossbow artisan from Yangzheng. A Yue skiff or a Shu raft cannot float without water. Though the people of Yue are accustomed to boats, without water, they cannot sail alone. Now, with snares and arrows poised above and nets spread below, how can one hope to soar? *Zeng* are short arrows for shooting birds; *ji* refers to their release. To soar is to fly high, wings rising and falling; to glide is to hold steady in the air.

Thus the *Odes* say:
*Plucking, plucking the* juan’er,
*Not filling even a shallow basket—*
*Alas, I long for that man,*
*Placed upon the royal road.*

This speaks of yearning for the distant past. The verse is from the *Juan’er* poem in the *Zhou Nan* section of the *Odes*. It describes how easily gathered greens fail to fill even a small vessel, just as a ruler who does not focus his heart cannot fulfill the Dao—like plucking common herbs yet failing to fill a simple basket. *"Alas, I long for that man, placed upon the royal road"* means: I think of the ancient worthy, appointing the virtuous to office, placing them in their rightful ranks. Truly, when the worthy of old each found their proper place, it is said one yearns for that distant time.

*Huainan Honglie Jie*, Scroll Four, concludes.

**Huainan Honglie Jie, Scroll Five**

*Recorded by Minister of the Grand Commandant and Libationer Xu Shen*

**Heavenly Patterns, Part One**

"Pattern" (*wen*) means "image." All refer to the celestial omens sent down to admonish the world—sun, moon, five planets, comets, and broom stars—unified in one, hence called "Heavenly Patterns." Thus the chapter is titled.

Before Heaven fell into form, it was *fengfeng yiyi*, *dongdong zhuzhu*—thus called "Great Clarity." *Fengyi* and *dongzhu* describe the formless. *Dong* is read as the *tong* in *tingtong* (paulownia); *zhu* is read as the sound of an iron head striking the earth.

The Dao began in the Void (*xukuo*). The Void gave birth to Space-Time (*yuzhou*). Space-Time gave birth to *qi*. *Qi* possessed boundaries and layers. *Yu* encompasses the four directions and above and below. *Zhou* spans past and present. This describes the formation of Heaven and Earth. *Hanyin* depicts layered stability.

The pure and light ascended, dispersing to become Heaven—*bomi* resembling drifting dust. The heavy and turbid congealed to become Earth. The union of the subtle and refined was singular in purpose. Yet the congealing of the heavy and turbid was difficult, so Heaven formed first, and Earth stabilized later.

The essence of Heaven and Earth intermingled to form *yin* and *yang*. *Xi*, union; *jing*, *qi*. The concentrated essence of *yin* and *yang* produced the four seasons. The dispersed essence of the four seasons gave rise to the myriad things.

Accumulated *yang*’s hot *qi* generated fire; the essence of fire’s *qi* became the sun. Accumulated *yin*’s cold *qi* became water; the essence of water’s *qi* became the moon. The excess essence of the sun and moon formed the stars. Heaven received the sun, moon, and stars; Earth received water, floods, and dust.

In ancient times, Gonggong contended with Zhuanxu for the throne. Enraged, he struck Mount Buzhou. Gonggong was an official title, held by Boyu during the era between Fuxi and Shennong. His descendants, relying on cunning and punishment, grew strong, thus contending with Zhuanxu, grandson of the Yellow Emperor, for the throne. Mount Buzhou lies in the northwest.

The pillar of Heaven broke; Earth’s cords snapped. Heaven tilted to the northwest, so the sun, moon, and stars shifted there. *Qing* means "high." The *Yuandao* states: "Earth tilts to the southeast." Here, *qing* means "low." First mentioning the northwest’s tilt clarifies its height. Earth does not fill the southeast, so water, floods, and dust gather there.

Heaven’s Dao is round; Earth’s Dao is square. The square governs the obscure; the round governs the bright. The bright exhales *qi*—thus fire is called "outer radiance." The obscure contains *qi*—thus water is called "inner radiance." The exhaling *qi* bestows; the containing *qi* transforms. Therefore, *yang* bestows and *yin* transforms.

Heaven’s partial *qi*, when angered, becomes wind. The harmonious *qi* of Heaven and Earth becomes rain. *Yin* and *yang* press upon each other, stirring to become thunder. *Bo*, pressing; *gan*, movement. When agitated, it becomes lightning; when chaotic, it becomes fog. When *yang* *qi* prevails, it scatters into rain and dew. *San*, dispersal like mist. When *yin* *qi* prevails, it congeals into frost and snow.

Creatures with fur and feathers, which fly and move, belong to *yang*. Those with shells and scales, which hibernate, belong to *yin*. The sun is the lord of *yang*. Thus, in spring and summer, beasts shed their fur—*chu*, the winter coat thinning and falling. At the solstice, elk shed their antlers. At the winter solstice, elk antlers fall; at the summer solstice, deer antlers fall.

The moon is the ancestor of *yin*. Thus, when the moon wanes, fish brains diminish; when the moon dies, conch shells and clams shrink. *Zong*, root; *jian*, lessening. The flesh does not fill, reflecting *yin* *qi*. *Jiao* is read as the *jiao* in *wujiao miao* (steeped in wonder).

Fire rises; water flows downward. Thus, birds fly high, and fish move low. Creatures influence one another, their roots and branches responding. *Xun* is read as the *tan* in *getan* (kudzu vine); *biao* is read as the *mo* in *daomo* (knife’s tip).

Thus, the *yang* mirror (*yang sui*) catches the sun and ignites to produce fire. The *yang sui* is metal. Take an unrimmed metal cup, polish it until hot, hold it beneath the sun at noon, and place mugwort beneath it to catch the flame. The *fang zhu* catches the moon and exudes water. The *fang zhu* is a *yin* mirror, a large clam. Polish it until hot, face it toward the full moon, and water will form. Receive it with a bronze basin, and several drops will fall—so the masters taught.

When the tiger roars, the valley wind arrives. The tiger is an earthly creature; wind is the wood wind. Wood is born of earth, so when the tiger roars, the valley wind comes. When the dragon rises, auspicious clouds gather. The dragon is water; clouds are born of water, so when the dragon rises, auspicious clouds assemble. *Shu*, gathering.

When qilin fight, the sun and moon eclipse. When whales die, comets appear. When silkworms spin silk, the *shang* strings break. When silkworms age, their silk forms from within to without, appearing like golden essence *ya* inside and out—hence called *ya* silk. Another says: playing with silk in the mouth, the *shang* note is clear, the strings fine and taut, so they break first. When the *ben* star falls, the Bohai Sea overflows. The *ben* star is a guest star, also called a broom star. *Zhui*, falling; *bo*, great; *jue*, overflowing.

The ruler’s emotions ascend to communicate with Heaven. Thus, executing the cruel brings many whirlwinds. *Bao*, tyranny; *piaofeng*, swift winds. Distorting laws and decrees brings many insects and borers. *Ming* are those that eat the heart—grain’s calamity. Killing the innocent turns the land red. *Chidi*, drought. Failing to enforce decrees brings excessive rain. When timely decrees are not heeded, prolonged rain becomes a disaster.

The four seasons are Heaven’s officials; the sun and moon are Heaven’s messengers; the stars are Heaven’s markers. *Qi*, gathering. Rainbows, rainbows, and comets are Heaven’s taboos. The male is the rainbow; the female is the secondary rainbow.

The rainbow is of mixed colors. *Ji* means prohibition. Heaven has nine regions, nine thousand nine hundred and ninety-nine corners, extending five hundred million *li* from the earth. The nine regions are the wilds of the nine heavens. Each region has one thousand one hundred and eleven corners.

The five stars, eight winds, and twenty-eight constellations: the five stars are Jupiter, Mars, Saturn, Venus, and Mercury. The eight winds are the winds of the eight trigrams. The twenty-eight constellations are: in the east, Horn, Neck, Root, Chamber, Heart, Tail, and Winnowing Basket; in the north, Dipper, Ox, Girl, Emptiness, Rooftop, Encampment, and Wall; in the west, Straddler, Stomach, Pleiades, Net, Turtle Beak, and Orion; in the south, Well, Ghost, Willow, Star, Spread, Wings, and Axletree.

The five officials and six treasuries: the five officials are the officials of the five phases. The six treasuries include grain. The Purple Palace, Supreme Subtlety, Xuan Yuan, Pool of Harmony, Four Guards, and Celestial River—all are names of stars, explained below.

What are the nine regions? The center is called the Equalizing Heaven; its stars are Horn, Neck, and Root. This is the division of Han and Zheng. The east is called the Azure Heaven; its stars are Chamber, Heart, and Tail. The northeast is called the Changing Heaven, where yang *qi* begins to stir and the myriad things sprout, hence the name Changing Heaven. Its stars are Winnowing Basket, Dipper, and Ox-Leader. Tail and Winnowing Basket are also called Broken Tree, the division of Yan. The Dipper is the division of Wu. Ox-Leader, also called Star Mark, is the division of Yue.

The north is called the Dark Heaven; its stars are Weaving Girl, Emptiness, Rooftop, and Encampment. Emptiness and Rooftop are also called Dark Hollow, the division of Qi. The northwest is called the Dim Heaven; *you* means yin. In late autumn, the west approaches yin, hence the name Dim Heaven. Its stars are Eastern Wall, Straddler, and Stomach. Encampment and Eastern Wall are also called Receiving Grain, the division of Wei. Straddler and Stomach are also called Descending Grain, the division of Lu.

The west is called the Bright Heaven; *hao* means white. The west is metal, its color white, hence the name Bright Heaven. Some write it as *Wu*. Its stars are Stomach, Pleiades, and Net. Pleiades and Net are also called Great Bridge, the division of Zhao. The southwest is called the Vermilion Heaven; *zhu* means yang. The southwest is lesser yang, hence the name Vermilion Heaven. Its stars are Turtle Beak, Orion, and Eastern Well. Turtle Beak and Orion are also called True Sinking, the division of Jin.

The south is called the Blazing Heaven; its stars are Ghost Chariot, Willow, and Seven Stars. Willow, Seven Stars, and Spread are the division of Zhou, also called Quail Fire. The southeast is called the Yang Heaven; the southeast is pure *qian* in action, hence the name Yang Heaven. Its stars are Spread, Wings, and Axletree. Wings and Axletree are also called Quail Tail, the division of Chu.

What are the five stars? The east is wood; its emperor is Tai Hao. Tai Hao is the posthumous title of Fu Xi, who ruled all under Heaven; after death, he was enshrined as the emperor of the east. His assistant is Gou Mang, who holds the jade tablet and governs spring. His spirit is Jupiter, his beast the Azure Dragon, his note *jiao*, and his days *jia* and *yi*. Wood’s color is azure, and the Azure Dragon accords with this color. *Jiao* is wood. *Jia* and *yi* are both wood.

The south is fire; its emperor is the Flame Emperor. The Flame Emperor is the son of Shao Dian. He ruled all under Heaven by the virtue of fire and was called Shen Nong; after death, he was enshrined as the emperor of the south. His assistant is Zhu Ming—according to old accounts, Zhu Rong—who holds the balance and governs summer. His spirit is Mars, his beast the Vermilion Bird. Mars is one of the five stars; the Vermilion Bird is the Vermilion Sparrow. His note is *zhi*, and his days are *bing* and *ding*. *Zhi* is fire. *Bing* and *ding* are both fire.

The center is earth; its emperor is the Yellow Emperor. The Yellow Emperor is the son of Shao Dian. He ruled all under Heaven by the virtue of earth and was called Xuan Yuan; after death, he was enshrined as the emperor of the center. His assistant is Hou Tu, who holds the measuring line and regulates the four directions. His spirit is Saturn, his beast the Yellow Dragon—earth’s color is yellow. His note is *gong*, and his days are *wu* and *ji*. *Gong* is earth. *Wu* and *ji* are both earth.

The west is metal; its emperor is Shao Hao. Shao Hao is the son of the Yellow Emperor, Qing Yang. He ruled by the virtue of metal and was called Jin Tian; after death, he was enshrined as the emperor of the west. His assistant is Ru Shou, who holds the carpenter’s square and governs autumn. His spirit is Venus, his beast the White Tiger, his note *shang*, and his days *geng* and *xin*. *Shang* is metal. *Geng* and *xin* are both metal.

The north is water; its emperor is Zhuan Xu. Zhuan Xu is the grandson of the Yellow Emperor. He ruled all under Heaven by the virtue of water and was called Gao Yang; after death, he was enshrined as the emperor of the north. His assistant is Xuan Ming, who holds the scales and governs winter. His spirit is Mercury, his beast the Dark Warrior, his note *yu*, and his days *ren* and *gui*. *Yu* is water. *Ren* and *gui* are both water.

When the Great Yin is in the four midpoints, Jupiter moves through three lodges. *Zhong* means center; the four centers refer to the Great Yin being in the middle of the four directions: *mao*, *you*, *zi*, and *wu*. When the Great Yin is in the four hooks, Jupiter moves through two lodges. *Chou* hooks *chen*, *shen* hooks *si*, *yin* hooks *hai*, and *wei* hooks *xu*—this refers to the Great Yin being in the four corners. Two times eight is sixteen; three times four is twelve. Thus, in twelve years, it traverses the twenty-eight constellations. The moon moves one-twelfth of a degree per day, and in a year, it moves thirty degrees and seven-sixteenths of a degree. In twelve years, it completes a cycle. *Zhou* means complete.

Mars typically enters the Supreme Subtlety in the tenth month, receives its mandate, and moves through the constellations. It oversees the lawless states, bringing chaos, banditry, illness, mourning, famine, and war. It appears and disappears unpredictably, altering its color, sometimes visible, sometimes hidden.

These are all means by which the heavens admonish the ruler. When Saturn begins its cycle on *jiayin*, it establishes the Dipper; each year, it moves to guard one lodge. If it should reside in a lodge but does not, that state will lose territory. If it resides where it should not, that state will gain land, and the year will be bountiful. It moves one twenty-eighth of a degree per day, thirteen and five one-hundred-twelfths degrees per year, completing a cycle in eighteen years. Saturn’s course is partial.

Venus begins its cycle on the *jiayin* of the first month, emerging in the east at dawn with Mars, remaining visible for 240 days before entering. After 120 days of concealment, it reappears in the west at dusk for 240 days before entering again. After 35 days, it re-emerges in the east. It rises at *chen* and *xu*, and sets at *chou* and *wei*. If it fails to appear when it should, or enters when it should not, the world will lay down its arms. If it fails to enter when it should, or fails to emerge when it should, the world will raise its armies.

Mercury governs the four seasons: at the spring equinox in the second month, it appears near *Kui* and *Lou*; at the summer solstice in the fifth month, near *Dongjing* and *Yugui*; at the autumn equinox in the eighth month, near *Jiao* and *Kang*; and at the winter solstice in the eleventh month, near *Dou* and *Qianniu*. *Xiao* means "appearance." It rises at *chen* and *xu*, and sets at *chou* and *wei*, remaining visible for two ten-day periods. It is observed at dawn in the east and at dusk in the west. If it fails to appear for one season, that season will be unbalanced; if it fails to appear for all four seasons, the world will suffer great famine. A failure of the grain harvest is called famine.

What are the Eight Winds? Forty-five days after the winter solstice, the *Tiaofeng* arrives—this is the wind of the *Gen* trigram, also called *Rong*, associated with the *sheng* instrument. Forty-five days after the *Tiaofeng*, the *Mingshu Feng* arrives—this is the wind of the *Zhen* trigram, associated with the *guan* instrument. Forty-five days after the *Mingshu Feng*, the *Qingming Feng* arrives—this is the wind of the *Xun* trigram, associated with the *zhu* instrument. Forty-five days after the *Qingming Feng*, the *Jingfeng* arrives—this is the wind of the *Li* trigram, associated with the *xian* instrument. Forty-five days after the *Jingfeng*, the *Liangfeng* arrives—this is the wind of the *Kun* trigram, associated with the *xun* instrument. Forty-five days after the *Liangfeng*, the *Changhe Feng* arrives—this is the wind of the *Dui* trigram, associated with the *zhong* instrument. Forty-five days after the *Changhe Feng*, the *Buzhou Feng* arrives—this is the wind of the *Qian* trigram, associated with the *qing* instrument. Forty-five days after the *Buzhou Feng*, the *Guangmo Feng* arrives—this is the wind of the *Kan* trigram, associated with the *gu* instrument.

When the *Tiaofeng* arrives, light prisoners are released, and delayed cases are resolved—this occurs at *Lichun*, the beginning of spring, hence the release of light prisoners. When the *Mingshu Feng* arrives, borders are demarcated, and fields are cultivated—this occurs at the spring equinox, when grain is sown, hence the regulation of borders and the tilling of fields. When the *Qingming Feng* arrives, gifts of silk and coin are sent to enfeoff the feudal lords—this occurs at *Lixia*, the beginning of summer, when virtue is extended, hence the dispatch of gifts to the lords. When the *Jingfeng* arrives, ranks are conferred upon the worthy, and the meritorious are rewarded—this occurs at the summer solstice, when yin qi lies below and yang qi flourishes above, symbolizing the distribution of yang, hence the rewarding of the meritorious and the enfeoffment of lords. When the *Liangfeng* arrives, the virtue of the earth is repaid, and the four suburbs are sacrificed to—this occurs at *Liqiu*, the beginning of autumn, when the grain harvest is celebrated, hence the repayment of the earth’s virtue and the sacrifice to the gods of the four directions. When the *Changhe Feng* arrives, suspended bells and chimes are taken down, and lutes and zithers are not strung—this occurs at the autumn equinox, when the killing qi arises, and the ruler mourns, hence the removal of the music of bells, chimes, and suspended instruments.
