When the *Buzhou Feng* arrives, palaces and halls are repaired, and border walls are fortified—this occurs at *Lidong*, the beginning of winter, when earthworks commence, hence the repair of palaces and the fortification of border walls to prepare against banditry and calamity. When the *Guangmo Feng* arrives, passes and bridges are closed, and legal punishments are decided—this reflects the closure of the year in winter, when passes and bridges are not traversed. For doubtful cases of punishment, decisions are made in accordance with the season.

What are the Five Offices? The east is the Office of Fields, the south is the Office of the Minister of War, the west is the Office of Justice, the north is the Office of Public Works, and the center is the Capital. The Office of Fields oversees agriculture, the Office of the Minister of War oversees the military, the Office of Justice oversees prisons, the Office of Public Works oversees land, and the Capital is the foremost of the four directions.

What are the Six Treasuries? They are *zi-wu*, *chou-wei*, *yin-shen*, *mao-you*, *chen-xu*, and *si-hai*. The Supreme Subtlety is the court of the Great One. The Supreme Subtlety is a star, and the Great One is a celestial deity. The Purple Palace is the dwelling of the Great One. The Xuanyuan is the abode of the Emperor’s consorts. The Xianchi is the preserve of the water and fish—Xianchi is a star, and the water and fish are celestial deities. The Celestial River Gate is the threshold of the host of spirits. *Que* means "gate." The Four Palaces are responsible for administering rewards and punishments. The Four Palaces are the Purple Palace, Xuanyuan, Xianchi, and Celestial River Gate. The Supreme Subtlety governs the Vermilion Bird, *zhu* meaning "to oversee." The Purple Palace holds the Dipper and revolves leftward, the sun moving one degree per day to complete its circuit of the heavens. At the winter solstice, the sun reaches the Mountain of the Steep Wolf, the southernmost mountain. Moving one degree per day, the moon travels 182 and five-eighths degrees to reach the Mountain of the Ox’s Head at the summer solstice—the Ox’s Head is the northernmost mountain. After 365 and one-quarter degrees, a year is completed.

At the beginning of the Heavenly One’s cycle, in the first month, *jianyin*, the sun and moon both enter *Yingshi* at five degrees. After seventy-six years, the Heavenly One completes its initial cycle, and the sun and moon again enter *Yingshi* at five degrees in the first month, with no remainder—this is called one *ji*. After twenty *ji*, 1,520 years, the great cycle ends. The sun, moon, and stars return to the beginning of *jiayin*. The sun moves one degree per day, and the year has an excess of one-quarter degree, so after four years, 1,461 days accumulate, and the celestial bodies return to their original positions. After eighty years, the sun returns to its original (day).

*Zi-wu* and *mao-you* are the two cords—*sheng* means "straight." *Chou-yin*, *chen-si*, *wei-shen*, and *xu-hai* are the four hooks. The northeast is the corner of repaying virtue—*bao* means "to return." Yin qi reaches its extreme in the north, and yang qi arises in the east; from yin returning to yang, it is called the corner of repaying virtue.

The four corners are called *wei*. The southwest is the corner of turning from yang—having passed the southwest, yang is about to return to yin, hence it is called the corner of turning from yang. The southeast is the corner of *changyang*—*changyang* means neither advancing nor retreating. In the southeast, pure yang prevails, neither flourishing nor declining, ever thus, hence it is called the corner of *changyang*. The northwest is the corner of □-through—pure yin prevails in the northwest, and yang qi is closed and congealed; as yang qi is about to sprout, it first breaks through, hence it is called the corner of □-through.

At the winter solstice, the Dipper aligns northward with the cord; yin qi reaches its extreme, and yang qi begins to sprout, hence the winter solstice is called *virtue*. *Virtue* means "beginning to grow." At the summer solstice, the Dipper aligns southward with the cord; yang qi reaches its extreme, and yin qi begins to sprout, hence the summer solstice is called *punishment*. *Punishment* means "beginning to diminish."

When yin qi reaches its extreme, it descends to the Yellow Springs and extends north to the North Pole, hence one must not dig the earth or bore wells. All things close and hide; hibernating creatures retreat into their burrows, hence it is said that *virtue* resides indoors. When yang qi reaches its extreme, it extends south to the South Pole and rises to the Vermilion Heaven, hence one must not level mounds or ascend rooftops. All things flourish and multiply; the five grains begin to grow, hence it is said that *virtue* resides in the wilds.

At the winter solstice, water follows; at the summer solstice, fire follows. Thus, in the fifth month, the fire regulator prevails and water leaks—*fire regulator* means fire is ascendant, hence water seeps and leaks. Another explanation: when the Fire Star aligns at the center, the earth becomes damp. In the eleventh month, the water regulator prevails and yin overcomes—*water regulator* means water is ascendant, hence yin prevails. Another explanation: when the Encampment Mansion aligns at the center in the south.

Yang qi becomes fire, and yin qi becomes water; water prevails, hence at the summer solstice it is damp; fire prevails, hence at the winter solstice it is dry. Dryness makes charcoal light; dampness makes charcoal heavy.

At the solstice, well water swells, basin water overflows, sheep shed their wool, elk shed their antlers, and magpies begin to change their winter habits and build nests. An eight-foot gnomon casts a shadow of one zhang and three chi at noon.

At the summer solstice, flowing yellow oozes forth; the essence of stone appears. *Flowing yellow* is the essence of earth; yin qi stirs below, hence it oozes forth. *Stone essence* is the essence of the five colors. Cicadas begin to sing; *banxia* sprouts—*banxia* is a medicinal herb. Mosquitoes and horseflies do not bite foals or calves; birds of prey do not seize fledglings. In the fifth month, faint yin resides below; foals, calves, and fledglings are not yet fully grown, their flesh and blood tender, their limbs weak. Thus, mosquitoes and birds of prey, responding to yin, do not bite or seize them.

An eight-foot gnomon casts a shadow of one chi and five cun. When the shadow is long, yin qi prevails; when the shadow is short, yang qi prevails.

When yin qi prevails, there is flooding; when yang qi prevails, there is drought. The interplay of yin and yang’s punitive and virtuous powers unfolds across seven abodes.

What are the seven abodes? Chamber, hall, courtyard, gate, lane, thoroughfare, and wilds. For thirty days in the twelfth month, virtue resides in the chamber—fifteen days before the solstice and fifteen days after—before moving onward. Each abode it occupies endures for thirty days. When virtue is in the chamber, punishment lies in the wilds; when virtue is in the hall, punishment lies in the thoroughfare; when virtue is in the courtyard, punishment lies in the lane. When yin and yang harmonize in virtue, punishment and virtue converge at the gate. In the eighth and second months, yin and yang qi are balanced, day and night equal in length—thus it is said that punishment and virtue converge at the gate. When virtue faces south, life flourishes; when punishment faces south, life is cut short. Hence it is said: in the second month, all things converge and flourish; in the eighth month, all things converge and grasses and trees wither.

Between the two corners lies ninety-one and one-quarter degrees. From the northeast to the southeast are the two corners; encompassing the four corners are three hundred sixty-five degrees, each degree spanning two thousand nine hundred thirty-two *li*. The sun ascends by five sixteenths of a degree daily, traversing one degree in fifteen days to form a nodal period, thereby generating the twenty-four solar terms.

When the Dipper points to *zi*, it is the winter solstice, its tone corresponding to *Huangzhong*—*Huangzhong* being the eleventh month. *Zhong* means "to gather"; yang qi gathers beneath the Yellow Springs. Fifteen days later, when it points to *gui*, it is *Lesser Cold*, its tone corresponding to *Yingzhong*—*Yingzhong* being the tenth month. It signifies yin responding to yang, completing its work as all things gather and store in season—hence it is called *Yingzhong*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *chou*, it is *Greater Cold*, its tone corresponding to *Wuyi*—*Wuyi* being the ninth month. Yin qi rises while yang qi descends; all things follow yang in concealment, none venturing forth—hence it is called *Wuyi*. Fifteen days later, when it points to the corner of *Baode*, yin prevails upon the earth. Thus it is said: forty-six days after the winter solstice comes *Lichun*, when frozen yang thaws, its tone corresponding to *Nanlü*—*Nanlü* being the eighth month. *Nan* means "to bear"; yang qi lies concealed within while yin harmonizes with yang to fulfill its work—hence it is called *Nanlü*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *yin*, it is *Yushui*, its tone corresponding to *Yize*—*Yize* being the seventh month. *Yi* means "injury"; *ze* means "law." As yang wanes and yin emerges, all things wither and are injured, conforming to the law of their nature—hence it is called *Yize*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *jia*, it is *Jingzhe*, its tone corresponding to *Linzhong*—*Linzhong* being the sixth month. *Lin* means "multitude"; *zhong* means "to gather." As yang reaches its peak and yin begins to stir, all things gather in abundance—hence it is called *Linzhong*. Fifteen days later, when it aligns with the *mao* meridian, it is said that at the spring equinox, thunder moves, its tone corresponding to *Ruibin*—*Ruibin* being the fifth month. Yin qi droops below like a host, while yang presides above like a guest—hence it is called *Ruibin*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *yi*, the *Qingming* winds arrive, its tone corresponding to *Zhonglü*—*Zhonglü* being the fourth month. Yang lies without while yin resides within, thus *lü* extends to yang to assist in its work—hence it is called *Zhonglü*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *chen*, it is *Guyu*, its tone corresponding to *Guxi*—*Guxi* being the third month. *Gu* means "former"; *xi* means "new." Yang qi nurtures life, casting off the old for the new—hence it is called *Guxi*. Fifteen days later, when it points to the corner of *Changyang*, the spring equinox concludes. Thus it is said: forty-six days later comes *Lixia*, when great winds subside—*ji* meaning "to cease"—its tone corresponding to *Jiazhong*—*Jiazhong* being the second month. *Jia* means "to flank"; all things depart from yin and flank the yang earth to grow—hence it is called *Jiazhong*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *si*, it is *Xiaoman*—*Xiaoman* being the fourth month—its tone corresponding to *Taicou*—*Taicou* being the first month’s pitch. *Cou* means "to cluster"; as yin wanes and yang emerges, all things cluster upon the earth to grow—hence it is called *Taicou*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *bing*, it is *Mangzhong*, its tone corresponding to *Dalü*—*Dalü* being the twelfth month’s pitch. *Lü* means "companion"; all things stir below but have yet to emerge—hence it is called *Dalü*, paired with *Huangzhong* to aid yang in manifesting its work. Fifteen days later, when it points to *wu*, yang qi reaches its peak. Thus it is said: forty-six days later comes the summer solstice, its tone corresponding to *Huangzhong*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *ding*, it is *Xiaoshu*, its tone corresponding to *Dalü*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *wei*, it is *Dashu*, its tone corresponding to *Taicou*. Fifteen days later, when it points to the corner of *Beiyang*, the summer solstice concludes. Thus it is said: forty-six days later comes *Liqiu*, when cool winds arrive, its tone corresponding to *Jiazhong*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *shen*, it is *Chushu*, its tone corresponding to *Guxi*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *geng*, white dew descends, its tone corresponding to *Zhonglü*. Fifteen days later, when it aligns with the *you* meridian, it is said that at the autumn equinox, thunder retreats, hibernating creatures turn northward, its tone corresponding to *Ruibin*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *xin*, it is *Hanlu*, its tone corresponding to *Linzhong*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *xu*, it is *Shuangjiang*, its tone corresponding to *Yize*. Fifteen days later, when it points to the corner of *Tong*, the autumn equinox concludes. Thus it is said: forty-six days later comes *Lidong*, when grasses and trees perish entirely, its tone corresponding to *Nanlü*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *hai*, it is *Xiaoxue*, its tone corresponding to *Wuyi*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *ren*, it is *Daxue*, its tone corresponding to *Yingzhong*. Fifteen days later, when it points to *zi*, it is said: yang is born at *zi*, yin is born at *wu*. Yang is born at *zi*; thus in the eleventh month, at the winter solstice, magpies begin to build nests, and human qi converges at the head. Yin is born at *wu*; thus the fifth month is a time of lesser punishment, when shepherd’s purse and wheat wither, and winter-grown grasses and trees must die. The Dipper’s handle marks the lesser year: the first through fourth stars form the *kui*, while the fifth through seventh form the *shao*.

In the first month, the establishment is at *yin*, with the moon following the sequence of the twelve earthly branches. The *Xianchi* serves as the Great Year. In the second month, the establishment is at *mao*, with the moon proceeding rightward through the four extensions, cycling endlessly. When one faces the Great Year, disgrace follows; when one turns away, strength ensues. To the left brings decline; to the right brings prosperity. The Lesser Year: to the southeast brings life, to the northwest brings death. One must not face it, but may turn away; one must not go left, but may go right—this is what is meant.

The Great Time is the *Xianchi*. The Lesser Time is the monthly establishment. The celestial framework begins its cycle invariably at *yin*, commencing with a rightward shift. Each year it moves once, completing a full celestial cycle in twelve years, then beginning anew.

*Huainan Honglie Jie*, Scroll Five, concludes.

*Huainan Honglie Jie*, Scroll Six, recorded by Minister of the Grand Commandant and Libationer Xu Shen.

**Heavenly Patterns, Part Three**

In the winter of the first year of *Huainan*, the Great Unity was at *bingzi*; the winter solstice fell on *jiawu*, and the beginning of spring on *bingzi*. This was the first year of the composition of the *Huainanzi*. Another account states: King Liu Chang of Huainan, younger half-brother of Emperor Xiaowen of Han, usurped the title of Eastern Emperor. Exiled to Yandao, he died in Yong, and his four sons were all enfeoffed as marquises. At the time, people sang of him:

*A foot of silk, so fine and bright,
A pint of grain, so full and light.
Two brothers, yet they could not share—
Such strife was more than they could bear.*

When Emperor Wen heard this, he said, "Do they think I covet their lands?" He summoned the four marquises and made them kings. Thus, this marks the first year of King Liu An of Huainan’s reign, recorded to establish the era.

Two *yin* and one *yang* form *qi* as two; two *yang* and one *yin* form *qi* as three. *Yin* is coarse, thus it receives less *qi*; *yang* is refined, thus it receives more. Another explanation: the upper receives two, the lower receives three, combining to make five. Hence, "combined *qi* produces sound," and the number of sounds is five. Combined *qi* produces sound, combined *yin* produces *yang*, and combined *yang* produces pitch. Thus, there are five notes and six pitches. Sound doubles to form days, and pitch doubles to form celestial stems. Hence, there are ten days and twelve stems.

The moon travels thirteen degrees and seventy-six twenty-sixths of a degree per day (some texts read "eight" for "six"). Twenty-nine days and four hundred ninety-nine nine-hundred-fortieths of a day make a month, and twelve months make a year. The year has an excess of ten days and eight hundred twenty-seven nine-hundred-fortieths of a day, so after nineteen years, seven intercalary months are added.

The winter solstice occurs at *zi* and *wu*; the summer solstice at *mao* and *you*. Three days after the winter solstice is the day of the summer solstice. Three days after the winter solstice marks the summer solstice of the following year. The year shifts by six days, then returns to its beginning. This six-day shift means that if this year’s winter solstice is at *zi*, next year’s will be at *wu*.

When the winter solstice falls on *renwu*, *jiazi* receives control, and Wood governs affairs—fire smoke turns green. Wood’s color is green, associated with the east. After seventy-two days, *bingzi* receives control, and Fire governs affairs—fire smoke turns red. Fire’s color is red, associated with the south. After seventy-two days, *wuzi* receives control, and Earth governs affairs—fire smoke turns yellow. Earth is central, its color yellow. After seventy-two days, *gengzi* receives control, and Metal governs affairs—fire smoke turns white. Metal is of the west, its color white. After seventy-two days, *renzi* receives control, and Water governs affairs—fire smoke turns black. Water is of the north, its color black. After seventy-two days, the year concludes. *Gengzi* receives control, the year shifts by six days, and by calculation, after seventy years, it returns to *jiazi*.

When *jiazi* receives control, one should act with gentle kindness, lift prohibitions, open gates, clear obstructions, and refrain from felling trees. *Jia* is Wood, which rules the east; thus, one enacts gentle kindness. Hibernating creatures emerge from their burrows, so gates are opened, obstructions cleared. As Wood rules in spring, trees must not be felled.

When *bingzi* receives control, one should promote the worthy and good, reward merit, establish marquises, and distribute wealth. Fire governs affairs, symbolizing bright *yang*; merit is recognized, so marquises are enfeoffed, and wealth is distributed.

When *wuzi* receives control, one should care for the elderly, widows, and orphans, distribute gruel and porridge, and bestow grace. Earth governs affairs, symbolizing Earth’s nurturing nature; thus, grace is bestowed.

When *gengzi* receives control, one should repair walls and ramparts, fortify cities, enforce prohibitions, prepare armor and weapons, admonish officials, and punish the lawless. Metal governs affairs, symbolizing Metal’s cutting nature; thus, those who violate the law are punished.

When *renzi* receives control, one should close gates, conduct thorough searches, ban searches of guests, expel new guests, enforce punishments, execute the guilty, close passes and bridges, and prohibit migration. Water governs affairs, symbolizing winter’s closure; thus, migration is forbidden.

The *qi* of *jiazi* is dry and turbid; the *qi* of *bingzi* is dry and *yang*; the *qi* of *wuzi* is damp and turbid; the *qi* of *gengzi* is dry and cold; the *qi* of *renzi* is clear and cold.

If *bingzi* encroaches on *jiazi*, hibernating creatures emerge early, as Wood’s *qi* is warm—thus, they emerge early, and thunder arrives prematurely.

If *wuzi* encroaches on *jiazi*, embryos die, eggs fail to hatch, and birds and insects suffer harm.

If *gengzi* encroaches on *jiazi*, there is war.

If *renzi* encroaches on *jiazi*, frost appears in spring.

If *wuzi* encroaches on *bingzi*, there is thunder.

If *gengzi* encroaches on *bingzi*, there is injury (some texts read "lightning" for "injury").

If *renzi* encroaches on *bingzi*, there is hail.

If *jiazi* encroaches on *bingzi*, the earth quakes.

If *gengzi* encroaches on *wuzi*, the five grains suffer calamity.

If *renzi* encroaches on *wuzi*, summer is cold with frost and rain.

If *jiazi* encroaches on *wuzi*, armored insects do not form.

If *bingzi* encroaches on *wuzi*, there is severe drought, and *luo* plants wither. *Luo* is the *jiang* grass, which grows in water (or on land), its stalks intertwining to form mats. It is called *feng*. Drought dries it, hence it withers.

If *renzi* encroaches on *gengzi*, there is great hardness, and fish do not form.

If *jiazi* encroaches on *gengzi*, plants and trees die and revive.

If *bingzi* encroaches on *gengzi*, plants and trees bloom again. Now, in the eighth and ninth months, plums and crabapples bloom again and bear fruit—this is the case.

If *wuzi* encroaches on *gengzi*, the year may be preserved or lost.

If *jiazi* encroaches on *renzi*, winter fails to store. "Fails to store" means Earth’s *qi* is released.

If *bingzi* encroaches on *renzi*, stars fall. "Fall" means to descend.

If *wuzi* encroaches on *renzi*, hibernating creatures emerge in winter from their dens.

If *gengzi* encroaches on *renzi*, there is winter thunder in their region.

In the third month of late spring, *Fenglong* emerges to usher in the rain. *Fenglong* is thunder. By the third month of late autumn, Earth’s *qi* ceases to store, and its killing force is gathered. The hundred insects hibernate, dwelling quietly behind closed doors, as the killing *qi* prevails.

The Blue Maiden emerges to descend frost and snow. The Blue Maiden is the celestial deity Qingyu Nü, who governs frost and thunder. She circulates the *qi* of the twelve hours, and by the evening of the second month of mid-spring, she withdraws her store and seals away the cold—gathering what she has stored and closing it away.

Nüyi strikes the drum and sings to harmonize Heaven’s harmony, to nurture the hundred grains, birds, beasts, grasses, and trees. Nüyi presides over spring and summer, the deity of growth and nourishment. In the first month of early summer, the grains and millet ripen, and the male turtledove calls long, heralding the year for the emperor and lords. The male turtledove is the cuckoo.

Thus, if Heaven does not release its *yin*, the myriad things do not come to life; if Earth does not release its *yang*, the myriad things do not mature. Heaven is round, Earth is square, and the Dao resides at the center. The sun embodies *virtue*, the moon embodies punishment; when the moon returns, the myriad things die, and when the sun reaches its solstice, the myriad things are born.

Distant mountains conceal their mountain *qi*; distant waters cause their aquatic creatures to hibernate; distant trees cause their leaves to wither. If the sun is not seen for five days, it has lost its position, and the sage does not rejoice—for *yu* means "to delight."

The sun rises from Yang Valley, bathes in the Bitter Pool, and brushes past Fusang—this is called *Morning Light*. *Fu* means "to pass." This marks the first arrival of the day. Ascending Fusang, it begins its journey—this is called *Dawn’s Glimmer*. *Dawn’s Glimmer* signifies the approach of light. *Fei* is read as in *feinuogao*. Reaching Qu’e, this is called *Daybreak*—the break of dawn. Arriving at Zengquan, this is called *Early Meal*. Reaching Sangye, this is called *Late Meal*. Reaching Hengyang, this is called *Corner Noon*. Reaching Kunwu, this is called *True Noon*. Kunwu is a hill in the south. Reaching the Bird’s Roost, this is called *Lesser Return*. The Bird’s Roost is a mountain in the southwest where birds lodge. Reaching Sorrowful Valley, this is called *Evening Meal*. Sorrowful Valley is a great ravine in the southwest—its depths are so steep that gazing upon it evokes sorrow, hence its name. Reaching Nüji, this is called *Greater Return*. Nüji is a *yin* land in the northwest. Reaching Yuan’ao, this is called *High Pestle*. Yuan’ao is a place name. *High Pestle* refers to the hour of *xu*, when people pound their grain. Reaching Lianshi, this is called *Lower Pestle*. Lianshi is a mountain in the northwest. As dusk approaches, the image of pestles at work below is complete, hence *Lower Pestle*. *Lian* is read as in "rotten." Reaching Sorrowful Spring, she halts her maidens and rests her horses—this is called *Hanging the Chariot*. Reaching Yu’ao, this is called *Dusk*. Reaching Meng Valley, this is called *Settling Dusk*. Meng Valley is a mountain in the north—the place where Lu Ao saw the "above" as described. The sun sets at the shore of Yu’ao and dawns at the bank of Meng Valley. *Shu* means "bright"; *pu* means "shore."

The sun traverses the nine provinces and seven lodges, covering 510,739 *li*. From Yang Valley to Yu’ao, there are sixteen stations, comprising the nine provinces and seven lodges. Yu divided them into morning, day, dusk, and night.

At the summer solstice, *yin* rides over *yang*, and thus the myriad things wither and die. At the winter solstice, *yang* rides over *yin*, and thus the myriad things rise and live. Day is the portion of *yang*; night is the portion of *yin*. Therefore, when *yang* *qi* prevails, the days lengthen and the nights shorten; when *yin* *qi* prevails, the days shorten and the nights lengthen.

The Emperor stretches the four cords and rotates them with the Dipper. *Yun* means "to revolve." The moon shifts one celestial mansion and then returns to its place. In the first month, it points to *yin*; in the twelfth month, it points to *chou*—completing a full cycle in a year before beginning anew.

When it points to *yin*, the myriad things stir—*yin* signifies the appearance of movement. The pitch receives *Tai Cang*. *Tai Cang* is the sprouting that has yet to emerge. When it points to *mao*, *mao* flourishes abundantly. The pitch receives *Jia Zhong*. *Jia Zhong* is when seeds begin to pod. When it points to *chen*, *chen* causes things to shake. The pitch receives *Gu Xi*. *Gu Xi* is the old departing and the new arriving. When it points to *si*, *si* signifies life has taken form. The pitch receives *Zhong Lü*. *Zhong Lü* is the center filling and expanding. When it points to *wu*, *wu* means opposition. The pitch receives *Rui Bin*. *Rui Bin* is peace and submission. When it points to *wei*, *wei* means obscurity. The pitch receives *Lin Zhong*. *Lin Zhong* is drawing to a halt. When it points to *shen*, *shen* means groaning. The pitch receives *Yi Ze*. *Yi Ze* is the changing of norms, and *virtue* departs. When it points to *you*, *you* means fullness. The pitch receives *Nan Lü*. *Nan Lü* is bearing and encompassing greatness. When it points to *xu*, *xu* means extinction. The pitch receives *Wu Yi*. *Wu Yi* enters into insatiability. When it points to *hai*, *hai* means closure. The pitch receives *Ying Zhong*. *Ying Zhong* is responding to its bell. When it points to *zi*, *zi* means "here." The pitch receives *Huang Zhong*. *Huang Zhong* is the bell having turned yellow. When it points to *chou*, *chou* means binding. The pitch receives *Da Lü*. *Da Lü* is traveling away in succession.

When it aligns with *mao* and *you*, *yin* and *yang* divide, and day and night are balanced. Thus it is said: the compass gives life, the square brings death; the balance beam extends, the steelyard conceals; the plumb line resides at the center, serving as the root of the four seasons.

The Dao is called the compass. It begins with the One, yet the One does not generate, so it divides into *yin* and *yang*. *Yin* and *yang* unite in harmony, and the myriad things are born. Thus it is said: the One generates the Two, the Two generates the Three, and the Three generates the myriad things.

Heaven and Earth take three months to form a season. Therefore, sacrificial rites use three servings of rice as propriety; mourning observances use three leaps as ritual; and military regulations use three layers of armor as system. Taking three to verify things, three threes make nine. Thus, the pitch of *Huang Zhong* is nine inches, and the *gong* note is harmonized—*tiao* means "harmony." Multiplying nine by nine yields eighty-one, so the number of *Huang Zhong* is established. *Huang* is the color of Earth’s *virtue*; *zhong* is where *qi* is sown.

At the winter solstice, the *virtue*-*qi* of Earth prevails, and Earth’s color is yellow—hence it is called *Huang Zhong*. The number of the pitch-pipes is six, divided into female and male, thus twelve pipes correspond to the twelve months. Each of the twelve is completed by threes, so setting one and multiplying eleven by three yields a product of 707,147—thus the great number of *Huang Zhong* is established. Altogether there are twelve pitch-pipes:

*Huang Zhong* as *gong*,
*Tai Cou* as *shang*,
*Gu Xi* as *jiao*,
*Lin Zhong* as *zhi*,
*Nan Lü* as *yu*.

Things are completed by threes, and sounds are established by fives. Three and five make eight, so creatures born from eggs have eight orifices. When the pitch-pipes first arise, they emulate the phoenix’s song—thus sound is born from eight. *Huang Zhong* is *gong*, and *gong* is the ruler of sounds. Therefore, *Huang Zhong* occupies the position of *zi*, its number is eighty-one, it governs the eleventh month, and descends to generate *Lin Zhong*. *Lin Zhong*’s number is fifty-four, it governs the sixth month, and ascends to generate *Tai Cou*. *Tai Cou*’s number is seventy-two, it governs the first month, and descends to generate *Nan Lü*. *Nan Lü*’s number is forty-eight, it governs the eighth month, and ascends to generate *Gu Xi*. *Gu Xi*’s number is sixty-four, it governs the third month, and descends to generate *Ying Zhong*. *Ying Zhong*’s number is forty-two, it governs the tenth month, and ascends to generate *Rui Bin*. *Rui Bin*’s number is fifty-seven, it governs the fifth month, and ascends to generate *Da Lü*. *Da Lü*’s number is seventy-six, it governs the twelfth month, and descends to generate *Yi Ze*. *Yi Ze*’s number is fifty-one, it governs the seventh month, and ascends to generate *Jia Zhong*. *Jia Zhong*’s number is sixty-eight, it governs the second month, and descends to generate *Wu Yi*. *Wu Yi*’s number is forty-five, it governs the ninth month, and ascends to generate *Zhong Lü*. *Zhong Lü*’s number is sixty, it governs the fourth month, and reaches its limit without generating further.

*Zhi* generates *gong*, *gong* generates *shang*, *shang* generates *yu*, *yu* generates *jiao*, *jiao* generates *Gu Xi*, and *Gu Xi* generates *Ying Zhong*—when compared to the standard notes, they form harmony. *Ying Zhong* corresponds to the tenth month, and when compared to the standard notes, it forms harmony. *He* means "to follow sound," or is also called "harmony." *Ying Zhong* generates *Rui Bin*, which does not compare to the standard notes—thus it is called *miu*.

At the winter solstice, the sound corresponds to *Lin Zhong*, gradually growing more turbid. At the summer solstice, the sound corresponds to *Huang Zhong*, gradually growing clearer. The twelve pitch-pipes respond to the twenty-four seasonal changes: *jia-zi* is the *zhi* of *Zhong Lü*; *bing-zi* is the *yu* of *Jia Zhong*; *wu-zi* is the *gong* of *Huang Zhong*; *geng-zi* is the *shang* of *Wu Yi*; *ren-zi* is the *jiao* of *Yi Ze*.

In ancient times, the standards for measures, weights, and capacities were born of the Way of Heaven. The length of the *Huang Zhong* pitch-pipe is nine inches. Things are generated by threes, and three nines make twenty-seven—thus the width of cloth is two feet and seven inches. In ancient times, all cloth widths were like this. Sound is generated by eights, so a person’s height is eight *chi*. A *xun* is double this, so eight *chi* make one *xun*. Where there is form, there is sound. The number of sounds is five, and multiplying five by eight yields forty—thus forty *chi* make one *pi*. A *pi* is the measure of an average person, and one *pi* establishes the standard.

At the autumn equinox, the *biao* is fixed, and when the *biao* is fixed, the grain ripens. *Biao* refers to the awns of grain ears and the husks of millet. *Ding* means "completion," hence the grain ripens. The character for *biao* is read like *mao* in the phrase "there are cats and tigers," and in ancient texts was written as *miao*.

The number of the pitch-pipes is twelve, so twelve *biao* equal one grain of millet, and twelve grains of millet equal one *cun*. The pitch-pipes correspond to the celestial stems, and sounds correspond to the days. The number of days is ten, from *jia* to *gui*. Thus ten *cun* make one *chi*, and ten *chi* make one *zhang*. For capacity, twelve grains of millet equal one *fen*—*fen* refers to the division of weight into *zhu*. Twelve *fen* equal one *zhu*, and twelve *zhu* equal half a *liang*. The balance has left and right, so doubling it makes twenty-four *zhu* equal one *liang*.

Heaven has four seasons to complete one year, so multiplying by four yields sixteen—thus sixteen *liang* make one *jin*. Three months make one season, and thirty days make one month—thus thirty *jin* make one *jun*. Four seasons make one year—thus four *jun* make one *dan*. For sound, one pitch-pipe generates five notes, and twelve pitch-pipes make sixty sounds. Multiplying by six yields thirty-six—thus three hundred sixty sounds correspond to the days of one year. Therefore, the numbers of pitch-pipes and calendars are the Way of Heaven and Earth.

For descending generation, double the number and divide by three. For ascending generation, multiply by four and divide by three. The pitch-pipes generate one another in ascent and descent, guiding without haste.

The Great *Yin* begins at *jia-yin*. After one cycle, it reaches *jia-xu*; after two cycles, it reaches *jia-wu*; after three cycles, it returns to the origin of *jia-yin*. Each year it shifts one celestial stem. After the Beginning of Spring, it attains its stem and moves in its proper sequence. With three before and five after, all affairs may be undertaken. "Before and after" refer to the positions before and after the Great *Yin*. Where the Great *Yin* is established, hibernating insects first burrow into their dens, and magpies orient their nests toward it as a door.

When the Great *Yin* is in *yin*, the Vermilion Bird is in *mao*, the Curved Array is in *zi*, the Dark Warrior is in *xu*, the White Tiger is in *you*, and the Azure Dragon is in *chen*. *Yin* is *jian*, *mao* is *chu*, *chen* is *man*, *si* is *ping*—these govern generation. *Wu* is *ding*, *wei* is *zhi*—these govern decline. *Shen* is *po*—this governs balance. *You* is *wei*—this governs the handle. *Xu* is *cheng*—this governs lesser *virtue*. *Hai* is *shou*—this governs great *virtue*. *Zi* is *kai*—this governs the Grand Year. *Chou* is *bi*—this governs the Great *Yin*.

When the Great *Yin* is in *yin*, the year is called *She Ti Ge*. Its male counterpart is Jupiter, which resides in *Dou* and *Niu*, and in the eleventh month rises with it in the eastern sky, with *Dong Jing* and *Yu Gui* opposite.

When the Great *Yin* is in *mao*, the year is called *Shan E*. *Shan* is read as the *ming* in *mingyang*. Jupiter resides in *Xu Nü*, *Xu*, and *Wei*, and in the twelfth month rises with it in the eastern sky, with *Liu*, *Qi Xing*, and *Zhang* opposite.

When the Great *Yin* is in *chen*, the year is called *Zhi Xu*. Jupiter resides in *Ying Shi* and *Dong Bi*, and in the first month rises with it in the eastern sky, with *Yi* and *Zhen* opposite.

When the Great *Yin* is in *si*, the year is called *Da Huang Luo*. Jupiter resides in *Kui* and *Lou*, and in the second month rises with it in the eastern sky, with *Jiao* and *Kang* opposite.

When the Great *Yin* is in *wu*, the year is called *Dun Zang*. Jupiter resides in *Wei*, *Mao*, and *Bi*, and in the third month rises with it in the eastern sky, with *Di*, *Fang*, and *Xin* opposite.

When the Great *Yin* is in *wei*, the year is called *Xie Qia*. Jupiter resides in *Zi Xiu* and *Shen*, and in the fourth month rises with it in the eastern sky, with *Wei* and *Ji* opposite.

When the Great *Yin* is in *shen*, the year is called *Tun Tan*. Jupiter resides in *Dong Jing* and *Yu Gui*, and in the fifth month rises with it in the eastern sky, with *Dou* and *Qian Niu* opposite.

When the Great *Yin* is in *you*, the year is called *Zuo E*. *Zuo* is read as *zuo*. Jupiter resides in *Liu*, *Qi Xing*, and *Zhang*, and in the sixth month rises with it in the eastern sky, with *Xu Nü*, *Xu*, and *Wei* opposite.

When the Great *Yin* is in *xu*, the year is called *Yan Mao*. Jupiter resides in *Yi* and *Zhen*, and in the seventh month rises with it in the eastern sky, with *Ying Shi* and *Dong Bi* opposite.

When the Great *Yin* is in *hai*, the year is called *Da Yuan Xian*. Jupiter resides in *Jiao* and *Kang*, and in the eighth month rises with it in the eastern sky, with *Kui* and *Lou* opposite.

When the Great *Yin* is in *zi*, the year is called *Kun Dun*. *Kun* is read as *qun*. Jupiter resides in *Di*, *Fang*, and *Xin*, and in the ninth month rises with it in the eastern sky, with *Wei*, *Mao*, and *Bi* opposite.

When the Great *Yin* is in *chou*, the year is called *Chi Fen Ruo*. Jupiter resides in *Wei* and *Ji*, and in the tenth month rises with it in the eastern sky, with *Zi Xiu* and *Shen* opposite.

When the Great *Yin* is in *jiazi*, *Xing* and *De* converge in the eastern palace. They constantly shift to what they cannot overcome, converging for four years before parting, and parting for sixteen years before reconverging. The reason for their parting is that *Xing* cannot enter the central palace but shifts to *Wood*. Where the Great *Yin* resides is called *De*; the celestial branch is *Xing*. *De* is the *Gang* that doubles itself by cause, and the *Rou* that shifts to what it cannot overcome. *Xing* is *Water* in the branch of *Wood*, and *Wood* in the branch of *Water*; *Metal* and *Fire* establish their positions. In all shifts of the spirits, the Vermilion Bird is one position ahead of the Great *Yin*, the Curved Array is three positions behind, the Dark Warrior is five positions ahead, the White Tiger is six positions behind, and the *Xu* star rides the Curved Array, whereupon Heaven and Earth converge. *Xi* means harmony.

In all cases, *jia* is firm and *yi* is yielding, *bing* is firm and *ding* is yielding, continuing thus to *gui*. *Wood* is born in *hai*, matures in *mao*, and dies in *wei*—these three branches are all *Wood*. *Fire* is born in *yin*, matures in *wu*, and dies in *xu*—these three branches are all *Fire*. *Earth* is born in *wu*, matures in *xu*, and dies in *yin*—these three branches are all *Earth*. *Metal* is born in *si*, matures in *you*, and dies in *chou*—these three branches are all *Metal*. *Water* is born in *shen*, matures in *zi*, and dies in *chen*—these three branches are all *Water*. Thus, the five conquests give birth to one, mature at five, and end at nine. Five times nine is forty-five, so the spirits shift once every forty-five days, responding to three with five, and after eight shifts, the year concludes.

When employing the Great *Yin*, strike to the left with *Xing* ahead and to the right with *De* behind. Attack the opposing branch of the Curved Array, and in battle, victory is assured; in assault, conquest is certain. To know the Way of Heaven, take the sun as the master. In the sixth month, it aligns with the heart, circling leftward, dividing into twelve months corresponding to the days. Heaven and Earth converge in double harmony, and afterward, no misfortune will befall.

The stars: in the first month, *Ying Shi* is established; in the second month, *Kui* and *Lou*; in the third month, *Wei*. The stars should refer to the sun. The *Ming Tang Yue Ling* states: in the first month of spring, the sun is in *Ying Shi*; in the second month, in *Kui* and *Lou*; in the third month, in *Wei*. This means the stars establish *Ying Shi* in the first month—there is an error in the character.

In the fourth month, *Bi* is established; in the fifth month, *Dong Jing*; in the sixth month, *Zhang*; in the seventh month, *Yi*; in the eighth month, *Kang*; in the ninth month, *Fang*; in the tenth month, *Wei*; in the eleventh month, *Qian Niu*; in the twelfth month, *Xu*.

The degrees of the stellar divisions: *Jiao* twelve, *Kang* nine, *Di* fifteen, *Fang* five, *Xin* five, *Wei* eighteen, *Ji* eleven and one quarter, *Dou* twenty-six, *Qian Niu* eight, *Xu Nü* twelve, *Xu* ten, *Wei* seventeen, *Ying Shi* sixteen, *Dong Bi* nine, *Kui* sixteen, *Lou* twelve, *Wei* fourteen, *Mao* eleven, *Bi* sixteen, *Zi Xiu* two, *Shen* nine, *Dong Jing* thirty, *Yu Gui* four, *Liu* fifteen, *Qi Xing* seven, *Zhang* eighteen, *Yi* eighteen, *Zhen* seventeen—altogether the twenty-eight lodges.

The stellar lodges and their corresponding regions: *Jiao* and *Kang*: Zheng; *Di*, *Fang*, and *Xin*: Song; *Wei* and *Ji*: Yan; *Dou* and *Qian Niu*: Yue; *Xu Nü*: Wu; *Xu* and *Wei*: Qi; *Ying Shi* and *Dong Bi*: Wei; *Kui* and *Lou*: Lu; *Wei*, *Mao*, and *Bi*: Wei; *Zi Xiu* and *Shen*: Zhao; *Dong Jing* and *Yu Gui*: Qin; *Liu*, *Qi Xing*, and *Zhang*: Zhou; *Yi* and *Zhen*: Chu.

Where Jupiter resides, the five grains flourish abundantly. Its opposite is the opposing position, and in that year, misfortune befalls. If it should reside but does not, or strays to another position, the ruler dies and the state perishes.

When the Great *Yin* governs spring, it desires to enact gentle kindness and temperate coolness. The *virtue* of *Wood* is benevolence, hence the gentle coolness. When the Great *Yin* governs summer, it desires to bestow and proclaim clarity.

The *virtue* of *Fire* is yang, hence its bestowal and proclamation are partial brightness. When the Great *Yin* governs autumn, it desires to repair armaments and refine weapons. The *virtue* of *Metal* is severance and division, hence the refinement of weapons. When the Great *Yin* governs winter, it desires fierceness, resoluteness, and unyielding strength. Pure *yin* seals and solidifies; water congeals into ice, hence its unyielding strength.

After three years, its disposition changes; after six years, its norm alters. Thus, famine occurs once every three years, decline once every six, and prosperity once every twelve. *Kang* means abundance.

*Jia* corresponds to Qi, *Yi* to Eastern Yi, *Bing* to Chu, *Ding* to Southern Yi, *Wu* to Wei, *Ji* to Han, *Geng* to Qin, *Xin* to Western Yi, *Ren* to Wei, *Gui* to Yue, *Zi* to Zhou, *Chou* to Di, *Yin* to Chu, *Mao* to Zheng; *Chen* to Jin, *Si* to Wei, *Wu* to Qin, *Wei* to Song, *Shen* to Qi, *You* to Lu, *Xu* to Zhao, *Hai* to Yan.

*Jia*, *Yi*, *Yin*, and *Mao* belong to *Wood*. *Bing*, *Ding*, *Si*, and *Wu* belong to *Fire*. *Wu*, *Ji*, and the four seasons belong to *Earth*. *Geng*, *Xin*, *Shen*, and *You* belong to *Metal*. *Ren*, *Gui*, *Hai*, and *Zi* belong to *Water*.

*Water* generates *Wood*, *Wood* generates *Fire*, *Fire* generates *Earth*, *Earth* generates *Metal*, *Metal* generates *Water*. When the child generates the mother, it is called *righteousness*; when the mother generates the child, it is called *nurturance*. When child and mother unite, it is called *specialization*. When the mother overcomes the child, it is called *restraint*; when the child overcomes the mother, it is called *distress*.

To strike and kill with dominance brings victory without retaliation. To act with *specialization* yields success. To conduct affairs with *righteousness* establishes a name that does not falter. To nurture and cultivate with *nurturance* causes the myriad things to flourish abundantly. To undertake matters with *distress* leads to ruin, destruction, and death.

The deities of the Northern Dipper possess both feminine and masculine aspects. In the eleventh month, they begin their alignment at *zi*, with each month advancing by one celestial position. The masculine aspect moves leftward, while the feminine moves rightward. In the fifth month, they converge at *wu* to deliberate the celestial registers; in the eleventh month, they converge at *zi* to deliberate virtue. The position occupied by the Great Yin becomes the *yann* day—a day on which no affairs should be initiated.

The *Kanyu* moves slowly, and the masculine discerns the feminine by sound, thus forming the *qi* celestial stems. The reckoning begins with *jia-zi*, as child and mother seek one another, and their conjunction is called *he*. Ten days and twelve celestial branches complete a cycle of sixty days, totaling eight conjunctions. If the conjunction occurs before the year’s end, death follows; if after, no misfortune arises.

*Jia-xu* governs Yan; *yi-you*, Qi; *bing-wu*, Yue; *ding-si*, Chu; *geng-shen*, Qin; *xin-mao*, the Rong; *ren-zi*, Dai; *gui-hai*, the Hu. *Wu-xu* and *ji-hai* govern Han; *ji-you* and *ji-mao*, Wei; *wu-wu* and *wu-zi* unify the realm in eight conjunctions.

When the Great Yin, Lesser Year, stars, sun, and celestial branches—all five spirits—converge, and clouds, wind, or rain appear on that day, the ruler of the state shall bear the omen. Among celestial deities, none is more revered than the Azure Dragon, also called Heavenly One or the Great Yin. Where the Great Yin resides, one must not turn away but may face it. Where the Northern Dipper strikes, none may oppose.

Heaven and Earth are established, dividing into yin and yang. Yang arises from yin, and yin arises from yang. Yin and yang intertwine, and the four cardinal directions are thus connected. Life and death alternate, and all things come to be. Crawling creatures, those with beaks and breath, orifices and limbs—all communicate with Heaven. Heaven possesses nine layers and nine apertures.

Heaven has four seasons to regulate the twelve months, just as the four limbs govern the twelve joints. None is more noble than humanity, which employs its twelve joints. Thus, undertaking affairs contrary to Heaven’s will—beginning from the winter solstice to count the coming year’s first month and new moon—ensures the people’s sustenance is secure. If fewer than fifty days remain, each person consumes one *dou* daily. For each additional day, the ration increases by one *sheng*.

The governance of the year is as follows:

In the year of *Sheti Ge*, *ge* means "to rise." It speaks of the myriad things responding to yang and rising. The year brings early floods and late droughts; rice suffers blight, silkworms fail to mature (*deng* means "to complete"), soybeans and wheat flourish, and the people consume four *sheng* daily. At *yin*, within *jia*, it is called *Yanpeng*. It signifies the myriad things’ sharp edges poised to emerge, yet restrained and unopened—hence *Yanpeng*.

In the year of *Shanyan*, *shan* means "exhausted," and *yan* means "to halt." It speaks of yang qi propelling the myriad things to rise while yin qi is exhausted and ceases. The year is harmonious; rice, soybeans, wheat, and silkworms thrive, and the people consume five *sheng* daily. At *mao*, within *yi*, it is called *Zhanmeng*. Within *yi*, it signifies things obscured and restrained, breaking through their sheaths—hence *Zhanmeng*.

In the year of *Zhixu*, *zhi* means "concealed," and *xu* means "leisurely." It speaks of hibernating creatures all dispersing and emerging at ease. The year brings early droughts and late floods, minor famine, silkworms confined, wheat ripening, and the people consume three *sheng* daily. At *chen*, within *bing*, it is called *Rouzhao*. Within *bing*, the myriad things all sprout branches and spread leaves—hence *Rouzhao*.

In the year of *Dahuangluo*, *huang* means "great," and *luo* means "to scatter." It speaks of the myriad things flourishing and bursting forth, spreading abundantly. The year brings minor warfare, silkworms mature slightly, wheat thrives, soybeans suffer blight, and the people consume two *sheng* daily. At *si*, within *ding*, it is called *Qiangyu*. Within *ding*, the myriad things are robust and flourishing—hence *Qiangyu*.

In the year of *Dunzang*, it speaks of the myriad things all thriving and strong. *Dun* means "abundant," and *zang* means "vigorous." The year brings great droughts, silkworms mature, rice suffers blight, soybeans and wheat thrive, millet fails, and the people consume two *sheng* daily. At *wu*, within *wu*, it is called *Zhuyong*. Within *wu*, it signifies the central position, with the myriad things nourishing the four directions—hence *Zhuyong*.

In the year of *Xieqia*, *xie* means "harmony," and *qia* means "union." It speaks of yin desiring to transform and unite the myriad things. The year brings minor warfare, silkworms mature, rice thrives, soybeans and wheat fail, and the people consume three *sheng* daily. At *wei*, within *ji*, it is called *Tuwei*. Within *ji*, the myriad things each fulfill their nature—hence *Tuwei*. *Tu* means "to separate," and *wei* means "to part."

In the year of *Tuntan*, *tun* means "great," and *tan* means "to refine." It speaks of the myriad things all refining their essence and qi. The year is harmonious, with light rains, silkworms maturing, soybeans and wheat thriving, and the people consume three *sheng* daily. At *shen*, within *geng*, it is called *Shangzhang*. Within *geng*, yin qi ascends, and the myriad things reach completion—hence *Shangzhang*.

In the year of *Zuoe*, *zuoe* means "to wither and fall." The myriad things all decline. The year brings great warfare, pestilence among the people, silkworms failing to mature, soybeans and wheat failing, millet infested, and the people consume five *sheng* daily. At *you*, within *xin*, it is called *Chongguang*. Within *xin*, the myriad things reach maturity, shining brilliantly—hence *Chongguang*.

In the year of *Yanmao*, *yan* means "to conceal," and *mao* means "luxuriant." The myriad things are all obscured and covered. The year brings minor famine, warfare, silkworms failing to mature, wheat failing to thrive, and the people consume seven *sheng* daily. At *xu*, within *ren*, it is called *Xuanyi*. Within *ren*, it signifies the year’s end encompassing the myriad things—hence *Xuanyi*.

In the year of *Dayuanxian*, *yuan* means "to store," and *xian* means "to welcome." It speaks of the myriad things concluding at *hai*, with all—great and small—hidden and burrowed to welcome yang. The year brings great warfare, severe famine, silkworms emerging, soybeans and wheat failing, millet infested, and the people consume three *sheng* daily.

In the year of *Kundun*, *kun* means "chaotic," and *dun* means "turbid." It speaks of yang qi all mixed and murky, with the myriad things sprouting. The year brings great mists, floods, silkworms, rice, soybeans, and wheat thriving, and the people consume three *dou* daily. At *zi*, within *gui*, it is called *Zhaoyang*. Within *gui*, yang qi begins to sprout, and the myriad things unite in generation—hence *Zhaoyang*.

In the year of *Chifenruo*, *fen* means "to rise," and *ruo* means "to follow." It speaks of yang qi rousing the myriad things to rise, with none failing to follow their nature. *Chi* is the color of yang. The year brings minor warfare, droughts and floods, silkworms failing to emerge, rice blight, soybeans failing to grow, wheat thriving, and the people consume one *sheng* daily. At the first dawn—alternatively, the first month—of the year: in the evening, first plant a gnomon in the east, then hold another gnomon and retreat ten paces from the first. Align the sight with the sun’s first emergence at its northern edge. When the sun is directly overhead at its setting, plant another gnomon in the east, and using the western gnomon, align the sight with the sun’s entry at its northern edge to determine the east. The midpoint between the two gnomons, together with the western gnomon, marks the true east-west line.

At the winter solstice, the sun rises at the southeast corner and sets at the southwest corner. At the spring and autumn equinoxes, it rises due east and sets due west. At the summer solstice, it rises at the northeast corner and sets at the northwest corner, and at noon it is due south. To determine the breadth and length of the east-west and north-south distances: erect four gnomons to form a square with sides of one *li*. Before the spring equinox or after the autumn equinox by ten days or more, from the northern gnomon align the sight with the sun’s first emergence at dawn to await the corresponding moment. When the alignment corresponds, this marks the point directly beneath the sun. Immediately align the sight with the southern gnomon, using the number of *cun* where the sun enters the front gnomon as the divisor to calculate the breadth. Subtract the length of the erected gnomon to determine the east-west distance from this point. For example, if the sun enters the center of the front gnomon by one *cun*, then one *cun* corresponds to one *li*. One *li* contains eighteen thousand *cun*, so from this point eastward it is eighteen thousand *li*. If the sun enters the front gnomon by half a *cun*, then half a *cun* corresponds to one *li*. Dividing the accumulated *cun* of one *li* by half a *cun* yields thirty-six thousand *li*, which is the westward distance from this point. Summing the east and west distances gives the total diameter.

If the alignment occurs before the spring equinox or fails to occur after the autumn equinox, this location is south of the center. If the alignment occurs before the autumn equinox or fails to occur after the spring equinox, this location is north of the center. If the alignment occurs precisely at the equinoxes or solstices, this location is at the central point between north and south. From the central point, to determine the distance to the southern extreme: if the alignment fails to occur before the autumn equinox, this location is at the central point between north and south. To determine the distance to the northern or southern extremes from the central point: from the southwestern gnomon, align the sight with the sun. At the summer solstice, when the sun first emerges, align it with the northern gnomon, which will be equal to the distance from the east to the northeastern gnomon. Due east is eighteen thousand *li*, so from the center northward is also eighteen thousand *li*. Doubling this gives the total north-south distance. For locations not at the center, adjust the calculation based on the number of *cun* the sun enters or exits the front gnomon: for every *cun* the sun enters the gnomon, the sun is one *li* closer; for every *cun* it exits, the sun is one *li* farther.

To determine the height of the heavens: erect a gnomon ten *chi* tall, with a north-south distance of one thousand *li* between gnomons. On the same day, measure their shadows. The northern gnomon casts a shadow of two *chi*, while the southern gnomon casts a shadow of one *chi* and nine *cun*. This means that for every thousand *li* southward, the shadow shortens by one *cun*. At twenty thousand *li* south, there is no shadow—this is the point directly beneath the sun. A shadow of two *chi* corresponding to a gnomon height of one *zhang* means that for every one unit southward, the height increases by five. Thus, taking the distance from this point south to the point beneath the sun and multiplying by five gives one hundred thousand *li*, which is the height of the heavens. If the shadow equals the height of the gnomon, then the height equals the distance.

*Huainanzi Honglie Jie*, Scroll Six, concludes here.

*Huainanzi Honglie Jie*, Scroll Seven
Recorded by Minister of the Grand Commandant, Xu Shen.

**Topical Study on Earthly Forms**

This section records the mountains, rivers, marshes, and lakes of the east, west, south, and north—the earth’s burdens and the manifestations of the myriad things’ transformations. Hence it is called *Earthly Forms* and thus titles the chapter.

The earth bears all within the Six Directions and the Four Extremes. The Six Directions were previously explained in *The Primal Dao*. The Four Extremes are the farthest reaches of the four directions. Beyond them lies nothing, so they are called “within.” The sun and moon illuminate it; the stars and constellations traverse it; the four seasons order it; and the Great Year governs it. *Governs* here means *to correct*—the position of the Great Year corrects the celestial timing.

Between heaven and earth lie the Nine Provinces and Eight Extremes. The Eight Extremes are the farthest reaches of the eight directions. The earth has nine mountains, nine strategic passes, nine marshes, eight winds, and six waters.

What are the Nine Provinces?
The Divine Province of the southeast is called *Agricultural Soil*. The southeast’s *chen* constellation governs agriculture, where Hou Ji wove his patterns—hence it is called *Agricultural Soil*.
The next province due south is called *Fertile Soil*. *Fertile* means *abundant*. The fifth month aligns with *wu*, when crops flourish—hence it is called *Fertile Soil*.
The Rong Province of the southwest is called *Vast Soil*. *Vast* means *great*. The seventh month aligns with *shen*, when the five grains grow large—hence it is called *Vast Soil*.
The Yan Province due west is called *Unified Soil*. *Unified* means *completed*. The eighth month aligns with *you*, when the hundred grains ripen—hence it is called *Unified Soil*.
The central Ji Province is called *Central Soil*. *Ji* means *great*, as it governs the four directions—hence it is called *Central Soil*.
The Tai Province of the northwest is called *Rich Soil*.
The Ji Province due north is called *Completed Soil*—its meaning is unknown.
The Bo Province of the northeast is called *Hidden Soil*. *Bo* means *level*, as it is where the hidden *qi* lies concealed—hence it is called *Hidden Soil*.
The Yang Province due east is called *Renewed Soil*. *Renewed* means *repeated*, for when the *yin* *qi* is exhausted in the north, the *yang* *qi* revives in the northeast—hence it is called *Renewed Soil*.

What are the Nine Mountains?
They are Mount Kuaiji, Mount Tai, Mount Wangwu, Mount Shou, Mount Taihua, Mount Qi, Mount Taihang, Mount Yangchang, and Mengmen.
Mount Kuaiji lies in Kuaiji Commandery.
Mount Tai is now in Taishan Commandery—it is the Eastern Marchmount.
Mount Wangwu is northeast of present-day Heng County in Hedong, where the Shen River rises.
Mount Shou lies south of Puban County in the bend of the Yellow River—it is where Boyi hid.
Mount Taihua is now Mount Yin in Hongnong—it is the Western Marchmount.
Mount Qi is north of present-day Hanyang County in Fufeng—it was the capital of the Zhou.
Mount Taihang is now at Taihang Pass in Shangdang, directly aligned with Yewang County in Henan.
Mount Yangchang is a mountain. The *Garden of Persuasions* states: “Jie’s dwelling had the Yellow River and Ji River to the left, Mount Taihua to the right, Yique to the south, and Yangchang to the north.” Now, ninety *li* northwest of Jinyang in Taiyuan, a pass called Yangchangji connects Hexi and Shang Commandery—this is Mengmen, the boundary of Mount Taihang.

What are the Nine Strategic Passes?
They are Dafeng, Miane, Jingruan, Fangcheng, Xiaohan, Jingxing, Lingci, Gouzhu, and Juyong.
Dafeng is in Jin.
Miane is now Mianchi in Hongnong.
Jingruan and Fangcheng are both in Chu.
Xiaohan is in Hongnong Commandery’s Mianchi, at Xiaoyin.
Jingxing is in Changshan, the pass to Taiyuan.
Lingci is in Liaoxi.
Gouzhu is in Yanmen, at Yinguang Gouzhu.
Juyong is east of Zuyang in Shanggu, the pass to Yundu.

What are the Nine Marshes?
*Marshes* here means *lakes*.
They are Juqu in Yue, Yunmeng in Chu, Yangyu in Qin, Dalu in Jin, Putian in Zheng, Mengzhu in Song, Haiyu in Qi, Julu in Zhao, and Zhaoyu in Yan.
Juqu lies between Wu and Yue.
Yunmeng is in Huarong in Nanjun.
Yangyu, also called Jupu, is likely in Chiyang in Fengyi.
Dalu is where Wei Xianzi perished in flames.
Putian is now in Zhongmou in Henan. The *Commentary* states: “Zheng has Yuanpu, just as Qin has Jupu. You may take its elk and deer to ease our state’s troubles.”
Mengzhu is now in Suiyang, the marsh northeast of Liangyuan.
Haiyu means *seacoast*, likely near the sea’s edge.
Julu is now the Guang’e Marsh.
Zhaoyu is now in Taiyuan Commandery—it once belonged to Yan.

What are the Eight Winds?
The northeast wind is called *Blazing Wind*, born of *gen* *qi*—also called *Fusion Wind*.
The east wind is called *Seasonal Wind*, born of *zhen* *qi*—also called *Bright Multitude Wind*.
The southeast wind is called *Scenic Wind*, born of *xun* *qi*—also called *Clear Brightness Wind*.
The south wind is called *Mighty Wind*, born of mixed *qi*—also called *Joyous Wind*.
The southwest wind is called *Cool Wind*, born of *kun* *qi*.
The west wind is called *Whistling Wind*, born of *dui* *qi*.
The northwest wind is called *Luminous Wind*, born of *qian* *qi*—also called *Gate-Shutting Wind*.
The north wind is called *Cold Wind*, born of *kan* *qi*—also called *Vast Desert Wind*.

What are the Six Waters?
They are the Yellow River, Red Water, Liao River, Black Water, Yangzi River, and Huai River.
The Yellow River rises from the northeast corner of Kunlun.
The Red Water rises from its southeast corner.
The Liao River rises from Mount Jieshi, flowing east from the northern frontier and emptying into the sea southwest of Liaodong.
The Black Water is in Yongzhou.
The Yangzi River rises from Mount Min in the far west of Shu.
The Huai River rises south of Mount Tongbo in Pingyang.

Within the Four Seas, the distance from east to west is twenty-eight thousand *li*, and from south to north, twenty-six thousand *li*. *Zi* and *wu* mark the meridian; *mao* and *you* mark the parallel—thus the meridian is shorter and the parallel longer. The waterways stretch eight thousand *li*, with six hundred named rivers among them. The land routes extend three thousand *li*.

The land routes are slanting paths. *Lu* means "earth." Yu then dispatched Taizhang to pace from the eastern extremity to the western extremity, measuring two hundred million, thirty-three thousand, five hundred *li* and seventy-five *bu*. He sent Shuhai to pace from the northern extremity to the southern extremity, measuring two hundred million, thirty-three thousand, five hundred *li* and seventy-five *bu*. Taizhang and Shuhai were swift walkers, both ministers of Yu. Within the seas, the distance from east to west is shorter, while from south to north it is longer, yet the extremities are equal in measure.

All great floodwaters and deep marshes, from three hundred *ren* upward, extend two hundred million, thirty-three thousand, five hundred and fifty *li*, comprising nine abysses. Yu then used *xi* soil to fill the floodwaters and create famous mountains. *Xi* soil does not diminish; the more it is excavated, the more it multiplies, thus it was used to fill the floodwaters. Famous mountains are great mountains. Digging below the Kunlun Void levels the earth, or in some versions, forms pools.

At its center stands the Ninefold Augmented City, rising eleven thousand *li*, one hundred fourteen *bu*, two *chi*, and six *cun*. The "center" refers to the midst of the Kunlun Void. *Zeng* means "layered." There are Five Cities and Twelve Towers, as recorded in the *Kuodi Xiang*. This account may be fanciful, for in truth, such things are unheard of.

Atop it grows the Wood Grain, reaching five *xun* in height—*xun* being thirty-five *chi*. To its west stand the Pearl Tree, Jade Tree, *Xuan* Tree, and Deathless Tree. To its east grow the *Shatang* and *Langgan*, both names of jade. One version holds that *Shatang* is a tree name. The *Lüshi Chunqiu* states: "Of fruits most excellent, the fruit of the *Shatang*." To its south stands the Crimson Tree—*jiang* meaning "red." To its north stand the Jasper Tree and *Yao* Tree—*bi* meaning "blue-green jade." These lie north of the Wood Grain.

Surrounding it are four hundred forty gates, with ten gates on each side. Between gates lie four *li*, and between *li* lie nine *chun*—each *chun* measuring one *zhang* and five *chi*. *Chun* is a unit of measure. Alongside stand nine jade wells, linked at the northwest corner. *Heng* means "radiant." In some versions, *heng* is written as *peng*, referring to the vessel that holds the elixir of immortality.

The northern gate opens to admit the wind from Buzhou. There are the Inclined Palace and the Rotating Chamber—the Inclined Palace fills a *xu* when at its center. The Rotating Chamber is adorned with rotating jade. One version holds that the chamber’s *xuanji* lock can turn, hence its name. The Suspended Garden, Cool Breeze, and *Fantong* lie within the Kunlun’s *Changhe* gate. *Changhe* is the name of the Kunlun Void’s gate. The Suspended Garden, Cool Breeze, and *Fantong* are all names of Kunlun’s mountains. *Fan* is pronounced like the *fan* in "barley meal." This is its vegetable garden.

The pool of the vegetable garden is irrigated by the Yellow Water, which encircles it thrice before returning to its source. The source is its origin. This is called the Cinnabar Water, and drinking it grants immortality.

The Yellow River emerges from the northeast corner of Kunlun, passes through the Bohai Sea, and enters the Jishi Mountain, where Yu dredged it. The Bohai is the great sea. The Yellow River flows underground from Kunlun, and Yu dredged it to make it passable, reaching Jishi Mountain. The *Book* states: "The River issues from Jishi." Here, "enters" means "exits."

The Red Water emerges from its southeast corner and flows southwest into the southern sea, east of the Cinnabar Marsh. East of the Red Water, the Weak Water issues from Qiongshi—Qiongshi being a mountain name in Zhangye, a northern frontier waterway. It reaches Heli, and its remnant waves enter the Flowing Sands, crossing the Flowing Sands to reach the southern sea. *Jue* means "to pass." The Flowing Sands flow onward.

The Yang Water emerges from its northwest corner and enters the southern sea south of the Feathered People. The Yang Water passes through the Lintao Shidao, east to Wudu, where it becomes Hanyang. In some versions, it is written as *Yangshui*. These four waters are the divine springs of the Thearch, used to harmonize the hundred medicines and moisten the myriad things.

The Kunlun Mound may be twice as high—if it is ten thousand *li* tall, doubling it makes twenty thousand *li*. This is called the Cool Breeze Mountain, and ascending it grants immortality. Doubling its height again, it is called the Suspended Garden, and ascending it grants numinous power, able to summon wind and rain. Doubling it once more, it reaches the heavens above, and ascending it grants divinity. This is the abode of the Supreme Thearch. The Supreme Thearch is the Heavenly Thearch.

The Fusang Tree stands in Yangzhou, where the sun shines. Fusang is the *fusang* tree, south of the Tang Valley. *Bi* means "to illuminate." Passing through Yangzhou, the east. *Bi* is pronounced like the *zhi* in "leafless branch." The Upright Tree stands in Duguan—its form resembles life, and pulling it reveals bark like a yellow-green snake’s, with leaves like a net. Duguan is a mountain name in the south. The myriad thearchs ascend and descend from here. At noon, there is no shadow, and a call echoes without direction, for this is the center of heaven and earth. The thearchs ascend to heaven and descend from Duguan Mountain, hence "ascend and descend." At noon, the sun stands directly overhead, casting no shadow, thus it is called the center of heaven and earth.

The Ruo Tree stands west of the Upright Tree, its tip bearing ten suns, whose blossoms illuminate the earth below. The "tip" is its end. The Ruo Tree’s end holds ten suns, shaped like lotus blossoms. *Hua* means "light," which shines upon the earth below.

The greatness of the Nine Provinces spans a pure square of a thousand *li*. *Chun* means "edge," and is also a unit of measure. Beyond the Nine Provinces lie the Eight *Yin*, each also a thousand-*li* square. *Yin* means "distant." *Yin* is pronounced like *yin* in "descendant."

To the northeast lies the Great Marsh, called Wutong. The Great Marsh and Wutong are both marsh names. To the east lies the Great Islet, called the Lesser Sea. An islet is land amid water. The east is water-rich, hence the Lesser Sea, also a marsh name. To the southeast lies Juyu, called Yuanzhe. *Yuan* is pronounced like the *xue* in "uncle" as spoken by the people of Changshan. To the south lie the Great Dream and the Vast Marsh.

"Dream" refers to Yunmeng. *Hao* also means "great." To the southwest lies Zhuzi, called Danzé. As it is near the Dan River, it takes its name, hence Danzé. To the west lie the Nine Regions, called Quanzé. To the northwest lies Daxia, called Haizé. To the north lies Daming, called Hanzé. The north abounds in cold waters, hence Hanzé.

The eight *Yin* and eight marshes are said to "rain upon the Nine Provinces." Beyond the eight *Yin* lie the Eight *Xian*. *Xian* means "cord" or "tie," binding heaven and earth as their boundary, hence *Xian*. Each is also a thousand-*li* square:

To the northeast lies Heqiu, called Huangtu. Where the phoenix sings and the *luan* dances, it is named Heqiu and Huangtu. To the east lies Jilin, called Sangye. To the southeast lies Daqiong, called Zhongnü. To the south lies Duguang, called Fanhù. Duguang is a kingdom’s name. The mountain lies within this land, thus also called Duguang Mountain. As it lies south of the homeland, all doors face north, hence "reversed doors." To the southwest lies Jiaoyao, called Yantu. Jiaoyao is the land of short people, who stand less than three *chi* in fear. To the west lies Jinqiu, called Woye. The west is the position of metal, hence Jinqiu. *Wo* means "white," and the west is white, hence Woye. To the northwest lies Yimu, called Shasuo. The people of this land have one eye, centered on the face. Shasuo is where flowing sands arise, also said to be a marsh name. To the north lies Jibing, called Weiyu. The north is where cold ice gathers, thus taking its name. Jibing means "accumulated ice." Weiyu is a mountain name, lying at the northern pole where the sun is never seen.

The *qi* of the Eight *Xian* issues forth cold and heat, aligning with the Eight *Zheng* through wind and rain. The Eight *Zheng* are the proper winds of the eight directions, bringing wind and rain within the Eight *Xian*. Beyond the Eight *Xian* lie the Eight *Ji*:

To the northeast lies Fangtu Mountain, called Cang Gate. As wood governs the northeast, it is the beginning of sound, hence Cang Gate. To the east lies Dongji Mountain, called the Gate of Opening Light. *Ming* means "yang," where the sun rises, hence the Gate of Opening Light. To the southeast lies Bomu Mountain, called Yang Gate. In the southeast, the lunar station is *si*, where pure yang governs, hence Yang Gate. All cities’ southeast corner gates are Yang Gates, of this kind. To the south lies Nanji Mountain, called Shu Gate. The south is the height of yang, where warmth accumulates, hence Shu Gate. To the southwest lies Bianju Mountain, called Bai Gate. In the southwest, the lunar station is *shen*, the beginning of metal *qi*. Metal *qi* is white, hence Bai Gate. To the west lies Xiji Mountain, called the Gate of Changhe. In the west, the eighth month’s lunar station is *you*, when all things reach completion and are ready for harvest. *Chang* means "great."

*He* means "to close." The great gathering of the myriad things is enclosed, hence the Gate of Changhe. To the northwest lies Buzhou Mountain, called the Gate of Youdu. *You* means "enclosed," and *du* means "gathered." As Xuanming (Dark and Frozen) *qi* begins to take effect, following yin to gather, it is called the Gate of Youdu. To the north lies Beiji Mountain, called the Gate of Han. It is where cold accumulates, hence the Gate of Han.

The clouds of the Eight Poles bring rain to the world; the winds of the Eight Gates regulate cold and heat. The clouds of the Eight Strings, Eight Borders, and Eight Marshes rain upon the Nine Provinces and harmonize the Central Land. The Central Land is Jizhou.

The finest of the east is found in the *xunyuqi* jade of Yiwulü. Yiwulü is a mountain name, located in Liaodong’s dependent state. *Xunyuqi* is the name of a jade. The finest of the southeast is found in the bamboo arrows of Kuaiji. Kuaiji Mountain lies south of present-day Shanyin County in Kuaiji, where Yu was buried. Bamboo arrows are the fine bamboo arrows produced in the Kuaiji region today. The finest of the south is found in the rhinoceros and elephant of Liang Mountain. Liang Mountain is in Kuaiji. In Changsha and south of the Xiang River, rhinoceros horn and elephant tusk are treasures of these creatures. The finest of the southwest is found in the metals and stones of Mount Hua. *Metal* refers to fine metal; *stone* refers to stone containing jade. Mount Hua is present-day Mount Hua south of Huayin in Hongnong. The finest of the west is found in the pearls and jades of Mount Huo. It produces luminous pearls and jade of jade color. This is present-day Yong’an County in Hedong. The finest of the northwest is found in the *qiulin* and *langgan* of Kunlun. *Qiulin* and *langgan* are both fine jades. The finest of the north is found in the sinews and horns of Youdu. Ancient Youdu lay north of Yingmen; its livestock were suited to cattle, sheep, and horses, and it produced fine sinews and horns for making bows and crossbows. The finest of the northeast is found in the patterned hides of Chi Mountain. *Chi* is read as in "Chiqiu." *Patterned hides* are the pelts of leopards and tigers. As the tradition states: "The son of Wu Zhong sent Meng Le through Wei Zhuangzi to present leopard and tiger pelts in order to seek peace with the Rong tribes." The finest of the center is found in Mount Tai, which produces the Five Grains, mulberry, hemp, fish, and salt. Mount Tai is Mount Dai. It is where kings perform the feng and shan sacrifices at the change of dynasties, hence called Mount Dai. The Five Grains, mulberry, hemp, fish, and salt are what nourish the people. *Produces* means "grows."

In general, the earth’s forms: east-west is *wei* (latitude), north-south is *jing* (longitude). Mountains accumulate virtue; rivers accumulate punishment. Mountains are benevolent, for the myriad things are born there, hence they accumulate virtue. Rivers are wise, and wisdom makes judgments, hence they accumulate punishment. As the *Analects* says: "The benevolent delight in mountains; the wise delight in water."

The high are for life; the low are for death. The high are yang and govern life; the low are yin and govern death. Hills are male; valleys are female. Hills are lofty and open, yang, hence male. Valleys are low and sunken, yin, hence female. Where water bends in circles, there are pearls; where it bends in squares, there is jade. Circular bends are yang. Pearls are yang within yin. Square bends are yin. Jade is yin within yang. All follow their kind.

Clear waters contain yellow gold; dragon pools contain *yuying* jade. Clear waters are limpid, hence yellow gold is found there. Dragon pools are where dragons emerge and roam. *Yuying* jade transforms, possessing luminous essence. Lands each produce according to their kind. Thus, mountain *qi* yields many males; marsh *qi* yields many females; barrier *qi* yields many dull-witted; wind *qi* yields many deaf; forest *qi* yields many infirm; wood *qi* yields many hunchbacked. From this point up to "mountain *qi* yields many males," all refer to children born with these conditions. Shore *qi* yields many swollen; stone *qi* yields many strong, like the hardness of stone. Perilous *qi* yields many goiters, for the *qi* of perilous heights and depths surges into the throat and congeals, causing many goiters and throat ailments. Heat *qi* yields many who die young, their lives cut short. Cold *qi* yields many long-lived. Valley *qi* yields many with numbness. Hill *qi* yields many mad. Floodplain *qi* yields many benevolent, for floodplains are low and marshy. Mound *qi* yields many greedy. Light soils yield quickness; heavy soils yield slowness. *Quickness* means swiftness.

Clear waters have soft sounds; turbid waters have loud sounds. *Sounds* refer to voices. Swift waters yield light people; slow waters yield heavy people. *Swift* refers to rushing, violent waters. The Central Land yields many sages. All reflect their *qi*; all correspond to their kind.

Thus, in the south there are grasses that never die, while in the north there is ice that never melts. The south is warm, so its grasses never perish; the north is cold, so its ice never thaws. In the east lies the Land of Gentlemen, for the east is ruled by the virtue of wood, which is benevolence, hence the Land of Gentlemen. Its people wear robes, caps, and swords, and eat the flesh of beasts, employing two striped tigers as attendants.

In the west lie corpses with mutilated forms. When one sleeps and dwells, dreams come directly—when a person dies, they become a ghost. The west is governed by metal, and metal is associated with cutting, severing, and warfare, hence the corpses with mutilated forms. *Qin* means sleep; *ju* means dwelling. The *qi* of metal is unyielding and strong, so in sleep and dwelling, dreams are vivid and direct, thus called "direct dreams." Those who do not live out their allotted years die and become ghosts, capable of bringing demonic afflictions upon people. Another account says: the mutilated corpses there have their two breasts as eyes and their navels as mouths, wielding shields and axes in dance. The Celestial Spirits sever their hands, and the Supreme Emperor later severs their heads—hence their sleep and dwelling yield direct dreams.

Magnetite soars upward, mica draws water, earthen dragons summon rain, and swallows and geese take turns in flight. When Tang suffered drought, he fashioned earthen dragons to resemble true dragons. Clouds follow dragons, thus bringing rain. Swallows, the dark birds, arrive at the spring equinox, while geese at the spring equinox fly north to the deserts. Swallows depart at the autumn equinox, and geese at the autumn equinox fly south to Pengli Marsh—hence they "take turns in flight." *Dai* means alternation.

Clams, crabs, pearls, and turtles wax and wane with the moon. *Yu* means to follow. Therefore, people of firm soils are resolute; those of weak soils are plump; those of loamy soils are large; those of sandy soils are fine. *Lu* is read as the *lu* in *lu sheng* (hempen rope). *Xi* means small. People of fertile soils are comely; those of barren soils are unsightly.

Those who drink water are skilled swimmers and endure the cold—such are fish, turtles, ducks, and egrets. Those who eat earth have no hearts yet are clever—such are earthworms. Those who eat wood are strong and fierce—such are bears and brown bears. *Bi* refers to the yellow markings of the intestines; *bi* is read as the *bi* in *nei bi gan zhong guo* (internal distress in the Central Land), near the nose. Those who eat grass are swift but foolish—such are elk and deer. Those who eat leaves produce silk—such are moths and silkworms. Those who eat meat are brave and fierce—such are tigers, leopards, eagles, and goshawks. Those who consume *qi* are spiritually enlightened and long-lived—such are the immortals Peng and Wang. Those who eat grain are intelligent but short-lived; those who eat nothing do not die and become spirits.
