All people, birds, beasts, and the myriad creatures, including the *zhen* insects, each have their means of life. *Zhen* insects refer to all small creatures with slender waists. Some are odd, some even; some fly, some walk—none know their true nature. Only those who comprehend the Dao can trace their origins.

Heaven is one, Earth is two, and Man is three. One is yang; two is yin. Humans are born of Heaven and Earth, hence called three. Three threes make nine, and nine nines make eighty-one. One governs the sun, and the sun’s number is ten—ten spans from *jia* to *gui*. The sun governs humanity, so humans are born after ten months. Eight nines are seventy-two, two governs the even, and the even supports the odd. The odd governs the celestial stems, the stems govern the moon, the moon governs horses, so horses are born after twelve months. Seven nines are sixty-three, three governs the Dipper, the Dipper governs dogs, so dogs are born after three months. Six nines are fifty-four, four governs the seasons, the seasons govern swine, so swine are born after four months. Five nines are forty-five, five governs sound, sound governs apes, so apes are born after five months. Four nines are thirty-six, six governs the pitch pipes, the pipes govern elk and deer, so elk and deer are born after six months. Three nines are twenty-seven, seven governs the stars, the stars govern tigers, so tigers are born after seven months. Two nines are eighteen, eight governs the wind, the wind governs insects, so insects transform after eight months.

Birds and fish are born of yin, and yin belongs to yang, so birds and fish are all born from eggs. Fish swim in water, birds fly in clouds, thus at the onset of winter, swallows and sparrows enter the sea and transform into clams. The myriad creatures are born, each of distinct kinds: silkworms eat but do not drink, cicadas drink but do not eat, mayflies neither drink nor eat. Those with shells and scales eat in summer and hibernate in winter. *Jie* refers to armor, such as turtles and softshell turtles; *lin* refers to scales, such as fish and dragons. Those that gnaw and swallow have eight orifices and are born from eggs—such are birds and fish. Those that chew and swallow have nine orifices and are born from wombs—such are four-legged creatures. Those with horns lack upper teeth; those without horns are fat in the front. *Gao* refers to pigs and such; *xiong* and *yuan* (bears and gibbons) are fat in the front. Those with horns are lean in the back—such are oxen, sheep, and elk. *Wu hou* means fat accumulates in the rear.

Those born by day resemble their fathers; those born by night resemble their mothers. Extreme yin gives birth to females; extreme yang gives birth to males. Bears and brown bears hibernate in seclusion; birds migrate with the seasons.

Thus, white waters suit jade; black waters suit whetstones—whetstones are fine stones. Blue waters suit jasper; red waters suit cinnabar; yellow waters suit gold; clear waters suit turtles. The muddy Fen River suits hemp; the harmonious Ji River suits wheat; the moderately turbid Yellow River suits beans; the light and swift Luo River suits millet; the strong Wei River suits glutinous millet; the heavy and calm Han River suits bamboo; the fertile and benevolent Yangtze suits rice. People of level lands are clever and suited to the five grains.

*Huainan Honglie Jie*, Scroll Seven, concludes.

*Huainan Honglie Jie*, Scroll Eight

**Topographical Instructions (Part Two)**

The east is where rivers and valleys converge, where the sun and moon rise. Its people have pointed heads and small skulls, high noses and wide mouths, sloping shoulders and a gait on tiptoe. Their orifices connect to the eyes, and their sinews and qi are bound there. Their complexion is green, governing the liver. They are tall, precocious, yet short-lived. Their lands suit wheat and abound in tigers and leopards.

The south is where yang qi accumulates, where heat and dampness reside. Its people are elongated in form with pointed crowns, wide mouths and gaping eyes. Their orifices connect to the ears, and their blood and vessels are bound there. Their complexion is red, governing the heart. They mature early but die young. Their lands suit rice and abound in rhinoceroses and elephants.

The west is where highlands and valleys emerge, where the sun and moon set. Its people have sloping foreheads and hunched backs, long necks and a stooped gait. Their orifices connect to the nose—their backs are like spines. Their skin and hide are bound there. Their complexion is white, governing the lungs. They are brave yet lack benevolence. Their lands suit glutinous millet and abound in yaks and rhinoceroses. *Mao* is pronounced similarly to the *mou* in *chóumóu*, requiring a sharp intonation.

The north is dark and obscure, where Heaven seals itself, where cold waters gather, and hibernating creatures lie concealed. Its people have contracted forms and short necks—*xi* is read like the *xie* in *xiegàn*. They have broad shoulders and low buttocks. Their orifices connect to the yin, and their bones and frame are bound there. Their complexion is black, governing the kidneys. They are dull-witted, beast-like, yet long-lived. *Chong* is read as when people say *yiran wuzhi*, meaning "blank and unknowing." The pronunciation requires pursed lips.

Their lands suit beans—*shu* means "beans." They abound in dogs and horses. As the tradition states: "North of Ji, the land where horses are born," referring to Yan and Dai as horse-producing regions. The center is where all four directions converge, where winds and qi circulate, and where rain and dew gather. Its people have broad faces and short jaws, fine beards but dislike obesity. Their orifices connect to the mouth, and their skin and flesh belong there. Their complexion is yellow, governing the stomach. They are wise and sagely, fond of governance. Their lands suit millet and abound in cattle, sheep, and the six livestock.

Wood overcomes earth, earth overcomes water, water overcomes fire, fire overcomes metal, and metal overcomes wood. Thus, millet sprouts in spring and withers in autumn—millet belongs to wood, thriving when wood prevails in spring and perishing when metal prevails in autumn. Beans sprout in summer and die in winter—beans belong to fire, thriving when fire prevails in summer and perishing when water prevails in winter. Wheat sprouts in autumn and dies in summer—wheat belongs to metal, thriving when metal prevails and perishing when fire prevails. Watercress sprouts in winter and dies in midsummer—watercress belongs to water, thriving when water prevails and perishing when earth prevails.

Wood flourishes when water ages, fire is born when wood ages, metal is imprisoned when fire ages, and earth dies when metal ages. Fire flourishes when wood ages, earth is born when fire ages, water is imprisoned when earth ages, and metal dies when water ages. Earth flourishes when fire ages, metal is born when earth ages, wood is imprisoned when metal ages, and water dies when wood ages. Metal flourishes when earth ages, water is born when metal ages, fire is imprisoned when water ages, and wood dies when fire ages. Water flourishes when metal ages, wood is born when water ages, earth is imprisoned when wood ages, and fire dies when earth ages.

Sound has five notes, with *gong* as their ruler. The five notes are *gong*, *shang*, *jiao*, *zhi*, and *yu*. *Gong* stands at the center, hence its primacy. Color has five hues, with yellow as their ruler. Taste has five transformations, with sweetness as their ruler. The five phases have earth as their ruler.

Thus, refining earth generates wood, refining wood generates fire, refining fire generates clouds—clouds arise from the qi of metal. Refining clouds generates water, and refining water returns to earth. Refining sweetness generates sourness, refining sourness generates acridity, refining acridity generates bitterness, refining bitterness generates saltiness, and refining saltiness returns to sweetness. *Lian* means "to refine" or "to cultivate."

Transforming *gong* generates *zhi*, transforming *zhi* generates *shang*, transforming *shang* generates *yu*, transforming *yu* generates *jiao*, and transforming *jiao* returns to *gong*. *Bian* means "to transform." Thus, water harmonizes with earth, earth harmonizes with fire, fire transforms metal, metal governs wood, and wood returns to earth. The five phases govern one another to

Kunlun lies to the southwest, while Huaqiu is situated to its southeast, also to the southeast of the Wujimin. There are found remnant jades, azure horses, *shirou* (a form of living flesh), and a people who do not speak. Yangtao, gancha, and ganhua—from which all fruits arise—are all wondrous things. That which grows on trees is called *guo* (fruit), while that which grows on the ground is called *luo* (gourd).

Heqiu lies to its northeast. A mound with four elevated sides is called a *qiu* (hill); it is where the *luan*-bird sings of its own accord and the phoenix dances of its own accord, hence its name, Heqiu. It is located to the northeast of the Wujimin.

The Three Mulberries, leafless, stand to its west. Kuafu and Dan’er dwell to its north. Dan’er have ears that hang down to their shoulders. *Dan* is pronounced like the *zhe* in *zheyi* (pleated robes). Some texts write it as *she*, meaning they grasp their ears with both hands, dwelling in the sea. Kuafu discarded his staff, which became Denglin. Kuafu was a divine beast who drank from the Yellow and Wei Rivers but found it insufficient; intending to drink from the Western Sea, he died of thirst en route. As recorded in the *Classic of Mountains and Seas*, his staff took root and grew into a forest. *Deng* signifies "wood." Another account says he was an immortal.

Kunwu Hill lies to the south. Kunwu was the grandson of Zhurong, ancestor of Chu, and son of Luzhong, serving as the Lord of Xia. The *Book of Songs* states, "Kunwu was Jie of Xia."

Xuanyuan Hill lies to the west. Xuanyuan was the title of the Yellow Emperor when he ruled all under heaven.

Wu Xian resides to its north. Wu Xian understood the Way of Heaven and discerned good and ill fortune.

Dengbao Mountain, Yang Valley, and Fusang lie to the east. Yang Valley is where the sun emerges. Fusang is located to the northeast of Dengbao Mountain.

You Song lies north of Buzhou. The elder daughter was Jian Di, and the younger was Jian Bi. You Song is the name of a state; Buzhou, the name of a mountain. *Song* is pronounced like the *song* in *Songgao* (Mount Song). The two sisters resided in the Jasper Terrace as consorts of Emperor Yi. Heaven sent a dark bird to descend at dawn; Jian Di swallowed it and conceived Qi, the Dark King, ancestor of the Yin. The *Book of Songs* says, "Heaven commanded the dark bird to descend and give birth to Shang."

The Queen Mother of the West dwells on the shores of the Flowing Sands. The *Treatise on Geography* states that the Western Jade Chamber lies northwest of Jincheng and Linqiang, beyond the frontier.

The Lemin and Nalü reside on the isles of the Weak River of Kunlun. That which can be inhabited amid water is called a *zhou* (isle).

Sanwei lies west of the Lemin. Sanwei is the name of a mountain in the western maple groves.

Xiaoming and Zhuguang dwell on the isles of the Yellow River, illuminating a thousand *li* in all directions. *Zhou* refers to that which is inhabited amid water. The light of Zhuguang illuminates a thousand *li*.

The Dragon Gate lies in the depths of the Yellow River. Tuanchi lies within Kunlun. The Dragon Gate is situated at the boundary of Fengyi and Xiayin in the Yellow River. Xuanyaobu, Buzhou—Xuanyaobu is the name of a river. Another account says it is a mountain.

Shenchi lies at the edge of the sea. The edge of the sea is a marsh.

Mengzhu lies in Pei. Mengzhu is a marsh of Song, located northeast of Suiyang.

Shaoshi and Taishi lie in Jizhou. Shaoshi and Taishi are alternate names for Mount Songgao in Yangcheng. *Ji* refers to Jizhou, the capital of Yao. *Ji* was the title for all under heaven.

The Torch Dragon dwells north of Yanmen, concealed by Mount Weiyu, where the sun is not seen. It is a divine being with the face of a human and the body of a dragon, but without feet. *Bi* means "to reach." Weiyu is the name of a mountain in the north. Another account says the dragon holds a torch in its mouth to illuminate the Great Yin; its body stretches a thousand *li*, its gaze brings daylight, its closing eyes bring night, its breath brings winter, and its exhalation brings summer.

Houji’s tomb lies west of the Jianmu Tree. Jianmu stands in Du Guang. Du Guang is the name of a marsh in the south. Some texts speak of its mountain, others of its marsh. *Long* means "tomb" or "home." The people there die and revive; some become half-fish, dwelling in between. In the south, the dead revive or transform into fish amid the Jianmu Tree in Du Guang.

Liuhuang and the Womin dwell three hundred *li* to its north, while the Dog Kingdom lies to its east.

The Thunder Marsh has a spirit with the body of a dragon and the head of a human, who drums its belly in play. The Thunder Marsh is a great marsh. *Gu* means "to strike," and *xi* means "to frolic." The *Treatise on Geography* states that the *Yu Gong*’s Thunder Marsh lies northwest of Chengyang in Jiyin; Chengyang contains the tomb of Yao.

The Yangtze rises from Mount Min, flowing east to cross the Han before entering the sea. It turns left to flow north, reaching the north of Kaimu, then turns right to flow east to the eastern extremity. Mount Min lies west of Shu’s Jishui. *Jue* means "to cross." Kaimu is the name of a mountain in the Eastern Sea.

The Yellow River rises from Jishi. The Sui rises from Mount Jing. The Yellow River’s source is in Kunlun, flowing underground for three thousand *li* before Yu dredged and channeled it, hence its emergence at Jishi. Mount Jishi lies southwest of Heguan County in Jincheng Commandery. Mount Jing is part of the northern range in the *Yu Gong*; it lies south of Huaide County in Zuo Fengyi, where the Jingpiao Plain marks the irrigation of Yongzhou.

The Huai rises from Mount Tongbo. The Sui rises from Mount Yu. Mount Tongbo lies in Shangdang. The Clear Zhang River rises from Jieli. The Turbid Zhang River rises from Fabao. Mount Jieli lies in the Shangdang region. Mount Fabao, also called Mount Luku, lies in Changzi of Shangdang. The two Zhang Rivers converge, flowing through Wei Commandery into the Clear River.

The Ji rises from Mount Wangwu.

The Shi, Si, and Yi Rivers rise from Mount Tai, Mount Tai, and Mount Shu. Mount Wangwu lies northeast of Yuan County in Hedong. The Shi, Si, and Yi are all names of rivers; Mount Tai, Mount Tai, and Mount Shu are all names of mountains. Their precise locations remain unknown.

The Luo rises from Mount Lie. Mount Lie lies among the northwestern tribes of Beidi; the Luo flows southeast into the Wei. As the *Book of Songs* says: *"Gazing upon that Luo—how vast its waters!"*

The Wen rises from Mount Fuqi, flowing to join the Ji. Mount Fuqi lies east of Zhuxu County in Beihai.

The Han rises from Mount Boyang. The Jing rises from Mount Boluo. Mount Boyang lies on the western border of Hanyang County, where the Han River originates, flowing south into Guanghan, then southeast into Yongzhou to join the Yangtze. Mount Boluo, also called Mount Jitou, lies west of Linjing County in Anding; it is the source of the Jing River as recorded in the *Tribute of Yu*, which flows southeast to join the Wei at Yangling.

The Wei rises from Mount Bird-and-Mouse-Same-Hole. The Yi rises from Mount Shangwei. Mount Bird-and-Mouse-Same-Hole lies southwest of Shouyang in Longxi, directly where the Wei River emerges, flowing east to join the Li, then into the Yellow River—a river of Yongzhou. Mount Shangwei is a mountain name; its location remains unknown.

The Luo rises from Mount Bear’s Ear. Mount Bear’s Ear lies northwest of the capital’s Zhivei. The Jun rises from Mount Huaqiao. The Wei rises from Mount Overturned Boat. The Fen rises from Mount Yan Jing. Yan Jing is a mountain name; it lies in Fenyang of Taiyuan, where the Fen River originates, flowing southwest to Fenyang—a marsh of Jizhou.

The Ren rises from Mount Fen Xiong. The Zi rises from Mount Mu Yi. Mu Yi is a mountain name. The Dan River rises from Mount Gao Chu. Gao Chu, also called Mount Zhong Ling, lies in Shangluo of Jingzhao, where the Dan River originates, flowing east to Jun to join the Mian. The Gu rises from Mount Jiao. The Hao rises from Mount Xian Yu. The Liang rises from Mount Mao Lu and Mount Stone Beam. Xian Yu, Mao Lu, and Stone Beam are all mountain names.

The Ru rises from Mount Meng. The Qi rises from Mount Da Hao. Mount Meng, also called Mount Gao Ling, lies in Dingling County of Runan, where the Ru River originates, flowing southeast to Xincai to join the Huai. Mount Da Hao lies north of Qiong County in Henan, or some say west of Linlü.

The Jin rises from Mount Dragon and Mount Jie Ge, which merge at Mount Feng Yang. Jie Ge is another name for He. Mount Dragon lies northwest of Jinyang, where the Jin River originates, flowing east to join the Fen. Feng Yang is a mountain name.

The Liao rises from Mount Whetstone. The Fu rises from Mount Jing. Whetstone is a mountain name, lying beyond the frontier, where the Liao River originates, flowing south into the sea. Mount Jing lies southwest of Handan; the Fu River originates there, flowing south into the Zhang. Its source bubbles and surges like boiling water in a cauldron, hence the name Fu, now called Fukou.

The Qi rises from Mount Stone Bridge. The Hu Chi rises from Mount Lu Ping. Lu Ping is a mountain name. The Hu Chi is a marsh of Bingzhou—what is now the Hutuo River in Hanchang of Zhongshan.

The Muddy Abyss rises from Mount Man. Man is pronounced like the surname Man. The Wei Shi flows north from Yan. It flows through northern Yan, which lies beyond the frontier.

Zhu Ji and She Ti are where the Branch Wind arises. Zhu Ji and She Ti are names of celestial spirits. Gen corresponds to the Branch Wind. Tong Shi is where the Bright Multitude Wind arises. Tong Shi is a celestial spirit. The Bright Multitude Wind arises from the Zhen trigram.

Chi Fen Ruo is where the Clear Bright Wind arises. Chi Fen Ruo is a celestial spirit. Xun corresponds to the Clear Bright Wind. Gong Gong is where the Scenic Wind arises. Gong Gong is a celestial spirit with a human face and serpent’s body. Li corresponds to the Scenic Wind.

Zhu Bi is where the Cool Wind arises. Zhu Bi is a celestial spirit. Kun corresponds to the Cool Wind. Gao Ji is where the Gate-Opening Wind arises. Gao Ji is a celestial spirit. Dui corresponds to the Gate-Opening Wind.

Yu Qiang is where the Not-Surrounding Wind arises. Yu Qiang is a celestial spirit. Qian corresponds to the Not-Surrounding Wind. Qiong Qi is where the Vast Desolation Wind arises. Qiong Qi is a celestial spirit; in the northern regions, it rides a rain dragon, its form like a tiger. Kan corresponds to the Vast Desolation Wind.

Tu Sheng was the first of the Sea People. Tu was the ancestor of humankind. The Sea People gave birth to Ruo Jun. Jun is pronounced like the lower *qun* in *qun*. Ruo Jun gave birth to the sage, the sage to the common people, and all those with form were born of the common people.

Yu Jia gave birth to the Flying Dragon. The Flying Dragon and Yu Jia were the first of winged creatures. The Flying Dragon had wings. The Flying Dragon gave birth to the phoenix, the phoenix to the luan bird, the luan bird to common birds, and all winged creatures were born of common birds.

Mao Du gave birth to the Responding Dragon. The Responding Dragon gave birth to the Jian Horse, the Jian Horse to the qilin, the qilin to common beasts, and all furred creatures were born of common beasts.

Jie Lin gave birth to the Jiao Dragon. Jie Lin was the first of scaled creatures. The Jiao Dragon was a dragon with scales and armor. The Jiao Dragon gave birth to the Kun Geng, the Kun Geng to the Jian Xie, the Jian Xie to common fish, and all scaled creatures were born of common fish.

Jie Tan gave birth to the First Dragon. Jie refers to a state, the first of turtles. Tan is pronounced like the state of Tan. The First Dragon gave birth to the Dark Soft-shelled Turtle, the Dark Soft-shelled Turtle to the Spirit Turtle, the Spirit Turtle to common turtles, and all shelled creatures were born of common turtles.

Warm Dampness gave birth to Form. Warm is also read as *mo*, describing the appearance of wind-dried dryness. Warm Dampness arose from Fur Wind, Fur Wind from Damp Mystery, Damp Mystery from Feather Wind, Feather Wind from Warm Shell, Warm Shell from Scale Membrane, and Scale Membrane gave birth to Warm Shell.

The five kinds intermingled and flourished externally, taking shape and multiplying. *Xiao* means resemblance—each succeeding form resembled the last and multiplied.

It is said that Feng gave birth to Yang E. Feng was the first of trees. Yang E gave birth to Qiao Ru, Qiao Ru to Dry Wood, Dry Wood to common trees, and all root-uprooted trees were born of common trees.

Gen Ba gave birth to Cheng Ruo. Gen Ba was the first of root-born grasses. Cheng Ruo gave birth to Dark Jade, Dark Jade to Sweet Springs, Sweet Springs to Huang Gu, Huang Gu to common grasses, and all root-bound grasses were born of common grasses.

Hai Lü gave birth to the Coiled Dragon. Hai Lü was the first of floating grasses. The Coiled Dragon was a wandering dragon, a swan-goose. As the *Book of Songs* says, “In the sun is the wandering dragon”—*qu* is a scribal error for *you*.

The Coiled Dragon gave birth to Rong Hua. Rong Hua was the lotus flower. Rong Hua gave birth to Piao, Piao to floating duckweed, floating duckweed to floating grasses, and all floating, rootless plants were born of floating duckweed.

The qi of the central earth ascends to the Dusty Heaven. After five hundred years, the Dusty Heaven gives birth to Que. After five hundred years, Que gives birth to Yellow Dust. After five hundred years, Yellow Dust gives birth to Yellow Hong. After five hundred years, Yellow Hong gives birth to Yellow Gold. Yellow Gold is a stone name. The central number is five, hence five hundred years for each transformation. Hong is mercury.

After a thousand years, Yellow Gold gives birth to the Yellow Dragon, which retreats into hiding and gives birth to the Yellow Spring. The dust of the Yellow Spring rises to become Yellow Clouds. Yin and yang press together to form thunder, their clash producing lightning. The upper descends to the lower, flowing water seeks passage, and all converge in the Yellow Sea.

The Yellow Sea is the central sea. The qi of the eastern earth ascends to the Clear Heaven. After eight hundred years, the Clear Heaven gives birth to Green Zeng. After eight hundred years, Green Zeng gives birth to Green Hong. After eight hundred years, Green Hong gives birth to Green Gold. After eight hundred years, Green Gold gives birth to the Green Dragon. The east corresponds to wood, its color is green, and its number is eight, hence eight hundred years for each transformation. The Green Dragon retreats into hiding and gives birth to the Clear Spring. The dust of the Clear Spring rises to become Green Clouds. Yin and yang press together to form cloud thunder, their clash producing lightning. The upper descends to the lower, flowing water seeks passage, and all converge in the Green Sea, the eastern sea.

The qi of the southern earth ascends to the Red Heaven. After seven hundred years, the Red Heaven gives birth to Red Dan. After seven hundred years, Red Dan gives birth to Red Hong. After seven hundred years, Red Hong gives birth to Red Gold. The south corresponds to fire, its color is red, and its number is seven, hence seven hundred years for each transformation. After a thousand years, Red Gold gives birth to the Red Dragon. The Red Dragon retreats into hiding and gives birth to the Red Spring. The dust of the Red Spring rises to become Red Clouds. Yin and yang press together to form thunder, their clash producing lightning. The upper descends to the lower, flowing water seeks passage, and all converge in the Red Sea, the southern sea.

The qi of the western earth ascends to the White Heaven. After nine hundred years, the White Heaven gives birth to White Yu. After nine hundred years, White Yu gives birth to White Hong. After nine hundred years, White Hong gives birth to White Gold. White Gold is White Yu, a kind of stone. White Hong is mercury. The west corresponds to metal, its color is white, and its number is nine, hence nine hundred years for each transformation. After a thousand years, White Gold gives birth to the White Dragon. The White Dragon retreats into hiding and gives birth to the White Spring. The dust of the White Spring rises to become White Clouds. Yin and yang press together to form thunder, their clash producing lightning. The upper descends to the lower, flowing water seeks passage, and all converge in the White Sea, the western sea.

The qi of the northern earth ascends to the Dark Heaven. After six hundred years, the Dark Heaven gives birth to Dark Di, a black stone. After six hundred years, Dark Di gives birth to Dark Hong. After six hundred years, Dark Hong gives birth to Dark Gold. The north corresponds to water, its color is black, and its number is six, hence six hundred years for each transformation. After a thousand years, Dark Gold gives birth to the Dark Dragon. The Dark Dragon retreats into hiding and gives birth to the Dark Spring. The dust of the Dark Spring rises to become Dark Clouds. Yin and yang press together to form thunder, their clash producing lightning. The upper descends to the lower, flowing water seeks passage, and all converge in the Dark Sea, the northern sea.

The upper descends to the lower, and the heavenly qi once again flows down from the heavens.

All waters of the Dao’s flow converge into the sea.

*Huainan Honglie Jie*, Scroll Eight, concludes.

*Huainan Honglie Jie*, Scroll Nine
Recorded by the Grand Commandant and Libationer, Your Servant Xu Shen

**Shi Ze Xun (On the Standards of the Seasons), Part One**

*Shi* means "standard"—the constant laws of the four seasons, cold and heat, and the twelve months. Hence it is called *Shi Ze*, and the chapter is titled accordingly.

In the first month of spring, the *Zhaoyao* points to *yin*.
*Zhaoyao* refers to the Dipper’s handle.

At dusk, *Shen* culminates; at dawn, *Wei* culminates.
*Shen* is the western White Tiger constellation, which at dusk stands at the meridian in the south.
*Wei* is the eastern Azure Dragon constellation, which at dawn stands at the meridian in the south.

Its position is the east; its days are *jia-yi*. The flourishing power resides in wood, and the spirit of Taihao governs the east.
*Jia-yi* are the days of wood. The flourishing power resides in wood, for wood reigns in the east.

Its creatures are scaled; its tone is *jue*. The east is Lesser Yang, and beings depart from Great Yin.
*Jia* disperses, and dispersion gives rise to scales. The scaled creatures are led by the dragon.
*Jue* is wood, whose position is in the east.

The pitch standard is *Tai Cou*; its number is eight.
The *lü* are the notes of the pitch pipes. As Yin wanes and Yang arises, the myriad things sprout from the earth in *Tai Cou*, hence the name. Its number is eight: in the five phases, wood is third, hence eight.

Its flavor is sour; its scent is rank.
Wood’s flavor is sour. *Suan* ("sour") means "to bore," for the myriad things bore through the earth to emerge.
*Shan* is the rank scent of wood.

Its sacrifice is at the door; the offering precedes the spleen.
Hibernating creatures first stir and emerge through the door, hence the sacrifice at the door. The spleen belongs to earth; when arranging the sacrificial vessels, the spleen is placed foremost. Spring wood overcomes earth, indicating the regular consumption of what it conquers. Another interpretation: the spleen belongs to wood, which employs its own organ.

The east wind thaws the ice; hibernating creatures begin to stir and revive.
The east is wood, mother of fire. As the qi warms, the east wind melts the frozen ice.
*Zhen* means "to move"; *su* means "to live."

Fish rise bearing ice on their backs; otters sacrifice fish.
In this month, carp respond to the Yang and stir, rising with ice on their backs. Otters are aquatic mammals. In this month, otters arrange carp at the water’s edge on all sides, calling it the "sacrifice of fish."

The wild geese head north.
This is the seasonal sign: geese come from Pengli, pass north through Zhou and Luo, and reach Hanzhong to lay eggs and hatch their young.

The Son of Heaven wears azure robes, rides a blue-green dragon, and carries azure jade.
According to the *Zhou Rituals*, a horse seven *chi* or taller is called a "dragon."
He bears azure jade and raises a green banner.
*Fu* means "to wear." The bear and tiger are emblems of the banner.

He eats wheat and mutton.
Wheat is the grain of metal; mutton is the livestock of earth. In this month, metal and earth are aged, so he eats what they conquer. He first eats wheat, making it the staple.

He drinks the water of the eight winds and cooks with fire from *qi* wood.
He collects dew from a bronze basin—water blown by the winds of the eight directions—and drinks it. He cooks with fire kindled from *qi* wood.
*Qi* is read as *gaibei* ("all-encompassing").

The palace ladies of the Eastern Palace wear green, don green silks, and play the zither and se.
The zither and *se* are of wood. As wood reigns in spring, they play them.

Their weapon is the spear.
The spear has a sharp point, resembling the myriad things boring through the earth to emerge.

Their livestock is the sheep.
Sheep belong to earth, mother of wood, hence they are raised.

They hold court at the left hall of Qingshang to issue the spring decrees.
On the first day of the month, the Son of Heaven faces east in the left hall of Qingshang to greet the sun. The east-facing hall is called Qingshang; the northern chamber is called the "left decree." *Jin* means "to separate." The spring decrees are those of leniency and harmony.

They spread virtue and bestow kindness, enact rewards, and reduce corvée and taxes.
They spread the Yang virtue and bestow gentle kindness. *Qing* means "goodness"; *shang* means "to grant." They lessen the labor of corvée and lighten taxes.

On the day of *Lichun*, the Son of Heaven personally leads the Three Dukes, the Nine Ministers, and the great officers to welcome the year in the eastern suburbs.
*Shuai* means "to lead." To "welcome the year" is to [meet] spring. The eastern suburbs lie eight *li* beyond the outer walls.

They repair the altars and arrange the sacrificial positions, present jade and silk to pray to the spirits, and use male animals as sacrificial victims.
The "sacrificial positions" are the altars and screened enclosures. *Bi* are jade tablets and silk. To "pray to the spirits" is to seek blessings. Spirits of humans are called *gui*; spirits of heaven are called *shen*. Male victims are used to emphasize purity.

They forbid the felling of trees.
In spring, wood reigns and should be nurtured, hence the prohibition.

They forbid the overturning of nests, the killing of pregnant animals or fledglings, the taking of fawns or eggs.
"Pregnant animals" are those carrying young not yet born. The young of elk are called *yao*; those of deer are called *min*. Eggs not yet hatched are also forbidden to be taken, to foster the flourishing of the myriad things.

They forbid the assembling of crowds or the building of city walls, and order the burial of exposed bones.
They forbid the gathering of large crowds or the construction of city walls, which would hinder agricultural work. *Ge* are bones with flesh; they are to be covered and buried to respect the vitality of life.

If in the first month of spring the summer decrees are followed, then wind and rain will not be timely, grasses and trees will wither early, and the state will be filled with fear.
In the first month of spring, the power of wood is in effect. If one follows the fiery energy of summer above, grasses and trees will wither prematurely, and the state will be gripped by terror.

If the autumn decrees are followed, then the people will suffer great epidemics, violent winds and torrential rains will arrive together, and weeds and brambles will flourish.
Spring is mild and benevolent, but the autumn decrees are those of the metal axe. If the qi are not harmonious, the people will suffer epidemics, and winds and rains will come in haste. Hence weeds and brambles—coarse and foul grasses—will flourish.

If the winter decrees are followed, then floods will cause ruin, frost and great hail will strike, and the first harvests will not be gathered.
In spring, the Yang qi should rise, but if the Yin qi of winter prevails, floods will wreak havoc, frost and hail will fall heavily, and the early crops will fail.

Winter is Yin, and the springs surge forth—if spring’s decrees are enacted then, ruin will follow. The qi are not harmonious, hence great hail and heavy frost fall, and the crops do not ripen.

In the first month, the office of *Sikong* presides, and its tree is the poplar. The *Sikong* governs earth, and in spring the earth receives the fine harvest, hence the office of *Sikong*. The *Erya* states: "The poplar is the *puliuliu*." The poplar flourishes in spring’s light, hence its tree is the poplar.

In the second spring month, the *Zhaoyao* star points to *mao*, the *Hu* star culminates at dusk, and the *Jianxing* star culminates at dawn. The *Hu* star lies south of *Yugui*; this month, it culminates in the south at dusk. The *Jianxing* star lies above the Dipper; this month, it culminates in the south at dawn. Its position is the east, its days are *jia* and *yi*, its creatures are scaled, its tone is *jiao*, and its pitch is *Jiazhong*. This month, the myriad things leave Yin and embrace Yang, gathering upon the earth to grow—hence it is called *Jiazhong*. Its number is eight, its flavor is sour, its scent is rank, its sacrifice is at the door, and the spleen is offered first.

The rains begin, and the peach and plum trees first blossom. From winter’s ice and snow to this spring’s equinox and grain rains, hence it is called "the rains begin," and the peach and plum trees all bloom. The *canggeng* sings, and the hawk transforms into the turtledove. The *canggeng*—the *Erya* calls it *shanggeng* or *lihuang*, the Chu sparrow. The Qi people call it *bozhu*, the Qin call it *huangliuli*, and in You and Ji it is called the yellow bird. Another account says it is the woodpecker, which sings in this month. The hawk transforms into the turtledove, its beak straight and no longer predatory. The turtledove is the cuckoo.

The Son of Heaven wears blue-green robes, rides a green dragon chariot, adorns himself with azure jade, raises a blue-green banner, eats wheat and mutton, drinks the water of the eight winds, and cooks with fire drilled from wood. The women of the Eastern Palace wear blue-green, dress in blue-green hues, and play the zither and se. Their weapon is the spear, their livestock is the sheep, and they hold court in the *Qingyang* ancestral temple. The ancestral temple faces east, its hall at the center.

He commands his officials to inspect the prisons, remove fetters and shackles, forbid flogging and torture, and halt litigation. The prison is the husband’s chamber. To inspect it is to pardon minor offenses. That which binds the feet is called *zhi*, and that which binds the hands is called *gu*. To forbid flogging and torture is to say they are not used. *Zhi* means to prohibit. Nurture the young, care for the orphaned and solitary, and ensure the sprouts flourish. Follow the spring Yang to foster the young and make them abundant. One without a father is called orphaned, and one without children is called solitary. To care for them is to honor the Yang qi. Thus, if grasses and trees do not sprout, it is because [the Yang qi is not revered].

Choose an auspicious day and command the people to perform the *she* sacrifice. *Yuan* is the chief of virtues. The days run from *jia* to *gui*. The *she* is for praying on behalf of the people; to avoid inauspicious days, one speaks of choosing an auspicious one.

In this month, day and night are equal, thunder first sounds, and hibernating creatures all stir and revive. *Fen* means equal. In winter, Yin is closed and firm, and thunder lies dormant; this month, Yang rises, and thunder first sounds. *Xian* means all. *Dongsu* means to live. Three days before the thunder, ring the bell to announce to the people: "Thunder is about to sound." The *duo* is a wooden bell with a metal mouth and wooden tongue, used to proclaim to the myriad people. *Zhao* means a great number. *Qie* means "will."

Those who fail to restrain their bearing and conduct will bear incomplete children, and misfortune and disaster will surely follow. Those who couple amid thunder and lightning will bear children afflicted with muteness, deafness, seminal incontinence, idiocy, or madness—hence it is said that incompleteness brings misfortune and disaster.

Command the officials to standardize the markets, unify measures and weights, calibrate scales and stone weights, and level pecks and steelyards. *Du* refers to lengths—*zhang* and *chi*. *Liang* refers to volumes—*fu* and *zhong*. *Jun* means "equal." *Hengshi* refers to weighing stones, with one hundred twenty *jin* making one *shi*. *Jiao* means "level." *Doucheng* are measuring vessels. Rectify weights and measures: *duan* means "correct," and *gai* means "level."

Do not drain rivers and marshes, do not dredge ponds and pools, and do not burn mountains and forests, for these would prematurely exhaust creatures and annihilate species. Do not undertake great affairs that would hinder agricultural work. Great affairs refer to military campaigns and punitive expeditions, which harm the people’s farming.

In sacrifices, do not use animal victims but instead offer *gui* jades and *bi* disks, substituting hides and silk. This month values life and growth, so animal victims are not used. *Geng* means "substitute," replacing victims with *gui*, *bi*, hides, and silk. *Pi* refers to deer hides, and *bi* refers to black and reddish-brown bundled silk. As the *Liji* states, "Silk, jade, and hides are presented to announce at the ancestral temple."

If autumnal ordinances are enacted in mid-spring, the state will suffer great floods, cold air will converge in abundance, and hostile armies will invade. Mid-spring is the height of Yang; Yang qi fosters growth, yet if autumn’s punitive and destructive ordinances are enacted, cold air will rush in, and enemy forces will invade the state. If winter ordinances are enacted, Yang qi will not prevail, wheat will fail to ripen, and the people will turn on one another. Enacting winter’s Yin ordinances in mid-spring causes Yin to overpower Yang; thus Yang fails, wheat does not mature, and the people become predatory. If summer ordinances are enacted, the state will suffer severe drought, warmth will arrive prematurely, and insects and borers will cause harm. Enacting summer’s extreme Yang ordinances in mid-spring brings great drought, and excessive heat causes warmth to peak. Yang generates Yin, so insects and borers emerge to wreak havoc. *Ming* refers to insects that eat the heart.

In the second month, the Granary Official oversees the planting of apricot trees. The second month sees the start of farming and grain sowing, hence the Granary Official’s role. The apricot has a cavity at its center, symbolizing Yin’s dissemination above—thus apricot trees are planted.

In the third month of spring, the *zhaoyao* star points to *chen*, the Seven Stars culminate at dusk, and the Herdboy culminates at dawn. The Seven Stars are the southern Vermilion Bird’s lodgings; this month, they culminate in the south at dusk. The Herdboy is the northern Dark Warrior’s lodging; this month, it culminates in the south at dawn. Its position is the east, its days are *jia* and *yi*, its creatures are scaled, its note is *jue*, and its pitch pipe is *Guxi*. *Gu* means "old," and *xi* means "new." This month, Yang nurtures life, casting off the old and embracing the new—hence *Guxi*. Its number is eight, its flavor is sour, its scent is rank, its sacrifice is at the door, and the spleen is first offered. The paulownia begins to bloom, and the field mouse transforms into the *ru* bird. The paulownia is the *wutong*; this month, it blooms. The field mouse is the mole rat. The *ru* is the quail; in Qing and Xu, it is called *mou*, while in You and Ji, it is called *chun*. The rainbow first appears, and duckweed begins to grow. The rainbow is the *didi*. As the *Odes* says, "The *didi* appears in the east—none dare point at it." Duckweed is aquatic algae; this month, it begins to grow.

The Son of Heaven wears azure robes, rides a blue-green dragon chariot, adorns himself with azure jade, raises a blue-green banner, eats wheat and mutton, drinks the Eight Winds’ water, and cooks with fire from *qi* kindling. The Eastern Palace’s consorts wear azure, dress in azure hues, and play zithers and sevens-stringed instruments. Their weapon is the spear, their sacrificial animal is the sheep, and they hold court in the eastern Bright Hall’s right chamber. The hall faces east, with the southern chamber at its head—hence the "right chamber."

The Boat Overseer overturns the boat five times, inspecting it five times, before presenting it to the Son of Heaven. The Boat Overseer is the official in charge of boats. This month, the Son of Heaven will board a boat to fish, so it is overturned and examined repeatedly to check for leaks. Five overturnings and five inspections show utmost caution. The Son of Heaven first boards the boat in safety, offers sturgeon at the temple and sleeping chambers, and prays for wheat’s fruition. *Niao* means "peaceful"; from winter until now, he boards the boat in safety—hence "first boarding." *Jian* means "present." The sturgeon resembles a carp but is larger. This fish is presented at the temple and sleeping chambers to beseech ancestral spirits for wheat’s fruition. The front is the temple, and the rear is the sleeping chamber. As the *Odes* says, "Temple and sleeping chamber, grand and connected."

This month, vital qi flourishes, and Yang qi disperses—*faxie* means "to disseminate." All curled creatures emerge, and all sprouts reach forth; nothing should be repressed. The Son of Heaven commands officials to open granaries and storehouses, aid the poor and destitute, and relieve the exhausted and cut off. Those without wealth are called poor, while the widowed, orphaned, childless, and solitary are called destitute. *Zhen* means "to rescue." Open treasuries and bring forth silk and cloth to send envoys to the feudal lords. Treasuries store silk and cloth; envoys are sent to pay respects to the feudal lords. Summon renowned scholars and honor the worthy. Those with renowned virtue and great worth are summoned and honored, to be employed in governance.

Command the Minister of Works: as timely rains approach, water below rises and mist above ascends. Patrol the capital and its outskirts, surveying the plains and fields. The Minister of Works oversees water and earth. This month, as water below rises and mist above ascends, there is concern for flooding that could harm the five grains—hence patrolling and surveying. Broad and flat lands are called *yuan*, and the outskirts are called *ye*. Repair and reinforce dikes, dredge and clear ditches, and open roads, beginning in the capital and ending at the borders.

End hunting with nets and arrows, and remove snares, traps, and poisonous drugs from the nine gates. *Bi* are covering nets, and *yi* are arrows with cords. As the *Odes* says, "Shoot teal and wild geese." *Ju* are rabbit nets. As the *Odes* says, "Swiftly the rabbit nets are set." *Bi* and *luo* are bird nets. As the *Odes* says, "Mandarin ducks in the *fu*—net them, snare them." *Fu* is the general term for deer nets.

The Son of Heaven’s city has twelve gates. The three eastern gates are where the royal *qi* resides, and from these gates, poisonous drugs for slaying beasts must not be allowed to exit—this is to uphold life and nurture. Though the remaining nine gates permit their passage, they are expressly forbidden, as if they were not to leave at all.

Wild wardens are then commanded not to fell mulberry or *tuo* trees. Mulberry and *tuo* both serve to rear silkworms, hence the people are forbidden to cut them down. The turtledove spreads its wings, and the shrike descends upon the mulberry. The turtledove is the bird that swiftly beats its wings, soaring straight upward into the clouds. The *zai shi* is the shrike. As the *Odes* says, *"The shrike is in the mulberry; its young are in the plum."*

Prepare curved baskets and square-bottomed containers. *Pu* means "to hold," and three turns make a *pu*. *Pu* is pronounced like the word for "mountain ridge" in Nanyang speech. *Qu* means "thin," and in Qing and Xu, it is called *qu*. A round-bottomed vessel is called a *ju*, and a square-bottomed one a *kuang*—both are tools for receiving mulberry leaves.

The empress and consorts purify themselves, face east, and personally pluck mulberry leaves, overseeing the women’s work and encouraging sericulture. The Five Armories are ordered to inspect metals, iron, hides, sinews, horns, arrow shafts, tallow, glue, cinnabar, and lacquer—none may be of poor quality.

A propitious day in the last third of the month is chosen to hold a grand musical assembly and foster joy. Music serves to transform customs and shift mores, so a fortunate day is selected for this great gathering to bring about harmony and delight.

Then the finest bulls and stallions are assembled, and mares are released to pasture. *Te* bulls are prime bulls. *Teng* horses are spirited colts that kick up their hooves and excel at leading herds. They are allowed to roam freely among the mares in the grazing lands. *Te* is pronounced like *lei* in "creeping vine."

The state performs the *nuo* exorcism: at the nine gates, dogs are dismembered to dispel inauspicious influences and complete the *qi* of spring. *San* means "to disperse." In the secluded corners and dim recesses of palaces and chambers, drums are beaten and loud cries raised to drive out ill fortune—this is akin to the present-day practice of expelling pestilence. The nine gates refer to the three gates on each of the three sides. Dismembering dogs exhausts the yang *qi*, hence it is said to complete the *qi* of spring.

If the ordinances of this month are followed, sweet rain will fall for thirty days.

If in late spring the ordinances of winter are enacted, cold *qi* will arise at times, grasses and trees will wither, and the state will face great terror. Late spring governed by winter’s killing cold *qi* causes intermittent cold snaps. When plants shed their leaves prematurely, it is called *su*. If the ordinances of summer are enacted, the people will suffer many epidemics, timely rains will not fall, and the hills and mounds will yield no harvest. Late spring governed by summer’s scorching yang *qi* disrupts harmony, leading to disease among the people and drought, so plants fail to mature. If the ordinances of autumn are enacted, the skies will be heavy with gloom, excessive rains will fall prematurely, and warfare will erupt. Autumn is the season when metal *qi* prevails, and metal is the mother of water. When autumn’s *qi* is enacted in late spring, it generates dense yin and excessive rain. Metal governs weapons and war, hence conflicts arise.

In the third month, the office of the district is established, and its tree is the plum. In the third month, the populace’s households are registered, hence the office of the district. The plum, like the apricot, has a pit, and its late ripening places it in the third month.

In the first month of summer, the Big Dipper’s handle points to *si*. At dusk, the Wings constellation culminates, and at dawn, the Woman constellation culminates. The Wings are a constellation of the Vermilion Bird of the south, and this month at dusk, it culminates in the south. The Woman, also called the Serving Maid, is a constellation of the Dark Warrior of the north, and this month at dawn, it culminates in the south.

Its position is the south, its days are *bing* and *ding*, and its supreme virtue resides in fire. The spirit of the Blazing Emperor governs the south. *Bing* and *ding* are fire days. Supreme virtue resides in fire, and fire rules the south. Its creatures are feathered, its note is *zhi*, and flourishing yang prevails as scales disperse. Feathered creatures are led by the phoenix. The *zhi* note corresponds to fire. The pitch pipe *Zhonglü* is attuned, and its number is seven. This month, yang disperses externally while yin solidifies within, thus traveling yang achieves success—hence it is called *Zhonglü*. Its number is seven: the generating number is five, and fire is the second, hence seven.

Its flavor is bitter, its scent is scorched. Fire’s flavor is bitter. Scorched refers to the charred aroma of fire. Its sacrifice is the hearth, and the first offering is the sacrificial meat. Zhu Rong and Wu Hui served as Fire Ministers to Gao Xin, and upon death, they became fire spirits, their worship entrusted to the hearth. As fire rules this month, the hearth is sacrificed to. The sacrificial meat is the sister’s portion. The meat used in sacrifice is first that which overcomes. Alternatively, it is said to be the sister’s fire, using its own store.

Mole crickets chirp, toads emerge, and earthworms appear. The mole cricket is the mole cricket. The *guo* is the toad. In the fourth month, yin *qi* begins to stir below, so these creatures respond by calling. The *qiu yan* is the earthworm.

The royal gourd grows, and sow thistle blooms. The royal gourd is the *guālóu*. The *Erya* states, "That which bears fruit without flowering is called *xiu*." Sow thistle is said to bloom properly. The Son of Heaven wears red robes, rides a red steed, adorns himself with red jade, and raises a red banner—this accords with the virtue of fire. He eats beans and chicken. Beans are those with intact skins. Chicken and beans are both nurtured by fire. He drinks water from the eight winds, cooks with *zhe* wood and fire drilled from it. In the Southern Palace, the imperial consorts wear red, dress in red hues, and play reed pipes and *sheng* flutes. As fire rules the south, they reside in the Southern Palace. Reed pipes and *sheng* flutes are hollow, symbolizing yang, hence they are played. His weapon is the halberd. The halberd has branches and a shaft, symbolizing yang’s dispersion. Alternatively, the halberd may be written as the crossbow. His animal is the chicken.

At dawn, he holds court in the left chamber of the Bright Hall to issue the summer ordinances. The hall faces south, aligning with flourishing yang—hence it is called the Bright Hall. The eastern chamber is called the left chamber. Conducting affairs in this chamber enacts the ordinances of this month. The chicken is a feathered creature, a symbol of yang—hence it is raised.

On the day of the summer solstice, the Son of Heaven personally leads the Three Dukes, the Nine Ministers, and the great officers to welcome the year at the southern suburbs. Welcoming the year means welcoming summer. The southern suburbs lie seven *li* from the city. Upon returning, he bestows rewards, enfeoffs the feudal lords, refines rites and music, and feasts his attendants.

Upon returning from the southern suburbs, he rewards those with merit and enfeoffs them with land and titles. As the tradition states: "Rewards are bestowed in spring and summer, punishments in autumn and winter." He refines rites and music to pacify superiors and govern the people, transforming customs and mores. His attendants are his close ministers.

He commands the Grand Commandant to commend the outstanding, select the worthy and good, and recommend the filial and fraternal. The Grand Commandant is a ministerial office. *Ming* means to order; *zan* means to proclaim. Those with talent surpassing a thousand are called outstanding. Selecting the worthy, good, filial, and fraternal to employ them is not the Grand Commandant’s usual duty, hence he is specially commanded.

He confers ranks and bestows emoluments to assist Heaven’s nurturing and growth, continuing cultivation and elevation without decay or ruin. He forbids earthworks and the felling of great trees. He orders the Wildland Wardens to patrol the fields and marshes, encouraging agriculture and driving away beasts and livestock to prevent them from harming the grain.

The Son of Heaven tastes wheat with pork, first offering it at the ancestral temple. In this month, wheat first ripens, hence pork is used to taste it. The pig is a water creature, suited to wheat. Offering it first at the ancestral temple is the height of filial piety.

He gathers and stores all medicinal herbs, for the withered grasses die. In this month, yang qi reaches its peak, and medicinal herbs mature, hence they are gathered and stored. Withered grasses include *tingli* and the like.

When the wheat harvest arrives, he adjudicates minor crimes and metes out light punishments. In the fourth month, yang qi flourishes above, and by the fifth month, yin qi stirs below—hence it is called the wheat harvest. Adjudicating minor crimes and meting out light punishments accords with the qi of killing.

If in early summer autumn ordinances are enacted, bitter rains will frequently come, the five grains will not flourish, and the people of the four directions will take refuge within the walls. Early summer is the height of yang, when nurturing and growth should be assisted. Enacting the metal qi’s ordinances of killing will bring bitter rains that harm the grain, preventing its flourishing. The people of the four directions will enter the cities and fortresses to defend themselves.

If winter ordinances are enacted, grasses and trees will wither early, followed by great floods that ruin city walls. Enacting winter’s ordinances of cold and closure will cause grasses and trees to wither prematurely, and great floods will destroy the city walls. These are the consequences of violating the proper seasons and their ordinances.

If spring ordinances are enacted, locusts will cause devastation, violent winds will arrive, and flowering grasses will not bear fruit. Early summer should continue cultivation and elevation to assist yang’s nurturing and growth. Enacting spring’s ordinances of opening and soaking will bring locust devastation. Spring is the qi of wood, abundant in wind—hence violent winds will come, preventing flowering grasses from maturing.

In the fourth month, the Office of Fields tends to the peach trees. The fourth month encourages agriculture, hence the Office of Fields. The peach is mentioned alongside the apricot. As the plum ripens later, it is called the fourth-month peach.

In the mid-summer month, the *zhaoyao* points to *wu*, the *kang* culminates at dusk, and the *wei* culminates at dawn. *Kang* is a constellation of the eastern Azure Dragon, culminating in the south at dusk this month. *Wei* is a constellation of the northern Dark Warrior, culminating in the south at dawn this month.

Its position is the south, its days are *bing* and *ding*, its creatures are feathered, its note is *zhi*, its pitch pipe is *Ruibin*. Its number is seven. In this month, yin qi droops below like a host, while yang qi resides above like a guest—hence it is called "establishing the guest." Its flavor is bitter, its scent is scorched. Its sacrifice is the stove, and the lungs are offered first.

When the lesser heat arrives, the mantis is born. The mantis is commonly called the "heavenly horse," also known as *chiyou*; in Yan and Yu, it is called the "great axe." The shrike begins to call, and the mockingbird falls silent. The shrike is the *bailao* bird. In the fifth month, yin qi stirs below, and the shrike, responding to yin at the summer solstice, calls while killing snakes in the trees. As the tradition states: "The Bo Zhao clan governs the solstice." The mockingbird is the hundred-tongued bird, able to twist its tongue and alter its voice to mimic the calls of a hundred birds—hence it is called the hundred-tongued bird. It falls silent because in the fifth month, yang qi peaks above while faint yin arises below, and the mockingbird, lacking yin, is thus voiceless.

The Son of Heaven wears red robes, rides a red steed, adorns himself with red jade, carries a red banner, eats beans and chicken, and drinks the water of the eight winds. He cooks with jujube and catalpa firewood. The women of the Southern Palace wear red, dressed in red hues. They play the *yu* and *sheng*. His weapon is the halberd, his animal the chicken. He holds court at the Bright Hall’s ancestral temple. The temple is the south-facing hall’s central chamber.

He commands the Music Masters to repair the drums, *tao* and *pi*, zithers, lutes, flutes, and panpipes, tune the *yu* and *chi*, and adorn the bells and chimes. The *guan* has one hole, resembling a flute. The *xiao* is today’s song flute. The *chi* is pronounced like the "chi" in "pond." He wields shields, *ge* axes, halberds, and feathered banners. The shield is a *gan*; the *ge* is an axe; the halberd is a type of *ji*. The feathered banner is the *duo* held by warriors.

He commands the officials to pray and sacrifice to the mountains, rivers, and all the plains for the people, and to perform the great *yu* sacrifice to the Supreme Emperor with grand music. The mountains, rivers, and plains of the state that can summon clouds and rain are all prayed to and sacrificed to. The *yu* is a drought sacrifice. The "Supreme" is the Emperor. To pray for rain for the people, grand music is used. Grand music refers to the music of the six dynasties.

The Son of Heaven tastes millet with pheasant. The pheasant is a type of chicken. It is not called "tasting chicken" but "tasting millet" because grain is primary. He offers the cherry, first presenting it at the temple. *Xiu* means to offer. The cherry is what the oriole plucks and eats—hence it is called the "contained cherry." It ripens this month, hence it is offered.

He forbids the people from cutting indigo to dye, as the indigo’s blue is not yet fully developed. He forbids burning ash, for in this month grasses and trees are not yet mature, and one must not prematurely harm things. He forbids exposing cloth to the sun, for fire is fierce—exposing cloth will make it brittle and damaged. Gates and lanes are not closed, and passes and markets are not inspected. Gates are city gates; lanes are village gates. The people follow the yang qi, dispersing and dwelling outside, coming and going freely—hence they are not closed. Gates are strategic points; markets are where people gather. "No inspection" means no taxation. He lightens the burdens of heavy prisoners and increases their food. *Ting* means to ease.

He attends to the widowed and bereaved, providing relief for those who died in service. *Guan* refers to the elderly without wives; *gua* refers to the elderly without husbands—he attends to them all. For those whose ancestors died in service to the state, he aids their descendants. He separates mares from their herds, restrains stallions, and issues equine decrees. In this month, mares’ pregnancies are established, so they are separated from the herds. To prevent stallions from injuring the fetuses with their hooves, they are restrained. *Ban* means to announce; *ma zheng* refers to the officials in charge of horses. *Teng ju* are stallions. According to the *Rites of Zhou*, horses under five *chi* in height are called *ju*.

The days grow short to their limit; yin and yang contend, and life and death diverge. The noble man fasts and abstains, restraining himself from restlessness. He moderates music and sensual pleasures, tempers rich flavors, stills the hundred officials, and ensures no affairs proceed without due process—thus stabilizing the subtle yin’s accomplishments. *"No affairs proceed without due process"* means that later actions must first be deliberated. *Yan yin* refers to subtle yin.

Deer shed their antlers, and cicadas begin to sing. At the summer solstice, deer shed their antlers; cicadas beat their wings and begin to call. *Banxia* sprouts, and *mujin* blooms. *Banxia* is a medicinal herb. *Mujin* blooms at dawn and withers by dusk; the tree grows five or six *chi* tall, and its leaves resemble those of the pomegranate. It blooms this month and can be used to make hairpins. In Luo, it is called *chaosheng*. As the *Book of Songs* says, *"Fair as the blooming flower."* He forbids the people from kindling fires. *Fa* means to ignite.

One may dwell in high and bright places, gazing afar from hills and mounds, or reside in terraces and pavilions. A *tai* is earth piled high on all sides; a *tai* with a chamber is called a *xie*. This accords with the yang’s brightness. Another saying: observe the clouds and omens of the atmosphere.

If in mid-summer winter’s commands are enacted, hail and sleet will harm the grain, roads will become impassable, and violent armies will arrive. Winter’s freezing waters cause hail and sleet to damage the five grains. Winter’s qi is closed, and with abundant rain, roads sink and become impassable; thus, armies of destruction arrive unexpectedly. If spring’s commands are enacted, the five grains will not ripen, and locusts will arise in swarms, bringing famine to the land. Spring’s wood qi, favoring growth, delays the ripening of the five grains. *Bai teng* are insects of the locust family that arise in swarms to harm the grain, causing famine. If autumn’s commands are enacted, grasses and trees will wither prematurely, fruits will ripen too soon, and the people will suffer from epidemics. Fruits with pits are called *guo*; those without are called *luo*. Enacting autumn’s commands of ripening in mid-summer causes grasses and trees to wither and fruits to mature early. As this contravenes the season’s qi, the people fall ill with epidemics.

In the fifth month, the *Xiang* official is appointed, and elms are planted. This month, the yang qi flourishes and nurtures, hence the *Xiang* official is appointed. *Xiang* means assistant. The significance of the elm is not yet known.

In the final month of summer, the *Zhaoyao* star points south; at dusk, the Heart star culminates, and at dawn, the Straddler star culminates. The Heart is the eastern Azure Dragon’s constellation; this month, it culminates in the south at dusk. The Straddler is the western White Tiger’s constellation; this month, it culminates in the south at dawn. Its position is the center; its days are *wu* and *ji*. The supreme virtue resides in earth, and the Yellow Emperor’s spirit governs the center. *Wu* and *ji* are earth’s days. The supreme virtue resides in earth, for earth rules the center. Its creatures are the *luo*; its note is *gong*. Feathers fall and [become *luo*]; the *luo* insects and scaled creatures lead them. *Gong* is earth, the center, and the master of the five notes. The pitch corresponds to *Bai Zhong*; its number is five. *Bai Zhong* is *Lin Zhong*. This month, yang is at its peak and yin begins to rise, nurturing the myriad things—hence it is called *Bai Zhong*. Its number is five, for earth is the fifth of the Five Phases. Its flavor is sweet; its scent is fragrant. Earth’s flavor is sweet; earth’s scent is fragrant. Its sacrifice is the central channel, and it venerates the Heart. Earth is in charge, so the central channel is sacrificed. The central channel is the sacrifice within the chamber, venerating the Earth Lord. The Heart is fire, using what it overcomes. Another saying: the Heart is earth, employing its own storehouse.

Cool winds begin to arrive, and crickets dwell in the inner chambers. Crickets are *qinglie*, hastening to weave. As the *Book of Songs* says, *"In the seventh month, in the wilds; this day, in the inner chambers"*—this does not align with the classic. *Ao* may also be written as *bi*. Hawks begin to practice hunting, and rotten grass transforms into fireflies. As autumn’s season approaches, hawks train themselves to strike. *Yuan* are fireflies; in You and Ji, they are called *Qinqu*. *Yuan* is read as *jing* in *xi jing*.

The Son of Heaven wears pale yellow, rides a yellow-roan horse, adorns himself with yellow jade, and raises a yellow banner. Yellow accords with earth’s color. *Huang* refers to the color of ripe millet. He eats millet and beef, for both millet and cattle belong to earth. He drinks the water of the eight winds, cooks with jujube wood, and lights fires with mulberry. The central palace’s consorts wear yellow, dressed in yellow hues; their weapon is the sword. The final month of summer corresponds to the center. The sword has two edges, signifying that it generates nothing. Another saying: it signifies that nothing is mastered, yet all is mastered.

Its livestock is the ox, which presents itself at the central palace. In this month, the Son of Heaven holds court in the central palace. The central palace is the great chamber.

He commands the fishery officers to fell *jiao* and take *tuo*, to present tortoises and take *yuan*. The fishery officers oversee the fishing offices. *Yu* (fishing) is read as *yu* in *xiang yu* (mutual speech). *Jiao*, *tuo*, and *yuan* all belong to the fish kind. *Tuo* can be made into drums, as in the *Odes*: “The *tuo* drums resound.” *Yuan* can be made into broth, as the *Tradition* says: “The people of Chu presented a *yuan* to Duke Ling of Zheng. The Duke did not share the *yuan* broth with Prince Song, who in anger dipped his finger into the cauldron, tasted it, and departed.” None of these harm humans and are easily obtained, hence the word “take.” *Jiao* have scales and armor, can harm humans, and are difficult to obtain, hence the word “fell.” The tortoise is divine, can determine fortune and misfortune, and enters the ancestral temple; it is revered, hence the word “present.”

He commands the marsh officers to gather reeds and rushes. The marsh officers oversee the lakes and marshes. Gathering reeds and rushes supplies the state’s needs.

He commands the four inspectors to order the hundred counties to regularly provide fodder and straw to nourish the sacrificial animals. Under the Zhou system, the Son of Heaven’s domain extended a thousand *li*, divided into a hundred counties, each county having four commanderies, and each commandery four borderlands. Thus, the *Spring and Autumn Annals* say: “Minor grand masters receive counties; major grand masters receive commanderies.” When Qin was first established, it set up thirty-six commanderies to oversee the counties. Here, “hundred counties” refers to the counties within the royal domain under the Zhou system. The four inspectors oversee the four commandery grand masters. *Zhi* (regular) refers to what is due to be provided, hence it is gathered to nourish the sacrificial animals, to be offered to August Heaven and the Lord on High, the famous mountains and great rivers, the gods of the four directions, the ancestral temples and altars of soil and grain, to pray for blessings and bestow kindness on the people.

He commands that the dead be mourned and the sick inquired after, that the elderly be visited and cared for, that gruel be distributed, thick mats and bedding be provided, to send off the myriad things as they return. He commands the women’s offices to dye fabrics, embroidering patterns of *fu* and *fu*, with blue, yellow, white, and black—none failing in quality and excellence. Women are skilled at distinguishing the five colors, hence they dye fabrics. White and black form *fu*; blue and red form *fu*; black and red form *wen*; red and white form *zhang*. *Zhi* means fine; *liang* means good. These are used for the robes of the ancestral temples, which must be displayed in full and made bright. *Xuan* means complete; *ming* means radiant.

In this month, the trees are in full vigor; one must not dare to fell them. One may not assemble the feudal lords or initiate earthworks. To mobilize the masses or raise arms will surely bring heavenly calamity. *Yang* means punishment.

The earth is moist with summer heat, and great rains come in season. It is beneficial to kill weeds to fertilize the fields, enriching the soil and strengthening the boundaries. In this month of great heat, the earth is moist and the summer dampness heavy. There are also timely rains, which can be used to kill weeds for fertilizer, beautifying the soil and strengthening the fields. *Jiang* refers to the divisions of the land.

If in the final month of summer the commands of spring are enacted, the grain will split and fall, winds and coughs will abound, and the people will migrate. In spring, wood is in its ascendancy; the nature of wood is to shed and fall. When yang is released, winds are many. If its commands are enacted, the grain will split and fall, and the people will suffer from wind-borne illnesses, coughing and gasping for breath, resembling the scattering of spring yang. Thus, the people migrate.

If the commands of autumn are enacted, the hills and lowlands will flood, the crops will not ripen, and there will be many female calamities. *Qiu* means high; *xi* means low. This says that both high and low places will be flooded, thus killing the crops and preventing their ripening. When yin qi encounters disorder, there will be many female calamities. Female calamities refer to children not being raised.

If the commands of winter are enacted, the winds and cold will be untimely, hawks and falcons will strike early, and the people of the four borderlands will take refuge in walled settlements. In winter, yin is desolate and killing. If its commands are enacted, the cold winds will be unseasonable, hawks and falcons will strike early, and the people of the four frontiers will all enter the cities and towns to defend themselves.

The sixth month’s office is the *Shaonei*; its tree is the catalpa. In the sixth month, the crops ripen, hence the office of *Shaonei*. The catalpa’s significance is not yet known.

*Huainan Honglie Jie*, Scroll Nine, concludes.

*Huainan Honglie Jie*, Scroll Ten.
Presented by the Grandee Secretary and Libationer, your servant Xu Shen.

In the Seasonal Instructions for the Lesser Months:

In the first month of autumn, the stellar pointer *Zhaoyao* aligns with *Shen*. At dusk, the Dipper culminates; at dawn, the *Bi* asterism culminates. The Dipper is the northern constellation of the Dark Warrior, culminating at dusk in the southern sky this month. *Bi* is the western constellation of the White Tiger, culminating at dawn in the southern sky. Its position is the west; its days are *geng* and *xin*. The flourishing power resides in metal, and the deity Shaohao governs the west. *Geng* and *xin* correspond to metal. The flourishing power resides in metal, for metal rules the west. Its creatures are furred; its tone is *shang*. The qi of metal is cold, and armored creatures don fur. The tiger is the chief of furred creatures. *Shang* corresponds to metal, whose position is the west. The pitch standard is *Yize*. Its number is nine. *Yi* means "injury"; *ze* means "rule." This month, yang wanes and yin waxes, and the myriad things wither and suffer injury, conforming to the rule and completing their natures—hence *Yize*. Its number is nine, for in the five phases, metal is the fourth, and thus its number is nine. Its flavor is pungent; its odor is rank. Metal’s flavor is pungent; metal’s odor is rank. Its sacrifice is at the gate, and the liver is offered first. At the onset of early autumn, entry is made through the gate, hence the sacrifice at the gate. The liver corresponds to wood, and in sacrifice, the phase that metal conquers is used. Another saying: the liver sinks metal, employing its own organ. The cool wind arrives, white dew descends, the cold cicada sings, and the hawk begins to "sacrifice birds," commencing the execution of punishments. This month, hawks strike and kill birds in the great marshes, arranging them on all sides—this is called "sacrificing birds." From this time, the execution of punishments and penalties begins, aligning with the qi of autumn.

The Son of Heaven wears white robes, rides a white *luo* horse, adorns himself with white jade, raises a white banner, and white accords with the color of metal. A *luo* is a white horse with black mane. He eats hemp and dog, drinks the water of the eight winds, and cooks with fire from *zhe* wood. The consorts of the Western Palace wear white, dress in white hues, and strike the white bell. As metal rules the west, they reside in the Western Palace. Its weapon is the dagger-axe; its domestic animal is the dog. The court assembles at the *Zongzhang* hall’s left chamber to issue the autumnal commands. *Zongzhang* is the west-facing hall, where the myriad things are gathered and made manifest—hence *Zongzhang*. The left chamber is the southernmost room. From this chamber, the commands of the month are issued. The dog is the domestic animal of metal. Those who are unfilial, disobedient, violent, arrogant, or defiant are sought out and punished to assist the waning qi. The waning qi is yin qi.

On the day of the Beginning of Autumn, the Son of Heaven personally leads the Three Dukes, the Nine Ministers, and the grand masters to welcome autumn at the western suburbs. The western suburbs lie beyond the nine-*li* outer boundary. Upon returning, he rewards military leaders and warriors in the court. The *junshuai* are the generals.

The martial in towns brings fame to the brave. The command is given to generals and officers to select soldiers, sharpen weapons, and train the most outstanding and capable, entrusting them to those with merit, to punish the unrighteous, seek out and execute the violent and insolent, and bring order to the four directions. *Shun* means to follow; the four directions are the world.

Officials are ordered to refine laws and systems, repair prisons, prohibit wickedness and block evil, carefully adjudicate cases, and settle disputes. *Jue* means to decide; *ping* means to govern.

Heaven and Earth begin their solemnity—excess must not be allowed. *Su* means killing; the killing *qi* begins to act. *Ying* means abundance, hence it is said that excess must not be allowed.

In this month, farmers begin to harvest grain, and the Son of Heaven tastes the new crop, first offering it to the ancestral temple. *Sheng* means completion; *jian* means to present.

The command is given to all officials to begin gathering and storing, for early autumn is the start of inward containment. Repair dikes and embankments, carefully fortify barriers and passes to prepare for floods; mend city walls and renovate palaces. In this month, the moon aligns with the *Bi* constellation, bringing heavy rains—hence the preparation for floods.

Do not enfeoff marquises, establish high offices, distribute valuable gifts, or dispatch grand envoys. In following this month’s commands, cool winds arrive within thirty days. *Feng hou* means granting land and enfeoffing towns. *Da guan* refers to the nine-rank nobility. *Zhong bi* are gifts of metal and silk. *Da shi* are envoys dispatched by high ministers. The *qi* of metal is contracting—none of these actions are suitable now, hence the prohibition.

If in early autumn the commands of winter are followed, *yin qi* will prevail excessively, armored insects will harm the grain, and hostile armies will arrive. Early autumn is *yin*, and if the dominant *qi* of winter water is enacted again, *yin qi* will dominate, and armored insects will damage the grain. As *yin qi* converges, hostile armies come.

If the commands of spring are followed, the land will suffer drought, *yang qi* will return, and the five grains will bear no fruit. Spring’s *yang* is scorching and dry, and enacting its commands will cause drought. *Yang qi* returning means that in this month, cool winds should prevail, yet warm winds are enacted instead—thus the grain is ruined and bears no fruit.

If the commands of summer are followed, winter will see many fires, cold and heat will be unregulated, and the people will suffer from malaria. Summer is ruled by fire, and enacting its commands will cause many fires. As cold and heat clash, they become unbalanced, leading to malaria. Malaria arises from cold and heat.

In the seventh month, the office is the armory, and its tree is the *lian*. The armory is the storehouse of weapons; as autumn’s season requires the ordering of arms, it is called the armory. Its tree is the *lian*, whose fruit is eaten by the phoenix—such trees still grow near Luoyang. The *lian* fruit ripens in autumn, hence its association. *Lian* is pronounced like the *lian* in dyeing and bleaching.

In the mid-autumn month, the *Zhaoyao* star points to *you*, the *Qianniu* constellation culminates at dusk, and the *ZiGui* culminates at dawn. *Qianniu* is the northern Dark Warrior constellation, which in this month culminates at dusk in the south. *ZiGui* is the western White Tiger constellation, which in this month culminates at dawn in the south.

Its position is the west, its days are *geng* and *xin*, its creatures are furred, its tone is *shang*, its pitch pipe is *Nanlü*, its number is nine, and the south is *ren*. This means the *yang qi* of *Nanlü* assists *yin*, and *yin* takes up the task of completing the myriad things. *Geng* and *xin* are the days of metal.

Its flavor is pungent, its scent is rank, its sacrifice is at the gate, and the liver is offered first. Cool winds arrive, the wild geese come, the swallows return, and flocks of birds soar. The seasonal geese come from the northern deserts, passing through Zhou and Luoyang to reach Pengli. The swallows return to their hibernation sites after the autumn equinox. The flocks of birds soar as the cold arrives, growing plump and testing their wings in high flight. *Xiang* means the six pinions do not move; some interpret it as *yang*, nurturing their feathers.

The Son of Heaven wears white robes, rides a white camel, adorns himself with white jade, raises a white banner, eats hemp and dog, drinks the water of the eight winds, and cooks with *zhe* fire. In the western palace, the consorts wear white, dress in white hues, and strike the white bells. Its weapons are spears and shields, its domestic animal is the dog, and court is held in the *Zongzhang* ancestral temple. *Zongzhang* is the west-facing hall; the ancestral temple is the central chamber.

Officials are ordered to strictly enforce all punishments, ensuring that executions are just and without distortion or leniency. *Wang* means crooked; *nao* means weak—this means to act with fairness and uprightness. If judgments are unjust, the misfortune will return to the judge. *Fan* means to return.

In this month, the elderly are cared for, provided with armrests and canes, and offered food and drink. The stewards and invocators are commanded to prepare sacrificial animals, inspecting the fodder-fed and grain-fed—those fed on grass are *chu*, and those fed on grain are *huan*.
