They review the records and examine the tributes. *Huan* is pronounced like the *huan* in "serving and learning." They inspect the animals’ fatness or leanness, wholeness, and purity—*quan* means without defect, and *cui* means the fur’s color is pure. *Cui* is pronounced like the *sui* in "misfortune."

They examine the creatures’ colors, compare their types, measure their sizes, and observe their ages, ensuring all meet the standards. The Son of Heaven then performs the *nuo* ritual to ward off autumn’s *qi*. *Nuo* means to expel; *yu* means to stop—stopping autumn’s *qi* to prevent harm. *Nuo* is pronounced like the *nan* in "restless difficulty." Some texts write *qi* as *bing* (weapons).

Hemp and dog are tasted and first offered to the ancestral temple. In this month, city walls and moats may be constructed, and capitals and towns established. A state with the ancestral temple of a former ruler is called a *du*; without, it is called a *yi*. *Du* are walled, and *yi* are built. Dig drainage channels and cellars, and repair granaries. *Chuan dou* are for water flow to prevent damp ground; *chuan jiao* are for storing grain. *Jiao* is pronounced like the *jiao* in "storing goods."

Officials are ordered to urge the people to gather and store, amass supplies, and encourage the planting of winter wheat. If the season is missed, punishment is certain without doubt.

In this month, thunder begins to withdraw, hibernating insects seal their burrows, killing *qi* grows increasingly strong, *yang qi* daily wanes, and waters begin to dry. *He* means to congeal and deplete; some texts write *he* as *sheng*, meaning *yin* prevails.

Day and night are equal. Standardize measurements, balance weights, correct steelyards and stone weights, adjust measuring vessels, regulate markets and customs, and welcome merchants and travelers. *Li* means to open and connect.

Gather goods and wealth to facilitate the people’s affairs. From all directions they come together, even from distant lands they arrive; resources are not lacking, the ruler has no shortage of supplies, and all matters thus come to fruition. *Fruition* means completion.

If in the mid-autumn month the spring command is enacted, autumn rains will not fall, grasses and trees will flourish, and the state will face great terror. Spring is the season of *yang qi*, and enacting its command prevents rain from descending. Moreover, the warmth and nurturing benevolence cause grasses and trees to bloom. When *qi* clash, disaster and misfortune must follow, hence the state is seized by great alarm.

If the summer command is enacted, the land will suffer drought, hibernating insects will not retreat into hiding, and the five grains will all sprout anew. Enacting the command of scorching *yang* brings drought. The heat causes hibernating insects to remain active and the five grains to regrow.

If the winter command is enacted, wind disasters will frequently arise, thunder will cease prematurely, and grasses and trees will die early. Enacting the command of cold *qi* provokes wind disasters. Moreover, winter is the season of closure and storage, so thunder withdraws early and grasses and trees perish prematurely.

In the eighth month, the office of the *Wei* is established, and the *zhe* tree is planted. *Wei* is the military official. This month is for training troops, hence the appointment of the *Wei*. As the saying goes, "The Yangshe Grand Master served as *Zhongjun Wei* of Zhe"—though the meaning of *zhe* remains unclear.

In the late autumn month, the *Zhaoyao* constellation points to *Xu*, the *Xu* constellation culminates at dusk, and the *Liu* constellation culminates at dawn. *Xu* is the northern constellation of the Dark Warrior; this month, it culminates in the southern sky at dusk. *Liu* is the southern constellation of the Vermilion Bird; this month, it culminates in the southern sky at dawn. Its position is the west, its days are *geng* and *xin*, its creatures are furred, its note is *shang*, and its pitch pipe is *Wuyi*. *Yin qi* ascends while *yang qi* descends, and all things follow *yang* into hiding—*Wuyi* emerges at this time. Its number is nine, its flavor is pungent, its odor is rank, its sacrifice is at the gate, and the liver is offered first in worship. The wild geese arrive as guests, and the guest sparrows enter the great waters to become clams.

This month, the geese come from the northern deserts, migrating south to Pengli. Those arriving in the eighth month are likely the parents, while those coming now are their offspring. Their wings are still tender and weak, so they follow behind. The *guest sparrows* are the elder sparrows that roost in the halls of human dwellings like guests, hence the name. The *great waters* refer to the sea. As the saying goes, "Sparrows enter the sea and become clams."

Chrysanthemums bloom with yellow flowers, and jackals offer beasts and slay birds. Jackals resemble dogs but have long tails and yellow fur. This month, they kill beasts and arrange them on all sides, a practice the world calls "offering beasts." *Slay* means to kill.

The Son of Heaven wears white robes, rides a white camel, adorns himself with white jade, raises a white banner, eats hemp and dog, drinks the water of the eight winds, and cooks with *zhe* fire. In the Western Palace, the consorts wear white, dress in white hues, and strike the white bell. Their weapon is the dagger-axe, their animal is the dog, and they hold court in the *Zongzhang* hall facing right. The right side of the hall faces west, and the northernmost chamber is called the right quarter.

Officials are ordered to enforce strict commands: all officials, high and low, must devote themselves to assisting in the storage of Heaven and Earth, allowing nothing to be released. The *Zhongzai* is then commanded to ensure the harvest is fully gathered, to compile the essential records of the five grains. *Zhong* means great, *zai* means to govern, and *qing* refers to the officials. *Essential* refers to the registers.

Store the harvest of the imperial fields in the divine granary. The Son of Heaven’s personal fields span a thousand *mu*, hence the term "imperial harvest." The grain from these fields is stored in the divine granary.

This month, frost begins to fall, and all artisans rest. With frost descending and the weather growing cold, red lacquer becomes difficult to apply, so all artisans cease work and no longer craft vessels.

Officials are then commanded: "The cold *qi* is fully arrived, and the people’s strength cannot endure it—let them all enter their homes." As the *Book of Songs* says, "Enter these chambers to dwell."

On the first *ding* day, students enter the academy to practice wind instruments. A grand sacrifice is offered to the Supreme Sovereign, and animal victims are tasted. The feudal lords are assembled, and the hundred counties are regulated. On the first *ding* day of the month’s first decade, students enter the academy to practice reed pipes and zithers, study ritual and music, sacrifice to the Supreme Sovereign with animal victims, and assemble the feudal lords to standardize the distinctions in carriages and robes, each according to their rank. The *hundred counties* refer to those within the royal domain; "hundred" is used to denote the whole.

Prepare for the coming year’s first day of the month, and determine the system of taxation for the feudal lords—its weight and measure, the annual tribute, and the standards based on the distance and suitability of the land. *Coming year* refers to the next year. *First day of the month* is like the modern practice of officials presenting the almanac for the coming year. *Standards* refer to the regularity of tribute and taxation.

Then instruct in the field hunt to practice the five weapons. *Weapons* refer to the blade, sword, spear, halberd, and arrow—hence the five weapons.

Command the Grand Coachman and the seven grooms to harness the *dairen* carriages, distribute them by rank, and arrange them properly outside the screen. *Rank* means grade; carriages are assigned according to the high or low status of their occupants. *Properly* means to stand them in place. *Arrange* means to set them in order. The Son of Heaven’s outer screen is a planted hedge. As the *Erya* says, "The hedge within the gate is called a planted hedge."

The Minister of Education, holding the staff, faces north to assist. *Holding* means to tuck it in. The staff is for instruction. Tucking it into the belt, he assists in the solemn ceremony. The Minister of Education oversees the masses and instructs them.

The Son of Heaven then dons fierce attire with grand adornments, takes up bow and arrow, and hunts. This month, the Son of Heaven values martial prowess, so he wears fierce and imposing garments with elaborate ornaments to capture game.

Command the master of sacrifices to offer beasts to the four directions. *Command* means to instruct. The *master of sacrifices* is the official in charge of rituals. Offering beasts to the four directions means sacrificing to the spirits who first set forth birds and beasts in the four directions, repaying their merit. Since their divine presence is unknown, offerings are broadly made to the four directions.

This month, grasses and trees yellow and shed their leaves. Thus, one fells timber to make charcoal. Hibernating creatures all crouch low, so one hastens to prisons and punishments, leaving no guilty party detained. *Crouch* means to lie concealed. In Qingzhou, *crouch* is pronounced as *俛*. *Leaving none detained* means judgments must be swift. One also reclaims salaries and emoluments from those unworthy of them, as well as support from those undeserving of sustenance. *Unworthy* refers to those without virtue who receive emoluments. *Undeserving* refers to the unfilial. Another interpretation: those supported have rendered no merit to the state, and their ancestors possessed no worthy virtue, so their support is deemed improper and thus revoked.

Roads are cleared and paths repaired, beginning at the borders and concluding within the capital. This month, the Son of Heaven samples hemp with dog meat, first offering it to the ancestral temple. This is the height of filial piety.

If in late autumn one implements summer ordinances, the state will suffer great floods, winter stores will be ruined, and the people will frequently suffer from nasal congestion and obstruction. Late autumn is a time of yin qi, yet if one enforces the summer’s ceaseless rains, floods will ensue. Fire qi (heat) disrupts winter storage, causing ruin. Fire and metal clash, so the people suffer nasal congestion—*鼽* is pronounced like *仇* (enmity). If one implements winter ordinances, the state will see many thieves and bandits, borders will be unsettled, and lands will be divided. Winter’s water is pure yin, breeding treacherous schemes, hence the proliferation of thieves and bandits, unsettling borderlands. Lands will be encroached upon and partitioned by neighboring states. If one implements spring ordinances, warm winds will arrive, the people’s qi will slacken, and armies will be mobilized. Spring’s yang qi is warm, so warm winds come, and the people’s qi grows lax. Wood invades metal, so armies are raised—2,500 men form a *division*, and 500 a *brigade*.

In the ninth month, the office of observation is established, and the tree is the locust. *Observation* means to watch. This month, defenses are repaired, hence the office of observation. The locust tree (*槐*) is associated with *embracing* (*怀*), for it can draw distant people near.

In the first month of winter, the *Diurnal Revolving Star* points to *Hai*, the *Rooftop* constellation culminates at dusk, and the *Seven Stars* culminate at dawn. *Rooftop* is a constellation of the northern Dark Warrior; this month, it culminates in the south at dusk. The *Seven Stars* are a constellation of the southern Vermilion Bird; this month, they culminate in the south at dawn. Its position is the north, its days are *Ren* and *Gui*, its supreme power resides in water, and the spirit Zhuanxu governs the north. *Ren* and *Gui* are water days. *Supreme power resides in water* means water rules the north. Its creatures are armored, its tone is *yu*, and *armored* refers to shells, symbolizing winter’s closure and solidity. The turtle is the chief of armored creatures. *Yu* pertains to water. The pitch pipe *Yingzhong* is in harmony, its number is six. Yin responds to yang, completing its work; all things gather and mature, hence *Yingzhong* (Responsive Bell). Its number is six because the five phases number five, and water is first, thus six. Its flavor is salty, its odor is putrid—water’s flavor is salty, and its odor is putrid. Its sacrifice is to the kidneys. Well water sustains people, hence its veneration. *Well* may also be written as *path*. The earth within gates is also venerated. Winter’s guard is within, hence its veneration. The kidneys pertain to water, opening their storehouse.

This month, ice begins to form, the earth starts to freeze, pheasants enter great waters and become clams, and rainbows hide from sight. *Clams* are bivalves. *Great waters* refer to the Huai River. Tradition states: "Pheasants entering the Huai become clams." Rainbows are yang within yin. This month, yin prevails, so they are not seen.

The Son of Heaven wears black robes, rides a dark steed, adorns himself with black jade, raises a black banner, and aligns with the power of water. Banners depict bears and tigers. He eats glutinous millet and pig, imbibes the eight winds’ water, cooks with pine and fir, and resides in the northern palace. The palace’s attendants wear black, dress in black hues, and strike sounding stones. Water rules the north, hence the northern palace. His weapons are forged, his livestock are pigs—forging retracts inward, symbolizing yin’s closure. Pigs are water’s creatures.

He holds court in the left chamber of the Black Hall to issue winter’s ordinances. The hall faces north, and the western chamber is called the *left chamber*. Residing here, he enacts this month’s decrees. He commands officials to enforce all prohibitions, aligning with yin’s closure. All that should be forbidden is entrusted to officials for enforcement. Migration is prohibited, gates and lanes are sealed, and guests are thoroughly searched. Tradition states: "Old guests are forbidden to reveal secrets; new guests are searched to observe their intentions." *Gates* are city gates; *lanes* are neighborhood gates. These are strictly sealed for defense. Punishments are meted out, and the guilty are executed—all due punishments are decided. Those deserving punishment are rightly condemned, hence executed. Those who flatter superiors and disrupt the law are punished. *Flattery* means currying favor with superiors to disrupt law and order. *Punished* means corrected.

On the day of the Beginning of Winter, the Son of Heaven personally leads the Three Dukes, Nine Ministers, and high officials to welcome the year at the northern suburbs. Upon returning, he rewards those who died in service and provides for orphans and widows. Those who died in loyal service to the state are honored by rewarding their descendants. *Orphans* are fatherless children; *widows* are husbandless women—both are comforted and relieved. This month, he commands the Grand Invocator to pray and sacrifice to the spirits, divine with tortoise and milfoil, and scrutinize hexagrams and omens to discern fortune and misfortune.

Now the Son of Heaven dons furs. He commands all officials to securely store provisions, orders the Minister of Education to gather supplies, repair city walls, fortify gates and lanes, mend weapons and locks, secure keys and seals—*seals* are doors, and *seals* are stamps. Borders are reinforced, strategic passes are fortified, footpaths are blocked, and mourning rites are prepared. Coffins, outer coffins, grave clothes, and shrouds are examined for their proper thickness. *Prepared* means arranged; *rites* refer to the twenty-five-month mourning period. Coffins, outer coffins, grave clothes, and shrouds vary in thickness by rank, hence their scrutiny. Graves and mounds are measured for size and height, ensuring nobles and commoners, high and low, each have their proper degree. *Measured* means assessed; *graves and mounds* are tombs, with size and height varying by rank.

This month, artisans present their works, ritual vessels are displayed, standards are reviewed, and firmness and precision are prized.

Reviewing the standards is *inspection*; *standards* are models. *Firm and precise* means sturdy craftsmanship. *For* signifies *therefore*; *supreme* means *abundant*. If artisans’ work is shoddy or careless, or their creations excessively ornate, they shall surely be punished. *Shoddy* means poor; *careless* means unsteady. *Excessively ornate* refers to craft beyond the proper measure. Therefore, they shall be punished. *Shoddy* here denotes salt that has caked.

This month, the great steaming sacrifice is held. The Son of Heaven prays to the Celestial Honored Ones for the coming year. *Steaming* is the winter sacrifice. At this time, great feasts of wine are held while offering sacrifices to seek blessings for the next year. All celestial deities belonging to the Son of Heaven—sun, moon, and stars—are called the Celestial Honored Ones. Grand supplications are made at the public altar to the earth, and upon completion, ancestors are feasted. *Supplication* means to entreat. The *public altar* is the sacrifice to the Queen of Earth. In life, she is the highest duke; in death, a revered spirit—hence called *duke*. *Completion* refers to feasting ancestors, observing the principle of honoring the public before the private.

The toiling farmers are granted rest. Commanders and generals drill troops in martial arts, practicing archery and charioteering, and testing strength in wrestling. *Drill* means to practice; *wrestling* takes place on level ground. *Strength* describes vigor. Then the Water Stewards and Fishery Masters are ordered to collect taxes from springs, pools, and marshes. *Stewards* are officials in charge of water; *masters* are leaders. *Taxes* are levies. Let none encroach or overreach. *Overreach* means excess.

If in early winter the seasonal decree of spring is enacted, then the frost’s closure will not be tight, the earth’s qi will leak forth, and the people will scatter in great numbers. For spring’s yang qi disperses and overflows—hence the frost’s closure is not tight and the earth’s qi leaks forth. The people scatter in great numbers, resembling the spreading of yang qi.

If the seasonal decree of summer is enacted, then violent winds will arise frequently, midwinter will lack cold, and hibernating creatures will emerge again. Winter should be a time of closure and storage; instead, the decree of summer’s flourishing is enacted—hence violent winds arise frequently. The warmth of yang qi ensures that even in the depths of winter there is no cold, causing hibernating creatures to emerge again.

If the seasonal decree of autumn is enacted, then snow and frost will fall untimely, minor conflicts will frequently arise, and the land will be encroached upon and diminished. Autumn’s qi is dry, and winter’s great cold should not bring snow or frost—yet they fall, hence they are untimely. Minor conflicts arise repeatedly, neighboring states invade and seize the land.

In the tenth month, the office of the Minister of War is in charge, and its tree is the sandalwood. Winter is the season for martial training, hence the office of the Minister of War. Sandalwood is a yin wood.

In the month of mid-winter, the Dipper’s handle points to the *zi* position, the *Bi* constellation culminates at dusk, and the *Zhen* constellation culminates at dawn. The Eastern Wall is the northern quadrant’s Dark Warrior constellation; this month it culminates in the south at dusk. *Zhen* is the southern quadrant’s Vermilion Bird constellation; this month it culminates in the south at dawn. Its position is the north, its days are *ren* and *gui*, its creatures are armored, its tone is *yu*, its pitch pipe is the Yellow Bell, and its number is six. The Yellow Bell signifies yang qi gathering below and yin qi flourishing above, with all things yellow and sprouting within the earth—hence it is called the Yellow Bell. Its flavor is salty, its odor is putrid, its sacrifice is to the well, and the kidneys are offered first.

Water grows stronger, the earth begins to crack, the *guān* and *jū* birds fall silent, and tigers begin to mate. The *guān* and *jū* are mountain birds. In this month, yin prevails, hence they fall silent. The tiger is yin within yang; with yin qi flourishing, it responds in kind. *Mate* is read as the *xiao* in *jiangxiao* (general).

The Son of Heaven wears black robes, rides a black-maned iron-black horse, adorns himself with dark jade, raises a black banner, eats millet and swine, drinks the water of the eight winds, and cooks with pine and fire-drill flames. In the northern palace, the consorts wear black, dress in black hues, and strike the sounding stone. Their weapon is the forged blade, their beast is the swine, and they hold court in the Dark Hall of the Grand Ancestral Temple. The hall faces north, the chamber lies at the center—hence it is called the Grand Ancestral Temple.

He commands the officials, saying: “Let no earthworks be undertaken, no dwellings opened, nor great assemblies gathered. This is called ‘opening the treasures of heaven and earth.’ All hibernating creatures will die, the people will surely suffer epidemics, and some will follow in death.”

Swiftly capture thieves and bandits, and execute those who are licentious, deceitful, or fraudulent. This month is called the *Chang* month. With yin qi above, the people are empty and idle—hence it is called the *Chang* month.

He commands the Intendant of the Palace Eunuchs to reiterate the palace decrees. *Yan* is the office; *yin* is the director. Reiterating the palace decrees means to issue stern warnings. Inspect the gates and lanes, secure the chambers, and ensure all are tightly sealed to assist the yin qi. Reduce the tasks of women.

Then he commands the Grand Brewer: the glutinous and non-glutinous rice must be uniform, the yeast and malt must be timely. The *qiú* is the official in charge of brewing. Fermenting the grains and yeast to maturity—hence he is called *qiú*. *Qiú* is read as the *qiú* in *qiúháo* (chieftain); *uniform* is read as the *qí* in *qíhé* (harmony). The yeast and malt must be made at the proper time; if untimely, they will not succeed. The steeping and steaming must be pure, the water and springs must be fragrant. *Zhàn* means to soak; the steaming must be immaculate. If the water and springs are fragrant, the wine will be excellent. *Zhàn* is read as the *shěn* in *shěnfǔ* (to examine a cauldron); *xī* is read as the *chì* in *chìhuǒ* (blazing fire).

The pottery must be fine, the firing temperature must be precise, with no deviations. The pottery refers to earthenware. The cooking and offering must be appropriate—hence it is said there should be no deviations.

The Son of Heaven then commands the officials to sacrifice to the four seas, great rivers, famous lakes, and marshes. They can summon clouds and rain—hence they are sacrificed to.

In this month, if farmers have not gathered and stored their harvests, or if cattle, horses, livestock, or wild animals have been lost or released, they may be taken without reproach. *Reproach* means to question or interrogate.

In the mountains, forests, marshes, and wetlands, those who gather wild foods or hunt birds and beasts are instructed and guided by the Wild Stewards. If there is any encroachment or seizure, the offenders are punished without pardon. Severe penalties are imposed.

In this month, the days reach their shortest, yin and yang contend, and the noble person fasts and abstains. They dwell in seclusion, their bodies seek stillness, and they shun music and beauty. *Music* refers to the sounds of strings, bamboo, metal, and stone; *beauty* refers to alluring appearances. Those who indulge in greed and excess are prohibited. They calm their bodies and settle their forms and natures, closing off emotions and desires.

In this month, *li* stalks emerge, *yun* begins to grow, earthworms coil, and elk shed their antlers. *Li* is the *mali* herb; *yun* is *yunhao*, a type of vegetable; *qiuyin* is a kind of insect, and *coiling* means to curl and knot. The shedding of elk antlers—all respond to the subtle rise of yang qi.

When springs and streams stir, trees may be felled, bamboo arrows gathered, and idle officials and useless implements dismissed. *Dismiss* means to reduce. Gates and courtyards are slowly closed, and prisons are built to assist Heaven and Earth in their closure.

If in the mid-winter month summer ordinances are enacted, the land will suffer drought, mist and fog will shroud the skies, and thunder will sound. Summer’s qi is scorching yang, hence the land dries; clear and turbid clash, hence mist and fog gather. Thunder in the eleventh month is untimely, thus it is said *then*.

If autumn ordinances are enacted, there will be excessive rain, gourds and melons will fail to ripen, and the land will face great warfare. Autumn’s metal qi is the mother of water, hence the rain; with water and metal in dominance, great warfare arises.

If spring ordinances are enacted, insects will ravage the crops, springs will dry up, and the people will suffer plagues. Spring’s yang qi stirs hibernating creatures, hence insects ruin the grain and springs run dry. Yang invades yin, qi is disharmonious, hence plagues spread.

In the eleventh month, the office of the Capital Defender is established, and jujube trees are planted. Winter is the season for military readiness, hence the Capital Defender is appointed. Jujubes are chosen for their red hearts.

In the final month of winter, the *Diurnal Star* points to *Chou*, the constellation *Lou* culminates at dusk, and *Di* culminates at dawn. *Lou* is the western White Tiger constellation, which at dusk this month aligns due south. *Di* is the eastern Azure Dragon constellation, which at dawn this month aligns due south. Its position is the north, its days are *ren* and *gui*, its creatures are armored, its tone is *yu*, and its pitch standard is *Dalü*. *Lü* means *to travel*—all things stir in the yellow springs yet cannot emerge, so they *travel* to leave yin and approach yang, aiding their completion, hence it is called *Great Lü*. Its number is six, its flavor is salty, its odor is putrid, its sacrifice is to the well, and the kidneys are offered first. Geese turn northward, and magpies begin to build nests. Geese on Pengli Lake all face north, preparing to reach the northern deserts. Magpies, sensing yang, rise to build nests. Pheasants call, and hens cluck for eggs. As the *Book of Songs* says, “At dawn the pheasant calls, still seeking his mate”—this is the meaning; hens cluck to gather their eggs.

The Son of Heaven wears black robes, rides a black steed, adorns himself with dark jade, raises a black banner, eats wheat and pork, drinks the water of the eight winds, and burns pine and fir for fire. The women of the Northern Palace wear black, dress in dark hues, and strike stone chimes. Their weapons are forged, their livestock are swine, and they hold court in the eastern chamber of the Dark Hall. *Eastern chamber* refers to the room on the east side.

He commands the officials to perform the Great Exorcism and the *Pangzhe* ritual, and to fashion the Earth Ox. The *Great Exorcism* is today’s rite of driving out yin and expelling pestilence to guide yang. *Pangzhe* means slaughtering dogs and sheep on all four sides to ward off illness and plague. The *Earth Ox* is the clay oxen now displayed in villages and counties to encourage farming.

He commands the Fishery Steward to begin fishing. This month, as fishing commences, he appoints its overseer. *Fishery* is read as in the *Analects*. The Son of Heaven personally goes to shoot fish, first offering them to the ancestral temple.

He orders the people to prepare the five grains, directs farmers to plan paired plowing, repair plows and plowshares, and ready farming tools. *Paired* means joined. He commands the Music Masters to gather for a grand wind performance and then dismiss them. He then orders the Four Inspectors to collect firewood for the ancestral temple and the hundred sacrifices.

In this month, the sun completes its cycle, the moon its course, and the stars their circuit. The twelve cycles end at the *Oxherd* constellation. The *course* concludes at its former lodging. The stars’ circuit of the heavens—referring to the twenty-eight lodgings appearing in the south—is completed this month.

As the year prepares to renew, he orders the farmers to rest and not be employed. The Son of Heaven then, with the dukes, ministers, and great officers, adorns the state’s laws, deliberates the seasonal ordinances, and awaits the suitability of the coming year.

He commands the Grand Scribe to arrange the feudal lords in order and levy their tribute of sacrificial animals. *Levy* means to distribute. These are to supply the offerings of hay and grain to August Heaven, the Supreme Lord, the altars of soil and grain.

He commands the states of the same surname to provide livestock for the ancestral temple, while ministers, great officers, and commoners supply the sacrifices for famous mountains, forests, and great rivers.

If in the final month of winter autumn ordinances are enacted, white dew will descend early, armored creatures will become omens, and the borderlands will retreat to fortified towns. Autumn’s season brings white dew, hence its early descent. Armored creatures become portents of disaster. Metal qi brings warfare, hence the people of the four borders enter walled cities for self-defense.

If spring ordinances are enacted, fetuses will be harmed, the land will suffer chronic illnesses, and this will be called *perverse*. The final month of winter is bitter cold, yet spring’s warmth is enacted—qi is disharmonious, hence fetuses are harmed and the land suffers grave illness. This violates the proper flow of qi, thus it is called *perverse*.

If summer ordinances are enacted, floods will ruin the land, timely snow will not fall, and ice will melt prematurely. Summer’s qi is scorching yang, bringing excessive rains, hence floods ruin the land. Timely snow should fall but does not; ice should not melt but does—both are signs of disorder.

In the twelfth month, the office of the Prison Warden is established, and oak trees are planted. The twelfth month marks the year’s end and the conclusion of punishments, hence the Prison Warden. Oaks can be used for chariot hubs; no other wood produces fire as readily as oak, which also responds to the qi of elimination.

The Five Directions: The eastern extreme begins at Mount Jieshi, passes through Chaoxian, crosses the land of the *Daren*, and ends at Jieshi on the western bank of the Ruo River in Liaoxi.

ChaoXian is the county of LeLang. *Guan* means "to pass through." The land of the *Daren* lies to its east. To the east, it extends to the place where the sun rises, the land of the *Fumu* tree, the wilds of blue earth and towering woods—*Fumu* is the *fusang* tree. This is the domain governed by TaiHao and GouMang, spanning twelve thousand *li*. TaiHao is FuXi, the Daoist emperor of the east, whose virtue is Wood. GouMang is the spirit of Wood; *si* means "to preside over." His decree states: Uphold all prohibitions, open and close the gates, unblock the obstructed, clear the blocked, act with ease, cast aside resentment and malice, absolve those bound by labor and punishment, and dispel cares and calamities. Punishments are to be mitigated; open the passes and bridges, distribute wealth, reconcile external grievances, pacify the four directions, enact gentle kindness, and restrain harsh strength. Those who are harsh and overbearing, who encroach upon others and do not follow the proper measures, are to be prohibited.

To the south, the extreme begins beyond Beihu Sun. Beihu Sun is the name of a state; the sun lies to its north, so all doors face north on account of the sun. It passes through the land of ZhuanXu and extends south to the wilds of scorching fire and blazing winds. This is the domain governed by the Red Emperor and ZhuRong, spanning twelve thousand *li*. The Red Emperor is YanDi, son of ShaoDian, known as ShenNong, the Daoist emperor of the south, whose virtue is Fire. ZhuRong is the grandson of ZhuanXu, son of LaoTong, named WuHui. He is also called Li and served as the Fire Minister of GaoXin; he was given the title ZhuRong and, upon death, became the spirit of Fire. His decree states: Confer ranks upon the virtuous, reward the meritorious, bestow kindness upon the worthy and good, relieve hunger and thirst, promote agriculture, aid the impoverished, care for the orphaned and widowed, attend to the weary and sick, dispense great emoluments, enact great rewards, restore ruined ancestral temples, establish heirs for the heirless, enfeoff lords, and appoint worthy ministers. These are responses to the yang qi and its manifestations.

At the central axis, from Kunlun eastward past the Two Heng Mountains—*zi* means "from," *jue* means "to pass." Heng Mountain is Chang Mountain; the "two" is unexplained—lies the path of the sun and moon, the sources of the Jiang and Han rivers. The sun and moon illuminate their traversed paths. The Jiang emerges from Min Mountain, the Han from Fan Zhong Mountain. This is the land of the multitudes, where the five grains thrive, where Longmen, the Yellow River, and the Ji River converge, where the息壤 soil dams the floodwaters of the provinces, extending east to Jieshi. This domain of twelve thousand *li* is governed by the Yellow Emperor and Hou Tu.

The Yellow Emperor, son of ShaoDian, rectified the realm with the virtue of Earth and was titled the Xuanyuan Clan. Upon death, he became the imperial spirit of Earth’s central virtue. Hou Tu was the son of the Gou Long Clan, named Hou Tu, who leveled the nine lands; upon death, he was venerated as the Earth Spirit.

His decree states: Be impartial yet not obsequious, discerning yet not harsh. Envelop and shelter all, moistening (*lu* means "to moisten") without exception. Embrace all with boundless impartiality, rectify and still the self to harmonize. Distribute grain, nourish the aged and infirm, mourn the dead and inquire after the sick, to guide the return of the ten thousand things. Earth is the master of the four directions, hence it is said that the ten thousand things return to it.

At the western extremity, from Kunlun past the Flowing Sands and the Sinking Feathers, west to the land of Sanwei—Flowing Sands likely lie southwest of Kunlun—stand stone cities and golden halls, the realm of the Qi-Drinking People, the land of the Undying. This domain of twelve thousand *li* is governed by Shaohao and Rushou.

Shaohao, son of the Yellow Emperor, was named Qingyang (also called Zhi). He ruled the realm with the virtue of Metal and was titled the Jin Tian Clan. Upon death, he became the imperial spirit of Metal’s western virtue. Rushou was a descendant of the Jin Tian Clan, named Xiu Li; upon death, he became the Metal Spirit.

His decree states: Apply laws with precision, execute only the guilty, guard against thieves and bandits, forbid wickedness and deceit. Adorn the herds and flocks, tend the granaries, repair city walls, mend breaches, block paths, obstruct ditches, halt flowing waters, dam valleys, guard gates and lanes, array weapons and armor, select officials, and punish the lawless. This is the response to Metal’s decisive power.

At the northern extremity, from the Nine Marshes to the farthest reaches of Great Darkness, north to the Valley of Lingzheng—Nine Marshes are the northern marshes; *xia* means "great," *hui* means "darkness"—lies a land of frozen cold, piled ice, snow, hail, frost, and sleet, where waters surge and moisten. This domain of twelve thousand *li* is governed by Zhuanxu and Xuanming.

Zhuanxu, grandson of the Yellow Emperor, ruled the realm with the virtue of Water and was titled the Gaoyang Clan. Upon death, he became the imperial spirit of Water’s northern virtue. The spirit Xuanming was a son of the Jin Tian Clan named Mei, who served as the Master of Dark Obscurity; upon death, he was venerated as the Water Spirit.

His decree states: Enforce prohibitions, secure and store, repair barriers and blockades, mend passes and bridges. Forbid relocation, impose punishments, execute the guilty, close gates and lanes, conduct great searches for outsiders, halt social gatherings, ban nighttime revelry. Close early and open late to block evildoers. Cultivate virtue, hold fast to it. When the celestial mandate nears its end, execute punishments without pardon. Even the most exalted kin must be judged by law. Do not channel water, do not open stores, do not release the guilty. This is the response to Yin’s destructive power.

The Six Harmonies:
- First Spring and First Autumn form a pair,
- Second Spring and Second Autumn form a pair,
- Third Spring and Third Autumn form a pair,
- First Summer and First Winter form a pair,
- Second Summer and Second Winter form a pair,
- Third Summer and Third Winter form a pair.

First Spring begins to lengthen (*ying* means "to grow long"), First Autumn begins to shorten (*suo* means "to contract"). Second Spring begins to emerge, Second Autumn begins to withdraw—*emerge* refers to sowing in the second month; *withdraw* refers to harvest in the eighth month. Third Spring greatly emerges, Third Autumn greatly withdraws. First Summer begins to relax (*huan* means "ease," as in the fourth month’s yang tranquility), First Winter begins to intensify (*ji* means "urgency," as in the tenth month’s cold severity). At the solstice of Second Summer, the sun reaches its northernmost point; at the solstice of Second Winter, it reaches its southernmost point—*short* and *long* both precede the solstice. In Third Summer, virtue is complete; in Third Winter, punishments are complete—*virtue complete* means yang’s power has borne fruit; *punishments complete* means legal cases are concluded.

Thus:
- If governance fails in the first month, cool winds will not arrive in the seventh month;
- If governance fails in the second month, thunder will not retreat in the eighth month;
- If governance fails in the third month, frost will not descend in the ninth month;
- If governance fails in the fourth month, freezing will not occur in the tenth month;
- If governance fails in the fifth month, hibernating creatures will emerge in the eleventh month;
- If governance fails in the sixth month, plants and trees will not shed their leaves in the twelfth month—*not shed* means leaves wither but remain on the branches, failing to fall;
- If governance fails in the seventh month, the first month will suffer unrelenting cold;
- If governance fails in the eighth month, thunder will not sound in the second month;
- If governance fails in the ninth month, spring winds will not cease in the third month—*cease* means "to halt";
- If governance fails in the tenth month, plants and trees will not bear fruit in the fourth month—*bear fruit* means "to grow";
- If governance fails in the eleventh month, hail and frost will fall in the fifth month;
- If governance fails in the twelfth month, the six grains will grow wildly in the sixth month—*grow wildly* means to bear fruit without flowering.

When spring enacts summer’s mandate, it leaks—an image of exuberant yang dispersing. When it enacts autumn’s mandate, it brings water—water is born in *shen* (the ninth Earthly Branch), hence water. When it enacts winter’s mandate, it becomes stern—an image of qi’s severity.

When summer enacts spring’s mandate, it brings wind—an image of spring’s abundant wood qi. When it enacts autumn’s mandate, it brings desolation—an image of autumn’s withered growth. When it enacts winter’s mandate, it becomes obstructed—*obstructed* means "divided," an image of winter’s severed punishments, where grace and favor fail to flow downward.

When autumn enacts summer’s mandate, it blossoms—an image of summer’s flourishing trees. When it enacts spring’s mandate, it flourishes—an image of spring’s burgeoning growth. When it enacts winter’s mandate, it withers—*wither* means "to fall and scatter."

When winter enacts spring’s mandate, it leaks—an image of spring’s spreading dispersal. When it enacts summer’s mandate, it brings drought—an image of scorching yang.

When autumn enacts autumn’s mandate, it brings mist—autumn’s qi is yin, hence the chaotic fog.

The Great System of Yin and Yang comprises six measures:
Heaven is the *plumb line*,
Earth is the *level*,
Spring is the *compass*,
Summer is the *balance*,
Autumn is the *square*,
Winter is the *weight*.

The *plumb line* serves to align all things.
*Align* means "to correct."
The *level* serves to level all things.
The *compass* serves to encircle all things.
The *balance* serves to balance all things.
The *square* serves to square all things.
The *weight* serves to weigh all things.

The *plumb line* as measure:
straight yet not contentious,
long yet not exhausted,
enduring yet not worn,
distant yet not forgotten.
In virtue it joins with Heaven,
in clarity it joins with the divine.
What it desires is attained,
what it detests vanishes.
From ancient times to the present,
it cannot be altered or deflected.
Its power is most precise,
vast and all-embracing.
Thus the Supreme Lord makes it the root of all things.
*Root* means "foundation."

The *level* as measure:
even yet not treacherous,
impartial yet not biased,
vast and all-embracing,
generous and harmonious,
soft yet not weak,
sharp yet not broken.
*Sharp* means "keen."
*Broken* means "to snap."
Flowing yet not stagnant,
*Flowing* means "moving."
*Stagnant* means "to halt."
Easy yet not corrupt,
penetrating and well-ordered.
*Ordered* means "guided by the Way."
Perfectly contained yet not leaking,
level and never failing,
all things are made even,
the people harbor no treacherous schemes,
resentment and malice do not arise.
Thus the Supreme Lord makes it the leveler of all things.
*Level* means "to correct"—read as the *evenness* of judgment.

The *compass* as measure:
revolving yet not blocked,
encircling yet not tangled.
*Blocked* means "obstructed."
*Tangled* means "entwined."
Gentle yet not indulgent,
vast and accommodating.
With reason it moves and stirs,
with order it penetrates.
Calm and unhurried,
no grievances arise.
*Calm and unhurried* describes its ease and spaciousness.
When the compass’s measure is not lost,
the qi of life is set in order.
The types of qi are regulated and made clear.

The *balance* as measure:
unhurried yet not delayed,
even yet not resented,
bestowing yet not claiming virtue,
consoling yet not demanding.
It constantly levels the people’s emoluments,
supplementing what is insufficient.
Vibrant and flourishing,
it acts only in accord with virtue.
Nurturing growth and transformation,
all things thrive and prosper,
the five grains mature,
borders are filled.
When its governance does not err,
Heaven and Earth become luminous.
*Luminous* means "ordered."

The *square* as measure:
solemn yet not perverse,
firm yet not confused,
taking yet not resented,
inward yet not harmful.
Majestic and stern yet not intimidating,
its commands are executed without fail.
When killing and punishment are justly applied,
enemies are subdued.
When the square’s measure is not lost,
all punishments are obeyed.

The *weight* as measure:
urgent yet not excessive,
lethal yet not cruel,
filled to abundance,
perfectly contained yet not leaking.
It destroys yet does not seize,
executes for crimes yet does not pardon.
Sincere and steadfast,
unyielding and resolute.
It hopes to eliminate harsh wickedness,
and cannot be bent.
Thus when winter’s governance is about to be enacted,
it must weaken the strong,
must soften the rigid.
When the weight’s measure is not lost,
all things are stored away.

The system of the Hall of Light:
at rest, it models the *level*;
in motion, it models the *plumb line*.
Spring governs with the *compass*,
autumn governs with the *square*,
winter governs with the *weight*,
summer governs with the *balance*.
Thus dryness, dampness, cold, and heat arrive in proper season,
sweet rain and fertile dew descend in due time.

**Surveying the Hidden**

Surveying the Hidden observes the origins of dark and mysterious transformations. When utmost essence moves Heaven, it penetrates without limit—hence the title *Surveying the Hidden*, by which this chapter is named.

In ancient times, Master Kuang played the melody *White Snow*, and numinous beings descended in response. Violent winds and sudden rains assailed the land; Duke Ping fell gravely ill, and the state of Jin was scorched by drought. *White Snow* is the name of a melody played on the fifty-stringed zither of the Great One. Numinous beings refer to those transformed by the divine—such as black cranes arriving, or headless ghosts brandishing spears in dance. Duke Ping was the son of Duke Dao of Jin, named Biao. His grave illness was called *□-disease*. *Red earth* signifies drought. Only a sagely ruler could master such portents and avert disaster. Duke Ping’s virtue was meager, and he could not endure it; thus he fell gravely ill, and great drought ensued.

A lowly woman cried out to Heaven, and thunder and lightning struck down the terrace of Duke Jing. His limbs were broken, and the sea surged forth. This woman, a humble widow of Qi, childless and unwed, served her mother-in-law with utmost reverence. The mother-in-law, having no son but only a daughter, coveted her daughter’s wealth and ordered her to remarry the widow. The widow refused, so the daughter murdered her mother and framed the widow. Unable to clear her name, the widow’s grievance rose to Heaven, which answered with thunder and lightning, shattering Duke Jing’s terrace. The terrace crumbled, his limbs were maimed, and the sea overflowed its bounds.

Now, the blind musician and the lowly woman held the basest of ranks, their authority lighter than a feather. *Shang* means "to preside"; *xi* refers to *xi’er*, a kind of vegetable. In You and Ji, it is called *tan cai*; in the Luo region, *hu xi*. Those who preside over such matters hold the most insignificant offices. The blind musician and the lowly woman were even lower in rank than those who oversaw such trifles—hence their authority was said to be lighter than a feather. Yet by concentrating their essence, steeling their will, and accumulating spirit, they ascended to the Nine Heavens, rousing the utmost essence. The Nine Heavens are the eight directions and the center. Through sincerity and devotion, they moved it.

From this, we see that Heaven’s judgment is inescapable. Though one may hide in desolate wastes, remote and concealed, buried deep in stone chambers, or shielded by perilous barriers, there is no refuge. *Heaven* refers to the Supreme Emperor, whose divine clarity is absolute. It means that even if one conceals or flees their crimes, they will still be punished. Thus, there is no escape.

When King Wu campaigned against Zhou, he crossed the Meng Ford, and the waves of Yang Hou surged against the current to strike him. Yang Hou was the marquis of Lingyang, whose state bordered water. He drowned, and his spirit became capable of summoning great waves to harm others—hence the name *Yang Hou’s Waves*. Fierce winds and darkening skies obscured men and horses from one another. Then King Wu grasped the yellow battle-axe in his left hand and the white yak-tail banner in his right, glared fiercely, and brandished them, declaring: *"I bear the mandate of all under Heaven—who dares oppose my will?"* At once, the winds stilled, and the waves subsided. *Ji* means "to cease."

Duke Yang of Lu waged war with Han, and as the battle raged into dusk, he raised his halberd and beckoned the sun, which retreated three *she*. Duke Yang was a county lord of Chu, grandson of King Ping of Chu and son of Sima Ziqi—known in the *Guoyu* as Duke Wen of Lu Yang. Though Chu had usurped the title of king, its county governors were still called dukes, hence *Duke Yang of Lu*. The present-day Lu Yang in Nanyang is the same place. *Han* refers to the moment when battle reaches its climax. Beckoning the sun caused it to retreat three *she*. A *she* is a day’s lodging.

To preserve one’s nature and safeguard truth, never harming one’s person—when pressed by dire peril, one’s essence communicates with Heaven. As for those who have never strayed from their origin, what could they not accomplish? *Essence communicating with Heaven* refers to the sage whose inherent nature aligns with the celestial, thus receiving Heaven’s aid. *Origin* is the root of the Dao—meaning one’s nature does not stray outward, and life remains in harmony with the Dao.

Death and life share the same realm; they cannot be coerced or overpowered. A single warrior, valiant and fierce, may become the hero of three armies. *Wu* means "warrior"; in the Jiang-Huai region, warriors are called *wu*. Such men seek only fame, yet even those who bind themselves to a purpose achieve such feats—how much more so those who take Heaven and Earth as their palace, embracing the myriad things? *Embracing* means to enfold, as in a sack. They befriend the workings of creation—creation being the interplay of yin and yang—and treat it as a companion. They contain the utmost harmony, outwardly resembling human form, yet within, they hold the great Dao. They observe the Nine and penetrate the One, knowing what is unknown. The *Nine* are the Nine Heavens; the *One* is the tortoise. By observing the changes of the Nine Heavens and divining the cracks in tortoise shells, even the unknown becomes as clear as stone. Yet their hearts never die. *Hearts that never die* refers to those whose minds are born in harmony with the Dao, not like those who merely observe the Nine and penetrate the One.

Long ago, Yongmen Zi visited Lord Mengchang with his weeping. Yongmen Zi, named Zhou, was skilled in the zither and renowned for his weeping. Yongmen was the western gate of Qi; he lived nearby and took it as his surname. *Weeping* here is akin to singing; *visited* means to move. Lord Mengchang was Tian Wen, the prime minister of Qi. After Yongmen Zi spoke, pouring out his heart and raising his voice, Lord Mengchang sighed deeply, his sobs uncontrollable, tears streaming down in torrents. *Zeng* means "repeated"; *jue yi* signifies a loss of voice. *Lang li* means "crossing and crisscrossing." *Jue* is pronounced like the *yang* in *yuanyang*; *yi* like the *yu* in *yin yu* from the *Zuozhuan*. When spirit takes form within, it outwardly conveys sorrow to the human heart—this is the untransmittable Dao. It means that through sincerity and grief, one can move another’s heart in ways that cannot be learned, hence the *untransmittable Dao*. If an ordinary person, ignorant of their lord’s bearing, were to mimic his expression, they would surely be ridiculed.

The "lordly form" refers to the utmost essence taking shape. Thus, Pujuzi could strike birds at a hundred *ren* in the sky—Pujuzi was a man of Chu, skilled in archery; seven *chi* make one *ren*. And Zhan He could lure fish in the great abyss—Zhan He was a man of Chu versed in the arts of the Dao. It speaks of his skill in angling, making fish rush toward the hook, hence "luring fish." They both attained the Dao of purity and tranquility, the harmony of the Great Vastness. For the resonance of things, subtle and profound, lies beyond the reach of knowledge to discuss or eloquence to unravel.

Thus, when the east wind arrives, wine brims over—the east wind is the wind of wood, and *zhan* wine is clear wine. As things descend and settle, it is called *zhan*. The sour taste of wood enters the wine, causing it to ferment and overflow, for things of a kind resonate. Silkworms chew silk and the *shang* string snaps, for some influence moves them. Old silkworms spin silk from their mouths, hence "chewing silk." New silk is brittle, and the *shang* note, the finest and most urgent of the five tones, thus breaks. *Er* may also be written as *earrings*—when silkworms age, the silk within their bodies turns yellow, appearing externally like earrings. *Shang* is the metal tone of the west, while the silkworm is the fire of *wu*. Fire in its prime restrains metal, so it responds only to *shang*, or perhaps it is the resonance of old and new. Drawings follow ash as the moon wanes, and when the whale dies, comets appear, for some movement stirs them. *Yun* is read as *encirclement* in *lianwei*. *Yun* means military—when armies besiege one another, the moon’s encirclement appears. If one draws a circle with reed ash beneath the moonlight and leaves one side open, the moon’s encirclement above will likewise wane. The whale, a great fish stretching several *li*, dies by the seashore. The fish’s body is base, while the comet is an omen of calamity, a harm to man—things of a kind move one another.

Thus, when the sage holds office, embracing the Dao without speech, his beneficence extends to the myriad people. The sage practices the natural and effortless Dao, so his blessings reach all. When lord and minister are at odds, deceit appears in the heavens, for spirit and qi respond, and signs manifest. The five-colored qi beside the sun, when they emerge outward on both sides, are called *bei* (turning away); outward-facing is *jue* (deceit), inward-facing is *er* (earrings), and when they emerge above, it is called *guan* (crown). Thus, mountain clouds resemble grass and trees, water clouds resemble fish scales—the qi of mountains forms clouds like vegetation, while the qi of water forms clouds like fish scales. Drought clouds resemble smoke and fire, while flood clouds resemble waves—each takes the form of its kind, thus moving one another. Drought clouds, born of scorching yang, resemble smoke and fire. *Cen* means great accumulation of water; clouds arising from *cen* resemble waves.

The yang burning-mirror draws fire from the sun, and the *fangzhu* gathers dew from the moon—*fu* is read as in *dafu* (grandee), as explained above. Another saying holds that water and fire derive from the Great Ultimate, present in man’s hands, yet beyond comprehension. Between heaven and earth, even the most skilled reckoner cannot enumerate their number. *Qiao* means skilled—between heaven and earth, the resonances of things are myriad, and even those skilled in calendrical arts cannot exhaust their count. The hand grasps in an instant, yet cannot seize their light. Though the hand may grasp at things in a fleeting moment, it cannot capture their brilliance. Another saying holds that the Dao of heaven is vast; though the hand may grasp at the formless and fleeting, it cannot seize the light of sun and moon.

Yet within the palm’s grasp, drawing things into the Great Ultimate above—the Great Ultimate is the time when heaven and earth first took shape; *above* means *beginning*—water and fire can be instantly summoned, for yin and yang share qi and move one another. *Move* means *transform*. This is why the tradition speaks of riding the tail of *Chen*—it tells how King Wuding of Yin dreamed of a worthy man, had artisans depict his likeness, and sought him far and wide, finding Fu Yue at Fu Rock, whom he made his minister. Fu Yue then composed the eighty-one tallying omens for Gaozong, bringing about a revival. In death, his spirit lodged in the star *Chenwei*, also called *Ce*.

Thus, utmost yin whispers, and utmost yang blazes. When the two intertwine and harmonize, the myriad things are born. If there were only males without females, what transformation could bring forth creation? This is the eloquence of silence, the Dao that cannot be spoken.

Thus, to summon the distant, act without acting—the distant are the four barbarians. To transform the distant lands, one must practice non-action, and the barbarian wastes will come of their own accord. To draw near those close, act without trouble—the near are the central states. To bring near those close, one must be without trouble, and those nearby will naturally attach themselves. Only those who walk in the night can possess this. *Walking in the night* is a metaphor for acting in darkness—acting through spiritual transformation, one can possess the world. Another saying holds that entering the Dao is like walking in darkness; only thus can one possess the way to summon the distant and draw near the close.

Thus, turn back the horses to manure the fields, and the ruts of chariots will not reach beyond distant lands—this is a saying of Laozi. Stop the horses from running and use them only for manure, the effect of practicing utmost virtue. Another saying holds that when a ruler lacks the Dao, warhorses breed in the wilds; without trouble, one stops the running horses to manure the fields, so the ruts of war chariots do not reach beyond distant lands. The space between two wheels is called a *rut*.

This is called sitting still while galloping, sinking while floating, brightening the night and darkening the day—sitting still yet acting through spiritual transformation, swifter than couriers; sinking and floating, darkening and brightening, in harmony with the Dao. To melt glue in winter or make ice in summer—of the Dao, there is no partiality in approach or departure. The capable have abundance, the clumsy fall short. It speaks of melting glue out of season or making ice in summer, tasks difficult to accomplish. The Dao of heaven is impartial in approach and departure; those who practice the Dao achieve more than enough.

Those who follow it prosper; those who oppose it meet misfortune. It is like the Pearl of Marquis Sui or the Jade Disc of Bian He—those who gain them grow rich, while those who lose them fall into poverty.

Marquis Sui was a vassal of the Ji clan in the state of Handong. Once, he saw a great serpent wounded and severed, so he applied medicine to heal it. Later, the serpent carried a large pearl from the river to repay him, and thus it was called the Pearl of Marquis Sui, also known as the Luminous Moon Pearl. Bian He of Chu found a raw jade in the mountains of Jing and presented it to King Wu. The king showed it to a jade appraiser, who dismissed it as mere stone, so the king had Bian He’s left foot cut off. When King Wen ascended the throne, Bian He presented it again, but it was still deemed stone, and his right foot was severed. Clutching the uncut jade, he wept blood. When King Cheng came to power, Bian He offered it once more. King Cheng said, “My predecessors took cutting off feet lightly but prized splitting stones.” He had the jade split open, and indeed, a fine piece of jade was found, which was fashioned into a disc—pure white and luminous in the night. This jade existed before the Spring and Autumn period, but since King Cheng did not record it, it was not documented.

The measure of gain and loss is profound and obscure, difficult to discern or debate. How do we know this? Consider the herb *dihuang*, which governs the bones, and licorice, which promotes flesh—if one demands that *dihuang* generate flesh or that licorice strengthen bones, it is like Wangsun Chuo hoping to double the dose of a medicine for partial paralysis to revive the dead. Such reasoning is surely flawed. Wangsun Chuo was a man of Zhou, said to be a descendant of Wangsun Jia of Wei. He claimed that a single dose could cure partial paralysis and sought to double it to revive the dead.

Just as fire can scorch wood, so too can it melt metal—this is the Way in action. Yet if one expects a lodestone to attract tiles as it does iron, it will prove difficult. Things cannot be judged by mere weight. The fire-drill draws flame from the sun, the lodestone draws iron, and crabs spoil lacquer—when crabs are placed in lacquer, it rots and fails to dry, becoming unusable. Sunflowers turn toward the sun, yet even the wise cannot make them do otherwise. Thus, the discernment of the eyes and ears is insufficient to fathom the principles of things, and the reasoning of the mind cannot settle right and wrong.

Therefore, those who govern by cunning struggle to maintain the state; only those who comprehend the Great Harmony and uphold the responses of nature can master it. When Yao Mountain collapses, the Boluo River runs dry—Yao Mountain lies in Yongzhou, while the Boluo River flows through Linjin in Fengyi, their depths interconnected. Some say the Boluo is the Jing River. When Ou Ye was born, the sword *Chunjun* was forged. *Ou* is pronounced like *ge’ou*. Ou Ye was a Yue man, a master swordsmith. *Chunjun* was an ancient, razor-sharp sword. When King Zhou of Shang indulged in tyranny, Zuo Qiang stood by his side—Zuo Qiang was a flattering minister who encouraged the king’s excesses. Yet Taigong lived in the same era, and thus King Wu’s achievements were established.

From this, we see that the paths of advantage and harm, the gates of fortune and misfortune, cannot be sought or attained. Their thresholds cannot be known in advance. They arrive suddenly, escaping all form.

The Dao and virtue are like rawhide and tanned leather—when you seek to distance yourself, they draw near; when you draw near, they recede. Leather’s essence mirrors the Dao, while rawhide’s essence mirrors virtue. If you wish to distance yourself from the Dao, it remains at your side; if you seek it through effort, it withdraws far from you. Those who act without contrivance are close to others; those who act with contrivance grow distant.

Without grasping the Dao, one gazes at the minnow—visible in the water yet unattainable, just as the Dao is. Thus, the sage is like a mirror: neither sending off nor welcoming, responding without concealing. The mirror reflects beauty or ugliness without hiding anything. Thus, the myriad transformations proceed without harm.

Those who claim to have attained it have already lost it; those who admit to losing it may yet attain it. To believe one has grasped the Dao is to have already lost it; to believe one has lost the Dao is not necessarily to be without it.

Consider the tuning of strings: strike the *gong* note, and the *gong* string resonates; pluck the *jiao* note, and the *jiao* string vibrates—this is the harmony of like sounds. Strike the great *gong*, and the lesser *gong* responds; pluck the great *jiao*, and the lesser *jiao* stirs. Thus, like tones harmonize. Yet if one adjusts a single string so that it no longer aligns with the five notes and strikes it, all twenty-five strings resonate—this is not because the sound differs, but because the ruler of tones has taken form. That single string is the *gong* note, the ruler of tones, so all twenty-five strings harmonize. Another interpretation: adjusting one string so it no longer matches the five notes is tuning it to the *gong* sound, hence it is said to be “not different from sound.” The five notes are governed by this single tone, so the ruler of tones has manifested.

Those who comprehend the Great Harmony are as if in a sweet slumber, drunk and at ease, wandering within it without knowing how they arrived. The Great Harmony refers to the harmony of life and death, the equality of poverty and prosperity. Within it lies the center of the Dao, yet one does not know how one came to be there. Utterly immersed, dull and dazed to the end, as if never having left their origin—*chun* means unity, *wen* means harmony, *lun* means sinking, a metaphor for concealment. *Dunmen* means without emotion, desiring to begin and end in the Dao. *Zong* means origin, as if form had never existed. This is called the Great Penetration.

Now, when the red *chi* and blue *qiu* dragons roam Jizhou, the sky is clear and the earth is still; venomous beasts do not stir, and birds do not take fright. They enter the thickets, feeding on *jianmei*—*jianmei* is a grass fruit resembling mulberries, red in color, growing by the riverside.

Tasting sweetness in their mouths, they never step beyond the bounds of fields and acres, yet serpents and eels scorn them, deeming them unfit to contend in the rivers and seas. *Zanwei* means long and fine. Serpents and eels believe themselves superior to the red *chi* and blue *qiu* dragons.

When at last the dark clouds gather at dawn—*xuan* means black, *su* means white—black clouds rise and converge in the bright morning. Yin and yang clash in strife, descending in a whirlwind, mingling with freezing rain. *Jiang* means to descend; *fufeng* is a fierce gale; *dongyu* is a torrential downpour. They surge upward in a spiraling ascent, riding the wind and rain away. Their might shakes heaven and earth, their roar resounds across the four seas, so that all within them stand in awe.

Serpents and eels bury themselves in mud a hundred *ren* deep—a *ren* is seven hundred feet, and *ren* also denotes the depth of waves, as the saying goes, "measured in *ren* for ditches and channels." Bears and brown bears crawl among jagged peaks, tigers and leopards slink into their dens and dare not roar. *Xi* means to enter; *pao* means to howl. Gibbons and langurs stumble and lose their grip on the branches—*you* is pronounced like *yi* in the phrase "to bestow a gift" from the people of Zhongshan. *You* refers to a kind of gibbon with a long tail and upturned nose. How much less, then, could mere serpents and eels compare?

When the phoenix soars, it is the advent of supreme virtue—the male is called *feng*, the female *huang*—a sign of a ruler of utmost virtue come to alight. Thunder does not rumble, wind and rain do not arise, rivers and valleys do not overflow—*dan* means to flood. The grasses and trees stand still, yet swallows and sparrows mock them, thinking themselves too nimble to vie with the phoenix in the vastness of the cosmos. Swallows and sparrows believe their own agility surpasses that of the phoenix. *Jiao* may also be written as *xiao*, meaning to cry. *Yu* refers to the eaves of a house, *zhou* to its ridgepole, as the *Yi* says, "Above, the ridgepole; below, the eaves."

Yet when the phoenix ascends to the heights of ten thousand *ren*—*ceng* means high, *shi* means to fly, or to turn—soaring beyond the four seas—*wai* means beyond. One wing rising and falling is called *ao*, gliding without movement is called *xiang*. It passes the *Shupu* gardens of Kunlun, drinks from the rushing rapids of *Dizhu*—*Shupu* lies atop Kunlun; *guo* means to traverse. *Dizhu* is a narrow stretch of the Yellow River, east of Dayang in Hedong. *□* is swift water, *lai* is clear, both describing swift, surging currents. It circles the islets of *Mengsi*—*zhanhui* means to linger, *Mengsi* refers to the source of a river where water spills forth, then returns to form an islet. An islet is a small sandbar. Lingering at the borders of Jizhou, it crosses *Duguang*, enters the land of *Yijie*—*nie* means to reach; *Duguang* is a mountain in the southeast, where the myriad spirits ascend and descend. It is said that the phoenix passes the wilds of *Guangdu*, escorting the sun to the land of *Yijie*, illustrating the vastness of its flight. *Nie* may also be written as *jue*, meaning to traverse; *jing* means to pass; *jue* means to cross.

Its wings skim the Weak Waters, and at dusk it roosts in the Wind Cave, bathing its feathers upon the Weak Waters. The Wind Cave is where the cold north wind issues from the earth. At this time, swans, cranes, and storks all cower in terror, fleeing to hide, pressing their beaks to the riverbanks—*zhuihui* means their beaks press to the ground, motionless. *Yi* means edge. How much less could mere swallows and sparrows compare?

This reveals those who understand the traces of small movements yet remain ignorant of the source of great principles.

In ancient times, when Wang Liang and Zaofu drove their chariots—Wang Liang was a grandee of Jin who served as charioteer to Wuxu, known as the skilled driver Liang. Also called Sun Wuzheng, he drove for Viscount Jian of Zhao and, after death, his spirit ascended to the star Tian Si, the star Wang Liang in the celestial charts. Zaofu, of the Ying clan, was a descendant of Boyi and son of Feilian, who served as charioteer to King Mu of Zhou—upon mounting the chariot and taking up the reins, the horses stood in perfect order and harmony. *Zhengqi* means without deviation; *lianxie* means the horses’ bearing and limbs were well-coordinated. Their steps were evenly measured, their exertion and rest as one—*yi* means unity of heart. Their spirits were joyful, their qi harmonious, their bodies agile and swift—*bi* means quick. At ease with labor and delighting in progress, they galloped as if vanishing—*mie* means to disappear, describing their speed. Turning left and right as if guided by a whip—*zuoyou* refers to the outer horses; the force of their steps was as if whipped. Another interpretation: the ease of wielding the whip to instruct them. Circling like a ring, as if following the driver’s will. The world regarded them as masters of their craft, yet their true worth remained unseen.

But when Qian Qie and Tai Bing drove—these two were charioteers of the Great Unity. Another interpretation: ancient adepts of the Dao who guided yin and yang with spirit and qi—they cast aside reins and bits, discarded whips and goads. The chariot moved of its own accord without being driven, the horses ran of their own will without being urged. They merely relied on the chariot and horses as vessels, their spirit and qi sustaining them. The sun traveled, the moon shifted, stars gleamed and the heavens turned—*yao* means to shine; *xuan* means the sky; *yun* means to move. Lightning bolted and ghosts leapt. Advancing and retreating, bending and stretching, no trace or boundary was visible—*zhen* means sign; *yin* means form. Thus, they did not beckon or shout, yet outpaced the returning geese at Mount Jieshi—describing the speed of their driving, arriving at their destination before the geese, which were then sent north to Jieshi, where the passing geese were overtaken. *Guo* is read as "to surpass." They overtook the *kuji* at Guyu—*yi* means to surpass from behind. Guyu is a mountain in Wu; *kuji* is another name for the phoenix. It is said that their driving was so swift that after passing the geese at Jieshi, they turned southeast and overtook the *kuji* at Guyu. They raced as if flying, dashed as if vanishing, treading upon the wind, chasing the whirlwind home—*zong* means to tread; swift as an arrow. *Nie* means to step. Another interpretation: the arrow was behind, unable to catch up, hence the word *zong*.

Their movement was swift, able to overtake an arrow—this is what *nie* describes. They pursued the *biao* and caught it. *Biao* refers to light with a shadow within. Suddenly, they returned, all reaching this point—speaking of their speed. They set out at dawn from *Tuan Sang* and entered the sun at *Luo Tang*. *Tuan Sang* is where the sun rises; *Luo Tang* is a mountain name, where the sun sets. This describes how non-action achieves its use. *Fei yong* means non-action. It was not through the scrutiny of thought or the skill of hands and claws, but rather that desires took shape in their hearts while their spirit harmonized with the six horses—this is governing by non-governing. It speaks of concealing the form of desires within the breast. *Yu* means harmony. Governing by non-governing means governing through the arts of the Dao.

In ancient times, the Yellow Emperor ruled the world, with Li Mu and Tai Shan Ji assisting him. Li Mu and Tai Shan Ji were the Yellow Emperor’s teachers. Mencius said, "The king’s teachers are his ministers." They regulated the movements of the sun and moon, *lü* meaning measure. They governed the *qi* of yin and yang, moderated the measures of the four seasons, corrected the calculations of pitch-pipes and calendars, distinguished male and female, differentiated the sexes, clarified hierarchy, ranked nobility, ensured the strong did not oppress the weak, the many did not bully the few, and the people preserved their lives without premature death—securing their nature and destiny without early demise. The seasons ripened without calamity—*bu xiong* meaning no disasters. The hundred officials were upright and selfless, all acting for the public good. Above and below were in harmony without grievance—rulers and ministers in accord, without fault. Laws and commands were clear and not obscured; assistants were impartial and not sycophantic; ministers and officials were just, not bending to private interests. Farmers did not encroach on boundaries; fishermen did not contend over deep pools—*wei* being the secluded depths where fish gather. No one picked up lost items on the road; markets did not engage in speculative pricing; city gates were not barred—*guan* meaning closed. Villages had no thieves; travelers in the countryside deferred to one another with their wealth, speaking of having abundance. Dogs and pigs spat out beans and grain on the roads without stirring quarrels. Thus, the sun and moon were bright and clear, the stars did not deviate from their courses, wind and rain came in season, the five grains ripened, tigers and wolves did not recklessly bite, birds of prey did not recklessly strike, phoenixes alighted in the courtyards—*xiang* meaning to rest—and qilin roamed the outskirts—*you* meaning to move. The outskirts were beyond the city. The Azure Dragon advanced to draw the chariot; the *Fei Huang* crouched in the stables. *Fei Huang* is the *Cheng Huang*, emerging from the west, shaped like a fox with horns on its back, living a thousand years. *Zao* means stable.

The states of Zhu Bei and Dan Er all presented their tributes and duties—both being northernmost barbarian lands. Yet even this did not match the Dao of Fu Xi. In ancient times, the four pillars collapsed, the nine provinces split—*lie* meaning divided; *fei* meaning broken. Heaven did not fully cover, earth did not completely bear. Fire blazed fiercely without extinguishing; water surged boundlessly without receding—*xi* meaning to subside. Fierce beasts devoured the innocent people—*zhuan* meaning good—and birds of prey snatched the old and weak—*jue* meaning to seize. Then Nü Wa smelted the five-colored stones to mend the azure sky. Nü Wa was a yin emperor, assisting Fu Xi in governance. During the Three Sovereigns’ era, heaven was deficient in the northwest, so she mended it—so the masters say. She severed the turtle’s legs to prop up the four pillars. *Ao* is a giant turtle. With heaven broken, she used the turtle’s legs as pillars. The *Chu Ci* says, "The turtle bears the mountain below—how could it be stable?" She slew the Black Dragon to aid Jizhou. The Black Dragon was the essence of water. Li Mu and Tai Ji killed it to stop the rain—*ji* meaning to assist. Jizhou was among the nine provinces, referring to the present lands within the four seas. She piled up reed ashes to halt the flooding waters. Reeds grow in water, so she amassed their ashes to stop the floods. Flooding waters rise from flat ground. The azure sky was mended, the four pillars set right, the flooding waters dried, Jizhou leveled, vicious creatures died, and the innocent people lived. *Chong* means beasts. Facing the square earth, embracing the round heaven, harmonizing spring’s warmth and summer’s heat, restraining autumn’s severity and winter’s harshness, resting the head on a square pillow and sleeping straight—*fang* being a four-inch carpenter’s square. *Qin sheng* means lying straight. Where yin and yang were congested and blocked, she opened the passages; where rebellious *qi* and perverse things harmed the people with their thick accumulation, she severed and halted them. *Ni qi* means chaotic *qi*.

The hoarded wealth that harmed the people and creatures—thus she severed and halted it.

At that time, she slept in tranquil repose and rose with vacant gaze. *Juju* means sleeping without thought or care; *ju* is read as the emptiness of *xu*. *Mianmian* describes a look devoid of cunning or guile. Some took themselves for horses, others for oxen; their gait was stumbling, their gaze dim. *Dian* is read as the *tian* of *tianyan*. All, in their simplicity, attained harmony, knowing not whence it arose. They wandered aimlessly, seeking nothing, and specters knew not where to go.

In that era, birds and beasts, vipers and serpents—none failed to conceal their claws and fangs, to hide their stings and venom, for none harbored intent to rend or devour. Assessing her meritorious deeds, above they reached the Nine Heavens, below they matched the Yellow Loam. Above, they joined the Nine Heavens; below, they harmonized with the Yellow Loam—the Yellow Springs beneath hold the earth’s loam. *Lu* is read as the *lu* of *shenglu*.

Her fame resounded through later ages, her radiance outshone the myriad things, lending luster to all. She rode a thunder chariot, yoked to a responding dragon, flanked by azure *qiu*. The central pair were the *fu* steeds; the outer, the *can*. Those with horns were dragons; those without, *qiu*. Another account holds that the responding dragon was a winged dragon. She grasped auspicious omens, spread the *luo* charts as her mat—the *jue* pearls of fortune she drew to herself. The charts were arrayed as her seat. Another account says the *luo* charts were the chariot’s seat.

Yellow clouds enveloped her, a white *chi* led before, and a darting serpent followed behind. *Luo* is read as the *lu* of *daolu*, referring to the chariot’s trailing adornments. Yellow cloud-qi wreathed her chariot; the white *chi* guided ahead. The *benshe* was a soaring serpent, trailing behind—all auspicious signs.

Wandering at ease, she communed with ghosts and spirits, ascended the Nine Heavens—the Nine Heavens being the eight directions and the center. She paid court to the Emperor at the Spirit Gate, attending the Supreme Emperor at the Spirit Gate. Serene and harmonious, she rested beneath the Great Ancestor—*mi* means tranquility; *mu*, harmony; *xiu*, repose. The Great Ancestor is the great lineage of the Dao.

Yet she did not display her merits nor proclaim her fame—*zhang* and *yang* both mean to make manifest. She concealed the Way of the Perfected Person, following the inherent nature of Heaven and Earth. *Yin* means to hide; the Perfected Person is one of true virtue. *Gu* means natural. Why? The Dao and virtue reached upward, and cunning and artifice vanished. For wisdom is but craft and deceit.

By the time of Xia Jie, the ruler was benighted and unenlightened, the Dao neglected and unrefined. The ways of benevolence and righteousness were no longer cultivated—hence it is said to be *lanman*. He cast aside the grace and punishments of the Five Emperors, overturned the legal records of the Three Kings. Thus, the utmost virtue perished and was not exalted; the imperial Dao was obscured and did not rise. *Xing* means to elevate.

His actions defied the Azure Heaven, his decrees ran counter to the four seasons. *Li* means to oppose. Spring and autumn withdrew their harmony; Heaven and Earth stripped away their virtue. *Suo* means to withdraw—speaking of harmony no longer prevailing. His deeds grew daily more vile, yet he knew it not—hence it is said their virtue was stripped away.
