The lord’s Dao is round: it revolves without end, for end means limit. His transformative nurturance is divine, empty and following the natural course, ever yielding and never leading. The minister’s Dao is also round: it revolves without fixed direction, judging rightness to act appropriately, initiating affairs, and upholding duties with clarity to achieve success.

Thus, when lord and minister follow distinct Daos, there is order, and their harmony cannot be altered. When they share the same Dao, there is chaos. If the lord deems something acceptable and the minister also says it is acceptable, if the lord deems something unacceptable and the minister also says it is unacceptable, this is sameness. Without mutual correction, it is called chaos.

When each attains what is fitting and occupies their proper place, superiors and inferiors have means to employ one another. The lord fulfills the lord’s Dao, the minister fulfills the minister’s Dao—this is called attaining what is fitting. When the lord governs with a mind yielding in intent and perception clear yet unobscured, all ministers converge like spokes to a hub, and none—whether foolish or wise, worthy or unworthy—fails to exhaust their abilities. Then the lord attains the means to govern his ministers, and the ministers attain the means to serve their lord. The Dao of governing the state is thus illuminated.

King Wen was wise yet fond of inquiry, hence his sagacity. Fond of inquiry, he wished to share merit with others. King Wu was brave yet fond of inquiry, hence his victory—his triumph over Yin. For he who rides the wisdom of the multitude can undertake anything; he who employs the strength of the multitude can overcome anything.

A weight of a thousand *jun*—even Wu Huo could not lift it. A *jun* equals ten thousand *jin*. Wu Huo was the mighty warrior of King Wu of Qin. When the king tested his strength by having him lift a great tripod, his wrist gave way and he could not bear it—hence it is said he could not lift it. Yet when the multitude unites as one, even a hundred men have strength to spare.

Thus, to rely on the strength of a single man is to find even Wu Huo insufficient—for he could not prevail, and so cannot be depended upon. But he who harnesses the control of the multitude finds the whole world not enough to contain him. With many hands and mighty force, even the world seems small—hence it is said there is not enough to possess.

Yu dredged the Yangtze and channeled the Yellow River to bring benefit to all under heaven, yet he could not make the waters flow westward. Ji cleared the land and tilled the soil to encourage the people to devote themselves to agriculture, yet he could not make grain grow in winter. Was this because human effort fell short? No—it was the nature of things that made it impossible. When the momentum of circumstances cannot be forced, and one does not follow the principles of the Dao, even the most divine sage cannot bring success—how much less a ruler of the present age?

A weak horse pulling a heavy load—even Zaofu could not make it go far. Zaofu was the master charioteer of King Mu of Zhou. But with a light carriage and fine horses, even an average driver can make them run swiftly. Thus, when the sage undertakes a task, how could he go against the principles of the Dao or defy the nature of things—twisting the crooked into straight, bending the bent into extended? He has never failed to work with what is given.

Therefore, what pooled strength can lift is never too heavy to overcome, and what collective wisdom can accomplish is never too difficult to achieve. The deaf may be made to shout orders, but not to hear; the mute may be made to guard the gates, but not to speak. The body has its limitations, and abilities have their bounds.

Thus, one form occupies one position, and one skill serves one task. When strength matches the burden, the lifter does not find it heavy; when ability suits the task, the doer does not find it difficult. Whether great or small, long or short, when each is fittingly employed, the world becomes as one, with none surpassing another. The sage employs all without discarding any talent.

The ruler values uprightness and esteems loyalty. When loyalty and uprightness hold high office, governing affairs with rectitude, then flatterers, deceivers, and treacherous men have no way to advance. It is like squares and circles not covering each other, or curves and straight lines not fitting together.

Birds and beasts cannot flock together because their kinds differ; tigers and deer do not roam together because their strength is unequal. Thus, when the sage attains his will and holds high position, those who would slander, deceive, or offend the ruler are like sparrows facing a hawk or mice encountering a wildcat—they will surely not survive. Therefore, every move a ruler makes must be made with utmost care.

When those he appoints are the right people, the state is well-governed, superiors and inferiors are in harmony, ministers are loyal, and the people are devoted. But when those he appoints are not the right people, the state is in peril, superiors and inferiors are at odds, ministers are resentful, and the people are in chaos. Thus, a single misstep can bring lifelong harm. The key to success or failure lies in the ruler’s hands.

When the plumb line hangs straight above, the wood below is straight—not because it has been worked upon, but because it follows what it relies upon to be set right. If the ruler is truly upright, honest officials take up their duties while the wicked hide themselves. If the ruler is not upright, the treacherous prevail while the loyal withdraw.

Why is it that people do not carve jade and stone but do carve gourds and melons? Jade and stone are hard—knives cannot penetrate them, so they are not carved. There is nothing to be gained from jade and stone, so they are left untouched. If the ruler holds to rectitude and fairness, following the plumb line to measure high and low, then when ministers come with deceit, it is like throwing eggs against stone or fire into water.

King Ling of Chu favored slender waists, and his people starved themselves to become thin. King Goujian of Yue prized courage, and his people risked death in reckless contests. From this, we see that the handle of power and influence can transform customs.

When Yao was a common man, he could not bring benevolence to a single village; when Jie sat on the throne, his commands were obeyed and his prohibitions enforced. From this, it is clear that virtue alone is not enough to govern, but power can change customs.

The *Book of Documents* says: "When one man has cause for celebration, the myriad people rely on him." This is what it means.

The world is often dazzled by reputation and rarely examines reality. Thus, recluses are honored for their fame, and wanderers are exalted for their eloquence. When we examine what is honored and exalted, we find no other reason than that the ruler does not clearly distinguish the grounds of advantage and harm, and so values the glibness of many tongues.

In governing the state, it is not so. Those who speak must be thoroughly examined by the law, and those who act must be governed by their offices. The ruler holds them to their titles and demands their results; ministers uphold their duties to demonstrate their achievements. Words must not exceed reality, and actions must not transgress the law. Ministers converge like spokes to a hub, none daring to usurp the ruler’s authority.

If a matter lies outside the law but can benefit the state and aid governance, it must be carefully considered through the five phases, secretly investigated to observe its outcome, and thoroughly examined through comprehensive inquiry. Without bias toward one aspect or partiality toward one affair, the ruler stands at the center, his illumination extending throughout the world.

When ministers are impartial and upright, none dare act perversely—impartiality being square and uprightness being straight. All officials fulfill their duties, striving to manifest their public deeds. The ruler, keen and discerning above, spurs officials to diligence below; treachery and deceit vanish without trace, and the myriad achievements advance daily. Thus the valiant exhaust themselves in the military, devoting all strength to martial merit.

In a disordered state, it is not so. Those with many admirers receive rewards despite no merit, while those who uphold their posts are punished despite no crime. The ruler above hears yet does not discern; ministers form cliques and disloyalty. Sophists wander in rhetoric, and the self-cultivated vie in self-aggrandizement—self-aggrandizement being self-benefit. When the ruler issues commands, they oppose them with partisanship; where laws forbid, they transgress with perversity, using factionalism to slander the ruler’s decrees and indulge in their own treachery. The cunning devote themselves to craft and deceit; the bold engage in strife and contention. High ministers monopolize power; petty officials wield influence. Factions form alliances, toying with their sovereign. Though the state may appear to endure, the ancients would call it already lost.

Moreover, to neglect official duties yet don armor, to forsake the southern fields yet gain renown as a sage—this is no way to govern a state. The *qiji* and *luer*, the swiftest horses under heaven, if driven will not advance and if reined will not halt, even a fool would not mount them. Now the signs of order and chaos are as visible as wheel tracks, yet rulers of the age fail to perceive them—this is why the Way of governance is obstructed.

Power and authority are the ruler’s chariot; ranks and emoluments are the ministers’ reins and bit. Thus the ruler occupies the pivot of power and authority, wields the handle of ranks and emoluments, carefully measures the degree of urgency, and aptly adjusts the rhythm of giving and taking. Thereby the world exerts its strength tirelessly.

The bond between ruler and minister is not one of fatherly kindness or kinship. Yet they exhaust their strength and risk death without sparing their bodies—why? The dynamics of power compel them. In former times, Yu Rang was a minister of Zhonghang Wenzi. Wenzi was Xun Yin, son of Zhonghang Muzi, a Jin grandee. When Zhibo attacked the Zhonghang clan and annexed their lands, Yu Rang abandoned his lord to serve Zhibo. Zhibo later battled Zhao Xiangzi at the foot of Jinyang, where he was killed and his corpse desecrated, his state divided into three parts held by Han, Wei, and Zhao—this was his fortune. Yu Rang sought to avenge Zhao Xiangzi, to repay Zhibo’s enmity by assassinating Xiangzi. He painted his body to resemble leprosy, swallowed charcoal to alter his voice, and knocked out his teeth to disguise his appearance.

How could one man’s heart serve two lords—abandoning one, then willing to die for the other? Was it not the difference in the weight of their favor and disfavor? The force of human kindness and grace made it so. When Zhou ruled all under heaven and received the homage of the feudal lords, wherever human footsteps reached or boats and oars traversed, none failed to submit. Yet King Wu, with but three thousand armored soldiers, captured him at Muye. Was it that the people of Zhou were willing to die for principle while the people of Yin rebelled? No—it was the depth of their lord’s virtue and power and the efficacy of his commands.

As fierce winds stir waves and lush trees draw birds, these are the workings of mutually engendering *qi*. Thus when ministers cannot obtain what they desire from the ruler, the ruler likewise cannot secure what he seeks from his ministers. The ruler’s bestowal upon his ministers is met by their reciprocation—this is the dynamic of mutual exchange. Therefore, ministers exhaust their strength and die for principle to serve their lord, while the ruler calculates their merits and confers ranks upon them. Thus the ruler cannot reward ministers without merit, nor can ministers die for a lord without virtue. If the ruler’s virtue does not flow down to the people yet he seeks to employ them, it is like whipping a horse’s hooves—like expecting crops to ripen without waiting for rain, an impossibility in the art of governance.

**Governance and the Way of Rulership (Part II)**

The Way of ruling over others begins with stillness to cultivate the self and frugality to lead those below. Stillness ensures the people are not disturbed; frugality ensures they do not resent. If the people are disturbed, governance falls into chaos; if they resent, the ruler’s virtue is meager. When governance is chaotic, the worthy will not offer counsel; when virtue is meager, the brave will not die for their lord.

Thus, when a ruler delights in startled birds and fierce beasts, treasures rare and strange objects, values gold and jade as precious, and regards the uncanny as marvelous, the extraordinary as wondrous—when he is restless and indolent, *kang* (at ease) and *huang* (disorderly), sparing no care for the people’s strength, galloping in the hunt, coming and going at untimely hours—then his officials will be consumed by chaos, affairs will labor the resources to exhaustion, and the myriad people will suffer in bitterness, their livelihoods neglected.

When a ruler favors lofty towers and deep ponds, intricate carvings and elaborate engravings, embroidered robes with *fu* (black-and-white patterns) and *fu* (blue-and-red designs), fine linen and coarse cloth, silk brocade, treasured jewels and jade—where *fu* is woven from black and white, *fu* from blue and red, *chi* and *xi* are made of kudzu (fine and coarse), and five colors compose embroidery—then taxes will be levied without measure, and the strength of the myriad people will be utterly spent.

When Yao possessed the realm, it was not out of greed for the wealth of the people or to secure his own position. Rather, seeing the people oppressed by force, the strong bullying the weak, the many tyrannizing the few, Yao personally practiced the conduct of moderation and frugality, illuminating the virtue of mutual care to harmonize and unite them. Thus, his thatched roof remained untrimmed, his rafters unhewn; his great carriage (*dalu*, the supreme four-horse chariot) went undecorated—though the Son of Heaven rides with six horses, Yao’s bore no paint, no ornament. His mats were woven from rushes, unhemmed; his grand broth was unseasoned, lacking the five flavors. His coarse grain was not husked to fineness. He toured the realm to teach, toiling for all under Heaven, circling the Five Peaks. Was his sustenance insufficient for joy? He lifted the realm to serve the altars of soil and grain, yet sought no profit therein.

As his years advanced and his resolve grew heavy with sorrow—for *shuai* means aged, and *min*, distress—he offered up all under Heaven to Shun as easily as stepping backward to shed one’s sandals. Such was the ease of his yielding.

Yet in a declining age, it is otherwise: the moment one assumes the throne and the power of rulership, the people’s strength is exhausted to gratify the ruler’s senses. His will fixates on palaces and terraces, ponds and parks, fierce beasts and black bears, curiosities and rarities. Thus, the poor go hungry, their husks and chaff unfit for their mouths, while tigers and wolves, bears and black bears feast on fine fodder. The common folk lack whole garments of coarse cloth, yet the palace walls shimmer with embroidered silks. The ruler hastens to these useless works, and the black-haired people grow gaunt throughout the realm—for *li* means the masses.

Thus, the world cannot rest in its nature, nor preserve its true essence, and deceit arises. The ruler’s abode is like the radiance of sun and moon, toward which all under Heaven turn their sidelong gaze, strain their ears to hear, stretch their necks, and rise on tiptoe in hope. Therefore, without detachment, virtue cannot be made luminous; without tranquility, the distant cannot be attained; without magnanimity, all cannot be sheltered; without kindness and generosity, the multitude cannot be embraced; without impartiality and rectitude, judgments cannot be rendered.

Thus, the worthy ruler employs people as a skilled craftsman shapes wood: the large pieces become hulls, oars, pillars, and beams—for *zhou* means boat, and *hang*, two boats lashed together to ferry across. The small become oars and sculls; the long, eaves and rafters—for *lü* are the eaves, and *cui*, the rafters. The short become caryatids and corbels—for *zhuru* are the kneeling figures atop beams, and *ji* is read like *ji* (chicken). Whether large or small, long or short, each finds its proper place; compass and square, circle and square, each has its use.

Among all things under Heaven, none is more poisonous than *jidu* (monkshood). Yet the skilled physician gathers and stores it, for it has its use. Thus, even the timber of forests and thickets is not to be discarded—how much less a person?

Now, those whom the court does not promote, whom the village lanes do not praise, are not necessarily unworthy; rather, the office to which they are assigned does not suit them. When a deer ascends a mountain, even the river deer cannot keep pace; yet when it descends, even a shepherd boy can pursue it—for abilities have their strengths and limits.

Therefore, one of grand strategy cannot be charged with nimble dexterity—for *lüe* means the Way of conduct. One of minor wit cannot be entrusted with great tasks. People have their talents, things have their forms; to burden one with a weight too heavy, or to task a hundred with what remains too light—this is folly. Thus, he who scrutinizes the minutest calculations will surely lose the great reckonings of the world—for *yi* means to lose. He who does not overlook the smallest details may falter in great undertakings. It is like expecting a wildcat to wrestle an ox, or a tiger to catch a mouse.

Now, some possess the talent to pacify the Nine Provinces, unite the lands beyond, preserve imperiled states, and restore broken lineages. Their resolve lies in the straight Way and correcting the crooked, in resolving entanglements and restoring order. Yet they are instead constrained by the etiquette of inner chambers and the trivialities of secluded halls. Others, with obsequious cunning and petty skills, flatter and fawn, curry favor with local customs, and lower themselves to the level of the common crowd. Yet these are entrusted with the reins of the world and the pivot of order—for *ji* means governance.

This is like shearing wool with an axe or prying wood with a knife—for *jian* is read like *zan* (to shear), and *zan* like the *zan* in *jingzan* (to gather). All lose their proper measure. For *yi* means fitting.

The ruler employs the eyes of all under heaven to see, the ears of all under heaven to hear, the wisdom of all under heaven to deliberate, and the strength of all under heaven to contend. Thus, his decrees penetrate to the lowest levels, and the sentiments of his ministers reach his ears—*wen* means to reach. The hundred offices are well-ordered and interconnected, while the assembled ministers converge like spokes around a hub. Hence the term *fucou* (convergence). He does not reward with gifts in times of joy nor punish with execution in times of anger, fearing misjudgment. Therefore, his authority is established without decay, his intelligence and clarity lead without obscurity—*bi* means darkness. His laws and commands are discerning without being oppressive—*cha* means clarity, *ke* means vexation. His senses are keen without blindness, and the truth or falsehood of matters is laid daily before him without obstruction. Thus, the worthy exhaust their wisdom, the unworthy exert their strength, virtue and grace extend universally without partiality, and all ministers strive diligently without slackening—*dai* means negligence. Those near are at ease in their nature, and those far are drawn to his virtue—*xing* means life, *huai* means to return. Why is this so? Because he has mastered the Way of employing others and does not rely solely on his own talents.

Thus, one who borrows a carriage and horses does not tire his feet yet travels a thousand *li*; one who rides a boat and oars cannot swim yet crosses rivers and seas—*jue* means to traverse. The ruler’s desire is to gather the wisdom of all within the seas and exhaust the strength of the multitude, yet those ministers whose aspirations are fulfilled and who offer loyal service rarely avoid endangering themselves—*kun* means peril. If their words are correct, even if they come from a commoner or a gatherer of firewood, they must not be discarded. Though their speech may be base, if it is right, it must not be cast aside. If their words are wrong, even if they come from a minister or ruler deliberating in the ancestral temple, they may not be used—*renjun* refers to the lord of a state, *yu* means to present, *ce* means counsel. Though their words be wrong, even if they are punished—*kui* means penalty—the right and wrong of a matter cannot be judged by the noble or base, the exalted or lowly.

Thus, the enlightened ruler, in listening to his ministers, deems their plans usable without shame for their lowly station. If their words are practicable, he does not fault their eloquence—he does not fault their florid speech. The benighted ruler acts otherwise: those he loves, befriends, and keeps close, though crooked and unrighteous, he cannot perceive; those distant, lowly, and humble, though they exhaust their strength in loyal service, he cannot recognize. Those who speak are silenced with sophistry, and those who remonstrate are punished with crimes. Ruling thus and wishing to illuminate all within the seas and preserve the myriad regions is like stopping one’s ears to distinguish clear and muddy sounds—*shang* tones are clear, *gong* tones are muddy—or covering one’s eyes to see blue and yellow. Such a ruler strays far from intelligence and clarity—*li* means to depart.

The law is the measure of all under heaven and the standard of the ruler. To suspend the law is to judge what is lawful and what is not; to establish rewards is to reward what deserves reward. Once the law is fixed, those who meet its standards are rewarded, and those who fall short are punished. The exalted are not lightly excused from penalty, nor are the lowly excessively burdened with punishment—this is called balance. Those who violate the law, though virtuous, must be punished; those who meet the standard, though unworthy, must go unpunished. Thus, the public Way is opened, and the private path is blocked—*gong* means upright, *si* means crooked, *se* means closed.

In ancient times, officials were appointed—*you si* likely refers to judicial officers—to restrain the people and prevent them from acting wantonly—*zi* means unrestrained. The ruler was established to restrain these officials and prevent them from acting arbitrarily—*zhuan* means to usurp. Laws, records, rites, and propriety exist to restrain the ruler and prevent him from acting on his own authority. When none may act wantonly, the Way prevails, and when the Way prevails, order is achieved. Thus, one returns to *wuwei* (non-action). *Wuwei* does not mean stagnation or inaction but that one’s words do not originate from oneself.

An inch is born from the *fu*, the *fu* from the *ri*, the *ri* from the *xing*, and the *xing* from the *jing*—this is the foundation of measurement. The *fu* is the awn of a grain stalk, such as the tip of a millet ear. Ten *fu* make one *fen*, ten *fen* make one *cun* (inch), ten *cun* make one *chi* (foot), and ten *chi* make one *zhang*. This is the foundation of governance.

Music arises from sound, sound from pitch, and pitch from the wind—this is the origin of voice. *Origin* also means *foundation*. Law arises from righteousness, righteousness from the collective good, and the collective good accords with the human heart—this is the essence of governance. *Essence* means to unify the many.

Thus, one who comprehends the foundation is not confused by its branches; one who perceives the essence is not bewildered by details. *Bewildered* means *dazzled*. Law is neither fallen from heaven nor sprung from the earth but emerges among men and then returns to correct them. *Returns* means *reverts*.

Therefore, what one possesses oneself, one does not condemn in others—possessing it oneself means having keen discernment. Not condemning it in others means extending forbearance to their conduct. What one lacks oneself, one does not demand of others—though one may lack unique insight, one does not impose blame on others. What is established below is not abandoned above: the ruler’s laws and prohibitions for the people are also practiced by himself. *Not abandoned above* means adhering to the law. What is forbidden to the people is not done by himself—improper deeds are not committed in private.

This is rectifying oneself to rectify others.

What is called a ruined state is not one without a ruler but one without law. Those who alter the law are not without law but possess law yet do not apply it—this is the same as having no law. *Same* means *equal*.

Thus, when a ruler establishes law, he first makes himself its model and standard. *Standard* means *rectitude*. Only then do his commands prevail throughout the land.

Confucius said: “When his person is correct, his commands are obeyed without being issued; when his person is not correct, though he issue commands, they are not followed.” Therefore, when prohibitions prevail over oneself, commands are obeyed by the people. *Prohibitions prevail over oneself* means not daring to violate them oneself—thus one’s commands are obeyed by the people.

The governance of a sagely ruler resembles the driving of Zaofu: harmony is achieved through the reins, urgency and ease through the harmony of his lips, proper measure within his breast, and control through the grip of his hands. *Control* means the switch. Within, it accords with his heart; without, it aligns with the horse’s will. Thus, he can advance and retreat in perfect straightness—*straightness* means *rectitude*—and turn in curves that fit the compass—*curves* means *bends*, *compass* means *circle*. He travels great distances with energy to spare, for he has truly mastered the art.

Thus, authority and power are the ruler’s chariot, and great ministers are the ruler’s team of four horses. If one’s body abandons the comfort of the chariot and one’s hands lose the hearts of the team, one cannot avoid danger—this has never been seen from ancient times to the present.

Therefore, if chariot and horses are not in harmony, even Wang Liang cannot travel the Way; if ruler and ministers are not in accord, even Yao and Shun cannot achieve good governance. If one wields the art of governance to control them, even the wisdom of Guan [Zhong] and Yan [Ying] is exhausted; if one clarifies duties to instruct them, even the treachery of Zhi and Zhuang Qiao ceases. *Zhi* was a robber in Confucius’ time. *Zhuang Qiao* was a general under King Wei of Chu, capable of great banditry.

Gazing into a well from the edge of a terrace, though one’s vision be sharp, one still cannot see the pupils of one’s eyes—*pupils* means the dark centers of the eyes.

If one borrows the clarity of a mirror to illuminate them, then even minute distinctions can be discerned. *Mirror* means a reflective surface. *Distinctions* refers to fine hairs, or alternatively, flaws.

Thus, the enlightened ruler’s ears and eyes do not labor, his spirit is not exhausted; when things arrive, he observes their forms, and when affairs come, he responds to their transformations. What is near does not fall into chaos, and what is distant is governed. Therefore, he does not rely on chance calculations but follows the inevitable Dao, so that in ten thousand undertakings, nothing is left unplanned.

Now, consider the charioteer: when the horse’s body is attuned to the carriage and the driver’s mind is in harmony with the horse, then traversing perilous paths and reaching distant places, advancing and retreating, circling and roaming—none of these fail to accord with his will. Even if there are fine steeds like Qilin or Lü’er, if a mere servant drives them, the horses will turn willful, and the man will be unable to control them. *Zang Huo* refers to an incompetent driver from Lu in ancient times.

Thus, in governance, one does not prize self-righteousness but values preventing wrongdoing. Therefore, it is said: Do not let desires arise, and do not say they will not be sought; do not let things be seized, and do not say they will not be contested. In this way, personal talents are set aside, and the public Dao prevails. The beautiful are measured by standards, and the insufficient are established in their uses—thus, all within the seas may be unified.

If one abandons official duties to heed praise and blame, discards public service for cliques and factions—*public* means upright—then extraordinary talents will rise recklessly and disrupt proper order. *Extraordinary talents* refers to those beyond the ordinary. *Rise recklessly* means they suddenly act without pure virtue, hence disrupting proper order. If those who hold office are thus obstructed and do not advance, then the customs of the people will be thrown into chaos, and meritorious ministers will vie for power at court. When those of extraordinary talent rise recklessly to surpass their proper rank, meritorious ministers, though their achievements are great, will not be duly recognized—hence the contention at court.

Thus, laws and measures are the means by which the ruler controls his subordinates—*control* means to restrain. To discard and not employ them is like driving without reins, and the ministers and common people will instead toy with their superior.

Therefore, with the Dao, one controls others; without it, one is controlled by others—being seized and restrained by others. A fish capable of swallowing a boat, if it strays and loses the water, will be controlled by ants—it has left its dwelling. *A fish capable of swallowing a boat* signifies its great size. *Its dwelling* is the water. A gibbon or martin, if it loses its tree, will be captured by foxes and wildcats—it is not in its proper place. *Its proper place* is a dense forest.

If the ruler of men abandons what he should uphold and contends with his ministers, entrusting finances to officials while holding his position through inaction—having no means to maintain his position—then those who hold office will curry favor with the ruler, following his desires to ingratiate themselves. Thus, ministers conceal their wisdom and do not employ it—refusing to offer their counsel to assist their superior—and instead shift their responsibilities onto him. When worthy ministers see that he is unwilling to accept their plans, they shift the burden back to him, forcing him to take control himself.

As the *Odes* says: "Zhongshan Fu was both enlightened and wise, thus preserving himself." The wealthy and noble regard labor as beneath them; those who understand affairs regard scrutiny as unnecessary; the arrogant and willful regard deference as unworthy, for their power does not equal the ruler’s.

If the ruler of men does not employ ability—failing to utilize the wisdom and talents of his ministers—but prefers to act on his own, then his wisdom will daily grow weary, and he will bear the burden alone. When his plans are repeatedly thwarted below, he cannot extend his governance; when his conduct falters in the state, he cannot maintain sole authority. If his wisdom is insufficient for governance and his might insufficient to execute punishments, then he will have no means to engage with the world.

When joy and anger take shape in the heart and desire to manifest outwardly, those who hold office will abandon uprightness and flatter their superior—*flatter* means to bend in compliance. Officials will distort the law to follow the wind—*wind* means command. Rewards will not match merit, and punishments will not fit crimes; superiors and subordinates will grow estranged, and ruler and ministers will resent one another. Thus, those in power will pander to the ruler, and when faults arise, there will be no means to hold them accountable. If crimes go unpunished, the hundred officials will grow disordered, and wisdom will be unable to resolve it. Slander and praise will arise, and clarity will be unable to illuminate them.

If one does not correct the root but instead cultivates oneself, the ruler will grow ever more labored, and his ministers ever more idle. This is like taking the place of the kitchen chef to butcher the sacrificial animal or acting as the master carpenter to hew the wood. Racing a horse on foot, one’s sinews will snap before catching up; mounting the chariot and taking the reins, the horse will die beneath the crossbar.

Thus, when Bo Le appraises the horse, Wang Liang drives it, and the enlightened ruler rides it, one may reach a thousand *li* without the labor of driving or appraising—riding upon the resources of others as if they were wings. *Resources* means talent.

Therefore, the ruler of men practices non-action while maintaining firmness, acts without personal preferences—having no private inclinations. If he acts, slander arises; if he has preferences, flattery emerges. Flatterers seize upon his will and rise.

In the past, Duke Huan of Qi loved fine flavors, and Yi Ya cooked his own firstborn son to feed him. *Duke Huan* was the son of Duke Xiang of Qi. The Lord of Yu prized treasures, and Jin lured him with jade and horses—*lured* means to entice. The King of the Hu loved music, and Duke Mu of Qin seduced him with female musicians—*seduced* means to bewitch. All were thus controlled by others through profit—*controlled* means to be seized.

Thus, what is well established cannot be uprooted—this speaks of establishing the formless. Fire is hot, yet water extinguishes it; metal is hard, yet fire melts it; wood is strong, yet the axe fells it; water flows, yet earth dams it. Only the Creator, in its transformations, cannot be overcome by things.

Thus, when inner desires do not leak out, it is called *sealed*; when external evils do not enter, it is called *blocked*. With inner sealing and outer blocking, what affair will not be moderated? With outer blocking and inner sealing, what affair will not be accomplished?

Only after not employing can one truly employ; only after not acting can one truly act. When the spirit is wearied, it scatters—*scatters* means to dissipate. When the ears and eyes are indulged, they are exhausted—*exhausted* means to perish.

Thus, the ruler who embodies the Dao extinguishes thoughts and dispels intentions, awaiting all with clarity and emptiness. He does not boast of his words, nor seize others’ affairs. He follows names to demand realities, allows them to govern themselves, entrusts without instructing, holds accountable without teaching. To regard not-knowing as the Dao—the Dao is always unknown.

The treasure lies in "what can be done about it?"
The Dao values formlessness—what is formless cannot be "done about," which is why the Dao is prized.

Thus, the affairs of the hundred officials each have their proper guardianship. To have proper guardianship is to say one does not depart from sealing. Grasping the handle of power and authority, transforming the people becomes easy.

When Duke Chu of Wei was enslaved on the road, it was because his authority was weighty. Duke Chu refers to Duke Chu of Wei. When Dukes Jing and Huan had Guan and Yan as ministers, it was because their positions were exalted. Guan Zhong served as minister to Duke Huan, and Yan Ying served Duke Jing—this was due to the exalted positions of the two rulers.

The cowardly overpower the brave, and the foolish control the wise—this is because what they rely upon in terms of power prevails. Thus, branches cannot exceed the trunk in size, nor can the ends surpass the root in strength, so that light and heavy, small and large, restrain one another.

Like the five fingers belonging to the arm, grasping, seizing, and snatching—all proceed as desired, for the small is subsumed under the great. Therefore, those who gain the advantage of power hold very little, yet preserve much; what they guard is minimal—*minimal* means essential, few—yet what they control is vast.

Thus, a tree ten spans in girth supports a house of a thousand jun, and a five-inch bolt governs opening and closing. Is this because the size of the material itself suffices? It is because of the essential position it occupies.

Confucius and Mo Di cultivated the arts of the former sages, mastering the discourses of the Six Arts. Their mouths proclaimed their words, their bodies enacted their aspirations, and they admired virtue and followed the transformative influence—*feng* meaning transformation. Yet those who served and labored for them numbered no more than a few dozen—*yi* meaning service. Had they occupied the Son of Heaven’s throne, the world entire would have become Confucians and Mohists. *Bian* means "all."

King Zhuang of Chu mourned the death of Wen Wuwei in Song, and in a surge of fury, he swept his sleeves and crossed the border. Armored ranks stretched unbroken along the roads, and his army encamped beneath Song’s walls—such was the weight of his authority. King Zhuang was the son of King Mu of Chu, Lü. He had sent Shen Hang to pay a state visit to Qi without requesting passage through Song. Wuwei said, "They may not necessarily ambush and kill me." The king replied, "If they kill you, we will attack Song." Wuwei set out wearing his ceremonial cap, refusing to request passage through Song. Hua Yuan said, "To pass through our land without requesting passage is to treat us with contempt—*bi* meaning to reduce us to nothing. If we use force to kill their envoy, we too will be destroyed." Thus they killed him. When King Zhuang heard this, he was enraged, and with a sweep of his sleeve he rose and encamped his army outside Song’s walls. Hence it is said: the weight of authority.

King Wen of Chu favored wearing the *xiezhi* cap, and the state of Chu imitated him. King Wen was the son of King Wu of Chu, Xiong Da, named Bi. The *xiezhi* cap later became the standard headwear for imperial censors. King Wuling of Zhao wore a cowrie-shell belt and *shundiao* sash to court, and the state of Zhao followed suit. King Wuling lived after the Spring and Autumn period; he adorned his belt with large cowrie shells and adopted Hu-style dress. *Shundiao* is read as *sipitou*; it is also called *guoluo* belt, with *weibei* and *gao* as its ornaments. Had he been a commoner in coarse cloth, wearing the *xiezhi* cap, cowrie-shell belt, and *shundiao* sash to court, he would not have escaped ridicule. *Shundiao* is read as *sipitou*, a character with three pronunciations.

That the people’s love of goodness and delight in uprightness should spontaneously conform to the law without prohibition or punishment is something that occurs not once in ten thousand cases. But when the commands issued below are such that compliance brings benefit and defiance brings misfortune, before the shadow of the sun has shifted, there is none within the seas who does not submit to the standard—*sheng* meaning "to correct."

Thus, grasping the blade of a sword to prevent Beigongzi and Sima Kuai Kui from engaging the enemy—Beigongzi was a man of Qi, the one Mencius called Beigong You. Sima Kuai Kui was descended from Cheng Bo Xiu Fu, whom King Xuan appointed as Minister of War, thus founding the Sima clan; Kuai Kui was his descendant. When the Zhou declined, he went to another state. Kuai Kui was in Yue, renowned for his skill in swordplay. *Ying* means "to strike." But if one holds the hilt and raises the tip, even an ordinary man can control victory. *Gu* refers to the sword’s hilt; *zhao* means "to raise."

Now, if Wu Huo and Jie Fan were to pull an ox backward by its tail, the tail would break and the ox would not follow—this is resistance. Wu Huo and Jie Fan were both men of great strength. But if one threads a mulberry twig through its nose, even a child of five *chi* can lead it to circle the four seas—this is compliance. That a seven-*chi* oar controls the movement of a boat to port and starboard is because it relies on water—*nao* refers to the oar; *zi* means "to use." *Nao* is read as in "vexation." When the Son of Heaven issues commands, orders are carried out and prohibitions observed, for he relies on the power of the multitude.

To remove what harms the people and open what benefits them is to exercise authority—like breaching a salt flat to release a reservoir. *Jian* refers to alkaline soil; *tang* means "dike." Both are used to store water. Thus, following the current downstream makes arrival easy, and sailing with the wind makes distance effortless. This is to rely on the natural tendency.

When Duke Huan established governance, he removed beasts that devoured flesh, birds that consumed grain, and nets that trapped game—three measures that delighted the hundred clans. King Zhou killed Prince Bigan, and his kin turned against him; he hacked the shins of those who waded through the morning frost, and the myriad people rebelled. Two measures, and the world was lost. Thus, virtue does not require benefiting all the people under heaven; benefiting one person, and the world follows the transformative influence. Tyranny does not require harming all within the seas; harming one person, and the world turns away in rebellion.

Thus, Duke Huan implemented three measures and nine times convened the feudal lords; King Zhou took two actions and could not even remain a commoner. Therefore, the deployment of measures cannot but be carefully considered. The three measures were removing beasts that devoured flesh, birds that consumed grain, and nets that trapped game. The two actions were killing Bigan and hacking the shins of those who waded through the frost.

When the ruler levies taxes on the people, he must first calculate the year’s harvest, assess the people’s stores, and know the surplus and deficit in times of famine and plenty. Only then does he take chariots, clothing, and food to satisfy his desires. Lofty towers and layered pavilions, connected halls and linked galleries—though not lacking in splendor—yet if the people have no dugouts or narrow huts to shelter their bodies, the enlightened ruler does not delight in them. He does not delight in their grand splendor. Rich wines and sweet delicacies—though not lacking in flavor—yet if the people have chaff, husks, beans, and coarse grain that do not reach their mouths, then the enlightened ruler does not savor them. He does not savor their rich flavors. A curved couch and fine mat—though not lacking in comfort—*kuang* means "secure"; *ruo* means "fine." Yet if the people dwell on the frontier, face peril and hardship, and die exposed with their bones unburied, the enlightened ruler does not rest easy. He does not rest easy on his curved couch and fine mat.

Thus, the rulers of antiquity who governed the people grieved for them with deep sorrow. When the state suffered famine, they did not partake of double flavors; when the people were cold, they did not don furs in winter, sharing their cold and hunger. Only when the year’s harvest was abundant and the people prosperous did they begin to hang bells and drums, display shields and axes, and ascend the hall—*deng* means "to complete," referring to a bountiful year. Ruler and ministers, high and low, rejoiced together, and there were none in the state who mourned. This means all were joyful.

Thus, the ancient use of metal and stone instruments, pipes and strings was to express joy—metal refers to bells, stone to chimes, pipes to flutes, and strings to zithers and lutes. Weapons, armor, axes, and halberds served to display wrath. Goblets, ladles, sacrificial vessels, and the rites of toasting and reciprocation were means to manifest goodness—*xiao* means "to convey." Mourning garments, hempen sandals, wailing, and lamentation served to convey sorrow—*lun* means "to make clear." All these arise from fullness within and take form without—*chong* means "substance."

Yet when a disordered ruler seizes from the people, he does not measure their strength—*zai* means "to gauge." When he demands from below, he does not consider their stores. Men and women cannot attend to the work of plowing and weaving to meet the ruler’s demands—*shi* means "to manage," and *ye* means "occupation." Their strength is exhausted, their resources depleted, and ruler and ministers grow mutually resentful. Thus, the people come to parched lips and boiling livers, living from day to day with no reserves—having food for today but no store for tomorrow. Yet only then do they begin to strike great bells, beat resounding drums, blow reed pipes and panpipes, and pluck zithers and lutes. This is like donning armor to enter the ancestral temple or wearing silk brocade to join the army—it loses the very source from which joy arises.

Now, the livelihood of the people: one man treads the plow, yet cultivates no more than ten *mu*. The yield of average land, the harvest of a full year, does not exceed four *shi* per *mu*. His wife and children, the old and weak, depend on this for sustenance. Yet there are also the calamities of floods and droughts—*cen* means prolonged waterlogging. And there are the demands of the ruler’s taxes, the costs of chariots, horses, weapons, and armor. Seen thus, human life is pitiable—*min* means "grieved, without joy."

The vastness of Heaven and Earth: if one calculates three years of plowing, there remains one year’s food in reserve. On average, nine years yield three years’ surplus, eighteen years six years’ accumulation—*ji* means "store." Twenty-seven years yield nine years’ provision. Even with the misfortunes of floods and droughts, the people do not fall into destitution or flee as refugees. Thus, a state without nine years’ surplus is called "insufficient"; without six years’ accumulation, "distressed"—*min* means "grieved," and *bing* means "urgent." Without three years’ surplus, it is called "impoverished."

Therefore, when there are humane rulers and enlightened lords, their taking from below is measured, their self-sustenance restrained. Then they receive the bounty of Heaven and Earth and do not suffer the miseries of hunger and cold. But if there are greedy and violent rulers who harass those below, plundering the people to satisfy endless desires, then the hundred clans cannot partake of Heaven’s harmony or tread upon Earth’s virtue—*tianhe* means "qi," and *dide* means "what Earth produces." Food is the root of the people. The people are the root of the state. The state is the root of the ruler.

Thus, the lord of men follows the seasons of Heaven above, exhausts the resources of Earth below, and employs human labor in between. Thereby, all living things flourish and grow, and the five grains multiply. He teaches the people to raise the six livestock, to plant trees in season, to diligently cultivate the fields, and to propagate mulberry and hemp. He enriches both fertile and barren land, high and low, each according to its suitability. On hills, slopes, and perilous terrain where the five grains do not grow, he plants bamboo and trees. In spring, he fells the withered and dead; in summer, he gathers fruits and melons—those with pits are called *guo*, those without, *luo*. In autumn, he stores vegetables and grains—vegetables are called *shu*, grains *shi*. In winter, he cuts firewood and kindling—large pieces are called *xin*, small ones *zheng*—to serve as the people’s resources—*zi* means "use."

Thus, the living lack nothing for their use, and the dead are not abandoned as corpses. *Zhuan* means "to discard."

Therefore, the laws of the former kings stipulated:
- In hunting, one must not trap entire herds. *Yan* means "to exhaust."
- One must not take fawns or young deer. The young of deer are called *mi*, and the young of *mi* are called *yao*.
- One must not drain marshes to fish. *Zhengze* means to dry up ponds.
- One must not burn forests to hunt.

All these measures serve to preserve all things.

Before the *chai* has performed its ritual of offering beasts, snares and nets may not be set in the wild. In the tenth month, the *chai* kills beasts and arranges them on all sides—this is called the "ritual of offering beasts." Before this ritual, snares and nets may not be set.

Before the otter has performed its ritual of offering fish, fishing nets may not enter the water. The *Ming Tang Yue Ling* states: "In the first month of spring, the otter offers fish." The otter catches carp and arranges them on all sides by the water—this is called the "ritual of offering fish." Before this ritual, fishing is not permitted.

Before the hawk has grasped its prey in the autumn, nets may not be spread in valleys and gorges. After the start of autumn, hawks grasp their prey; before this time, nets may not be set. *Jun* is sometimes written as *juan*.

Before plants and trees have shed their leaves, axes may not enter the mountain forests. In the ninth month, plants and trees begin to shed; before this time, mountain forests may not be felled.

Before insects have hibernated, fire may not be used to burn fields. In the tenth month, hibernating insects are fully concealed; before this time, burning fields is not permitted.

Pregnant creatures may not be killed; eggs may not be taken; fish shorter than a foot may not be caught; pigs less than a year old may not be eaten. All these measures serve to preserve all things.

Thus, the sprouting of plants and trees resembles rising qi; creatures gather to them like flowing springs; flying birds flock to them like clouds and mist—there is a reason they are drawn to them.

Therefore, the governance of the former kings stipulated:
- When clouds gather from the four seas, borders and boundaries are repaired. This occurs after the start of spring, when clouds emerge from the four seas.
- When frogs croak and swallows descend, roads are cleared and maintained. This occurs in the third month.
- When yin descends to the hundred springs, bridges and beams are repaired. This occurs in the tenth month.
- When the *Zhang* constellation appears at dusk, grains are sown. In the third month at dusk, the *Zhang* star culminates in the south. *Zhang* is a constellation of the Vermilion Bird in the south.
- When the Great Fire culminates, millet and beans are planted. The Great Fire is a constellation of the Azure Dragon in the east; in the fourth month, when the *si* branch culminates, it appears in the south. *Shu* means "beans."
- When the *Xu* constellation culminates, winter crops are sown. *Xu* is a constellation of the Dark Warrior in the north; in the eighth month, when the *you* branch culminates, it appears in the south.
- When the *Mao* constellation culminates, stores are gathered, and firewood is cut. The *Mao* constellation is the White Tiger in the west. In the last month of autumn, stores are gathered.

The former kings announced these measures to Heaven above and disseminated them to the people below. This was how they responded to the seasons, prepared accordingly, enriched the state, and benefited the people, filling the present and securing the future—their Way was complete.

*Shi* means "full," and *kuang* means "empty." They did not personally see and walk these paths; they desired to benefit the people. If the desire to benefit the people is never forgotten, governance naturally becomes complete.

The heart’s relation to the nine orifices and four limbs is such that it does not directly manage any single task, yet in movement and stillness, hearing and seeing, it serves as their master—this is because it never forgets the desire to benefit.

Thus, when Yao acted with virtue, all virtues came to him; when Jie acted with wickedness, all wickedness gathered around him. The accumulation of virtue leads to the completion of merit; the accumulation of wickedness leads to the utmost calamity. *Ji* means "utmost."

In general, people’s judgments should be:
- The heart should be small, while the aspirations should be great.
- Wisdom should be round, while conduct should be square.
- Abilities should be many, while affairs should be few.

The reason the heart should be small is to anticipate disasters before they arise, prepare for misfortunes before they occur, guard against faults, and be cautious of the minute, never indulging one’s desires. As the *Book of Songs* says: "It was this King Wen, watchful and reverent, brightly serving the Supreme God, who received abundant blessings." This expresses the same idea.

The reason aspirations should be great is to encompass all states, unify diverse customs, and shelter the hundred clans as if they were one family, with right and wrong converging like spokes toward the hub. The hub is an analogy for the king.

The reason wisdom should be round is that it revolves and circulates without beginning or end, like a seamless ring. It flows in all directions, deep and inexhaustible like a spring, so that the myriad things arise, and none fail to respond. *Ying* means "to harmonize."

The reason conduct should be square is to stand upright without bending. *Nao* means "weak and crooked." It remains pure and unstained; in poverty, it does not change its principles; in success, it does not indulge its will. *Si* means "to indulge."

The reason abilities should be many is to possess both civil and martial skills, to act and rest in accordance with propriety, to undertake or abandon tasks appropriately, to achieve what is fitting in every detail, to avoid conflict, and to ensure nothing is left undone. *Ji* means "to strike," and *li* means "to break."

The reason affairs should be few is to grasp the handle and hold to the method, to seize the essentials to respond to the many, to hold to simplicity to govern the vast, to abide in stillness and maintain the center, to revolve around the pivot, to unify the myriad things as if matching tally tokens. *Fu* means "tally."

Thus, a small heart forbids even the minute; great aspirations embrace all without exception. Rounded wisdom knows no ignorance; square conduct refrains from what is not upright. Many abilities leave nothing untended—*zhi* means "to act." Few affairs mean holding to essentials. *Yue* means "essential."

In ancient times, when the Son of Heaven held court, the dukes and ministers offered forthright admonitions, scholars recited the *Book of Songs*, blind musicians recited admonitions, the common people transmitted their words, historians recorded his faults, and stewards removed his meals. Yet they still considered this insufficient, so:
- Yao set up a drum for those who dared to admonish—those who wished to offer counsel would strike the drum.
- Shun erected a pillar for criticism, where people could write their praise or blame on the wooden board.
- Tang appointed officials of integrity—*Sizhi* was an office name, meaning "not crooked."
- King Wu established a rattle-drum for caution—when he wished to caution the ruler about doubtful matters, he would shake the rattle-drum.

Even the slightest error, once it occurred, was prepared for. *Bei* means "to prepare."

The sage, in matters of virtue, leaves nothing small undone—*ju* means "to employ." In matters of fault, he leaves nothing minute uncorrected. *Gai* means "to change."

Yao, Shun, Yu, Tang, Kings Wen and Wu all ruled the world with serene composure, facing south to hold court. With their backs to the screen, they received the feudal lords. In those times, they dined to the sound of the great war drum—*gaogu*, the music of the Son of Heaven’s meals. As the *Book of Songs* says, *"The drums and bells resound, the chimes are struck."* They performed the *"Yong"* after the meal—*"Yong"* being the music played when the feast was concluded. After eating, they offered sacrifice to the stove god, yet employed no shamans or invokers, for their virtue was complete and their conduct upright, seeking nothing from the spirits. Neither ghosts nor gods dared bring misfortune, nor mountains and rivers inflict calamity—such was their supreme nobility. Thus is the loftiness of perfect virtue. Yet they trembled with caution, growing more vigilant with each passing day. From this, we see that the hearts of sages are small indeed. As the *Book of Songs* says, *"Only this King Wen, reverent and cautious, served the Supreme God with brilliance, ever mindful of abundant blessings."* This describes him well.

When King Wu overthrew Zhou, he distributed the grain from Juqiao—*Juqiao* being the name of Zhou’s granary (another account says it was the bridge at Julu for transporting grain)—and scattered the wealth stored in Lutai—*Lutai* being the treasury where Zhou amassed his riches. King Wu dispersed these to relieve the suffering people. He restored the tomb of Bi Gan—Bi Gan being an uncle of Zhou who had remonstrated against his wrongdoing, only to be killed by Zhou—thus honoring his grave to commend his benevolence. He marked the lane of Shang Rong—Shang Rong being a worthy man of Yin and the teacher of Laozi, hence he exalted his neighborhood. The *Mu Cheng* chapter also states, *"Laozi studied under Shang Rong and, seeing his tongue, understood the virtue of softness."* He paid homage at the temple of Cheng Tang—Cheng Tang being the founding king of Yin, for sages honor those of their own kind. He freed Ji Zi from imprisonment—Ji Zi being a half-brother of Zhou. As the *Analects* says, *"Ji Zi was made a slave."* When King Wu overthrew Zhou, he released Ji Zi from captivity, consulted him on the *Great Plan*, and enfeoffed him in Chaoxian. He allowed each to dwell in their homes and till their fields, neither altering the old nor establishing the new, befriending only the worthy. Though he used what was not his and employed those who were not his subjects, all remained as tranquil as if it had always been so. From this, we see that the aspirations of sages are vast indeed.

King Wen surveyed the successes and failures of the world, examining right and wrong in all things. The reasons for the prosperity of Yao and Shun and the downfall of Jie and Zhou were all depicted in the Bright Hall—*depicted* meaning "illustrated." Thus, his wisdom was broad and his knowledge vast, enabling him to respond without limitation. From this, we see that the wisdom of sages is all-encompassing.

Kings Cheng and Kang inherited the legacy of Wen and Wu, upholding the institutions of the Bright Hall. They observed the traces of survival and ruin, witnessed the transformations of success and failure, spoke only of the Dao, and dared not utter what was not the intent of the sages. They acted only in accordance with righteousness, never presuming to follow what was not benevolent and just. Their words were never carelessly spoken, their actions never carelessly performed; they chose the good and only then proceeded. From this, we see that the conduct of sages is square and true.

Confucius’s understanding surpassed that of Chang Hong in wisdom, and his courage equaled that of Meng Ben. His feet could tread upon the wild hare, and his strength could lift the city gate’s bolt—his abilities were indeed many. Chang Hong was a grandee of Zhou, a minister to King Jing, renowned for his knowledge of the great Dao. Meng Ben was a warrior of great valor, yet Confucius matched him in ability. *Lift* means "to raise"; with one hand, he could grasp the bolt of a city gate and lift it. Thus it is said his abilities were many. Yet his bravery and strength went unnoticed, for none heard of him as a man of valor or might. His skills and craftsmanship were unknown, for none recognized him as one possessing such talents. He devoted himself solely to the practice of filial piety, thereby becoming the Uncrowned King—his achievements were few indeed.

Over the two hundred and forty-two years of the *Spring and Autumn* period, fifty-two states perished, and thirty-six rulers were assassinated. He culled the good and eradicated the wicked, thereby establishing the kingly Way—his judgments were indeed vast. Yet when besieged in Kuang, his countenance remained unchanged, and his zither playing and singing never ceased. Kuang was a town in Song (now the Kuang Pavilion west of Chenxiang County). Confucius said, *"Heaven has endowed me with virtue—what can the people of Kuang do to me?"* Thus his expression did not alter, and his music did not stop. Facing the brink of death, encountering peril and hardship, he adhered to righteousness and principle, and his resolve was never shaken—his discernment was clear indeed. *Encountered* means "to face," and *shaken* means "to fear."

Yet when he served as Minister of Justice in Lu, his judgments were invariably decisive—this was during his tenure as Minister of Justice under Duke Ding of Lu. In compiling the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, he made no mention of ghosts or spirits and dared not assert his own authority.

The wisdom of the sage is indeed vast, yet what he upholds is simple; thus his actions invariably bring honor. The wisdom of the foolish is indeed meager, yet what they pursue is manifold; thus their movements invariably lead to ruin. Wu Qi and Zhang Yi, though their intelligence fell short of Confucius and Mozi, contended for the favor of rulers of ten-thousand-chariot states—this is why they were torn apart limb from limb.

Those who govern through upright instruction find it easy and invariably succeed; those who manipulate the world through deceit and cunning find it difficult and invariably fail. For anyone who seeks to establish conduct and set a course in the world, to abandon what is easy and certain to succeed in favor of what is difficult and bound to fail is the result of folly and delusion. These six contradictions must not go unexamined.

The six contradictions refer to Confucius, Mozi, Chang Hong, Meng Ben, Wu Qi, and Zhang Yi. Their conduct was mutually opposed, hence they are called the "six contradictions." To possess knowledge of the myriad things yet lack understanding of the human Way cannot be called wisdom. To cherish all living beings yet not love humankind cannot be called benevolence.

Benevolence means loving one’s kind; wisdom means being free from delusion. The benevolent, even amid severance and division, reveal in their countenance what they cannot bear. The wise, even in the most intricate and trying matters, display in their actions what they do not obscure.

By turning inward to reflect on one’s own feelings, what one desires for oneself is not imposed upon others. From the near, one knows the far; from oneself, one knows others—this is how human wisdom converges in action. A small teaching brings great preservation; a minor punishment brings great peace. Small teachings in rectitude ensure great preservation; slight admonishments in righteousness secure great tranquility. Without rectitude, there is no preservation; without righteousness, there is no peace.

Only through compassion and extension of one’s feelings can this be put into practice—this is what the wise alone decide. Thus benevolence and wisdom intersect, sometimes converging, sometimes diverging. When they converge, it is rectitude; when they diverge, it is expediency—their principle is one.

Officials uphold the law; the noble man establishes righteousness. To follow the law without righteousness is merely to be an official, insufficient for governance.

Farming is laborious work; weaving is toilsome. That people do not abandon these toilsome and laborious tasks is because they know they provide clothing and food. Human nature cannot do without clothing and food, and the way to clothing and food must begin with plowing and weaving—this is evident to all the people.

Matters like plowing and weaving, though initially arduous, ultimately benefit the many. The foolish see little of this; the matters that can be weighed are many, yet the foolish weigh few—this is why the foolish encounter many misfortunes. The wise prepare for all that can be prepared; they weigh all that can be weighed—this is why the wise encounter few misfortunes.

Thus the wise first oppose and later align; *oppose* means to go against. The foolish begin with joy and end in sorrow. To ask, "What brings honor today, and what brings righteousness tomorrow?" is easy to answer. To ask, "What brings righteousness today, and what brings honor tomorrow?" is difficult to know.

A blind musician was asked, "What is white silk like?" He replied, "It is bright." "What is black like?" He said, "It is dark." When white and black were placed before him, he could not distinguish them. People see white and black with their eyes and speak of them with their mouths. The blind musician could speak of white and black but could not know them—thus his words about white and black were the same as others’, but his ability to distinguish them differed.

To be filial toward one’s parents at home and loyal to one’s lord abroad—all, whether foolish or wise, worthy or unworthy, know this to be righteousness. Yet few can expound on loyalty and filial piety and know their origins.

In all human deliberation, none proceed without first deeming something acceptable and then acting upon it. Whether it is right or wrong—this is how the foolish and the wise differ.

Of all human nature, nothing is more precious than benevolence, nothing more urgent than wisdom. Benevolence is the essence; wisdom is the means to practice it. These two are the foundation, and when augmented with courage, strength, eloquence, quick-wittedness, agility, diligence, skill, sensitivity, acuity, and discernment, they encompass all benefits.

If one’s person is not cultivated and one’s skills and arts are fully prepared, yet one lacks benevolence and wisdom as the trunk and branches, and instead piles on many adornments, it only increases one’s detriment. Thus one who is without benevolence yet possesses courage and daring will act recklessly and wield a sharp sword; *recklessly* means to act in disorder. One who is without wisdom yet is eloquent and quick-witted will abandon the swift steed and not take it as a model. The unwise, though eloquent and quick-witted, do not know how to judge—like discarding a horse and not knowing where to go. *Quick-witted* means to be cunning.

Even with talents and abilities, if their application is inappropriate and their placement unsuitable, they merely serve to aid falsehood and embellish wrongdoing. Thus many skills are not as good as few. Therefore, those with wild ambitions must not be lent advantageous circumstances; *wild* means external. Those with foolish natures must not be given sharp instruments. Laozi said, "The sharp instruments of the state must not be lent to others."

Fish delight in swimming when they have water; when the pond breaks and the water dries up, they are eaten by ants. If one is in charge of maintaining the dikes and repairing the breaches, the fish benefit. *In charge* means to preside. The state has what sustains it; people have what enables them to live. When the state has those who sustain it, the ruler is like a fish in water. The state is prosperous, thus the people thrive.

What sustains the state is benevolence and righteousness; what enables people to live is practicing goodness. A state without righteousness, though great, must perish—Jie and Zhou are examples. A person without good intentions, though brave, must be harmed. The *Analects* says, "One who is brave yet lacks propriety causes disorder; disorder leads to harm." In governing the state, those above must not interfere...

To prevent the dangers of collapse and harm is the art of those above. Being filial to parents, respectful to elder brothers and sisters-in-law, and trustworthy to friends—these need not await commands from above to be practiced. To abandon what one can do and demand what one cannot control is perverse.

When a scholar dwells in lowliness and obscurity yet wishes to rise, they must first turn inward. There is a Way to rise above: if one’s reputation does not arise, they cannot ascend. There is a Way to gain renown: if one is not trusted by friends, they cannot attain it. There is a Way to be trusted by friends: if one does not please their parents, they will not be trusted. If one cannot please their parents, friends will turn and distrust them.

There is a Way to please one’s parents: if one’s cultivation of the self is not sincere, they cannot serve their parents. There is a Way to sincerity in the self: if the heart is not single-minded, one cannot achieve wholehearted sincerity. The Way lies in what is easy, yet people seek it in what is difficult. "Easy" means turning inward and first cultivating the root. Without cultivating the root, yet desiring the reputation of pleasing parents and sincerity in the self—all these are difficult. Thus it is said, "The Way lies in what is easy, yet people seek it in what is difficult."

Proof lies near, yet people seek it far—hence they do not attain it. "Proof" means verification; "near" refers to the root, "far" to the branches. Thus they cannot attain it.

The "Miu Cheng Xun" – Erroneous and divergent theories borrow from things and categories, aligning them with the divine and luminous to discern what is precious.

The Dao is supremely high, without above; supremely deep, without below. It is level as a carpenter’s square, straight as a marking line, round as a compass, square as a ruler. It enfolds the cosmos without outer or inner, penetrating and uniting heaven and earth without obstruction. *Obstruction* means entanglement.

Thus, those who embody the Dao are neither sorrowful nor joyful, neither pleased nor angered. When they sit, they are without anxiety; when they sleep, they are without dreams. Things come, and they are named; affairs come, and they respond.

The ruler is the heart of the state. When the heart is ordered, the hundred joints are all at peace; when the heart is disturbed, the hundred joints are all in chaos. Therefore, when the heart is ordered, the limbs forget one another; when the state is ordered, ruler and ministers forget one another.

The Yellow Emperor said: "Vast and obscure, following the Dao of Heaven, sharing the same qi as the primordial." Thus, those of utmost virtue speak with shared brevity, act with shared purpose. Above and below are of one mind, without divergent paths or peripheral distractions. They bar the way to depravity and secure the path to goodness, and the people turn toward the proper direction.

Thus, the *Yi* says: "Gathering people in the wilds, it is favorable to cross the great river." This means that if one can unite people in the Dao to the point of the wilds, one can then ford the great river. The *great river* is a great difficulty.

The Dao is that by which things are guided; virtue is that by which nature is upheld. Benevolence is the visible evidence of accumulated kindness; righteousness is that which accords with the human heart and suits the many. Thus, when the Dao vanishes, virtue is employed; when virtue declines, benevolence and righteousness arise.

In the age of high antiquity, people embodied the Dao and did not rely on virtue. In the middle age, they preserved virtue and did not corrupt it. In the degenerate age, they cling tenaciously, fearing only the loss of benevolence and righteousness.

The noble person cannot live without benevolence and righteousness; to lose them is to lose that by which one lives. The petty person cannot live without desires; to lose them is to lose that by which one survives. Thus, the noble person fears losing benevolence and righteousness, while the petty person fears losing profit. Observing what they fear, one knows their differences.

The *Yi* says: "Pursuing the deer without a guide, one only enters the forest. The noble person nearly does not abandon it, but to proceed brings regret." *Pursuing* means to follow; the *deer* is a metaphor for the people. *Guide* means deception. *Nearly* means ultimately. To deceive the people and lead them into the forest is ultimately not as good as abandoning the pursuit, lest they fail to reach the end and bring regret upon themselves.

Those who bestow generously receive beautiful recompense; those who harbor great resentment suffer deep misfortune. To give little yet expect much, to accumulate resentment yet hope for no calamity—such things have never existed from ancient times to the present.

Thus, the sage examines what has gone before and knows what will come after. Is the Dao of the sage like placing a wine vessel in the middle of a crossroads? *Crossroads* refers to the six directions being open. *Vessel* is a wine container. Passersby pour and drink, each receiving what is fitting.

Thus, to win over one person is to win over a hundred. If one person comes and their heart is won, then a hundred will come, and their hearts will also be won. When one gives to those below what one desires from above, who would not bear it? When one serves those above with what one desires from below, who would not rejoice?

The *Poetry* says: "Charming this one person, responding to the lords with careful virtue." Virtue is great, the one person is small—yet if one can perfect the small, one can perfect the great.

The noble person, seeing faults, forgets punishment and thus can admonish. Seeing worthiness, forgets lowliness and thus can yield. Seeing insufficiency, forgets poverty and thus can give. Emotions reside within, and conduct takes shape without. All conduct that carries emotion, though it may err, incurs no resentment; conduct that does not carry emotion, though loyal, invites dislike. *Carry* means what the heart feels; *emotion* means sincerity.

Hou Ji brought great benefit to the world yet did not boast of himself. Yu had no abandoned achievements, no concealed wealth, and viewed himself as ever unsatisfied. *Unsatisfied* means not full; *full* is like sinking, and *sinking* means deficiency. *Substantial yet empty*—this is the perfection of it.

People all esteem what they love and love what pleases them. The world does not fail to elevate the worthy, yet some use them to bring order, others to bring chaos. It is not that the worthy hide themselves—*hide* means deception—but that people seek those who are the same as themselves. If one has not necessarily obtained the worthy yet seeks those who are the same as oneself, desiring to obtain the worthy is also far from likely.

If Yao were to assess Shun, it would be fitting; if Jie were to assess Yao, it would be like using a pint measure for a stone. Now, to call something a fox-raccoon is to certainly not know the fox, nor the raccoon. If one does not know these two beasts, it is not that one has never seen a fox, nor that one has never seen a raccoon. Fox and raccoon are not different—they are of the same kind—yet to call them a fox-raccoon is to not know fox or raccoon.

Thus, to call the unworthy worthy is certainly not to know the worthy; to call the worthy unworthy is certainly not to know the unworthy.

When the sage is above, the people delight in his governance; when below, the people long for his intent. When the petty person is in high position, it is like sleeping on a crossbar or drying silk floss—*sleeping* means lying on a crossbar, restless; *floss* is cocoon silk. To dry cocoon silk is to toss and turn without cease until death. One cannot have a moment’s peace.

Thus, the *Yi* says: "Mounting a horse, disarrayed, weeping blood in unbroken streams." This means that mounting a horse in disarray is difficult, hence the sorrow of weeping blood. It speaks of the petty person occupying a position not his own—it cannot last long.

Nothing exists without some use. Heavenly male and aconite are violently poisonous medicines, yet good physicians use them to save lives. Dwarves and blind musicians are people in dire straits—*dire* means stumbling, or *extreme*—yet the ruler employs them for entertainment.

Thus, the sage regulates and employs all materials, leaving nothing unused. *Regulates* means to prune and reduce. A brave warrior shouts once, and the three armies all retreat—his issuance is sincere.

Thus, if one sings and none harmonize, if one laments and none echo—*lament* means a grieving sound; *echo* means sighing—there must be something in their hearts that does not align.

Therefore, Shun did not rise from his mat yet ruled the world because he sought it within himself.

Thus, when superiors are full of pretexts, the people abound in deceit.

That a body bent should cast a straight shadow—this has never been heard of.

Where persuasion does not reach, demeanor does. The coarse in persuasion cannot compare to the subtlety of demeanor, which penetrates deeply into others.

Where demeanor does not reach, subtle influence does. Stirring the heart, illuminating wisdom, issuing forth to take form—this is the utmost refinement.

One may engage through posture and power, but cannot mirror another’s will.

The horses of the Rong and Di peoples can all be ridden, whether near or far, yet only Zaofu could exhaust their strength. The people of Sanmiao could all be made loyal and trustworthy, whether worthy or unworthy, yet only Yao and Shun could equalize their excellence—there must be something untransmittable.

The subtlety of heart-teaching cannot be transmitted.

Zhonghang Moubo wrestled tigers with his bare hands—Zhonghang Moubo was a minister of Jin, strong enough to grapple living tigers—yet could not keep them alive. His strength could kill tigers, but his virtue could not subdue them. For his might was superior, but his power fell short. *Power* here means *capacity*.

Employing what a hundred men can do yields the strength of a hundred men. Enacting what a thousand men love wins the hearts of a thousand men. It is like felling a tree by pulling its root—then the thousand branches and ten thousand leaves have no choice but to follow.

A loving father’s affection is not for the sake of repayment; it cannot be inwardly dissolved. The sage-king’s nurturing of the people is not to seek their service—it is a nature that cannot be restrained. Like fire’s spontaneous heat, like ice’s spontaneous cold, what cultivation is needed?

Yet those who rely on their strength and depend on their achievements are like men on a burning boat. The people in the boat unite to extinguish the fire, not *bestowing* favors upon one another.

Thus, the noble person, seeing the beginning, knows the end.

Matchmakers praise others, yet none feel gratitude toward them. Hiring a laborer and forcing him to eat—none feel affection for this. Even a loving father and a kind mother cannot surpass this: if there is an ulterior motive, kindness does not connect.

Therefore, sending off the departed is not for the sake of welcoming the coming. Bestowing upon the dead is not solely for the living.

Sincerity issuing from oneself moves what is distant.

Brocade and embroidery enter the ancestral temple—this honors ornamentation. *Enter* means *to bring in*. Jade tablets and scepters stand before one—this upholds substance. To sacrifice with jade is to honor substance.

When ornamentation does not surpass substance, this is called the noble person.
