Though none of these please the ear or eye, nor suit the mouth or belly, the former kings prized them, for they honored what was offered in ancestral temples. They put first things first and last things last.

In the sage’s dealings with things, though they shift a thousand ways and turn ten thousand times, there must be that which remains unchanged yet responds to change.

Cold and warmth are opposites. In the Great Cold, the earth splits and water congeals, yet fire does not diminish its heat. In the Great Heat, stones melt and metal flows, yet fire does not increase its intensity. The changes of cold and heat bring no gain or loss to its essence, for its nature is fixed. This speaks of the human nature that cannot be altered by fire.

The sage always follows and never leads, always responds and never initiates. He does not advance to seek, nor retreat to yield. For three years, he follows the times; when the time departs, it goes before him. For three years after it departs, the time remains behind him. Neither departing nor approaching, he stands at the center of his place.

The Way of Heaven shows no favoritism; it befriends only virtue. One who possesses the Dao does not miss the time or the person—missing the time means losing the moment, not losing the moment to give to another. One who lacks the Dao loses the time and takes from others.

Standing straight and awaiting fate, the moment’s arrival cannot be met by turning back; seeking agreement by blocking and intercepting, the moment’s departure cannot be grasped by pulling. Thus, one does not say, “I have nothing to offer, so all under heaven keeps its distance,” nor “I do not desire it, so all under heaven does not come.”

The ancients who preserved themselves delighted in virtue and forgot lowliness, so their fame did not sway their will. They delighted in the Dao and forgot poverty, so profit did not move their hearts. Though fame and profit filled all under heaven, they were not enough to sway their will. Thus, they could delight in both and remain tranquil and serene. Therefore, those who govern themselves may be spoken to of the Dao.

From the self upward to the distant past is immeasurably far—“from the self upward” means from one’s own birth back to the distant past. *Huang mang* refers to the age of remote antiquity, thus it is far indeed.

From death onward to the endlessness of heaven and earth is immeasurably vast—"from death onward" means from the time after one’s own death to the boundless end of heaven and earth. *Taotao* means long and unbroken. As for the span of mortal life, *za* means a full cycle. When a person has a child, from *zi* to *hai* marks one cycle. To worry over the world’s chaos is like weeping over the scarcity of river water, trying to add to it with tears. The tortoise lives three thousand years, for it expels the old and takes in the new, thus attaining such longevity. The mayfly does not last beyond three days—*fuyou* refers to its fleeting existence, living but three days before dying. To fret over the mayfly’s means of nurturing life as one would for the tortoise would surely invite ridicule. Thus, one who does not worry over the world’s chaos but delights in the governance of the self may be spoken to of the Dao.

The noble person, though he does good, cannot ensure that wealth will come; though he refrains from wrongdoing, cannot ensure that misfortune will not arrive. When fortune comes, it is not what he sought, so he does not boast of his merit. When misfortune arrives, it is not of his making, so he does not regret his conduct. Cultivating the utmost within—*ji* means the center—yet if calamity strikes from without, it is the work of heaven, not man. Thus, the heart remains ever tranquil and detached, accumulating virtue; the dog barks, yet one is not startled, trusting in one’s true nature. Therefore, those who know the Dao are not deluded, and those who understand fate are not anxious.

When the lord of ten thousand chariots dies, his bones are buried in the open wilderness, while his spirit is venerated in the *Mingtang*—the temple is called the *Mingtang*. The spirit is prized above the form. Thus, the spirit dwells in the hall while the body lies in the wild. When the spirit governs, the form follows—*shenzhi* refers to the emotions, meaning desires are not stirred, and the body complies with the heart’s harmony. When the form prevails, the spirit is exhausted—*xingsheng* means the body’s restlessness overpowers the spirit, and the spirit, depleted, departs. Though hearing and sight are employed, they must return to the spirit; though hearing and sight are used, they guard within. When the spirit is at peace, the self is whole. This is called *Taichong*—*chong* means harmony.

**Military Strategy**

War is defense—defense against the sprouts of chaos, all of which lie in strategic planning. This treatise elucidates the profound principles of employing troops.

Those who wielded arms in antiquity did not covet vast lands or plunder gold and jade—*lüe* means "to obtain." Rather, they sought to preserve what was perishing, restore what was severed, pacify the world’s turmoil, and eradicate the suffering of the people.

All creatures with blood and *qi*—those bearing fangs and horns, claws and spurs—gore with their horns, bite with their teeth, sting with their venom, and kick with their hooves. When joyful, they play together; when enraged, they harm one another. Such is the nature of Heaven.

Humans possess desires for clothing and food, yet resources cannot suffice. Thus, they gather in mixed communities. When distribution is unequal and needs go unmet, strife arises. In strife, the strong coerce the weak, and the bold invade the timid. Lacking the strength of sinew and bone or the sharpness of claws and fangs, humans flay hides to fashion armor and smelt iron to forge blades. The greedy and rapacious among them ravage the world, stirring the masses into turmoil, leaving none in peace with what they possess.

The sage arises in indignation, punishing the violent, quelling chaos, leveling peril, purging filth, transforming turbidity into clarity, and turning danger into tranquility—thus, there is no choice but to sever the line. *Zhongjue* refers to the annihilation of the Shang kings’ middle lineage.

The origins of warfare stretch far into the past. The Yellow Emperor once battled the Flame Emperor—the Flame Emperor being the final sovereign of the Divine Farmer’s line. They clashed at Banquan, where the Yellow Emperor vanquished him. Zhuanxu once contended with Gonggong. Gonggong vied with Zhuanxu for supremacy, striking Mount Buzhou. Thus, the Yellow Emperor fought on the fields of Zhuolu—the Yellow Emperor’s battle against Chi You at Zhuolu, which lies in Shanggu. Yao waged war at the banks of the Dan River, where he, as the Lord of Chu, executed the mandate to destroy the unjust at Dan River. The Dan River flows through Nanyang. Shun campaigned against the Three Miao. The Three Miao were the Sanmiao. Qi, son of Yu, attacked Youhu. Qi, son of Yu, struck Youhu at Gan. Gan lies in the Right Fengyi Commandery.

Even the Five Emperors could not lay down arms—how much less could a degenerate age? Warfare exists to suppress violence and punish disorder. The Flame Emperor brought fire disasters, so the Yellow Emperor captured him. Gonggong caused water calamities, so Zhuanxu executed him. When instruction in the Dao and guidance by virtue go unheeded, authority and might are brought to bear. If authority and might are defied, then arms and armor are employed to restrain them.

Thus, the sage’s use of arms is like combing hair or weeding seedlings: what is removed is little, while what benefits is great. To slay innocent people while sustaining an unrighteous ruler is the greatest harm. To exhaust the world’s wealth to sate one man’s desires is the deepest calamity.

Had Jie of Xia and Zhou of Yin inflicted harm upon the people but faced consequences before their reigns, they would not have resorted to the *paoluo* torture. Had Li of Jin and Kang of Song committed a single act of injustice but perished before their states fell, they would not have turned to plunder and violence. These four rulers each committed minor transgressions, yet none were *punished*—thus, they plunged the world into chaos, harmed the common folk, indulged their own wickedness, and prolonged the realm’s suffering. Such is the great discourse that rejects this course.

The purpose of establishing rulers is to suppress violence and punish disorder.

Now, riding the strength of the myriad people yet turning to cruelty and degradation—this is like adding wings to a tiger. Why should it not be eradicated?

Those who keep pond fish must remove otters and their kin; those who raise birds and beasts must drive out jackals and wolves. How much more so for governing people?

Thus, the armies of hegemons and kings are deliberated with foresight, plotted with strategy, and upheld by righteousness—not for destruction, but to preserve what would otherwise perish. When they hear of a ruler in a rival state who inflicts cruelty upon the people, they lead their troops to its borders, reproaching him for his unrighteousness and condemning his transgressions. Upon reaching its outskirts, the commander issues orders: "Do not fell trees, do not disturb tombs, do not trample the five grains, do not set fires, do not burn stored provisions, do not seize the people as captives, do not take livestock."

Then, a proclamation is issued: "This state’s ruler defies Heaven and insults the spirits, condemns the innocent in judgment, and slaughters the blameless—this is why Heaven punishes him, why the people revile him. Our army has come to abolish unrighteousness and restore virtue. Those who oppose Heaven’s Way and lead the people to ruin shall perish with their clans. Those who submit by household shall be rewarded with households; those who submit by village shall be rewarded with villages; those who submit by township shall be enfeoffed with townships; those who submit by county shall be enfeoffed with counties."

When a state is conquered, its people are spared. Its ruler is deposed, its governance reformed, its scholars honored, its worthy and good elevated, its orphans and widows relieved, its poor and destitute succored, its prisoners released, and its meritorious rewarded. The common folk open their gates in welcome, wash their rice in preparation, and fear only that the army will not come. This is how Tang and Wu attained kingship, and how Duke Huan of Qi and Duke Wen of Jin achieved hegemony.

Thus, when a ruler is without the Way, the people’s longing for righteous troops is like the parched yearning for rain or the thirsty craving for drink. Who would dare to meet them in battle? Therefore, when righteous armies arrive, they often prevail without fighting.

In later ages, even when rulers were without the Way, they would fortify moats and ramparts, man the battlements, and stand guard. Yet their attackers did not come to suppress violence or eliminate harm, but to seize land and expand territory. Thus, battles led to heaps of corpses and rivers of blood, dragging on day after day, and the achievements

The armor remains unscathed, blades untasted by blood; court officials hold their posts unchanged, merchants keep to their stalls, and farmers stay in their fields. Summoning righteousness and demanding allegiance, great states must pay homage, and small cities must submit. Riding the people’s desires and harnessing their strength, one removes the cruel and eliminates the bandits.

Thus, those who share a common benefit will die for one another; those who share a common sentiment will unite; those who share a common desire will aid each other. Moving in accord with the Dao, the world turns toward you; acting in accordance with the people’s will, the world becomes your weapon. Hunters pursue game, chariots speed, and men rush forward, each exerting their utmost strength. Without the threat of punishment, they yet scout and block key passes—scouts observe, and barriers seal—all for a shared benefit. When crossing a river in the same boat and suddenly encountering wind and waves, men of all clans swiftly grasp oars and poles, working together like left and right hands, not out of mutual affection but from shared peril.

Therefore, when a sagely king employs troops, it is to eliminate harm for the world and share its benefits with all people. The people’s service is like a son’s to his father or a younger brother’s to his elder. Where his might falls, it is like a mountain collapsing or a dam bursting—what enemy could withstand it? Thus, those skilled in warfare employ others as if for their own sake, while the unskilled employ them as if for their own use. Employing others as if for their own sake, there is none in the world who cannot be used; employing them for one’s own use, little is gained.

Warfare has three levels of urgency. The highest: governing the state, ordering the realm, practicing benevolence and righteousness, spreading virtue and kindness, establishing just laws, blocking the paths of evil, so that ministers draw near, the people harmonize, superiors and inferiors unite as one, and ruler and ministers join forces. The feudal lords submit to his might, and the four quarters cherish his virtue. Cultivating governance in the ancestral temple, he yet strikes down enemies a thousand *li* away. With a mere gesture or signal, the world responds—this is the highest use of arms. The next: lands are vast, the people numerous, the ruler worthy, and the generals loyal; the state is rich, the troops strong, discipline reliable, and commands clear. When two armies face each other, drums and bells resound in sight, yet before blades clash, the enemy flees—this is the second use of arms. The lowest: knowing the suitability of terrain, mastering the advantages of perilous passes, understanding the shifts of extraordinary tactics, and discerning the calculations of formations and maneuvers. Binding the drumsticks and sounding the drums, blades meet, arrows fly, blood flows and entrails spill, the dead are borne away and the wounded supported. Blood streams for a thousand *li*, corpses litter the field, and only then is victory decided—this is the lowest use of arms.

Now, the world knows only how to manage the branches but not how to cultivate the root, abandoning the trunk to tend the twigs. The means by which armies aid victory are many, but the means by which they secure certain triumph are few. Armor is sturdy, weapons sharp, chariots sturdy, horses fine, supplies abundant, and soldiers numerous—this is the great resource of an army, yet victory or defeat still hangs in the balance. Mastery of the movements of stars, sun, and moon, the calculations of *xing* and *de*, and the secrets of yin and yang—these are the aids to battle, yet survival or ruin still remains uncertain. The reason a great general always prevails lies in his unfathomable wisdom and the Dao that cannot be spoken, which the multitude cannot grasp.

When selecting and appointing officials, he is cautious; when moving or halting, he is timely. Officers and soldiers are discerning, weapons and armor well-maintained. He rectifies the Five Ranks, links squads and platoons, and clarifies drum and banner signals—this is the duty of the military commandant, who steadies the troops. He knows the dangers and ease of the terrain ahead and behind, assesses the enemy’s strength or weakness, and ensures no scout is left behind—this is the duty of the military scout. Roads are swiftly prepared, baggage trains ordered, encampments leveled, and wells and stoves connected—this is the duty of the military engineer. Supplies are gathered at the rear, and when the army moves, none are left behind; no excess baggage is carried, no equipment abandoned—this is the duty of the logistics officer. These five officers serve the general like limbs serve the body. He must choose men of ability, assign them to roles they can fulfill, and ensure each can perform his task. Instructing them in governance and reinforcing commands, he makes them like tigers and leopards with claws and fangs, or birds with six wings—none fail to serve.

Yet these are merely tools to aid victory, not the means to ensure it. The outcome of war lies fundamentally in governance. When governance prevails over the people, the lower ranks submit to the upper, and the army is strong. When the people prevail over governance, the lower ranks rebel against the upper, and the army is weak. Thus, virtue and righteousness sufficient to win the hearts of the world’s people, undertakings sufficient to meet the world’s crises, appointments sufficient to gain the hearts of worthy scholars, and planning sufficient to know the balance of strength and weakness—these are the roots of certain victory.

Vast lands and numerous people do not make one strong; sturdy armor and sharp weapons do not ensure victory; high walls and deep moats do not guarantee security; harsh commands and severe punishments do not inspire awe. A state with sound governance, though small, will endure; a state with failing governance, though large, will perish.

In ancient times, the lands of Chu extended southward to encompass the Yuan and Xiang Rivers—*juan* meaning to bend and take. The Yuan and Xiang are two rivers. To the north, it encircled the Ying and Si Rivers—the Ying and Si being two rivers. To the west, it embraced Ba and Shu; to the east, it enveloped Tan and the Huai. The Ba, Shu, Tan, and Huai are place names. The Ying and Ru were its drainage ditches—*xu* meaning channels. The Yangtze and Han served as its moats, fortified by the Deng Forest—the Deng Forest being a perilous stretch along the Mian River—and walled by the Fangcheng. *Mian* means to encircle; Fangcheng was Chu’s northern barrier, located in present-day Ye of Nanyang. Its mountains rose so high they brushed the clouds; its streams plunged so deep no light reached their depths—*si* meaning to extend. Such were its strategic advantages in terrain and topography. Its soldiers and people were brave, and their armor was fashioned from the hides of crocodiles, rhinoceroses, and water buffalo. Their weapons included long-forged short spears—*cong* being a small lance. The Qi formed the vanguard, while massed crossbows covered the rear—*ji nu* meaning repeating crossbows. Chariots flanked the sides, swift as arrows—*zhui* referring to arrows with metal tips and feathered shafts. When they clashed, it was like thunder and lightning; when they dispersed, it was like wind and rain. Yet their armies met disaster at Chuisha—Chuisha being a place name—and their forces were shattered at Baiju.

Though Chu’s might was vast, its lands and people accounting for half the world, King Huai still feared the Lord of Mengchang and was coerced by Qi. He abandoned the defense of his altars of state and surrendered himself to mighty Qin. When King Huai entered Qin, he was detained at Lantian. His armies were crushed, his lands diminished, and he died in exile, never to return.

The Second Emperor—Hu Hai, the younger son of the First Emperor of Qin—held the power of the Son of Heaven and possessed all under heaven. Wherever human footsteps reached or boats could sail, there were commanderies and counties. Yet he indulged his senses and exhausted extravagance, heedless of the people’s hunger, cold, and destitution. He mobilized the might of ten thousand chariots to build the Epang Palace—Epang being a place where Qin constructed its palace. He conscripted the poor from the alleys—Qin drafted the impoverished from the left lanes, though the dynasty fell before the levy was complete—and exacted taxes amounting to two-thirds of the people’s wealth. The people, summoned to endure extreme punishments, died in droves along the roads, their bodies piled like the crossbars of carts—*lu* being the horizontal bar used to pull a carriage. In a single day, the dead numbered in the thousands and tens of thousands. The world seethed as if scorched by fire, suffering as if burned by flames. Above and below could find no peace; officials and people had no one to rely on—*liao* meaning to depend.

Then the garrison soldier Chen Sheng rose in Daze Marsh—Chen Sheng, styled She, was a native of Ruyin; Daze was in Pei’s Qixian County. He bared his right arm and proclaimed the greatness of Chu, and all under heaven responded in unison. At that time, they had no sturdy armor or sharp weapons, no powerful crossbows or strong siege engines. They sharpened thorns and jujubes into spear shafts—thorns and jujubes being sour jujubes; *qin* meaning a spear handle—and carved Zhou awls into blades—*Zhou* meaning to bore. They honed their tools to a point and brandished hoes and axes, yet when they faced well-forged halberds and strong crossbows, attacked cities, and seized lands, none could withstand them. The world churned like boiling water, stirred like swarming ants, and surged forth like clouds rolling up a mat, spanning thousands of miles.

Though their status was the lowest and their weapons the crudest, when one man raised his voice, all under heaven answered—because the people’s grievances had long accumulated.

When King Wu campaigned against Zhou, he faced east to welcome the year—Taisui being in *yin*. At Fan, he encountered floods—Fan being a place name; *shui* meaning heavy rains. At Gongtou, the mountains crumbled—Gongtou being a mountain in the bend of the Yellow River; *zhui* meaning to fall. A comet appeared and handed its handle to the men of Yin—at the time, a comet appeared, its tail pointing east, as if to sweep away the westerners. During the battle, ten suns appeared in confusion above, while wind and rain lashed from within. Yet there were no rewards for those who trod into danger, nor punishments for those who fled. Before blades were fully drawn, all under heaven was won.

Thus, those skilled in defense need not resist, and those skilled in warfare need not fight. They understand the Dao of prohibitions and permissions, openings and closures, seize the momentum of the times, and harness the people’s desires to take all under heaven. Therefore, those who govern well accumulate virtue, and those who wage war well store up wrath. When virtue is accumulated, the people can be employed; when wrath is stored, awe can be established.

If the governance applied is shallow, the power it overcomes will be small. If the virtue bestowed is profound, the authority it commands will be vast. When the authority it commands is vast, one’s own strength grows while the enemy’s weakens. Thus, those skilled in warfare first weaken the enemy before engaging in battle, so their efforts are halved while their achievements are doubled.

Tang’s domain was but seventy *li* square, yet he reigned as king—because he cultivated virtue. Zhibo possessed a thousand *li* of land, yet he perished—because he exhausted military force. Therefore, a state of a thousand chariots that practices civil virtue will rule as king, while a state of ten thousand chariots that delights in war will perish.

Thus, victorious armies first secure victory and then do battle—first ensuring victory through virtue, then engaging in war, as Tang and Wu did. Defeated armies first fight and then seek victory.

When virtue is equal, the numerous prevail over the few. When strength is matched, the wise prevail over the foolish. When power is balanced, those with strategy overcome those without. In all warfare, one must first wage war in the ancestral temple. Assess which ruler is more worthy, which general more capable, which people more attached, which state better governed, which stores more abundant, which soldiers more disciplined, which armor sharper, and which equipment more suitable. Thus, one may devise strategies in the temple halls and decide victory a thousand *li* away.

What has form can be seen and contested by all under heaven; what is recorded in texts can be transmitted and studied by the people of the world. All these rely on form to prevail—yet those who excel in form do not follow such methods.

What is prized in the Dao is its formlessness. Formless, it cannot be constrained or compelled, cannot be measured or calculated, cannot be outwitted or schemed against. Where cunning is revealed, others devise strategies; where form is exposed, others achieve merit; where the multitude is seen, others submit; where weapons appear, others prepare. All movements—circling and returning, crouching and stretching—where craft and deceit may be applied, are not the methods of the truly adept.

The movements of the adept are spirit emerging and ghosts in motion, stars gleaming and the obscure in pursuit. Advancing and retreating, bending and extending, no trace of order is visible. Like the phoenix soaring and the qilin stirring, the phoenix in flight and the dragon ascending—launched like the autumn wind, swift as a startled dragon. The dragon is a fish, yet the swiftest in flight. Strike the living against the dead, the flourishing against the decaying, the swift against the slow, the sated against the hungry. Like water extinguishing fire, like boiling water melting snow—where can one go and not succeed? Where can one proceed and not prevail?

Within, the spirit is empty; without, the will is serene. Moving through the formless, striking from the unforeseen. Drifting like the fleeting breeze, vanishing like the sudden gust—none know where it goes. Emerging through the branches, entering through the gaps—none know where it gathers. Sudden as thunder, swift as wind and rain, as if rising from the earth, as if descending from the heavens. Alone it comes, alone it goes—none can resist. Swift as a loosed arrow, how can one counter it? Now hidden, now revealed—who knows its beginning or end? Before its emergence is seen, it has already arrived.

Thus, the master of warfare perceives the enemy’s vulnerability and seizes it without hesitation, pursues without relenting, presses without withdrawing. Strike when they waver, overwhelm when they falter—swift as thunder, leaving no time to cover the ears; swift as lightning, leaving no time to shield the eyes.

The master of warfare moves like echo answering sound, like drumbeat meeting drumskin’s resonance. Blinking cannot keep pace with the hand’s motion, nor breath with the battle cry. In such a moment, one looks up and does not see the heavens, looks down and does not see the earth; the hand does not wave the halberd, yet the blades are not fully drawn. The assault is like thunder, the onslaught like wind, the scorching like fire, the surge like waves. The enemy, whether still or in motion, knows neither what to defend nor what to do.

Thus, when drums roar and banners wave, all who stand before them falter, collapse, and crumble—who in the world would dare to resist their might with defiant resolve? Therefore, he who strikes first prevails; he who waits is defeated; he who lets others dictate his moves perishes.

When troops are composed, their defense is firm; when their focus is unified, their might is formidable; when their resolve is decisive, their courage is boundless; when their hearts waver, they flee; when their strength is divided, they weaken. Thus, if one can divide the enemy’s forces and sow doubt in their hearts, even the slightest advantage suffices; if one cannot divide their forces or unsettle their hearts, even a tenfold advantage proves insufficient.

King Zhou’s armies numbered in the millions, yet their hearts were scattered; King Wu’s troops, though but three thousand, were single-minded and united. Thus, a thousand men with one heart wield the strength of a thousand; ten thousand with divided hearts are as naught. When generals, officers, and common soldiers move as one body, only then can they meet the enemy in battle.

Therefore, plans must be set before action, decisions made before movement. The general must harbor no doubt, the troops no divided loyalty; their movements must be unwavering, their words unfeigned, their actions untested. They must respond to the enemy with swiftness and strike with urgency.

Thus, the general is the body to the people, and the people are the heart to the general. When the heart is true, the limbs will brave the blade; when the heart wavers, the limbs falter and flee. If the heart is not single-minded, the body cannot act in unison; if the general’s resolve is not steadfast, the troops will not fight with courage. Therefore, the finest general’s soldiers are like the tiger’s fangs, the rhinoceros’s horn, the bird’s pinions, the centipede’s legs—sharp as the horsefly’s sting. They can march, they can charge, they can bite, they can gore; though strong, they do not harm one another; though numerous, they do not turn on each other, for they are moved by a single heart.

Thus, when the people truly follow their commander’s orders, even the few need not fear; when they do not, even the many are as few. If the ranks do not trust their leaders, their hearts will not serve; if the troops do not fear their general, their discipline will not hold. Defense will be unshakable, and attack will be unstoppable—not even waiting for blades to clash before the outcome is already decided.

Warfare possesses three strategic advantages and two tactical powers: there is the momentum of *qi*, the advantage of terrain, and the leverage of circumstance.

When the general is bold and scorns the enemy, when the troops are resolute and eager for battle, when the three armies—numbering a million strong—aspire to the heavens and their *qi* surges like the whirlwind, their voices like thunder, their sincerity overwhelming and their might crushing the foe—this is called the momentum of *qi*.

Narrow passes, strategic fords, towering mountains, and winding defiles—where dragons coil and serpents twist, where paths reverse like an overturned bamboo hat, where the way twists like a sheep’s intestines, where the "bamboo-shoot gate" traps like a fish weir, allowing entry but no escape—here, a single man guarding the pass can bar the way to a thousand. This is called the advantage of terrain.

Exploiting the enemy’s exhaustion, weariness, disorder, hunger, thirst, cold, or heat; pushing when they teeter, shoving when they totter—this is called the leverage of circumstance.

The master of espionage employs double agents, scrutinizes plans, sets ambushes in thickets, conceals his form, and strikes from the unforeseen. The enemy’s forces, caught unprepared, know not where to turn—this is called knowing the tactical power of deception.

When formations are ordered, vanguards selected, advances and retreats synchronized, squads coordinated, front and rear unentangled, left and right undisturbed—few are those who take the blade, many those who wound the enemy. This is called the tactical power of execution.

When strategic advantages take shape, when officers and troops are single-minded and precise, when the capable are chosen and posts filled by the right men, when plans are set and decisions made, when life and death are clear, when actions are sound and errors avoided—none can withstand the shock. Thus, cities fall without siege engines or scaling ladders; battles are won without blades crossing; the certainty of victory is manifest.

Therefore, one does not engage in battle without assurance of victory, nor launch an attack without certainty of success. Victory must be assured before battle is joined, the signal given before movement begins. Thus, forces gather without vain dispersal, troops advance without empty return.

Only when there is no reckless movement—no "almost" or "nearly"—does one shake heaven and earth, defy the mountains, sweep the seas, make ghosts and spirits flee, and beasts take flight. Then, the wilds know no rival armies, the enemy’s forces dare not meet in battle again, and the nation’s cities stand undefended.

Calm overcomes agitation, order masters chaos; the formless controls the formed, non-action responds to change. Though one may not yet have triumphed over the enemy, the enemy has no path to victory. If the enemy moves first, their form is revealed; if they are restless while we are still, their strength is spent. When form is revealed, victory can be seized; when strength is spent, might can be established.

Observe their actions and adapt accordingly; discern their righteousness or deceit to command their fate. Bait them with what they desire, exhaust their steps.

Should the enemy exploit a gap, swiftly seal their breach, exhaust their permutations to bind them, and deplete their momentum to humble them. If the enemy reverts to stillness, launch the unexpected; when they fail to respond, exhaust their maneuvers alone—meaning, I exhaust my own maneuvers to await the enemy.

If they move and I counter, their actions are exposed; if they lag in rhythm, they become the enemy. "Lag" means falling behind the rhythm. The enemy behind compels the one ahead to act first. Adapt with their shifts. Where they amass, they must also falter: if their essence turns left, ensnare their right flank—the right flank being the west. Should the enemy rout and flee, their rear can yet be turned.

If pressed and unmoving, they are called "stagnant delay"; strike them like thunder, sever them like grass and trees, dazzle them like fire and lightning. Seek swiftness to overtake; men cannot match the pace of spurs, chariots cannot turn their hubs in time. Troops stand like rooted trees, crossbows coil like ram’s horns. Though their numbers be great, none dare resist the momentum.

All that bears form can be countered; all that takes shape can be met.

Thus the sage conceals form in the formless and roams the mind in emptiness. Wind and rain may be blocked, but cold and heat cannot be opened or closed—because they are without form. That which can slip through the subtlest crevices, pierce metal and stone, reach the farthest extremes, soar beyond the nine heavens (放 means "to lodge"), coil beneath the Yellow Springs—only the formless can do this.

The skilled commander strikes disorder, not order; he does not assault a fully arrayed foe or charge against firmly planted banners (填填: banners standing firm and upright). Before the enemy’s intent is visible, engage through numerical advantage. When they reveal a fatal flaw, seize and control it. If the enemy clings to rigid patterns, their movements will fall into shadow. Respond to the substantial with the insubstantial, and they will surely be captured.

Tigers and leopards do not stir and thus avoid pitfalls; deer do not move and thus escape snares; birds do not take flight and thus evade nets; fish and turtles do not shift and thus avoid hooks. No creature is not controlled by its own movement. Therefore the sage values stillness. Stillness can respond to agitation, lateness can respond to earliness, precision can overcome carelessness, breadth can capture gaps.

Thus the masterful general commands his troops by unifying their hearts and consolidating their strength. The brave cannot advance alone, the timid cannot retreat alone. They halt like mountains, advance like wind and rain. What they assail is broken, none can withstand their destruction. They move as one body, none can resist. Thus many wound the enemy, while few engage in hand-to-hand combat.

Five fingers taking turns striking are not as effective as a clenched fist; ten thousand men advancing in rotation are not as effective as a hundred striking together. Tigers and leopards are swift, bears and brown bears are strong, yet men eat their flesh and sit upon their hides—because they cannot unify their knowledge or concentrate their strength.

Water overpowers fire: when the Terrace of Zhanghua (a lofty tower of Chu) burned, attempting to douse it with a ladle’s worth of water—even if one drained wells and emptied ponds—would be futile. But raise a jug, a vat, a basin, a pot to pour, and the flames can be extinguished in an instant.

Men do not possess the overwhelming advantage of water over fire, yet to seek victory with the few against the many is clearly impossible. Some strategists claim that the few can overcome the many—this refers to leadership, not combat. To lead many but employ few is due to uneven momentum; uneven momentum arises from disunited strength. To lead few but employ many is due to harmonized effort.

As for fully utilizing each man’s talent and exhausting their strength to achieve victory with the few over the many—from ancient times to the present, this has never been heard of.

Nothing is more noble than Heaven, nothing more advantageous than Earth, nothing more urgent than timing, nothing more beneficial than men. These four are the pillars of warfare. Yet they must await the Dao before they can be employed—only then can they be used as one.

Terrain can overcome Heaven’s timing, skillful action can overcome terrain, momentum can overcome men. Thus those who rely on Heaven may be deceived, those who rely on Earth may be constrained, those who rely on timing may be pressured, those who rely on men may be confused.

Benevolence, courage, trustworthiness, and integrity are human virtues, yet the courageous can be lured, the benevolent can be robbed, the trustworthy can be deceived, the upright can be outmaneuvered. A commander who reveals even a single flaw will be captured.

From this it is clear: victory in war is achieved through principle, not the excellence of human talent.

Thus those who behave like deer may be trapped with snares—deer have weapons but cannot fight, for they lack strategy. Those who behave like fish and turtles may be caught with nets—their forces scatter and do not unite. Those who behave like swans and cranes may be struck with arrows—their forces are aloft but lack cover. Only the formless cannot be countered.

Therefore the sage hides in the formless origin, so his intentions cannot be observed; moves in the shapeless, so his formations cannot be mapped. Without fixed methods or patterns, he responds appropriately to what comes. Without name or form, he transforms and takes shape.

Profound and luminous, distant and boundless, enduring through winter and summer, spring and autumn, ascending to the highest reaches, descending to the deepest depths—his changes and transformations flow without obstruction. He establishes his heart in the realm of the obscure and conceals his will in the abyss of ninefold whirls (九旋: the deepest abyss, with nine turns). Even with keen eyes, who can fathom his intentions?

What warfare conceals is the Way of Heaven; what it diagrams is terrain; what it articulates is human affairs; what it employs to decide victory is strategic momentum.

Thus the supreme general in command of troops secures the Way of Heaven above, the advantages of Earth below, and the hearts of men in between. He acts with opportunity and strikes with momentum—thus he suffers no shattered armies or defeated troops.

The middling general, ignorant of Heaven’s Way above and Earth’s advantages below, relies solely on men and momentum. Though he may not achieve absolute perfection, his victories will surely be many.

The inferior general, with broad learning yet self-confusion, with much knowledge yet self-doubt, is fearful when stationary and hesitant when acting—thus his movements lead to capture.

Now, when two men cross blades, their skill being equal, why does the brave and resolute always prevail? Because his actions are wholehearted.

A massive axe striking paulownia wood need not wait for an auspicious day to split it. But place the axe upon the wood without a man to wield it—even if aligned with the Dipper’s handle and embracing the powers of punishment and virtue (招摇: the Dipper’s handle; 刑: the twelve celestial stems), it will achieve nothing.

Virtue (德) refers to the ten celestial stems. Yet without the power of momentum (勢), even it cannot split the wood. Thus, water surges with force when channeled, and arrows fly farther when loosed with vigor.

The arrowhead is bound with silver and tin—adorned, not bare. Though wrapped in fine silk or tipped with rotting lotus stems, it cannot strike alone. Only when lent the strength of sinew and horn, the momentum of bow and crossbow, does it pierce rhinoceros hide and cleave through leather shields.

The wind’s fury can tear roofs and snap trees; when it rises from the void, its descent is swift, yet ascending a high mound, it slows—such is the nature of all things set in motion.

Therefore, a master of warfare wields momentum like bursting a dam of accumulated water from a thousand-yard cliff, or rolling boulders down a ten-thousand-foot ravine. When the world sees my troops must be deployed, who dares oppose me?

A hundred men resolved to die are worth more than ten thousand certain to flee—how much more so an entire army charging through fire and water without turning back? Even if blades suddenly clash across the land, who would dare stand above them?

What is called "heaven’s decree" aligns thus: the Azure Dragon to the left, the White Tiger to the right, the Vermilion Bird ahead, the Dark Warrior behind. The Horn and Neck stars form the Azure Dragon; Orion’s Belt and the Well, the White Tiger; the Star and Spread, the Vermilion Bird; the Dipper and Ox, the Dark Warrior. In warfare, position the Well and Orion’s Belt to your right, the Horn and Neck to your left, turn your back to the Dipper and Ox, and face the Star and Spread—this follows the Dipper’s balance.

What is called "earth’s advantage" means life lies behind and death ahead, the male to the left and the female to the right. Heights are life; lowlands, death. Hills are male; valleys, female.

What is called "human affairs" demands rewards and punishments be certain, movements timely, and actions swift. These are the transmitted standards of conduct, yet they are not the source of life. Standards adapt to the times—they are not fixed.

Thus, one who sits in the shade of a hall knows the sun and moon’s order; seeing ice in a jar, one knows the world’s cold and heat. The signs by which things take form are subtle—only the sage grasps their essence.

The drum does not join the five notes yet governs them; water does not blend with the five flavors yet harmonizes them; the general does not partake in the five offices’ duties yet oversees them. Therefore, one who harmonizes the five notes does not belong to them; one who balances the five flavors does not mix with them; one who governs the five offices cannot be measured.

Thus, the general’s heart is ordered like spring, vast like summer, clear like autumn, steadfast like winter—constant and upright as winter’s rigor. Adapting to circumstances, he transforms with them; following the times, he shifts with them.

Shadows do not straighten crooked objects; echoes do not muddy clear sounds. Observe what comes, and respond with what prevails.

Therefore, act with righteousness, proceed by reason, cover your plans to strike decisively. Leverage resources to succeed, letting the enemy know your advances but not your retreats, your attacks but not your gatherings.

Begin like a fox—luring them to underestimate; close like a rhinoceros or tiger—driving them to flee. When birds of prey strike, they lower their heads; when fierce beasts seize, they hide their claws. Tigers and leopards do not bare their claws before biting, nor show their teeth before tearing.

Thus, the way of warfare is to display softness while meeting with hardness, show weakness while overpowering with strength, feign retreat while advancing, intend west while signaling east. Strike first in nature, then unite; act in darkness, then reveal. Like ghosts leaving no trace, like water leaving no wound.

Where you face is not where you go; what you reveal is not what you plot. In every movement, stillness, none can discern your design—like thunder’s strike, unpreparable. What is used is not reused, so victory is complete.

In communion with the profound and luminous, none know its gate—this is called supreme divinity.

An army’s strength lies in its people; the people’s resolve to die lies in righteousness; righteousness’s power to prevail lies in authority. Thus, unite them with culture, align them with discipline—this ensures victory. Authority and decorum together make supreme strength.

People cherish life and fear death, yet when high walls and deep moats bristle with arrows like rain, when on open plains and vast marshes blades cross, soldiers still rush to engage—not because they scorn death or welcome injury, but because rewards are certain and punishments clear.

Thus, if a ruler treats his people like children, they will regard him as a father; if he treats them like younger brothers, they will regard him as an elder brother. Treat them as children, and you will rule the four seas; regard him as a father, and the world will be ordered. Treat them as younger brothers, and they will not hesitate to die for you; serve him as an elder brother, and they will not hesitate to perish for him.

Thus, even enemies bound by father-son or brotherly ties cannot be fought—such is the power of accumulated kindness.

If four horses are unruly, even Zaofu cannot drive them far; if bow and arrow are misaligned, even Yi cannot strike true; if ruler and minister are at odds, even Sunzi cannot respond to the enemy.

*(Sunzi was Wu King Helü’s general, named Wu.)*

Thus, the ruler must cultivate governance within to accumulate virtue, and block external disgrace to establish awe. He must observe their toil and ease to know their hunger and satiety—then the day of battle will have its appointed time, and facing death will be like returning home.

Therefore, the general must share sweetness and bitterness, hunger and cold with his soldiers, so that their lives may be fully given in death. Thus, the skilled generals of old always led by example: in heat, they did not raise canopies; in cold, they did not wear furs, thereby measuring endurance through heat and cold. On perilous paths, they did not ride; when ascending heights, they dismounted, thereby equalizing toil and ease. They ate only after the army’s food was cooked, drank only after the army’s wells were dug, thereby sharing hunger and thirst. In battle, they stood within arrow’s range to share danger and safety.

Thus, a good general in warfare always strikes accumulated resentment with accumulated virtue, and accumulated hatred with accumulated love—how could he not prevail? What the ruler demands of the people are two things: that they toil for him, and that they die for him. What the people expect of the ruler are three things: that the hungry be fed, the weary be rested, and the meritorious be rewarded. If the people fulfill their two duties while the ruler fails their three expectations, then though the state be vast and its people numerous, its armies will still be weak.

But if the suffering are assured of joy, the toiling of gain, the beheaded of full reward, and the families of the fallen of recompense—for those who die in battle—then once these four promises are trusted by the people, the ruler may shoot birds in the clouds or angle fish in the abyss, play the zither and lute, strike bells and pipes, engage in six-board games, or toss arrows into high vases, yet his armies will remain strong and his commands will still be obeyed.

Thus, when the ruler’s provisions are sufficient, the people can be employed; when his virtue is sufficient to inspire admiration, his awe can be established. A general must possess three paths, four principles, five virtues, and ten steadfast qualities.

The three paths are: above, knowing the Way of Heaven; below, being versed in terrain; and in between, discerning human nature. These are the paths all people follow.

The four principles are: benefiting the state without betraying the army (betrayal here means failure to meet expectations), serving the ruler without regard for one’s life, facing peril without fearing death, and resolving doubts without shirking blame.

The five virtues are: being yielding yet uncoilable, firm yet unbreakable, benevolent yet unassailable, trustworthy yet undeceived, and courageous yet undominated.

The ten steadfast qualities are: spirit clear and unclouded, plans far-reaching and unenvious, resolve firm and unshaken, wisdom bright and unobscured, not covetous of wealth, not indulgent in things, not boastful in speech, not rigid in methods, not swayed by joy, and not provoked by anger.

This is called attaining the profound and obscure—who can fathom its depths? Every action must hit its mark, every word must align with principle, every movement must accord with the times, and every resolution must strike the proper balance.

To strike the proper balance is to align with principle. Mastering the interplay of movement and stillness, discerning the rhythms of opening and closing, and weighing the advantages and harms of every action—all must fit like tallying tokens.

Swift as a drawn crossbow, forceful as a loosed arrow, now like a dragon, now like a serpent, their movements never fixed in form. None see where they strike, none know where they end. When they attack, none can defend; when they defend, none can attack.

It is said that those skilled in warfare must first cultivate themselves before seeking from others; first ensure invincibility before pursuing victory. Cultivating oneself among others, seeking victory over the enemy—if one cannot govern oneself yet attacks another’s chaos, this is like quenching fire with fire or countering water with water. How can one prevail?

If a potter were transformed into clay, they could not shape vessels; if the clay were further reduced to raw earth, the potter could not restore it. If a weaver were turned into silk, they could not weave brocade. Sameness cannot govern sameness; thus, difference becomes the marvel.

Two sparrows fighting will not die, but when a goshawk arrives, they scatter—because it is of a different kind. Stillness is the marvel of restlessness, order the marvel of chaos, satiety the marvel of hunger, ease the marvel of toil. The interplay of marvel and norm is like water, fire, metal, and wood alternating as yin and yang.

Those skilled in warfare wield the five slayings in response—the five slayings being the five phases. Thus, they secure total victory. The inept dwell in the five deaths out of greed, so their movements lead only to capture.

War values plans that cannot be fathomed, forms that remain concealed, and strikes that come without warning, leaving no time for preparation. If plans are exposed, they fail; if forms are revealed, they are controlled. Thus, those skilled in warfare conceal themselves in heaven above, earth below, and among people.

Concealing in heaven means nothing cannot be controlled. What is concealing in heaven? Extreme cold or heat, fierce winds or violent rain, thick fog or dark obscurity—using these to create change.

What is concealing in earth? Mountains, hills, mounds, forests, thickets, and perilous terrain—places where one can lie in ambush unseen.

What is concealing among people? Obscuring ahead while observing behind, moving through formations with sudden strikes, swift as thunder or storm. Rolling up banners, silencing drums, appearing and vanishing without form, leaving no trace of their beginnings or ends.

Thus, ranks align evenly front and back, the four sides straight as a plumb line. Advancing and retreating, they do not overstep or encroach, their flanks light and sharp. Sometimes ahead, sometimes behind, scattering and regrouping without breaking formation—this is skill in ordering ranks.

Mastery of marvel and norm, yin and yang, punishment and virtue, the five phases, observing qi, divining by stars, tortoise shells, and milfoil stalks, and interpreting omens—this is skill in the Way of Heaven.

Setting traps, laying ambushes, employing water and fire, deploying rare marvels, and raising war cries to deafen the enemy’s ears. Dragging brushwood, scattering kindling, raising dust and stirring up earth to blind their eyes—this is skill in deception.

Heavy axes and halberds, steadfast and unshakable, rooted deep and hard to terrify—neither profit nor advantage can lure them, nor can the threat of death move them: this is skill in fullness and strength. Swift and fierce, agile and bold, they charge with reckless courage, vanishing like a snuffed flame: this is skill in employing light forces for surprise attacks.

Assessing terrain, choosing encampments, fortifying ramparts, surveying signals and outposts, occupying high ground, and selecting routes—this is skill in mastering topography. Exploiting the enemy’s hunger and thirst, cold and heat, exhaustion and disorder, fear and constriction, striking with elite troops by night—this is skill in seizing the moment and adapting to change.

On level ground, use chariots; on rough terrain, use cavalry. When crossing water, rely on bows, for in water the crossbow cannot be drawn. In narrow passes, use crossbows, for handheld crossbows serve best in confined spaces. By day, display many banners; by night, raise many torches. In darkness and gloom, sound many drums: this is skill in deploying forces.

Though these eight arts are indispensable, they are not the essence of warfare. The commander must possess unique vision and unique knowledge. Unique vision means seeing what others cannot see; unique knowledge means knowing what others do not know. Seeing what others cannot see is called clarity; knowing what others do not know is called spirit. Spirit and clarity ensure victory before battle. Such victory means an enemy’s defenses cannot be breached, their forces cannot be overcome, their attacks cannot prevail—for this is the mastery of emptiness and fullness.

When superiors and subordinates are divided, commanders and officers at odds, their cause unjust, and troops harboring resentment, this is called emptiness. When the ruler is enlightened and the commander capable, superiors and subordinates united in purpose, their qi and resolve rising as one, this is called fullness. Like water poured onto fire, where it strikes, what it overwhelms shifts—unyielding and yielding do not mix, yet victory lies in their interplay: this is the meaning of emptiness and fullness.

Thus, the skilled warrior does not depend on numbers, the skilled defender does not rely on fortifications. Victory lies in gaining awe, defeat in losing morale. When full, they fight; when empty, they flee. When flourishing, they are strong; when weakened, they retreat.

King Fuchai of Wu ruled over two thousand *li* of land, fielded seven hundred thousand armored troops, defeated Yue in the south at Mount Kuaiji, crushed Qi in the north at Ailing, and overawed the Duke of Jin in the west at Huangchi—subduing Jin. This was the power of a people’s full qi.

After this, King Fuchai grew arrogant and indulgent, rejecting remonstrance and delighting in flattery. His reckless ferocity exceeded all bounds—*hao* (憢) meaning fierce and impetuous—so that none could correct him. His great ministers seethed with resentment, and the common people turned away. The King of Yue selected three thousand crack troops and captured him at Zuì, exploiting his emptiness.

The presence of emptiness and fullness in qi is like the certainty of darkness following light. Thus, victorious armies are not always full, nor are defeated armies always empty. The skilled commander fills his people’s qi to await the enemy’s emptiness; the unskilled empties his people’s qi to await the enemy’s fullness. Therefore, the interplay of emptiness and fullness in qi is the most precious principle in warfare.

Whenever a state faced peril, the ruler would summon his general from the palace and address him, saying: “The fate of the altars of soil and grain rests with you. Now the state is in danger; I ask you to lead our forces in response.” The general, having received his charge, would order the invocators, historians, and grand diviners to fast for three days. They would then proceed to the ancestral temple, bore the sacred tortoise, and divine an auspicious day to receive the drums and banners.

The ruler would enter the temple gate and stand facing west, while the general, entering the gate, would hasten to the hall and stand facing north. The sovereign would personally take up the battle-axe, grasp its head, and present its haft to the general, saying: “From this point upward to Heaven, you shall command.” He would then take up the halberd, grasp its head, and present its haft to the general, saying: “From this point downward to the abyss, you shall command.”

Having received the axes, the general would reply: “A state cannot be governed from without, nor can an army be directed from within. A divided heart cannot serve a lord, nor can a distracted will face the enemy. Since I have already received your charge, the authority of the drums, banners, axes, and halberds rests with me. I ask that you grant me your command in a single word, without further appeal. If you do not consent, I dare not take command. If you consent, I shall take my leave and depart.”

He would then pare his nails—*jian zhao* (爪鬋), a funerary rite, removing the nails from hands and feet—and don the mourning garments, called *ming yi* (明衣), for though they are worn in darkness, they are called “bright.” He would then break through the ominous gate and depart—the ominous gate being the northern gate. The general’s departure was treated as a funeral rite, for he was bound to die.

Mounting his war chariot, bearing the banners, axes, and halberds, he would appear as one barely able to sustain their weight. When facing the enemy in decisive battle, he would disregard certain death, harboring no divided loyalty. Thus, he would have no Heaven above, no Earth below, no enemy before him, and no sovereign behind him. He would advance without seeking fame and retreat without avoiding blame, protecting only the people and aligning his actions with the ruler’s interests. This is the fullness of the state and the Way of the supreme general.

In this manner, the wise would devise strategies for him, the brave would fight for him, and their qi would soar like clouds, swift as a galloping steed. Thus, before the armies even engaged, the enemy would tremble in fear. If victorious and the enemy routed, he would fully accept rewards and honors: officers would be promoted, ranks and emoluments increased, lands apportioned as tribute, and decisions made beyond the borders. Judgment and execution of offenders would be carried out within the army.

Upon returning to the state, he would lower the banners and enter with the axes and halberds, reporting to the ruler: “The army requires no further governance.” He would then don plain white garments and withdraw to a secluded chamber to await punishment. The ruler would say: “I pardon you.” The general would withdraw and don ritual attire.

For a great victory, he would remain away from his residence for three years; for a moderate victory, two years; and for a minor victory, one year. Wherever the army was deployed, it was against a state without the Dao. Thus, one could achieve victory without reprisal, seize territory without returning it, the people would suffer no epidemics, the general would not die prematurely, the five grains would flourish, wind and rain would come in season, triumph abroad would bring blessings at home, and only when fame was secured would no further harm remain.

The "Explanation of Mountains" Discourse

Mountains form the root of the Dao, the abode of the benevolent. The essence of discoursing on the Dao accumulates like mountains—hence the title "Explanation of Mountains," from which this chapter takes its name.

Po asked Hun: “What constitutes the form of the Dao?”
Po is the yin spirit of man; Hun, the yang spirit. Yin’s Dao originates from yang, thus Po asks Hun: what form does the Dao possess?
Hun replied: “It takes non-being as its form.”
The Dao is formless, taking non-being as its form.
Po said: “Does non-being possess form?”
Hun said: “It does not.”
“Then how can it be perceived?”
If it has no form or shape, how can it be known?
Hun said: “I simply encountered it.”
“Encounter” means to come upon and know it.
“To see it, it has no form; to hear it, it makes no sound—this is called the obscure and dark.”
The obscure and dark serve as metaphors for the Dao, yet they are not the Dao itself. They resemble the Dao but are not the Dao.
Po said: “I have grasped it.”
“Grasped” means to know. He then turned inward to reflect.
Hun said: “Those who attain the Dao cannot be seen in form, nor can their names be proclaimed.”
“Proclaimed” means to be named; some texts render it as “manifest.”
“Now that you possess form and name, how can the Dao reside within you?”
Po said: “Then what is speech for?”
Po asked Hun: “You have no form, so why do you speak?”
“I shall return to my origin.”
“Origin” means the root. Po spoke of returning to non-being.
Po turned to look, and Hun suddenly vanished—Hun was no longer visible. Turning back to himself, he too dissolved into formlessness.
Some texts render “form” as “being.”

If one does not engage in minor learning, one will not fall into great delusion. If one’s learning is not broad, one cannot penetrate the Dao—hence great delusion.
If one does not possess petty cleverness, one will not fall into great folly. Petty cleverness cannot comprehend things—hence great folly.
No one gazes into turbulent rainwater but gazes into still water, for it is tranquil and undisturbed.
“Turbulent rainwater” refers to water covering a jar after rain. “Still” means unmoving water. “Disturbed” means in motion. Some texts render “turbulent rainwater” as “flowing runoff.”
In Zhan He’s fishing, even a thousand-year-old carp could not escape. Zhan He was Zhan What, an ancient adept of the Dao skilled in fishing, possessing refined techniques—thus he caught a thousand-year-old carp.
When Master Zeng clung to the funeral carriage, those pulling the bier halted for him. Master Zeng’s filial piety was such that, grieving at his parent’s funeral, he clung to the funeral carriage, and those pulling it were moved to stop.
“Bier” refers to the wheels beneath the coffin. “Bier” is pronounced like the *chūn* in “oxen moving *chūnchūn*.”
When the old mother sang as she walked, Shen Xi was moved—such was the power of her essence. Shen Xi was a man of Chu who lost his mother in youth. Hearing a beggar’s song as she walked, he was moved to go out and look, only to find it was his mother. Thus it is said: the power of her essence.
When Hu Ba played the zither, the wanton fish emerged to listen. Hu Ba was a man of Chu skilled in playing the zither. The wanton fish, fond of music, lifted their heads from the water to listen.
The wanton fish has a long head, its body half its length, over a *zhang* in size, with a pure white snout, jet-black body, and mouth beneath its chin. It resembles the *lige* fish but lacks scales, dwelling in the Yangtze.
When Bo Ya played the qin, the four horses raised their heads and ceased chewing. “Raised their heads and ceased chewing” means the horses lifted their heads and seemed to smile.
When Jie Zitui sang of dragons and serpents, Wenjun shed tears. Jie Zitui was Jie Pushi.

When Duke Wen of Jin, Chong'er, fled to Di, he encountered hardship and ran out of provisions. Jie Zitui cut flesh from his own thigh to feed him. Later, when the prince restored his state, he rewarded those who had followed him in exile, yet Zitui alone was overlooked. Thus he sang:

*A dragon soars high, yet loses its place.
A serpent follows, devouring its trace.
The dragon ascends to the clouds above,
While the serpent remains in the mud below.*

The dragon alludes to Duke Wen, the serpent to himself. Thereupon, Duke Wen awakened to his error and sought Jie Zitui, but failing to find him, wept in lament.

Thus, jade lies in the mountains, and the grasses and trees are moistened—jade being the yin within yang, it nourishes the grasses and trees. A pearl forms in the abyss, and the banks do not wither—the pearl being the yang within yin, its radiance keeps the banks from drying.

The earthworm, though lacking strong sinews and bones, sharp claws and teeth—known also as the *quanyu*—feeds above on sun-dried dust and drinks below from the Yellow Springs, all through the singleness of its intent. *Xi* means dry, *ke* refers to dust, which the people of Chu call *ke*. *One* signifies focused devotion.

Clarity brings illumination, as a cup of water reveals a mustard seed; turbidity brings obscurity, as the waters of the Yellow River cannot reveal Mount Tai. Gazing at the sun dazzles the eyes; listening to thunder deafens the ears. Man is at peace when he does nothing, but harmed when he acts. The Dao prizes non-action, hence peace. Action injures the Dao, for it does not value doing. Thus, those who govern through action are harmed as if by illness. Those who govern through non-action carry nothing—meaning that those who achieve governance through non-action constantly practice its absence.

Doing means being unable to be without action. *Doing* refers to action, to likes and dislikes, emotions and desires—being unable to remain tranquil and still, hence unable to practice non-action. Those who cannot practice non-action cannot achieve action. Those who cannot practice pure stillness and non-action cannot accomplish great deeds, bring about governance, or establish merit. Thus it is said: they cannot achieve action.

Man is spirit without speech. *Without speech* means the Dao does not speak, yet it transforms, hence it is spirit. Speech injures it. The Dao does not value speech, so speech causes harm. Those who are spirit without speech carry nothing—the Dao values silence, and through it attains the spirit. *Carry* means to practice, to constantly enact its absence of speech. Speech injures the spirit. Those who attain the spirit find the Dao scorns speech, yet often revert to it, thus harming their own spirit.

The nose breathes, the ears hear—both ultimately employ what is without use as their use. *Without use* refers to the hollow spaces within the nose and ears. All things rely on what they possess to employ what they lack, using what is without use as their use.

To test this, observe the *lai* and the *yu*. The *lai* is a three-holed flute. Its hollow pipes produce sound. Thus it is said: observe the *lai* and the *yu*.

Those burdened by thoughts cannot sleep. As the *Book of Songs* says:
*"Restless, I cannot sleep,
As if weighed by deep sorrow."*
And again:
*"Tossing upon my pillow,
I sigh through waking and dreaming."*

To halt thoughts is to act upon what is halted. *Halt* means to remove. Forcibly suppressing thoughts is not true absence of thought, but merely stopping where things stop. When both are gone—thoughts and the forced cessation of thoughts—then utmost virtue is pure.

*Both* refers to thoughts and the forced absence of thoughts. Abandoning these two, the spirit is inwardly guarded, and utmost virtue becomes pure and unified.

The sage speaks of governance his whole life, yet what he employs is not his speech, but what underlies it. *Not his speech* means not his usual words. *What underlies it* refers to the words suited to governance.

A singer has lyrics, yet what makes people admire them is not the lyrics themselves. *Admire them* means admiring the clarity and harmony of the sound, not the lyrics. Thus it is said: not the lyrics.

The parrot can speak, yet cannot be made to lead. The parrot is a bird from Shu Commandery, with a red beak, its plumage pale green, able to mimic human speech. *Lead* means to preside. Why is this so?

To grasp their words but not their underlying meaning—
*To grasp their words* means knowing how to mimic human speech.
Yet not understanding the words of leadership and command,
thus it is said: not grasping their underlying meaning.

Therefore, those who follow tracks are not those who create them.
*Follow* means to trail after.
Tracing another’s old tracks, they cannot establish foundations or devise systems,
nor forge new paths themselves—
just as the parrot knows how to mimic speech but cannot produce the words of a leader.

The divine serpent can sever itself and rejoin,
yet cannot prevent others from severing it.
The sacred tortoise can appear in King Yuan of Song’s dreams,
yet cannot free itself from the fisherman’s basket.
King Yuan of Song once dreamed of obtaining a divine tortoise but had not yet captured it;
the fisherman Yu Ju caught the tortoise while fishing and presented it to the king,
who then split its shell for divination.
Thus it is said: it could appear in the king’s dream but could not escape the fisherman’s basket.

The four directions are all gates and windows of the Dao—
it depends on which one you peer through.

Thus, angling can teach riding,
riding can teach charioteering,
and charioteering can teach boat-piercing.
These four arts all require reverence and adherence to their principles,
hence they can be taught to one another.

The people of Yue learn long-range archery,
shooting toward the heavens,
yet their arrows land within five paces.
The people of Yue are skilled in water and boats,
but know nothing of archery—
shooting upward toward the sky,
the arrow’s force exhausts itself and falls back,
thus landing within five paces.
*Toward* means to aim at.
Yet they do not alter their method.
*Method* refers to the technique of archery.
Since they do not understand archery,
they do not know to abandon the practice of aiming at the heavens.

The world has already changed,
yet they cling to the old ways—
this is like the archery of the people of Yue.
It speaks of clinging to the past without knowing how to adapt.

At the full moon, the sun eclipses its light—
yin cannot overpower yang.
On the fifteenth day, when the moon and sun face each other directly,
a lunar eclipse occurs, thus the moon’s light is stolen.
If misaligned, it wanes; at the dark of the moon, it vanishes entirely.
Thus it is said: yin cannot overpower yang.

When the sun rises, the stars disappear—
they cannot contend with its brilliance.
Stars are yin; they cannot steal the sun’s light.

Thus, the branch cannot surpass the root in strength,
nor can the finger exceed the arm in size.
If the lower is light and the upper heavy,
it will surely topple.

A single abyss cannot hold two *jiao*.
*The jiao* is the chief of fish, its skin bearing pearls,
now used to adorn the hilts of swords and knives.
Another account says a fish of two thousand *jin* is called a *jiao*.

When water is still, it is clear and level;
when stirred, it loses its balance.
Thus, only by not moving can it be the source of all movement.

The Yangtze and Yellow Rivers can nourish the hundred valleys
because they lower themselves.
Only by lowering themselves can they rise.
*Rise* means to become great.

Nothing in the world is as mutually destructive as glue and lacquer—once bound, they cannot be separated, hence called "mutual hatred." Another account says: when glue enters lacquer, it spoils; when lacquer enters glue, it too is ruined—judged by their proportions, thus called "mutual hatred." Yet nothing is as mutually nurturing as ice and charcoal. When ice meets charcoal, it melts and returns to water, restoring its nature; when charcoal meets ice, it preserves its essence—hence called "mutual love." Glue and lacquer devour each other; ice and charcoal bring each other rest.

A crumbling wall is all the more upright in its collapse—earth reverts to its origin, returning to soil, thus called "all the more upright." Melting ice is all the more solid in its dissolution, for it returns to its source. *Pàn* means to release and return to water. *Zōng* means origin.

The form of Mount Tai looms majestic and towering—*róng* means shape. Yet a thousand *li* away, one sees neither mound nor ridge, for distance obscures them. *Duǒ-kě* is like a screen or veil. *Duǒ* is pronounced like *wàng*, as in the speech of those between the Yangtze and Huai rivers. It can be understood thus.

The tip of an autumn hair sinks into the unfathomable.

Thus, what is too small cannot serve as the inner, just as what is too great cannot serve as the outer. What is too small to be inner is even smaller than the tip of an autumn hair—this is called "non-being." Yet "non-being" without form is the utmost vastness, and cannot serve as the outer.

Orchids grow in secluded valleys, yet do not cease to be fragrant for lack of wearers—their nature is to be fragrant. A boat lies upon rivers and seas, yet does not cease to float for lack of passengers—its nature is to float. The noble one practices righteousness, yet does not cease or rest for lack of recognition—his nature is benevolence and righteousness.

Now jade is lustrous and radiant, its sound leisurely and modulated—*shū* means unhurried, *yáng* means restrained. How it resembles! It resembles the noble one. *Huàn* is pronounced as when people call a wealthy household "lord of the waist." Without inner or outer, it conceals no flaws or filth—without inner or outer, its surface and interior are one. *Nì* means to hide.

Draw near, and it moistens; gaze from afar, and it gleams. A mirror reflects the pupils of the eye, discerns the finest autumn hair, and illuminates the darkest depths.

Thus the Heshi jade and the Marquis of Sui’s pearl, born of the essence of mountains and deep pools—when the noble one wears them, he follows auspiciousness and attains tranquility. *Fu* means to wear. The noble one wears them as symbols, free from passions and desires, able to follow goodness and secure his person.

Kings and marquises treasure them, using them to rectify all under heaven. *Bao* means to value. Kings and marquises esteem their celestial nature as common folk esteem pearls and jade, thus employing them to govern all under heaven without partiality or self-interest.

When Chen Chengzi Heng coerced Ziyuan Jie, Chen Chengzi was about to kill Duke Jian of Qi, sending sixteen warriors to threaten his minister Ziyuan Jie, desiring to divide the state with him. Jie refused, hence it is called coercion. When Zihan declined what he did not desire—not desiring the king’s treasure—he obtained what he did desire: the treasure of non-greed.

When Confucius saw the cicada-catcher, it was during Baigong Sheng’s inverted staff. The inverted staff injured his forehead, blood flowing to his shoes yet he remained unaware, for his spirit was wholly absorbed. When Lady Wei pleaded for punishment before Duke Huan, Lady Wei was a daughter of Wei and wife of Duke Huan of Qi. Duke Huan harbored intentions to attack Wei; Lady Wei perceived his countenance and knew it, thus pleading for the duke’s execution to atone for Wei’s offense.

When Confucius saw Zixia and asked, “Why are you so plump?”—it was because the Way prevailed, free from passions and desires, hence his plumpness. When Marquis Wen of Wei saw him, he turned his fur robe inside out to carry hay, knowing that when the hide is worn through, the fur has nothing to cling to.

When Er Yue explained the untying of knots to the King of Song—knots that could not be untied—he untied them by not untying. All these are subtle and profound matters from which one may observe principles. *Wei miao* means to perceive the end from the beginning.

A man marrying off his daughter instructed her, saying, “Go now, and be careful not to do good.” She asked, “If I do not do good, shall I do evil instead?” He replied, “If goodness is left undone, how much more so evil?” This preserves one’s celestial endowment. *Qi* means nature. Mencius said human nature is good, hence it is called preserving one’s celestial nature.

Those confined in prison count the days as long; those condemned to die in the marketplace count the days as short. The length of days has its measure: where one’s heart is set, days seem short; where it is not, they seem long—thus the center is not at peace. *Zhong* means the heart. Therefore, those who take imbalance as balance—such balance is not true balance.

Marrying a daughter to one afflicted with consumption: if the husband dies, she will have difficulty remarrying. Taking the daughter as a curse upon the husband, later men dare not wed her, hence remarrying is difficult. Another explanation: the daughter, seeing all men as consumed, refuses to remarry.

Thus one cannot sit beneath a crumbling eave, nor stand beside a leaning wall, for fear of collapse and crushing. Those who preside over prisons and cells remain free from illness, for malevolent spirits fear them and thus do not afflict them. Those sentenced to death grow plump and lustrous, their minds resolved, free from external concerns. Another explanation: those condemned to death, their sentences decided, are without worry, hence their plumpness and luster.

Those who have been mutilated often live long, their hearts unburdened. *Xingzhe* refers to the castrated. Free from the burden of passions and desires, their spirit is not depleted, hence they often live long.

A skilled physician constantly treats illnesses before they arise, thus preventing illness—by rectifying the true nature, the spirit guards within, hence no illness. The sage constantly addresses calamities before they arise, thus preventing calamity. *Zhi* means to govern.

The supreme craftsman does not use a sword, for his skill lies in mind and hand. The master of closure does not use bolts or bars, for he closes his heart, and thus needs no bolts. This is akin to Chun Yükun’s warning of a fire: Chun Yükun was a man of Qi. He warned his neighbor that the chimney would cause a fire and urged him to bend the flue and move the firewood. The neighbor did not heed him, and later the fire indeed broke out. The one who warned received no reward, while those who extinguished the fire, their heads and brows scorched, were made honored guests—criticizing the failure to prepare in advance. It illustrates how people do not know to preemptively close their passions and desires, yet expect others to rescue them from disaster.

Entering the turbid from the clear brings distress and humiliation; entering the clear from the turbid brings ruin and collapse. The noble one’s approach to goodness is like a firewood gatherer who, upon seeing even a single blade, plucks it, and upon seeing verdant greens, pulls them up—nothing is left behind. The noble one’s practice of goodness is likewise.

When the two qi of heaven conjoin, a rainbow forms; when the two qi of earth conjoin, the hidden is released—yin and yang interact, the two qi. When the two qi of man conjoin, illness arises. The perverse qi invades the upright qi, hence illness.

Yin cannot be yang, nor yang yin; winter cannot be summer, nor summer winter. The moon knows not day, nor the sun night—each cannot encompass the other.

The master archer never misses the mark, skilled in archery yet unskilled in what he shoots. What he shoots dies, hence it is called unskillful. The master angler never fails to catch, skilled in fishing yet unskillful in what he catches. What he catches is fish, hence unskillful toward the fish. Thus where there is skill, there is also lack of skill.
