When bells and chimes are near, the bell’s sound is full—*chong* means great. When far, the chime’s sound is distinct—*qing* is stone, its sound clear and bright, audible from afar and distinctly manifest. Some things are naturally better near than far, others better far than near.

Now rice grows in water yet cannot grow in swift rapids; *tuan* means rushing water. Purple mushrooms grow on mountains yet cannot grow on solid rock, for their roots have nowhere to take hold. Lodestone attracts iron, yet with copper, it does not work—*xing* means to cause, unable to make it follow.

Where waters are vast, fish grow large; where mountains are high, trees grow tall. To expand one’s land while thinning one’s virtue is like a potter shaping vessels—kneading and pressing the clay without adding thickness, so that breakage comes all the sooner. *Yu* means "increasing"; *ji* means "swift." *Die* is read as in *die mai* (pulse-taking).

The sage does not act before the wind blows or before thunder strikes; only when compelled does he move, and thus remains unburdened. When the moon waxes and wanes above, the snail responds below—shared *qi* stirs in resonance. *Dong* means "to move," "to be moved." This cannot be considered distant. When the moon waxes, the snail’s flesh diminishes, hence it is said that the snail responds below. The moon is yin essence; the snail is also yin, thus they share the same *qi*. Though they may resonate, it cannot be called distant.

Holding a sling to summon birds or waving a whip to call dogs—desiring to draw them near, one only drives them away. Thus fish cannot be hooked without bait, nor beasts lured with an empty vessel. *Zhao* means "to summon," "to draw near."

To flay an ox’s hide and stretch it into a drum to command the three armies—yet for the ox’s sake, it would be better to serve beneath the yoke. A robe of white fox fur may clothe the Son of Heaven as he sits in the ancestral temple, yet for the fox’s sake, it would be better to run through the marshes. This speaks to the value of life.

To lose a sheep and gain an ox is to see no disadvantage; to sever a finger and save one’s head is to see no disadvantage in the act. Thus human nature, amid profit, contends for the greater gain, and amid harm, contends for the lesser loss.

A general dares not ride a white horse, for fear of being recognized. Another explanation: white is mourning garb, so he dares not ride it. As the tradition says, when Duke Xiang of Jin joined forces with the Jiang Rong and wore black mourning clothes, he defeated the Qin army at Xiāo—this speaks to altering mourning attire, hence the reluctance to ride a white horse.

A fugitive dares not carry a torch at night, for fear of being seen. A city guard dares not keep a biting dog. *Bao* refers to those who dwell within city walls. The guard, though well-provided, dares not keep a dog that bites.

When the cock crows at dawn, the crane knows it is midnight—yet this does not spare it from the cauldron. To scheme with ignorance is to remain unable to escape the cauldron. This is to say that a general must possess all five virtues and cannot act without adaptability.

Where mountains harbor fierce beasts, the forest trees go uncut; where gardens harbor stinging insects, the wild greens go unpicked. This speaks to human fear.

To be a Confucian scholar yet lounge in the lanes and alleys—Confucians esteem ritual and propriety, yet lounging in the lanes is improper. To be a Mohist yet play the reed pipes in Chaoge—Mohism values frugality and disdains music, and Chaoge was a place Mozi refused to enter; playing the pipes is improper.

To seek to erase one’s tracks by running through snow, or to rescue a drowning man without getting wet—these are acts of impossibility, doing what cannot be done.

Now, the blind drinker may not fail to spill his wine, but if he measures it himself, even a fool will not err. Thus there is nothing in the world that can succeed without harmony. *He* means "fitting," "proper."

To seek beauty is not to obtain beauty; not to seek beauty is to attain it. If the heart seeks a beautiful name, it will not gain a beautiful name; yet to diminish oneself is to earn a beautiful name.

Thus Laozi said: "Excessive pursuit of carriages results in no carriages." To seek ugliness is not to obtain ugliness; to seek not-ugliness is to invite ugliness. To seek neither beauty nor ugliness is to be without beauty or ugliness—this is called "mysterious sameness." *Xuan* means "Heaven." Heaven seeks nothing. If a person can seek nothing, they become one with it.

Shentu Di carried a stone and drowned himself in the depths, yet this does not make the drowning virtuous. Shentu Di was a man of the late Yin who could not bear to witness King Zhou’s tyranny, so he drowned himself. *Kang* means "lofty." When Xian Gao deceived to save Zheng, deceit cannot be made a constant. There are responses that fit the moment but cannot be followed as a rule. Xian Gao falsified the Zheng lord’s command, offering twelve oxen to reward the Qin army and thus repelling them—hence it is said that he deceived to save Zheng. Deceit is not upright, so it cannot be made a constant.

A man of many words is like the cry of the hundred-tongued bird. The hundred-tongued bird is a bird that can shift its tongue to mimic the calls of a hundred birds—hence its name. This is to say that though a person may speak much, it avails nothing.

A man of few words is like an unoiled door. This speaks to its silence, hence unoiled, a metaphor for no sound. Another explanation: an unoiled door is hard to open and close, also a metaphor for a man of few words.

When the six domestic animals grow extra ears or eyes, it is considered inauspicious, as recorded in the books of prophecy. *Xiang* means "auspicious." Extra ears or eyes are seen as omens of misfortune. This is to say that a person of many words and little sincerity is likened to the inauspicious.

A hundred men lifting a float are not as effective as one man carrying it and running. *Kang* means "to lift"; *fu* means "raft." A hundred men lifting together are not as efficient as one man holding it and moving swiftly. Some things, though many, are not as good as few—like pulling a cart, which requires two teams of six before it moves. The shaft requires three men, and each side of the shaft six, hence "two sixes." Another explanation: twelve men. Some things depend on mutual support to succeed—two men drowning cannot save each other, but one on land can.

Thus the same cannot govern itself; it must await the different before it can be completed. *Same* means the ruler says "yes" and the minister also says "yes," the ruler says "no" and the minister also says "no"—like adding water to water, who can consume it? This is called "same," and thus cannot govern. *Different* means supporting the ruler’s "yes," replacing the ruler’s "no," guiding him toward the proper path—this is called "different," and thus can accomplish things.

A thousand-year-old pine has *fuling* beneath it and dodder above...

The *fuling* is the resin of a thousand-year-old pine. The dodder grows upon it without roots, also called *nüluo*. Above it thrives a thicket of milfoil; beneath it hides a crouching tortoise. The sage perceives the inner from the outer, knowing the hidden through what is seen.

Delighting in martial prowess is not true chivalry—chivalry is lightness. Delighting in letters is not true Confucianism; fondness for remedies is not true medicine; love of horses is not true horsemanship; understanding music is not true musicianship; discerning flavors is not true cookery. These six arts are all practiced with skill yet lack mastery, having no proper name—thus they are called "skilled in one aspect but without a defining term."

Wearing armor is not for combat within ten paces; beyond a hundred paces, the contest lies in depth—deep strikes reach the five viscera, shallow ones stop at the skin. The distance between life and death cannot be measured in miles; it is spoken of as immeasurable.

When the King of Chu lost his gibbon, the forest was ravaged for it. The King of Chu refers to King Zhuang during his travels. Gibbons are swift and restless, dwelling in trees, so the forest was destroyed in the search. When the Lord of Song lost his pearl, the fish in the ponds were exhausted. When fire spreads through the marshes, the forests grow anxious—anxiety arises from impending harm.

When the ruler seeks timber, ministers ravage the woods; when the ruler seeks fish, ministers drain the valleys. When the ruler asks for oars, the people provide boats; when the ruler speaks in silk threads, the people respond in thick cords. A single cord is a great line. When the ruler has one virtue, the people offer two praises; when the ruler has three faults, the people bring nine condemnations. Faults and condemnations are both metaphors for excess. As the saying goes, what the ruler favors, the people favor even more—hence the nine condemnations.

Minister Zhong knew how to strengthen Yue but not how to preserve himself—he was ultimately killed by Yue. Chang Hong knew how to preserve Zhou but not how to save himself—he was killed by Zhou. They knew the distant but not the near. The distant refers to strengthening Yue and preserving Zhou; the near refers to themselves.

Fearing a horse’s bolting, one dares not ride; dreading a carriage’s overturning, one dares not board—thus emptying misfortune while rejecting public benefit. Those who are unfilial or disobedient may curse their parents, yet those who bear children cannot guarantee their filial piety—still, they raise and nurture them.

When the Fan clan fell, a thief stole their bells and fled. The Fan clan refers to Fan Jishe, great-grandson of Fan Hui, son of Fan Yang, the Viscount Zhaozhi. Their fall came when Zhao Jianzi attacked them, prompting the theft of their bells. Another account says Zhi Bo destroyed the Fan clan. The bells clanged loudly, and in fear of being heard, the thief hastily covered his ears. If others heard, so be it; covering his own ears was folly—confusion.

The *sheng* cannot exceed the *dan* in size, for the *sheng* lies within the *dan*; night cannot prolong the year, for night lies within the year; benevolence and righteousness cannot surpass the Dao and virtue, for benevolence and righteousness are enveloped by the Dao and virtue. Benevolence and righteousness are small, while the Dao and virtue are great. They are contained within the Dao and virtue as the *sheng* is within the *dan*, as night is within the year.

First the needle, then the thread—thus a curtain may be made; first the thread, then the needle—thus no garment can be completed. With needles, one makes tents; with baskets, one builds walls. The success or failure of affairs must arise from the small—this speaks of gradual progression. A *mu* is a curtain: the top is called *mu*, the sides *wei*. Without needles, thread cannot pass through, so they must come first. A *léi* is a basket for earth. Beginning with a single basketful, one piles it upon the wall—thus it is said that the success or failure of affairs must arise from the small.

A dyer must first apply blue, then black—this is permissible; first black, then blue—this is not. A craftsman must first apply lacquer, then vermilion—this is permissible; first vermilion, then lacquer—this is not. All things are like this: what comes first or last, above or below, must be carefully considered. To consider is to know.

When water grows turbid, fish gasp at the surface, their gills pale and gaping as they strain for air above the water. Bodily toil disrupts the spirit; when the body is disordered, the spirit cannot govern.

Thus a state with a worthy ruler repels enemy assaults from a thousand miles away. *Qú* are war chariots, used to breach enemy walls—this means that a worthy ruler’s virtue cannot be assailed, so he can shatter the enemy’s assault chariots far beyond his borders, preventing their approach. When Marquis Wen of Wei honored and humbled himself before Duan Ganmu, the armies of Qin dared not advance: this is what it means.

One marries through a matchmaker, yet the marriage is not made by the matchmaker—it is ritual that establishes the household. One befriends through an intermediary, yet closeness does not come through the intermediary—it is virtue that draws near.

Those whose paths align and steps converge will follow one another across a thousand miles, no matter the distance; those whose aims diverge and ways part will not speak even when facing each other across a doorstep. As the *Odes* says: though the chamber is near, the person is far—hence the saying, “facing the door yet no communication.”

Though the sea is vast, it does not accept rotting bones or mustard seeds. The sun and moon do not respond to what is not their *qi*; the yang-burning mirror draws fire, the square vessel gathers water—only when *qi* corresponds does it answer. Without this, nothing is obtained, so it is said they do not respond to what is not their *qi*.

The noble person does not tolerate what is not of his kind. People do not love Chui’s hands but love their own fingers—*Chui* is read as *zhuì* in the *Odes*, as in “trembling with fear.” Chui was Yao’s master craftsman; even the most skillful cannot love his hands for Chui’s sake. They say Chui’s hands bring no benefit to themselves, so they cherish their own fingers instead. They do not prize the pearls of the Yangtze and Han but treasure their own fishhook. Though the Yangtze and Han hold fine pearls, they are of no use to oneself, so they are not prized. A hook, however, can catch fish—hence they value it.

They mistake bundled firewood for a ghost, taking rising smoke for its *qi*. Seeing bundled firewood, they flee in terror, thinking it a ghost. Taking the smoke of a fire for an omen of fortune or misfortune, they slaughter pigs and boil dogs to avert it—such delusion! Those who act thus prematurely fare worse than those who proceed with caution.

The skillful excel at measurement; the wise excel at foresight. *Yu* means preparation. Yi died by the peach-wood club and could not draw his bow in time; Qing Ji died by the sword’s edge and could not grapple in time. *Taobu* is a place name. Yi was a lord of the Xia, ruler of Youqiong, slain by his disciple Pang Meng before he could ready his shot. *Bo* means swift action.

Cen Ji was the son of King Liao of Wu. When Yao Li of the Heng Gate assassinated him, he perished by the sword before he could deploy his swift and agile strength.

Those who seek to extinguish slander announce at their door, "I truly had no part in this flattery or chaos." Yet slander only arises all the more. Attempting to quell words with words or halt affairs with affairs is like scattering dust to suppress dust or carrying firewood to extinguish a fire. To silence words, one should remain silent; to halt affairs, one should divine. Now, to suppress words with words or stop affairs with affairs is like scattering dust to quell dust—only to stir it further—or carrying firewood to put out a fire—only to fan its flames.

Rumors stain like black dye on white silk. *Liu* means to spread; *xue* means to remove. *Nie* is black; *su* is white. An arrow may pierce armor at ten paces but fail to penetrate Lu gauze at three hundred; a fine steed may gallop a thousand *li* in a day, yet upon reaching its destination, it collapses from exhaustion. *Shi* means to unharness; *jiang* means to fall. Like an arrow at three hundred paces failing to pierce Lu gauze, this speaks of strength spent and momentum exhausted.

When a great family attacks a small one, it is called tyranny; when a great state annexes a small one, it is called virtue. The Xia dynasty, for ten generations, could not esteem virtue, resorting instead to toil and force, deeming those who seized borders and annexed states as worthy. A small horse is not of the same kind as a great horse; petty knowledge is not of the same kind as great knowledge. A small horse cannot advance the Way to reach a thousand *li*, thus it is not of the same kind as a great horse. Petty knowledge cannot govern the world or lead the people, thus it is not of the same kind as great knowledge.

Wearing a sheepskin to hire oneself out is fitting; wearing a sable robe while carrying a basket is truly strange. The basket is a basket for earth. To treat purity as defilement is like bathing and then scooping filth or perfuming oneself and then carrying a pig. *Xun sui* means burning incense; the people of Chu call it *xun sui*. To treat an abscess, one does not discriminate between good flesh, bad flesh, or ugly flesh—all are cut away. A farmer does not distinguish between seedlings and weeds—all are uprooted. Is this not futile?

Breaking a dike to catch a turtle, tearing down a house to seek a wildcat, digging up a chamber to find a rat, or cutting one’s lips to treat a cavity—such are the ways of Jie and Zhi, with whom the noble person does not associate. Those who conduct affairs in this manner are like Jie and Zhi; the noble person does not partake. To slaughter a warhorse in pursuit of a fox, to grasp two soft-shelled turtles and lose a sacred tortoise, to sever one’s right arm for a single hair, or to break a *Mo Xie* sword for a small knife—those who employ their wisdom thus, how can their posterity be esteemed? *Gao* means esteem.

Better a hundred pricks with a needle than one with a blade; better to pull a heavy load once than to carry a light one for long. Better to hunger for a month than to starve for ten days. *Ji* means insufficient food; *e* means exhaustion. The tracks of ten thousand people surpass the pitfall of one. The people of Chu call *ji* (tracks) *qi*. *Yu* means to surpass; *sui* means a pitfall.

One who praises another for their diligence and frugality may pound grain until dawn, yet if it does not meet the standard, they still rebuke them. Upon closer inspection, it was their mother. *Zhe* means to reproach. To praise someone for diligence and frugality, then rebuke them for failing to meet the standard—this is the way of it. When the noble person sees this, they realize the mother was laboring for her child. To praise someone thus—how is it better than slandering them? Hence the saying: "Ask who slandered them, and it was the petty person who praised them." This is what it means. Thus, the praise of a petty person becomes a detriment. *Sun* means to harm.

When the mother of the eastern household died, her son wept without sorrow. The son of the western household saw this and returned to tell his mother, "Why does She love to die so soon? I will surely weep bitterly for She." Along the Jiang and Huai, mother is called *she*. *She* is read as in "Ah She," where the people of Su and Jia call their father *gong*. One who wishes for their mother’s death, even if she dies, cannot weep in sorrow.

To say one has no time to study is like those who, though idle, cannot learn. To speak of being occupied with affairs and having no time to study—such people, even when at leisure, cannot learn.

Seeing hollow wood float, one knows to make a boat; seeing tumbleweed roll, one knows to make a cart; seeing bird tracks, one knows to create writing—all are taken by analogy. *Kuan* means hollow and is read as *ke*. To take what is not righteous as righteous, what is not ritual as ritual, is like running naked in pursuit of a madman, stealing wealth to give to a beggar, secretly copying laws, or squatting while reciting the *Odes* and *Documents*.

To cut and then abandon it, even a *Mo Xie* sword cannot sever flesh; to grasp and not release it, even a horse’s tail can cut jade. *Mao* is a horse’s tail. The sage does not stagnate; they do not compare past years to deem the present worthy, for each day surpasses the last. *Xian* and *yu* mean to surpass, as in *xuan wen*. It speaks of the present year surpassing the past and today surpassing yesterday, illustrating the sage’s self-cultivation and progress.

A horse resembling a deer is worth a thousand gold, yet there is no deer in the world worth a thousand gold. Jade becomes an implement only after being worked by *jian zhu*; *jian zhu* is the stone that polishes jade. It speaks of things that become valuable through what is base. *Jian* means sharp; some simply call it *lan*. A jade disc worth a thousand gold has no use for a *zi zhui* of *jian zhu*. Six *zhu* make a *zi*, eight *zhu* make a *zhui*—it speaks of its baseness.

Receiving light through a crack illuminates one corner; receiving light through a window illuminates the northern wall; receiving light through a door illuminates the entire room without leaving anything unseen—how much more so when receiving light from the cosmos? There is nothing in the world that does not borrow brightness from what precedes it. From this, we see: what one receives is small, so what one perceives is shallow; what one receives is great, so what one illuminates is vast. *Yu* refers to the four directions and above and below; *zhou* refers to past and present—it speaks of the space within the four limits and between heaven and earth. Thus, nothing in the world does not borrow brightness from the sun and moon.

The Yangzi flows from Mount Min, the Yellow River from Kunlun, the Ji from Wangwu, the Ying from Shaoshi, and the Han from Mount Bozhong—these have already been explained in the *Treatise on Terrain*.

The rivers diverge and race, two streams pouring into the Eastern Sea—though their courses differ, their destination is one. "One" means unity. For those who master the Dao, it is like the axle of a chariot: though the hub itself does not move, it carries the wheel a thousand *li*, ever turning, beginning anew without end, revolving from an inexhaustible source. Those who fail to master the Dao are like the lost: though told of east and west, south and north, they remain bewildered, their understanding dim—so deep is their confusion. Turning away, they grasp nothing, unaware of the essential. Turning away, they grow only more perplexed, thus knowing nothing of the fundamental.

Cold cannot generate cold; heat cannot generate heat. Only what is neither cold nor hot can generate both cold and heat. Thus, form emerges from formlessness. Before heaven and earth existed, nothing could have given birth to them—so profound, so subtle, so vast is this truth. In the beginning, before heaven and earth, that which generated heaven and earth arose, and thus the formless gave rise to form.

Rain falls, yet nothing is drenched until it ceases; only when it stops can it truly soak. The arrow flies, yet nothing is pierced until it comes to rest; only when it stops can it truly penetrate. Only stillness can halt all motion. Stillness is like the arrow that stops to pierce its target. Another interpretation: only by stilling one’s own passions and desires can one still the myriad things, preventing them from acting against their nature.

One builds a terrace by ascending high ground, a pond by descending low—each follows its natural advantage, daring not alter it. The sage employs things as one ties straw dogs with red silk or fashions earthen dragons to summon rain. Straw dogs are revered to invoke blessings—here, "invoke" means "attain." One relies on the straw dog’s power to secure good fortune. Earthen dragons bring rain, and rain yields grain, so one depends on the earthen dragon’s spirit to obtain food. Another interpretation: earthen dragons are used in rain prayers to secure offerings of wine and meat.

A man of Lu was skilled at making hats, his wife adept at weaving shoes. They moved to Yue but fell into dire poverty, for they carried their craft to a land where it was unneeded. It is like planting lotus on a mountaintop—lotus, an aquatic plant, also called *fuqu*. Its stem is the *jia*, its base the *mi*, its root the *ou*, its flower the *furong*, its bud the *hanjiu*, and its seedpod the *lian*. The finest lotus bears flowers, and at the heart of the flower lies the *yi*. In Youzhou, all these are collectively called *guang*. (The word *he* is pronounced as *hutong* in the dialect of Yan when referring to the Qin.) Yet they tried to raise it in a fiery well. To wield a fishing rod on a mountain or an axe in the depths of a lake—how could one obtain what one seeks? To ride a chariot in Yue or a raft into Hu—*fang* means "to depart," *zhi* means "to arrive," and *fu* is a raft, also called a gourd—is to use tools where they do not belong. To desire what is unattainable is futile, for one seeks where nothing can be found.

The King of Chu possessed a white ape. When the king himself shot at it, the ape caught the arrows and played with them. But when Yang You, a minister of the king, took aim, the moment he drew his bow and straightened his arrow, the ape clutched a pillar and howled. *You* was his name, a subject of the king. *Tiao* means to draw the bow, and *jiao* means to straighten the arrow.

"To *yong* means to embrace; *hao* means to cry out. The *You Tong Fu* states, 'Yang You cast his sidelong glance, and the ape howled'—this is the case. There are those who hit the mark first, and there are those whose subtle precision ensures a hit before the arrow is loosed, for their essence and appearance stir in unison.

The jade disc of the Guo clan, the jade pendant of the Xia sovereign—when offered with bows and deference, they bring harmony; when hurled at someone in the night, they breed resentment. It is a matter of timing or its absence. *Not timing* refers to night. *Guo* is an ancient form of *he* (harmony).

To paint the face of Xi Shi—though beautiful, it cannot delight; to sketch the eyes of Meng Ben—though large, they cannot inspire awe. For the *ruler of form* is absent. The *sheng qi* (vital qi) is the ruler of the human form. To depict a human form without *sheng qi* is to say the *ruler of form* is lost.

When brothers divide their inheritance, though the amounts may be immeasurable and countless, the multitude calls it *yi* (righteousness). Precisely because it is immeasurable, it cannot be measured.

Ascending heights makes one long to gaze afar; peering into depths makes one long to peer further—such is the nature of the place. Archers compel others to stand upright; anglers make others reverent—such is the nature of the task. Only after standing aright does one hit the mark; only after reverence does one obtain the catch. Thus it is said, 'such is the nature of the task.'

It is said that slaughtering a weary ox can redeem a fine horse from death, yet none do so. Slaughtering an ox is a fate of certain ruin. Oxen are what cultivate the grain, the lifeblood of the people. Thus the king’s law forbids killing oxen, and those who violate the prohibition are executed. Hence it is called a fate of certain ruin. To use what is doomed to redeem what is not necessarily doomed—none have yet been able to practice this.

The Ji Sun clan coerced the ducal house. Ji Huanzi Si (also called Kangzi Fei), a grandee of Lu, intimidated Duke Ding and monopolized his governance. The *Annals* state, 'The emoluments departed from the ducal house.' Confucius persuaded him, first acquiescing to his actions, then joining him in governance, saying, 'Whether crooked or straight, how could one not attain it?' Yet when straightening crookedness, do not follow it to its end. Acquiesce to his schemes and comply, but do not proceed to extremes—join in minor matters. This is what is meant by 'sharing filth yet treading different paths.'

The multitude’s crookedness cannot tolerate straightness; the multitude’s perversity cannot tolerate uprightness. Thus, when people are many, they devour the wolf; when wolves are many, they devour people. Those who wish to act perversely must first clarify uprightness; those who wish to act crookedly must first grasp straightness. That the public Way does not stand while private desires find acceptance—from ancient times to the present, this has never been heard of. This is using goodness to cloak its ugliness. *Tuo* means to entrust. Like Li Ji, who wished to kill Crown Prince Shenzhu, first praised him to Duke Xian, then carried out her harm—this is of the same kind.

When the clamor of many opinions forms a forest, it flies without wings. When all people discuss it, a forest grows on level ground, and wingless birds take flight. All believe it to be true. Three men make a market tiger: three men return from the market, all claiming there is a tiger there. Though the market is no place for tigers, people believe one exists. Thus it is said, 'Three men make a market tiger.' A single village bends the mighty. *Nao* means weak. When all in a village claim someone can bend the mighty, people believe it.

The swimmer does not seek to bathe—he is already content within. Thus, beasts that eat grass do not hastily leave the marsh; *ji* means to rest. Aquatic creatures do not hastily leave the water. They undergo minor changes without losing their constancy. *Minor changes* refer to leaving water or grass. They eat grass because they are grass-eaters; they dwell in water because they are aquatic. Thus it is said they do not hastily lose their constancy.

There is trust that violates ritual propriety and thus loses it. Weisheng died beneath the bridge pillar—this was misplaced trust. Weisheng, a man of Lu, had a secret tryst with a woman beneath a bridge. He honored his oath so deeply that when the waters rose, he did not leave and drowned. Thus it is said his trust was misplaced. The Kong clan did not mourn their divorced mother—this was a lapse in ritual. According to ritual, a concubine’s son mourns his divorced mother for a year. The Kong clan refers to Zishang, whose courtesy name was Baizhong, the great-grandson of Confucius and son of Kong Ji. Later, Zibai’s mother died abroad. The *Records* state, 'When Zishang’s mother died, he did not mourn.' A disciple asked Zisi, 'Did your late lord mourn his divorced mother?' He replied, 'Yes.' 'Then why did he not make Baizhong do so?'"

He replied, "In former times, our late lord never strayed from the Dao. When the Dao flourished, he flourished with it; when the Dao was defiled, he was defiled with it. How could Ji act contrary to this? It was not that Ji refused to treat her as a wife, but that he refused to treat her as Bai’s mother. The Kong clan’s failure to mourn a divorced mother began with Zisi. Thus it is said this was the Kong clan’s lapse.

Zengzi established filial piety, yet would not pass through the lane named ‘Victorious Mother.’ Mozi rejected music, yet would not enter the city of Chaoge. Zengzi upheld integrity, yet would not drink from the Robber’s Spring. These are what is meant by ‘nurturing the will.’

When Zhou made ivory chopsticks, Jizi sighed in lament. Seeing the ivory chopsticks, he knew that jade cups would follow, and with jade cups, there would surely be bear paws and leopard fetuses to indulge every extravagance. Thus Jizi cried out in alarm.

When Lu buried the dead with wooden figurines, Confucius sighed, detesting their resemblance to humans and their use. He knew that later generations would surely use living persons as sacrifices, and so he sighed deeply.

Thus the sage sees frost and knows ice is coming. When a light frost descends, the great cold will follow, and solid ice will form.

If a bird is about to come, one sets a net to await it. The one who catches the bird is but a single mesh of the net. If one were to set a net of only one mesh, there would be no time one could catch a bird.

Now, those who don armor do so to prepare for unforeseen calamities. If one could always know where danger would strike, a single wooden plaque would suffice.

Some matters cannot be foreseen, and some things cannot be anticipated. Sudden and unforeseen events arise, so the sage accumulates the Dao to await the moment. The Dao can equalize transformations, and there is nothing it does not bestow. Thus the sage nurtures it to await the time, and when the time comes, responds—like King Wu’s campaign against Zhou.

Kuntun was a homely ox, already lacking horns and tail, its nose pierced and bridled. Kuntun describes its ugly appearance. A plow ox is not of pure color. *Ke* means hornless. The missing character refers to tailless. Its nose was pierced and a bridle placed to lead it.

When a calf was born, it was offered as a sacrificial victim. The spirit medium fasted and performed rites to sink it into the river. A *xi* is a sacrificial animal. The *shi* is the one who presides over the sacrifice to the spirits. The *zhu* offers prayers for blessings. To sacrifice to the River Lord is called *chen*. Would the River Lord be ashamed of its origins and refuse to accept the offering?

The *Book of Songs* says, ‘Gather the turnips, gather the radishes, yet do not discard their roots.’ The *Analects* says, ‘The calf of a plow ox is ruddy and well-horned. Though one might wish not to use it, would the mountains and rivers cast it aside?’

To command an army of ten thousand men is not as good as hearing a single apt word. *Apt* means understanding the seasons and terrain, knowing men—this is how one can subdue an enemy’s forces without battle.

To obtain the Marquis of Sui’s pearl is not as good as obtaining the means to accomplish a task. To obtain the He’s jade disc is not as good as obtaining the proper course for a matter. *Means* refers to use. *Proper course* refers to what is fitting.

One selects a fine horse not to chase foxes and raccoon dogs, but to shoot elk and deer. One sharpens a keen sword not to cut silk garments, but to sever rhinoceros and buffalo.

Thus, ‘The lofty mountain—one looks up to it; the great path—one follows it.’ Long ago, there were those who said: ‘Before a high mountain, I look up and halt; before a great man, I emulate and follow him.’ Thus it is said, ‘Long ago, such a man.’

Seeing a slingshot, one seeks roasted owl. A slingshot can be used to shoot an owl, yet one seeks roasted meat because of it. Seeing an egg, one seeks the crowing of dawn and night. The rooster knows the approach of dawn, the crane knows midnight. Seeing its egg, one thus anticipates its nighttime call, hence ‘seeks the crowing of dawn and night.’

Seeing hemp seeds, one seeks finished cloth. Though this is reasonable, it is not too late. *Fen* refers to hemp with seeds. It can be made into cloth, so one seeks its completion. Thus it is said, ‘Though this is reasonable, it is not too late’—meaning one acts early. *Fen* is read in the *Commentary* as ‘having seeds does not bring disaster.’

The elephant sheds its tusks, not resenting others for taking them. *Taking* means to seize. The dead discard their funeral biers, not begrudging others for taking them. *Zhaozhe* refers to the washing board on the deceased’s bed. *Resent* is the same as *detest*, differing only in literary style. *Ze* is read like the *ji* in *gongji* (merit).

If one can use what is not advantageous to oneself to benefit others, then it is acceptable. *What is not advantageous* refers to how Zihan did not profit from another’s treasure. *Benefit* is like how the jade merchant obtained the jade and made it his treasure. Thus it is said to be acceptable.

A madman runs east, and his pursuer also runs east. Running east, they are the same, yet the reason for running east differs. A drowning man enters the water, and his rescuer also enters the water. Entering the water, they are the same, yet the reason for entering the water differs. The difference lies in not drowning.

Thus the sage treats life and death as one, and the fool also treats life and death as one. The sage’s unity of life and death is grounded in understanding principle and fate; the fool’s unity of life and death arises from ignorance of where benefit and harm lie.

King Yan of Xu lost his state through benevolence and righteousness, yet those who lose their states are not necessarily benevolent and righteous. Xu is today’s Xiapi, Xu, and Tong. *Yan* is his posthumous name. Living in an age of chaos and disorder, he cultivated benevolence and righteousness and was destroyed by King Wen of Chu. Most who are destroyed do so through unrighteousness, thus it is said that losing a state is not necessarily due to benevolence and righteousness.

Bi Gan was dismembered for his loyalty, yet those who are executed are not necessarily loyal. Bi Gan was executed for remonstrating with Zhou. The world sees that many who remonstrate do so without loyalty, thus it is said that those who are executed are not necessarily loyal.

Thus, one shivers from cold, and the fearful also shiver—this is sameness in name but difference in reality. They share the name *shivering*, yet differ in that one shivers from cold, the other from fear. *Shiver* is read like the *zhan* in ‘shivering from the cold,’ and is written the same.

The luminous moon pearl comes from the conch; the Zhou’s plain jade tablet is born from rough stone. The pearl called ‘luminous moon’ is born within the conch. The *jian gui*, a large jade tablet, is fine jade born from stone, thus it is said to be ‘born from rough stone.’

The great Cai divine tortoise comes from the ditches. *Great Cai* is the name of the place where the primordial tortoise emerged, and thus the tortoise is named *Great Cai*. This refers to the tortoise kept by Zang Wenzhong.

A ruler of ten thousand chariots wears a crown of mere ounces and rides in a carriage worth a hundred gold."

Six *zhu* make a *zi*, eight *liang* make a *zhui*—this speaks of their meager worth.

Some things are base yet placed above, others noble yet placed below. *Carriage* may also be written as *to tread*. Oxhide is deemed lowly, yet it orders the ranks of the three armies. The drum’s sound stirs the *qi*, and thus can align the multitudes of the three armies.

One who wishes to learn singing must first master the *zheng* and *yu* modes of the *feng* music. *Zheng* is the fire of the south; *yu* is the water of the north. When the five notes are correct, the music is correct. Nothing moves heaven and earth, stirs ghosts and spirits, more closely than poetry and music. *Feng* is how the above transforms the below, and the below admonishes the above—hence it is called *feng*.

One who desires harmonious beauty must first begin with *Yang’e* and *Cai Ling*. *Yang’e* and *Cai Ling* are harmonious melodies. *Yang’e* is an ancient name for a non-*fei* melody, renowned for its harmony.

All these seek to learn what they have not learned in order to reach what they desire. The cicada-illuminator focuses on brightening his flame; the angler focuses on scenting his bait. Brightening the flame is how one lures the cicada; scenting the bait is how one entices the fish. *Yao* means bright; *fang* means fragrant. When the flame is bright and the bait fragrant, cicadas and fish will come. In governing a state, if one brightens virtue and beautifies governance, the people of the world will gather like cicadas and fish to a bright flame and fragrant bait.

One who wishes to attract fish must first channel the waters; one who wishes to attract birds must first plant trees. Where waters gather, fish congregate; where trees flourish, birds alight.

The skilled fowler first prepares his *jiao* and *zeng*. *Jiao* is a large fishing line; *zeng* is a short arrow. The *jiao* is for striking—it shoots flying birds. As the *Odes* say, “Shooting the swan and the wild goose.”

The skilled angler first prepares his *gu* and *fu*. *Fu* is a fine net. The *Traditions* say, “Dense nets do not enter the turbid pond.” *Fu* is a large net. As the *Odes* say, “Setting the net with a splash, the perch and sturgeon leap.” Never has one gained advantage without the proper tools. This means one has never seen a lord without the Way who could win the people’s hearts.

To give a man a horse yet untie its bridle, to give a man a carriage yet remove its *yi*—the *yi* being what secures the crossbar—is to love little yet lose much. Thus the village saying goes: “To boil an ox without washing is to ruin the endeavor.” Without salt, the broth is not broth—hence it is called ruining the endeavor. The *Records of Ritual* say, “The guest stirs the broth; the host declines, saying he cannot cook.” This shows he knows how to make broth.

Jie had an accomplishment: he knew to make tiles to roof houses, leaving a legacy for later generations. Yao had a failing: *yi* means loss. This refers to his inability to banish the Four Fiends and employ the Sixteen Ministers. Another explanation: not passing the throne to Dan Zhu but abdicating to Shun, earning the reputation of lacking filial piety—hence it is said he had a failing.

Momu had her beauty. Momu was an ugly woman of old, yet her conduct was upright—hence it is said she had her beauty. *Mo* is read like the *mo* in “model.”

Xishi had her ugliness. Xishi was a beautiful woman of old. Though her appearance was radiant, her character was not necessarily upright—hence it is said she had her ugliness.

Thus, the laws of a ruined state may have aspects worth following, and the customs of a well-governed state may have aspects worth criticizing. *Worth following* is like Momu having her beauty; *worth criticizing* is like Xishi having her ugliness.

The *wan* and *yan* jades lie in filthy mud, yet even the incorruptible do not cast them aside. *Wan* and *yan* are fine jades; *shi* means to abandon. A cracked steamer or a chipped pot sits atop a fine mat, yet even the greedy do not seize them. *Qiong* is the band of the steamer; *bo* means to take. *Qiong* is read like the *meng* in *qing meng*.

Where beauty resides, though it be in filth and disgrace, the world cannot deem it lowly. Where ugliness resides, though it be in lofty heights, the world cannot deem it noble. *The world cannot deem it lowly* alludes to the worthy in humble, base positions; *the world cannot deem it noble* alludes to the unworthy in high, exalted positions.

Spring loans and autumn levies gladden the people—hungry in spring, they are given; abundant in autumn, they repay. Spring levies and autumn loans enrage the masses. Gain and loss are the same; joy and anger differ because the timing is not.

The virtue of fish is not to be carried into the depths; the gift to apes is not to be borne up trees—let them go where they belong. This is like governance: when offices are properly ordered, the literary take literary posts, the martial take martial posts—hence it is said, “Let them go where they belong.”

A marten-fur robe with mixed pelts is not as fine as a fox-fur robe of pure hue. *Mixed* means variegated; *pure* means unadulterated. Thus, nothing is worse than lacking constancy in conduct. *Lacking constancy* is like the *Analects* saying, “A man without steadfastness cannot be a shaman or a physician”—hence it is said to be detestable.

One may appraise horses yet fail to recognize a horse—*fail* means not to know. Yet the fine horse remains within the appraisal. A fine horse may live long or die young; its bone structure cannot be appraised. Not knowing, it is said to remain within the appraisal.

When people set fires, some carry flames to feed the blaze, others fetch water to quench it—both achieve nothing, yet the resentment and virtue between them are far apart.

A man of Ying sought a roof beam, desiring timber three spans in girth. Ying was the capital of Chu, located north of present-day Jiangling. *Beam* refers to the ridgepole. Yet he was offered a chariot hub; kneeling, he measured it. Though its girth sufficed, its length was inadequate. *Girth* means size; *length inadequate* means it was too short.

Qubo Yu transformed through virtue. Qubo Yu was Qu Ao, a grandee of Wei. When Viscount Jian of Zhao was about to attack Wei, he sent Shi Mo to observe it. Shi Mo said, “Qubo Yu governs—you cannot send troops against them.” Hence it is said he transformed through virtue.

Gongsun Yang ruled through punishment and guilt—their ends were the same. Gongsun Yang was the son of Lord Shuzuo of Wei. Fleeing from Wei to Qin, he served Duke Xiao as minister, establishing laws of mutual responsibility—hence it is said he ruled through punishment and guilt.

The state of Qin enfeoffed him as Lord of Shang, hence he was called Shang Yang. Shang lies southeast of Jingzhao. Yu transformed through virtue, while Yang ruled through punishment—yet their ends were the same.

The ailing lie upon bedding. *Lie* means to recline; *bedding* refers to the mat. The physician employs needles and stone probes, while the shaman uses sacrificial grains and reeds—both seek to save in equal measure. *Physician* denotes the master healer. Male shamans are called *xi*; female shamans, *wu*. Stone needles are whetted to lance abscesses, draining foul blood. *Sacrificial grains* are polished rice offered to spirits; *reeds* are rushes. All serve to cure illness and seek blessings—hence it is said they save in equal measure.

The head of a leopard-cat cures rat bites; the seed of the foxnut heals scrofula. When rats gnaw a person’s wound, the leopard-cat remedies it. *Scrofula* is a swelling of the neck. *Foxnut* is the aquatic *qian*, called *yantou* in Youzhou—it too effects a cure. Horseflies disperse congealed blood; hewing wood relieves tooth decay—these are instances of extending the principle. *Extending* means applying.

Grease kills turtles; magpie droppings strike hedgehogs—*strike* also means to kill. Rotten ash breeds maggots; lacquer fails to dry when exposed to crab—these are instances where the principle does not extend. *Rotten* means decayed; *dry* means to harden.

Whether extending or not extending, there are cases of seeming falsehood that are true, and seeming truth that is false—who can fathom their subtleties? The world holds no pure-white fox, yet there are pure-white fox-fur robes, woven from many white pelts.

The adept learner is like the King of Qi eating chicken: he must consume the feet, dozens of them, before he is sated. *Feet* refers to the chicken’s talons. This illustrates that in seeking the Dao, one gathers from many sources before attaining sufficiency.

A knife may shave hair, but to fell a great tree, only an axe will suffice. *Suffice* means to sever. Thus, things inherently possess means by which the lesser may succeed where the greater falls short.

Gazing at a square inch of an ox, one does not perceive its size compared to a sheep; only by surveying the whole body does one grasp the vastness of the difference. *Vast* here implies multiplicity.

A pregnant woman who sees a hare may bear a child with a cleft chest; one who sees a elk may give birth to a child with four eyes. A small horse with large eyes cannot be called a large horse; a large horse with small eyes is termed a "small-eyed horse." Things inherently possess semblances that are yet not so.

Thus, severing a finger may lead to death, while severing an arm may preserve life—*sever* means to wound. The outcome cannot be invariably deduced. One tempers a sharp sword with a soft whetstone—*soft* means moist. One strikes bells and chimes with a dampened mallet; a sturdy hub requires supple spokes. Two rigid things cannot harmonize; two strong things cannot submit to one another.

Therefore, the catalpa splits the horn, and the *mali* cuts jade—this speaks of the soft overcoming the hard. A deceiver does not study deceit but succeeds through it and thus breeds distrust—*deceiver* means one who feigns. A brawler does not study contention but stands firm in it and thus fosters no yielding.

Thus, the noble person does not enter prison, for it wounds benevolence, nor the marketplace, for it shames integrity—*shames* means to disgrace. Accumulation cannot be treated without caution.

One does not run with bound hands, for bound hands cannot run swiftly; one does not fly with a bent tail, for a bent tail cannot fly far. That which is used must rely on that which is not used.

Thus, that which enables sight is itself unseen; that which makes the drum sound is itself silent—*silent* means without sound. Tasting a single morsel of meat reveals the flavor of the entire cauldron—*cauldron* refers to a vessel with feet, while *pot* has none. Hanging a feather and charcoal together reveals the qi of dryness and dampness—dryness makes the charcoal light, dampness makes it heavy.

By a small sign, one sees a single leaf fall and knows the year is drawing to a close; one glimpses ice in a jar and knows the world’s cold. From the near, one infers the far—*infers* means to know.

Three men walking abreast cannot pass through a single door—for the door cannot accommodate them. One man following another may traverse the entire world. This speaks of non-concurrency.

Feet press the earth to leave tracks; swift movement in sunlight casts shadows—this is easy yet difficult. *Press* means to tread. Treading the earth, tracks form of themselves; walking at midday, shadows arise of themselves—this is the easy part. To make the tracks straight and the shadows upright—this is the difficult part.

King Zhuang executed Li Shi, while Sunshu Ao prepared his cap and washed his robes. *Li Shi* was a sycophantic minister. Hating the wicked man’s death, Sunshu Ao knew he would soon be employed, so he prepared his cap and washed his robes.

Duke Wen discarded his wormwood mat, which had grown moldy and black. Jiu Fan resigned and left, saying: "I have followed you through your wanderings, and my faults are many. If even I am aware of them, how much more must you be? I beg to take my leave now." Thus, he *resigned and left*.

Thus, when mulberry leaves fall, the aged grow sorrowful. As the mulberry leaves wither and scatter, the elderly fear their lives are nearing their end, and so they are moved to sorrow.

A small tripod is used daily yet not esteemed, for though it is seen every day, it cannot harmonize the five flavors. A Zhou tripod is never heated yet cannot be disdained, for though the great Zhou tripod is not used daily for cooking, it can harmonize flavors. Thus, some things are valuable precisely because they are not used. *Not used* refers to the tripod not being heated; *valuable* refers to its role in harmonizing the five flavors.

When the ground is level, water does not flow; when weights are balanced, the scale does not tilt. *Flow* means to move; *tilt* means to incline. That which is extreme must have something to which it responds. *Extreme* means excess. Light and heavy strike and counterbalance each other, so it is said that there must be something to which it responds. *Responds* means to move. Thus, some things have their greatest use precisely in not being used. The scale weighs things, yet it is not the things themselves that are used—only by using the scale does one know their weight. Thus, it is said that not being used is its great use.

Bathing before undressing is acceptable; undressing before bathing is not. Offering sacrifices before the feast is proper—ritual dictates that one must first offer food in sacrifice to show precedence. *Feast* means to eat. Feasting before offering sacrifices is improper, for it is disrespectful. Thus, it is said to be unacceptable. The sequence of things has its proper order.

On the day of sacrifice, to speak of dogs giving birth; on the evening of taking a wife, to speak of mourning garments; on the day of setting out wine, to speak of visiting graves—all are improper.

To invoke the past when crossing the Yangtze or Yellow River—*the waves of Yang Hou*. The Marquis of Yangling drowned, and his spirit could raise great waves to harm people, hence the name *the waves of Yang Hou*. Boatmen do not wish to speak of it.

Some say: knowing a pardon is imminent and killing many is unbenevolent. Others say: knowing a pardon is imminent and sparing many makes one a benevolent person. Their hope for pardon is the same, but the harm or benefit differs. Thus, some blow on fire to kindle it, while others blow on fire to extinguish it—the difference lies in how they blow.

To feast one’s village by slaughtering an ox, yet curse the mother of one’s eastern neighbor—failing to repay virtue while bringing peril upon oneself. *Peril* means harm.

King Wen’s sunken chest and Bao Shen’s hunched back contributed to the governance of the state of Chu. *King Wen* was the son of King Wu of Chu. *Xiong Ci* had a sunken chest. *Bao Shen* was a minister of Chu. *Hunched back* means bent. *Contributed to governance* means they were worthy.

Bi Chen left the city and gained insight, thereby aiding Zichan’s affairs. *Bi Chen* was a grandee of Zheng. Planning in the wilds succeeded; planning within the state failed. When Zheng faced difficulties, Zichan took him into the countryside to discuss matters with the four neighboring states. Thus, it is said he aided Zichan’s affairs. The *Analects* states: "Bi Chen drafted the plans, Shishu deliberated on them, and Dongli Zichan refined them."

A dwarf’s doorway is higher than a tall man’s gate. The tall man said, "I do not know." The dwarf replied, "Though you do not know, you are still closer to it than I am." Thus, in all inquiries, one must ask those who are near.

When bandits approached, the lame man warned the blind man, and the blind man carried him to flee—both survived, each employing their abilities. Had the blind man been made to speak and the lame man to run, they would have lost their proper roles.

A man of Ying sought to sell his mother. He pleaded with the buyer, saying: "This mother is old. I beg you to feed her well and not make her suffer." *Ying* was the capital of Chu. *Sell* means to offer for sale. *Feed* means to care for.

This is an act of great unrighteousness, yet one seeks to perform minor righteousness.

The movements of armored creatures are for defense—such as turtles and crabs. *Movement* means action. The movements of chaste insects are for stinging—such as wasps and mud-daubers. *Chaste* means lacking male-female union. Having venom, they can sting. *[螫] is read as the "release" in "explanation."*

The movements of bears are for seizing and grappling. *Seizing* means to snatch. Bears are strong, so they can snatch and grapple. The movements of rhinoceroses and oxen are for butting. *Rhinoceros* is a horned beast. *Ox* refers to the plow-ox. No creature employs its strengths while using its weaknesses. *Employs* means to apply.

Governing a state is like weeding a field—one removes only what harms the seedlings. Now, one who washes their hair loses strands yet continues without cease, for what is removed is little, and what benefits is much.

A whetstone may be dull yet can sharpen metal—*metal* refers to blades and swords. A bow-rest may be crooked yet can straighten a bow—*rest* is the frame that holds a bow. Read as *qíng*.

Indeed, some things are crooked yet can straighten, dull yet can sharpen. The crooked is the rest, the straight is the bow; the dull is the whetstone, the sharp is the metal.

Strength values evenness, wisdom values swiftness. When attainment is equal, speed is superior. *Evenness* is read as *jī* (as in "minced"). Both *evenness* and *swiftness* imply quickness. When victory is equal, slowness is inferior.

The value of the *Mo Ye* sword lies in its responsiveness to things and its cutting edge. *Cut* means to sever. If the door-bar is not released, the ox-cart’s axle will snap. *Bar* means to latch. The people of Chu call the latch that breaks the axle when a cart passes over it.

Mencius said, "The ruts at the city gate are not made by the strength of two horses." *Axle* is read near *lán*. It must be pronounced with a quick tongue to be correct.

To abandon the Six Arts because Confucius was stranded in Chen and Cai would be delusion—*Six Arts* are ritual, music, archery, charioteering, calligraphy, and mathematics. For a physician to be unable to treat their own illness, to be sick yet refuse medicine, would be recklessness. *Recklessness* means acting without discernment.

*Huainanzi Honglie Jie*, Scroll Twenty-Three concludes.
*Huainanzi Honglie Jie*, Scroll Twenty-Four.

The Grand Commandant and Libationer, your servant Xu Shen, respectfully records:

*Shuolin Xun* – Trees growing in clusters are called a *forest*. It explains how the myriad things rely on abundance, gathering like a forest, hence the title *Shuolin*, which is used to name this chapter.

Governing the world by the measures of a single age is like a traveler on a boat who drops his sword in midstream and hastily carves a mark on the mast—*carve* means to notch. *Mast* refers to the side planks of the ship. The sword fell into the current, and he carved the side of the boat, saying that the sword was lost beneath this mark. *Mast* is pronounced like *Fan* in the *Zuozhuan*, where King Xiang of Zhou resided in Fan of Zheng. Seeking it at dusk when the boat nears the shore, he looks only where he carved the mark—his ignorance of the nature of things is extreme. Following the traces of a single corner without knowing how to roam through heaven and earth, no delusion is greater. Though there may be occasional coincidences, they are not to be valued. It is like the clay dragons of drought years or the straw effigies of pestilence—these are what rulers rely on. Clay dragons are used to pray for rain, and straw dogs to seek blessings; they are valued at times. The Cao clan’s torn cloth is prized by those with boils, yet it is not the jade *huang* of the Xia dynasty. The people of Chu call cloth *Cao*; today, common folk tie the first woven cloth to its side, calling it *Cao cloth*. Burning it to treat boils brings healing, so those with boils value it. A half-wall is called a *huang*; the *huang* summons the masses and is a treasure of the state, hence it is said it is not the *huang* of the Xia dynasty.

Without past or present, without beginning or end, it gave birth to heaven and earth before heaven and earth existed—profound, subtle, vast, and great. To say it is profound, subtle, vast, and great is to say it can give birth to heaven and earth. That which relies on [stepping] is shallow; yet it awaits what it does not tread to proceed—*stepping* means to tread. What relies on treading to proceed cannot proceed, hence it is said to await what it does not tread before proceeding. What wisdom knows is narrow; yet it awaits what it does not know to become enlightened. *Narrow* means limited. Knowing what is known and what is not known completes enlightenment.

Swimmers stumble with their feet and flail with their hands, failing to grasp the method, stumbling and failing all the more—*failing* means sinking. Only when one can truly swim does it no longer depend on hands and feet. Birds fly back to their homeland, rabbits run to their burrows, foxes die with their heads toward the hills, and cold birds soar over water—each mourns its origin. *Cold birds* are waterfowl. *Mourn* means to grieve.

Do not give a mirror to the blind, nor shoes to the lame, nor bestow *zhangfu* caps upon the Yue people—these are not for their use. *Bestow* means to give. *Zhangfu* is a cap. The Yue people cut their hair and have no use for caps. A hammer with a hundred handles cannot drive itself; eyes that see a hundred paces away cannot see their own eyelashes. This illustrates that people can do things for others but not for themselves. Dogs and pigs do not choose their bowls and jars when eating, fattening their bodies while nearing death—*fatten* means to take. *Nearing* means drawing close. Once fattened, they are cooked, hence they near death. The phoenix soars high above a thousand *ren*, so none can reach it. A *ren* is seven feet; without a sage ruler of virtue, it cannot be summoned, hence it is said none can reach it.

The moon illuminates the world yet is eclipsed by the *zhan zhu*; the flying serpent glides through mist yet is endangered by the *ji qu*. *Zhan zhu* is the toad in the moon that eats the moon, hence it is said to be eclipsed by the *zhan zhu*. *Endangered* means to fear. *Ji qu* is the cricket; the *Erya* calls it the *qinglie* with a large belly. When the upper serpent sees it, the serpent does not dare move, hence it is said to be endangered by the *ji qu*. The crow’s strength surpasses the sun, yet it submits to the *zhui li*—this shows the limits of its power. Crows appear in daylight, hence it is said they surpass the sun. *Submits* means to fear. *Zhui li*, according to the *Erya*, is the *bili*; the people of Qin call it *sishi*. When a bird crows at dawn during the silkworm season, the great birds all fear it—hence it is said to show the limits of its power.

Nothing lives longer than a child who dies young, yet Peng Zu is considered short-lived. Life is a sojourn; death is a return. The child who dies young departs from its sojourn and returns to its destined place, hence is considered long-lived. Peng Zu was an ancestor of Chu, living four hundred years; not returning early, he is considered short-lived. The *Analects* says, "I privately compare myself to Old Peng." This likely refers to him. Another account says Peng Zu was a student of immortality in the time of the Yellow Emperor, implying he did not return to the spirit early enough.

A short rope cannot draw from deep waters; a small vessel cannot hold great things—these are not their proper tasks. *Task* is read like the *ren* in *burden*. Anger arises from non-anger; action arises from non-action. Non-anger is true anger; non-action is true action. Seeing the formless, one attains what is seen; hearing the soundless, one attains what is heard—this means all things are easily cared for when soundless, hence one attains what is heard. The highest flavor is not satisfying; the highest words are not ornate; the highest joy does not laugh; the highest sound does not clamor; the great craftsman does not carve; the great vessel is not adorned; the great warrior does not fight—*satisfying* means gratifying. *Clamor* means shouting. *Not carve* means not carving itself. *Vessel* refers to the implements of *fu*, *fu*, *bian*, and *dou*. The great warrior is feared upon hearing of him, so he no longer fights.

Attaining the Dao, virtue follows. It is like the yellow bell harmonizing with the *gong* note or the great *cu* harmonizing with the *shang*—no further tuning is needed.

"More" means change. One who tempers with clay remains whole; one who tempers with metal stumbles; one who tempers with jade shatters. *Temper* (鉒) is read like the *zhu* in "bronze pillar" (金之铜柱余之鉒). *Zhu* means to lift a horse—Lu household calls it *tou pian*. *Metal* refers to the golden step-guard. *Stumbles* means to trip and flee. *Shatters* means swift and sudden, read like the *fa* in "shooting a hundred arrows" (射百发之发). Thus, what is valued externally hollows what lies within. *Valued* refers to gold and jade. *Hollows* means qi becomes unsettled and inauspicious.

The hunter pursuing game does not see Mount Tai—he sees only the beast. When desires lie without, clarity is obscured. *Obscured* means seeing only the benefit of things, not their harm.

He who listens to sounds with sound is deaf; he who listens to soundless sound is keen. Neither deaf nor keen, he communes with spirit-light.

The diviner grasps the tortoise; the augur aligns the stalks, consulting the numbers—yet where lies the true question? *Stalks* are the forty-nine stalks. They may divine fortune or misfortune, may consult the numbers. *Numbers* refer to those who seek divination.

Dancers raise their joints; sitters, without prior agreement, all clap as one—what they reach is the same.

The sun rises from Tang Valley and sets in Yu Abyss. None perceive its motion, yet in an instant it bows to the nape of man. *Bows* means to bend.

No one wishes to learn dragon-riding, yet all wish to learn horse-riding; no one wishes to learn ghost-governance, yet all wish to learn human governance—what is urgently needed is pursued. Dragon-riding and ghost-governance bring no benefit to worldly use, thus horse-riding and human governance become urgent tasks.

Dismantling a gate to use as firewood, blocking a well to make a mortar—human endeavors sometimes resemble one another. *Sometimes* means there are instances. *Resemble* means resembling folly.

Water and fire hate each other, yet the *wei* sits between them, harmonizing the five flavors. *Wei* is a small cauldron. Another saying: a cauldron without ears is called *wei*. *Wei* is read like *hui* in "brightness" (日慧). The *wei* holds water while fire cooks it—thus it is said to sit between them.

Bone and flesh love each other, yet slander and treachery divide them, endangering father and son. Such were King Ping of Chu and Duke Xian of Jin.

That which nourishes yet harms what it nourishes is like cutting the foot to fit the shoe or severing the head to suit the hat. *Nourishes* alludes to slander and treachery. *Harms what it nourishes* alludes to bone and flesh. *Severing* also refers to the shoe. The head is large, the hat small—they do not suit. To cut or pare the head to fit the hat is folly. *Severing the head* may also be written as *ze*.

The *chang* plant drives away lice yet invites *qin qiong*—*chang* is sweet flag. *Qin qiong* is the earwig, an ear-infesting insect. Removing a small harm invites a greater calamity—thus small gratification harms great benefit.

A crumbling wall is worse than none, for it may collapse onto the roof. *Worse than none* means it would be better without the wall. *Collapse onto the roof* means the ruined house; the wall’s decay returns it to earth, its origin—thus it is said to collapse onto the roof.

The jade bi and ai become vessels through the work of *jian zhu*—*jian zhu* is the stone that polishes jade. The *Book of Songs* says, "Stones from other mountains may serve as whetstones." *Jian* is read like *lian* in the surname Lian. The *Mo Ye* sword cuts through all, honed by grinding and sharpening. *Honed* also means effort—*interwoven* patterns.

When the cunning hare is caught, the hunting hound is boiled; when the high bird is slain, the strong crossbow is stored away. *Boiled* means killed; *stored* means discarded—implying they are no longer used.

The *tuo* and the steed travel a thousand li without flying, hunger without provisions of grain. A fire breaks out and rain falls—fire is misfortune, rain is fortune. Thus, within calamity lies blessing.

The coffin-seller desires the people’s illness; the grain-hoarder desires years of famine. *Famine* means great hunger, when grain does not ripen.

Still water is level; level, it becomes clear; clear, it reveals the forms of things, leaving nothing hidden—thus it may serve as a standard. *Hidden* means to escape.

When the river runs dry, the valley empties—*empties* means without water. When the hill is leveled, the abyss fills—*leveled* means flattened; *fills* means full. When the lips are gone, the teeth grow cold.

The depth of the Yellow River lies in its banks, which stand in the mountains—this is no matter of a single morning or evening.

A bolt of fine white silk: one end makes a cap, the other a shoe. The cap is worn upon the head, the shoe □ upon the foot.

Those who know themselves cannot be lured by things—things cannot move them. Those who understand life and death cannot be deterred by peril—peril cannot frighten them. Thus, the skilled swimmer cannot be daunted by fording. Fording, he cannot drown.

No bond is closer than that of flesh and blood, for the limbs and kin are linked as one. *Flesh and blood* refers to the body itself; hence it is said the limbs and kin are connected. When the heart loses its restraint, it turns to self-harm—this means that when the heart loses its discipline, it harms the body. How much more so for those distant and estranged? *Distant and estranged* refers to others.

The sage’s relation to the Dao is like the sunflower’s to the sun: though it cannot remain with it from beginning to end, its turning toward it is sincere. *Turning* means facing; *sincere* means true.

When palace pools overflow with rain, they flood; in drought, they dry. *Overflow* means heavy rain. The source of the Yangtze’s waters cannot be exhausted by deep springs. *Exhausted* means depleted.

Surely not the rafters alone can block the sun, nor the wheel’s spokes alone pursue speed—yet rafters and spokes are not to be relied upon. Metal overcomes wood not by a single blade felling a forest; earth overcomes water not by a single clod damming a river.

The lame man sees a tiger and does not flee—not from courage, but because his position is unfavorable. What is tilted is easily overturned; what leans is easily toppled. *Tilted* means near to falling; *toppled* is read as *fǔ* in *fǔjì* (toppling aid). *Near* means close. Dampness invites rain.

The mousetrap snaps when triggered; the fisherman’s float bobs when the line is cast. *Triggered* means sprung, and the mouse is caught. *Bobbing* means the float moves. *Moves* means the fish is hooked. *Task* refers to the carrying-pole, as in the *Book of Songs*: “We bear our burdens.”

The straw dog can stand but cannot walk; snake-bed resembles *ligusticum* but cannot be fragrant. *Snake-bed* is foul; *ligusticum* is sweet.

It is said that Xu You had no virtue, nor Wu Huo strength—yet both showed displeasure in their countenance. *Displeasure* means anger; another says shame. People are never stirred except by what they lack. *Stirred* means roused.

If a hare’s speed were as great as a horse’s, it would outrun the wind. *Outrun the wind* speaks of its swiftness. Yet if it were a horse, it could not run at all.

Winter may bring thunder and lightning, summer frost and snow—yet the power of cold and heat remains unchanged; small changes do not alter the great order.

The Yellow Emperor gave birth to yin and yang. The Yellow Emperor is the ancient celestial spirit who, at the dawn of human creation, brought forth yin and yang. Shang Pian gave rise to ears and eyes; Sang Lin gave rise to arms and hands. *Shang Pian* and *Sang Lin* are names of spirits. This is how Nü Wa achieved her seventy transformations. Nü Wa was a ruler of the world who, through seventy changes, shaped creation—just as Yu’s governance of the world was not the work of one man alone.

One may speak all day of sagely deeds, and among a hundred shots, some will surely display the skill of Yi or Peng Meng. Yet the world does not acknowledge them, for their adherence to discipline is not genuine. *Not genuine* means not truly so.

The bones of an ox’s hoof or a pig’s skull are still bones, yet the world does not divine with them. It must inquire of the tortoise about fortune and misfortune, for the tortoise has endured many years. Those near Ao Granary do not eat more for its abundance; those beside the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers do not drink more for their vastness—they fill their bellies and no more. *Ao Granary* was an ancient ever-full granary, located north of Rongyang.

Orchids and angelica are fragrant, yet they have never seen frost. The owl wards off weapons, and its lifespan ends at the full moon of the fifth month. *Owl* likely refers to the *xiao* (screech owl); another says the toad. In later times, people made effigies of the *xiao* or toad to burn at the full moon of the fifth month, saying such things are not fit for use.

Between the tongue and the teeth, which wears away first? *Wears away* means to be ground down. Between the butt-spike and the blade, which fails first? *Butt-spike* is the bronze ferrule at the base of a lance. The butt-spike does not decay, yet the blade rusts first. *Butt-spike* is read as *dùn* in *dǔnshǒu* (to bow the head).

Between the plumb line and the arrow, which is straighter? *Arrow* means the shaft. Now, the eel and the snake, the silkworm and the candle—their forms are similar, yet affection and aversion differ. People love the eel and the silkworm but fear the snake and the candle; hence it is said they differ.

Jin used the jade of Chuiji to gain Yu and Guo—this is explained in the *Qi Su* chapter. The Li Rong destroyed the state of Jin with a beautiful woman. *Beautiful woman* refers to Li Ji. *Destroyed* means to bring chaos.

The deaf do not sing, for they have no way to delight themselves; the blind do not gaze, for they have no way to perceive things. *Perceive* means to see.

Those who watch archery forget their skill; *skill* means craft. Those who read books forget their love—when the mind is fixed on one thing, it forgets what it once held dear.

What was done in ancient times cannot be changed: thus, the handcart remains to this day without a *chanju*. *Chanju* is a type of vehicle, read like *jué* in *juéxiàng* from the phrase “Confucius shot at the Juéxiang clan.”

If one merely blows the *yu*, and the Shi clan fills the holes, though the notes are in tune, they cannot be heard. *Merely* refers to an ancient person who did not know how to play; *merely* is read like *wúyán* in *Yan wúyánchú*. It lacks the form of a ruler. *Ruler* means the master of office.

To treat the same ailment as the dead is difficult for a skilled physician;
to follow the same path as a fallen kingdom makes counsel impossible.

*Counsel* may also be read as *yù* (preparation).

To prepare food as a guest while eating only *líhé* oneself—
one’s reputation exceeds reality.
*Reputation* means weight.
To bear the name of *rén* and *yì* (benevolence and righteousness)
is heavier than the reality of preparing food.

A nursing puppy snapping at a tiger,
a crouching hen striking a weasel—
favor bestowed does not measure their strength.

To bend the *yǐng* (shadow) is to shape the form;
when the form bends, the shadow bends.
To muddy the *yìng* (echo) is to corrupt the sound;
when the sound is muddied, the echo is muddied.

One whose emotions leak is easily fathomed.
If desires are not restrained and spill outward,
then the heart’s depths are known.

Flowers out of season are inedible.
*Flowers* means fruit.
Like eating late melons in the eighth or ninth month,
which causes malaria—
this is why it is said to be inedible.
It illustrates that excessive speech, untimely and misplaced,
should not be heeded.

The *zhí* (ultimate) of *zhíyuè* (crossing) comes by boat or by cart;
though paths differ, the destination is one.
*Zhí* means to reach.
*Extreme* also means to reach.

(Play on characters: *hù* #6, *wén* ear → *hùwén* mutual.)

Though beautiful women differ in physique and fair ones in face,
all please the eye.
*Beautiful* and *fair* are synonymous.
Though pear, orange, date, and chestnut differ in taste,
all harmonize the palate.
*Harmonize* means to suit.

There may be thieves among the wealthy, though wealth does not guarantee theft;
there may be the virtuous among the poor, though poverty does not guarantee integrity.

The *shāngmiáo* (hemp plant) resembles cotton but cannot be spun into it.
The *zhènmiáo* (reed sprout), called *dí* in Chu,
*dí* read as in *dízhàn* (enemy in battle).
Yan and You call it *dídiǎo*.

The *zhī* (hemp with seed) does not resemble cloth but can be made into it.
*Zhī* is read as in *fēi* from the *Zuǒzhuàn* (left-hand record) phrase *“fēi bù wéi zāi”* (the swarm does not bring disaster).

Those who emerge from the forest cannot walk straight paths;
those who tread perilous ground cannot follow the plumb line.
*The plumb line* is also a straight path.

What enables *Yì* (the archer) to strike distant and minute targets
is not the bow and arrows;
what enables *Zàofù* (the charioteer) to overtake swift steeds and travel far
is not the bit and bridle.

The sea’s bounty is contained within it, hence its vastness;
thunder and rain arise from the sea, then return through valleys—
thus, it is said to contain its own source.

The wheel returns to its path, hence its endurance.
*Its path* means unceasing rotation.

Sheep’s flesh does not covet ants, yet ants are drawn to sheep’s flesh—
for it is rank with *shān* (gamey qi).

*Sōng* (pickled fish) and *suān* (sour sauce) do not covet gnats,
yet gnats are drawn to *sōng* and *suān*.

Taste a single slice of meat and know the flavor of the whole pot;
hang a feather beside a charcoal and discern the qi of dryness and dampness—
thus, the small reveals the great, the near suggests the far.

A reservoir of ten *qǐng* can irrigate forty *qǐng*,
for a reservoir stores water—*pí*.
Yet a reservoir of one *qǐng* can irrigate four *qǐng*—
the great and small differ in proportion.

The light of the bright moon can be seen from afar,
yet it cannot be used for fine calligraphy;
on a dense foggy morning, one can write fine calligraphy,
yet cannot see beyond the ordinary.

A painter who meticulously renders every hair loses the likeness;
who focuses on every minute hair, dwelling on the small,
loses the overall form.

An archer who aims at the small misses the large—
who sights only the small and shoots accordingly,
thus strikes true.

Each matter has its proper measure.

Plugging a rat’s hole ruins the neighborhood;
dabbing a small pustule spreads a carbuncle—
*pāo*, a facial *qi* eruption.
*Zé-jū*, a festering boil.

Like a pearl with its blemish, jade with its flaw—
leave them be and they remain whole;
remove them and they are diminished.

The bramble’s nest dwells where the forest thrives—
that is ease;
the hollow’s den takes shelter in the cliff’s embrace—
that is convenience.

The cliff’s rampart, a high barrier against flood.

King Zicheng’s son, Regui, trod upon deer and wild ox,
grappling with tiger and rhinoceros,
yet when confined in the dark chamber,
he could not wrestle with tortoise and turtle—
his strength was ill-suited.

Regui was the son of King Liao of Wu.

Tang expelled his lord and earned honor’s name—
Tang, the thirteenth descendant of King Gui,
son of Yi, whose given name was Wu.
To "expel his lord" means to subdue Jie.
He removed the people’s harm,
thus earning honor’s name.

Cui Zhu assassinated his ruler and incurred great blame—
Cui Zhu, son of the great minister Cui Ye of Qi,
who killed Duke Zhao of Qi.

Their methods were the same in purpose,
yet their means were different.
Their purpose was the same, but their actions diverged—
Tang slew his lord to benefit the people,
while Cui Zhu acted for his own gain—
thus they differed.

Lü Wang made the aged strive—
Lü Wang wielded his knife and fished with hook,
yet at seventy he first learned to read,
and at ninety became King Wen’s teacher,
aiding King Wu in conquering Jie.
King Cheng then enfeoffed him in Qi,
so the aged emulated him and strove with vigor.

Xiang Tuo made infants proud—
by kindred emulation.
Xiang Tuo, at seven, impoverished Confucius
and became his teacher,
thus making the lowly presume greatness.

He made leaves fall by stirring the wind,
made waters muddy by agitating the fish.

The tiger’s and leopard’s markings drew hunters—
their patterns lured the archer’s aim.
The monkey’s swiftness brought the snare—
its agility summoned the hunter’s strike.

A single chess move reveals not wisdom,
a single string’s pluck reveals not sorrow.

A three-inch flute cannot fill the world,
yet a ten-stone measure suffices—
a hundred dou is enough.
To gauge the river with a pole,
then measure the water’s depth—
this is folly.
The pole sinks, yet one takes the river’s depth as its end—
thus it is called folly.

The fisherman flees to the deep—
*Yu* as in the *Analects*.
The woodcutter flees to the mountain—
what is urgent is survival.

In the morning market, he runs;
at dusk, he walks past—
what is sought is lost.

The leopard’s pelt, though mixed, is not as pure as the fox’s.
A white jade with flaws is not a treasure—
*kao*, a blemish.

This speaks of purity’s difficulty.
