chunks.original_text: 故机械之心藏於胸中，则纯白不粹，神德不全。 机械，巧诈也。 藏之於胸臆之内，故纯白之道不粹，精神专一之德不全也。 粹读祸祟之祟也。 在身者不知，何远之所能怀。 怀，来也。 是故革坚则兵利，城成则冲生。 言攻战之备於此生也。 若以汤沃沸，乱乃逾甚。 是故鞭噬狗，策蹄马，而欲教之，虽伊尹造父弗能化。 伊尹名挚，殷汤之贤相也。 造父，周穆王之臣也，而善御。 虽此二人不能化之。 欲（寅）〔害〕#2之心亡於中，则饥虎可尾，何况狗马之类乎？ 故体道者逸而不穷，任数者劳而无功。 夫峭法刻诛者，非霸王之业也，棰策繁用者，非致远之术也。 繁，数也。 离朱之明，察箴末於百步之外，离朱者，黄帝臣，明目人也。 不能见渊中之鱼； 师旷之聪，合八风之调，师旷，晋平公乐师子野也。 八风，八卦之风声也。 而不能听十里之外。 故任一人之能，不足以治三亩之宅也。 修道理之数，因天地之自然，则六合不足均也。 均，平也。 是故禹之决渎也，因水以为师； 神农之播谷也，因苗以为教。 禹，鲧之子，名文命。 受挥成功，曰禹。 因以水性自下，决使东流，以为后世师法也。 神农，少典之子，炎帝也。 农植嘉谷，神而化之，故号曰神农也。 播，布也。 布种百谷，因苗之生而长育之，以为后世之常教也。 夫萍树根於水，萍，大苹也。 木树根於土，鸟排虚而飞，兽跖实而走，跖，足也。 实，地也。 跖读捂摭之抚。 蛟龙水居，虎豹山处，天地之性也。 蛟，水蛟，其皮有珠。 世人以为刀剑之口是也。 蛟读人情性交易之交，缓气言乃得耳。 两木相摩而然，金火相守而流，流，译也。 贠者常转，窾者主浮，自然之势也。 员，轮丸之属也。 窾，空也，舟船之属也。 故曰自然之势也。 窾读科条之科也。 是故春风至则甘雨降，生育万物。 明堂月令曰：清风至则谷雨是也。 育，长也。 风或作分合。 羽者妪伏，毛者孕育。 妪伏，以气剖卵也。 孕者，怀胎育生也。 草木荣华，鸟兽卵胎，莫见其为者，而功既成矣。 既，已也。 秋风下霜，到生挫伤； 草木首地而生，故曰到生。 挫伤者，雕落也。 鹰雕搏鸷，昆虫蛰藏，鸷读什伍之十。 草水注根，鱼鳌凑渊，莫见其为者，灭而无形。 灭，没也。 形，见也。 木处榛巢，水居窟穴，聚木曰榛。 禽兽有芃，芃，蓐。 人民有室。 陆处宜牛马，舟行宜多水。 匈奴出秽裘，匈奴，猃吮北胡也。 于越生葛絺。 于，吴也。 絺，细葛也。 各生所急，以备燥湿。 各因所处，以御寒暑。 并得其宜，物便其所。 由此观之，万物固以自然，圣人又何事焉。 事，治也。 九疑之南，陆事寡而水事众，九疑，山名也，在苍梧。 虞舜所葬也。 於是民人被发文身，以像鳞虫； 被，翦也。 文身，刻画其体，内默其中，为蛟龙之状，以入水蛟龙不害也。 故曰以像鳞虫也。 短绻不绔，以便涉游； 短袂攘卷，以便刺舟； 因之也。 卷，卷臂也。 因之因水之宜也。 雁门之北，狄不谷食，贱长贵壮，俗尚气力。 人不 弓，马不解勒，便之也。 不谷，食肉酪而已。 北狄，鲜卑也。 弛，舍也，便，习也。 故禹之裸国，解衣而入，衣带而出，因之也。 裸国在南方，圣人治礼不求变俗，故曰因之也。 今夫徙树者，失其阴阳之性，则莫不枯槁。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus when the heart of cunning and deceit lies hidden within the breast, purity remains unsullied no longer, and the power of spirit and virtue becomes incomplete. *Cunning and deceit* refers to artifice and guile. Concealed within the depths of the heart, the pure and unblemished Dao loses its perfection, and the virtue of undivided spirit cannot be whole. *Unsullied* is read as the "sui" in "misfortune and calamity."

What dwells within the self remains unknown—how then can what is distant be drawn near? *Drawn near* means "to come."

Therefore, when armor is hardened, weapons grow sharp; when walls are raised, siege engines arise. This speaks of how preparations for war give rise to conflict. It is like pouring boiling water on a fire—chaos only worsens.

To whip a snapping dog or spur a kicking horse, hoping to tame them—even Yi Yin or Zao Fu could not transform their nature. *Yi Yin*, named Zhi, was a worthy minister of Tang of Yin. *Zao Fu* was a servant of King Mu of Zhou, renowned for his charioteering. Yet even these two could not alter their nature.

When the heart of harm and malice vanishes from within, even a starving tiger may be grasped by the tail—how much more so dogs and horses? Thus one who embodies the Dao remains at ease and never exhausted, while one who relies on schemes toils without success.

Those who govern with harsh laws and cruel punishments do not build the enterprise of hegemons and kings; those who frequently resort to the whip and prod do not achieve far-reaching ends. *Frequently* means "repeatedly."

Li Zhu’s keen vision could discern the tip of a needle at a hundred paces—*Li Zhu* was a minister of the Yellow Emperor, a man of sharp eyesight—yet he could not see the fish in the depths of a pool. Shi Kuang’s acute hearing could harmonize the eight winds—*Shi Kuang* was the music master Ziye of Duke Ping of Jin; *the eight winds* refers to the winds of the eight trigrams—yet he could not hear what lay ten *li* away.

Thus relying on the ability of a single person is insufficient to govern even a three-*mu* estate. But if one cultivates the principles of the Dao and follows the natural patterns of Heaven and Earth, then the Six Directions are not too vast to bring into harmony. *Harmony* means "balance."

Therefore, when Yu dredged the waterways, he took the water itself as his teacher. When Shennong sowed the grains, he took the sprouts as his guide. *Yu*, son of Gun, was named Wenming. He received the jade baton and succeeded in his task, hence the name Yu. Following the nature of water, which flows downward, he dredged the rivers to flow eastward, setting an example for later generations. *Shennong*, son of Shaodian, was the Flame Emperor. He cultivated fine grains, transforming them through spiritual power, and was thus called Shennong. *Sowed* means "to scatter." He scattered the seeds of the hundred grains, nurturing their growth in accordance with their sprouting, establishing a constant teaching for later generations.

The duckweed takes root in water, *duckweed* being the great *ping*; trees take root in earth; birds soar through empty space; beasts tread upon solid ground—*tread* means "to step"; *solid* means "the earth." *Tread* is read as the "fu" in "to comfort and gather." Dragons dwell in water; tigers and leopards inhabit the mountains—this is the nature of Heaven and Earth. *Jiao* refers to the water dragon, whose skin bears pearls. In later times, this was used for the hilts of swords. *Jiao* is read as the "jiao" in "human nature and temperament," pronounced with a drawn-out breath.

When two pieces of wood are rubbed together, they ignite; when metal and fire are kept close, they melt—*melt* means "to flow." Wheels and spheres constantly turn; hollow things float—this is the natural tendency of things. *Wheels and spheres* refer to objects like wheels and pellets. *Hollow* means "empty," as in boats and ships. Thus it is said to be the natural tendency. *Hollow* is read as the "ke" in "sections and branches."

Therefore, when the spring wind arrives, sweet rain falls, nurturing the myriad things. *The Monthly Ordinances of the Hall of Light* states: "When the clear wind arrives, the Grain Rain follows." *Nurturing* means "to grow." *Wind* may also be written as *fenhe* (allotment and union).

Feathered creatures brood and hatch; furred creatures conceive and bear. *Brood* means "to warm and hatch eggs with qi." *Conceive* means "to carry offspring in the womb and give birth." The flourishing of plants and trees, the hatching of birds, the bearing of beasts—none see the one who acts, yet the work is already accomplished. *Already* means "complete."

When the autumn wind brings frost, the sprouting of life is checked and harmed. Plants and trees grow from the earth, hence "sprouting." *Checked and harmed* means "withered and fallen." Eagles and hawks strike with ferocity; insects and worms hide in hibernation—*ferocity* is read as the "shi" in "ten and five." Plants send their moisture to their roots; fish and turtles gather in the depths—none see the one who acts, yet all vanish without a trace. *Vanish* means "to disappear"; *trace* means "to appear."

Trees dwell in nests of brushwood—*brushwood* means "a thicket of trees"; water creatures live in caves and dens. Birds and beasts have their lairs—*lairs* means "bedding." Humans have their dwellings. On land, oxen and horses thrive; by water, boats travel far. The Xiongnu produce coarse furs—*Xiongnu* refers to the northern barbarians of Xianyun. The people of Yue weave fine kudzu cloth—*Yu* refers to Wu; *kudzu cloth* is fine kudzu fabric. Each produces what they urgently need to prepare for dryness and dampness. Each adapts to their environment to ward off cold and heat. All attain what is fitting, and things find their proper place.

From this, we observe that the myriad things are fundamentally natural—what then does the sage have to do? *Do* means "to govern."

South of the Nine Doubts, land-based work is scarce while water-based work abounds—*Nine Doubts* is a mountain name, located in Cangwu, where Yu Shun was buried. There, the people cut their hair and tattoo their bodies to resemble scaled creatures. *Cut* means "to shear"; *tattoo* means "to carve and paint their bodies, concealing the patterns within, forming the shapes of dragons and serpents so that when they enter the water, the dragons and serpents do not harm them." Thus it is said "to resemble scaled creatures."

They wear short sleeves and do not don trousers, to facilitate wading and swimming. They roll up their sleeves to make rowing easier—this is following the ways of water. *Roll up* means "to gather the sleeves"; *following* means "adapting to the suitability of water."

North of Yanmen, the Di do not eat grains, esteeming the strong and scorning the old, with customs that value strength. People do not unstring their bows; horses are not untethered—this is convenience. *Do not eat grains* means "they eat only meat and fermented milk." The northern Di are the Xianbei. *Unstring* means "to release"; *convenience* means "practice."

Thus when Yu entered the land of the naked, he removed his clothes to go in and put on his belt to come out—this was following their ways. *The land of the naked* lies in the south; the sage, in governing ritual, does not seek to change customs, hence "following their ways."

Now, when one transplants a tree and loses its balance of yin and yang, there is none that does not wither and die.

chunks.original_text: 失犹易也。 故橘树之江北，则化而为枳。 鸲鹆不过济，貈渡汶而死。 见於周礼。 故春秋传曰：鸲鹆来巢。 言非中国之禽，所以为鲁昭公仁，异也。 形性不可易，势居不可移也。 是故达於道者，反於清净； 反，本也。 天本授人清静之性，故曰反也。 究於物者，终於无为。 无为者，不为物为也。 以恬养性，以漠处神，则入于天门。 所谓天者，纯粹朴素，质直皓白，未始有与杂糅者也。 所谓人者，偶 智故，曲巧伪诈，所以俛仰於世人，而与俗交者。 故牛歧蹄而戴角，马被髦而全足者，天也。 络马之口，穿牛之鼻者，人也。 循天者，与道游者也。 循，随也。 游，行也。 随人者，与俗交者也。 夫井鱼不可与语大，拘於隘也。 夏虫不可与语寒，言蜩蝉不知寒雪也。 笃於时也。 曲士不可与语至道，拘於俗，束於教也。 故圣人不以人滑天，不以欲乱情。 天，身也。 不以人事滑乱其身也，不以欲乱其情，浊之性者也。 不谋而当，不言而信，不虑而得，不为而成。 诗云：不识不知，顺帝之则。 故曰不谋而当，不虑而得也。 精通于灵府，与造化者为人。 为，治也。 夫善游者溺，善骑者堕，各以其所好，反自为祸。 祸，害也。 是故好事者未尝不中，中，伤也。 好为情欲之事者，未尝不自伤也。 争利者未尝不穷也。 昔共工之力触不周之山，使地东南倾，共工以水行霸於伏牺神农间者也，非尧时共工也。 不周山，昆仑西北。 倾，犹下也。 天文言天倾西北，地倾东南，先言倾，高也。 些言东南，后言倾，明其下也。 与高辛争为帝。 高辛，帝誉。 有天下之号也，誉，黄帝之曾孙。 遂潜于渊，宗族残灭，继嗣绝祀。 谓共工也。 越王翳逃山穴，越人熏而出之，遂不得已。 已，止也。 翳，越太子也。 贤不欲为王，逃於山穴之中，越人以火熏出而立之。 故曰还不得已。 在春秋后，故不书于经也。 由此观之，得在时，不在争； 治在道，不在圣。 治，为也。 虽圣不得为，故曰在道，孔子是也。 土处下不争高，故安而不危； 水下流不争先，故疾而不迟。 昔舜耕於历山，期年而田者争处烧埆，以封壤肥饶相让。 历山，在济阴成阳也。 一曰济南历城山也。 境埆读人相烧椽之硗。 钓於河渎，期年而渔者争处湍濑，以曲限深潭相予。 渔读告语。 湍濑，水浅流急，少鱼之处也。 曲限，崖岸委曲，深潭四流饶鱼之处。 覃读葛覃之覃。 当此之时，口不设言，手不指麾，口不设不信之言也，手不指麾，不妄有所规儗也。 执玄德於心，而化驰若神。 玄，天也，驰，行也。 若神，若有神化之也。 使舜无其志，虽口辩而户说之，不能化一人。 志，王天下之志也。 一曰人心之志也。 是故不道之道，莽乎大哉。 道不可道，故曰不道之道。 夫能理三苗，朝羽民，三苗，尧时所放浑敦、穷奇、饕餮之等。 理，治也。 羽民，南方羽国之民。 使之朝者，德以怀远也。 从裸国，纳肃慎，未发号施令而移风易俗者，其唯心行者乎。 裸国在南方，禹所入也，从，化也，肃慎，北方，远也。 傅曰：肃慎、燕、亳，吾北土也。 唯仁化为能然也。
chunks.translated_text:
Losing it is akin to changing it. Thus, when the orange tree is planted north of the Jiang, it transforms into the zhi. The myna bird does not cross the Ji River; the raccoon-dog dies upon fording the Wen. As recorded in the *Rites of Zhou*. The *Spring and Autumn Annals* states: "The myna bird came to nest." It speaks of a bird not native to the Central States—this was why it was deemed a sign of Duke Zhao of Lu’s virtue, an anomaly. Form and nature cannot be altered; position and dwelling cannot be shifted.

Therefore, those who attain the Dao return to clarity and stillness. *Return* means "to revert to the root." Heaven originally bestows upon man a nature of clarity and stillness, hence "return." Those who exhaust themselves in things end in non-action. *Non-action* means "not being acted upon by things." Nurturing one’s nature with tranquility and abiding the spirit in emptiness, one enters the Gate of Heaven. What is called *Heaven* is pure, unadulterated simplicity—upright, bright, and white—never yet mingled with anything impure. What is called *man* is entangled in cunning and deceit, crooked artifices and falsehoods, bowing and scraping before the world, engaging with common customs.

Thus, the ox has cloven hooves and bears horns; the horse is covered in mane and has whole hooves—this is Heaven. Bridling the horse’s mouth and piercing the ox’s nose—this is man. Those who follow Heaven wander with the Dao. *Follow* means "to comply"; *wander* means "to act." Those who follow man engage with common customs.

The well-dwelling fish cannot be spoken to of the great—it is confined by narrowness. The summer insect cannot be spoken to of cold—it speaks of the cicada that knows not winter’s snow. It is bound by its time. The narrow-minded scholar cannot be spoken to of the ultimate Dao—he is constrained by custom and fettered by doctrine.

Thus, the sage does not let human affairs disturb Heaven, nor desires disorder the emotions. *Heaven* refers to the body. He does not let human affairs disturb his body, nor desires disorder his emotions—this is the nature of the undefiled. Without plotting, he is fitting; without speaking, he is trusted; without deliberation, he attains; without acting, he accomplishes. The *Book of Songs* says: "Unknowing, unperceiving, he follows the pattern of the Lord." Thus it is said: without plotting, he is fitting; without deliberation, he attains.

With spirit penetrating the numinous palace, he becomes one who shapes creation. *Becomes* means "to govern." The good swimmer drowns; the good rider falls—each by their own fondness brings disaster upon themselves. *Disaster* means "harm." Thus, those fond of affairs are never without injury. *Injury* means "wounding." Those fond of indulging in emotions and desires never fail to wound themselves. Those who contend for profit never fail to reach exhaustion.

Of old, Gonggong’s strength struck Mount Buzhou, causing the earth to tilt southeast. Gonggong was one who wielded water to establish hegemony between Fuxi and Shennong—this was not the Gonggong of Yao’s time. Mount Buzhou lies northwest of Kunlun. *Tilt* means "to sink." The astronomical texts speak of Heaven tilting northwest and earth tilting southeast—first mentioning "tilt" to denote height. Later mentioning "southeast" clarifies its sinking. He contended with Gaoxin for the throne. Gaoxin was Emperor Ku, a title held over the realm. Ku was the great-grandson of the Yellow Emperor. Gonggong then submerged himself in the depths, his clan annihilated, his lineage and sacrifices cut off. This refers to Gonggong.

King Yi of Yue fled into a mountain cave, and the people of Yue smoked him out, leaving him no choice. *No choice* means "no recourse." Yi was the crown prince of Yue. Though virtuous and unwilling to be king, he fled into a mountain cave, but the people of Yue used fire to smoke him out and enthroned him. Thus it is said: "He had no choice but to return." This occurred after the *Spring and Autumn* period, hence it was not recorded in the classic.

From this, we see that attainment lies in timing, not in contention; governance lies in the Dao, not in sagacity. *Governance* means "to act." Though sagacious, one cannot act without the Dao—thus it is said to lie in the Dao, as with Confucius.

Earth, dwelling below, does not contend for height—thus it is secure and not endangered. Water, flowing downward, does not contend for precedence—thus it is swift and not slow.

Of old, Shun tilled the fields of Mount Li. After a year, those who farmed vied to occupy the scorched and barren land, yielding the fertile and rich soil to one another. Mount Li lies in Chengyang of Jiyin. Another account places it in Licheng Mountain of Jinan. *Scorched and barren* is read as the hard and infertile land where people burn rafters.

He fished in the rivers and streams. After a year, those who fished vied to occupy the rapids and shallows, yielding the deep pools within winding banks to one another. *Fished* is read as conversing. *Rapids and shallows* are places where water is shallow and swift, with few fish. *Winding banks* are the curved shores where deep pools teem with fish. *Yielding* is read as in the *Book of Songs*: "The spreading vine."

At that time, he set no words with his mouth nor gestured with his hands. *Set no words* means he spoke no untrustworthy words; *gestured with no hands* means he did not presumptuously scheme or plan. Holding the profound virtue in his heart, his transformations spread like a spirit. *Profound* means Heaven; *spread* means "to act." *Like a spirit* means as if by divine transformation.

Had Shun lacked such resolve, though he spoke eloquently and expounded from door to door, he could not have transformed even one person. *Resolve* means the aspiration to rule all under Heaven. Another interpretation refers to the resolve of the human heart.

Thus, the Dao that cannot be spoken of is vast indeed. *Cannot be spoken of* means the Dao is ineffable, hence "the Dao that cannot be spoken of."

He who can govern the Sanmiao, bring the Feathered People to court—the Sanmiao were those exiled in Yao’s time, such as Hundun, Qiongqi, and Taotie. *Govern* means "to rule." The Feathered People were the inhabitants of the southern Feathered State. That they came to court was due to virtue drawing the distant near.

He who could follow the Land of the Naked and receive the Sushen without issuing commands or decrees yet altered customs and transformed manners—was this not solely the work of one whose conduct was rooted in the heart? The Land of the Naked lies in the south, where Yu entered. *Follow* means "to transform." The Sushen dwell in the distant north. The *Fu* says: "Sushen, Yan, and Bo are our northern lands." Only the transformative power of virtue can achieve this.

chunks.translated_text:
The imposition of laws and punishments—how could these suffice to achieve such ends? Words alone are insufficient to bring them about, making clear that nothing compares to the transformative power of a heart imbued with benevolence. Thus, the sage cultivates the root within and does not adorn the branches without; he preserves his spirit, lays aside cunning and artifice, and abides in serene non-action—yet nothing remains undone. His capacity for non-action ensures that all things are transformed without resistance. In stillness, he governs nothing—yet nothing is left ungoverned.

What is called *non-action* is not acting before things arise. What is called *not acting* is following the natural course of things. It is to accord with the inherent nature of things. What is called *non-governance* is not altering what is natural. What is called *nothing left ungoverned* is following the mutual suitability of things. *Suitability* here means "what is fitting."

chunks.original_text: 原道训下 万物有所生，而独知守其根。 根，本也。 百事有所出，而独知守其门。 门，禁要也。 故穷无穷，极无极，照物而不眩，响应而不乏，此之谓天解。 眩，惑也。 天解，天之解故也。 言能明天意也。 故得道者，志弱而事强，弱，柔也。 强。 无不胜也。 心虚而应当。 当； 合也。 所谓志弱者，柔毳安静，藏於不敢，行於不能，恬然无虑，动不失时，与万物回周旋转，不为先唱， 感而应之。 感动应和。 是故贵者必以贱为号，贵者，谓公王侯伯，称孤寡不谷，故曰以贱为号。 而高者必以下为基。 基，始也。 夫筑京台先从下起也。 托小以包大，在中以制外，行柔而刚，用弱而强。 转化推移，得一之道，而以少正多。 而，能也。 能以寡统众。 所谓其事强者，遭变应卒，排患抒难，力无不胜，敌无不凌。 应化揆时，莫能害之。 是故欲刚者，必以柔守之。 欲强者，必以弱保之。 积於柔则刚，积於弱射强。 观其所积，以知祸福之乡。 乡，方也。 强胜不若己者，至於若己者而同。 夫强者能胜不如己者，同，等也。 至於如己者，则等不能胜也。 育强之为小也，道家所不贵也。 柔胜出於己者，其力不可量。 夫能弱柔胜己者，其力不可訾也。 言柔之为大也，道家所贵。 故兵强则灭，木强则折，革固则裂，齿坚於舌而先之弊。 兵犹火也，强则盛，盛则衰，故曰则灭。 以火论也。 木强则折，不能徐屈也。 革坚则裂，鼓是也。 弊，尽。 齿坚於舌而先舌尽。 是故柔弱者，生之干也，干，质也。 而坚强者，死之徒也。 徒，众也。 先唱者，穷之路也； 后动者，达之原也。 先者颓陷， 故曰穷也。 后者以谋，故曰达也。 何以知其然也？ 凡人中寿七十岁，然而趋舍指凑，日以月悔也，以至於死。 故蓬伯玉年五十，而有四十九年非。 伯玉，卫大夫蘧瑷也。 今年所行是也，则还顾知去年之所行非也。 岁岁悔之，以至於死。 故有四十九非，所谓月悔朔，日悔昨也。 何者？ 先者难为知，而后者易为攻也。
chunks.translated_text:
**On Tracing the Dao, Part Two**

All things have their origins, yet only the wise preserve their roots.
*Roots* are the foundation.
All affairs arise from some source, yet only the wise guard their gates.
*Gates* are the crucial restraints.

Thus, to fathom the unfathomable, to reach the unreachable, to illumine things without confusion, to respond to echoes without exhaustion—this is called *heavenly release*.
*Confusion* means delusion.
*Heavenly release* is the release of Heaven’s intent.
It is to comprehend the will of Heaven.

Therefore, those who attain the Dao set their minds on weakness yet accomplish strength.
*Weakness* is softness.
*Strength* is invincibility.
Their hearts are empty yet their responses are fitting.
*Fitting* means harmonious.

What is called *setting the mind on weakness* is to be gentle, tranquil, and still, concealing oneself in non-daring, acting from non-ability, serene and without care, moving without missing the moment, revolving and turning with the myriad things, never taking the lead—only responding when moved.
*Moved* means stirred; *responding* means harmonizing.

Thus, the noble must take the lowly as their title.
*The noble* refers to dukes, kings, marquises, and earls, who style themselves "the solitary," "the widowed," or "the unworthy"—hence the saying, "taking the lowly as their title."
And the exalted must take the low as their foundation.
*Foundation* is the beginning.
For even the building of a towering terrace begins from the ground.

They entrust the small to encompass the great, reside within to govern without, act with softness yet are firm, employ weakness yet are strong. Through transformation and change, they grasp the Dao of unity and thereby rectify the many with the few.
*And* means "to be able."
To govern the many with the few.

What is called *accomplishing strength* is to meet sudden changes, respond to emergencies, dispel calamities, and resolve difficulties—no force is unconquerable, no enemy undefeated. Adapting to transformations and measuring the times, nothing can harm them.

Thus, those who desire firmness must hold to softness.
Those who desire strength must preserve weakness.
Accumulate softness, and firmness arises.
Accumulate weakness, and strength emerges.
Observe what they accumulate, and you will know the direction of fortune and misfortune.
*Direction* means "course."

Strength can overcome what is inferior to itself, but when it encounters its equal, it meets its match.
*Equal* means "the same."
Strength can overcome what is not its equal, but when it meets its equal, it cannot prevail.
This is why the smallness of strength is not valued by the Daoists.

Softness that overcomes what surpasses itself—its power is immeasurable.
For one who can be weak and soft yet overcome what is stronger, their power is beyond estimation.
Thus, the greatness of softness is what the Daoists value.

Therefore, when armies are strong, they perish.
Like fire, when strength blazes, it burns fiercely, and when it burns fiercely, it declines—hence the saying, "they perish."
This is the lesson of fire.
When wood is strong, it snaps—it cannot bend slowly.
When leather is rigid, it splits—like a drum.
*Perish* means "to be exhausted."
Though teeth are harder than the tongue, they wear out first.

Thus, softness and weakness are the stalks of life.
*Stalks* are the essence.
While firmness and strength are the followers of death.
*Followers* are the multitude.

Those who take the lead are on the path to exhaustion.
The first to act meet ruin—hence the saying, "exhaustion."
Those who act later do so with strategy—hence the saying, "attainment."

How do we know this is so?
The average person lives seventy years, yet in their pursuits and abandonments, their choices converge, and with each passing month, they feel regret—until death.
Thus, when Master Peng of Wey reached fifty, he recognized forty-nine years of error.
*Master Peng* was Qu Boyu, a grandee of Wey.
What he did this year was right, so he looked back and knew that what he did the previous year was wrong. Year after year, he felt regret—until death.
Thus, he had forty-nine years of error, which is what is meant by "monthly regret at the new moon, daily regret for yesterday."

Why is this?
The first to act are difficult to understand, while those who follow are easy to overcome.

chunks.original_text: 先者上高，则后者攀之； 先者谕下，则后者蹶之； 先者颓陷，则后者以谋； 先者败绩，则后者（逢）〔违〕#1之。 蹙，履也。 音展，非展也。 楚人读踬为颓。 颓者，车承。 或言跋踬之踬也。 由此观之，先者则后者之弓矢质的也。 质的，射者之准执也。 犹錞之与刃，刃犯难而錞无患者，何也？ 以其托於后位也。 錞，矛戈之錞也。 读曰顿刃矛戈之刃也。 刃在前，故犯难。 顿在后，故以无患，故曰其托於后位也。 此俗世庸民之所公见也，而贤知者弗能避也。 庸，众也。 公，详也，众民详所见知。 贤者不能避为锋刃也，以谕利欲也，故曰有所屏蔽也。 所谓后者，非谓其底滞而不发，凝竭而不流，底读曰纸。 发，动也。 凝如脂凝也流行。 贵其周於数而合於时也。 周，调也。 数，术也。 合於时，时行则行，时止则止也。 夫执道理以耦变，先亦制后，后亦制先。 道当胜事，为变不必待於先，人事当在后，趋时当居先也。 是何则？ 不失其所以制人，人不能制也。 时之反侧，间不容息。 言时反侧之间，不容气息促之甚也。 先之则大过，后之则不逮。 夫日回而月周，时不与人游。 故圣人不贵尺之璧，而重寸之阴，时难得而易失也。 禹之趋时也，履遗而弗取，冠挂而弗顾，非争其先也，而争其得时也。 是故圣人守清道而抱雌节，清，和诤也。 雌，柔弱也。 因循应变，常后而不先。 柔弱以静，舒安以定，舒，详也。 攻大坚，莫能与之争。 攻大坚，谕难也，无与圣人之争也。 天下之物，莫柔弱於水，然而大不可极，深不可测，测，尽也。 修极於无穷，远渝於无崖，息耗减益，通於不訾。 訾，量也。 上天则为雨露，下地则为润泽，万物弗得不生，百事不得不成。 大包群生，而无好憎； 泽及蚑蛲蚑，蚑行也。 蛲，微小之虫也。 而不求报。 施而不有也。
chunks.translated_text:
Those who take the lead ascend to heights, and followers climb after them; those who lead descend into low places, and followers trip them; those who lead collapse and fall, and followers scheme against them; those who lead suffer defeat, and followers oppose them.

*Cù* means "to tread." Its pronunciation is *zhǎn*, not *zhǎn*. The people of Chu read *zhì* as *tuí*. *Tuí* refers to the carriage’s crossbar. Some say it is the *zhì* in *bázhì* ("stumbling"). From this, we see that those who lead become the target for those who follow—the *zhìdì*, the standard and aim of the archer. The *zhìdì* is what the archer takes as his mark.

It is like the blade and the butt of a spear: the blade faces danger, while the butt remains unharmed. Why? Because it relies on its position behind. *Chún* refers to the butt of a spear or halberd. Read it as *dùn*, the butt of a spear or halberd. The blade is in front, so it faces danger; the butt is behind, so it remains unharmed. Thus, it is said to rely on its position behind.

This is something even the common and mediocre see plainly, yet the wise and worthy cannot avoid it. *Yōng* means "the multitude"; *gōng* means "to examine in detail"—what the multitude sees and knows in detail. The worthy cannot avoid becoming the blade’s edge, for they are drawn by desire for profit. Thus, it is said they must have something to shield them.

What is meant by "those who follow" is not that they stagnate and do not act, congeal and do not flow. *Dǐ* is read as *zhǐ*. *Fā* means "to move." *Níng* is like congealed fat; *liú* means "to flow." What is valued is their harmony with the method and their accord with the times. *Zhōu* means "to harmonize"; *shù* means "technique." To accord with the times is to act when the time is right for action and to stop when the time is right for stopping.

Those who grasp the Dao and adapt to change may lead and thereby control those who follow, or follow and thereby control those who lead. The Dao should prevail over circumstances; adaptation to change need not wait upon taking the lead. Human affairs should come after, while seizing the moment should come first.

Why is this? Because if one does not lose what enables control over others, others cannot control them. The turning of the times allows no room for breath—so swift is the moment between reversal and counter-reversal. To lead is to overreach; to follow is to fall short.

The sun revolves and the moon completes its cycle; time does not move in step with man. Thus, the sage does not prize jade disks a foot in diameter but values an inch of time, for time is hard to gain and easy to lose.

When Yu hastened to seize the moment, he left his sandals behind and did not retrieve them, passed by his fallen cap and did not glance back. He did not contend to be first but to seize the right time.

Therefore, the sage maintains the pure Dao and embraces the feminine principle. *Qīng* means "harmonious and upright"; *cí* means "soft and weak." He responds to change by following along, always remaining behind rather than taking the lead. Soft and weak, tranquil and composed—*shū* means "unhurried"—he attacks great and hard obstacles, and none can contend with him. To "attack great and hard" is to overcome difficulties; none can contend with the sage.

Of all things under heaven, none is softer or weaker than water, yet its greatness cannot be fathomed, its depth cannot be measured. *Cè* means "to exhaust." It extends endlessly and flows boundlessly, now diminishing, now increasing, yet always beyond measure. *Zī* means "to calculate." It becomes rain and dew in the heavens and moistens the earth below, giving life to all things and bringing all affairs to completion. It embraces all living things without favor or aversion, bestowing its benefits even upon crawling insects and tiny creatures—*qí* means "to crawl"; *náo* refers to the smallest of creatures—yet seeks no reward. It gives without possessing.

chunks.original_text: 富赡天下而不既，瞻，足也。 既，尽也。 德施百姓而不费。 德泽加於百姓，不以为己财费也。 行而不可得穷极也，流膏不止也。 微而不可得把握也。 击之无创，刺之不伤，斩之不断，焚之不然。 水之性也。 淖溺流遁，错缪相纷，适，逸也。 错缪相纷，彼此相纠也。 而不可靡散。 利贯金石，强济天下，水流缺石，是其利也。 舟船所载，无有重，是其强也，济，通也。 动溶无形之域，而翱翔忽区之上。 忽，怳之。 区，上也。 言其飞为云，无所不上也。 邅回川谷之间，邅回，犹委曲也。 而淹腾大荒之野。 有余不足，与天地取与，授万物而无所前后。 前后皆与之。 是故无所私而无所公，公私一也。 靡滥振荡，与天地鸿洞； 鸿，大也。 洞，通也。 读同异之同也。 无所左而无所右，蟠委错紾，与万物始终。 紾，转也。 是谓至德。 言水之为德最大，故曰至德也。 夫水所以能成其至德於天下者，以其淖溺润滑也。 故老聃之言曰:天下至柔，驰骋於天下之至坚，出於无有，入於无间，水是也。 吾是以知无为之有益。 有益於生。 夫无形者，物之大祖也。 无音者，声之大宗也。 无形生有形，故为物大祖也。 无音生有音，故为声大宗祖。 宗皆本也。 其子为光，其孙为水，皆生於形乎。 光无形，道所贵也。 观之，故子为光也，水形而不可毁，差之，故孙为水也。 夫光可见，而不可握。 水可循，而不可毁。 故有像之类，莫尊於水。 出生入死，自无跖有，自有跖无，而以衰贱矣。 出生，出生道，谓去清净也。 入死，入死道，谓情欲也。 跖，适也。 自无形适有形，离其本也。 自有形适无形，不能复得道家所弃。 故曰而以衰贱也。 是故清静者，德之至也； 而柔弱者，道之要也； 要，约也。 虚而恬愉者，万物之用者。 万物由之得为人用。 肃然应感，殷然反本，则沦於无形矣。 所谓无形者，一之谓也。 一者，道之本也。 所谓一者，无匹合於天下者也。 卓然独立，块然独处。 上通九天，下贯九野。 九天，八方中央也，九野亦如之。 贠不中规，方不中矩。 大浑而为一，叶累而无根。 无根，言微妙也。 怀囊天地，为道关门。 门，道之门。 穆忞隐闵，纯德独存。 穆忞隐闵，皆无形之类也。 纯，不杂糅也。 布施而不既，用之而不勤。 既，尽也。 勤，劳也。 是故视之不见其形，听之不闻其声，循之不得其身。 无形而有形生焉，无形，道也。 有形，万物也。 无声而五音鸣焉，音生於无声也。 无味而五味形焉，形或作和也。 无色而五色成焉。 是故有生於无，实出於虚。 有形生於无形，人也。 实，财也。 天下为之圈，则名实同居。 圈，陬也。 名，爵号之名也，实，币帛之属也。 一曰仁义之功赏也。 音之数不过五，宫商角征羽也。 而五音之变，不可胜听也。 变，更相生也。 味之和不过五，甘酸咸辛苦也。 而五味之化，不可胜尝也。 化，亦变也。 色之数不过五，青赤白黑黄也。 而五色之变，不可胜观也。 常事曰视，非常曰观。 春秋鲁隐公观渔於棠是也。 故音者，宫立而五音形矣。 言在中央，声之主也。 形，正也。 味者，甘立而五味亭矣。 亭，平也。 甘，中央味也。 色者，白立而五色成矣。 白者，所在以染之，故五色可成也。 道者，一立而万物生矣。
chunks.translated_text:
The Way enriches all under heaven without exhaustion—*zhān* means "to suffice"; *jì* means "to deplete." Its virtue bestows upon the hundred clans without expense, for its blessings extend to the people without being counted as personal wealth. Its flow cannot be exhausted, its flowing essence never ceases. It is so subtle it cannot be grasped, struck without wounding, pierced without injury, severed without breaking, burned without igniting—such is the nature of water.

Soft and yielding, it flows and flees, intertwining in endless tangles—*shì* means "to escape"; *cuòmiù xiāngfēn* describes mutual entanglement—yet it cannot be scattered. Its sharpness pierces metal and stone, its strength sustains all under heaven: water wears away stone, demonstrating its keen edge; boats carry boundless weight, showing its might—*jì* means "to penetrate." It moves through formless realms and soars above the fleeting and boundless—*hū* means "elusive"; *qū* means "above," for it ascends as clouds without limit. It winds through rivers and valleys—*zhānhuí* means "to meander"—and surges across the vast wilds. In surplus or scarcity, it aligns with heaven and earth in giving and receiving, granting to the ten thousand things without preference. Thus, it is neither private nor public, for public and private become one.

Vast and surging, it harmonizes with the great oneness of heaven and earth—*hóng* means "great"; *dòng* means "pervading"; *tóng* here reads as "oneness." It favors neither left nor right, coiling and twisting in endless turns, beginning and ending with the ten thousand things—*zhěn* means "to revolve." This is called the supreme virtue, for water’s power is greatest, hence the term *supreme virtue*.

That water achieves such supreme virtue under heaven is due to its softness and smoothness. Thus, the words of Lao Dan say: "The softest under heaven gallops through the hardest. Emerging from non-being, it enters where there is no gap"—this describes water. "Thus I know the benefit of non-action," for it benefits all life.

The formless is the great ancestor of things; the soundless is the great origin of sound. The formless gives birth to form, hence its title as the great ancestor. The soundless gives birth to sound, hence its title as the great origin—*zōng* means "root." Its child is light, its grandchild is water, both born of form. Light is formless, prized by the Dao; thus, it is called the child. Water, though formed, cannot be destroyed; thus, it is called the grandchild. Light can be seen but not grasped; water can be followed but not destroyed. Among all things with form, none is more revered than water.

Emerging into life and entering death, from non-being to being, from being to non-being—it thus declines and debases. "Emerging into life" means departing from purity; "entering death" means succumbing to desire—*zhí* means "to proceed." From formlessness to form is to stray from the root; from form to formlessness is to fail to return to what the Daoists discard. Hence, it is said to decline and debase.

Thus, stillness is the perfection of virtue; softness and weakness are the essence of the Dao—*yào* means "essential." Emptiness and tranquility are the use of the ten thousand things, for through them all things serve humanity. Responding with solemnity and returning to the root, one merges into formlessness. The so-called formless is called the One, for the One is the root of the Dao. The One is that which has no equal under heaven, standing alone and solitary. It reaches the nine heavens above and penetrates the nine wilds below—the nine heavens are the eight directions and the center; the nine wilds follow likewise. It is neither round nor square, vast and undifferentiated as one, layered yet rootless—*rootless* signifies its subtlety. It embraces heaven and earth, serving as the gateway of the Dao—*gate* is the gate of the Dao. Profound and hidden, pure virtue alone endures—*mùmǐn yǐnmǐn* describe the formless; *pure* means unadulterated. It bestows without exhaustion, and its use is never laborious—*jì* means "to deplete"; *qín* means "to toil."

Thus, gazing upon it, one sees no form; listening, one hears no sound; tracing it, one finds no body. From the formless, form arises—the formless is the Dao; form is the ten thousand things. From the soundless, the five tones resound—sound is born of silence. From the tasteless, the five flavors take shape—*shape* may also read as *harmony*. From the colorless, the five colors emerge. Thus, being arises from non-being, and substance emerges from emptiness. Form arises from the formless—this refers to humanity. *Substance* means wealth; when the world is enclosed, name and reality dwell together—*enclosure* means "corner"; *name* refers to titles and ranks, *reality* to goods like silk. Another interpretation: rewards for benevolence and righteousness.

The notes of sound do not exceed five—*gōng, shāng, jué, zhǐ, yǔ*—yet the variations of the five tones are endless—*variations* means mutual generation. The harmonies of taste do not exceed five—sweet, sour, salty, bitter, pungent—yet the transformations of the five flavors are beyond tasting—*transformation* also means change. The hues of color do not exceed five—blue, red, white, black, yellow—yet the variations of the five colors are beyond beholding—*chángshì* means "ordinary sight"; *fēicháng* means "extraordinary vision," as when Duke Yin of Lu observed fishing at Tang.

Thus, in sound, when *gōng* is established, the five tones take shape—*gōng* stands at the center, master of sound; *shape* means "to rectify." In flavor, when sweetness is established, the five flavors are harmonized—*harmonized* means "balanced"; sweetness is the central taste. In color, when white is established, the five colors are completed—white can be dyed in any hue, hence the five colors are achieved. In the Dao, when the One is established, the ten thousand things are born.

It becomes rain and dew in the heavens and moistens the earth below, giving life to all things and bringing all affairs to completion. It embraces all living things without favor or aversion, bestowing its benefits even upon crawling insects and tiny creatures—*qí* means "to crawl"; *náo* refers to the smallest of creatures—yet seeks no reward. It gives without possessing.

chunks.original_text: 是故一之理，施四海； 理，道也。 一之解，际天地。 解，达也。 际，机也。 解读解故之解也。 其全也，纯兮若朴； 朴若玉朴也，在石而未剖。 其散也，混兮若浊。 浊而徐清，冲而徐盈。 澹兮其若深渊，冲，虚也。 盈，满也。 澹，定不动之貌。 泛兮其若浮云。 若无而有，若亡而存。 万物之总，皆阅一孔； 总，众聚也。 百事之根，皆出一门。 道之门也。 其动无形，变化若神； 其行无迩，常后而先。 道之 先也。 是故至人之治也，至道之人。 掩其聪明，灭其文章，依道废智，与民同出于公。 公，正。 〔约其所守，寡其所求，〕#2去其诱慕，除其嗜欲，诱慕，谕贪荣势也，故去之也。 嗜欲，情欲也，故除之也。 损其思虑。 常，浩澹也。 约其所守则察，不烦扰也。 寡其所求则得。 易供故得。 夫任耳目以听视者，劳形而不明； 以知虑为治者，苦心而无功。 是故圣人一度循轨，一，齐也。 轨，法也。 不变其宜，不易其常，放准修绳，曲因其当。 夫喜怒者，道之邪也。 道贵平和，故喜怒为邪也。 忧悲者，德之失也。 德尚恬和，以忧悲为失。 论语曰：其德坦荡是也。 好憎者，心之过也。 嗜欲者，性之累也。 心当专。 中扃外闭，反有所好憎，故曰过。 性当清静以奉天素，而反嗜欲，故为之累也。 人大怒破阴，大喜坠阳。 怒者，阴气也。 阴为坚冰，积阴相薄，故破阴。 喜者，阳气。 阳升於上，积阳相薄，故曰阳坠也。 薄气发喑，惊怖为狂。 忧悲多恚，病乃成积。 好僧繁多，祸乃相随。 故心不忧乐，德之至也； 通而不变，静之至也； 变，更也。 嗜欲不载，虚之至也； 不载於性。 无所好憎，平之至也； 不与物散，粹之至也。 散乱粹纯。 能此五者，则通於神明。 通於神明者，得其内者也。 是故以中制外，百事不废。 中，心也。 外，情欲。 中能得之，则外能收之。 不养也。 中之得则五藏宁，思虑平，五藏宁者，各得其所。 思虑平者，本妄喜怒。 筋力劲强，耳目聪明，疏达而不悖，悖，谬也。 坚强而不鞼。 鞼，折。 无所大过，而无所不逮。 处小而不逼，处大而不窕。 在小能小，在大能大。 其魂不躁，其神不娆。 躁，狡娆烦娆也。 言精神定矣。 湫漻寂寞，为天下枭。 湫漻，清静也。 寂漠，恬淡也。 枭，雄也。 迫则能应，感则能动，物穆无穷，穆，美。 变无形像。 言能化也。 优游委纵，如响之与景。 响应声，影应形。 登高临下，无失所秉； 履危行险，无忘玄仗。 玄仗，道也。 能存之此，其德不亏。 万物纷糅，与之转化。 以听天下，若背风而驰，疾而易也。 是谓至德。 至德则乐矣。 古之人有居岩穴而神不遗者，遗，失也。 末世有势为万乘而日忧悲者。 由此观之，圣亡乎治人，而在于得道； 乐亡于富贵，而在于德和。 （之）〔知〕#3大己而小天下，则几於道矣。 几，近也，许由务光是。 所谓乐者，岂必处京台章华，京台章华，皆楚之大台。 游云梦沙丘，云梦，楚泽，在南郡华容也。 沙丘，纣台名也，在巨鹿也。 耳听九韶六莹，九韶，舜乐也。 莹，颛顼乐也。 口味煎熬芬芳，驰骋夷道，夷，平也。 钓射鹔鸘之乐乎？ 鹔鸘，鸟名也。 长经绿身，其形似雁。 一曰凤凰之别名也。 吾所谓乐者，人得其得者。 夫得其得者，不以奢为乐，不以廉为悲，廉犹俭也。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, the principle of the One extends to the four seas—*principle* means the Dao. The understanding of the One pervades heaven and earth—*understanding* means "to penetrate"; *pervade* means "to reach the mechanism." This *understanding* is the same as the *understanding* in "to comprehend."

In its wholeness, it is pure as uncarved jade—*uncarved* means jade still embedded in stone, uncut. In its dispersion, it is turbid as muddied waters—yet turbid waters gradually clear, and emptiness gradually fills. Still as a deep abyss—*still* means unmoving. Drifting as floating clouds—seeming not to exist yet existing, seeming to vanish yet enduring.

The sum of the ten thousand things all passes through a single aperture—*sum* means "gathering of the many." The root of the hundred affairs all emerges from a single gate—the gate of the Dao. Its movement is formless, its transformations divine. Its course knows no nearness, yet it is always last to arrive and first to precede—the precedence of the Dao.

Therefore, the governance of the perfected person—the person of utmost Dao—veils their keen insight, effaces their adornments, abides by the Dao and discards cunning, and emerges with the people from impartiality—*impartiality* means "uprightness." [They restrict what they hold to, diminish what they seek,]#2 abandon allurements and desires—*allurements* refers to craving for glory and power, hence they are abandoned; *desires* refers to emotional cravings, hence they are removed. They reduce their thoughts and cares—*constant* means "vast and still." Restricting what they hold to brings clarity, free from disturbance. Diminishing what they seek brings attainment—for it is easy to provide.

Those who rely on ears and eyes to hear and see exhaust their forms yet remain unclear. Those who govern through knowledge and deliberation strain their minds yet achieve nothing. Thus, the sage uniformly follows the track—*uniformly* means "to align"; *track* means "the standard." They do not alter what is fitting, nor change what is constant. They model themselves on the level and the marking-line, bending only where appropriate.

Joy and anger are the deviations of the Dao—the Dao values equilibrium and harmony, hence joy and anger are deviations. Sorrow and grief are the losses of virtue—virtue esteems serenity and harmony, hence sorrow and grief are losses. As the *Analects* says: "Their virtue is broad and unobstructed." Preference and aversion are the faults of the heart. Cravings and desires are the burdens of nature—the heart should be focused; when inner gates are sealed and outer ones closed, yet preferences and aversions arise, this is called *fault*. Nature should be clear and still to serve Heaven’s purity, yet cravings and desires arise, hence they are called *burdens*.

Great anger shatters the yin; great joy topples the yang—anger is yin qi; yin congeals into solid ice, and when accumulated yin forces press against one another, yin is shattered. Joy is yang qi; when yang ascends above, and accumulated yang forces press against one another, yang is said to topple. When qi presses and surges, speech is lost; when terror and fright arise, madness follows. Excessive sorrow and resentment breed illness and accumulation. Excessive preferences and aversions bring calamity in their wake.

Thus, a heart free from sorrow and joy is the perfection of virtue. Unchanging in its openness is the perfection of stillness—*unchanging* means "without alteration." Free from cravings and desires is the perfection of emptiness—*free from* means "not carried by nature." Without preferences or aversions is the perfection of equilibrium. Unscattered by things is the perfection of purity—*scattered* means "disordered"; *purity* means "unmixed." One who masters these five attains communion with the divine—*communion with the divine* means "grasping the inner." Thus, by the center controlling the outer, the hundred affairs are not neglected—*center* means "the heart"; *outer* means "emotions and desires." When the center is attained, the outer is gathered. Without cultivation, the center’s attainment brings peace to the five viscera and balance to thoughts and cares—*peace in the five viscera* means each finds its proper place; *balance in thoughts and cares* means eliminating reckless joy and anger. Sinews and strength become robust, ears and eyes keen. One is unobstructed yet not perverse—*perverse* means "erroneous"—and firm yet not brittle—*brittle* means "broken." Without great excess, nothing is beyond reach. In small matters, one is not constrained; in great matters, one is not slack—small in smallness, great in greatness. Their spirit is not restless, their mind not vexed—*restless* means "fickle and troubled." Their essence and spirit are settled.

Serene and silent, they become the leader of the world—*serene* means "clear and still"; *silent* means "tranquil and indifferent." Pressed, they can respond; moved, they can act. Things are harmonious without end—*harmonious* means "beautiful." Transformations have no fixed form—this speaks of their power to change. Leisurely and unconstrained, they are like echo to sound, like shadow to form. Ascending heights and gazing down, they never lose their grasp; treading peril and traversing danger, they never forget the mysterious staff—*mysterious staff* means the Dao. One who preserves this finds their virtue unblemished.

The ten thousand things, tangled and intertwined, transform with them. In governing the world, it is like riding with the wind at one’s back—swift and effortless. This is called *utmost virtue*. In utmost virtue, there is joy.

The ancients had those who dwelt in mountain caves yet whose spirit did not stray—*stray* means "lost." In later ages, there were those who wielded the power of ten thousand chariots yet suffered daily sorrow and grief. From this, we see that sageliness lies not in governing others but in attaining the Dao; joy lies not in wealth and nobility but in the harmony of virtue.

One who knows the greatness of the self and the smallness of the world draws near to the Dao—*draws near* means "approaches"; this refers to Xu You and Wu Guang. What is called *joy*—must it be dwelling in the grand towers of Jingtái and Zhānghuá—both great towers of Chu—roaming Cloud Dream and Shaqiu—*Cloud Dream* is a marsh of Chu, in Huáróng of Nánjùn; *Shaqiu* is the name of a tower of Zhòu, in Jùlù—listening to the *Nine Shao* and *Six Ying*—*Nine Shao* is the music of Shùn; *Ying* is the music of Zhuānxū—savoring rich and fragrant delicacies, galloping on level roads, delighting in the pleasures of fishing and hunting swans and egrets—*swans and egrets* are bird names; long-necked and green-bodied, their form resembles geese. Some say they are alternate names for the phoenix.

What I call *joy* is when a person attains what they should attain. One who attains what they should attain does not find joy in extravagance nor sorrow in frugality—*frugality* means "thrift."

chunks.original_text: 与阴俱闭，与阳俱开。 故子夏心战而臞，得道而肥。 子夏名商，孔子弟子也。 入学见先王之道而说之，又出见富贵之乐而欲之。 二者交争，故战而臞也。 先王之道胜无所复思，故肥也。 圣人不以身役物，不以欲滑和。 不以身为物役，不以情欲乱中和之道也。 是故其为曜不忻欣，忻忻为过制也。 其为悲不惙惙。 惙惙为伤性也。 万方百变，消摇而无所定。 吾独忼慨，遗物而与道同出。 是故有以自得也。 自得其天性也。 乔木之下，空穴之中，足以适情。 乔木上疏，少阴之木也。 空穴，岩穴也。 唯处此中夫自得者，足以适其情性。 无以自得也，虽以天下为家，万民为臣妾，不足以养生也。 言无以自得之人，犹以此为不足也。 能至于无乐者，则无不乐，无不乐，则至极乐矣。 至乐，至德之乐。 极亦至也。 夫建锺鼓，列管弦，席旃茵，傅旄象； 管，箫也。 弦，琴瑟也。 传，着也。 旄，旌也。 象，以象牙为饰也。 耳听朝歌北鄙靡靡之乐，朝歌，纣都。 鄙，邑也。 纣使师涓作鄙邑靡靡之乐也。 故师延为晋平公歌之，师旷知之曰，亡国之音也。 齐靡曼之色，齐，列也。 靡曼，美也。 陈酒行觞，夜以继日； 乐不辍也。
chunks.translated_text:
With yin they close together, with yang they open as one. Thus Zixia’s heart waged war and grew emaciated, yet attained the Dao and grew plump. Zixia, named Shang, was a disciple of Confucius. Entering the academy, he beheld the Way of the Former Kings and delighted in it; stepping forth, he saw the pleasures of wealth and nobility and desired them. The two contended within him, so his heart waged war and he grew emaciated. When the Way of the Former Kings prevailed, he had no further thoughts, and so grew plump.

The sage does not enslave the self to things, nor does he disturb harmony with desire. He does not make the self a servant to things, nor does he disorder the central harmony of the Dao with emotions and desires. Thus his joy is not exultant—exultation would be excessive restraint—and his sorrow is not grieving—grieving would harm his nature. Though the world’s ten thousand directions and hundred changes sway and drift without fixed abode, I alone stand resolute, leaving things behind to emerge with the Dao as one. Thus I possess that by which I attain my own nature.

Beneath the tall trees, within the hollow caves, this suffices to satisfy the heart. The tall trees are lofty and sparse, the yin-woods of the heights. The hollow caves are the grottoes of the cliffs. Only one who attains his own nature can dwell here and suffice to satisfy his heart and nature. Without that by which one attains one’s own nature, though one make the world one’s home and the myriad people one’s servants and concubines, it is not enough to nourish life. This speaks of one who lacks that by which he attains his own nature, and thus finds even this insufficient.

One who can reach the state of no-joy attains joy in all things; attaining joy in all things, one reaches the ultimate joy. The ultimate joy is the joy of the ultimate virtue. *Ultimate* here means *supreme*.

Now they erect bells and drums, array pipes and strings, spread felt carpets, adorn with yak-tail banners and ivory ornaments—*pipes* are flutes; *strings* are zithers and lutes; *adorn* means "to embellish"; *yak-tail* refers to banners; *ivory* refers to ornaments made of ivory. The ear listens to the decadent music of *Zhaoge* and the northern borderlands—*Zhaoge* was the capital of Zhòu; *borderlands* refers to towns. Zhòu commanded Master Jue to compose the decadent music of the border towns. Thus when Master Yan sang it for Duke Ping of Jin, Master Kuang recognized it, saying, "This is the sound of a doomed state." They display ranks of alluring beauties—*display* means "to arrange"; *alluring* means "beautiful"—pass around wine cups, and revel night into day, their pleasures unceasing.

chunks.original_text: 强弩（千）〔弋〕#4高鸟，走犬逐狡兔； 此其为乐也，炎炎赫赫，怵然若有所诱慕。 诱，进慕，有所思。 怵然犹惕然。 解车休马，罢酒彻乐，而心忽然若有所丧，怅然若有所亡也。 是何则？ 不以内乐外，而以外乐内。 乐作而喜，曲终而悲，悲喜转而相生，精神乱营不得须臾平。 营，惑。 察其所以不得其形，不得乐之形也。 而日以伤生，失其得者也。 是故内不得於中，禀授於外而以自饰也，不浸于肌肤，不浃于骨髓，浸，润也。 浃，通也。 不留于心志，不滞于五藏。 故从外入者，无主於中，不止。 从中出者，无应於外，不行。 故听善言便计，虽愚者知说之； 称至德高行，虽不肖者知慕之。 说之者众，而用之者鲜； 慕之者多，而行之者寡。
chunks.translated_text:
They draw mighty crossbows to shoot high-flying birds, unleash hunting dogs to chase swift hares—such are their pleasures, blazing and resplendent, stirring the heart with restless longing. *Longing* means yearning for advancement; *restless* is akin to alarmed. When they unharness the chariots and rest the horses, cease the wine and stow the music, their hearts suddenly feel as though something is lost, forlorn as if something has vanished. Why is this? They do not cultivate inner joy to guide the outer, but instead seek outer joy to fill the inner. When the music begins, they rejoice; when the melody ends, they grieve—joy and sorrow shift and give rise to one another, their spirits disordered and unsettled, never finding a moment’s peace. *Disordered* means confused.

Examine the cause of this formless disquiet: it is the inability to grasp the true form of joy. Day by day, it harms their lives, for they have lost what they ought to attain. Thus, when the inner self finds no fulfillment within, it borrows from without to adorn itself—yet this does not seep into the skin, nor penetrate to the bone and marrow. *Seep* means to moisten; *penetrate* means to permeate. It does not linger in the heart’s resolve, nor lodge in the five viscera. Therefore, what enters from without finds no master within and does not abide; what emerges from within finds no response without and does not flow.

Hence, when wise counsel or clever plans are heard, even fools delight in them; when supreme virtue or lofty conduct is praised, even the unworthy yearn for them. Those who delight in such words are many, yet those who apply them are few; those who yearn for such ways are numerous, yet those who practice them are scarce.

They display ranks of alluring beauties—*display* means "to arrange"; *alluring* means "beautiful"—pass around wine cups, and revel night into day, their pleasures unceasing.

chunks.original_text: 所以然者何也？ 不能反诸性也。 夫内不开於中而强学问者，不入於耳，而不着於心。 此何以异於聋者之歌也，效人为之，而无以自乐也，声出於口，则越而散矣。 散去耳不闻也。 夫心者，五藏之主也，所以制使四支，流行血气，驰骋于是非之境，而出入于百事之门户者也。 是故不得於心，而有经天下之气，是犹无耳而欲调锺鼓，无目而欲喜文章也。 亦必不胜其任矣。 经，理。 故天下神器，不可为也。 器，物用也，为，治也。 为者败之，执者失之。 夫许由小天下而不以己易尧者，志遗於天下。 许由，阳城人也。 箕山之隐士也。 尧以其贤，聘之，欲禅天下焉，不肯就。 故曰志遗於天下也。 所以然者何也？ 因天下而为天下也。 天下之要，不任於彼而在於我，彼，谓尧也。 我，谓许由。 不在於人而在於我身。 身得则万物备矣。 彻於心术之论，则嗜欲好憎外矣。 外不在心。 是故无所喜而无所怒，无所乐而无所苦，万物玄同也。 玄，天也。 无非无是，化育玄耀，生而如死。 玄，天也。 耀，明也。 生而如死，无所欲。 夫天下者，亦吾有也，吾亦天下之有也。 天下之与我，岂有间哉？ 言相比也。 夫有天下者，岂必摄权持势，操杀生之柄，而以行其号令邪？ 吾所谓有天下者，非谓此也，自得而已。 自得其天性也，一曰不失其身也。 自得则天下亦得我矣。 吾与天下相得，则常相有已。 又焉有不得容其间者乎？ 所谓自得者，全其身者也，全其身则与道为一矣。 故虽游於江浔海裔，浔，崖也。 裔，边也。 溽读葛覃之覃也。 驰要袅，建翠盖，驷驾，要袅，马名也。 日行万里。 袅，挠弱之挠。 翠盖，以翠袅羽饰盖也。 目观掉羽武象之乐，掉羽，羽舞。 武象，周武王之乐。 耳听淹朗奇丽激抮之音，激有激扬抮转皆曲名也，扬郑卫之浩乐，结激楚之遗风，郑声，郑会晋平公说新声，使师延为桑间濮上之乐，濮在卫地，故郑卫之浩乐也，结激清楚之声也，必为郑为之俗乐。 夫结激清楚以娱乐也。 遗风，犹余声也。 射沼滨之高鸟，逐苑囿之走兽，此齐民之所以淫泆流湎。 齐於凡民，故曰齐民也。 沼，池也，滨，水崖也。 圣人处之，不足以营其精神，乱其气志，营，惑也。 使心怵然失其情性。 处穷僻之．乡，侧溪谷之间，侧，伏也。 隐于榛薄之中，丛木曰榛。 深草曰薄。 环堵之室，茨之以生茅，蓬户瓷牖，揉桑为枢，堵长一丈，高一丈，面环一堵，为方一丈。 故曰环者，言其小也。 编蓬为户，以破瓮蔽牖，揉桑条以为元枢。 上漏下湿，润浸北房，浸，渍也。 北房，阴堂也。 雪霜□灖，浸潭蓏蒋，□灖，雪霜之貌也。 浸潭之润，以生蓏蒋，实蓏者，蒋实也。 其米曰□胡。 □读繀绳之繀。 灖读校灭之校。 蓏读觚哉之觚也。 蒋读水浆之浆也。 逍遥于广泽之中，而仿洋于山峡之旁，两山之间为峡。 此齐民之所为形植黎累，忧悲而不得志也。 圣人处之，不为愁悴怨怼，怼，病也。 而不失其所以自乐也。 是何也？
chunks.translated_text:
Why is this so? It is because they cannot return to their inherent nature. Those who lack inner clarity yet force themselves to study and inquire do not truly hear with their ears, nor do their hearts grasp what they learn. How does this differ from a deaf man’s singing—mimicking others’ voices without finding joy in it? The sound leaves his mouth and scatters, vanishing so that even his own ears do not hear it.

The heart is the master of the five viscera, governing the four limbs, circulating blood and qi, galloping through the realm of right and wrong, and passing in and out through the gateways of a hundred affairs. Thus, if the heart does not attain its proper state yet seeks to order the qi of all under heaven, it is like trying to tune bells and drums without ears, or delighting in patterns and colors without eyes—it will surely fail in its task. *Order* means to regulate.

Therefore, the divine vessel of all under heaven cannot be forcibly governed. *Vessel* refers to an instrument of use; *govern* means to manage. Those who govern it ruin it; those who grasp it lose it. When Xu You deemed all under heaven insignificant and would not exchange himself for Yao, his resolve transcended the world. Xu You was a man of Yangcheng and a recluse on Mount Ji. Yao, recognizing his worth, sought him out, wishing to cede the throne to him, but he refused. Thus it is said his resolve transcended the world.

Why was this so? Because he acted in accordance with the world for the sake of the world. The essence of all under heaven does not lie in another but in oneself. *Another* refers to Yao; *oneself* refers to Xu You. It does not rest in others but in one’s own person. When the self is fulfilled, the myriad things are complete. When the discourse on the art of the heart is thoroughly understood, desires, aversions, likes, and hatreds lie beyond it—external to the heart. Thus, there is nothing to delight in and nothing to anger, nothing to rejoice in and nothing to suffer. The myriad things are united in mystery. *Mystery* is heaven. There is no wrong and no right; transformation and nurturance shine in mystery, living as though dead. *Mystery* is heaven; *shine* means brightness. Living as though dead means having no desires.

All under heaven is also mine, and I am also possessed by all under heaven. Between all under heaven and myself, is there any separation? They are comparable. Does possessing all under heaven necessarily mean seizing power, wielding authority, controlling life and death, and issuing decrees? What I call possessing all under heaven is not this—it is self-attainment alone. Attaining one’s heavenly nature, or in other words, not losing one’s true self. When the self is attained, all under heaven also attains me. When I and all under heaven attain one another, we perpetually possess each other. How then could there be no room for such attainment?

What is called self-attainment is preserving one’s person. Preserving one’s person is to become one with the Dao. Thus, though one roams the riverbanks and seashores—*riverbanks* meaning cliffs, *shores* meaning edges—dons fine robes of layered kudzu, rides swift steeds with kingfisher canopies, and travels ten thousand li in a day—*swift steeds* being the name of a horse breed, *kingfisher canopy* adorned with kingfisher feathers—gazes upon the martial dances of waving plumes, listens to the resounding, clear, and exquisite melodies of stirring and twisting tunes—*stirring* and *twisting* being names of musical pieces—indulges in the vast pleasures of Zheng and Wei, and weaves the lingering echoes of Chu’s music—*Zheng music* refers to when the Duke of Jin, Ping, delighted in new sounds, and Shi Yan composed the music of Sangjian and Puzhou, which lay in Wei territory, hence the vast pleasures of Zheng and Wei; *weaving* means to bind the clear sounds of Chu, inevitably becoming the vulgar music of Zheng—though one binds the clear sounds of Chu for amusement, *lingering echoes* being the remnants of its music, hunts the high-flying birds of marsh and shore, and pursues the running beasts of parks and gardens, this is how the common people become licentious, dissipated, and lost in excess. *Common* means ordinary people.

Yet the sage dwells amidst these things without allowing them to disturb his spirit or disorder his qi and resolve. *Disturb* means to confuse, causing the heart to lose its true nature in alarm. Living in a remote and secluded village, beside streams and valleys—*beside* means to dwell—hidden among thickets and undergrowth—*thickets* being dense woods, *undergrowth* being deep grass—in a walled hut thatched with rough grass, with a door of woven reeds and a window of broken pottery, its hinge made of twisted mulberry, where the roof leaks and the floor is damp, moisture seeping into the northern chamber—*seeping* means to soak, *northern chamber* being the shady hall—where snow and frost descend, nourishing gourds and reeds—*descend* describes the appearance of snow and frost; *nourishing* means the moisture that fosters gourds and reeds, the fruit of the gourd being the reed’s fruit, its grain called *su*; *su* is read as the *sui* in *suisheng*, *descend* is read as the *xiao* in *xiaomie*, *gourd* is read as the *gu* in *guzai*, and *reed* is read as the *jiang* in *shuijiang*—wandering freely in broad marshes and drifting along mountain gorges—*gorges* being the space between two mountains—this is what the common people find burdensome, sorrowful, and unfulfilling.

Yet the sage dwells here without becoming distressed or resentful, never losing what brings him joy. Why is this?

Hence, when wise counsel or clever plans are heard, even fools delight in them; when supreme virtue or lofty conduct is praised, even the unworthy yearn for them. Those who delight in such words are many, yet those who apply them are few; those who yearn for such ways are numerous, yet those who practice them are scarce.

chunks.original_text: 则内有以通于天机，机，发也。 而不以贵贱贫富劳逸失其志德者也。 故夫乌之哑哑，鹊之唶唶，岂尝为寒暑燥湿变其声哉？ 言体道者不为贵贱贫富劳逸易其志，如鸟鹊之不为寒暑易其声。 是故夫得道已定，而不待万物之（惟）〔推〕#5移也。 非以一时之变化，而定吾所以自得也。 吾所谓得者，性命之情处其所安也。 夫性命者，与形俱出其宗。 宗，本。 形备而性命成，性命成而好僧生矣。 故士有一定之论，女有不易之行。 士有同志，同志，德也。 至其交接，有一会而公定，故曰有一定之论也。 贞女专一，亦无二心，虽有偏丧，不复更醮，故曰有不易之行者也。 规矩不能方圆，钩绳不能曲直。 虽规矩钩绳，无以施於此。 天地之永，登丘不可为修，居卑不可为短。 是故得道者，穷而不慑，达而不荣，虽穷贱不以为慑惧也，虽显达不以为荣幸 也。 处高而不机，机，危也。 持盈而不倾倾，覆也。 新而不□，久而不渝，□，明也。 渝，变也。 □读汝南□陵之□。 入火不焦，入水不濡。 是故不待势而尊，不待财而富，不待力而强，平虚下流，与化翱翔。 翱翔犹倾仰也。 若然者，藏金於山，藏珠於渊，舜藏金於靳岩之山，藏珠於五湖之渊，以塞贪淫之欲也。 不利货财，不贪势名。 势位，爵号之名也。 是故不以康为乐，康，安也。 不以慊为悲，慊，约也。 慊读辟向慊之慊也。 不以贵为安，不以贱为危。 形神气志，各居其宜，以随天地之所为。 夫形者，生之舍也； 气者，生之充也； 神者，生之制也。 一失位则二者伤矣。 是故圣人使人各处其位，守其职，而不得相干也。 故夫形者，非其所安也而处之则废。 气不当其所充而用之则泄。 神非其所宜而行之则昧。 昧，不明也。 些二者，不可不慎守也。 夫举天下万物，蚑蛲贞虫，蚑行蛲动之虫也。 蛲读饶，贞虫细腰之属也。 蠕动蚑作，蚑读鸟蚑步之蚑也。 皆知其所喜憎利害者，何也？ 以其性之在焉而不离也。
chunks.translated_text:
Then within, one connects to the celestial mechanism—*mechanism* meaning inception—without allowing rank or poverty, toil or ease to disrupt one’s resolve or virtue. Thus, when the crow caws and the magpie chatters, do they ever alter their cries for cold or heat, dryness or damp? This speaks of those who embody the Dao: they do not shift their aspirations for wealth or poverty, toil or ease, just as birds do not change their calls for the seasons.

Therefore, once the Dao is attained and settled, one does not await the shifting tides of the myriad things. It is not through fleeting transformations that I secure what I have gained. What I call attainment is the natural disposition of life and destiny resting in its proper place. For life and destiny emerge together with form from their source—*source* meaning root. When form is complete, life and destiny are fulfilled, and with their fulfillment, preferences and aversions arise.

Thus, the scholar holds to unchanging principles, and the woman maintains steadfast conduct. Scholars share a common purpose—*common purpose* meaning virtue—yet in their interactions, a single encounter may establish a public consensus, hence the saying, "the scholar has unchanging discourse." The chaste woman remains single-minded, without duplicity; even in widowhood, she does not remarry, hence the saying, "she has unwavering conduct." Compass and square cannot make true circles and squares, nor can hooks and plumb lines enforce curves and straightness. Though compass and square, hook and plumb line exist, they have no application here.

The enduring vastness of heaven and earth: ascending a hill does not make one tall, nor does dwelling in lowliness make one short. Thus, one who has attained the Dao is impoverished yet unafraid, prosperous yet not elated—though destitute and lowly, they feel no dread; though eminent and successful, they feel no pride. They stand high without peril—*peril* meaning danger—hold fullness without toppling—*toppling* meaning collapse. They are new yet not ostentatious—*ostentatious* meaning showy—enduring yet unchanging—*unchanging* meaning alteration. *Ostentatious* is read as the *yu* in *Yuling* of Runan. They enter fire without scorching, enter water without getting wet.

Thus, they need not rely on power to be revered, nor on wealth to be rich, nor on force to be strong. Abiding in emptiness and humility, they soar with transformation—*soar* meaning to incline and rise. Such a one may hide gold in the mountains and pearls in the depths, as Shun concealed gold in Mount Jin and pearls in the Five Lakes to curb the desires of greed and excess. They do not profit from goods or wealth, nor covet power or fame—*power* referring to rank, *fame* to titles and names.

Thus, they do not find joy in comfort—*comfort* meaning ease—nor sorrow in hardship—*hardship* meaning constraint. *Constraint* is read as the *qian* in *pixiangqian*. They do not find security in nobility nor peril in lowliness. Form, spirit, qi, and will each reside in their proper place, following the course of heaven and earth.

For form is the dwelling of life, qi is the vitality of life, and spirit is the regulator of life. If any one of these loses its place, the other two are harmed. Therefore, the sage ensures each occupies its proper station, guards its role, and does not encroach upon the others. Thus, if form is not at ease in its place, it decays; if qi is not properly vitalized, it dissipates; if spirit acts where it does not belong, it grows dim—*dim* meaning unclear. These two must be guarded with utmost care.

Even the myriad creatures of the world—creeping insects and wriggling worms—*creeping insects* referring to those that crawl, *wriggling worms* to those with slender waists—know their likes and dislikes, their benefits and harms. Why? Because their nature resides within and never departs.

chunks.original_text: 忽去之，则骨肉无伦矣。 去之，去逆也，则骨肉靡灭，无伦匹也。 今人之所以睦然能视，畦，读曰桂。 营然能听，营读疾营之营也。 形体能抗，抗读扣耳之扣。 而百节可屈伸，察能分白黑、视丑美，而知能别同异、明是非者，何也？ 气为之充而神为之使也。 何以知其然也？ 凡人之志，各有所在，而神有所击者，其行也。 足蹪趎埳，头低植木，而不自知也，蹪，踬也。 楚人读踬为蹪。 知犹觉也。 招之而不能见也，呼之而不能闻也，不能见招之者，不能间呼之者。 耳目〔非〕#6去之也，然而不能应者，何也？ 神失其守也。 精神失其所守。 故在於小则忘於大，在於中则忘於外，在於上则忘於下，在於左则忘於右，若楚白公胜将欲虑乱，立於朝，倒杖策，上贯其头，血流至地，而不觉。 此之类也。 无所不充则无所不在。

chunks.original_text: 精神无所不充。 在，存也。 是故贵虚者，以毫末为宅。 虚者，情无所念虑也。 以毫末为宅者，言精微也。 今夫狂者之不能避水火之难而越沟读之险者，岂无形神气志哉？ 然而用之异也。 与人异也。 失其所守之位，而离其外内之舍，是故举错不能当，动静不能中，当，合也。 中，适也。 终身运枯形于连嵝列埒之门，运，行也。 推辅，病也。 形，体也。 于，於也。 连嵝，犹离嵝也，委曲之类。 列埒，不平均也。 连读陵聋幽州陵陵莲之连。 嵝读□嵝无松栢之嵝。 而蹪蹈于污壑究陷之中。 污壑，大壑。 壑读赫赫明明之赫。 虽生俱与人钧，然而不免为人戮笑者，何也？ 形神相失也。 故以神为主者，形从而利； 以形为制者，神从而害。 神清静故利，形有情欲故害也。 贪饕多欲之人，漠□於势利，诱慕於名位，漠□，犹钝□不知，足类诱进也。 慕，贪。 漠溺之漠。 □读织。 绢致密□无间孔之□也。 冀以过人之智植于高世，冀犹庶几也。 植，立也。 庶几立高名於世也。 则精神日以耗而弥远，耗，秃也。 久淫而不还，淫，过。 还，复。 形闭中距，则神无由入矣。 神，精神也。 清净之性无从还入也。 是以天下时有盲妄自失之患，此膏烛之类也，火逾然而消逾亟。 逾，益也。 亟，疾也。
chunks.translated_text:
The spirit fills all without exception. "In" means to reside. Thus, those who value emptiness take the tip of a hair as their dwelling. Emptiness means the mind harbors no thoughts or concerns. Taking the tip of a hair as their dwelling signifies the utmost subtlety.

Consider the madman who cannot avoid the dangers of water and fire or surmount the perils of ditches and chasms—does he lack form, spirit, qi, or will? No, yet his use of them differs from others. He has lost the proper station of his spirit and departed from the inner and outer abodes of his being. Thus, his actions and movements never align; his stillness and motion never hit the mark. "Align" means to fit; "hit the mark" means to be fitting.

All his life, he drags his withered form through crooked gates and uneven thresholds—"drags" means to move; "pushes and assists" signifies affliction; "form" means the body; "through" means within. "Crooked gates" are like winding paths, a kind of convolution. "Uneven thresholds" are not level. "Crooked" is read as *lián*, like the *lián* in *línglóng* (intricate); "thresholds" is read as *liè*, like the *liè* in *lièliè* (uneven). And he stumbles into filthy ravines and bottomless pits. "Filthy ravines" are great chasms; "ravines" is read as *hè*, like the *hè* in *hèhè* (bright).

Though born equal to others, he cannot escape being mocked and ridiculed. Why? Because form and spirit have parted ways. Thus, those who take spirit as their master find their form following to their benefit; those who take form as their ruler find their spirit following to their harm. Spirit is clear and still, hence beneficial; form is moved by passions and desires, hence harmful.

The greedy and covetous, obsessed with power and profit, lured and enticed by fame and rank—"obsessed" is like being dull and unaware, as if their feet were led astray; "lured" means to covet; "obsessed" is read as *mò*, like the *mò* in *mònì* (drowning). *Mò* is read as *zhī*, like the *zhī* in *juàn* (silk), dense and without gaps—hoping with their superior wisdom to stand above the world, "hoping" means to aspire; "stand" means to establish, aspiring to establish a lofty name in the world. Yet their spirit daily wanes and drifts ever farther. "Wanes" means to diminish; "drifts" means to depart without return. When the form is blocked and obstructed within, the spirit has no way to enter. "Spirit" means the essence of spirit; its clear and still nature has no path to return.

Thus, the world often suffers from blindness, delusion, and self-loss—like the case of a candle: the brighter the flame, the swifter its consumption. "Brighter" means to increase; "swifter" means to hasten.

The essence of spirit, qi, and will—when still, daily grows full and thus strengthens; when restless, daily depletes and thus ages. chunks.original_text: 俶真训上 俶，始也。 真，实说道之实。 始於无有，化育于有，故曰怀真。 因以题篇。 有始者，天地开辟之始也。 有未始有有始者，言万物萌兆未始。 有始者，始成形也。 有未始有夫未始有有始者。 言天地合气，寂寞萧条，未始有也。 夫未始有始，彷佛也。 有有者，言万物始有形兆也。 有无者，言天地浩大，言无可名也。 有未始有有无者，有未始有夫未始有有无者。 所谓有始者，繁愤未废，萌兆牙蘖，未有形埒垠堮，无无蠕蠕，将欲生兴而未成物类。 繁愤，众积之貌。 发，愤也。 有未始有有始者，天气始下，地气始上，阴阳错合，相与优游竞畅于宇宙之间。 被德含和，缤纷龙苁，欲与物接而未成兆朕。 竞，逐也。 畅，达也。 和，气也。 缤纷，杂糅也。 茏苁； 聚会也。 兆朕，形怪也。 有未始有夫未始有有始者，天含和而未降，地怀气而未扬，虚无寂寞，萧条霄雿，无有仿佛，气遂而大通冥冥者也。 霄读绀绡之绡。 窕，翟氏之翟也。 有有者，言万物掺落，根茎枝叶，青葱苓茏，雚蔰炫煌，蠉飞蠕动，鈙行哙息，可切循把握而有数量。 掺读参星之参。 雚蔰炫煌，采色貌也。 蚑读车蚑辙之蚑。 哙读不说择外之哙。 切，摩也。 循，顺也。 雚读曰唯也，蔰读曰扈。 有无者，视之不见其形，听之不闻其声，扪之不可得也，望之不可极也，储与扈治，储与扈治，褒大意也。 浩浩瀚瀚，不可隐仪揆度而通光耀者。 浩浩瀚瀚，广大貌也。 光耀，无形。 有未始有有无者，包裹天地，陶冶万物，大通混冥。 深闳广大，不可为外； 析豪剖芒，不可为内。 无环堵之宇，而生有无之根。 混，真人冥之中，谓道也。 有未始有夫未始有有无者，天地未剖，阴阳未判，剖判混分。 四时未分，万物未生，汪然平静，寂然清澄，莫见其形。 汪读传尸诸周氏之汪同。 若光耀之间於无有，退而自失也。 自失役不见也。
chunks.translated_text:
**The Inaugural Truth, Part One**

*Chu* means "beginning." *Zhen* means the true reality of the spoken Dao. Beginning from Non-Being, it transforms and nurtures into Being—thus it is called "embracing truth." This is why the chapter is so titled.

There is a beginning: the inception of Heaven and Earth. There is that which precedes the beginning of the beginning: the first stirrings of the myriad things before any inception. There is a beginning: the formation of shapes. There is that which precedes the beginning of what precedes the beginning: when Heaven and Earth conjoined their qi, silent and desolate, before any inception existed. What precedes the beginning of the beginning is but a faint semblance.

There is Being: the first signs and shapes of the myriad things. There is Non-Being: the vastness of Heaven and Earth, beyond naming. There is that which precedes the existence of Being and Non-Being, and that which precedes the beginning of what precedes the existence of Being and Non-Being.

The so-called "beginning" refers to when the teeming masses had not yet dispersed, when sprouts and shoots had not yet taken form, when no boundaries or edges existed, when the formless writhed and squirmed—about to arise but not yet manifest as distinct kinds. *Fanfen* describes the appearance of accumulated masses; *fa* means "to burst forth."

There is that which precedes the beginning of the beginning: when the qi of Heaven first descended and the qi of Earth first ascended, when yin and yang intermingled, freely roaming and vying in harmony within the cosmos. Clothed in virtue and containing harmony, they gathered in profusion like tangled vines, desiring to engage with things yet leaving no trace or sign. *Jing* means "to pursue"; *chang*, "to extend." *He* is qi. *Binfan* means "intermixed." *Longcong* means "to assemble." *Zhaozhen* refers to strange forms.

There is that which precedes the beginning of what precedes the beginning of the beginning: when Heaven contained harmony but had not yet sent it down, when Earth held qi but had not yet raised it—void and silent, desolate and boundless, with no semblance to be found, when qi flowed unimpeded into the great obscurity. *Xiao* is read as the *xiao* in *ganxiao* ("deep blue silk"). *Diao* is the *di* in the surname *Dishi*.

There is Being: when the myriad things scatter and fall, their roots, stems, branches, and leaves verdant and lush, their colors resplendent and dazzling, when winged creatures fly and wriggling things move, when crawling things creep and panting things breathe—all tangible, graspable, and measurable. *Can* is read as the *can* in *canxing* ("the three stars"). *Guanhuo xuanghuang* describes the appearance of colors. *Qi* is read as the *qi* in *cheqi zhe* ("wheel tracks"). *Kuai* is read as the *kuai* in *bu shuo ze wai* ("unwilling to choose the outer"). *Qie* means "to rub"; *xun*, "to follow." *Guan* is read as *wei* ("only"); *huo* is read as *hu* ("to guard").

There is Non-Being: invisible in form, inaudible in sound, untouchable to the hand, unbounded to the gaze—vast and boundless, beyond containment or governance, immeasurably vast. *Haohao hanhan* describes boundless expanse. *Guangyao* is formless.

There is that which precedes the existence of Being and Non-Being: it envelops Heaven and Earth, shapes the myriad things, and flows unimpeded through the great obscurity. Profound and expansive, it has no exterior; minute and precise, it has no interior. Without walls or enclosures, it gives rise to the root of Being and Non-Being. *Hun* refers to the state of the perfected person in profound obscurity—this is the Dao.

There is that which precedes the beginning of what precedes the existence of Being and Non-Being: when Heaven and Earth had not yet split, when yin and yang had not yet divided, when separation and distinction were undifferentiated. When the four seasons had not yet emerged, when the myriad things had not yet arisen—all was vast, still, and limpid, with no form to be seen. *Wang* is read as in *chuan shi zhu Zhou shi zhi wang* ("the vastness of the Zhou clan’s ancestral transmissions"). Like light shining between Non-Being, it recedes and vanishes from sight. To vanish is to be unseen.

chunks.original_text: 曰：予能有无，而未能无无也。 能有无为也，未能本性自无为也，故曰未能无也。 及其为无无，至妙何从及此哉。 夫大块载我以形，劳我以生，大块，天地之间也。 逸我以老，休我以死。 庄子曰：生乃徭役，死乃休息也。 故曰休我以死。 善我生者，乃所以善吾死也。 善吾生之乐，乃欲善吾死之乐也。 明死变化有知，欲劝人同死生也。 夫藏舟於壑，藏山於泽，人谓之固矣。 虽然，夜半有力者负而趋，趋，走。 寐者不知，犹有所遁。 夜半有力者负舟与山走，故寐者不知也。 若藏天下於天下，则无所遁其形矣。 大丈夫以天下为室，以藏万物。 物岂可谓无大扬攉乎。 扬攉，无虑大数名也。 攉读镐京之镐。 一范人之形而犹喜，范，犹遇也，遭也。 说范，法也。 言物一法效人形，尚由善也。 若人者，千变万化而未始有极也，言死生变化而梦，故曰末始有极也。 弊而复新，其为乐也，可胜计邪？ 譬若□为鸟而飞於天，□为鱼而没於渊，方其□也，不知其□也，觉而后知其□也。 今将有大觉，然后知今此之为大□也。 始吾未生之时，焉知生之乐也。 今吾未死，又焉知死之不乐也？ 昔公牛哀转病也，七日化为虎，转病，易病也。 江淮之间，公牛氏有易病，化为虎，若中国有狂疾者，发作有时也。 其为虎者，便还食人，食人者因作真虎。 不食人者，更复化为人。 公牛氏，韩人，淮南之人，因牛食刍，谓之刍豢，有验于此。 其兄觇户而入规之，则虎搏而杀之。 杀其兄。
chunks.translated_text:
The Master said: "I can grasp Being and Non-Being, yet I cannot grasp Non-Being of Non-Being. To grasp Being and Non-Being is action, but to be fundamentally non-active in one’s inherent nature—this I have not yet attained. Thus it is said I cannot grasp Non-Being. When one attains Non-Being of Non-Being, how could such supreme subtlety be reached?

The great clod burdens me with form, wearies me with life—the great clod being the space between Heaven and Earth. It grants me ease in old age, repose in death. As Zhuangzi said: 'Life is corvée labor; death is rest.' Thus it is said to grant me repose in death. To treat my life well is to treat my death well. To delight in the goodness of my life is to desire the goodness of my death. Understanding the transformations of death and the awareness therein, one seeks to reconcile life and death as one.

Hiding a boat in a ravine, concealing a mountain in a marsh—people call this secure. Yet in the dead of night, a strong man may bear them away in flight. The sleeper knows nothing; still, they have slipped away. If one hides the world within the world, then no form can escape. The great person takes the world as their chamber, storing all things within. How could one say there is no vast upheaval? *Yanghuo*—a term for boundless magnitude—*huo* is read as in *Gaojing* (the capital of Zhou).

A single encounter with human form brings joy—*fan* means 'to meet' or 'to suffer,' but here it signifies 'to mold' or 'to pattern.' Even when things imitate human form, they are deemed good. Yet for humans, there are ten thousand transformations without end. Life and death shift like dreams; thus it is said there is no ultimate limit. Worn out and then renewed—how could the joy therein be measured?

It is like one who becomes a bird and soars in the sky, or becomes a fish and plunges into the depths. While in that state, one does not know it; only upon waking does one recognize it. Now, when the great awakening comes, only then will we know that this present state is the great dream. Before I was born, how could I have known the joy of life? Now that I have not yet died, how could I know that death is not joy?

Long ago, Gongniu Ai suffered a transforming illness. After seven days, he became a tiger. *Zhuanbing* means 'changing illness.' In the region between the Yangtze and Huai rivers, the Gongniu clan had a condition where one would transform into a tiger—like those in the Central States who suffer from madness, with outbreaks at certain times. Those who became tigers would then eat people, and those who ate people became true tigers. Those who did not eat people would transform back into humans.

Gongniu was a man of Han, from the Huai-Nan region. Because cattle eat grass, they are called *chuhuan* ('grass-fed'), and this case serves as proof. His brother peered through the door to observe him, but the tiger pounced and killed him."

chunks.original_text: 掩读曰奄也。 觇，视也。 是故文章成兽，爪牙移易，移易，人爪牙为虎爪牙也。 志与心变，神与形化。 志心皆变，神形皆化。 方其为虎也，不知其尝为人也； 方其为人，不知其且为虎也。 二者代谢舛驰，各乐其成形。 代，更也。 谢，叙也。 舛，牙也。 形谓成虎形人。 舛读舛卖之舛也。 狡猾钝愍，是非无端，孰知其所萌。 萌，生也。 夫水向冬则凝而为冰，冰迎春则浮而为水。 冰水移易手前后，若周负而趋，孰暇知其所苦乐乎。 泮，释也。 趋，归也。 是故形伤于寒暑燥湿之虐者，形苑而神壮； 苑，枯病也。 壮，伤也。 苑读南阳苑。 神伤乎喜怒思虑之患者，神尽而形有余。 故罢马之死也，剥之若槁。 罢，老。 气力竭尽，故若槁也。 狡狗之死也，割之犹濡。 狡，少也。 濡，濡湿。 气力未尽。 是故伤死者其鬼娆，娆，烦娆，善行病祟人。 时既者其神漠。 既，尽也。
chunks.translated_text:
Yan means "sudden." *Chan* means "to observe." Thus, when the body becomes that of a beast, claws and fangs transform—this transformation means human claws and fangs become those of a tiger. Will and heart change; spirit and form shift. Will and heart both alter; spirit and form both transform. When one is a tiger, one does not recall having been human; when one is human, one does not foresee becoming a tiger. These two states alternate and diverge, each delighting in its formed shape. *Dai* means "to replace"; *xie*, "to unfold"; *chuan*, "to clash." *Xing* refers to the formed shape of tiger or human. *Chuan* is read as in *chuanmai*. Cunning or dull, kind or cruel, right or wrong—none knows whence these arise. *Meng* means "to arise."

Water, when winter comes, congeals into ice; ice, when spring arrives, melts and becomes water. Ice and water transform before and after, like a millstone turning in haste—who has leisure to know what brings suffering or joy? *Pan* means "to dissolve"; *qu*, "to return." Thus, when form is harmed by the ravages of cold, heat, dryness, or dampness, the form withers while the spirit remains strong. *Yuan* means "withered and ailing"; *zhuang*, "harmed." *Yuan* is read as in Nanyang *Yuan*. When the spirit is harmed by the afflictions of joy, anger, thought, or worry, the spirit is exhausted while the form lingers. Thus, when an old horse dies, flaying it reveals dryness like withered wood. *Pi* means "aged." Its qi and strength are spent, hence it resembles withered wood. When a young dog dies, flaying it remains moist. *Jiao* means "young"; *ru*, "moist." Its qi and strength are not yet exhausted. Therefore, those who die from harm have ghosts that are restless—*rao* means "vexing and restless," prone to inflicting illness upon people. Those who die in their time have spirits that are serene. *Ji* means "exhausted."

chunks.original_text: 时既当老者，则神寂漠。 漠，定也。 是皆不得形神俱没也。 道家养形养神，皆以寿终。 形神俱没，不俱漠而已也。 老子曰：以道莅天下，其鬼不神，此谓俱没也。 夫圣人用心，杖性依神，相扶而得终始，是故其寐不□，其觉不忧。 精神无所思虑，故不□。 志存仁义，患不得至，故不忧也。 古之人有处混冥之中，神气不荡于外，万物恬漠以愉静，搀抢衡杓之气，莫不弥靡，搀抢，彗孛也。 杓，北斗柄第七星。 而不能为害。 当此之时，万民猖狂，不知东西，含哺而游，鼓腹而熙。 鼓，击也。 熙，戏也。 交被天和，食于地德，交，俱也。 和，气也。 地德，五谷。 不以曲故，是非相尤，茫茫沈沈，是谓大治。 曲故，曲巧也，尤，过也。 茫茫沈沈，盛貌也。 茫读王莽也。 沈读水出沈沈沈白之沈。 於是在上位者，左右而使之，毋淫其性； 镇抚而有之，毋迁其德。
chunks.translated_text:
When one reaches the proper time of old age, the spirit becomes serene and still. *Mo* means "settled." In all these cases, form and spirit do not perish together. Daoists cultivate both form and spirit to achieve death in old age. When form and spirit perish together, it is not merely that both become still.

Laozi said: "One who governs the world with the Dao—its ghosts possess no numinous power." This is what is meant by "perishing together." The sage’s mind relies on nature and leans upon the spirit, the two supporting each other to complete the cycle of beginning and end. Thus, in sleep, they are not [disturbed]; in wakefulness, they are not anxious. Their essence and spirit harbor no thoughts or worries, hence no [disturbance]. Their will abides in benevolence and righteousness, and no calamity befalls them, hence no anxiety.

In ancient times, there were those who dwelled in primordial chaos, their spirit and qi undispersed outwardly. All things were tranquil and still, delighting in quietude. The baleful qi of comets and the handle of the Northern Dipper could not inflict harm. In that age, the people roamed wildly, knowing neither east nor west, wandering with food in their mouths, striking their bellies in play. *Gu* means "to strike"; *xi*, "to frolic." They were enveloped by the harmony of heaven and nourished by the virtue of earth. *Jiao* means "both"; *he*, "qi"; *de* of earth, "the five grains." Without cunning schemes, they did not blame one another for faults. In boundless vastness, this was called Great Governance. *Qugu* means "crafty contrivance"; *you*, "fault." *Mangmang chenchen* describes a state of abundance. *Mang* is read as in Wang Mang; *chen*, as in the phrase "water flows *chenchen* from Shenbai."

Thus, those in positions of authority guided and employed the people without corrupting their nature; they pacified and governed them without altering their virtue.
