chunks.original_text: 天子城门十二，东方三门，王气所在，（门）#3馁兽之毒药所不得出，尚生育也。 兼余九门得出，故特戒之，如其毋出。 乃禁野虞，毋伐桑拓。 桑、拓皆可养蚕，（文）［故］#4禁民伐之也。 鸣鸠奋其羽，载鵀降于桑，呜鸠，奋迅其羽，直刺上飞入云中者是也。 载鵀，载胜鸟也。 诗曰，尸鸠在桑，其子在梅是也。 具扑曲筥筐，扑，持也，三转谓之扑。 扑，读南阳人言山陵同。 曲，薄也，青、徐谓之曲。 贠底曰筥，方底曰筐，皆受桑器也。 后妃斋戒，东乡亲桑，省妇使，劝蚕事。 命五库，令百工审金铁皮革，筋角箭干，脂胶丹漆，无有不良。 择下旬吉日，大合乐，致欢欣。 乐所以移风易俗也，故择吉日大合之，以致欢和也。 乃合□牛腾马，游牝于牧。 □牛，特牛也。 腾马，腾驹跐蹄，善将群者也。 游从牝於所牧之地风合之。 □，读葛藟之藟也。 令国傩，九门磔攘，以毕春气。 傼，散。 宫室中区隅幽暗之处，击鼓大呼，以逐不祥之气，如今驱疫逐除是也。 九门，三方九门也。 磔犬，阳气尽之，故曰毕春之气也。 行是月令，甘雨至三旬。 季春行冬令，则寒气时发，草木皆肃，国有大恐。 季春行冬寒杀之气也，故寒气时起。 草木上疏曰肃也。 行夏令，则民多疾疫，时雨不降，山陵不登。 季春行夏元阳之令，气不和，故民疾疫，雨泽不降，故草木不登成也。 行秋令，则天多沈阴，淫雨早降，兵革并起。 秋，金气用事，水之母也。 季春行之，故多阴沈为雨也。 金为兵革，故并起也。 三月官乡，其树李。 三月科民户口，故官乡也。 李亦有核，说与杏同。 李后杳熟，故三月李也。 孟夏之月，招摇指巳，昏翼中，旦婺女中。 翼，南方朱鸟之宿，是月昏时中於南方。 婺女，一曰须女，北方玄武之宿，是月平旦中於南方也。 其位南方，其日丙丁，盛德在火，炎帝之神治南方也。 丙丁，火日也。 盛德在火，火王南方也。 其虫羽，其音征，盛阳用事，鳞散。 羽，羽虫，凤（之）〔为］#5长。 征音，火也。 律中仲吕，其数七，是月阳散在外，阴实在中，所以旅阳成功，故曰仲吕。 其数七，生数五，火第二，故曰七也。 其味苦，其臭焦，火味苦也。 焦，火香焦。 其祀灶，祭先胏。 祝融吴回为高辛氏火正，死为火神，托祀於灶。 是月火王，故祀灶。 胏，姊金也。 祭祀之肉先用所胜也。 一曰，姊火，自用其藏也。 蝼蝈鸣，丘蟥出，蝼，蝼蛄也。 蝈，虾蟇也。 四月阴气始动於下，故类应鸣也。 丘演，蠢蠕也。 王瓜生，苦菜秀。 王瓜，栝楼也。 尔雅曰，不荣而实曰秀。 苦菜宜言荣也。 天子衣赤衣，乘赤骝，服赤玉，建赤旗，（烦）〔顺#6火德也。 食菽与鸡，菽，连皮也。 鸡、豆皆属火之所养也。 服八风水，爨柘燧火，南宫御女赤色，衣赤采，吹竽笙，火王南方，故处南宫也。 竽笙空中，像阳，故吹之。 其兵戟，戟有枝干，象阳布散也。 戟或作弩也。 其畜鸡，朝于明堂左令，以出夏令。 南向堂，当盛阳，故曰明堂也。 东头室，故曰左个。 居是室，行是月之令也。 鸡，羽虫，阳也，故畜之。 立夏之日，天子亲率三公九卿大夫以迎岁於南郊。 迎岁，迎夏也。 南郊，七里之郊也。 还，乃赏赐，封诸侯，修礼乐，飨左右。
chunks.translated_text:
The Son of Heaven’s city has twelve gates. The three eastern gates are where the royal *qi* resides, and from these gates, poisonous drugs for slaying beasts must not be allowed to exit—this is to uphold life and nurture. Though the remaining nine gates permit their passage, they are expressly forbidden, as if they were not to leave at all.

Wild wardens are then commanded not to fell mulberry or *tuo* trees. Mulberry and *tuo* both serve to rear silkworms, hence the people are forbidden to cut them down. The turtledove spreads its wings, and the shrike descends upon the mulberry. The turtledove is the bird that swiftly beats its wings, soaring straight upward into the clouds. The *zai shi* is the shrike. As the *Odes* says, *"The shrike is in the mulberry; its young are in the plum."*

Prepare curved baskets and square-bottomed containers. *Pu* means "to hold," and three turns make a *pu*. *Pu* is pronounced like the word for "mountain ridge" in Nanyang speech. *Qu* means "thin," and in Qing and Xu, it is called *qu*. A round-bottomed vessel is called a *ju*, and a square-bottomed one a *kuang*—both are tools for receiving mulberry leaves.

The empress and consorts purify themselves, face east, and personally pluck mulberry leaves, overseeing the women’s work and encouraging sericulture. The Five Armories are ordered to inspect metals, iron, hides, sinews, horns, arrow shafts, tallow, glue, cinnabar, and lacquer—none may be of poor quality.

A propitious day in the last third of the month is chosen to hold a grand musical assembly and foster joy. Music serves to transform customs and shift mores, so a fortunate day is selected for this great gathering to bring about harmony and delight.

Then the finest bulls and stallions are assembled, and mares are released to pasture. *Te* bulls are prime bulls. *Teng* horses are spirited colts that kick up their hooves and excel at leading herds. They are allowed to roam freely among the mares in the grazing lands. *Te* is pronounced like *lei* in "creeping vine."

The state performs the *nuo* exorcism: at the nine gates, dogs are dismembered to dispel inauspicious influences and complete the *qi* of spring. *San* means "to disperse." In the secluded corners and dim recesses of palaces and chambers, drums are beaten and loud cries raised to drive out ill fortune—this is akin to the present-day practice of expelling pestilence. The nine gates refer to the three gates on each of the three sides. Dismembering dogs exhausts the yang *qi*, hence it is said to complete the *qi* of spring.

If the ordinances of this month are followed, sweet rain will fall for thirty days.

If in late spring the ordinances of winter are enacted, cold *qi* will arise at times, grasses and trees will wither, and the state will face great terror. Late spring governed by winter’s killing cold *qi* causes intermittent cold snaps. When plants shed their leaves prematurely, it is called *su*. If the ordinances of summer are enacted, the people will suffer many epidemics, timely rains will not fall, and the hills and mounds will yield no harvest. Late spring governed by summer’s scorching yang *qi* disrupts harmony, leading to disease among the people and drought, so plants fail to mature. If the ordinances of autumn are enacted, the skies will be heavy with gloom, excessive rains will fall prematurely, and warfare will erupt. Autumn is the season when metal *qi* prevails, and metal is the mother of water. When autumn’s *qi* is enacted in late spring, it generates dense yin and excessive rain. Metal governs weapons and war, hence conflicts arise.

In the third month, the office of the district is established, and its tree is the plum. In the third month, the populace’s households are registered, hence the office of the district. The plum, like the apricot, has a pit, and its late ripening places it in the third month.

In the first month of summer, the Big Dipper’s handle points to *si*. At dusk, the Wings constellation culminates, and at dawn, the Woman constellation culminates. The Wings are a constellation of the Vermilion Bird of the south, and this month at dusk, it culminates in the south. The Woman, also called the Serving Maid, is a constellation of the Dark Warrior of the north, and this month at dawn, it culminates in the south.

Its position is the south, its days are *bing* and *ding*, and its supreme virtue resides in fire. The spirit of the Blazing Emperor governs the south. *Bing* and *ding* are fire days. Supreme virtue resides in fire, and fire rules the south. Its creatures are feathered, its note is *zhi*, and flourishing yang prevails as scales disperse. Feathered creatures are led by the phoenix. The *zhi* note corresponds to fire. The pitch pipe *Zhonglü* is attuned, and its number is seven. This month, yang disperses externally while yin solidifies within, thus traveling yang achieves success—hence it is called *Zhonglü*. Its number is seven: the generating number is five, and fire is the second, hence seven.

Its flavor is bitter, its scent is scorched. Fire’s flavor is bitter. Scorched refers to the charred aroma of fire. Its sacrifice is the hearth, and the first offering is the sacrificial meat. Zhu Rong and Wu Hui served as Fire Ministers to Gao Xin, and upon death, they became fire spirits, their worship entrusted to the hearth. As fire rules this month, the hearth is sacrificed to. The sacrificial meat is the sister’s portion. The meat used in sacrifice is first that which overcomes. Alternatively, it is said to be the sister’s fire, using its own store.

Mole crickets chirp, toads emerge, and earthworms appear. The mole cricket is the mole cricket. The *guo* is the toad. In the fourth month, yin *qi* begins to stir below, so these creatures respond by calling. The *qiu yan* is the earthworm.

The royal gourd grows, and sow thistle blooms. The royal gourd is the *guālóu*. The *Erya* states, "That which bears fruit without flowering is called *xiu*." Sow thistle is said to bloom properly. The Son of Heaven wears red robes, rides a red steed, adorns himself with red jade, and raises a red banner—this accords with the virtue of fire. He eats beans and chicken. Beans are those with intact skins. Chicken and beans are both nurtured by fire. He drinks water from the eight winds, cooks with *zhe* wood and fire drilled from it. In the Southern Palace, the imperial consorts wear red, dress in red hues, and play reed pipes and *sheng* flutes. As fire rules the south, they reside in the Southern Palace. Reed pipes and *sheng* flutes are hollow, symbolizing yang, hence they are played. His weapon is the halberd. The halberd has branches and a shaft, symbolizing yang’s dispersion. Alternatively, the halberd may be written as the crossbow. His animal is the chicken.

At dawn, he holds court in the left chamber of the Bright Hall to issue the summer ordinances. The hall faces south, aligning with flourishing yang—hence it is called the Bright Hall. The eastern chamber is called the left chamber. Conducting affairs in this chamber enacts the ordinances of this month. The chicken is a feathered creature, a symbol of yang—hence it is raised.

On the day of the summer solstice, the Son of Heaven personally leads the Three Dukes, the Nine Ministers, and the great officers to welcome the year at the southern suburbs. Welcoming the year means welcoming summer. The southern suburbs lie seven *li* from the city. Upon returning, he bestows rewards, enfeoffs the feudal lords, refines rites and music, and feasts his attendants.

End hunting with nets and arrows, and remove snares, traps, and poisonous drugs from the nine gates. *Bi* are covering nets, and *yi* are arrows with cords. As the *Odes* says, "Shoot teal and wild geese." *Ju* are rabbit nets. As the *Odes* says, "Swiftly the rabbit nets are set." *Bi* and *luo* are bird nets. As the *Odes* says, "Mandarin ducks in the *fu*—net them, snare them." *Fu* is the general term for deer nets.

chunks.original_text: 还，从南郊还也。 赏赐有功，割土封爵。 传曰，赏以春夏，刑以秋冬也。 修治礼乐，所以安上治民，移风易俗。 左右，近臣也。 命太尉，赞杰俊，选贤良，举孝悌，太尉，卿官也。 命，使也。 赞，白也。 才过千人为杰。 选择贤良孝悌，举而用之，盖非太尉之职，故特命之也。 行爵出禄，佐天长养，继修增高，无有隳坏，毋兴土功，毋伐大树。 令野虞，行田原，劝农事，驱兽畜，勿令害谷。 天子以彘尝麦，先荐寝庙。 是月麦始升，故以豕尝麦。 豕，水畜，宜〔麦〕#7，先荐寝庙，孝之至也。 聚畜百药，靡草死，是月阳气极，药草成，故聚积之也。 靡草则亭历之属。 麦秋至，决小罪， 断薄刑。 四月阳气盛於上，及五月阴气作於下，故曰麦秋至。 决小罪，断薄刑，杀气也。 孟夏行秋令，则苦雨数来，五谷不滋，四邻入保。 孟夏盛阳，当助长养，而行金气杀戮之令，故苦雨杀谷，不得滋长也。 四方之民来入城郭自保守也。 行冬令，则草木早枯，后乃大水，败坏城郭。 行冬寒闭固之令，故草木早枯，大水败坏其城郭。 奸时违行之应也。 行春令，则蠡蝗为败暴风来格，秀草不实。 孟夏当继修增高，助阳长养，而行春时启垫之令，故致螽蝗之败。 春，木气，多风，故言暴风来至，使当秀之草不长茂也。 四月官田，其树桃。 四月勉农事，故官田也。 桃，说与杏同。 后李熟，故曰四月桃也。 仲夏之月，招摇指午，昏亢中，旦危中。 亢，东方苍龙之宿，是月昏时中於南方。 危，北方玄武之宿，是月平旦时中於南方也。 其位南方，其日丙丁，其虫羽，其音征，律中蕤宾，其数七，是月阴气萎蕤在下，像主人也，阳气在上，像宾客也，故曰奠宾。 其味苦，其臭焦，其祀灶，祭先肺。 小暑至，螳螂生，螳螂，世谓之天马，一名齿疣，兖、豫谓之巨斧也。 鵙始鸣，反舌无声。 鵙，百劳鸟也。 五月阴气於下，伯劳夏至应阴而呜，杀蛇於木。 传曰，伯赵氏司至者。 反舌，百舌鸟也，能辩变其舌，反易其声，以效百乌之呜，故谓百舌。 无声者，五月阳气极於上，微阴起於下，百舌无阴，故无声也。 天子衣赤衣，乘赤骝，服赤玉，载赤旗，食菽与鸡，服八风水，爨柘燧火，南宫御女赤色，衣赤采，吹竽笙，其兵戟，其畜鸡，朝于明堂太庙。 庙，南向堂，中央室也。 命乐师，修鼗鼙琴瑟管箫，调竽箎，饰锺磬，管，一孔，似笛。 箫，今之歌箫是也。 箎，读如池泽之池也。 执干戚戈羽。 干，盾也。 戈，斧也，戟，属也。 羽，武（也）［者〕#8所持翿也。 命有司，为民祈祀山川百原，大雩帝，用盛乐。 国之山川百原能兴云雨者，皆祈祀之也。 雩，旱祭也。 上，帝也。 为民祈雨，故用盛乐。 盛乐，六代之乐也。 天子以雉尝黍，雉，杂鸡也。 不言尝鸡而言尝黍者，以谷为主也。 羞以含桃，先荐庙。 羞，进也。 含桃，莺所含食，故言含桃。 是月而熟，故进之。 禁民无刈蓝以染，为蓝青未成故。 毋烧灰，是月草木未成，不夭物也。 毋暴布，火盛曰猛，暴布则脆伤也。 门闾无闭，关市无索，门，城门也。 闾，里门也。 民顺阳气，散布在外，当出入，故不闭也。 门，要塞也。 市，人聚也。 无索，不征税也。 挺重囚，益其食，挺，缓。
chunks.translated_text:
Upon returning from the southern suburbs, he rewards those with merit and enfeoffs them with land and titles. As the tradition states: "Rewards are bestowed in spring and summer, punishments in autumn and winter." He refines rites and music to pacify superiors and govern the people, transforming customs and mores. His attendants are his close ministers.

He commands the Grand Commandant to commend the outstanding, select the worthy and good, and recommend the filial and fraternal. The Grand Commandant is a ministerial office. *Ming* means to order; *zan* means to proclaim. Those with talent surpassing a thousand are called outstanding. Selecting the worthy, good, filial, and fraternal to employ them is not the Grand Commandant’s usual duty, hence he is specially commanded.

He confers ranks and bestows emoluments to assist Heaven’s nurturing and growth, continuing cultivation and elevation without decay or ruin. He forbids earthworks and the felling of great trees. He orders the Wildland Wardens to patrol the fields and marshes, encouraging agriculture and driving away beasts and livestock to prevent them from harming the grain.

The Son of Heaven tastes wheat with pork, first offering it at the ancestral temple. In this month, wheat first ripens, hence pork is used to taste it. The pig is a water creature, suited to wheat. Offering it first at the ancestral temple is the height of filial piety.

He gathers and stores all medicinal herbs, for the withered grasses die. In this month, yang qi reaches its peak, and medicinal herbs mature, hence they are gathered and stored. Withered grasses include *tingli* and the like.

When the wheat harvest arrives, he adjudicates minor crimes and metes out light punishments. In the fourth month, yang qi flourishes above, and by the fifth month, yin qi stirs below—hence it is called the wheat harvest. Adjudicating minor crimes and meting out light punishments accords with the qi of killing.

If in early summer autumn ordinances are enacted, bitter rains will frequently come, the five grains will not flourish, and the people of the four directions will take refuge within the walls. Early summer is the height of yang, when nurturing and growth should be assisted. Enacting the metal qi’s ordinances of killing will bring bitter rains that harm the grain, preventing its flourishing. The people of the four directions will enter the cities and fortresses to defend themselves.

If winter ordinances are enacted, grasses and trees will wither early, followed by great floods that ruin city walls. Enacting winter’s ordinances of cold and closure will cause grasses and trees to wither prematurely, and great floods will destroy the city walls. These are the consequences of violating the proper seasons and their ordinances.

If spring ordinances are enacted, locusts will cause devastation, violent winds will arrive, and flowering grasses will not bear fruit. Early summer should continue cultivation and elevation to assist yang’s nurturing and growth. Enacting spring’s ordinances of opening and soaking will bring locust devastation. Spring is the qi of wood, abundant in wind—hence violent winds will come, preventing flowering grasses from maturing.

In the fourth month, the Office of Fields tends to the peach trees. The fourth month encourages agriculture, hence the Office of Fields. The peach is mentioned alongside the apricot. As the plum ripens later, it is called the fourth-month peach.

In the mid-summer month, the *zhaoyao* points to *wu*, the *kang* culminates at dusk, and the *wei* culminates at dawn. *Kang* is a constellation of the eastern Azure Dragon, culminating in the south at dusk this month. *Wei* is a constellation of the northern Dark Warrior, culminating in the south at dawn this month.

Its position is the south, its days are *bing* and *ding*, its creatures are feathered, its note is *zhi*, its pitch pipe is *Ruibin*. Its number is seven. In this month, yin qi droops below like a host, while yang qi resides above like a guest—hence it is called "establishing the guest." Its flavor is bitter, its scent is scorched. Its sacrifice is the stove, and the lungs are offered first.

When the lesser heat arrives, the mantis is born. The mantis is commonly called the "heavenly horse," also known as *chiyou*; in Yan and Yu, it is called the "great axe." The shrike begins to call, and the mockingbird falls silent. The shrike is the *bailao* bird. In the fifth month, yin qi stirs below, and the shrike, responding to yin at the summer solstice, calls while killing snakes in the trees. As the tradition states: "The Bo Zhao clan governs the solstice." The mockingbird is the hundred-tongued bird, able to twist its tongue and alter its voice to mimic the calls of a hundred birds—hence it is called the hundred-tongued bird. It falls silent because in the fifth month, yang qi peaks above while faint yin arises below, and the mockingbird, lacking yin, is thus voiceless.

The Son of Heaven wears red robes, rides a red steed, adorns himself with red jade, carries a red banner, eats beans and chicken, and drinks the water of the eight winds. He cooks with jujube and catalpa firewood. The women of the Southern Palace wear red, dressed in red hues. They play the *yu* and *sheng*. His weapon is the halberd, his animal the chicken. He holds court at the Bright Hall’s ancestral temple. The temple is the south-facing hall’s central chamber.

He commands the Music Masters to repair the drums, *tao* and *pi*, zithers, lutes, flutes, and panpipes, tune the *yu* and *chi*, and adorn the bells and chimes. The *guan* has one hole, resembling a flute. The *xiao* is today’s song flute. The *chi* is pronounced like the "chi" in "pond." He wields shields, *ge* axes, halberds, and feathered banners. The shield is a *gan*; the *ge* is an axe; the halberd is a type of *ji*. The feathered banner is the *duo* held by warriors.

He commands the officials to pray and sacrifice to the mountains, rivers, and all the plains for the people, and to perform the great *yu* sacrifice to the Supreme Emperor with grand music. The mountains, rivers, and plains of the state that can summon clouds and rain are all prayed to and sacrificed to. The *yu* is a drought sacrifice. The "Supreme" is the Emperor. To pray for rain for the people, grand music is used. Grand music refers to the music of the six dynasties.

The Son of Heaven tastes millet with pheasant. The pheasant is a type of chicken. It is not called "tasting chicken" but "tasting millet" because grain is primary. He offers the cherry, first presenting it at the temple. *Xiu* means to offer. The cherry is what the oriole plucks and eats—hence it is called the "contained cherry." It ripens this month, hence it is offered.

He forbids the people from cutting indigo to dye, as the indigo’s blue is not yet fully developed. He forbids burning ash, for in this month grasses and trees are not yet mature, and one must not prematurely harm things. He forbids exposing cloth to the sun, for fire is fierce—exposing cloth will make it brittle and damaged. Gates and lanes are not closed, and passes and markets are not inspected. Gates are city gates; lanes are village gates. The people follow the yang qi, dispersing and dwelling outside, coming and going freely—hence they are not closed. Gates are strategic points; markets are where people gather. "No inspection" means no taxation. He lightens the burdens of heavy prisoners and increases their food. *Ting* means to ease.
chunks.overlap_context:
mber enacts the ordinances of this month. The chicken is a feathered creature, a symbol of yang—hence it is raised.

On the day of the summer solstice, the Son of Heaven personally leads the Three Dukes, the Nine Ministers, and the great officers to welcome the year at the southern suburbs. Welcoming the year means welcoming summer. The southern suburbs lie seven *li* from the city. Upon returning, he bestows rewards, enfeoffs the feudal lords, refines rites and music, and feasts his attendants.

chunks.original_text: 存鳏寡，振死事，老无妻曰鳏，老无夫日寡也，皆存之。 有先人为死难，振起其子孙也。 游牝别其群，执腾驹，班马政。 是月牝马怀胎已定，故别其群。 不欲腾驹蹄伤其胎育，故执也。 斑，告也。 马政，掌马官也。 腾驹，腾马也。 周礼，马五尺以下曰驹也。 日短至，阴阳争，死生分，君子斋戒，慎身无躁，节声色，薄滋味，百官静，事无径，以定晏阴之所成。 事无径，详后行当先请也。 晏阴，微阴也。 鹿角解，蝉始呜，夏至鹿角解堕也。 蝉鼓翼始呜也。 半夏生，木堇荣。 半夏，草药也。 木堇，朝荣暮落，树高五六尺，其叶与安石榴相似也。 是月生荣华，可用作丞也。 雒家谓朝生。 诗云，颜如舞华也。 禁民无发火，发，起。 可以居高明，远眺望登丘陵，处台榭。 积土四方而高曰台也。 台有室曰榭也。 顺阳宜明也。 一曰，望云物，占气祥也仲夏行冬令，则雹霰伤谷，道路不通暴兵来至。 冬水冻，故雹霰伤害五谷也。 冬气闭，又多水雨，故道陷坏不通利，暴害之兵横来至也。 行春令，则五谷不熟，百螣时起，其国乃饥。 行春木王好生育之令，故五谷晚熟。 百螣，动股蝗属也，时起害谷，故国饥也。 行秋令，则草木零落，果实蚤成，民殃於疫。 有核曰果，无核曰蓏。 仲夏行秋成熟之令，故草木零落，果实早成。 非其时气，故民有疾疫也。 五月官相，树榆。 是月阳气长养，故官相。 相，佐也。 榆，说未闻也。 季夏之月，招榣指未，昏心中，旦奎中。 心，东方苍龙之宿也，是月昏时中於南方。 奎，西方白虎之宿也，是月中旦时中於南方也。 其位中央，其日戊己，盛德在土，黄帝之神治中央也。 戊己，土日也。 盛德在土，土正中央也。 其虫赢，其音宫，羽落而〔为赢〕#9，蠃虫鳞为之长。 宫，土也，位中央，五音之主也。 律中百锺，其数五，百锺，林锺也。 是月阳盛阴起，生养万物，故曰百锺。 其数五，五行数土第五也。 其味甘，其臭香，土味甘也，土臭香也。 其祀中溜，祭先心。 土用事，故祀中溜。 中溜，室中之祭，祀后土也。 心，火也，用所胜也。 一曰，心，土也，自用其藏也。 凉风始至，蟋蟀居奥，蟋蟀，蜻烈，趣织也。 诗云，七月在野，此日居奥，不与经合。 奥或作壁也。 鹰乃学习，腐草化为蚈。 秋节将至，鹰自习击也。 蚈，马炫也，幽、冀谓之秦渠。 蚈，读奚径之径也。 天子衣苑黄，乘黄骝服黄玉，建黄旗，黄，顺土色也。 黄谓登饴之登也。 食稷与牛，稷、牛皆属土也。 服八风水，爨柘燧火，中宫御女黄色，衣黄采，其兵剑，季夏，中央也。 剑有两刃，谕无所生也。 一曰，谕无所主皆主之也。
chunks.translated_text:
He attends to the widowed and bereaved, providing relief for those who died in service. *Guan* refers to the elderly without wives; *gua* refers to the elderly without husbands—he attends to them all. For those whose ancestors died in service to the state, he aids their descendants. He separates mares from their herds, restrains stallions, and issues equine decrees. In this month, mares’ pregnancies are established, so they are separated from the herds. To prevent stallions from injuring the fetuses with their hooves, they are restrained. *Ban* means to announce; *ma zheng* refers to the officials in charge of horses. *Teng ju* are stallions. According to the *Rites of Zhou*, horses under five *chi* in height are called *ju*.

The days grow short to their limit; yin and yang contend, and life and death diverge. The noble man fasts and abstains, restraining himself from restlessness. He moderates music and sensual pleasures, tempers rich flavors, stills the hundred officials, and ensures no affairs proceed without due process—thus stabilizing the subtle yin’s accomplishments. *"No affairs proceed without due process"* means that later actions must first be deliberated. *Yan yin* refers to subtle yin.

Deer shed their antlers, and cicadas begin to sing. At the summer solstice, deer shed their antlers; cicadas beat their wings and begin to call. *Banxia* sprouts, and *mujin* blooms. *Banxia* is a medicinal herb. *Mujin* blooms at dawn and withers by dusk; the tree grows five or six *chi* tall, and its leaves resemble those of the pomegranate. It blooms this month and can be used to make hairpins. In Luo, it is called *chaosheng*. As the *Book of Songs* says, *"Fair as the blooming flower."* He forbids the people from kindling fires. *Fa* means to ignite.

One may dwell in high and bright places, gazing afar from hills and mounds, or reside in terraces and pavilions. A *tai* is earth piled high on all sides; a *tai* with a chamber is called a *xie*. This accords with the yang’s brightness. Another saying: observe the clouds and omens of the atmosphere.

If in mid-summer winter’s commands are enacted, hail and sleet will harm the grain, roads will become impassable, and violent armies will arrive. Winter’s freezing waters cause hail and sleet to damage the five grains. Winter’s qi is closed, and with abundant rain, roads sink and become impassable; thus, armies of destruction arrive unexpectedly. If spring’s commands are enacted, the five grains will not ripen, and locusts will arise in swarms, bringing famine to the land. Spring’s wood qi, favoring growth, delays the ripening of the five grains. *Bai teng* are insects of the locust family that arise in swarms to harm the grain, causing famine. If autumn’s commands are enacted, grasses and trees will wither prematurely, fruits will ripen too soon, and the people will suffer from epidemics. Fruits with pits are called *guo*; those without are called *luo*. Enacting autumn’s commands of ripening in mid-summer causes grasses and trees to wither and fruits to mature early. As this contravenes the season’s qi, the people fall ill with epidemics.

In the fifth month, the *Xiang* official is appointed, and elms are planted. This month, the yang qi flourishes and nurtures, hence the *Xiang* official is appointed. *Xiang* means assistant. The significance of the elm is not yet known.

In the final month of summer, the *Zhaoyao* star points south; at dusk, the Heart star culminates, and at dawn, the Straddler star culminates. The Heart is the eastern Azure Dragon’s constellation; this month, it culminates in the south at dusk. The Straddler is the western White Tiger’s constellation; this month, it culminates in the south at dawn. Its position is the center; its days are *wu* and *ji*. The supreme virtue resides in earth, and the Yellow Emperor’s spirit governs the center. *Wu* and *ji* are earth’s days. The supreme virtue resides in earth, for earth rules the center. Its creatures are the *luo*; its note is *gong*. Feathers fall and [become *luo*]; the *luo* insects and scaled creatures lead them. *Gong* is earth, the center, and the master of the five notes. The pitch corresponds to *Bai Zhong*; its number is five. *Bai Zhong* is *Lin Zhong*. This month, yang is at its peak and yin begins to rise, nurturing the myriad things—hence it is called *Bai Zhong*. Its number is five, for earth is the fifth of the Five Phases. Its flavor is sweet; its scent is fragrant. Earth’s flavor is sweet; earth’s scent is fragrant. Its sacrifice is the central channel, and it venerates the Heart. Earth is in charge, so the central channel is sacrificed. The central channel is the sacrifice within the chamber, venerating the Earth Lord. The Heart is fire, using what it overcomes. Another saying: the Heart is earth, employing its own storehouse.

Cool winds begin to arrive, and crickets dwell in the inner chambers. Crickets are *qinglie*, hastening to weave. As the *Book of Songs* says, *"In the seventh month, in the wilds; this day, in the inner chambers"*—this does not align with the classic. *Ao* may also be written as *bi*. Hawks begin to practice hunting, and rotten grass transforms into fireflies. As autumn’s season approaches, hawks train themselves to strike. *Yuan* are fireflies; in You and Ji, they are called *Qinqu*. *Yuan* is read as *jing* in *xi jing*.

The Son of Heaven wears pale yellow, rides a yellow-roan horse, adorns himself with yellow jade, and raises a yellow banner. Yellow accords with earth’s color. *Huang* refers to the color of ripe millet. He eats millet and beef, for both millet and cattle belong to earth. He drinks the water of the eight winds, cooks with jujube wood, and lights fires with mulberry. The central palace’s consorts wear yellow, dressed in yellow hues; their weapon is the sword. The final month of summer corresponds to the center. The sword has two edges, signifying that it generates nothing. Another saying: it signifies that nothing is mastered, yet all is mastered.

Gates are city gates; lanes are village gates. The people follow the yang qi, dispersing and dwelling outside, coming and going freely—hence they are not closed. Gates are strategic points; markets are where people gather. "No inspection" means no taxation. He lightens the burdens of heavy prisoners and increases their food. *Ting* means to ease.

chunks.original_text: 其畜牛，朝于中宫。 是月天子朝於中宫。 中宫，大室。 乃命渔人，伐蛟取鼉，登龟取鼋。 渔人，掌渔官也。 渔，读相语之语也。 蛟、鼉、鼋皆鱼属也，鼉可以作鼓，诗曰，鼉鼓洋洋。 鼋可以作羹也。 传曰，楚人献鼋於郑灵公，灵公不与公子宋鼋羹，公子怒，染指於鼎，尝之而出是也。 皆不害人，易得，故言取。 蛟有鳞甲，能害人，难得，言伐。 龟神，可决吉凶，入宗庙，尊之，故言登也。 令滂人，入材苇。 滂人，掌池泽官也。 入材苇，供国用也。 命四监大夫，令百县之秩刍以养牺牲。 周制，天子地方千里，分为百县，县有四郡，郡有四鄙。 故春秋传言，下大夫受县，上大夫受郡。 秦初置三十六郡以监县耳。 此云百县者，谓周制畿内之县也。 四监，监四郡大夫也。 秩，常所当出，故聚之用养牺牲也。 以共皇天上帝，名山大川，四方之神，宗庙社稷，为民祈福行惠。 令吊死问疾，存视长老，行稃鬻，厚席蓐，以送万物归也。 命妇官染采，黼黻文章，青黄白黑，莫不质良，妇人能别五色，故染采。 白与黑为黼，青与赤为黻，黑与赤为文，赤与白为章。 质，美也。 良，善也。 以给宗庙之服，必宣以明。 宣，徧也。 明，鲜明也。 是月也，树木方盛，勿敢斩伐，不可以合诸侯，起土功。 动众兴兵，必有天殃。 殃，罚。 土润褥暑，大雨时行，利以杀草粪田畴，以肥土僵。 是月大暑，土润得，暑湿重也。 又有时［雨〕#10，可以杀草为粪，美土疆。 〔疆〕#11，土分畔者也。 季夏行春令，则谷实解落，多风欬，民乃迁徙。 春木王，木性堕落，阳发多风，而行其令，故谷实解落，民疾病风，饮嗽上气，像春阳布散，民迁徙者也。 行秋令，则丘隰水潦，稼穑不熟，乃多女灾。 丘，高也。 隰，卑也。 言高下皆有水潦，故杀稼令不熟也。 阴气遇差，故多女灾。 女灾，生子不育也。 行冬令，则风寒不时，鹰隼蚤挚，四鄙入保。 冬阴萧杀，而行其令，故寒风不节，鹰隼蚤挚击，四界之民皆入城郭自保守也。 六月官少内，其树梓。 六月植稼成熟，故官少内也。 梓，说未闻也。 淮南鸿烈解卷之九竟 #1『逆』字脱，据集解本补。 #2『鼠』，『鼠』字之误，据集解本改正。 #3『门』字脱，据集解本剧。 #4『文』，『故』字之误，据集解本改。 #5『之』，『为』字之误，据集解本改。 #6『烦』，『顺』字之误，据集解本改。 #7『麦』字脱，据集解本补。 #8『也』，『者』字之误，据集解本改。 #9『为赢』二字脱，据集解本补。 #10『雨』字脱，据集解本补。 #11『疆』字脱，据集解本补。 淮南鸿烈解卷之十 太尉祭酒臣许慎记上
chunks.translated_text:
Its livestock is the ox, which presents itself at the central palace. In this month, the Son of Heaven holds court in the central palace. The central palace is the great chamber.

He commands the fishery officers to fell *jiao* and take *tuo*, to present tortoises and take *yuan*. The fishery officers oversee the fishing offices. *Yu* (fishing) is read as *yu* in *xiang yu* (mutual speech). *Jiao*, *tuo*, and *yuan* all belong to the fish kind. *Tuo* can be made into drums, as in the *Odes*: “The *tuo* drums resound.” *Yuan* can be made into broth, as the *Tradition* says: “The people of Chu presented a *yuan* to Duke Ling of Zheng. The Duke did not share the *yuan* broth with Prince Song, who in anger dipped his finger into the cauldron, tasted it, and departed.” None of these harm humans and are easily obtained, hence the word “take.” *Jiao* have scales and armor, can harm humans, and are difficult to obtain, hence the word “fell.” The tortoise is divine, can determine fortune and misfortune, and enters the ancestral temple; it is revered, hence the word “present.”

He commands the marsh officers to gather reeds and rushes. The marsh officers oversee the lakes and marshes. Gathering reeds and rushes supplies the state’s needs.

He commands the four inspectors to order the hundred counties to regularly provide fodder and straw to nourish the sacrificial animals. Under the Zhou system, the Son of Heaven’s domain extended a thousand *li*, divided into a hundred counties, each county having four commanderies, and each commandery four borderlands. Thus, the *Spring and Autumn Annals* say: “Minor grand masters receive counties; major grand masters receive commanderies.” When Qin was first established, it set up thirty-six commanderies to oversee the counties. Here, “hundred counties” refers to the counties within the royal domain under the Zhou system. The four inspectors oversee the four commandery grand masters. *Zhi* (regular) refers to what is due to be provided, hence it is gathered to nourish the sacrificial animals, to be offered to August Heaven and the Lord on High, the famous mountains and great rivers, the gods of the four directions, the ancestral temples and altars of soil and grain, to pray for blessings and bestow kindness on the people.

He commands that the dead be mourned and the sick inquired after, that the elderly be visited and cared for, that gruel be distributed, thick mats and bedding be provided, to send off the myriad things as they return. He commands the women’s offices to dye fabrics, embroidering patterns of *fu* and *fu*, with blue, yellow, white, and black—none failing in quality and excellence. Women are skilled at distinguishing the five colors, hence they dye fabrics. White and black form *fu*; blue and red form *fu*; black and red form *wen*; red and white form *zhang*. *Zhi* means fine; *liang* means good. These are used for the robes of the ancestral temples, which must be displayed in full and made bright. *Xuan* means complete; *ming* means radiant.

In this month, the trees are in full vigor; one must not dare to fell them. One may not assemble the feudal lords or initiate earthworks. To mobilize the masses or raise arms will surely bring heavenly calamity. *Yang* means punishment.

The earth is moist with summer heat, and great rains come in season. It is beneficial to kill weeds to fertilize the fields, enriching the soil and strengthening the boundaries. In this month of great heat, the earth is moist and the summer dampness heavy. There are also timely rains, which can be used to kill weeds for fertilizer, beautifying the soil and strengthening the fields. *Jiang* refers to the divisions of the land.

If in the final month of summer the commands of spring are enacted, the grain will split and fall, winds and coughs will abound, and the people will migrate. In spring, wood is in its ascendancy; the nature of wood is to shed and fall. When yang is released, winds are many. If its commands are enacted, the grain will split and fall, and the people will suffer from wind-borne illnesses, coughing and gasping for breath, resembling the scattering of spring yang. Thus, the people migrate.

If the commands of autumn are enacted, the hills and lowlands will flood, the crops will not ripen, and there will be many female calamities. *Qiu* means high; *xi* means low. This says that both high and low places will be flooded, thus killing the crops and preventing their ripening. When yin qi encounters disorder, there will be many female calamities. Female calamities refer to children not being raised.

If the commands of winter are enacted, the winds and cold will be untimely, hawks and falcons will strike early, and the people of the four borderlands will take refuge in walled settlements. In winter, yin is desolate and killing. If its commands are enacted, the cold winds will be unseasonable, hawks and falcons will strike early, and the people of the four frontiers will all enter the cities and towns to defend themselves.

The sixth month’s office is the *Shaonei*; its tree is the catalpa. In the sixth month, the crops ripen, hence the office of *Shaonei*. The catalpa’s significance is not yet known.

*Huainan Honglie Jie*, Scroll Nine, concludes.

*Huainan Honglie Jie*, Scroll Ten.
Presented by the Grandee Secretary and Libationer, your servant Xu Shen.

chunks.original_text: 时则训下 孟秋之月，招摇指申，昏斗中，旦毕中。 斗，北方玄武之宿，是日昏时中於南方。 毕，西方白虎之宿，是月平旦时中於南方也。 其位西方，其日庚辛，盛德在金，少皞之神治西方也。 庚辛，金也。 盛德在金，金王西方也。 其虫毛，其音商，金气寒，蠃者衣毛。 毛虫虎为之长。 商，金也，位在西方。 律中夷则，其数九，夷，伤也。 则，法也。 是月阳衰阴盛，万物凋伤，应法成性，故曰夷则也。 其数九，五行数五，金第四，故曰九也。 其味辛，其臭腥，金味辛也，金臭腥也。 其祀门，祭先肝。 孟秋始内，入由门，故祀门也。 肝，木也，祭祀之，用所胜也。 一曰，肝沈金，自用其藏也。 凉风至，白露降，寒蝉鸣，鹰乃祭鸟，用始行戮。 是月鹰搏鸷，杀鸟於大泽之中，四面陈之，世谓之祭鸟。 用是时，乃始行杀戮刑罚，顺秋气也。 天子衣白衣，乘白骆，服白玉，建白旗，白，顺金色也。 白马黑毛曰骆也。 食麻与犬，服八风水，爨柘燧火，西宫御女白色，衣白采，撞白锺，金王西，故处西宫也。 其兵戈，其畜狗，朝于总章左个，以出秋令。 总章，西向堂也。 西方总成万物而章明之，故曰总章。 左个，南头室也。 居是室，行是月之令。 狗，金畜也。 求不孝不悌、戮暴傲悍而罚之，以助损气。 损气，阴气。 立秋之日，天子亲率三公九卿大夫以迎秋于西郊。 西郊，（也）［九〕#1里之外郊也。 还，乃赏军率武人於朝。 军率，军将。
chunks.translated_text:
In the Seasonal Instructions for the Lesser Months:

In the first month of autumn, the stellar pointer *Zhaoyao* aligns with *Shen*. At dusk, the Dipper culminates; at dawn, the *Bi* asterism culminates. The Dipper is the northern constellation of the Dark Warrior, culminating at dusk in the southern sky this month. *Bi* is the western constellation of the White Tiger, culminating at dawn in the southern sky. Its position is the west; its days are *geng* and *xin*. The flourishing power resides in metal, and the deity Shaohao governs the west. *Geng* and *xin* correspond to metal. The flourishing power resides in metal, for metal rules the west. Its creatures are furred; its tone is *shang*. The qi of metal is cold, and armored creatures don fur. The tiger is the chief of furred creatures. *Shang* corresponds to metal, whose position is the west. The pitch standard is *Yize*. Its number is nine. *Yi* means "injury"; *ze* means "rule." This month, yang wanes and yin waxes, and the myriad things wither and suffer injury, conforming to the rule and completing their natures—hence *Yize*. Its number is nine, for in the five phases, metal is the fourth, and thus its number is nine. Its flavor is pungent; its odor is rank. Metal’s flavor is pungent; metal’s odor is rank. Its sacrifice is at the gate, and the liver is offered first. At the onset of early autumn, entry is made through the gate, hence the sacrifice at the gate. The liver corresponds to wood, and in sacrifice, the phase that metal conquers is used. Another saying: the liver sinks metal, employing its own organ. The cool wind arrives, white dew descends, the cold cicada sings, and the hawk begins to "sacrifice birds," commencing the execution of punishments. This month, hawks strike and kill birds in the great marshes, arranging them on all sides—this is called "sacrificing birds." From this time, the execution of punishments and penalties begins, aligning with the qi of autumn.

The Son of Heaven wears white robes, rides a white *luo* horse, adorns himself with white jade, raises a white banner, and white accords with the color of metal. A *luo* is a white horse with black mane. He eats hemp and dog, drinks the water of the eight winds, and cooks with fire from *zhe* wood. The consorts of the Western Palace wear white, dress in white hues, and strike the white bell. As metal rules the west, they reside in the Western Palace. Its weapon is the dagger-axe; its domestic animal is the dog. The court assembles at the *Zongzhang* hall’s left chamber to issue the autumnal commands. *Zongzhang* is the west-facing hall, where the myriad things are gathered and made manifest—hence *Zongzhang*. The left chamber is the southernmost room. From this chamber, the commands of the month are issued. The dog is the domestic animal of metal. Those who are unfilial, disobedient, violent, arrogant, or defiant are sought out and punished to assist the waning qi. The waning qi is yin qi.

On the day of the Beginning of Autumn, the Son of Heaven personally leads the Three Dukes, the Nine Ministers, and the grand masters to welcome autumn at the western suburbs. The western suburbs lie beyond the nine-*li* outer boundary. Upon returning, he rewards military leaders and warriors in the court. The *junshuai* are the generals.

chunks.original_text: 邑武，勇者功名也。 命将率，选卒厉兵，简练桀俊，专任有功，以征不义，请诛暴慢，顺彼四方。 顺，循也。 四方，天下也。 命有司，修法制，缮囹圄，禁奸塞邪，审决狱，平词讼。 决，断也。 平，治也。 天地始肃，不可以赢。 肃，杀也。 杀气始行也。 赢，盛也，故曰不可也。 是月农始升谷，天子尝新，先荐寝庙。 升，成。 荐，进也。 命百官，始收敛，孟秋始内也。 完堤防，谨障塞，以备水潦，修城郭，缮宫室，是月月丽于毕，俾滂沲矣，故备水潦也。 毋以封侯，立太官，行重币，出大使。 行是月令，凉风至三旬。 封侯，列土封邑也。 大官，九命之爵也。 重币，金帛之币也。 大使，命卿使之。 金气收敛，皆近不宜行也，故言毋也。 孟秋行冬令，则阴气大胜，介虫败谷，戎兵乃来。 孟秋，阴也，复行冬水王之令，故阴气胜也，其介虫败谷也。 阴气并，故戎兵来也。 行春令，则其国乃旱，阳气复还，五谷无实。 春阳亢燥，而行其令，故旱也。 阳气还者，此月凉风，而反行温风之令，故败谷，令无实也。 行夏令，则冬多火灾，寒暑不节，民多 疟疾。 夏火王，而行其令，故多火灾。 寒暑相干，故不节，使疟疾。 疟疾，寒暑所生也。 七月官库，其树楝。 库，兵府也。 秋节整兵，故官库也。 其树楝，楝实，凤凰所食也，今雒城旁有树。 楝实秋熟，故其树楝也。 楝，读练染之练也。 仲秋之月，招摇指酉，昏牵牛中，旦觜巂中。 牵牛，北方玄武之宿，是（月）#2月昏时中於南方。 觜巂，西方白虎之宿也，是月平旦时中於南方也。 其位西方，其日庚辛，其虫毛，其音商，律中南吕，其数九，南，任也。 言阳气吕旅而志助阴，阴任成万物也。 庚辛，金日也。 其味辛，其臭腥，其祀门，祭先肝。 凉风至，候雁来，，玄鸟归，群鸟翔。 候时之雁从北漠中来，过周、雒，南至彭蠡也。 玄鸟归，秋分后归蛰所也。 群鸟翔，寒气至，群鸟肥盛，试其羽翼而高翔。 翔者，六翮不动也。 或作养，养育其羽毛也。 天子衣白衣，乘白骆，服白玉，建白旗，食麻与犬，服八风水，爨柘燧火，西宫御女白色，衣白采，撞白锺，其兵戈，其畜犬，朝于总章太庙。 总章，西向堂也。 太庙中央室也。 命有司，申严百刑，斩杀必当，无或枉挠。 枉，曲也。 挠，弱也。 言平直也。 决狱不当，反受其殃。 反，还。 是月也，养长老，授几杖，行桴鬻饮食。 乃命宰祝，行牺牲，案刍豢，草养曰刍，谷养曰豢。 案其簿书阅租之。 豢，读宦学之宦。 视肥臞全粹，全，无亏缺也。 粹，毛色纯也。 粹，读祸祟之祟。 察物色，课比类，量小大，视少长，莫不中度。 天子乃傩，以御秋气。 傩，犹除也。 御，止也。 止秋气，不使为害也。 傩，读躁难之难。 气或作兵也。 以犬〔尝〕#3麻，先荐寝庙。 是月可以筑城郭，建都邑，国有先君之宗庙曰都，无曰邑。 都曰城，邑曰筑。 穿窦窖，修囷仓。 穿窦，所以通水，不欲地湿也。 穿窖，可以盛谷也。 窖读窖藏人物之窖也。 乃命有司，趣民收敛畜采，多积聚，劝种宿麦，若或失时，行罪无疑。 是月也，雷乃始收，蛰虫培户，杀气浸盛，阳气日衰，水始涸，涸，凝竭。 涸或作盛。 盛，言阴胜也。 日夜分。 一度量，平权衡，正钧石角斗称，理关市，来商旅，理，通也。
chunks.translated_text:
The martial in towns brings fame to the brave. The command is given to generals and officers to select soldiers, sharpen weapons, and train the most outstanding and capable, entrusting them to those with merit, to punish the unrighteous, seek out and execute the violent and insolent, and bring order to the four directions. *Shun* means to follow; the four directions are the world.

Officials are ordered to refine laws and systems, repair prisons, prohibit wickedness and block evil, carefully adjudicate cases, and settle disputes. *Jue* means to decide; *ping* means to govern.

Heaven and Earth begin their solemnity—excess must not be allowed. *Su* means killing; the killing *qi* begins to act. *Ying* means abundance, hence it is said that excess must not be allowed.

In this month, farmers begin to harvest grain, and the Son of Heaven tastes the new crop, first offering it to the ancestral temple. *Sheng* means completion; *jian* means to present.

The command is given to all officials to begin gathering and storing, for early autumn is the start of inward containment. Repair dikes and embankments, carefully fortify barriers and passes to prepare for floods; mend city walls and renovate palaces. In this month, the moon aligns with the *Bi* constellation, bringing heavy rains—hence the preparation for floods.

Do not enfeoff marquises, establish high offices, distribute valuable gifts, or dispatch grand envoys. In following this month’s commands, cool winds arrive within thirty days. *Feng hou* means granting land and enfeoffing towns. *Da guan* refers to the nine-rank nobility. *Zhong bi* are gifts of metal and silk. *Da shi* are envoys dispatched by high ministers. The *qi* of metal is contracting—none of these actions are suitable now, hence the prohibition.

If in early autumn the commands of winter are followed, *yin qi* will prevail excessively, armored insects will harm the grain, and hostile armies will arrive. Early autumn is *yin*, and if the dominant *qi* of winter water is enacted again, *yin qi* will dominate, and armored insects will damage the grain. As *yin qi* converges, hostile armies come.

If the commands of spring are followed, the land will suffer drought, *yang qi* will return, and the five grains will bear no fruit. Spring’s *yang* is scorching and dry, and enacting its commands will cause drought. *Yang qi* returning means that in this month, cool winds should prevail, yet warm winds are enacted instead—thus the grain is ruined and bears no fruit.

If the commands of summer are followed, winter will see many fires, cold and heat will be unregulated, and the people will suffer from malaria. Summer is ruled by fire, and enacting its commands will cause many fires. As cold and heat clash, they become unbalanced, leading to malaria. Malaria arises from cold and heat.

In the seventh month, the office is the armory, and its tree is the *lian*. The armory is the storehouse of weapons; as autumn’s season requires the ordering of arms, it is called the armory. Its tree is the *lian*, whose fruit is eaten by the phoenix—such trees still grow near Luoyang. The *lian* fruit ripens in autumn, hence its association. *Lian* is pronounced like the *lian* in dyeing and bleaching.

In the mid-autumn month, the *Zhaoyao* star points to *you*, the *Qianniu* constellation culminates at dusk, and the *ZiGui* culminates at dawn. *Qianniu* is the northern Dark Warrior constellation, which in this month culminates at dusk in the south. *ZiGui* is the western White Tiger constellation, which in this month culminates at dawn in the south.

Its position is the west, its days are *geng* and *xin*, its creatures are furred, its tone is *shang*, its pitch pipe is *Nanlü*, its number is nine, and the south is *ren*. This means the *yang qi* of *Nanlü* assists *yin*, and *yin* takes up the task of completing the myriad things. *Geng* and *xin* are the days of metal.

Its flavor is pungent, its scent is rank, its sacrifice is at the gate, and the liver is offered first. Cool winds arrive, the wild geese come, the swallows return, and flocks of birds soar. The seasonal geese come from the northern deserts, passing through Zhou and Luoyang to reach Pengli. The swallows return to their hibernation sites after the autumn equinox. The flocks of birds soar as the cold arrives, growing plump and testing their wings in high flight. *Xiang* means the six pinions do not move; some interpret it as *yang*, nurturing their feathers.

The Son of Heaven wears white robes, rides a white camel, adorns himself with white jade, raises a white banner, eats hemp and dog, drinks the water of the eight winds, and cooks with *zhe* fire. In the western palace, the consorts wear white, dress in white hues, and strike the white bells. Its weapons are spears and shields, its domestic animal is the dog, and court is held in the *Zongzhang* ancestral temple. *Zongzhang* is the west-facing hall; the ancestral temple is the central chamber.

Officials are ordered to strictly enforce all punishments, ensuring that executions are just and without distortion or leniency. *Wang* means crooked; *nao* means weak—this means to act with fairness and uprightness. If judgments are unjust, the misfortune will return to the judge. *Fan* means to return.

In this month, the elderly are cared for, provided with armrests and canes, and offered food and drink. The stewards and invocators are commanded to prepare sacrificial animals, inspecting the fodder-fed and grain-fed—those fed on grass are *chu*, and those fed on grain are *huan*. They review the records and examine the tributes. *Huan* is pronounced like the *huan* in "serving and learning." They inspect the animals’ fatness or leanness, wholeness, and purity—*quan* means without defect, and *cui* means the fur’s color is pure. *Cui* is pronounced like the *sui* in "misfortune."

They examine the creatures’ colors, compare their types, measure their sizes, and observe their ages, ensuring all meet the standards. The Son of Heaven then performs the *nuo* ritual to ward off autumn’s *qi*. *Nuo* means to expel; *yu* means to stop—stopping autumn’s *qi* to prevent harm. *Nuo* is pronounced like the *nan* in "restless difficulty." Some texts write *qi* as *bing* (weapons).

Hemp and dog are tasted and first offered to the ancestral temple. In this month, city walls and moats may be constructed, and capitals and towns established. A state with the ancestral temple of a former ruler is called a *du*; without, it is called a *yi*. *Du* are walled, and *yi* are built. Dig drainage channels and cellars, and repair granaries. *Chuan dou* are for water flow to prevent damp ground; *chuan jiao* are for storing grain. *Jiao* is pronounced like the *jiao* in "storing goods."

Officials are ordered to urge the people to gather and store, amass supplies, and encourage the planting of winter wheat. If the season is missed, punishment is certain without doubt.

In this month, thunder begins to withdraw, hibernating insects seal their burrows, killing *qi* grows increasingly strong, *yang qi* daily wanes, and waters begin to dry. *He* means to congeal and deplete; some texts write *he* as *sheng*, meaning *yin* prevails.

Day and night are equal. Standardize measurements, balance weights, correct steelyards and stone weights, adjust measuring vessels, regulate markets and customs, and welcome merchants and travelers. *Li* means to open and connect.

On the day of the Beginning of Autumn, the Son of Heaven personally leads the Three Dukes, the Nine Ministers, and the grand masters to welcome autumn at the western suburbs. The western suburbs lie beyond the nine-*li* outer boundary. Upon returning, he rewards military leaders and warriors in the court. The *junshuai* are the generals.

chunks.original_text: 入货财，以便民事。 四方来集，远方皆至，财物不匮，上无乏用，百事乃遂。 遂，成也。 仲秋行春令，则秋雨不降，草木生荣，国有大恐。 春阳气，而行其令，故雨不降。 又温煦之仁，故草木生荣华也。 气相干，必有灾咎，故国大惶恐。 行夏令，则其国乃旱，蛰虫不藏，五谷皆复生。 行炎阳之令，故旱涸。 气热，故蛰虫不藏，使五谷复生。 行冬令，则风灾数起，收雷先行，草木早死。 冬行寒气激之令，故有风灾。 又冬闭藏，故收雷先行，草木早死也。 八月官尉，其树柘，尉，戎官也。 是月治兵，故官尉。 传曰，羊舌大夫为中军尉柘，说未闻也。 季秋之月，招摇指戌，昏虚中，旦柳中。 虚，北方玄武之宿，是月昏时中於南方。 柳，南方朱雀之宿也，是月平旦中於南方也。 其位西方，其日庚辛，其虫毛，其音商，律中无射，阴气上升，阳气下降，万物随阳而藏，无射出见也。 其数九，其味辛，其臭腥，其祀门，祭先肝，侯雁来，宾雀入大水为蛤，是月时侯之雁从北漠中来，南之彭蠡。 盖以为八月〔来〕#4者，其父母也，是月来者，盖其子也。 羽翼稚弱，故在后耳。 宾雀者，老雀也，栖宿人家堂宇之间，如宾客者也，故谓之宾。 大水，海水也。 传曰，雀入海为蛤也。 菊有黄华，豺乃祭兽戮禽。 豺，似狗而长尾，其色黄。 是月时，豺杀兽，四面陈之，世谓之祭兽。 戮，犹杀也。 天子衣白衣，乘白骆，服白玉，建白旗，食麻与犬，服八风水，爨柘燧火，西宫御女白色，衣白采，撞白锺，其兵戈，其畜犬，朝于总章右令。 西向堂，北头室，故谓右个也。 命有司，申严号令，百官贵贱，无不务入，以会天地之藏，无有宣出。 乃命冢宰，农事备收，举五谷之要，冢，大也。 宰，治也。 卿，官也。 要，簿书也。 藏帝籍之收於神仓。 天子籍田千亩，故曰帝籍之收。 籍田所收之谷也。 神仓，仓也。 是月也，霜始降，百工休。 霜降天寒，朱漆难成，故百工休止，不复作器也。 乃命有司曰，寒气总至，民力不堪，其皆入室。 诗曰，入此室处是也。 上丁入学习吹，大飨帝，尝牺牲，合诸侯，制百县，是月上旬丁日，入学官，吹笙竽，习礼乐，飨上帝，用牺牲。 合诸侯之制，度车服之差，各（两）〔以〕#5其命数也。 百县，畿内之县，言百，举全数耳。 五家为邻，五邻为里，四里为郑，四郑为鄙，四鄙为县，然则县二千五百家也。 为来岁受朔日，与诸侯所税於民，轻重之法，贡岁之数，以远近土地所宜为度。 来岁，明年。 受朔日，如今计吏朝贺，豫明年之历日也。 度者，职贡多少有常也。 乃教於田猎，以习五戎。 戎，兵也。 刀、剑、予、戟、矢，故曰五戎也。 命太仆及七驺，咸驾戴荏，授车以级，皆正设于屏外。 级，等也。 授当车者以高下各随其等级。 正，立。 设，陈也。 天子外屏。 屏，树垣也。 尔雅曰，门内之垣谓之树垣者也。 司徒搢朴北向以赞之。 搢，插也。 朴，以教导也。 插置带间，赞相威仪也。 司徒主众，教导之也。 天子乃厉服广饰，执弓操矢以猎。 是月天子尚武，乃服猛厉之服，广其所佩之饰，以取禽也。 命主祠，祭禽四方。 命，教也。 主祠，典祀之官也。 祭禽四方，祀始设禽兽者於四方，报其功，不知其神所在，故博求之於四方也。
chunks.translated_text:
Gather goods and wealth to facilitate the people’s affairs. From all directions they come together, even from distant lands they arrive; resources are not lacking, the ruler has no shortage of supplies, and all matters thus come to fruition. *Fruition* means completion.

If in the mid-autumn month the spring command is enacted, autumn rains will not fall, grasses and trees will flourish, and the state will face great terror. Spring is the season of *yang qi*, and enacting its command prevents rain from descending. Moreover, the warmth and nurturing benevolence cause grasses and trees to bloom. When *qi* clash, disaster and misfortune must follow, hence the state is seized by great alarm.

If the summer command is enacted, the land will suffer drought, hibernating insects will not retreat into hiding, and the five grains will all sprout anew. Enacting the command of scorching *yang* brings drought. The heat causes hibernating insects to remain active and the five grains to regrow.

If the winter command is enacted, wind disasters will frequently arise, thunder will cease prematurely, and grasses and trees will die early. Enacting the command of cold *qi* provokes wind disasters. Moreover, winter is the season of closure and storage, so thunder withdraws early and grasses and trees perish prematurely.

In the eighth month, the office of the *Wei* is established, and the *zhe* tree is planted. *Wei* is the military official. This month is for training troops, hence the appointment of the *Wei*. As the saying goes, "The Yangshe Grand Master served as *Zhongjun Wei* of Zhe"—though the meaning of *zhe* remains unclear.

In the late autumn month, the *Zhaoyao* constellation points to *Xu*, the *Xu* constellation culminates at dusk, and the *Liu* constellation culminates at dawn. *Xu* is the northern constellation of the Dark Warrior; this month, it culminates in the southern sky at dusk. *Liu* is the southern constellation of the Vermilion Bird; this month, it culminates in the southern sky at dawn. Its position is the west, its days are *geng* and *xin*, its creatures are furred, its note is *shang*, and its pitch pipe is *Wuyi*. *Yin qi* ascends while *yang qi* descends, and all things follow *yang* into hiding—*Wuyi* emerges at this time. Its number is nine, its flavor is pungent, its odor is rank, its sacrifice is at the gate, and the liver is offered first in worship. The wild geese arrive as guests, and the guest sparrows enter the great waters to become clams.

This month, the geese come from the northern deserts, migrating south to Pengli. Those arriving in the eighth month are likely the parents, while those coming now are their offspring. Their wings are still tender and weak, so they follow behind. The *guest sparrows* are the elder sparrows that roost in the halls of human dwellings like guests, hence the name. The *great waters* refer to the sea. As the saying goes, "Sparrows enter the sea and become clams."

Chrysanthemums bloom with yellow flowers, and jackals offer beasts and slay birds. Jackals resemble dogs but have long tails and yellow fur. This month, they kill beasts and arrange them on all sides, a practice the world calls "offering beasts." *Slay* means to kill.

The Son of Heaven wears white robes, rides a white camel, adorns himself with white jade, raises a white banner, eats hemp and dog, drinks the water of the eight winds, and cooks with *zhe* fire. In the Western Palace, the consorts wear white, dress in white hues, and strike the white bell. Their weapon is the dagger-axe, their animal is the dog, and they hold court in the *Zongzhang* hall facing right. The right side of the hall faces west, and the northernmost chamber is called the right quarter.

Officials are ordered to enforce strict commands: all officials, high and low, must devote themselves to assisting in the storage of Heaven and Earth, allowing nothing to be released. The *Zhongzai* is then commanded to ensure the harvest is fully gathered, to compile the essential records of the five grains. *Zhong* means great, *zai* means to govern, and *qing* refers to the officials. *Essential* refers to the registers.

Store the harvest of the imperial fields in the divine granary. The Son of Heaven’s personal fields span a thousand *mu*, hence the term "imperial harvest." The grain from these fields is stored in the divine granary.

This month, frost begins to fall, and all artisans rest. With frost descending and the weather growing cold, red lacquer becomes difficult to apply, so all artisans cease work and no longer craft vessels.

Officials are then commanded: "The cold *qi* is fully arrived, and the people’s strength cannot endure it—let them all enter their homes." As the *Book of Songs* says, "Enter these chambers to dwell."

On the first *ding* day, students enter the academy to practice wind instruments. A grand sacrifice is offered to the Supreme Sovereign, and animal victims are tasted. The feudal lords are assembled, and the hundred counties are regulated. On the first *ding* day of the month’s first decade, students enter the academy to practice reed pipes and zithers, study ritual and music, sacrifice to the Supreme Sovereign with animal victims, and assemble the feudal lords to standardize the distinctions in carriages and robes, each according to their rank. The *hundred counties* refer to those within the royal domain; "hundred" is used to denote the whole.

Prepare for the coming year’s first day of the month, and determine the system of taxation for the feudal lords—its weight and measure, the annual tribute, and the standards based on the distance and suitability of the land. *Coming year* refers to the next year. *First day of the month* is like the modern practice of officials presenting the almanac for the coming year. *Standards* refer to the regularity of tribute and taxation.

Then instruct in the field hunt to practice the five weapons. *Weapons* refer to the blade, sword, spear, halberd, and arrow—hence the five weapons.

Command the Grand Coachman and the seven grooms to harness the *dairen* carriages, distribute them by rank, and arrange them properly outside the screen. *Rank* means grade; carriages are assigned according to the high or low status of their occupants. *Properly* means to stand them in place. *Arrange* means to set them in order. The Son of Heaven’s outer screen is a planted hedge. As the *Erya* says, "The hedge within the gate is called a planted hedge."

The Minister of Education, holding the staff, faces north to assist. *Holding* means to tuck it in. The staff is for instruction. Tucking it into the belt, he assists in the solemn ceremony. The Minister of Education oversees the masses and instructs them.

The Son of Heaven then dons fierce attire with grand adornments, takes up bow and arrow, and hunts. This month, the Son of Heaven values martial prowess, so he wears fierce and imposing garments with elaborate ornaments to capture game.

Command the master of sacrifices to offer beasts to the four directions. *Command* means to instruct. The *master of sacrifices* is the official in charge of rituals. Offering beasts to the four directions means sacrificing to the spirits who first set forth birds and beasts in the four directions, repaying their merit. Since their divine presence is unknown, offerings are broadly made to the four directions.

chunks.original_text: 是月草木黄落，乃伐薪为炭，蛰虫咸俛，乃趋狱刑，毋留有罪，俛，伏也。 青州为伏为俛也。 无留，言当断也。 收禄秩之不当，供养之不宜者。 不当，谓无德受禄也。 不宜，谓不孝也。 一曰所养者无勋於国，其先人又无贤德，所不宜养，故收也。 通路除道，从境始，至国而后已。 是月，天子乃以犬尝麻，先荐寝庙。 孝之至也。 季秋行夏令，则其国大水，冬藏殃败，民多鼽窒。 季秋阴气，而行夏月霖雨之令，故大水。 火气〔热〕#6故冬藏殃败也。 火金相干，故民鼽窒，鼻不通利也。 鼽，读怨仇之仇也。 行冬令，则国多盗贼，边境不宁，土地分裂。 冬水纯阴，奸谋所生，故多盗贼，使边境之民不安宁也。 则土地见侵削，为邻国所分裂也。 行春令，则暖风来至，民气解隋，师旅并兴。 春气阳温，故暖风至，民气解堕也。 木干金，故师旅并兴也。 二千五百人为师，五百人为旅也。 九月官候，其树槐。 侯，望也。 是月缮修守备，故曰官候也。 槐，怀也，可以怀来远人也。 孟冬之月，招摇指亥，昏危中，旦七星中。 危，北方玄武之宿也，是月昏时中於南方。 七星，南方朱鸟之宿也，是月平旦时中於南方者也。 其位北方，其日壬癸，盛德在水，颛顼之神治北方也。 壬癸，水日也。 盛德在水，王北方也。 其虫介，其音羽，介，甲也。 像冬闭固，皮漫胡也。 甲虫，龟为之长。 羽，属水也。 律中应锺，其数六，阴应於阳，转成其功，万物聚成，故曰应锺。 其数六，五行数五，水第一，故曰六也。 其味咸，其臭腐，水味咸也，水臭腐也。 其祀，祭先肾。 井水给人，故祀也。 井或作行。 门内地。 冬守在内，故祀也。 肾，水，自开其藏也。 水始冰，地始冻，雉入大水为蜃，虹藏不见。 蜃，蛤也。 大水，淮也。 传曰，雉入于淮为蜃。 虹，阴中之阳也。 是月阴盛，故不见也。 天子衣黑衣，乘玄骊，服玄玉，建玄旗，顺水德也。 熊与虎曰旗也。 食黍彘贪，服八风水，爨松燧火，北宫御女黑色，衣黑采，击磬石，水王北方，故处北宫也。 其兵锻，其畜彘，锻者却内，像阴闭。 彘，水畜。 朝于玄堂左个，以出冬令。 北向堂，西头室，故曰左个。 居是室，行此月令也。 命有司，修群禁，顺阴闭，诸所当禁，皆使有司禁也。 禁外徙，闭门闾，大搜客，传曰，禁旧客，为露情也，有新客，搜出之，为观衅也。 门，城门也。 闾，里门也。 严闭之，守备也。 断罚刑，杀当罪，诸罚刑当决也。 当罚正罪，故杀之也。 阿上乱法者诛。 阿意曲从，取容於上，以乱法度也。 诛，洽也。 立冬之日，天子亲率三公九卿大夫以迎岁于北郊。 还，乃赏死事，存孤寡。 有忠节蹈义死王事者，赏其子孙也。 幼无父曰孤，无夫曰寡，皆存慰矜恤之。 是月，命太祝祷祀神位，占龟策，审卦兆，以察吉凶。 於是天子始裘，命百官谨盖藏，命司徒行积聚，修城郭，警门闾，修枪闭，慎管钥，固封玺，封，门也。 玺，印也。 修边境，完要塞，绝蹊径，饰丧纪，审棺椁衣衾之薄厚，饰，治也。 纪，数也。 二十五月之数也。 棺椁衣衾薄厚各有差等，故审之。 营丘垄之小大高庳，使贵贱卑尊各有等级。 营，度也。 丘垄，冢也。 小大高下各有度量也。 是月也，工师效功，陈祭器，案度呈，坚致为上。
chunks.translated_text:
This month, grasses and trees yellow and shed their leaves. Thus, one fells timber to make charcoal. Hibernating creatures all crouch low, so one hastens to prisons and punishments, leaving no guilty party detained. *Crouch* means to lie concealed. In Qingzhou, *crouch* is pronounced as *俛*. *Leaving none detained* means judgments must be swift. One also reclaims salaries and emoluments from those unworthy of them, as well as support from those undeserving of sustenance. *Unworthy* refers to those without virtue who receive emoluments. *Undeserving* refers to the unfilial. Another interpretation: those supported have rendered no merit to the state, and their ancestors possessed no worthy virtue, so their support is deemed improper and thus revoked.

Roads are cleared and paths repaired, beginning at the borders and concluding within the capital. This month, the Son of Heaven samples hemp with dog meat, first offering it to the ancestral temple. This is the height of filial piety.

If in late autumn one implements summer ordinances, the state will suffer great floods, winter stores will be ruined, and the people will frequently suffer from nasal congestion and obstruction. Late autumn is a time of yin qi, yet if one enforces the summer’s ceaseless rains, floods will ensue. Fire qi (heat) disrupts winter storage, causing ruin. Fire and metal clash, so the people suffer nasal congestion—*鼽* is pronounced like *仇* (enmity). If one implements winter ordinances, the state will see many thieves and bandits, borders will be unsettled, and lands will be divided. Winter’s water is pure yin, breeding treacherous schemes, hence the proliferation of thieves and bandits, unsettling borderlands. Lands will be encroached upon and partitioned by neighboring states. If one implements spring ordinances, warm winds will arrive, the people’s qi will slacken, and armies will be mobilized. Spring’s yang qi is warm, so warm winds come, and the people’s qi grows lax. Wood invades metal, so armies are raised—2,500 men form a *division*, and 500 a *brigade*.

In the ninth month, the office of observation is established, and the tree is the locust. *Observation* means to watch. This month, defenses are repaired, hence the office of observation. The locust tree (*槐*) is associated with *embracing* (*怀*), for it can draw distant people near.

In the first month of winter, the *Diurnal Revolving Star* points to *Hai*, the *Rooftop* constellation culminates at dusk, and the *Seven Stars* culminate at dawn. *Rooftop* is a constellation of the northern Dark Warrior; this month, it culminates in the south at dusk. The *Seven Stars* are a constellation of the southern Vermilion Bird; this month, they culminate in the south at dawn. Its position is the north, its days are *Ren* and *Gui*, its supreme power resides in water, and the spirit Zhuanxu governs the north. *Ren* and *Gui* are water days. *Supreme power resides in water* means water rules the north. Its creatures are armored, its tone is *yu*, and *armored* refers to shells, symbolizing winter’s closure and solidity. The turtle is the chief of armored creatures. *Yu* pertains to water. The pitch pipe *Yingzhong* is in harmony, its number is six. Yin responds to yang, completing its work; all things gather and mature, hence *Yingzhong* (Responsive Bell). Its number is six because the five phases number five, and water is first, thus six. Its flavor is salty, its odor is putrid—water’s flavor is salty, and its odor is putrid. Its sacrifice is to the kidneys. Well water sustains people, hence its veneration. *Well* may also be written as *path*. The earth within gates is also venerated. Winter’s guard is within, hence its veneration. The kidneys pertain to water, opening their storehouse.

This month, ice begins to form, the earth starts to freeze, pheasants enter great waters and become clams, and rainbows hide from sight. *Clams* are bivalves. *Great waters* refer to the Huai River. Tradition states: "Pheasants entering the Huai become clams." Rainbows are yang within yin. This month, yin prevails, so they are not seen.

The Son of Heaven wears black robes, rides a dark steed, adorns himself with black jade, raises a black banner, and aligns with the power of water. Banners depict bears and tigers. He eats glutinous millet and pig, imbibes the eight winds’ water, cooks with pine and fir, and resides in the northern palace. The palace’s attendants wear black, dress in black hues, and strike sounding stones. Water rules the north, hence the northern palace. His weapons are forged, his livestock are pigs—forging retracts inward, symbolizing yin’s closure. Pigs are water’s creatures.

He holds court in the left chamber of the Black Hall to issue winter’s ordinances. The hall faces north, and the western chamber is called the *left chamber*. Residing here, he enacts this month’s decrees. He commands officials to enforce all prohibitions, aligning with yin’s closure. All that should be forbidden is entrusted to officials for enforcement. Migration is prohibited, gates and lanes are sealed, and guests are thoroughly searched. Tradition states: "Old guests are forbidden to reveal secrets; new guests are searched to observe their intentions." *Gates* are city gates; *lanes* are neighborhood gates. These are strictly sealed for defense. Punishments are meted out, and the guilty are executed—all due punishments are decided. Those deserving punishment are rightly condemned, hence executed. Those who flatter superiors and disrupt the law are punished. *Flattery* means currying favor with superiors to disrupt law and order. *Punished* means corrected.

On the day of the Beginning of Winter, the Son of Heaven personally leads the Three Dukes, Nine Ministers, and high officials to welcome the year at the northern suburbs. Upon returning, he rewards those who died in service and provides for orphans and widows. Those who died in loyal service to the state are honored by rewarding their descendants. *Orphans* are fatherless children; *widows* are husbandless women—both are comforted and relieved. This month, he commands the Grand Invocator to pray and sacrifice to the spirits, divine with tortoise and milfoil, and scrutinize hexagrams and omens to discern fortune and misfortune.

Now the Son of Heaven dons furs. He commands all officials to securely store provisions, orders the Minister of Education to gather supplies, repair city walls, fortify gates and lanes, mend weapons and locks, secure keys and seals—*seals* are doors, and *seals* are stamps. Borders are reinforced, strategic passes are fortified, footpaths are blocked, and mourning rites are prepared. Coffins, outer coffins, grave clothes, and shrouds are examined for their proper thickness. *Prepared* means arranged; *rites* refer to the twenty-five-month mourning period. Coffins, outer coffins, grave clothes, and shrouds vary in thickness by rank, hence their scrutiny. Graves and mounds are measured for size and height, ensuring nobles and commoners, high and low, each have their proper degree. *Measured* means assessed; *graves and mounds* are tombs, with size and height varying by rank.

This month, artisans present their works, ritual vessels are displayed, standards are reviewed, and firmness and precision are prized.

ss, so he wears fierce and imposing garments with elaborate ornaments to capture game.

Command the master of sacrifices to offer beasts to the four directions. *Command* means to instruct. The *master of sacrifices* is the official in charge of rituals. Offering beasts to the four directions means sacrificing to the spirits who first set forth birds and beasts in the four directions, repaying their merit. Since their divine presence is unknown, offerings are broadly made to the four directions.

chunks.original_text: 案，视也。 度，法也。 坚致，功牢也。 为，故也。 上，盛也。 工事苦慢，作为淫巧，必行其罪。 苦，恶也。 慢，不牢也。 淫巧、非常之巧也。 故行其罪。 苦，谓盐会之盐也。 是月也，大饮蒸，天子祈来年於天宗，蒸，冬祭也。 於是时，大饮酒而祭，求明年之福祥也。 凡属天子之神，日月星辰皆为天宗也。 大祷祭于公社，毕，飨先祖。 祷，求也。 公社也，后土之祭也。 生为上公，死为贵神，故曰公也。 毕，飨先祖，先公后私之义也。 劳农夫，以休息之。 命将率讲武，律射御，角力劲。 律，习也。 角，平地也。 劲，强貌也。 乃命水虞渔师，收水泉池泽之赋，虞，掌水官也。 师，长也。 赋，税也。 毋或侵牟。 牟，多。
chunks.translated_text:
Reviewing the standards is *inspection*; *standards* are models. *Firm and precise* means sturdy craftsmanship. *For* signifies *therefore*; *supreme* means *abundant*. If artisans’ work is shoddy or careless, or their creations excessively ornate, they shall surely be punished. *Shoddy* means poor; *careless* means unsteady. *Excessively ornate* refers to craft beyond the proper measure. Therefore, they shall be punished. *Shoddy* here denotes salt that has caked.

This month, the great steaming sacrifice is held. The Son of Heaven prays to the Celestial Honored Ones for the coming year. *Steaming* is the winter sacrifice. At this time, great feasts of wine are held while offering sacrifices to seek blessings for the next year. All celestial deities belonging to the Son of Heaven—sun, moon, and stars—are called the Celestial Honored Ones. Grand supplications are made at the public altar to the earth, and upon completion, ancestors are feasted. *Supplication* means to entreat. The *public altar* is the sacrifice to the Queen of Earth. In life, she is the highest duke; in death, a revered spirit—hence called *duke*. *Completion* refers to feasting ancestors, observing the principle of honoring the public before the private.

The toiling farmers are granted rest. Commanders and generals drill troops in martial arts, practicing archery and charioteering, and testing strength in wrestling. *Drill* means to practice; *wrestling* takes place on level ground. *Strength* describes vigor. Then the Water Stewards and Fishery Masters are ordered to collect taxes from springs, pools, and marshes. *Stewards* are officials in charge of water; *masters* are leaders. *Taxes* are levies. Let none encroach or overreach. *Overreach* means excess.

chunks.original_text: 孟冬行春令，则冻闭不密，地气发泄，民多流亡。 春阳气散越，故冻闭不密，地气发泄也。 民多流亡，像阳气布散。 行夏令，则多暴风，方冬不寒，蛰虫复出。 冬当闭藏，反行夏盛肠之令，故多暴疾。 阳气温，故盛冬不寒，令蛰伏之虫复出也。 行秋令，则雪霜不时，小兵时起，土地侵削。 秋气干冬，大寒不当雪而雪，不当霜而霜，故曰时也。 小兵数起，邻国来伐，侵削其土地。 十月官司马，其树檀。 冬间讲武，故官司马也。 檀，阴木也。 仲冬之月，招摇指子，昏壁中，旦轸中。 东壁，北方玄武之宿，是月昏时中於南方。 轸，南方朱鸟之宿，是月平旦时中於南方也。 其位北方，其日壬癸，其虫介，其音羽，律中黄锺，其数六，黄锺者，阳气聚於下，阴气盛於上，万物黄，萌於地中，故曰黄锺也。 其味咸，其臭腐，其祀井，祭先肾。 水益壮，地始坼，鳱鴡不鸣，虎始交。 鳱鴡，山乌。 （阳）#7是月阴盛，故不鸣也。 虎，阳中之阴也，阴气盛，以类发也。 交，读将校之校也。 天子衣黑衣，乘铁骊，服玄玉，建玄旗，食黍与彘，服八风水，爨松燧火，北宫御女黑色，衣黑采，击磬石，其兵锻，其畜彘，朝于玄堂太庙。 北向堂，中央室，故曰太庙也。 命有司曰，土事无作，无发室居，及起大众，是谓发天地之藏，诸蛰则死，民必疾疫，有随以丧。 急捕盗贼，诛淫泆诈伪之人，命曰畼月。 阴气在上，民人空间，故命曰畼月。 命奄尹，申宫令，奄，官也。 尹，正也。 申宫令，重戒敕也。 审门（门）〔闾〕#8，谨房室，必重闭，助阴气也。 省妇事。 乃命大酋，秫稻必齐，麴蘗必时，酋，主沽酒官也。 酝酿米麴，使化熟，故谓之酋。 酋读酋豪之酋，齐读齐和之齐也。 作麴蘗当得其时，不时则不成也。 湛熺必洁，水泉必香，湛，渍也。 熺炊必令圭洁也。 水泉（者）［香〕#9则酒善也，湛，读审釜之审。 熺，炊炽火之炽也。 陶器必良，火齐必得，无有差忒。 陶器，瓦器也。 炊享必得其适，故曰无有差忒也。 天子乃命有司，祀四海大川名泽。 能兴云雨，故祀之也。 是月也，农有不收藏积聚，牛马畜兽有放失者，取之不诘。 诘，呵问也。 山林薮泽，有能取疏食，田猎禽兽者，野虞教导之。 其有相侵夺，罪之不赦。 大加刑也。
chunks.translated_text:
If in early winter the seasonal decree of spring is enacted, then the frost’s closure will not be tight, the earth’s qi will leak forth, and the people will scatter in great numbers. For spring’s yang qi disperses and overflows—hence the frost’s closure is not tight and the earth’s qi leaks forth. The people scatter in great numbers, resembling the spreading of yang qi.

If the seasonal decree of summer is enacted, then violent winds will arise frequently, midwinter will lack cold, and hibernating creatures will emerge again. Winter should be a time of closure and storage; instead, the decree of summer’s flourishing is enacted—hence violent winds arise frequently. The warmth of yang qi ensures that even in the depths of winter there is no cold, causing hibernating creatures to emerge again.

If the seasonal decree of autumn is enacted, then snow and frost will fall untimely, minor conflicts will frequently arise, and the land will be encroached upon and diminished. Autumn’s qi is dry, and winter’s great cold should not bring snow or frost—yet they fall, hence they are untimely. Minor conflicts arise repeatedly, neighboring states invade and seize the land.

In the tenth month, the office of the Minister of War is in charge, and its tree is the sandalwood. Winter is the season for martial training, hence the office of the Minister of War. Sandalwood is a yin wood.

In the month of mid-winter, the Dipper’s handle points to the *zi* position, the *Bi* constellation culminates at dusk, and the *Zhen* constellation culminates at dawn. The Eastern Wall is the northern quadrant’s Dark Warrior constellation; this month it culminates in the south at dusk. *Zhen* is the southern quadrant’s Vermilion Bird constellation; this month it culminates in the south at dawn. Its position is the north, its days are *ren* and *gui*, its creatures are armored, its tone is *yu*, its pitch pipe is the Yellow Bell, and its number is six. The Yellow Bell signifies yang qi gathering below and yin qi flourishing above, with all things yellow and sprouting within the earth—hence it is called the Yellow Bell. Its flavor is salty, its odor is putrid, its sacrifice is to the well, and the kidneys are offered first.

Water grows stronger, the earth begins to crack, the *guān* and *jū* birds fall silent, and tigers begin to mate. The *guān* and *jū* are mountain birds. In this month, yin prevails, hence they fall silent. The tiger is yin within yang; with yin qi flourishing, it responds in kind. *Mate* is read as the *xiao* in *jiangxiao* (general).

The Son of Heaven wears black robes, rides a black-maned iron-black horse, adorns himself with dark jade, raises a black banner, eats millet and swine, drinks the water of the eight winds, and cooks with pine and fire-drill flames. In the northern palace, the consorts wear black, dress in black hues, and strike the sounding stone. Their weapon is the forged blade, their beast is the swine, and they hold court in the Dark Hall of the Grand Ancestral Temple. The hall faces north, the chamber lies at the center—hence it is called the Grand Ancestral Temple.

He commands the officials, saying: “Let no earthworks be undertaken, no dwellings opened, nor great assemblies gathered. This is called ‘opening the treasures of heaven and earth.’ All hibernating creatures will die, the people will surely suffer epidemics, and some will follow in death.”

Swiftly capture thieves and bandits, and execute those who are licentious, deceitful, or fraudulent. This month is called the *Chang* month. With yin qi above, the people are empty and idle—hence it is called the *Chang* month.

He commands the Intendant of the Palace Eunuchs to reiterate the palace decrees. *Yan* is the office; *yin* is the director. Reiterating the palace decrees means to issue stern warnings. Inspect the gates and lanes, secure the chambers, and ensure all are tightly sealed to assist the yin qi. Reduce the tasks of women.

Then he commands the Grand Brewer: the glutinous and non-glutinous rice must be uniform, the yeast and malt must be timely. The *qiú* is the official in charge of brewing. Fermenting the grains and yeast to maturity—hence he is called *qiú*. *Qiú* is read as the *qiú* in *qiúháo* (chieftain); *uniform* is read as the *qí* in *qíhé* (harmony). The yeast and malt must be made at the proper time; if untimely, they will not succeed. The steeping and steaming must be pure, the water and springs must be fragrant. *Zhàn* means to soak; the steaming must be immaculate. If the water and springs are fragrant, the wine will be excellent. *Zhàn* is read as the *shěn* in *shěnfǔ* (to examine a cauldron); *xī* is read as the *chì* in *chìhuǒ* (blazing fire).

The pottery must be fine, the firing temperature must be precise, with no deviations. The pottery refers to earthenware. The cooking and offering must be appropriate—hence it is said there should be no deviations.

The Son of Heaven then commands the officials to sacrifice to the four seas, great rivers, famous lakes, and marshes. They can summon clouds and rain—hence they are sacrificed to.

In this month, if farmers have not gathered and stored their harvests, or if cattle, horses, livestock, or wild animals have been lost or released, they may be taken without reproach. *Reproach* means to question or interrogate.

In the mountains, forests, marshes, and wetlands, those who gather wild foods or hunt birds and beasts are instructed and guided by the Wild Stewards. If there is any encroachment or seizure, the offenders are punished without pardon. Severe penalties are imposed.
