chunks.original_text: 精神训 精者，人之气，神者，人之守也。 本其原，说其意，故曰精神，因以题篇。 古未有天地之时，惟像无形，惟，思也。 念天地未成形之时无有形。 生有形，故天地成焉。 窈窈冥冥，芒芠漠闵，澒蒙鸿洞，莫知其门。 皆未成形之气也。 芒，读玉莽之莽也。 芠，读□灭之□。 闵，读〔闵〕#1子骞之闵。 澒，言项羽之项。 鸿，读子赣之赣。 洞，读同游之同也。 皆无之象，故曰莫知其门也。 有二神混生，经天营地，二神，阴阳之神也。 混生，俱生也。 孔乎莫知其所终极，孔，深貌也。 滔乎莫知其所止息，滔，大貌也。 於是乃别为阴阳，离为八极，刚柔相成，万物乃形，离，散也。 八极，八方之极。 刚柔，阴阳也。 烦气为虫，烦，乱。 精气为人。 是故精神，天之有也，而骨骸者，地之有也。 精神入其门，而。 骨骸反其根，精神无形，故能入天门。 骨骸有形，故反其根，归土也。 我尚何存？ 言人死各有所归，我何犹常存。 是故圣人法天顺情，不拘於俗，不诱於人，诱，犹惑也。 以天为父，以地为母，阴阳为纲，四时为纪。 天静以清，地定以宁，万物失之者死，法之者生。 夫静漠者，神明之宅也，虚无者，道之所居也。 是故或求之於外者，失之於内，有守之於内者，失之於外。 譬犹本与末也，从本引之，千枝万叶莫不随也。 夫精神者，所受於天也，而形体者，所禀於地也。 故曰，一生二，二生三，三生万物。 一谓道也，二曰神明也，三曰和气也。 或说一者，元气也，生二者，乾坤也； 二生三，三生万物。 天地设位，阴阳通流，万物乃生。 万物背阴而抱阳，冲气以为和。 万物以背为阴，以腹为阳，身中空虚，和气所行。 为阴，故肾双，为阳，故心特。 阴阳与和，共生物形； 君臣以和致太平也。 故曰一月而膏，始育如膏也。 二月而胅，三月而胎，四月而肌，五月而筋，六月而骨，七月而成，八月而动，九月而躁，十月而生。 形体以成，五藏乃形，是故肺主目，肺象朱雀，朱雀，火也。 火外景，故主目也。 肾主鼻，肾象龟，龟，水也，水所以通沟也，鼻所以通气也，故主鼻也。 胆主口，胆，勇者决所以处，故主口也。 肝主耳。 肝，金也，金内景，故主耳也。 外为表而内为裹，开闭张歙，各有经纪。 歙，读胁也。 故头之圆也象天，足之方也象地，有四时、五行、九解、四时，春夏秋冬也。 五行，金木水火土也。 九解，谓九十为一解也。 一说，九解六一之所解合也。 一说，八方中央故曰九解也。 三百六十六日，人亦有四支，五藏，九窍，三百六十六节。 天有风雨寒暑，人亦有取与喜怒。 故胆为云，胆，金也，金石，云之所出故为云。 肺为气，肺，火也，故为气。 肝为风，肝，木也，木为风生，故为风。 肾为雨，肾，水也，因水故雨。 雨或作电。 肾，水也，水为光，故为电。 脾为雷，以与天地相参也，而心为之主。 心，土也，故为四行之主也。 是故耳目者日月也，血气者风雨也，日中有蹲乌，踆，犹蹲也，谓三足乌。 踆读踆魏之踆。 而月中有蟾蜍。 蟾蜍，虾蟆。 日月失其行，薄蚀无光，薄者，迫也。 薄，读享薄之薄也。 风雨非其时，毁折生灾； 五星失其行，州国受殃。 五星，荧惑、太白、岁星、辰星、镇星也。
chunks.translated_text:
**The Training of Essence and Spirit**

Essence is the qi of humanity; spirit is the guardian of humanity. Tracing to its origin and expounding its meaning, it is thus called "essence and spirit," and so the chapter is titled.

In the time before Heaven and Earth existed, there was only formlessness—*wei* means "to ponder." It speaks of the time before Heaven and Earth took shape, when there was no form. Once form arose, Heaven and Earth were completed.

Vast and obscure, boundless and indistinct, murky and expansive—none knew its gate. All were the qi of unformed chaos. *Mang* is read as the *mang* in "jade wilderness"; *weng* is read as [the missing character] in "[missing] extinction"; *min* is read as the *min* in "Min Ziqian"; *hong* is read as the *xiang* in "Zi Gong"; *dong* is read as the *tong* in "traveling together." All are images of nothingness, hence it is said none knew its gate.

Two spirits emerged in primordial union, traversing Heaven and ordering Earth. These two spirits are the deities of yin and yang. "Mixed birth" means they arose together. Profound and fathomless, none knew their ultimate end; vast and boundless, none knew where they would cease. *Kong* describes depth; *tao* describes greatness.

Thereupon they separated into yin and yang, dispersed into the eight directions, and through the interplay of hardness and softness, the myriad things took shape. *Li* means "to scatter"; the eight directions are the extremities of the eight poles. Hardness and softness are yin and yang.

Disordered qi became insects; refined qi became humans. Thus, essence and spirit belong to Heaven, while bones and flesh belong to Earth. Essence and spirit enter their gate, while bones and flesh return to their root. Essence and spirit are formless, so they can enter the gate of Heaven; bones and flesh are formed, so they return to their root and revert to earth. What then remains of me? It means that when humans die, each returns to its place—how can I alone endure?

Therefore, the sage models himself on Heaven and follows nature, unbound by custom or swayed by others. *You* means "to be deluded." He takes Heaven as his father and Earth as his mother, yin and yang as his warp, and the four seasons as his weft. Heaven is still and clear; Earth is settled and tranquil. The myriad things perish when they lose this, and live when they emulate it.

Stillness and silence are the abode of spirit and clarity; emptiness and nothingness are where the Dao resides. Thus, those who seek it externally lose it internally, while those who guard it internally lose it externally. It is like the root and the branches: if you draw from the root, the thousand branches and ten thousand leaves will follow without fail.

Essence and spirit are what one receives from Heaven, while form and body are what one is endowed with from Earth. Thus it is said: "One gives rise to two, two gives rise to three, and three gives rise to the myriad things." One refers to the Dao; two refers to spirit and clarity; three refers to harmonious qi. Another interpretation: one is primordial qi; two are Qian and Kun; two give rise to three, and three give rise to the myriad things. Heaven and Earth take their positions, yin and yang flow freely, and the myriad things are born. The myriad things turn their backs to yin and embrace yang, with harmonious qi as their mediator. They turn their backs (the spine) to yin and their bellies to yang; the hollow within the body is where harmonious qi circulates.

Yin is why the kidneys are paired; yang is why the heart stands alone. Yin, yang, and harmony together generate physical form—just as ruler and minister achieve great peace through harmony. Thus, in the first month, it is like cream, beginning to nurture; in the second month, it takes shape; in the third, it becomes an embryo; in the fourth, flesh forms; in the fifth, sinews develop; in the sixth, bones harden; in the seventh, it is complete; in the eighth, it stirs; in the ninth, it becomes restless; in the tenth, it is born. Once the body is formed, the five viscera take shape.

Thus, the lungs govern the eyes—the lungs resemble the Vermilion Bird, and the Vermilion Bird is fire. Fire manifests externally, hence it governs the eyes. The kidneys govern the nose—the kidneys resemble the tortoise, and the tortoise is water. Water flows through channels, just as the nose conducts qi, hence it governs the nose. The gallbladder governs the mouth—the gallbladder is where the brave make decisions, hence it governs the mouth. The liver governs the ears—the liver is metal, and metal manifests internally, hence it governs the ears.

The exterior serves as the surface, while the interior serves as the wrapping; opening and closing, expanding and contracting, each follows its own order. *Xi* is read as "flank."

Thus, the roundness of the head resembles Heaven, and the squareness of the feet resembles Earth. There are the four seasons, the five phases, the nine divisions, and the three hundred sixty-six days. The four seasons are spring, summer, autumn, and winter; the five phases are metal, wood, water, fire, and earth. The nine divisions refer to the nine tens making one division. Another interpretation: the nine divisions are the six ones that combine and divide. Another interpretation: the eight directions and the center make nine divisions. The year has three hundred sixty-six days, and humans likewise have four limbs, five viscera, nine orifices, and three hundred sixty-six joints.

Heaven has wind, rain, cold, and heat, and humans likewise have taking and giving, joy and anger. Thus, the gallbladder becomes clouds—the gallbladder is metal, and metal and stone give rise to clouds, hence it becomes clouds. The lungs become qi—the lungs are fire, hence they become qi. The liver becomes wind—the liver is wood, and wood generates wind, hence it becomes wind. The kidneys become rain—the kidneys are water, and water gives rise to rain. (Another reading: rain or lightning. The kidneys are water, and water generates light, hence they become lightning.) The spleen becomes thunder, aligning with Heaven and Earth, while the heart governs them. The heart is earth, hence it governs the four phases.

Thus, the ears and eyes are the sun and moon, and blood and qi are wind and rain. Within the sun is the crouching crow (*cun* means "to crouch," referring to the three-legged crow); *cun* is read as in "Cun Wei." Within the moon is the toad—the toad is a frog. When the sun and moon lose their course, they are eclipsed and dimmed; *bo* means "to press close." *Bo* is read as in "offering meagerly." When wind and rain come unseasonably, they destroy and break, causing disasters. When the five stars lose their course, the states and regions suffer calamity. The five stars are Mars, Venus, Jupiter, Mercury, and Saturn.

chunks.original_text: 今荧犯角、亢，则州国受其殃（他）〔也］#2，余准此也。 夫天地之道，至弦以大，尚犹节其章光，爱其神明，人之耳目曷能久熏劳而不息乎？ 息，止。 精神何能久驰骋而不既乎？ 既，尽。 是故（面）［血〕#3气者，人之华也； 而五藏者，人之精也。 夫（面）［血〕#4气能专于五藏专，一。 而不外越，则胸腹充而嗜欲省矣。 胸腹充而嗜欲省，则耳目清，听视达矣。 耳目清，听视达，谓之明。 五藏能属於心而无乖，则志胜而行不僻矣。 志胜，言己之教志也。 僻，邪也。 胜或作逐。 言教或迟去，故行正而不邪也。 志胜而行之不僻，则精神盛而气不散矣。 精神盛而气不散则理，理则均，均则通，通则神，神则以视无不见，以听无不闻也，以为无不成也。 是故忧患不能入也，而邪气不能袭。 袭，犹因也，亦入。 故事有求之於四海之外而不能遇，遇，得。 或守之於形骸之内心无欲也。 而不见也。 故所求多者所得少，所见大者所知小。 夫孔窍者，精神之户牖也； 而气志者，五藏之使候也。 耳目淫於声色之乐，则五藏摇动而不定矣。 五藏摇动而不定，则血气滔荡而不休矣。 血气滔荡而不休，则精神驰骋於外而不守矣。 多情欲，故神不内守。 精神驰骋於外而不守，则祸福之至，虽如丘山，无由识之矣。 丘山谕大。 识，知也。 使耳目精明玄达而无诱慕，气志虚静恬愉而省嗜欲，五藏定宁充盈而不泄，精神内守形骸而不外越，则望於往世之前，而视於来事之后，犹未足为也，犹，尚也。 为，治也。 岂直祸福之间哉。 故曰，其出弥远者，其知弥少。 言虽知道，故少。 以言夫精神之不可使外淫也。 是故五色乱目，使目不明，不明，视而昏也。 五声哗耳，使耳不聪，不聪，听无闻也。 五味乱口，使口爽伤，爽，病。 病伤滋味也。 趣舍滑心，使行飞扬。 滑，乱也。 飞扬，不从轨度也。 此四者，天下之所养性也，性，生也。 然皆人累也。 故曰，嗜欲者，使人之气越，越，失。 而好憎者，使人之心劳，劳，病。 弗疾去，则志气日耗。 耗，犹乱也。 夫人之所以不能终其寿命而中道夭於刑戮者，何也？ 以其生生之厚。 言生生之厚者，何必极嗜欲，淫滥无厌，以伤耳目情性，故不终其寿命，中道夭殒於飞辟之戮也。 夫惟能无以生为者，则所以修得生也。 无以生为者，轻利害之乡，除情性之欲，则长得生矣。 夫天地运而相通，万物总而为一。 总，合也。 一，同也。 万物合同，统於一道。 能知一，则无一之不知也； 上一，道也。 下一，物也。 不能知一，则无一之能知也。 譬吾处於天下也，亦为一物矣。 不识天下之以我备其物与，与，邪，辞也。 且惟无我而物无不备者乎？ 然则我亦物也，物亦物也，物之与物也，有何以相物也？ 物亦物也，何相名为物也。 虽然，其生我也，将以何益？ 言生我，自然之道，亦当以何益乎。 其杀我也，将以何损？ 损，减。 夫造化者既以我为坯矣，将无所违之矣。 言既以我为人，无所离之。 谕不求亦不避也。
chunks.translated_text:
Now when Mars encroaches upon Horn and Neck, the states and regions suffer its calamity—this applies to all such cases.

The Dao of Heaven and Earth, vast even at its crescent, still moderates its radiance and cherishes its numinous brightness. How then can human ears and eyes endure prolonged strain without rest? *Rest* means cessation. How can the spirit and essence sustain ceaseless galloping without exhaustion? *Exhaustion* means depletion.

Thus, blood and qi are the bloom of humanity, while the five viscera are the essence. When blood and qi concentrate within the five viscera—*concentrate* means unity—and do not scatter outward, the chest and abdomen become full and desires diminish. When the chest and abdomen are full and desires diminish, the ears and eyes become clear, and hearing and vision become penetrating. When the ears and eyes are clear and hearing and vision penetrating, this is called illumination. When the five viscera align with the heart without discord, then the will prevails and conduct remains unswayed. *The will prevails* refers to one’s guiding resolve. *Unswayed* means uncorrupted. *Prevails* may also be read as *pursues*, meaning the guiding resolve may depart slowly, thus keeping conduct upright and free from corruption. When the will prevails and conduct remains unswayed, the spirit flourishes and qi does not dissipate. When the spirit flourishes and qi does not dissipate, there is coherence; coherence leads to balance, balance to penetration, penetration to the numinous. When numinous, one sees all without obstruction, hears all without impediment, and accomplishes all without fail. Thus, cares and troubles cannot enter, and perverse qi cannot invade. *Invade* means to follow or enter.

Therefore, some seek what lies beyond the four seas yet cannot obtain it—*obtain* means to attain—while others guard what lies within their own form, their hearts free from desire, yet do not perceive it. Hence, those who seek much gain little, and those who perceive the vast know but little.

The apertures are the doors and windows of the spirit, while qi and will are the messengers and sentinels of the five viscera. When the ears and eyes indulge in the pleasures of sound and color, the five viscera become agitated and unsettled. When the five viscera are agitated and unsettled, blood and qi surge and do not cease. When blood and qi surge without ceasing, the spirit gallops outward and does not remain within—this is due to excessive desires, causing the spirit to fail in inward guard. When the spirit gallops outward and does not remain within, then blessings and misfortunes arrive like mountains, yet one cannot recognize them. *Mountains* symbolize greatness. *Recognize* means to know.

If the ears and eyes are keen, profound, and free from allurement, if qi and will are empty, tranquil, and joyful while desires are diminished, if the five viscera are settled, serene, full, and not depleted, and if the spirit guards the form within and does not scatter outward, then gazing into the past or foreseeing the future would still not suffice—*still* means *yet*, and *suffice* means *to govern*. How could this be limited merely to discerning blessings and misfortunes?

Thus it is said: the farther one reaches outward, the less one knows. This speaks of those who, though they may know the Dao, remain deficient. It illustrates that the spirit must not be allowed to stray outward.

Therefore, the five colors confuse the eyes, causing them to lose clarity—*lose clarity* means dimmed vision. The five sounds deafen the ears, causing them to lose acuity—*lose acuity* means hearing nothing. The five flavors disorder the mouth, causing injury and impairment—*impairment* means illness, harm to the sense of taste. Preferences and aversions disturb the heart, causing conduct to become reckless. *Disturb* means disorder; *reckless* means deviating from proper measure.

These four are what the world uses to nourish life—*life* means *to live*—yet they are all human burdens. Thus it is said: desires cause human qi to scatter—*scatter* means loss—and likes and dislikes cause the human heart to labor—*labor* means affliction. If not swiftly abandoned, the will and qi daily dissipate—*dissipate* means disorder.

Why is it that people cannot fulfill their natural lifespans and instead perish midway through punishment and execution? It is due to their excessive indulgence in life. What does *excessive indulgence in life* entail? It means nothing less than extreme desires, boundless indulgence without satiety, harming the ears, eyes, emotions, and nature. Thus they do not fulfill their lifespans but perish midway under the execution of lawless violence.

Only those who do not treat life as something to be clung to can truly cultivate and attain life. Those who do not treat life as something to be clung to lightly regard the pursuit of profit and harm, removing the desires of emotion and nature—thus they long preserve life.

Heaven and Earth revolve and interconnect; the myriad things unite as one. *Unite* means to converge; *one* means sameness. The myriad things converge and are governed by the one Dao. Those who know the one know all things—*the first one* is the Dao, *the second one* is things. Those who do not know the one cannot know anything.

Consider my place in the world: I too am but one thing. Do I not know whether the world uses me to complete its things, or whether, in the absence of me, things are not already complete? Thus, I am also a thing, and things are also things. Between things and things, how can one thing be distinguished from another? Things are also things—why name them as things?

Nevertheless, in giving me life, what benefit does it confer? *Giving life* is the natural Dao—what benefit should it provide? In taking my life, what harm does it inflict? *Harm* means diminution. Since the Creator has already made me a vessel, there is nothing to oppose. This means that once made human, there is nothing to depart from—it illustrates that one neither seeks nor avoids.

chunks.original_text: 吾安知夫刺炙而欲生者之非或也？ 又安知夫绞经而求死者之非福也？ 或者生乃徭役也，而死乃休息也？ 天下茫茫，孰知〔之哉〕#5。 其生我也不疆求已，已，止也。 言不恶生也。 其杀我也不疆求止。 言不畏死。 欲生而不事，事，治。 憎死而不辞，唯义所在，故不辞也。 贱之而弗憎，贵之而弗喜，人有恶贱己者，己不憎也。 人有尊己者，己不喜也。 随其天资而安之不极。 资，时也。 一曰，性也。 极，急也。 谕道人不急求生也。 吾生也有七尺之形，吾死也有一棺之土。 吾之於比有形之类，犹吾死之沦於无形之中也。 沦，入也。 然则吾生也物不以益众，吾死也土不以加厚，吾又安知所喜憎利害其间者乎。 不知喜生之利，不知憎死之害，守其正性也。 夫造化者之攫援物也，攫，撮也。 援，引也。 譬犹陶人之埏埴也，其取之地而已为盆盎也，与其未离於地也无以异，其已成器，而破碎漫澜而复归其故也，陶人，作瓦器治官也。 顿泥坯取之於地以为器，明人不当恶死，死，复归其未生之故耳。 譬犹瓦器之破，而复反於土也。 与其为盆盎亦无以异矣。 无以异於土也。 夫临江之乡，居人汲水以浸其园，江水弗憎也，苦洿之家，决垮而注之江，洿水弗乐也。 是故其在江也，无以异其浸园也，其在洿也，亦无以异其在江也。 道尚空虚，贵无形，江水大，去不可消，就易，故不憎也。 窊水小，去易小消，就不消，故不乐也。 洿水，犹澹水也。 苦，犹疾也。 一说，言各自安其处也。 及其转易，亦无憎乐也。 是故圣人因时以安其位，当世而乐其业。 业，事也。 夫悲乐者，德之邪也； 而喜怒者，道之过也； 好憎者，心之暴也。 故曰，其生也天行，似天气也。 其死也物化，如物之变化也。 静则与阴俱闭，动则与阳俱开。 精神澹然无极，极，尽。 不与物散，而天下自服。 散，杂乱貌。 自服，服於德也。 故心者，形之主也； 而神者，心之宝也。 形劳而不休则蹶，蹶，颠。 精用而不已则竭。 是故圣人贵而尊之，不敢越也。
chunks.translated_text:
How do I know that those who seek life through acupuncture and moxibustion do not err? And how do I know that those who seek death by hanging or cutting their throats do not find fortune? Perhaps life is but forced labor, and death but rest? In this vast world, who can truly know?

When I am given life, I do not insist on its continuance—*continuance* meaning cessation. This is to say, I do not despise life. When I am taken by death, I do not insist on its cessation. This is to say, I do not fear death. Those who desire life do not strive for it—*strive* meaning to manage. Those who detest death do not reject it, for they follow what is right and thus do not refuse. They scorn me, yet I feel no hatred; they honor me, yet I feel no joy. When others despise me, I do not hate them. When others revere me, I do not rejoice. I follow my natural endowment and rest in it without urgency—*endowment* meaning time, or else nature; *urgency* meaning haste. This illustrates that the Daoist does not hastily seek life.

In life, I possess a seven-foot form; in death, I return to a coffin’s worth of earth. My existence among the realm of forms is like my death’s dissolution into the formless—*dissolution* meaning entry. Thus, my life does not increase the multitude of things, nor does my death thicken the earth. How then can I know what to delight in or detest, what to deem beneficial or harmful? I do not know the benefit of delighting in life, nor the harm of detesting death, for I abide in my true nature.

The Creator seizes and draws forth things—*seizes* meaning to gather; *draws forth* meaning to pull—just as a potter works clay. The clay taken from the earth to make vessels differs not from the clay still in the ground. Once shaped into vessels, they may shatter and dissolve, returning to their origin. The potter, the official who crafts earthenware, molds the clay taken from the earth into vessels. This makes clear that one should not despise death, for death is but a return to the state before life—like a shattered vessel returning to earth. In this, it differs not from the clay that became a vessel.

In a riverside village, people draw water to irrigate their gardens, yet the river does not resent it. In a filthy household, they drain their ditches into the river, yet the stagnant water does not rejoice. Thus, when in the river, it differs not from irrigating the garden; when in the ditch, it differs not from being in the river. The Dao values emptiness and honors the formless. The river is vast, its departure imperceptible, so it does not resent. The ditch is small, its departure swift, so it does not rejoice—*stagnant water* like still water. *Filth* means haste. Another interpretation: each rests content in its place, and when they transform, there is neither resentment nor joy.

Thus, the sage adapts to the times and rests content in his position, delighting in his work in the present age—*work* meaning affairs. Grief and joy are deviations of virtue; delight and anger are excesses of the Dao; love and hatred are outbursts of the heart. Therefore, it is said: in life, one moves with the heavens, like the qi of heaven. In death, one transforms with things, like the changes of things. At rest, one closes with yin; in motion, one opens with yang. The spirit remains serene and boundless—*boundless* meaning without end. It does not scatter with things, yet the world naturally submits—*scatter* meaning disorder; *submits* meaning submits to virtue.

Thus, the heart is the master of the form, and the spirit is the heart’s treasure. If the form labors without rest, it stumbles—*stumbles* meaning to fall. If essence is used without cease, it is exhausted. Therefore, the sage honors and reveres it, daring not to transgress.

chunks.original_text: 夫有夏后氏之璜者，匣匮而藏之，宝之至也。 半璧曰璜，珍玉也。 夫精神之可宝也，非直夏后氏之璜也。 直，犹但也。 是故圣人以无应有，必究其理； 以虚受实，必穷其节； 恬愉虚静，以终其命。 是故无所甚疏，而无所甚亲，抱德炀和，以顺于天。 炀，炙也。 向火中炙和气，以顺天道也。 炀，读供养之养。 与道为际，与德为邻，际，合也。 邻，比也。 不为福始，不为祸先。 魂魄处其宅，而精神守其根，死生无变於己，故曰至神。 变，动。 所谓真人者，性合于道也。 真人者，虙戏、黄帝、老聃是也。 故有而若无，实而若虚，处其一不知其二，治其内不识其外，治其内，守精神也。 识其外，外不好憎也。 明白太素，无为复朴，体本抱神以游于天地之樊，樊，崖也。 樊，读麦饭之饭也。 芒然仿佯于尘垢之外，芒，读王莽之莽。 而消摇于无事之业。 浩浩荡荡乎，机械之巧弗载於心。 是故死生亦大矣，而不为变； 不为变者，同死生也。 虽天地覆育，亦不与之抮抱矣。 抮抱，犹持着者。 言不以天地养育万物，故强与持着，守其纯热也。 审乎无瑕，而不与物糅； 瑕，犹衅也。 忤见利欲之貌也。 能审顺之，故不与物相杂糅。 见事之乱，而能守其宗。 见事有者止之，乱不能眩惑，故能守其宗。 宗，本也。 若然者，正肝胆，遗耳目，言精神内守也。 心志专于内，通达耦于一。 一者，道也。 居不知所为，行不知所之，言志意无所系。 浑然而往，逮然而来。 浑，转行貌。 逯，谓无所为。 忽然往来也。 逯，读谓绿衣之绿也。 浑，读大珠挥挥之挥也。 形若槁木，心若死灰，槁木无气，死灰无热，谕无为也。 忘其五藏，损其形骸。 不学而知，不视而见，不为而成，不治而辩。 感而应，迫而动，迫切不得不动，然后乃动也。 不得已而往，如光之耀，如景之放，以道为紃，有待而然。 紃者，决也。 以道待万物，故曰有待，而默默如是。 抱其太清之本而无所容与，无所容与於情欲也。 而物无能营，营，惑也。 一曰乱。 廓惝而虚，清靖而无思虑，不劳精神。 大泽焚而不能热，河汉涸而不能寒也，大雷毁山而不能惊也，大风晦日而不能伤也。 言体道之人，闭情守虚，虽此四者之大； 不能惑也。 是故视珍宝珠玉犹石砾也，视至尊穷宠犹行客也，至尊，谓帝王也，故曰穷宠也。 行客，犹行路过客。 视毛嫱、西施犹颠丑也。 毛嫱、西施，皆古之美人。 颠，头也。 方相氏黄金四目衣赭，稀世之类貌，非生人也。 但其像耳目颠丑，言极丑也。 以死生为一化，以万物为一方，方，类也。 同精於太清之本，而游於忽区之旁。 忽区，忽恍无形之区旁也。 有精而不使者，有神而不行，言不浊其精，不劳其神，此之谓也。 契大浑之朴，而立至清之中。 朴，犹质也。 浑，不散之貌也。 浑，读挥章之挥。 是故其寝不梦，其智不萌，其寝不梦，神内守也。 其智不萌，无思念也。 其魄不抑，其魂不腾。 魄，阴神。 魂，阳神。 阴不沈抑，阳不飞腾，各守其宅。 反复终始，不知其端绪，甘暝太宵之宅，太宵，长夜之中也。 言其直瞑於大道之处，冥视昭昭矣。 而觉视于昭昭之宇，休息于无委曲之隅，而游敖于无形埒之野。 无委曲之隅，无形埒之野，冥冥无形像之貌也。
chunks.translated_text:
The Xia-hou clan’s jade half-disc—stored in a sealed casket—was treasured to the utmost. A half-disc is called a *huang*, a precious jade. Yet the treasure of spirit surpasses even the Xia-hou’s *huang*. *Surpasses* meaning not merely.

Thus, the sage responds to being with non-being, exhausting its principles; receives the solid with emptiness, penetrating its limits. Serene and joyful, empty and still, they fulfill their destiny. Therefore, they are neither overly distant nor overly intimate, embracing virtue and warming harmony to follow heaven. *Warming* means to roast; warming harmony in fire to align with the Dao of heaven. *Warming* is read as *yang*, like the *yang* in "nourishment."

They join with the Dao as their boundary, dwell beside virtue as their neighbor. *Boundary* means union; *neighbor* means proximity. They do not initiate fortune nor precede misfortune. The hun and po reside in their abode, while spirit guards its root. Life and death bring no change to them—hence they are called *perfect spirit*. *Change* means disturbance.

The so-called *True Person* aligns their nature with the Dao. The True Persons are Fu Xi, the Yellow Emperor, and Lao Dan. Thus, they possess yet seem without; are full yet seem empty. Abiding in oneness, they know not duality; governing the inner, they recognize not the outer. *Governing the inner* means guarding the spirit; *recognizing the outer* means not indulging in love or hatred.

They comprehend the Great Simplicity, practice non-action to restore simplicity, embody the root and embrace spirit to wander within heaven and earth’s bounds. *Bounds* means limits; *bounds* is read like the *fan* in "steamed rice." Vaguely they roam beyond the dust and grime, drifting in the work of non-action. Vast and unbounded, the craft of mechanisms does not burden their heart.

Thus, though death and life are great indeed, they do not alter. *Do not alter* means equating death and life. Though heaven and earth nurture all, they do not cling to them. *Cling* means grasping; they do not forcefully hold to heaven and earth’s nurturing of the myriad things, preserving their pure harmony.

They discern the flawless and do not mingle with things. *Flawless* means fault; it describes the appearance of resisting profit and desire. Able to discern and follow, they do not intermingle with things. Perceiving disorder in affairs, they yet guard their origin. *Origin* means root. Seeing things arise, they halt them; chaos cannot delude, so they guard their origin.

Thus, they rectify the liver and gall, forsake the ears and eyes—speaking of spirit’s inner guard. The heart’s will focuses within, penetrating duality to unite with the One. *The One* is the Dao. They dwell without knowing what they do, move without knowing where they go—speaking of the will unshackled. Vastly they depart, freely they arrive. *Vastly* describes turning movement; *freely* means without purpose, wandering without aim. *Freely* is read like the *lü* in "green robe"; *vastly* like the *hui* in "the great pearl’s brilliance."

Their form is like withered wood, their heart like dead ashes. *Withered wood* has no breath; *dead ashes* have no heat—metaphors for non-action. They forget their five viscera, diminish their bodily frame. They know without learning, see without gazing, accomplish without acting, discern without governing.

They respond to stimuli, move under compulsion. *Compulsion* means unavoidable movement, then they act. They proceed only when necessary, like light’s radiance, like a reflection’s projection, following the Dao as their guide, awaiting conditions to be so. *Guide* means decision; following the Dao to await the myriad things—hence they say "awaiting," yet remain silent thus.

They embrace the Great Purity’s root and admit no attachments—no attachments to emotions or desires. Thus, things cannot disturb them. *Disturb* means delusion; one says *disorder*. Vast and desolate, empty and still, they harbor no thoughts, do not labor the spirit.

Great marshes may burn, yet they cannot be hot; the Milky Way may dry, yet they cannot be cold; great thunder may shatter mountains, yet they cannot be startled; great winds may darken the sun, yet they cannot be harmed. This speaks of those who embody the Dao: closing emotions and guarding emptiness, even these four great forces cannot delude them.

Thus, they regard treasures, pearls, and jades as mere pebbles; view the most exalted and lavish honors as passing travelers. *Most exalted* refers to emperors and kings—hence *lavish honors*; *passing travelers* are like wayfarers on the road. They see Mao Qiang and Xi Shi as grotesque. Mao Qiang and Xi Shi were ancient beauties. *Grotesque* means misshapen; the *fangxiang* spirit’s four golden eyes and vermilion robes are rare, inhuman visages—yet their likeness is but misshapen eyes and faces, speaking of extreme ugliness.

They regard death and life as one transformation, the myriad things as one kind. *Kind* means category. Uniting essence with the Great Purity’s root, they wander beside the indistinct realm. *Indistinct realm* means the vague, formless region.

They possess essence yet do not employ it; possess spirit yet do not move—speaking of not polluting their essence or laboring their spirit. They join with the Great Simplicity’s uncarved block and stand at the Perfect Purity’s center. *Uncarved block* means substance; *Great Simplicity* describes its undispersed state. *Great Simplicity* is read like the *hui* in "brilliant chapter."

Thus, in sleep they do not dream; their wisdom does not sprout. *Do not dream* means spirit guards within; *wisdom does not sprout* means no thoughts arise. Their po is not repressed, their hun does not soar. *Po* is the yin spirit; *hun* is the yang spirit. Yin is not sunken or repressed; yang does not fly or soar—each guards its abode.

Revolving through beginning and end, they know not the thread’s start. They sweetly slumber in the Great Night’s abode. *Great Night* means the long night’s midst—speaking of their direct repose in the great Dao’s realm, darkly seeing the luminous. Yet they awaken to gaze upon the luminous world, rest in the corner without crooks, and roam the wilds without bounds. *Corner without crooks* and *wilds without bounds* describe the formless, obscure state.

Thus, they rectify the liver and gall, forsake the ears and eyes—speaking of spirit’s inner guard. The heart’s will focuses within, penetrating duality to unite with the One. *The One* is the Dao. They dwell without knowing what they do, move without knowing where they go—speaking of the will unshackled. Vastly they depart, freely they arrive. *Vastly* describes turning movement; *freely* means without purpose, wandering without aim. Their form is like withered wood, their heart like dead ashes. They forget their five viscera, diminish their bodily frame. They know without learning, see without gazing, accomplish without acting, discern without governing. They respond to stimuli, move under compulsion. They proceed only when necessary, like light’s radiance, like a reflection’s projection, following the Dao as their guide.
chunks.overlap_context:
one opens with yang. The spirit remains serene and boundless—*boundless* meaning without end. It does not scatter with things, yet the world naturally submits—*scatter* meaning disorder; *submits* meaning submits to virtue.

Thus, the heart is the master of the form, and the spirit is the heart’s treasure. If the form labors without rest, it stumbles—*stumbles* meaning to fall. If essence is used without cease, it is exhausted. Therefore, the sage honors and reveres it, daring not to transgress.

chunks.original_text: 居而无容，处而无所，其人居无形容可得见也，处无常所。 其动无形，其静无体，无形无体，道之容也。 存而若亡，生而若死，出入无间，役使鬼神，言能化也。 人不与鬼同形，而能使之者，道也。 天神曰神，人神曰鬼也。 沦於不测，入於无间，以不同形相嬗也，嬗，传也。 万物之形不同，道以相传生也。 终始若环，莫得其伦。 伦，理也，道也，人莫能得焉。 此精神之所以能登假于道也，假，至也。 上至於道也。 或作虾蟆云气。 是故真人之所游。 游，行。 若吹呴呼吸，吐故内新，熊经鸟伸，凫浴猿躩，鸱视虎顾，是养形之人也，不以滑心。 经，动摇也。 伸，频伸也。 若此养形之人，导引其神，屈伸跳踉，是非真人为之道也。 滑，乱也。 言此养形者耳，不足以乱真人之心也。 使神滔荡而不失其充，充，实。 日夜无伤而与物为春，体道人同。 日夜，谕贼害也。 无伤，无所贼害也。 与物为春，言养物也。 则是合而生时干心也。 若是者，合於道，生四时化其心也。 言不干时害物也。 且人有戒形而无损於心，戒，备也。 人形体备具。 戒或作革。 革，改也。 言人形骸有改更而作化也。 心谕神，神不损伤也。 有缀宅而无耗精。 缀宅，身也。 精神居其宅则生，离其宅则死。 言人虽死，精神终不耗灭，故曰无耗精也。 夫癞者趋不变，狂者形不亏，神将有所远徙，孰暇知其所为。 言病癞者形生神在，故趋不变也。 或作介，介，被甲者。 礼，介者不拜而能趋於步，故曰不变也。 狂体具存，故曰不亏，但精神散越耳，故曰，神有所远徙也。 故形有摩而神未尝化者，摩，灭，犹死也。 神变归於无形也，故曰，未尝化也。 化，犹死也。 以不化应化，千变万抮而未始有极。 不化，精神也。 化者，形骸。 死者形为灰土，为日化也。 化者，复归於无形也； 不化者，与天地俱生也。 夫木之死也，青青去之也。 夫使木生者岂木也？ 使木生者天也，故曰岂木哉。 犹充形者之非形也。 充形者，气也。 故曰非形也。 故生生者未尝死也，其所生则死矣。 生生者道。 谕道之人若，天气，未尝死也。 下所生者，万物矣。 化物者未尝化也，化物者道也。 道不化，故未尝化也。 其所化则化矣。 所化者，万物也。 万物有变，故曰则化。 轻天下，则神无累矣； 轻薄天下宠势之权者，许由是也，故其精神无留累於物也。 细万物，则心不惑矣； 以万物为小事而弗欲，故心不惑物也。 齐死生，则志不慑矣； 齐，等也。 不畏义死，不乐不义生，其志意无所慑惧，故曰等也。 同变化，则明木眩矣。 眩，惑。 众人以为虚言吾，将举类而实之。 实，明。 人之所以乐为人主者，以其穷耳目之欲，而适躬体之便也。 今高台层榭，人之所丽也，四方高曰台，加木曰榭。 丽，美也。 而尧朴桷不斲，素题不枅。 朴，采也。 桷，椽也。 不斲削，加宓石之。 素题也，不加采饰。 故曰，不枅者，不施欂櫖。 俱交架也。 枅，读鸡枅，或作刮也。 珍怪奇异，人之所美也，而尧粝粢之饭，藜霍之羹。 粝，粗也。 粢，稷也。 粝读赖恃之赖。 粢，读齐衰之齐。 文绣狐白，人之所好也，而尧布衣揜形，鹿裘御寒。 养性之具不加厚，而增之以任重之忧，任，读任侠之任。 故举天下而传之于舜，传，禅。
chunks.translated_text:
Dwelling without form, abiding without place—their person resides where no shape can be seen, abides where no fixed location exists. Their movement leaves no trace, their stillness no substance; no trace, no substance—such is the appearance of the Dao. Existing yet seeming to vanish, living yet seeming to die, they enter and exit without gap, command ghosts and spirits—speaking of their power of transformation. Though humans do not share form with ghosts, they can employ them—this is the Dao. Heavenly spirits are called *shen*; human spirits, *gui*.

They merge into the unfathomable, penetrate the seamless, for they transmit through forms that differ. *Shan* means transmission. The forms of the ten thousand things differ, yet the Dao transmits and gives them life. Beginning and end form a circle, none can grasp its principle. *Lun* means pattern, the Dao—none can attain it. This is how the spirit ascends to reach the Dao. *Jia* means to arrive, to ascend to the Dao.

Thus it is the realm where the Perfected Person wanders. *You* means to travel. Like the breath of exhalation and inhalation, expelling the old and drawing in the new; like the bear’s hanging and the bird’s stretching, the wild duck’s bathing and the ape’s leaping, the owl’s gaze and the tiger’s glance—these are the practices of those who cultivate the body, not to disturb the heart. *Jing* means to sway; *shen* means to stretch frequently. Such are the body-cultivators who guide their spirit, bending and extending, leaping and bounding—this is not the Dao of the Perfected Person. *Gu* means disorder. These methods of body-cultivation are not enough to disturb the heart of the Perfected Person.

They let the spirit roam freely without losing its fullness. *Chong* means repletion. Day and night unharmed, they bring springtime to all things—one with the person who embodies the Dao. *Day and night* symbolize harm; *unharmed* means no injury is done. *Bringing springtime to all things* means nurturing them, thus uniting with the generative force of the seasons and transforming the heart. If so, they harmonize with the Dao, letting the four seasons transform their heart—meaning they do not oppose the times to harm things.

Moreover, humans may alter their form without harming the heart. *Jie* means preparation; the human body is fully equipped. *Jie* may also be written as *ge*, meaning change—speaking of the body’s transformations. The heart symbolizes the spirit, which remains unharmed. Though the dwelling may decay, the essence is not consumed. *Zhui zhai* means the body; when the spirit resides in its dwelling, life exists; when it departs, death follows. Yet though the person dies, the spirit is never exhausted—thus it is said, "the essence is not consumed."

The leper’s gait does not change, the madman’s form is not diminished—the spirit is about to migrate far, who has time to know what it does? The leper’s form lives while the spirit remains, so their gait does not change. *Jie* may also mean armored; in ritual, the armored do not bow but can still walk—thus it is said, "does not change." The madman’s body remains intact—thus it is said, "not diminished"—but the spirit scatters and strays, so it is said, "the spirit is about to migrate far."

Thus the form may perish, yet the spirit never transforms. *Mo* means destruction, like death. The spirit’s change returns to the formless—thus it is said, "never transforms." *Hua* means death. Responding to transformation without transforming, through ten thousand changes and countless shifts, it never reaches an end. *Not transforming* refers to the spirit; *transforming* refers to the body. The dead become ashes and dust—this is called *hua*. *Hua* means returning to the formless; *not transforming* means being born together with heaven and earth.

When a tree dies, its greenness departs. Yet what makes the tree live—is it the tree? What makes the tree live is heaven—thus it is said, "is it the tree?" So too is the one who fills the form not the form. The one who fills the form is *qi*—thus it is said, "not the form." Therefore, that which gives life never dies; what it gives life to dies. *That which gives life* is the Dao. The person who embodies the Dao is like heaven’s *qi*—it never dies. What it gives life to are the ten thousand things.

That which transforms things never transforms; that which transforms things is the Dao. The Dao does not transform—thus it is said, "never transforms." What it transforms does transform. What it transforms are the ten thousand things. The ten thousand things change—thus it is said, "does transform."

Disregarding the world, the spirit is unburdened. To treat the world’s honors and powers as trivial—like Xu You—is to keep the spirit free from entanglement with things. Seeing the ten thousand things as insignificant, the heart is not confused. Equating life and death, the will is not daunted. *Qi* means to equalize. Not fearing righteous death, not delighting in unrighteous life, the will has nothing to dread—thus it is said, "to equalize." Harmonizing with change, clarity is not obscured. *Xuan* means confusion. The multitude may call my words empty, but I will cite examples to make them real.

What delights people about being a ruler is the ability to exhaust the desires of the ears and eyes and satisfy the body’s comforts. Now, lofty towers and layered pavilions are what people admire—*tai* means a high platform on all sides; *xie* means a wooden structure atop it. *Li* means beauty. Yet Yao’s rafters were unhewn, his plain crossbeams unadorned. *Pu* means uncarved; *jue* means rafters. They were not planed, only smoothed with stone. The plain crossbeams were not decorated—thus it is said, "unadorned," meaning no brackets were applied. *Jī* is read as *jī* (like "chicken perch"), or may be written as *guā* (to scrape). Rare treasures and strange wonders are what people cherish, yet Yao ate coarse millet and drank soup of wild greens. *Lì* means coarse; *zī* means millet. *Lì* is read like the *lài* in *làishì* (to rely on); *zī* is read like the *qí* in *qīcuī* (mourning attire). Fine embroidery and white fox fur are what people desire, yet Yao wore rough cloth to cover his body and a deerskin to ward off the cold.

The tools for nurturing life were not made lavish, yet he added to them the burden of heavy cares. *Rèn* is read like the *rèn* in *rènxiá* (chivalrous). Thus he offered the world to Shun. *Chuán* means to abdicate.

chunks.original_text: 若解重负然。 非直辞让，诚无以为也。 此轻天下之具也。 禹南省方，济于江，巡狩为省，省视四方也。 济，渡也。 黄龙负舟，舟中之人五色无主，禹乃熙笑而称曰，我受命於天，竭力而劳万民，劳，忧，也。 生，寄也，死，归也，何足以滑和。 人寿盖不过百年，故曰生寄也。 死灭没化不见，故曰归也。 滑，乱也。 和，适也。 视龙犹蝘蜓，蝘蜓，蜥蜴也，或曰守宫也。 东方朔射覆，对武帝曰，谓为龙，无有角，谓为蛇，而有足。 骙骙脉脉，喜缘壁，非守宫，当晰蜴是也。 颜色不变，龙乃弥耳掉尾而逃。 逃，去。 禹之视物亦细矣。
chunks.translated_text:
As if shedding a heavy burden. It was not merely a matter of yielding the throne—truly, he had nothing to claim as his own. Such were the means by which he made light of the world.

When Yu inspected the southern regions and crossed the Yangtze, his tour of inspection was to observe the four quarters. *Jì* means to cross. A yellow dragon bore his boat upon its back, and the people aboard were struck pale with fear, their faces drained of color. Yu, however, smiled broadly and declared: "I received my mandate from Heaven and have exhausted my strength in toiling for the myriad people. *Láo* means to worry. Life is but a temporary lodging; death, a return. What is there to disrupt harmony? Human life rarely exceeds a hundred years—thus it is said, life is a lodging. Death is extinction, transformation, disappearance—thus it is called a return. *Gǔ* means disorder; *hé*, harmony.

He regarded the dragon as no more than a lizard—a *yǎntíng*, that is, a skink, or as some say, a gecko. Dongfang Shuo, in his riddle-guessing before the Martial Emperor, said: 'If it were a dragon, it would lack horns; if a snake, it would have feet.' With its sturdy gait and gentle gaze, fond of clinging to walls—it was no gecko, but surely a skink. Yet when Yu’s countenance remained unchanged, the dragon flicked its ears and wagged its tail in flight. *Táo* means to depart. Thus did Yu perceive things in their true measure."

The tools for nurturing life were not made lavish, yet he added to them the burden of heavy cares. *Rèn* is read like the *rèn* in *rènxiá* (chivalrous). Thus he offered the world to Shun. *Chuán* means to abdicate.

chunks.original_text: 郑之神巫相壶子林，见其征，神在男曰觋，在女曰巫。 巫能占骨法吉凶之气，故见其兆征。 征，应也。 告列子。 列子行泣报壶子，列子，郑之隐士，壶子弟子也。 报，白也。 壶子持以天壤，言精神天之有也，形骸地之有也，死自归其本，故曰持天壤矣。 名实不入，机发於踵。 名，爵号之名也。 实，币帛货财之实。 不入者，必不恤也。 机，谕疾也。 谓命危殆，不旋踵而至，犹不恐惧。 壶子之视死生亦齐。 齐，等。 子求行年五十有四而病伛偻，脊管高于顶，□下迫颐，两髀在上，子求，楚人也。 偻，脊管下窍也。 高於顶，出头上也。 □，肝胸也。 迫，薄至於颐也。 两脾下在上，躯正贠也。 □，读精神□越无之歇也。 烛营指天，烛，阴华也。 营，其窍也。 上指（六）〔天〕#6也。 烛营，读曰括撮也。 匍匐自窥於井，临井水自观照。 曰，伟哉造化者，其以我为此拘拘邪？ 伟哉，犹美哉也。 造化，谓天也。 拘拘，好貌。 此其视变化亦同矣。 故睹尧之道，乃知天下之轻也，以其禅舜。 观禹之志，乃知天下之细也。 以其视龙犹蝘蜓也。 原壶子之论，乃知死生之齐也。 论持以天壤也。 见子求之行，乃知变化之同也。 行，匍匐窥於井，此之谓也。 夫至人倚不拔之柱，行不关之涂，倚於不可拔摇之柱，行於不可关闭之涂，言无不通。 禀不竭之府，学不死之师，无往而不遂，往而遂也。 无至而不通。 至而通也。 生不足以挂志，死不足以幽神，屈伸俛仰，抱命而婉转。 抱天命而婉转，不离违也。 祸福利害，千变万紾，紾，转。 孰足以患心。 若此人者，抱素守精，蝉蜕蛇解，游於太清，轻举独住，忽然入冥。 凤凰不能与之俪，俪，偕。 而况斥鴳乎。 斥泽之鴳雀，飞不能出於顷晦，谕弱也。 势位爵禄何足以槩志也。 不足以槩至人之志。 晏子与崔杼盟，临死地而不易其义。 晏子名婴，字平仲，齐大夫也。 崔杼杀齐庄公，盟诸侯曰，不唯崔庆是从者，如此盟。 晏子曰，婴所不唯忠於君而利社稷者是从，亦如而利之。 故曰临死地而不易其义者也。 殖、华将战而死，莒君厚赂而止之，不改其行。 殖，杞梁也； 华，华周，皆齐士也。 为君伐莒之队，莒人围之，壮其勇力，厚赂而止之，不可，遂战而死。 故曰不改其行也。 故晏子可迫以仁不可劫以兵，晏子不从崔杼之盟，将见杀。 晏子曰，句戟何不句，夜矛何不摧，不挠不义。 故曰不可劫以兵也。 殖、华可止以义，而不可县以利。 县，视也。 言不为利动也。 君子义死，而不可以死亡恐也，彼则直为义耳，而尚犹不拘於物，又况无为者矣。 尧不以有天下为贵，故授舜，公子扎不以有国为尊，故让位； 扎，吴寿梦之少子，延州来季子也。 让位不受兄国，春秋贤之。 诸侯之子称公子也。

The divine diviner of Zheng, Master Hú of the Lin clan, perceived his omens—when the spirit resides in a man, he is called a *xí*; in a woman, a *wū*. The *wū* could divine the auspicious or inauspicious *qi* through bone divination, thus discerning its signs. *Zhēng* means response.

He informed Liezi. Liezi went weeping to report to Master Hú. Liezi was a recluse of Zheng and a disciple of Master Hú. *Bào* means to inform. Master Hú held to Heaven and Earth, saying that spirit belongs to Heaven, while form and bones belong to Earth; in death, one returns to their origin—thus he spoke of holding to Heaven and Earth. Names and realities did not enter his concern. *Míng* refers to titles and ranks; *shí*, to gifts of silk and wealth. *Bù rù* means he paid them no heed. The trigger of danger arose from his heels. *Jī* signifies swiftness, meaning that when life was imperiled, death came before he could turn his heel—yet he felt no fear. Master Hú regarded death and life as equal. *Qí* means equivalence.

Zǐqiú, a man of Chu, sought to know his age at fifty-four, yet he was afflicted with a hunched back, his spine protruding above his head, his chest pressing against his chin, and his thighs positioned above. *Yǔlǚ* refers to the lower opening of the spine. *Gāo yú dǐng* means it rose above his head. *□* refers to the chest. *Pò* means it pressed against his chin. With his thighs below now above, his body was contorted. *□* is read as the dissipation of spirit, like the fading of *yuèwú*. His candle-like *yíng* pointed to the heavens. *Zhú* refers to the yin brilliance; *yíng*, to its opening. It pointed upward to Heaven. *Zhúyíng* is read as *kuòcuō*. He crawled to peer into a well, gazing at his reflection in the water. He said, "How wondrous is the Creator! Why has it made me thus, so constrained?" *Wěi zāi* means "how magnificent"; *zàohuà* refers to Heaven; *jūjū*, to a pleasing appearance. In this, his view of transformation was likewise equal.

Thus, observing Yao’s Dao, one knows the insignificance of the world—through his abdication to Shun. Witnessing Yu’s resolve, one knows the pettiness of the world—through his seeing a dragon as no more than a skink. Tracing Master Hú’s discourse, one knows the equality of death and life—through his holding to Heaven and Earth. Seeing Zǐqiú’s conduct, one knows the sameness of transformation—his crawling to peer into the well is what this means.

The perfected person leans upon an unshakable pillar and walks an unobstructed path—resting on a column that cannot be uprooted, traversing a road that cannot be barred, speaking of unimpeded passage. They draw from an inexhaustible storehouse and study under an immortal teacher, going nowhere without success, arriving nowhere without understanding. *Wú wǎng ér suì* means to proceed and succeed; *wú zhì ér tōng*, to arrive and understand. Life is not enough to preoccupy their mind, nor death enough to darken their spirit. In bending and stretching, bowing and rising, they embrace their fate and flow with it—holding to Heaven’s mandate and turning with it, never departing from it. Amidst the ten thousand twists of fortune and misfortune, gain and harm, *zhěn* means to turn—what could trouble their heart?

Such a person embraces simplicity and guards their essence, shedding their form like a cicada or a snake, roaming the Great Purity, rising lightly and dwelling alone, vanishing suddenly into darkness. The phoenix cannot match their pairing—*lì* means to accompany—how much less the marsh sparrow? The sparrow of the marshes and lakes cannot fly beyond a moment’s dusk, a metaphor for weakness. Rank, position, titles, and emoluments—how could these sway their resolve? They are not enough to sway the perfected person’s will.

When Yanzi pledged an oath with Cuī Zhù, he faced death yet did not alter his righteousness. Yanzi, named Yīng, styled Píngzhòng, was a grandee of Qi. Cuī Zhù killed Duke Zhuang of Qi and forced the feudal lords to swear, "Whoever does not follow Cuī and Qìng shall face this oath." Yanzi said, "I will follow only what is loyal to the ruler and beneficial to the state—likewise, I will follow what benefits it." Thus it is said he faced death yet did not alter his righteousness.

When Zhí and Huá were about to die in battle, the Lord of Jǔ offered them rich bribes to stop, yet they did not change their conduct. Zhí was Qǐ Liáng; Huá, Huá Zhōu—both were knights of Qi. When they led an expedition against Jǔ, the men of Jǔ surrounded them, admiring their courage and offering lavish bribes to halt them, but they refused and died in battle. Thus it is said they did not change their conduct.

Therefore, Yanzi could be pressed by benevolence but not coerced by arms. When Yanzi refused Cuī Zhù’s oath and was about to be killed, he said, "Why do your halberds not hook, your night spears not shatter? I will not yield to unrighteousness." Thus it is said he could not be coerced by arms. Zhí and Huá could be stopped by righteousness but not tempted by profit. *Xiàn* means to regard—speaking of not being moved by gain. The noble person dies for righteousness and cannot be frightened by the threat of death. They act solely for righteousness and are not bound by things—how much more so for those who act without contrivance?

Yao did not value possessing the world, thus he abdicated to Shun. Gōngzǐ Zhá did not esteem ruling a state, thus he yielded his position. Zhá was the youngest son of Shòumèng of Wú, known as Jìzǐ of Yánzhōulái. He declined the throne and did not accept his elder brother’s state—*Chūnqiū* praised him. The sons of feudal lords are called *gōngzǐ*.

Dongfang Shuo, in his riddle-guessing before the Martial Emperor, said: 'If it were a dragon, it would lack horns; if a snake, it would have feet.' chunks.original_text: 子罕不以玉为富，故不受宝； 子罕，宋戴公六世之孙，西乡士之子，司成乐喜也。 宋人或得玉，以献子罕，子罕不受。 献玉者曰，以示玉人，玉人以为宝，故敢献之。 子罕曰，我以不贪为宝，子以玉为宝。 若（子）〔与〕#7我，是皆丧宝也。 不如人有其宝。 稽首告曰，小人怀璧，不可以越乡，纳此以请死，子罕置诸其里，使玉人为之攻之，富而后使复其所。 故曰不受宝也。 务光不以生害义，故自投於渊。 务光，汤时隐士也。 汤代桀，让天下於务光，人谓务光曰，汤杀其君，将归不义之名於子，务光因抱石自投於深渊而死。 由此观之，至贵不待爵，以至德见贵，许由、务光是也，故曰不待爵也。 至富不待财。 以至德见富，若楚狂接舆是也。 王闻其贤，使使者赍金百镒聘之，欲以为相，而不受，故曰至富不待财也。 天下至大矣，而以与佗人也； 尧是。 身至亲矣，而弃之渊。 务光是也。 外此，其余无足利矣。 外，犹除也。 利，犹食利。 或作私，私，独受也。 此之谓无累之人。 无累之人，不以天下为贵矣。 上观至人之论，深原道德之意，以下考世俗之行，乃足羞也。 考，观也。 故通许由之意，金縢、豹韬废矣； 金縢，豹韬，周公、太公阴谋图王之书也。 许由轻天下不受，焉用此书为，故曰废矣。 延陵季子不受吴国，而讼闲田者惭矣； 讼闲田者，虞、芮及暴桓公、苏信公是也。 子罕不利宝玉，而争券契者媿矣； 务光不污於世，而贪利偷生者闷矣。 故不观大义者，不知生之不足贪也； 大义，死君亲之难也。 不闻大言者，不知天下之不足利也。 大言，体道无欲之言。 今夫穷鄙之社也，叩盆拊瓴，相和而歌，自以为乐矣。 穷鄙之社，穷巷之小社也。 盆瓴器，叩之有音声，故曰自以为乐也。 尝试为之击建鼓，撞巨钟，乃性仍仍然，知其盆瓴之足羞也。 仍仍，不得志之貌。 仍仍或作聆聆，犹闻也。 藏诗、书，修文学，而不知至论之旨，则拊盆叩瓴之徒也。 夫以天下为者，学之建鼓矣。 建鼓，乐之大者。 尊势厚利，人之所贪也。 尊势，穷位。 厚利，重禄。 使之（尤）〔左〕#8据天下图而右手刎其喉，愚夫不为。 由此观之，生尊于天下也。 天下至大，非手所据，故不言手也。 使得据天下之图籍，行其权势，而刎喉杀身，虽愚者不肯为也，故曰生贵於天下矣。 圣人食足以接气，衣足以盖形，适情不求余，接，续也。 盖，覆也。 余，饶也。 无天下不亏其性，有天下不羡其和。 亏，损也。 羡，过也。 和，适也。 有天下，无天下，一实也。 实，等。 今赣人敖仓，予人河水，赣，赐也。 敖，地名。 仓者，以之常满仓也，在今荣阳县北。 饥而餐之，渴而饮之，其入腹者不过箪食瓢浆，箪，笋。 则身饱而敖仓不为之减也，减少。 腹满，而河水不为之竭也。 竭，尽。 有之不加饱，无之不为之饥，与守其篅□、有其井，一实。 篅□，受谷器也。 井，家人之井水也。 篅读颛孙之颛也。 人大怒破阴，大喜坠阳，巳说在原道也。 大忧内崩，大怖生狂。 除秽去累，漠若未始出其宗，乃为大通。 清目而不以视，清，明。 静耳而不以听，钳口而不以言，委心而不以虑，弃聪明而反太素，休精神而弃知故，觉而若昧，以生而若死，昧，暗也，厌也。
chunks.translated_text:
Kong Han did not regard jade as wealth, thus he refused the treasure. Kong Han was the sixth-generation descendant of Duke Dai of Song, the son of a scholar from the western district, named Le Xi, the Minister of Music. Someone from Song obtained a jade and offered it to Kong Han, who declined. The one who presented the jade said, "I showed it to a jade expert, who deemed it a treasure, so I dare offer it." Kong Han replied, "I regard not being greedy as my treasure, while you regard jade as yours. If you give it to me, we both lose our treasures. It is better for each to keep their own." The man bowed deeply and said, "A humble man carrying jade cannot travel beyond his village. I offer this to beg for my life." Kong Han placed it in his neighborhood, had a jade worker refine it, enriched the man, and then sent him back home. Thus it is said he did not accept the treasure.

Wu Guang did not harm righteousness for the sake of life, so he cast himself into the abyss. Wu Guang was a recluse during Tang’s time. When Tang succeeded Jie, he offered the world to Wu Guang. Someone told Wu Guang, "Tang killed his lord and will bring the name of unrighteousness upon you." Wu Guang then embraced a stone and threw himself into a deep abyss to die.

From this, we see that the most noble do not rely on rank—those of utmost virtue are esteemed, such as Xu You and Wu Guang. Thus it is said they do not rely on rank. The richest do not depend on wealth—those of utmost virtue are rich, like Jie Yu, the madman of Chu. The king heard of his worthiness and sent an envoy with a hundred *yi* of gold to invite him, wishing to make him a minister, but he refused. Thus it is said the richest do not rely on wealth.

The world is vast, yet one may give it to another—Yao is such a case. One’s own body is most intimate, yet one may cast it into the abyss—Wu Guang is such a case. Beyond these, nothing else is worth pursuing. "Beyond" means to exclude; "pursuing" means seeking profit. Some interpret it as "private," meaning exclusive possession. These are called men without encumbrances. Such men do not regard the world as valuable.

Looking up to the discourse of the utmost person and deeply exploring the meaning of the Dao and virtue, then examining the conduct of the common world below, one finds it truly shameful. "Examining" means observing. Thus, understanding Xu You’s intent, the *Jin Teng* and *Pao Tao* become obsolete. *Jin Teng* and *Pao Tao* are books of secret schemes by the Duke of Zhou and Jiang Taigong to seize the throne. Xu You disdained the world and did not accept it—why would he need such books? Thus they are obsolete. When Yanling Jizi refused the state of Wu, those who litigated over idle fields were ashamed. Those who litigated over idle fields were Yu and Rui, as well as Duke Bao Huan and Duke Su Xin. When Kong Han did not covet jade treasures, those who quarreled over contracts were shamed. When Wu Guang remained unstained by the world, those who greedily clung to life were confounded.

Thus, those who do not observe great righteousness do not know that life is not worth coveting. "Great righteousness" refers to dying for one’s lord or kin in peril. Those who do not hear great words do not know that the world is not worth pursuing. "Great words" are those that embody the Dao and lack desire.

Now, consider the village festivals of the poor and remote: they strike basins and clay jars, sing in harmony, and consider it joy. Yet if one were to beat the great war drum and strike the massive bell for them, they would feel discontented and ashamed of their basins and jars. "Discontented" describes their dejected appearance. Some write it as "lingling," meaning "to hear."

Those who store poetry and books and cultivate literature yet do not understand the essence of the utmost discourse are like those who strike basins and jars. For those who regard the world as their possession, learning is like the great war drum. High status and great profit are what people covet. "High status" means the highest position; "great profit" means substantial emolument. If one were to hold the world’s maps in the left hand while cutting one’s throat with the right, even a fool would not do it. From this, we see that life is more valuable than the world. The world is vast and cannot be held in the hand, so it is not spoken of as such. Even if one could hold the world’s registers, wield its power, and cut one’s throat to kill oneself, even a fool would not do it. Thus it is said life is more valuable than the world.

The sage eats enough to sustain qi, wears enough to cover the body, and satisfies desires without seeking excess. "Sustain" means to continue; "cover" means to clothe; "excess" means surplus. Possessing the world does not harm their nature, nor does lacking it make them envious of harmony. "Harm" means to damage; "envious" means to exceed; "harmony" means contentment. Having the world or not is the same in reality. "Reality" means equality.

Now, if one bestows upon a person the granary of Ao and the waters of the Yellow River—"bestows" means to grant; Ao is a place name, where the granary is always full, located north of present-day Rongyang County—when hungry, they eat from it; when thirsty, they drink from it. What enters their stomach is no more than a basket of food and a gourd of broth. Thus their body is full, yet the granary of Ao is not diminished, nor are the waters of the Yellow River exhausted. "Diminished" means reduced; "exhausted" means depleted. Having them does not make one fuller, nor does lacking them make one hungrier. It is the same as guarding one’s grain basket and possessing one’s well. "Basket" is a vessel for holding grain; "well" refers to the household’s well water. "Basket" is read like the first character of Zhuan Sun’s name.

Great anger harms the yin, great joy collapses the yang—this is already explained in the *Origin of the Dao*. Great sorrow causes internal collapse, great terror drives one mad. Eliminate filth and remove encumbrances, remain indifferent as if one had never left one’s origin, and one attains great freedom.

Clear the eyes yet do not use them to see, purify the ears yet do not use them to hear, seal the mouth yet do not use it to speak, entrust the heart yet do not use it to ponder. Discard brilliance and return to primal simplicity, rest the spirit and abandon cunning and knowledge. Awake yet seeming dim, alive yet seeming dead. "Dim" means dark or weary.

chunks.original_text: 楚人谓厌为昧，论无知也。 终则反本未生之时，而与化为一体。 言人之未生时。 欲同死生也，故曰与化为一体也。 死之与生，一体也。 今夫繇者，揭镢舀，鱼笼土，繇，役也。 今河东谓治道为繇道。 揭，举也。 镢，斫也。 臿，铧也。 青州谓之铧，有刃也。 三辅谓之□也。 笼； 受土笼也。 盐汗交流，喘息薄喉。 白汗咸如盐，故曰盐汗也。 薄，迫也，气衢喉也。 当此之时，薅越下，则脱然而喜矣。 薅，阴也。 三辅人谓休华树下为薅也。 楚人树上大本小，如车盖状为越，言多荫也。 脱，舒也。 言县人之得小休息，则气得舒，故喜也。 越，读经无重越之越也。 岩穴之间，非直越下之休也。 病疵瘕者，捧心抑腹，膝上叩头，抑，按也。 叩或作跔，跔，读车軥之軥也。 蜷局而谛，通夕不寐。 当此之时，哙然得卧，则亲戚兄弟欢然而喜。 夫修夜之宁，非直一哙之乐也。 谓得安卧极夜者。 乐於一哙之乐，然不得比长夜之乐也。 故知宇宙之大，则不可劫以死生； 劫，迫。 知养生之和，则不可县以天下； 养生之和，谓正道也。 已修正道不惑，故不可示以天下之穷势而移也。 知未生之乐，则不可畏以死； 乐其不生之时，虽惧之以死，不知使之畏死。 言不畏死。 知许由之贵于舜，则不贪物。 言不贪利欲之物也。 墙之立，不若其偃也，又况不为墙乎。 冰之凝，不若其释也，又况不为冰乎。 不如未为墙冰之时，偃、凝能变也。 自无跖有，自有跖无，自无跖有，从无形至有形也。 自有迹无，从有形至无形也。 至无形，谓死生变化也。 终始无端，莫知其所萌。 非通于外内，孰能无好憎？ 好憎，情欲。 无外之外，至大也； 无内之内，至贵也； 言天无有垠外，而能为之外，喻极大也。 无内，言其小，小无内，而能为之内。 道尚微妙，故曰至贵也。 能知大贵，何往而不遂。 大贵，谓无内之内也。 言道至微，能出入於无间，故曰何往而不遂。 遂，通也。 衰世凑学，不知原心反本，凑，趋也。 趋其末，不修稽古之典，苟邀名号耳，故曰不知原心反本也。 直雕琢其性，矫拂其情，以与世交，直，犹但也。 雕琢其天性，拂戾其本情，以合流俗，与世人交接也。 故目虽欲之，禁之以度，心虽乐之，节之以礼，趋翔周旋，诎节卑拜，肉凝而不食，酒澄而不饮，外束其形，内总其德，钳阴阳之和，而迫性命之情，故终身为悲人。 悲，衰也。 谓衰世之学。 达至道者则不然，理情性，治心术，养以和，持以适，乐道而忘贱，安德而忘贫，性有不欲，无欲而不得，言其守虚，执持不欲之情性，则无有所欲而不得也。 心有不乐，无乐而弗为，言其志正，不乐邪淫之乐，则无有正乐而不为乐。 言皆为之乐也。 无益情者不以累德，而便於性者不以滑〔和〕#9滑，乱。 故纵体肆意，而度制可以为天下仪。 纵，放也。 肆，缓也。 仪，法。 今夫儒者，不本其所以欲而禁其所欲，本所以欲，谓正性恬漠也。 所欲，谓情欲骄奢权势也。 不原其所以乐而闭其所乐，是犹决江河之源而障之以手也。 障，蔽也。 言不能揜也。

The people of Chu call "weary" *mei*; this refers to the state of non-knowing. In the end, one returns to the state before birth and becomes one with transformation. This speaks of the time before a person’s birth. One desires to equate death with life, hence the saying "becomes one with transformation." Death and life are of a single body.

Now consider the laborer who hoists his spade, dredges his fish trap, and carries his soil basket—*yao* means servitude. In Hedong, repairing roads is called *yao* roads. *Jie* means to lift; *jue* means to chop; *cha* is a plowshare. In Qingzhou, it is called a *hua*, for it has a blade. In the Three Adjuncts, it is called [a missing character]. The basket is a vessel for holding soil. Sweat and brine flow together, breath rasps at the throat. White sweat is salty like brine, hence called brine-sweat. *Bo* means pressing, as qi crowds the throat. At such a time, if one rests beneath the shade, one feels sudden joy. *Hao* means shade. In the Three Adjuncts, resting beneath a flowering tree is called *hao*. The people of Chu call a tree with a broad base and small top, shaped like a carriage canopy, a *yue*, for it provides ample shade. *Tuo* means relaxed. This speaks of the suspended laborer who gains a brief rest, so his qi is eased and he rejoices. *Yue* is read like the *yue* in "no double *yue*" in the classics.

In the recesses of caves, one does not merely rest in the shade. Those afflicted with illness or tumors clutch their hearts and press their bellies, bowing their heads to their knees. *Yi* means to press. *Kou* is sometimes written as *ju*, read like the *qu* in *chequ*. Curled up and still, they pass the night without sleep. At such a time, if they suddenly find rest, their kin and brothers rejoice with them. The peace of a full night’s rest is not merely the joy of a single moment’s respite. This speaks of attaining undisturbed sleep through the night. The joy of a brief respite cannot compare to the bliss of a long night’s rest.

Thus, one who knows the vastness of the cosmos cannot be coerced by life and death. *Jie* means coercion. One who knows the harmony of nurturing life cannot be swayed by the world. The harmony of nurturing life refers to the correct Dao. Having cultivated the correct Dao without confusion, one cannot be moved by the world’s dire circumstances. One who knows the joy of the time before birth cannot be frightened by death. Delighting in the state before birth, even if threatened with death, one does not fear it. This speaks of not fearing death. One who knows that Xu You was nobler than Shun does not covet things. This speaks of not coveting material desires or worldly gains.

A wall standing is not as good as it lying down; how much less so if it were never a wall at all? Ice frozen is not as good as it melted; how much less so if it were never ice? It is better than the time before the wall or ice existed, for lying down and freezing can change. From nonbeing to being, from being to nonbeing—from formless to formed, from formed to formless. Reaching formlessness refers to the transformations of life and death. Beginning and end have no origin; none know where they sprout. Without penetrating the external and internal, who can be free of likes and dislikes? Likes and dislikes are the emotions and desires.

Beyond the external is the greatest vastness; within the internal is the utmost nobility. This speaks of heaven having no outer limit yet being able to extend beyond it, illustrating its boundlessness. "Without internal" speaks of its smallness, for the smallest has no interior yet can contain an interior. The Dao values subtlety and mystery, hence it is called the utmost nobility. One who knows the greatest nobility goes nowhere without success. The greatest nobility refers to the innermost within. The Dao is so subtle that it can enter and exit without gaps, hence the saying "goes nowhere without success." *Sui* means to penetrate.

In a declining age, scholars flock to learning without understanding how to return to the origin of the heart and revert to the root. *Cou* means to flock. They rush toward the branches without studying the ancient canons, merely seeking fame and titles, hence the saying "without understanding how to return to the origin of the heart and revert to the root." They merely carve and polish their nature, suppress and distort their emotions, to engage with the world. *Zhi* means merely. They carve their innate nature and distort their true emotions to conform to世俗 and interact with others.

Thus, though their eyes desire something, they restrain themselves with measures; though their hearts delight in something, they temper themselves with ritual. They move with measured steps, bowing and scraping, their flesh congealed yet uneaten, their wine settled yet undrunk. Outwardly, they bind their forms; inwardly, they constrain their virtue. They clamp down on the harmony of yin and yang, forcing the true nature of life and destiny. Thus, they spend their lives as sorrowful beings. *Bei* means sorrowful, referring to the learning of a declining age.

Those who comprehend the ultimate Dao are not like this. They order their emotions and nature, govern their minds, nurture them with harmony, and maintain them with balance. They delight in the Dao and forget lowliness, embody virtue and forget poverty. If their nature has no desires, there is nothing they desire that they do not attain. This speaks of guarding emptiness and holding fast to the nature of non-desire, so there is nothing they desire that they do not attain. If their hearts have no joy, there is no joy they do not manifest. This speaks of their minds being upright, not delighting in perverse pleasures, so there is no proper joy they do not embrace. This speaks of all joys being realized.

What does not benefit the emotions is not used to burden virtue, and what is convenient for nature is not used to disturb harmony. Thus, they let their bodies roam freely and their intentions follow their desires, so their regulations and systems can serve as models for the world. *Zong* means to release; *si* means to relax. *Yi* means model.

Now consider the Confucians: they do not trace the root of desire yet forbid what is desired. The root of desire refers to the correct nature of tranquility and indifference. What is desired refers to the emotions and desires for arrogance, luxury, power, and influence. They do not investigate the root of joy yet block what brings joy. This is like unsealing the source of the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers yet trying to dam them with one’s hands. *Zhang* means to block, speaking of the impossibility of covering them.

chunks.original_text: 夫牧民者，犹畜禽兽也，不塞其囿垣，使有野心，系绊其足，以禁其动，而欲修生寿终，岂可得乎。 夫颜回、季路、子夏、冉伯牛，孔子之通学也。 然颜渊夭死，季路菹於卫； 颜渊＋八而卒，孔子曰，回不幸短命死矣。 故曰夭也。 季路仕於卫，卫君父子争国，季路死，孔子曰，若由不得其死然。 言不得以寿命终也，故曰然。 卫人醢之以为酱，故曰菹。 子夏失明，冉伯牛为厉。 子夏学於西河，哭其子而失明，曾子哭之。 伯牛有疾，孔子自牖执其手，曰，斯人也，而有斯疾也。 此皆迫性拂情而不得其和也。 故子夏见曾子，一臞一肥，曾子问其故，曰，出见富贵之乐而欲之，入见先王之道又说之，两者心战，故臞。 先王之道胜，故肥。 道胜，不（感）〔惑］#10县於富贵，精神内守无思虑，故肥也。 推此志，非能贪富贵之位，不便侈靡之乐，此志，子夏之志。 直宜迫性闭欲，以义自防也。 宜，犹但也。 虽情心郁殪，形性屈竭，犹不得已自强也，故莫能终其天年。 义以自防，故情心郁壹不通，形性屈竭也。 以不得止而自勉强，故无能终其天年之命。 若夫至人，量腹而食，度形而衣，容身而游，适情而行，余天下而不贪，委万物而不利，委，弃也。 不以万物为利矣。 处大廓之宇，游无极之野，廓，虚也。 极，尽也。 登太皇，冯太一，玩天地于掌握之中，太皇，天也。 冯，依也。 太一，天之形神也。 玩，畀也。 夫岂为贫富肥臞哉。 故儒者非能使人弗欲，而能止之； 言不能使人无情欲也。 己虽欲之，能以义自止也。 非能使人勿乐，而能禁之。 言不能使人无乐富贵，能以礼自禁制之。 论语曰，不义而富且贵，於我如浮云也。 夫使天下畏刑而不敢盗，岂若能使无有盗心哉。 越人得髯蛇，以为上肴，中国得而弃之无用。 髯蛇，大蛇也。 其长数丈，厚以为上肴。 故知其无所用，贪者能辞之； 不知其无所用，廉者不能让也。 夫人主之所以残亡其国家，损弃其社稷，身死於人手，为天下笑，未尝非为非欲也。 夫仇由贪大锺之赂而亡其国，仇由，近晋之狄国也。 晋智襄子伐之，先赂以大锺。 仇由之君贪，开道来受锺，为和亲。 智伯因是以兵灭取其国也。 仇，读仇余之仇也。 虞君利垂棘之璧而擒其身，晋大夫荀息谋於献公，以屈产之马，垂棘之璧，假道於虞以伐虢。 虞公贪璧马，假晋道。 既灭虢，还馆於虞，遂袭虞，灭之。 君死位曰灭，故曰擒其身也。 献公艳骊姬之美而乱四世，晋献公伐骊戎，得骊姬及其娣。 好色曰美。 好体曰艳。 献公璧之，生奚齐，其娣生卓子，遂为杀太子申生而立奚齐。 杀适立庶，故曰乱。 四世者，奚齐、卓子、惠公夷吾、怀公圉也。 桓公甘易牙之和而不以时葬，齐桓好味，易牙蒸其首子而进之，遂见信用，专任国政，乱嫡庶。 桓公卒，五公子争立，六十日而殡，虫流出户，五月不葬，故曰不以时葬也。 胡王淫女乐之娱而亡上地。 胡，盖西戎之君也。 秦穆公欲伐之，先遗女乐以淫其志。 其臣由余谏，不从，去戎来适秦。 秦伐，得其上地。 上地，美地也。 使此（王）〔五〕#11君者，适情辞余，以已为度，不随物而动，岂有此大患哉。 五君，仇由、虞公、晋献、齐桓、胡王也。 适，犹节也。
chunks.translated_text:
Those who govern the people are like herders of birds and beasts: if they do not seal off the hunting parks and enclosures, allowing wild ambitions to arise, and instead bind their feet to restrict their movement, how can they hope to cultivate life and attain longevity? Consider Yan Hui, Ji Lu, Zixia, and Ran Boniu—all were Confucius’ most accomplished disciples. Yet Yan Yuan died young, and Ji Lu was minced in Wei. Yan Yuan passed at thirty-eight, and Confucius lamented, "Hui’s untimely death was a misfortune." Thus, it is called an early death. Ji Lu served in Wei, where the ruler and his son contended for the state; Ji Lu perished, and Confucius said, "It seems You did not meet a natural end." This means he did not die of old age, hence the lament. The people of Wei pickled him into sauce, thus it is called *mincing*. Zixia lost his sight, and Ran Boniu contracted a loathsome disease. Zixia studied by the Western River; when his son died, he wept until he went blind, and Zengzi mourned for him. When Boniu fell ill, Confucius reached through the window to grasp his hand, saying, "Such a man, yet afflicted with such a disease!" All these resulted from forcing their nature and suppressing their emotions, failing to achieve harmony.

Thus, when Zixia met Zengzi, one was emaciated and the other plump. Zengzi asked the reason, and Zixia replied, "Upon going out, I saw the pleasures of wealth and nobility and desired them; upon returning, I beheld the Dao of the former kings and rejoiced in it. The two contended in my heart, hence my emaciation." When the Dao of the former kings prevailed, he grew plump. The Dao’s triumph meant he was no longer swayed by wealth and nobility, his spirit turned inward, and without anxious thoughts, he grew plump. Extending this resolve—this being Zixia’s resolve—he was not truly covetous of noble rank or indulgent in extravagant pleasures. He merely ought to have constrained his nature and restrained his desires, using righteousness as his defense. *Ought* here means *only*. Though his emotions were stifled and his form and nature exhausted, he still forced himself to endure, yet could not fulfill his natural lifespan. Using righteousness as a defense, his emotions became pent-up and stagnant, his form and nature worn out. Unable to cease, he compelled himself, thus none could complete their Heaven-appointed years.

As for the perfected person, they eat according to their stomach’s measure, dress according to their body’s needs, roam where they find shelter, and act as their emotions incline. They relinquish the world without greed and abandon all things without seeking profit. *Relinquish* means to discard, not treating all things as advantageous. They dwell in the vast expanse of the universe, wander the boundless wilds—*expanse* meaning emptiness, *boundless* meaning limitless. They ascend the Great Sovereign, rely upon the Great Unity, and hold heaven and earth in their grasp. The *Great Sovereign* is Heaven; *rely* means to depend upon; the *Great Unity* is the form and spirit of Heaven; *hold* means to embrace. How could they be concerned with poverty or wealth, plumpness or emaciation?

Thus, the Confucians cannot prevent people from desiring, but can only restrain them—meaning they cannot eliminate human emotions and desires, yet though they themselves may desire, they can use righteousness to restrain themselves. They cannot prevent people from finding joy, but can only forbid it—meaning they cannot stop people from delighting in wealth and nobility, yet can use ritual to restrain themselves. As the *Analects* says, "Wealth and nobility obtained through unrighteousness are to me like floating clouds." Is making the world fear punishment and dare not steal truly better than eliminating the very thought of theft? The people of Yue prized bearded serpents as the finest delicacy, while those of the Central States discarded them as useless. *Bearded serpents* are giant snakes, several *zhang* in length, which the Yue considered a supreme dish. Knowing their uselessness, even the greedy can refuse them; not knowing their uselessness, even the incorruptible cannot decline.

Now, the reason rulers bring ruin to their states, abandon their altars of soil and grain, die at the hands of others, and become a laughingstock to the world is never unrelated to their perverse desires. The lord of Chou You coveted the great bells’ bribe and lost his state. Chou You was a Di state near Jin. When Jin’s Viscount Zhi Xiang attacked, he first offered a great bell as a bribe. The lord of Chou You, greedy, opened the road to receive the bell, seeking peace. Viscount Zhi then used this pretext to invade and annihilate the state. *Chou* is read as *chou yu*. The lord of Yu desired the jade of Chui Ji and was captured. When Jin’s minister Xun Xi plotted with Duke Xian, he used the horses of Qu Chan and the jade of Chui Ji to borrow passage through Yu to attack Guo. The lord of Yu, coveting the jade and horses, granted Jin passage. After destroying Guo, Jin turned back to lodge in Yu and then attacked, annihilating it. When a ruler dies and his position is lost, it is called *annihilation*, hence it is said he was *captured*. Duke Xian was infatuated with Li Ji’s beauty and threw four generations into chaos. When Duke Xian of Jin attacked the Li Rong, he obtained Li Ji and her younger sister. *Infatuated* refers to her beauty of form; *enamored* refers to her beauty of appearance. Duke Xian favored her, and she bore Xi Qi; her sister bore Zhuo Zi. He then killed the crown prince Shen Sheng and enthroned Xi Qi. Killing the legitimate heir to establish a concubine’s son is called *chaos*. The four generations were Xi Qi, Zhuo Zi, Duke Hui (Yi Wu), and Duke Huai (Yu). Duke Huan savored Yi Ya’s delicacies and failed to bury him in a timely manner. Duke Huan of Qi loved fine flavors; Yi Ya steamed his eldest son and presented him, thus gaining trust and monopolizing state power, sowing discord between the legitimate heir and concubine’s sons. When Duke Huan died, his five sons contended for the throne; his corpse lay in state for sixty days, maggots crawling from the door, and he was not buried for five months, hence it is said he was *not buried in a timely manner*. The king of Hu indulged in women and music’s pleasures and lost his finest lands. Hu was likely a ruler of the Western Rong. When Duke Mu of Qin wished to attack, he first sent female musicians to corrupt his resolve. His minister You Yu remonstrated, but he did not heed, so You Yu left the Rong and went to Qin. Qin then attacked and seized his finest lands. *Finest lands* means fertile territory.

Had these five rulers—of Chou You, Yu, Jin, Qi, and Hu—moderated their emotions, declined excess, taken themselves as the measure, and not been swayed by external things, how could they have suffered such great disasters? The five rulers are those of Chou You, Yu, Duke Xian of Jin, Duke Huan of Qi, and the king of Hu. *Moderated* means *restrained*.

chunks.original_text: 动，犹惑也。 故射者非矢不中也，学射者不治矢也； 不治矢，言不为而得用之。 然则为者不得用之。 御者非辔不行，学御者不为辔也。 知冬日之箑，夏日之裘无用於己，则万物之变为尘埃矣。 故以汤止沸，沸乃不止； 诚知其本，则去火而已矣。 箑，扇也。 楚人谓扇为箑。 已，止也。 淮南鸿烈解卷之十二竟 #1脱『闵』字，据集解本补。 #2『他』，『也』字之误，据集解本改。 #3『面』，『血』字之误，据集解本改。 #4#5脱『之哉』二字，据集解本补。 #6『六』，『天』字之误，据集解本改。 #7『子』，『与」字之误，据集解本改。 #8『尤』，『左』字之误，据集解本改。 #9『和』字脱，据集解本补。 #10『感』，『惑』字之误，据集解本改。 #11『王』，『五』字之误。 据集解本改。 淮南鸿烈解卷之十三

Movement is like delusion. Thus, an archer does not hit the mark without arrows, yet one who learns archery does not craft arrows—meaning one obtains their use without making them. Yet those who craft them do not obtain their use.

A charioteer does not drive without reins, yet one who learns charioteering does not make reins. If one knows that a fan is useless in winter and fur robes are useless in summer, then the myriad transformations of things become mere dust.

Thus, pouring water to stop boiling only fails to halt it; if one truly knows the root, one need only remove the fire. *箑* means *fan*. The people of Chu call a fan *箑*. *已* means *to cease*.
