chunks.original_text: 太尉祭酒臣许慎记上 本经训 本，始也。 经，常也。 天经造化出於道，治乱之由，得失有常，故曰本经，因以题篇也。 太清之始也，和顺以寂漠，清，静也。 太清，无为之始者。 谓三皇之时和顺，不逆天暴物也。 寂漠，不扰民。 质真而素朴，闲静而不躁，推而无故，质，性也。 真，不变也。 素朴，精不散也。 闲静，言无欲也。 不躁扰，故常也。 在内而合乎道，出於外而调于义，在内者，志在心。 平欲，故能合於道。 出於外者，身所履行也。 行不越规矩，故能调义。 义或作德也。 发动而成于文，行快而便于物，发，作也。 动，行也。 文，文章也。 便，利也。 物，事也。 其言略而循理，其行悦而顺情，略，约要也。 侻，简易也。 侻读射侻取不觉之侻也。 其心愉而不伪，其事素而不饰。 愉，和也。 伪，虚诈也。 素，朴也。 饰，巧也。 是以不择时日，不占卦兆，择，选也。 卦，八卦也。 兆，契龟之兆也。 世所以占吉凶也。 不谋所始，不议所终，安则止，激则行，通体于天地，同精于阴阳，一和于四时，一，同也。 明照于日月，与造化者相雌雄。 造化，天地也。 雌雄，犹和适也。 是以天覆以德，地载以乐，乐，生也。 四时不失其叙，风雨不降其虐，日月淑清而扬光，光，明也。 五星循轨而不失其行。 五星，荧惑、太白、镇、辰、岁星也。 轨，道也。 循，顺也。 当此之时，玄元至砀而运照，玄，天也。 元，气也。 砀，大也。 言盛德之君，恩仁广大，徧照四海也。 凤麟至，蓍龟兆，凤麟圣德之世至於门庭。 着，四十九策。 兆，信也。 善言否臧也。 甘露下，竹实满，流黄出，而朱草生，满，成也。 流黄，玉也。 朱草生於庭，皆瑞应也。 机械诈伪莫藏于心。 莫，无也。 逮至衰世，镌山石，，犹凿也，求金玉也。 锲金玉，擿蚌蜃，锲刻金玉以为器也。 擿，犹开也，开以求珠也。 消铜铁，而万物不滋。 不滋长也，言尽物类也。 刳胎杀夭，麒麟不游，胎，兽胎也。 夭，麋子也。 为类见害，故不来游。 覆巢毁卵，凤凰不翔。 鸟未鷇曰卵也。 钻燧取火，构木为台，焚林而田，竭泽而渔，田，猎也。 竭泽，漏池也。 人械不足，畜藏有余，械，器用也。 畜积藏余，府库实也。 而万物不繁兆，萌牙卵胎而不成者，处之太半矣。 积壤而丘处，粪田而种谷，掘地而井饮，疏川而为利，疏，通。 筑城而为固，拘兽以为畜，则阴阳缪戾，四时失叙，雷霆毁折，电霰降虐，气雾雪霜不霁，霁，止也。 而万物燋夭。 霜雪之害不止，则万物燋夭不繁茂也。 菑榛秽，聚埒亩，菑草曰茂，木聚曰榛，积之於疆亩。 芟野菼，长苗秀，芟，杀也。 菼，草也。 苗，稼也。 不荣而实曰秀也。 草木之句萌、衔华、戴实而死者，不可胜数。 乃至夏屋宫驾，县联房植，夏屋，大屋也。 县联，联受雀头着桷者。 一曰，辟带也。 房，室也。 植，户植也。 橑檐榱题，橑，檐橑也。 檐，屋垂也。 榱，栋也。 题，当也。 雕琢刻镂，乔枝菱阿，芙蓉芰荷，阿，曲屋也。 芙蓉，藕华也。 菱角，交萏也。 荷，芙蕖也。 五采争胜，流漫陆离，流漫采色相参和。 陆离，美好貌。 修掞曲校，夭矫曾桡，芒繁纷挐，皆屋饰也。 （其）〔芒〕#1读麦芒之芒，挐读上谷茹县之茹。
chunks.translated_text:
The Grand Commandant and Libationer, your servant Xu Shen, respectfully records:

This *Benjing Xun* begins with *ben* (root). *Jing* means constancy. The constant transformations of Heaven emerge from the Dao/Way, and the causes of order and chaos, of gain and loss, are ever-fixed. Thus it is called *Benjing* (Root and Constancy), and the title of the scroll follows accordingly.

The inception of the Great Clarity (*Taiqing*) is harmony and compliance, serene and still. *Qing* means tranquility. *Taiqing* is the beginning of non-action. It refers to the era of the Three Sovereigns, when harmony and compliance prevailed, neither opposing Heaven nor harming creatures. *Jimo* (serene and still) means not disturbing the people. Their nature was true and unadorned, their essence pure and undispersed. They were leisurely and quiet, free from restlessness. *Zhi* means nature; *zhen* means unchanging; *supo* (unadorned simplicity) means essence undispersed. *Xianjing* (leisurely and quiet) means desireless. Without disturbance, they remained constant.

Internally, they aligned with the Dao/Way; externally, they harmonized with righteousness. *Internally* refers to the will residing in the heart. By moderating desires, they could align with the Dao/Way. *Externally* refers to the conduct they practiced. Their actions did not transgress rules and norms, thus they could harmonize with righteousness. (Righteousness may also be rendered as virtue/power.) Their actions manifested in refinement, their conduct swift and beneficial to all things. *Fa* (manifest) means to initiate; *dong* (act) means to move. *Wen* means refinement; *bian* (beneficial) means advantage; *wu* (things) means affairs.

Their words were concise yet followed principle; their conduct was joyful yet accorded with human feelings. *Lüe* (concise) means essential and succinct. *Tuo* (joyful) means simple and easy. *Tuo* is read as in *she tuo* (unnoticed swiftness in archery). Their hearts were joyful yet without deceit; their affairs were plain yet without adornment. *Yu* (joyful) means harmony; *wei* (deceit) means falsehood and cunning. *Su* (plain) means unadorned; *shi* (adornment) means artifice.

Thus, they did not select auspicious days or divine through hexagrams and omens. *Ze* (select) means to choose; *gua* (hexagrams) refers to the eight trigrams; *zhao* (omens) refers to the cracks in tortoise shells. These were the means by which the world divined fortune and misfortune. They did not scheme over beginnings or debate endings. When at ease, they rested; when pressed, they acted. Their entire being merged with Heaven and Earth, their essence aligned with yin and yang. They harmonized with the four seasons. *Yi* (harmonized) means united. They shone brightly like the sun and moon, and vied with the creators in balance. *Zaohua* (creators) refers to Heaven and Earth; *cixiong* (balance) means harmony and accord.

Thus, Heaven covered all with virtue/power, Earth bore all with joy. *Le* (joy) means life. The four seasons did not err in their sequence; wind and rain did not descend with cruelty. The sun and moon were pure and radiant. *Guang* (radiant) means brightness. The five planets followed their paths without deviating from their courses. The five planets are Mars, Venus, Saturn, Jupiter, and Mercury. *Gui* (paths) means courses; *xun* (followed) means compliance.

In this era, the mysterious origin reached its vastness and radiated illumination. *Xuan* means Heaven; *yuan* means qi. *Dang* (vastness) means greatness. It speaks of a ruler of utmost virtue/power, whose benevolence and kindness were boundless, illuminating all within the four seas. Phoenixes and unicorns arrived; milfoil and tortoise shells divined. Phoenixes and unicorns appeared at the gates of an era of sagely virtue/power. *Shi* (milfoil) refers to the forty-nine stalks; *zhao* (divination) means trust. They spoke truly of good and ill fortune. Sweet dew descended; bamboo bore fruit in abundance; flowing yellow emerged; and vermilion grass grew. *Man* (abundance) means fulfillment. *Liuhuang* (flowing yellow) refers to jade. The growth of vermilion grass in courtyards—all were auspicious signs.

Cunning devices and deceit did not lodge in their hearts. *Mo* means without. By the time of the degenerate age, mountains were quarried for stone, and metals and jades were sought. *Juan* (quarried) means chiseled, to seek gold and jade. Gold and jade were carved into vessels; clams and oysters were pried open. *Qie* (carved) means to engrave; *ti* (pried) means to open, to seek pearls. Copper and iron were smelted, yet the myriad things did not flourish. They did not grow, meaning all things were exhausted.

Fetuses were destroyed, and the young were killed. Unicorns did not roam. *Tai* (fetuses) refers to animal embryos; *yao* (young) refers to fawns. As their kind were harmed, they did not come to roam. Nests were overturned, and eggs were shattered. Phoenixes did not soar. Eggs refer to those not yet hatched. Fire was drilled from wood; towers were constructed from timber. Forests were burned for the hunt; marshes were drained for fishing. *Tian* (hunt) means to chase game; *jie ze* (drained marshes) means to empty pools.

Tools were insufficient, yet stored goods were in surplus. *Xie* (tools) refers to implements; *xu zang* (stored goods) means accumulated reserves filling storehouses. Yet the myriad things did not multiply in signs. Sprouts, buds, eggs, and embryos failed to mature—more than half perished.

Earth was piled into mounds for dwelling; fields were manured to grow grain. Wells were dug for drinking; rivers were dredged for benefit. *Shu* (dredged) means cleared. Walls were built for defense; beasts were captured for domestication. Then yin and yang became disordered, the four seasons lost their sequence. Thunder and lightning wrought destruction; hail and sleet descended cruelly. Mists, snow, and frost did not clear. *Ji* (clear) means to cease. And the myriad things withered and died. The harm of frost and snow unceasing, the myriad things withered and failed to flourish.

Thorns and brambles overgrew; weeds and brush filled the fields. *Zi* (thorns) refers to dense grass; *zhen* (brambles) refers to clustered trees, heaped in the fields. Wild grasses were cut down; seedlings and grain stalks grew. *Shan* (cut) means to kill; *tan* (wild grasses) refers to weeds; *miao* (seedlings) refers to crops. They did not bloom yet bore fruit—this is called *xiu* (fruiting without flowering). The sprouting, flowering, and fruiting of grasses and trees, only to die—these were beyond counting.

Then came vast halls and towering palaces, linked chambers and aligned pillars. *Xiawu* (vast halls) means great houses; *xianlian* (linked chambers) refers to connected eaves where sparrows nested. Another says it means ornamental belts. *Fang* (chambers) means rooms; *zhi* (pillars) refers to doorposts. Eaves and beams, rafters and ridgepoles—*lao* (eaves) refers to the eaves beams; *yan* (beams) refers to the overhanging roof; *cui* (rafters) refers to the ridgepoles; *ti* (ridgepoles) means aligned.

Carved and chiseled, towering branches and winding eaves, lotus and water chestnut, coiling roofs and curved halls—*furong* (lotus) refers to the flower of the lotus root; *lingjiao* (water chestnut) refers to the horned water caltrop; *he* (water lily) refers to the lotus. Five colors vied in splendor, flowing and mingling in dazzling beauty. *Liuman* (flowing) means colors intermingling; *luli* (dazzling) means splendid in appearance. Curved and twisted beams, supple and bending rafters, sharp and tangled, dense and intertwined—all were adornments of the halls. *Mang* (sharp) is read as in *mai mang* (wheat awn); *na* (tangled) is read as in *Ruxian* of Shanggu.

chunks.original_text: 以相交持，公输、王尔无所错其剞削锯，公输，巧者。 一曰鲁班之号也。 王尔，古之巧匠也。 剖，巧刺画尽头黑边笺也。 ，尺。 削，两刃句刀也。 剖，读枝尺之枝也。 ，读诗蹶角之蹶。 削，读绡头之绡也。 然犹未能赡人主之欲也。 是以松柏菌露夏槁，松柏根茂，菌露竹筦，皆冬生难杀之木，当是时夏槁死也。 刺君作事不时，阴阳失序。 菌读似纶。 露，读南阳人言道路之路。 江、河、三川绝而不流，泾、渭、汧也，出於岐山。 绝，竭也。 故曰不流。 国语曰，何竭而商亡也。 夷羊在牧，夷羊，土神。 殷之将亡，见於商郊牧野之地。 飞蛮满野，蛩，蝉，蠛蠓之属也。 一曰蝗也。 兖州谓之螣。 螣读近殆，缓气言之。 蛩，读诗受拱之拱。 天旱地坼，坼，燥裂也。 凤凰不下，句爪、居牙、戴角、出距之兽於是鸷矣。 句爪，鹰鹯之属也。 居牙，熊虎之属也。 距读拒守之拒。 民之专室蓬庐，无所归宿，专，特小室也。 蓬庐，籧蒢覆也。 言小，有宾客归之，无所庇宿也。 冻饿饥寒死者，相枕席也。 言其众也。 及至分山溪谷使有壤界，计人多少众寡使有分数，筑城掘池，设机械险阻以为备，饰职事，制服等，等，差也。 异贵贱，差贤不肖，经诽誉，行赏罚，经，书也。 诽恶誉善，赏可赏，罚可罚也。 则兵革兴而分争生，民之灭抑天隐，虐杀不辜而刑诛无罪，於是生矣。 抑，役也。 言民有灭役夭折之痛。 天地之合和，阴阳之陶化万物，皆乘人气者也。 天地合和其气，故生阴阳，陶化万物。 是故上下离心，气乃上蒸，离者，不和也。 君臣不和，五谷不为。 不为五谷。 距日冬至四十六日，天含和而未降也，怀气而未扬，自立冬到冬至皆未动也。 阴阳储与，呼吸浸潭，包裹风俗，储与，犹尚羊，无所生之貌也。 一曰，褒大貌也。 浸潭，广衍。 故曰包裹风俗也。 斟酌万殊，旁薄众宜，旁，并也。 薄，近也。 众物宜适也。 以相呕咐酝酿，而成育群生。 咐读符命之符。 酝酿，犹和调也。 是故春肃秋荣，冬雷夏霜，皆贼气之所生。 由此观之，天地宇宙，一人之身也； 以身谕也。 六合之内，一人之制也。 六合，四方上下也。 是故明於性者，天地不能胁也； 胁，恐也。 审於符者，怪物不能惑也。 审，明也。 符，验也。 怪物非常，人所疑惑也。 故圣人者，由近知远，而万殊为一。 殊，异也。 一，同也。 古之人，同气于天地，与一世而优游。 优游，犹委从也。 当此之时，无庆贺之利，刑罚之（感）〔威〕#2礼义廉耻不设，毁誉仁鄙不立，而万民莫相侵欺暴虐，犹在于混冥之中。 混，大也。 大冥之中，谓道也。 逮至衰世，人众财寡，事力劳而养不足，於是忿争生，是以贵仁。 仁鄙不齐，比周朋党，设诈谞，怀机械巧故之心，而性失矣，谞，谋也。 性失，失其纯朴之性也。 是以贵义。 阴阳之情，莫不有血气之感，男女群居杂处而无别，是以贵礼。 礼以别也。 性命之情，淫而相胁，胁，迫。 以不得己，则不和，是以贵乐。 以乐和之。 是故仁义礼乐者，可以救败，而非通治之至也。 夫仁者所以救争也，义者所以救失也，礼者所以救淫也，乐者所以救忧也。 神明定於天下，而心反其初，心反其初，而民性善，初者，始也，有情也。
chunks.translated_text:
The timbers interlock and support one another, yet even the craft of Gongshu or Wang Er—with no need for their adzes, *ji* knives, or saws—could not suffice for the desires of rulers. Gongshu was a master artisan; one account calls him the sobriquet of Lu Ban. Wang Er was an ancient master craftsman. *Pou* (剖) refers to the skillful carving of black-bordered patterns to their edges. *Ji* () is the carpenter’s square. *Xue* (削) is a double-edged hooked knife. *Pou* is pronounced like *zhi* in *zhi chi* (measuring rod); *ji* like *jue* in *jue jiao* (stumbling); *xue* like *xiao* in *xiao tou* (silk headband). Yet even so, they could not satisfy the ruler’s desires.

Thus, pine and cypress withered in summer, their roots robust yet their foliage scorched; bamboo shoots and fungal growths sprouted in winter—these were woods hardy against the cold, yet at that time, even they perished in the summer drought. This was because the ruler’s actions defied the seasons, disrupting the harmony of yin and yang. *Jun* (菌) is pronounced like *lun* (纶); *lu* (露) like *lu* in the southern Yang dialect for "road." The Jiang, the He, and the Three Rivers ran dry and ceased to flow—the Jing, the Wei, and the Qian, all rising from Mount Qi. *Jue* (绝) means exhausted; hence, "ceased to flow." As the *Guoyu* states: "How could the Shang perish if not for exhaustion?" The *yiyang* beast grazed in the fields—the *yiyang* was a earth spirit. When the Yin was on the verge of collapse, it appeared in the outskirts of Shang, in the pastures of Muye. Flying insects filled the wilds—*qiong* (蛩), cicadas, and midges, or in another account, locusts. In Yanzhou, they were called *teng*. *Teng* is pronounced near *dai*, with a drawn-out breath. *Qiong* is pronounced like *gong* in *shou gong* (受拱). The land cracked from drought, *che* (坼) meaning parched and split. The phoenix did not descend, and beasts with hooked claws, bared fangs, crested horns, and spurred talons grew fierce—*gou zhao* (句爪) referred to eagles and hawks; *ju ya* (居牙) to bears and tigers. *Ju* (距) is pronounced like *ju* in *ju shou* (拒守).

The people dwelled in thatched huts and hovels, with nowhere to seek shelter—*zhuan* (专) meant small, solitary dwellings; *peng lu* (蓬庐) were shelters of woven reeds. If guests arrived, there was no refuge to offer. Those who froze or starved, who perished from hunger or cold, lay piled like mattresses—so numerous were they. Only when mountains and valleys were divided into territories, when populations were tallied and apportioned, when walls were raised and moats dug, when traps and fortifications were set as defenses, when offices were adorned and ranks established—*deng* (等) meaning distinctions—when noble and base were differentiated, worthy and unworthy distinguished, when records of praise and blame were kept, when rewards and punishments were meted out—*jing* (经) meaning inscribed, *fei* (诽) for condemnation, *yu* (誉) for acclaim—only then did arms rise and strife arise. The people were crushed and oppressed, their nature obscured; the innocent were slaughtered, and the blameless executed—such was the world that emerged.

*Yi* (抑) means servitude; the people suffered the agony of annihilation and premature death. The union of Heaven and Earth, the molding of the myriad things by yin and yang—all depend on the qi of humanity. When Heaven and Earth harmonize their qi, yin and yang arise, shaping the ten thousand things. Thus, when ruler and minister grow estranged, qi ascends in steam—*li* (离) means discord. When lord and subject are at odds, the five grains fail to grow. From the winter solstice to the forty-sixth day thereafter, Heaven holds its harmony but does not yet descend; it harbors qi but does not yet release it. From the onset of winter to the solstice, all remains inert. Yin and yang gather and linger, breathing in slow, deep currents, enveloping customs and mores—*chu yu* (储与) means lingering, as in *shang yang* (尚羊), a state of suspended generation. Another account calls it vast and expansive. *Jin tan* (浸潭) means broad and overflowing; hence, "enveloping customs and mores." Measuring the myriad differences, balancing the needs of all—*pang* (旁) means alongside; *bo* (薄) means near. All things find their proper place. Through mutual exchange and fermentation, they nurture the multitude of life. *Fu* (咐) is pronounced like *fu* in *fu ming* (符命); *yun niang* (酝酿) means harmonious blending.

Thus, spring’s solemnity and autumn’s flourishing, winter’s thunder and summer’s frost—all arise from perverse qi. From this perspective, Heaven and Earth, the cosmos, are as one body—an analogy drawn from the self. The six directions—all within the realm of a single person’s control. The six directions are the four quarters, above and below. Therefore, one who understands nature cannot be coerced by Heaven and Earth—*xie* (胁) means intimidation. One who discerns signs cannot be deluded by strange phenomena—*shen* (审) means clarity; *fu* (符) means verification. Strange phenomena are the abnormal, which bewilder people.

Thus, the sage infers the distant from the near, unifying the myriad differences—*shu* (殊) means divergence; *yi* (一) means unity. The ancients harmonized their qi with Heaven and Earth, moving in ease with their age. *You you* (优游) means yielding and following. In that time, there was no profit in celebration, no awe in punishment—*wei* (威) originally written as *gan* (感)—no rites, no duty, no integrity, no shame; no praise or blame for benevolence or baseness. Yet the people did not encroach upon or deceive one another, nor did they commit violence—all remained within the great obscurity. *Hun* (混) means vast; the vast obscurity refers to the Dao.

When the age declined, people multiplied while resources dwindled; toil increased, yet sustenance was insufficient. Thus, resentment and strife arose, and benevolence was prized. Yet benevolence and baseness were unequal; cliques and factions formed, deceit and cunning flourished, hearts filled with artifice and guile—and human nature was lost. *Xu* (谞) means scheming; *xing shi* (性失) means the loss of pure, unadulterated nature. Thus, righteousness was prized. The passions of yin and yang, all beings endowed with blood and qi, men and women dwelling together without distinction—thus, rites were prized. Rites serve to differentiate. The impulses of life and destiny, when excessive and coercive—*xie* (胁) means compulsion—when driven by necessity, lead to disharmony. Thus, music was prized, for music brings harmony.

Therefore, benevolence, righteousness, rites, and music can remedy decline, but they are not the ultimate path to universal governance. Benevolence remedies strife; righteousness remedies loss; rites remedy excess; music remedies sorrow. When the numinous clarity is established throughout the world, and the heart returns to its origin—when the heart returns to its origin, the people’s nature becomes good. The origin is the beginning, the state of pure emotion.

chunks.original_text: 未有情欲，故性善也。 民性善，而天地阴阳从而包之，则财足而人赡矣，贪鄙忿争不得生焉。 由此观之，则仁义不用矣。 道德定於天下而民纯朴，则目不营於色，营，惑。 耳不淫於声，坐俳而歌谣，被发而浮（淫）〔游〕#3，虽有毛嫱、西施之色，不知悦也，言尚德也。 掉羽、武象，不知乐也。 掉羽，羽舞也。 武象，周武王乐也。 淫泆无别，不得生焉。 由此观之，礼乐不用也。 是故德衰然后仁生，行沮然后义立，沮，败也。 和失然后声调，礼淫然后容饰。 是故知神明然后知道德之不足为也，知道德然后知仁义之不足行也，道德本，仁义末。 知仁义然后知礼乐之不足修也。 仁义大也，礼乐小也。 今背其本而求其末，释其要而索之于详，未可与言至也。 至，至德之道也。 天地之大，可以矩表识也； 矩，度也。 表，影表。 识，知也。 星月之行，可以历推得也； 历，术也。 推，求也。 雷震之声，可以鼓锺写也； 写，犹放教也。 风雨之变，可以音律知也。 律知阴阳。 是故大可睹者，可得而量也； 明可见者，可得而蔽也； 蔽或作察。 声可闻者，可得而调也； 色可察者，可得而别也。 夫至大，天地弗能含也； 至微，神明弗能领也。 领，理也。 及至建律历，别五色，异清浊，清商，浊宫。 味甘苦，则朴散而为器矣。 立仁义，修礼乐，则德迁而为伪矣。 修，设也。 迁，移也。 及伪之生也，饰智以惊愚，设诈以巧上，巧欺上也。 天下有能持之者，有能治之者也。 有能持之者，桀、纣之民。 有能治之者，汤、武之君也。 昔者苍颉作书而天雨粟，鬼夜哭； 苍颉始视乌迹之文，造书有契，则诈伪萌生，诈伪萌生，则去本趋末，弃耕作之业，而务锥刀之利。 天知其将饿，故为雨粟。 鬼恐为书文所效，故夜哭也。 鬼或作兔，兔恐见取毫作笔，害及其躯，故夜哭。 伯益作井，而龙登玄云，神栖昆仑； 伯益佐舜，初作井，凿地而求水。 龙知将决川谷，洒陂池，恐见害，故登云而去，栖其神於昆仑之山也。 能愈多而德愈薄矣。 愈，益也。
chunks.translated_text:
Before desires arise, thus is nature good. When the people’s nature is good, and heaven and earth, yin and yang, envelop them, then resources suffice and people abound—greed, baseness, wrath, and strife cannot arise. From this perspective, benevolence and righteousness are no longer needed.

When the Dao and its virtue are established throughout the world and the people remain pure and simple, the eye does not covet beauty—*ying* (营) means infatuation—the ear is not seduced by sound. They sit idly singing folk songs, hair unbound wandering freely. Though Mao Qiang and Xi Shi’s beauty be before them, they know no delight, for they esteem virtue. The dances of *Diaoyu* and *Wuxiang*—*Diaoyu* being the feather dance, *Wuxiang* the music of King Wu of Zhou—they know no joy. Wantonness and excess, with no distinction, cannot arise. From this perspective, rites and music are no longer needed.

Thus, when virtue declines, benevolence arises; when conduct falters, righteousness is established—*ju* (沮) means ruin. When harmony is lost, tones and tunes emerge; when rites become excessive, adornments follow. Therefore, only when one knows the numinous clarity does one realize the insufficiency of the Dao and its virtue. Only when one knows the Dao and its virtue does one realize the insufficiency of benevolence and righteousness—the Dao and its virtue are the root, benevolence and righteousness the branches. Only when one knows benevolence and righteousness does one realize the insufficiency of rites and music—benevolence and righteousness are great, rites and music small.

Now, to turn from the root and seek the branches, to abandon the essential and pursue the elaborate—this is no way to speak of the ultimate. The ultimate is the Way of supreme virtue.

The vastness of heaven and earth can be measured by the carpenter’s square and gnomon—*ju* (矩) means measure, *biao* (表) the shadow staff, *shi* (识) knowledge. The movements of stars and moon can be calculated by calendrical arts—*li* (历) means method, *tui* (推) to deduce. The sound of thunder can be imitated by drums and bells—*xie* (写) means to replicate or teach. The changes of wind and rain can be known through musical tuning, for tuning discerns yin and yang.

Thus, what is vast and visible can be measured; what is bright and apparent can be obscured—*bi* (蔽) may also mean observed. What is audible can be harmonized; what is perceptible in color can be distinguished. Yet the supremely great, heaven and earth cannot contain; the supremely subtle, the numinous clarity cannot govern—*ling* (领) means to order.

When one establishes calendrical arts, distinguishes the five colors, and separates the pure from the turbid—*qingshang* being the pure, *zhuogong* the turbid—when one discriminates sweet and bitter tastes, then simplicity scatters and becomes vessels. When one institutes benevolence and righteousness, cultivates rites and music, then virtue shifts and becomes artifice—*xiu* (修) means to establish, *qian* (迁) to transform.

Once artifice arises, cunning is adorned to startle the foolish, deceit is devised to deceive superiors. In the world, some can uphold this, some can govern it. Those who uphold it are the people of Jie and Zhou; those who govern it are the lords Tang and Wu.

Of old, Cang Jie created writing, and heaven rained grain while ghosts wept at night. Cang Jie first observed the patterns of birds’ tracks and devised written contracts—thus deception and falsehood sprouted. When deception and falsehood sprout, one turns from the root to the branches, abandons the work of plowing and weaving, and pursues the profit of needle and knife. Heaven, knowing they would starve, thus rained grain. Ghosts, fearing they would be imitated by written words, wept at night—*gui* (鬼) may also be *tu* (兔), the hare, fearing its fur would be taken for brushes, harming its body, thus wept at night.

Bo Yi dug the first well, and dragons ascended dark clouds while spirits dwelled on Kunlun. Bo Yi, assisting Shun, first dug wells to seek water. Dragons, knowing rivers and valleys would be drained, ponds and reservoirs breached, feared harm and thus ascended clouds, their spirits dwelling on Kunlun’s mountain.

The more abilities increase, the thinner virtue grows. *Yu* (愈) means to increase.

chunks.original_text: 故周鼎着倕，使衔其指，以明大巧之不可为也。 倕，尧之巧工也。 及周铸鼎，着倕像於鼎，使衔其指。 假令倕在见之，伎巧不能复踰，但当衔啮其指，故曰以明巧之不可为也。 一说，周人铸鼎画像，镂倕身於鼎，使自衔其指，以戒后世，明不当大巧为也。 故至人之治也，心与神处，形〔与性］#4调，静而体德，动而理通，随自然之性而缘不得已之化，洞然无为而天下自和，澹然无欲而民自朴，无机祥而民不夭，不忿争而养足，兼苞海内，泽及后世，不知为之者谁何。 道无姓名，自当然也，故曰，不知谁何也。 是故生无号，死无谧，实不聚而名不立，实，财也。 道不名，故名不立。 施者不德，受者不让，施者不以为恩德，振不足而已。 受者不让之，则受之，不饰辞让也。 德交归焉而莫之充忍也。 忍，不忍也。 故德之所总，道弗能害也； 总，一也。 智之所不知，辩弗能解也。 有智谋者尚不能知，但口辩者何不解也。 不言之辩，不道之道，若或通焉，谓之天府。 或，有也。 有能通不言之辩，不道之道者，入天之府藏。 取焉而不损，损，减也。 酌焉而不竭，酌，犹予。 竭，尽也。 莫知其所由出，是谓瑶光。 瑶光者，资粮万物者也。 瑶光，谓北斗杓第七星也。 居中而运，历指十二辰，擿起阴阳，以杀生万物也。 一说，瑶光，和气之见者也。 振困穷，补不足，则名生； 名，仁名也。 兴利除害，伐乱禁暴，则成功。 功，武功也。 世无灾害，虽神无所施其德； 上下和辑，虽贤无所立其功。

Thus, the Zhou tripods depicted Chui with his fingers in his mouth, to demonstrate that great craft cannot be forced. Chui was the master artisan of Yao. When the Zhou cast the tripods, they engraved Chui’s likeness upon them, his fingers held in his mouth. Had Chui lived to see it, his skill could not have surpassed it—he could only bite his fingers in awe. Hence it is said: this clarifies that craft cannot be forced.

Another account holds that the Zhou, in casting the tripods, carved Chui’s form upon them, making him bite his own fingers as a warning to later ages, showing that one ought not force great craft.

Therefore, the governance of the perfected person is such that the heart abides with spirit, form harmonizes with nature, stillness embodies virtue, and motion accords with principle. Following the natural disposition and adhering to inevitable transformations, one acts with effortless clarity, and the world harmonizes of itself. With serene desirelessness, the people return to simplicity. Without omens or portents, the people do not die young. Without strife or contention, nurturance suffices. Embracing all within the seas, beneficence extends to later generations—yet none know who it is that effects this.

The Dao has no name; it is simply so of itself. Hence it is said: none know who it is.

Thus, in life there is no title, in death no posthumous name. Substance does not accumulate, and names are not established. *Substance* here means wealth. The Dao is not named, so names are not established.

The giver does not claim virtue, the receiver does not decline. The giver does not regard it as a favor but merely aids the needy. The receiver does not refuse but accepts without embellished modesty. Virtue and exchange return to it, yet none can bear to withhold it. *Bear* here means *not bear*.

Therefore, where virtue is unified, the Dao cannot harm it. *Unified* means *as one*. Where wisdom does not reach, eloquence cannot resolve it. Even the most cunning cannot know it; how could mere words untangle it?

The eloquence of silence, the Dao of non-discourse—should one penetrate these, it is called the Celestial Treasury. *Penetrate* means *to attain*. One who attains the eloquence of silence and the Dao of non-discourse enters the treasury of Heaven.

Draw from it without depletion; *depletion* means *diminishment*. Bestow from it without exhaustion; *bestow* means *to give*, and *exhaustion* means *to deplete*. None know whence it arises—this is called *Yaoguang*.

*Yaoguang* is that which provisions the myriad things. *Yaoguang* refers to the seventh star of the Northern Dipper’s handle. Abiding at the center, it revolves, pointing through the twelve celestial branches, stirring yin and yang to give life and death to the myriad things.

Another account holds that *Yaoguang* is the manifestation of harmonious qi. When it relieves the destitute and supplements the deficient, a name arises—*name* here means *benevolent renown*. When it promotes benefit, removes harm, punishes disorder, and restrains violence, success is achieved—*success* here means *martial achievement*.

In an age without calamity, even spirits have no virtue to bestow. When above and below are in harmony, even the worthy have no merit to establish.

chunks.original_text: 昔容成氏之时，道路雁行列处，容成，黄帝时造历术也。 雁行，长幼有差也。 托婴儿於巢上，置余粮於晦首，虎豹可尾，虺蛇可蹍，而不知其所由然。 虎豹扰人，无害人之心，故可牵尾。 虺蛇不螫毒，故可蹍履也。 时人谓自当然耳，故曰，不知其所由然。 逮至尧之时，十日并出，焦禾稼，杀草木，而民无所食。 猰貐、凿齿、九婴、大风、封豨、修蛇皆为民害。 猰，读车轧履人之轧。 貐疾除愈之愈也。 尧乃使羿诛凿齿於畴华之野，凿齿，兽名，齿长三尺，其状如凿，下彻颔下，而持戈盾。 羿善射，尧使羿射杀之。 畴华，南方泽名也。 杀九婴於凶水之上，九婴，水火之怪，为人害。 北狄之地有凶水。 缴大风於青丘之泽，大风，风伯也，能壤人屋舍。 羿於青丘之泽缴遮，使不为害也。 一日，以缴击矢射杀之。 青丘，东方之泽名也。 上射十日而下杀猰输，十日并出，羿射去九。 猰貐，兽名也，状若龙首。 或曰，似狸，善走而食人，在西方也。 断修蛇於洞庭，擒封狶於桑林。 修蛇，大蛇也，吞象三年而出其骨之类。 洞庭，南方泽名。 封狶，大豕也。 楚人谓豕为狶也。 桑林，汤所祷早桑山之林。 万民皆喜，置尧以为天子。 於是天下广陕险易远近始有道里。 舜之时，共工振滔洪水，以薄空桑，共工，水官名也。 栢有之后。 振，动也。 滔，荡也。 欲壅防百川，滔高烟庳，以害天下者。 薄，迫也。 空桑，地名，在鲁也。 龙门未开，吕梁未发，江淮通流，四海溟涬，民皆上丘陵，赴树木。 龙门，河之隘也。 在左冯翊夏阳北，禹所凿也。 吕梁，在彭成吕县，石生水中，禹决而通之，民所由得度也，故曰吕梁也。 未发之时，水道不通，江、淮合流，四海溟泽，无岸畔也。 舜乃使禹疏三江五湖，辟伊阙，导瀍，涧，伊阙，山名也。 禹所开以通伊水，故曰辟。 伊阙在雒阳西南九十里。 瀍、涧，两水名也。 瀍读裹缠之缠也。 平通沟陆，流注东海，鸿水漏，九州乾，万民皆宁其性。 是以称尧舜以为圣。 晚世之时，帝有桀、纣、为璇室、瑶台、象廊、玉床，璇、瑶，石之似玉，以饰室台也。 用象牙饰廊殿，以玉为床。 言淫役也。 璇或作旋，瑶或作摇，言室施机关，可转旋也。 台可摇动，极土木之巧也。 纣为肉圃、酒池，纣积肉以为园圃，积酒以为渊也。 今河内朝歌，纣所都也。 城西有糟丘，酒池处是也。 燎焚天下之财，罢苦万民之力，刳谏者，剔孕妇，王子比于，纣之诸父也，数谏纣之不道，纣剖其心而观之，故曰刳谏者。 孕，孕妇，身将就草之妇也。 纣解剔观其胞裹，故曰剔孕妇也。 攘天下，虐百性。 於是汤乃以革车三百乘伐桀于南巢，放之夏台，革车，兵车也。 南巢，今卢江巢县是也。 夏台，大台，故作宫也。 武王甲卒三千破纣牧野，杀之于宣室，武王，周文王之子发也。 在车曰士，步曰卒。 牧野，南郊地名，在朝歌城外。 宣室，殷宫名。 一曰，宣室，狱也。 天下宁定，百姓和集。 是以称汤、武之贤。 由此观之，有贤圣之名者，必遭乱世之患也。 今至人生乱世之中，含德怀道，拘无穷之智，钳口寝说，遂不言而死者众矣。 至人，至德之人。 然天下莫知贵其不言也。 无有贵钳口不言而死也。 故道可道，非常道；
chunks.translated_text:
In the age of Rongcheng, roads were walked in ordered ranks—Rongcheng was the one who devised the calendar under the Yellow Emperor. *Ordered ranks* means elders and juniors kept their proper places. Infants were entrusted to nests above, surplus grain was stored at the ends of eaves, tigers and leopards could be tailed, and vipers and serpents could be trodden underfoot, yet none knew the reason for such harmony. Tigers and leopards, though fierce, harbored no intent to harm, so their tails could be grasped. Vipers and serpents bore no venom, so they could be trampled. People of that time took it as natural, saying they knew not why it was so.

By the time of Yao, ten suns rose together, scorching the crops, withering the grasses and trees, leaving the people with nothing to eat. *Yaoyu*, *Zaochi*, *Jiuying*, *Dafeng*, *Fengxi*, and *Xiusheshe* all wrought havoc upon the people. *Ya* is pronounced like the *zha* in *zha lü ren* (crushing a man under a cart). *Yu* is the *yu* in *ji chu yu* (swiftly cured). Yao then sent Yi to slay *Zaochi* in the wilds of Chouhua—*Zaochi* was a beast with teeth three feet long, shaped like a chisel, extending below its jaw while wielding spear and shield. Yi, skilled in archery, was sent by Yao to shoot and kill it. Chouhua was a marsh in the south. He slew *Jiuying* by the banks of the Xiongshui—*Jiuying* was a monster of water and fire that harmed people. The land of the northern Di had the Xiongshui. He shot down *Dafeng* at the marsh of Qingqiu—*Dafeng* was the Earl of Wind, capable of destroying homes. Yi intercepted it at Qingqiu’s marsh to prevent its harm. Another account says he shot it down with a feathered arrow. Qingqiu was a marsh in the east. Above, he shot the ten suns, and below, he killed *Yaoyu*—with ten suns rising together, Yi shot down nine. *Yaoyu* was a beast resembling a dragon’s head. Some say it was like a leopard, swift and man-eating, dwelling in the west. He severed *Xiusheshe* at Dongting and captured *Fengxi* at Sanglin—*Xiusheshe* was a great serpent that could swallow an elephant and disgorge its bones after three years. Dongting was a marsh in the south. *Fengxi* was a giant boar—the people of Chu called boars *xi*. Sanglin was the mulberry grove where Tang prayed for rain. The people rejoiced and set Yao upon the throne as Son of Heaven. From this time, the world’s vast distances, hazards, and remotenesses first had measured roads.

Then in the time of Shun, Gonggong stirred the surging floodwaters to press against Kongsang—Gonggong was the name of the water official, a descendant of Bohou. *Stirred* means set in motion; *surging* means overflowing. He sought to dam and block the hundred rivers, raising the high and lowering the low to harm the world. *Pressed* means forced. Kongsang was a place in Lu. The Dragon Gate remained unopened, Lüliang unbreached, the Yangtze and Huai flowed as one, and the four seas merged into a vast expanse, so the people climbed hills and fled to trees. The Dragon Gate was a narrow pass of the Yellow River, located north of Xiayang in Zuo Fengyi, carved by Yu. Lüliang was in Lü County of Pengcheng, where rocks rose from the water; Yu dredged it to allow passage, so it was called Lüliang. Before it was breached, waterways were blocked, the Yangtze and Huai merged, and the four seas became a boundless marsh. Shun then sent Yu to dredge the Three Rivers and Five Lakes, split Yique, and guide the Chan and Jian—Yique was a mountain name. Yu opened it to channel the Yi River, so it was called *split*. Yique lay ninety *li* southwest of Luoyang. Chan and Jian were two rivers. *Chan* is pronounced like the *chan* in *guo chan* (wrapping and binding). He leveled the ditches and fields, directing the flow into the Eastern Sea. The Great Flood receded, the Nine Provinces dried, and the people all settled into their natures. Thus Yao and Shun were hailed as sages.

In later ages, emperors like Jie and Zhou built *xuan* halls, *yao* terraces, ivory galleries, and jade beds—*xuan* and *yao* were stones resembling jade, used to adorn halls and terraces. Ivory was used to decorate galleries, and jade to make beds. This spoke of their excessive labor. *Xuan* is sometimes written as *xuan* (revolving), *yao* as *yao* (shaking), meaning the halls had mechanisms to turn, and the terraces could be shaken, showcasing the utmost craftsmanship in earth and timber. Zhou created meat gardens and wine pools—Zhou amassed meat into gardens and wine into pools. Today, Chaoge in Henei was Zhou’s capital. West of the city lies a mound of dregs, the site of the wine pool. He burned and squandered the world’s wealth, exhausted the people’s strength, disemboweled remonstrators, and ripped open pregnant women. Prince Bi Gan, Zhou’s uncle, repeatedly admonished Zhou’s tyranny, so Zhou split his heart to examine it—hence *disemboweled remonstrators*. *Pregnant women* refers to those about to give birth. Zhou cut them open to observe their wombs—hence *ripped open pregnant women*. He plundered the world and oppressed the people. Thus Tang led three hundred war chariots to attack Jie at Nanchao, exiling him to the Summer Terrace—*war chariots* were military vehicles. Nanchao is today’s Chaoxian in Lujiang. The Summer Terrace was a great terrace, originally a palace. King Wu, with three thousand armored soldiers, defeated Zhou at Muye and killed him in the Xuan Hall—King Wu was King Wen’s son, Fa. Those in chariots were called *shi*; those on foot, *zu*. Muye was a place in the southern suburbs, outside Chaoge’s city. The Xuan Hall was a palace of Yin. Another account says it was a prison. The world was pacified, and the people lived in harmony. Thus Tang and Wu were praised as worthy.

From this we see that those with the names of sages and worthies must encounter the perils of troubled times. Now, when perfected ones are born into such ages, harboring virtue and embracing the Dao, restraining their boundless wisdom, clamping their mouths shut and ceasing speech, many die without uttering a word. *Perfected ones* are those of utmost virtue. Yet the world knows not the value of their silence. None esteem those who die with sealed lips. Thus, *the Dao that can be spoken is not the enduring Dao*.

Another account holds that *Yaoguang* is the manifestation of harmonious qi. When it relieves the destitute and supplements the deficient, a name arises—*name* here means *benevolent renown*. chunks.original_text: 至道无名，不可道，故曰可道者，非常道也。 名可名，非常名。 真人之名不可得名也。 着於竹帛，镂於金石，可传於人者，其粗也。 五帝三王，殊事而同指，异路而同归。 五帝，黄帝、颛顼、帝誉、帝尧、帝舜。 三王，夏禹、殷汤、周文王。 同归，同归修仁义也。 晚世学者，不知道之所一体，德之所总要，总，凡也。 要，约也。 取成之迹，相与危坐而说之，鼓歌而舞之，故博学多闻，而不兔於惑。 诗云，不敢暴虎，不敢冯河，人知其一，莫知其他。 此之谓也。 无兵搏虎日暴虎，无舟檝而渡曰冯河。 言小人而为政，不可不敬〔不敬〕#5则危，犹暴虎冯河之必死。 人皆暴虎冯河立至害也，故曰知其一，而不知当畏慎小人危亡也，故曰莫知其他。 此不免於惑，此之谓也。 帝者体太一，体，法也。 太一，天之刑神也。 王者法阴阳，霸者则四时，君者用六律。 秉太一者，牢笼天地； 弹压山川，牢，读星溜，楚人谓牢为溜。 弹山川，令出云雨，后能压止之。 含吐阴阳，伸曳四时，伸曳，犹神引，和调之。 纪纲八极，经纬六合，覆露照导，普汜无私，普，大也。 汜，众也。 无私爱憎，言皆公也。 蠉飞蠕动，莫不仰德而生。 阴阳者，承天地之和，形万殊之体，含气化物，以成埒类，埒，形也。 赢缩卷舒，沦於不测，赢，长也。 缩，烜也。 卷，屈也。 舒，散也。 沦，入也。 测，深也。 入於不可测尽之深。 终始虚满，转於无原。 转化归於无穷之源本也。 四时者，春生夏长，秋收冬藏，取于有节，出入有时，开阖张歙，不失其叙，歙，读曰胁。 叙，次也。 喜怒刚柔，不离其理。 理，道也。 六律者，生之与杀也，赏之与罚也，子之与夺也，子，布施也。 夺，取收也。 非此无道也，则四时用六律之君，非用此上事，其余无他道也。 故谨於权衡准绳，审乎轻重，足以治其境内矣。 权衡，平也。 准，法也。 绳，直也。 是故体太一者，明於天地之情，通於道德之伦，聪明耀於日月，精神通於万物，动静调於阴阳，喜怒和于四时，德泽施于方外，施，廷。 廷於远方之外。 名声传于后世。
chunks.translated_text:
The utmost Dao has no name and cannot be spoken—thus it is said, "The Dao that can be spoken is not the enduring Dao." The name that can be named is not the enduring name. The name of the *zhenren* cannot be named. What is inscribed on bamboo and silk, carved into metal and stone, and transmitted to others is but its coarse form.

The Five Emperors and Three Kings pursued different affairs yet shared the same aim, followed different paths yet reached the same destination. The Five Emperors were the Yellow Emperor, Zhuanxu, Emperor Ku, Emperor Yao, and Emperor Shun. The Three Kings were Yu of Xia, Tang of Yin, and King Wen of Zhou. "Same destination" means they all cultivated benevolence and righteousness.

Scholars of later ages, not understanding the unity of the Dao or the essentials of virtue—*zong* meaning "all," *yao* meaning "to summarize"—cling to the traces of past achievements. They sit solemnly together discoursing on them, singing and dancing in celebration. Thus, though they amass broad learning and much knowledge, they remain mired in confusion.

As the *Odes* says:
*"Dare not wrestle tigers bare-handed,
Dare not ford rivers without boats—
People know this one thing,
But know not the rest."*
This is what it means.

To wrestle tigers without weapons is called *baohu*; to cross rivers without boats or oars is called *pinghe*. To govern while acting as a petty man is to court peril if one is not reverent—for recklessness invites ruin, just as *baohu* and *pinghe* lead inevitably to death. People see only the immediate harm in *baohu* and *pinghe*, yet fail to recognize the need for caution against the perils of petty men. Thus it is said, "They know this one thing, but know not the rest." This is what it means to remain mired in confusion.

Those who embody the *Emperor* model themselves on the *Taiyi*; *ti* means "to emulate." The *Taiyi* is the punitive spirit of Heaven. Those who embody the *King* follow the patterns of yin and yang. Those who embody the *Hegemon* align with the four seasons. Those who embody the *Ruler* employ the six pitch-pipes.

Those who grasp the *Taiyi* encompass Heaven and Earth, press down upon mountains and rivers—*lao* is read as *liu* (to flow), as the people of Chu call "encompassing" *liu*. To "press down" upon mountains and rivers is to command clouds and rain, then restrain them. They inhale and exhale yin and yang, extend and draw in the four seasons—*shenye* meaning to guide and harmonize them. They order the eight directions, weave the warp and weft of the six directions, bestow their covering dew and illuminating guidance universally, without partiality—*pu* meaning "great," *si* meaning "multitude." Without private loves or hates, they act with impartiality. All that flies and wriggles looks up to their virtue to live.

Yin and yang uphold the harmony of Heaven and Earth, shaping the myriad forms, containing qi to transform things and complete their kinds—*lie* meaning "form." They expand and contract, coil and unfurl, sinking into the unfathomable—*ying* meaning "to extend," *suo* meaning "to shrink," *juan* meaning "to coil," *shu* meaning "to unfurl." *Lun* means "to enter," *ce* means "depth," entering the immeasurable depths. They cycle through emptiness and fullness, revolving without origin, returning to the boundless source.

The four seasons—spring’s birth, summer’s growth, autumn’s harvest, winter’s storage—take from what is timely, proceed and retreat in due season, open and close, expand and contract, never losing their order—*xi* is read as *xie* (to contract), *xu* meaning "sequence." Joy and anger, firmness and softness never depart from their principle. *Li* means "Dao."

The six pitch-pipes govern life and death, reward and punishment, bestowal and seizure—*zi* meaning "to bestow," *duo* meaning "to take away." Without these, there is no Dao. Thus, the ruler who employs the four seasons and six pitch-pipes uses nothing beyond these principles.

Therefore, by carefully attending to the balance of the steelyard, the level of the water, and the straightness of the marking line, and by discerning weight and lightness, one suffices to govern within one’s borders. *Quanheng* means "balance," *zhun* means "standard," *sheng* means "straight."

Thus, those who embody the *Taiyi* understand the nature of Heaven and Earth, penetrate the principles of the Dao and virtue, shine with a brilliance surpassing sun and moon, and extend their spirit to all things. Their movement and stillness harmonize with yin and yang, their joy and anger align with the four seasons. Their virtue and grace extend beyond the four seas—*shi* meaning "to reach distant lands." Their fame endures for generations to come.

chunks.original_text: 后世传闻之也。 法阴阳者，德与天地参，参，明。 明与日月并，并，并也。 精与鬼神总，总，合也。 戴圆履方，抱表怀绳，圆，天也。 方，地也。 表，正也。 绳，直也。 内能治身，外能得人，能得人之欢心。 发号施令，天下莫不从风。 风，化也。 则四时者，柔而不脆，刚而不鞼，鞼，折也。 宽而不肆，肆，缓。 虽宽不缓，过齐非也。 肃而不悖，肃，急也。 虽急不促悖。 优柔委从，以养群类，类，物类也。 其德含愚而容不肖，无所私爱。 私，邪也。 用六律者，伐乱禁暴，进贤而废不肖，扶拨以为正，拨，任也。 扶，治也。 坏险以为平，矫枉以为直，矫，正也。 枉，曲也。 明於禁舍开闭之道，乘时因势以服役人心也。 役，使也。 帝者体阴阳则侵，为诸夏所侵陵。 王者法四时则削，为诸夏所侵削。 传曰，诸侯侵犯王略也。 霸者节六律则辱，为邻国所侮辱。 君者失准绳则废。 为臣所废，绌更立贤。 故小而行大，则滔窕而不亲，滔窕，不满密也。 不为臣下所亲附也。 大而行小，则狭隘而不容。 行小则正狭隘，而不容包臣下。 贵贱不失其体，而天下治矣。 不失其体，大行大，小行小也。 天爱其精，地爱其平，精，光明也。 平，正也。 人爱其情，情，性也。 天之精，日月星辰雷电风雨也； 地之平，水火金木土也； 人之情，思虑聪明喜怒也。 故闭四关，止五遁，则与道沦。 四关，耳、目、心、口。 遁，逸也。 沦，入也。 是故神明藏於无形，精神反於至真，真，身也。 则目明而不以视，耳聪而不以听，心条达而不以思虑，委而弗为，和而弗矜，矜，自大也。 真性命之情，而智故不得杂焉。 杂，糅也。 精泄於目则其视明，泄，犹通也。 在於耳则其听聪，留於口则其言当，当，合也。 集於心则其虑通。 集，止也。 故闭四关则身无患，百节莫苑，苑，病也。 苑读南阳之宛也。 莫死莫生，莫虚莫盈，计是谓真人。 言守其常。 凡乱之所由生者，皆在流遁。 流遁之所生者五：流，放也。 遁，逸也。 大构驾，兴宫室，构，连也。 驾，材木相乘驾也。 延楼栈道，鸡栖井干，延楼，高楼也。 栈道，飞阁复道相通。 鸡栖井干，复屋荧井也，刻花置其中也。 檦标欂櫖，以相支持，木巧之饰，饰巧。 盘纡刻俨，盘，盘龙也。 纡，曲屈。 刻俨，浮首虎头之属，皆屋饰也。 俨，读严然之俨也。 嬴镂雕琢，诡文回波，嬴镂，文章镂。 雕，画也。 玉曰琢。 皆饰巧也。 诡文，奇异之文也。 回波，若水波也。 淌游瀷淢，菱杼紾抱，尚游瀷淢，皆文尽，拟像水势之貌也。 菱，芰。 杼，采实。 紾，戾也。 抱，转也。 皆壮采相衔持貌也。 淌，读平敞之敞。 瀷，燕人强春言欶之欶。 淢读郁乎文哉之郁美读楚言杼紾，读紾结之紾。 抱读岐嶷之嶷。 芒繁乱泽，巧伪纷挐，以相摧错，此遁於木也。 皆采色形像文章貌。 挐，读人性纷挐不解之挐。 凿污池之深，肆畛崖之远，肆，极也。 崖垠也。 来溪谷之流，饰曲岸之际，积牒旋石，以纯修碕，饰，治也。 牒，累。 纯，缘也。 以玉石致之水边，为修碕。 或作旋（佑）〔石〕#6旋石切以牒累流水边，为修碕。 修碕，曲中水所棠处也。 抑淢怒濑，以扬激波，抑，止也。 淢，怒水也。 颛，急流也，而抑止之，故激扬之波起也。
chunks.translated_text:
The transmission of their fame endures through later generations.

Those who model themselves upon yin and yang share virtue with Heaven and Earth—*can* meaning "to align." Their clarity rivals sun and moon—*bing* meaning "to parallel." Their essence merges with spirits and gods—*zong* meaning "to unite."

They bear the round and tread the square, embracing the upright and holding the straight—*yuan* signifying Heaven, *fang* signifying Earth, *biao* meaning "upright," and *sheng* meaning "straight." Within, they govern the self; without, they win the hearts of others. When they issue commands, none under Heaven fail to follow their transformative influence—*feng* meaning "transformation."

Thus, the four seasons are supple yet unbroken, firm yet unyielding—*gui* meaning "to snap." They are generous yet not lax—*si* meaning "slack." Though generous, they do not overstep moderation. They are solemn yet not oppressive—*su* meaning "urgent." Though urgent, they do not rush to disorder.

Gentle and yielding, they nurture all beings—*lei* meaning "all creatures." Their virtue embraces the foolish and accommodates the unworthy, without partiality—*si* meaning "bias."

Those who employ the six pitch-pipes suppress disorder and restrain violence, promote the worthy and demote the unworthy, support the upright—*ba* meaning "to appoint," *fu* meaning "to govern." They level peril to create evenness, straighten crookedness to restore rectitude—*jiao* meaning "to correct," *wang* meaning "bent." They master the principles of prohibition and permission, opening and closing, seizing the moment and leveraging circumstances to subdue and employ the hearts of the people—*yi* meaning "to employ."

Thus, emperors who embody yin and yang invite encroachment, suffering incursions from the Central States. Kings who model themselves upon the four seasons face diminution, enduring encroachments from the Central States—*zhuan* states that feudal lords violate royal authority. Hegemons who regulate the six pitch-pipes suffer humiliation, enduring contempt from neighboring states. Rulers who lose the standard and plumb line are deposed, replaced by worthier ministers.

Therefore, those who act grandly in petty matters overflow without intimacy—*taoyao* meaning "unfilled and loose," failing to win the allegiance of their ministers. Those who act meagerly in great matters become narrow and unaccommodating, their governance constricted and unable to embrace their ministers.

When the noble and base do not transgress their proper stations, all under Heaven is well-ordered. To not transgress their stations is to act grandly in grand matters and meagerly in meager ones.

Heaven cherishes its luminosity—*jing* meaning "brilliance." Earth cherishes its levelness—*ping* meaning "evenness." Humans cherish their nature—*qing* meaning "innate disposition." Heaven’s luminosity resides in the sun, moon, stars, thunder, lightning, wind, and rain. Earth’s levelness resides in water, fire, metal, wood, and soil. Human nature resides in thought, discernment, joy, and anger.

Thus, by sealing the four gates and halting the five escapes, one merges with the Dao—*si guan* referring to the ears, eyes, heart, and mouth; *dun* meaning "to flee"; *lun* meaning "to enter."

Therefore, divine clarity conceals itself in formlessness, and essence returns to utmost authenticity—*zhen* meaning "the self." The eyes see without gazing, the ears hear without listening, the heart flows unimpeded without deliberation. One surrenders without acting, harmonizes without arrogance—*jin* meaning "self-importance." This is the true nature of life and destiny, where cunning and artifice cannot intrude—*za* meaning "to mingle."

When essence flows through the eyes, vision becomes clear. When it resides in the ears, hearing becomes acute. When it lingers in the mouth, speech becomes fitting—*dang* meaning "appropriate." When it gathers in the heart, thought becomes penetrating—*ji* meaning "to settle."

Thus, sealing the four gates ensures the body remains free from affliction, and the hundred joints suffer no ailment—*yuan* meaning "illness," pronounced like *Wan* of Nanyang. Neither death nor life, neither emptiness nor fullness—this is called the *zhenren*, one who preserves constancy.

All disorder arises from dissipation and escape. Dissipation and escape arise from five sources—*liu* meaning "to indulge," *dun* meaning "to flee."

First, the grand construction of palaces and halls—*gou* meaning "to connect," *jia* meaning "timber joined in framework." The erection of lofty towers and elevated walkways—*yanlou* meaning "tall towers," *zhandao* meaning "flying galleries and connecting corridors." The ornate carving of roosts and well-frames—*jiqi jingan* referring to elaborate well enclosures with carved patterns.

Second, the intricate joinery of beams and brackets, mutually supporting one another—*biao* and *bolü* referring to decorative woodwork, *shi qiao* meaning "artful embellishment." The winding carvings and solemn figures—*pan* meaning "coiled dragons," *yu* meaning "curving," *keyan* referring to raised tiger-head ornaments and the like, all palace decorations—*yan* pronounced like the solemnity of *yanran.*

Third, the lavish engravings and intricate inlays—*yinglou* meaning "elaborate patterns," *diao* meaning "carving," *zhuo* referring to jade carving. The deceptive designs and swirling motifs—*guiwen* meaning "eccentric patterns," *huibo* resembling water ripples.

Fourth, the flowing, undulating, and intertwined embellishments—*tangyou* and *yiyu* describing patterns mimicking water’s movement, *ling* meaning "water caltrop," *zhu* meaning "fruit," *shen* meaning "twisted," *bao* meaning "entwined." All depict the interlocking grandeur of decorative motifs—*tang* pronounced like the openness of *chang*, *yi* as in the Yan dialect’s *qiangchun* for *shuo*, *yu* pronounced like the richness of *yu hu wen zai*, *mei* as in the Chu dialect’s *zhu shen*, *bao* pronounced like the prominence of *qi yi.*

Fifth, the chaotic profusion of excessive ornamentation, the tangled web of artifice—*mangfan* meaning "disorderly abundance," *luannuo* meaning "confused entanglement." These clash and compete, all escaping into woodwork.

The excavation of deep pools, the extension of embankments to distant shores—*si* meaning "to extend," *ya* meaning "boundary." The diversion of mountain streams, the adornment of winding banks, the piling of stones in spirals to refine the water’s edge—*shi* meaning "to embellish," *die* meaning "to layer," *chun* meaning "to border." With jade and stone, they adorn the water’s edge, creating refined curves—*xiuqi* referring to the curved banks where water gathers. Some stack stones in spirals along the water’s edge—*xuanshi* meaning "spiraled stones," *die* meaning "to layer," forming *xiuqi.*

They suppress turbulent rapids to stir up surging waves—*yi* meaning "to restrain," *yu* meaning "raging waters," *lao* meaning "torrent." By holding back the rushing currents, they provoke the rise of crashing waves.

chunks.original_text: 曲拂邅回，以像湡、浯，拂，戾也。 邅回，转流也。 湡，番隅。 浯，苍梧。 之二国多水，江湖环之，故多象渠池以自邅回，法而像之也。 湡，读愚戆之愚也。 益树莲菱，以食鳖鱼，树，种也。 莲，藕实地。 菱芰也。 皆可以养鱼鳖。 莲，读莲羊鱼之莲也。 鸿鹄鹔鸘，稻梁饶余，鹔鸘雁类也。 一曰凤之别类也。 龙舟鹢首，浮吹以娱，此遁於水也。 龙舟，大舟也。 刻为龙文，以为饰也。 蠲，大鸟也，画其象着船头，故曰鹢首也。 於舟中吹籁与竽，以为乐，故曰浮吹以娱。 高筑城郭，设树险阻，崇台榭之隆，设，施也。 树，立也。 一说，种树木以为险阻，今难攻易守也。 积土高丈曰台，加木曰榭也。 侈苑囿之大，以穷要妙之望，侈，广也。 有墙曰苑，无墙曰囿，所以畜禽兽也。 尽极要之观望也。 魏阙之高，上际青云，大厦曾加，拟於昆仑，门阙高祟巍巍然，故曰魏阙也。 大厦，大屋也。 曾，重。 架，材木相秉架也。 其高与昆仑山相像也。 修为墙垣，甬道相连，甬道，飞阁复道也。 甬，读踊跃之踊。 道，读道布之道也。 残高增下，积土为山，残，堕也。 增，益也。 接径历远，直道夷险，接，疾也。 径，行也。 道之阨者正直之。 夷，平也。 终日驰骛，而无迹蹈之患，此遁於土也。 大锺鼎，美重器，锺，音之君也。 重器，大器，盖锺鼎也。 华虫疏镂，以相缪紾，书曰，山龙华虫藻火粉米。 缪紾，相缠结也。 寝兕伏虎，蟠龙连组，兕，兽名。 寝伏各有形也。 蟠龙诎屈相连，文错如织组文也。 焜昱错眩，照耀辉煌，错，杂也。 眩惑也。 照耀辉煌，焜光泽色貌也。 偃蹇□纠，曲成文章，雕琢之饰，锻锡文铙，乍晦乍明，雕，画也。 缘错锡可刷，如连珠不可棳，故曰乍晦乍明也。 抑微灭瑕，霜文沈居，若箪蘧蒢，言剑理之美，没灭其瑕，文铙如霜，皆役身中，故曰沈居。 箪，竹席。 蘧蒢，苇席。 取其邪文次叙，剑铙若此也。 缠锦经冗，以数而疏，剑文相句，连缠如绮，经冗如锦，似数如疏，文铙美眩人目。 此遁於金也。 煎熬焚炙调齐和之适，以穷荆、吴甘酸之变，荆，楚。 言二国善酸咸之和，而穷尽之。 焚林而猎，烧燎大木，鼓橐吹埵，以销铜铁，鼓，系也。 橐，治炉排橐也。 埵，铜橐口铁笛，埵入火中吹火也，故曰吹埵。 销，铄。 靡流坚鍜，无厌足（日）〔目〕#7，山无峻干，林无柘梓，峻干，长枝也。 柘，桑。 梓，滋生也。 燎木以为炭，燔草而为灰，野莽白素，不得其时，槁，草。 白，素。 上掩天光，下殄地财，此遁於火也。 殄，尽也。 珍读曰典也。
chunks.translated_text:
The waters curve and twist in winding detours, mimicking the rivers of Yu and Wu—*fu* meaning "to bend," *zhānhuí* meaning "to turn and flow." Yu and Wu were two states abundant in water, encircled by rivers and lakes, so they built winding canals and pools to emulate their meandering courses. *Yu* is pronounced like the first syllable of *yúgàng* ("foolish"); *Wu* refers to Cangwu.

They plant more lotus and water caltrop to feed the turtles and fish—*shù* meaning "to cultivate." The lotus bears roots and seeds; the caltrop is the water chestnut. Both nourish fish and turtles. *Lián* is pronounced like the first syllable of *liányángyú* ("sheepfish lotus").

Swan geese and egrets abound, their rice and grain plentiful in surplus. *Sùshuāng* are birds of the goose family; some say they are a kind of phoenix. Dragon boats with egret-prowed heads float upon the waters, where pipes and reed organs play for amusement—this is the Way of Water in retreat. *Lóngzhōu* are great boats carved with dragon patterns as adornment. *Yì* is a large bird; its image is painted on the prow, hence "egret-prowed." Within the boats, flutes and reed organs play for pleasure, thus "floating music for amusement."

They build towering city walls and erect barriers of peril, raising lofty terraces and pavilions—*shè* meaning "to establish," *shù* meaning "to erect." Another interpretation holds that trees are planted to create natural defenses, making the city difficult to attack and easy to defend. A mound of earth a *zhàng* high is called a *tái*; when wood is added, it becomes a *xiè*. They expand the grandeur of parks and gardens to exhaust the subtlest vistas—*chǐ* meaning "to enlarge." Enclosures with walls are called *yuàn*; those without are *yòu*, used for raising birds and beasts. They pursue the most refined views to their utmost.

The lofty gates rise so high their tops touch the blue clouds; great halls are layered upon one another, rivaling Kunlun in grandeur. The gate towers stand tall and majestic, hence *wèiquè* ("towering gates"). *Dàshà* are great halls; *céng* means "layered"; *jià* refers to the interlocking of timber. Their height rivals that of Mount Kunlun. They construct walls and connecting corridors—*yǒngdào* are elevated walkways and covered bridges. *Yǒng* is pronounced like *yǒngyuè* ("leaping"); *dào* like *dàobù* ("path").

They level the high and augment the low, piling earth to form mountains—*cán* meaning "to collapse," *zēng* meaning "to increase." Paths stretch far, straightening both level and treacherous terrain—*jiē* meaning "swift," *jìng* meaning "to traverse." Dangerous paths are made straight and even. *Yí* means "level." They gallop all day without fear of treading missteps—this is the Way of Earth in retreat.

Great bells and tripods, fine and weighty vessels—*zhōng* is the lord of sounds. *Zhòngqì* are heavy vessels, namely bells and tripods. They carve intricate patterns of birds and insects, intertwining them in elaborate coils—*Shū* states: "mountains, dragons, birds, fire, grain, and white." *Miùzhěn* means "to intertwine and coil." Reclining rhinoceroses and crouching tigers, coiling dragons linked in rows—*sì* is a beast; *qǐnfú* describe their postures. Dragons twist and coil in sequence, their patterns interlocking like woven silk. Their brilliance dazzles and confounds, gleaming with radiant splendor—*cuò* means "intermingled"; *xuàn* means "to bewilder." *Zhàoyào huīhuáng* describes their luminous, lustrous appearance.

Towering and twisted, they curve into elegant patterns. Through carving and chiseling, they inlay with tin and bronze, now dim, now bright—*diāo* means "to carve"; *zhuó* means "to chisel." The inlaid tin can be polished like linked pearls, impossible to separate, hence "now dim, now bright." They suppress flaws and erase blemishes, their frosty patterns sinking deep within, like bamboo or reed mats—this speaks of the beauty of sword patterns, where flaws are erased, and the frosty inlays lie embedded within. *Dān* is a bamboo mat; *qúchú* is a reed mat. Their slanted patterns follow in order, like the inlays of a sword. Woven brocade threads through the excess, dense yet sparse—sword patterns interlock like silk, their threads running through the excess like brocade, appearing dense yet sparse, their brilliance dazzling to the eye. This is the Way of Metal in retreat.

They boil, roast, and burn, blending flavors to perfection, exhausting the sweet and sour variations of Jing and Wu—*Jīng* refers to Chu. These two states excel in balancing sour and salty flavors, pursuing them to their utmost. They burn forests for hunting, setting great trees aflame, pumping bellows to blow embers, melting copper and iron—*gǔ* means "to pump"; *tuó* is the bellows of a furnace. *Duǒ* is the iron pipe at the mouth of the bellows; it is inserted into the fire to blow air, hence "blowing embers." *Xiāo* means "to melt." They refine and forge without end, insatiable in their pursuit—mountains are stripped of their tallest branches, forests of their *zhè* and *zǐ*. *Jùn gàn* are long branches; *zhè* is the mulberry; *zǐ* means "to flourish." They burn wood into charcoal, incinerate grass into ash—*gǎo* is withered grass; *bái* means "white." Above, they obscure the light of heaven; below, they exhaust the wealth of the earth—this is the Way of Fire in retreat. *Tiǎn* means "to deplete." *Zhēn* is read as *diǎn* ("classic").

They suppress turbulent rapids to stir up surging waves—*yi* meaning "to restrain," *yu* meaning "raging waters," *lao* meaning "torrent." By holding back the rushing currents, they provoke the rise of crashing waves.

chunks.original_text: 此五者一，足以亡天下矣。 五者之中有一，则足以灭亡也。 是故古者明堂之制，下之润湿弗能及，上之雾露弗能入，四方之风弗能袭，明堂，王者布政之堂。 上圆下方，堂四出，各有左右房，谓之个，凡十二所。 王者月居其房，告朔朝历，颁宣其令，谓之明堂。 其中可以叙昭穆，谓之太庙。 其上可以望气祥，书云物，谓之灵台。 其外圆，似辟雍。 诸侯之制半天子，谓之宫，诗云，矫矫鲁侯，在泮献（公）〔馘是〕#8也。 土事不文，质也。 木工不斲，朴而已。
chunks.translated_text:
These five as one are enough to ruin the world. Among these five, even one alone suffices to bring about destruction.

Thus, the ancient system of the *Ming Tang* was designed so that dampness from below could not reach it, mist and dew from above could not penetrate it, and winds from the four directions could not assail it. The *Ming Tang* was the hall where the ruler issued governance. Its structure was round above and square below, with four entrances, each flanked by chambers on the left and right—called *ge*—totaling twelve spaces. Each month, the ruler resided in its chambers to announce the new moon, receive the calendar, and proclaim decrees—hence its name, *Ming Tang*. Within it, ancestral ranks could be ordered, and so it was called the *Grand Temple*. Above it, one could observe auspicious *qi* and record celestial phenomena—thus it was called the *Spirit Terrace*. Its outer form was circular, resembling the *Bi Yong*. The system for feudal lords was half that of the Son of Heaven, and it was called the *Palace*. As the *Book of Songs* says: *"Majestic is the Lord of Lu, at the Pond offering captives."* Earthen works were unadorned, for they were plain. Woodwork was uncarved, for it remained simple.

chunks.original_text: 斲或作琢，（而）［不］#9。 雕画也。 金器不镂，不错镂设文饰也。 镂，读娄之娄。 衣无隅差之削，隅，角也。 差，邪也。 古者质，皆全幅为衣裳，无有邪角。 邪角，削杀也。 冠无觚赢之理，觚赢之理，谓若马目笼相连干也。 言无者，冠文取平直而已也。 嬴，读指端嬴文之嬴也。 堂大足以周旋理文，堂，明堂。 所以升降揖让修礼容，故曰周旋。 理文，理政事文书也。 静洁足以飨上帝，礼鬼神，以示民知俭节。 孝经曰，宗祀文王於明堂，以配上帝也。 夫声色五味，远国珍怪，瑰异奇物，足以变心易志，摇荡精神，感动血气者，不可胜计也。 夫天地之生财也，本不过五。 不过五行之数。 圣人节五行，则治不荒。 五行，金、木、水、火、土也。 水属阴行，火为阳行，木为燠行，金为寒行，土为风行。 五气常行，故曰五行。 凡人之性，心和欲得则乐，心和，不喜不怒。 欲得，无违耳。 乐斯动，动斯蹈，蹈斯荡，荡斯歌，歌斯舞，歌舞节则禽兽跳矣。 人之性，心有忧丧则悲，悲则哀，有忧，艰难也。 丧，（事）［亡］#10也。 亡失所离，爱则悲，悲则伤。 哀斯愤，愤斯怒，怒斯动，动则手足不静。 静，宁也。 擗踊哭泣，哀以送之也。 人之性，有侵犯则怒，怒则血充，人欲有侵犯则怒盛，血气充盈，以成其势。 血充则气激，气激则发怒，发怒则有所释憾矣。 释，解也。 憾，恨也。 故锺鼓管箫，干戚羽旄，所以饰喜也。 衰绖苴杖，苴，麻之有实者。 衰，读曰崔杼之崔也。 哭踊有节，所以饰哀也。 为哀所容，故曰饰也。 兵革羽旄，金鼓斧钺，所以饰怒也。 必有其质，乃为之文。 古者圣王在上，政教平，仁爱洽，上下同心，君臣辑睦，衣食有余，家给人足，父慈慈，柔也。 子孝，兄良弟顺，生者不怨，死者不恨，有道之世，人得其志，故生者不怨也。 皆终其天命，故死者不恨。 天下和洽，人得其愿。 夫人相乐，无所发贶，故圣人为之作乐以和节之。 夫人，众人也。 但中心相乐，所以发其恩赐也，故圣人为之作乐以节之，犹通制也。 末世之政，田渔重税，关市急征，泽梁毕禁，网罟无所布，耒耜无所设，民力竭於徭役，财殚於会赋，会，计。 计人口数，责其税敛也。 居者无食，行者无粮，老者不养，死者不葬，赘妻鬻子，以给上求，犹弗能赡，赘，从嫁也。 或作赁妻。 愚夫意妇皆有流连之心，凄怆之志，流连，犹烂漫，失其职业也。 凄怆，伤悼之貌。 憃读近贮益之□戆，茏口言之也。 乃使始为之撞大锺，击鸣鼓，吹竽笙，弹琴瑟，失乐之本矣。 古者上求薄而民用给，给，足。 君施其德，臣尽其忠，父行其慈，子竭其孝，竭，尽也。 善事父母曰孝也。 各致其爱而无憾恨其间。 无憾恨，各得其愿也。 夫三年之丧，非强而致之，非强行致孝子之情也，情自发於中。 听乐不乐，食旨不甘，思慕之心未能绝也。 三年之思，思慕之心未能自绝於哀戚也。 晚世风流俗败，嗜欲多，礼义废，君臣相欺，父子〔相〕#11疑，怨尤充胸，思心尽亡，尽丧其忠孝思慕之心也。 被衰戴绖，戏笑其中，虽致之三年，失丧之本也。 本在哀戚。 古者天子一畿，诸侯一同，方千里为畿，方百里为同。 各守其分，不得相侵。 分，犹界也。
chunks.translated_text:
Carving may also be written as *zhuo*, yet it was not done. This refers to engraving and painting. Metal vessels were not inlaid, nor were they adorned with decorative patterns. *Lou* is read as the *lou* in *loulou*. Garments had no angled or slanted cuts—*yu* means corner, and *chai* means slant. In antiquity, all clothing was made from whole bolts of cloth, without angled or slanted edges. Such edges were trimmed away. Crowns had no *guying* patterns—*guying* refers to designs like linked horse-eye motifs. The absence of such patterns meant that crown ornamentation was merely straight and plain. *Ying* is read as the *ying* in *zhiduan yingwen*. The hall was spacious enough for proper movement and governance—this hall refers to the *Ming Tang*. It was used for ascending, descending, bowing, and yielding to perform ritual postures, hence the term *circuit* (*zhouxuan*). *Liwen* refers to managing administrative documents. Its purity and cleanliness sufficed to offer sacrifices to the Supreme Lord and honor ghosts and spirits, thereby teaching the people frugality and moderation. As the *Classic of Filial Piety* says: *"In the Ming Tang, King Wen is venerated in ancestral rites to be paired with the Supreme Lord."*

The sounds and colors, the five flavors, rare treasures from distant lands, and strange, wondrous objects—all these are more than enough to alter the heart and shift the will, to agitate the spirit and stir the blood and *qi*, and their varieties are beyond counting. Yet the resources produced by Heaven and Earth fundamentally do not exceed five—this is the number of the Five Phases. The sage regulates the Five Phases, and thus governance does not fall into chaos. The Five Phases are Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth. Water belongs to the *yin* phase, Fire to the *yang* phase, Wood to the warming phase, Metal to the cooling phase, and Earth to the wind phase. As the five *qi* constantly move, they are called the Five Phases.

In human nature, when the heart is harmonious and desires are fulfilled, there is joy. *Heart harmonious* means neither joy nor anger; *desires fulfilled* means nothing is obstructed. Joy leads to movement, movement to stamping, stamping to swaying, swaying to singing, and singing to dancing. When song and dance are regulated, even birds and beasts leap. In human nature, when the heart is burdened with grief and loss, there is sorrow. *Grief* arises from hardship and difficulty; *loss* refers to separation from what one cherishes. When one is parted from what one loves, there is sorrow, and sorrow causes harm. Grief leads to indignation, indignation to anger, anger to action, and action makes the hands and feet restless. *Restless* means unsettled. Beating the breast and stamping the feet, wailing and weeping—these express sorrow in sending off the deceased.

In human nature, when one is violated or offended, there is anger. Anger causes the blood to surge—when one’s desires are violated, anger swells, and the blood and *qi* become full to assert one’s force. When the blood surges, the *qi* is stirred; when the *qi* is stirred, anger erupts, and when anger erupts, resentment is released. *Release* means to resolve; *resentment* means grievance. Thus, bells and drums, flutes and panpipes, shields and axes, and feathered banners are used to adorn joy. Sackcloth and hempen girdles, staffs of mourning, and the *ju* plant—*ju* refers to hemp with seeds—*cui* is read as the *cui* in *Cuizhu*—and regulated wailing and stamping are used to adorn grief. These are the forms of sorrow, hence the term *adorn*. Weapons and armor, feathered banners, metal drums, axes, and halberds are used to adorn anger.

Only when there is substance is ornamentation applied. In ancient times, when sagely kings ruled above, governance and education were equitable, benevolence and love were pervasive, superiors and inferiors were of one mind, and ruler and minister were harmonious. Clothing and food were abundant, households were provided for, and people were content. Fathers were kind, children filial, elder brothers good, and younger brothers obedient. The living bore no grudges, and the dead held no resentments. In an age of the Dao, people attained their aspirations, so the living bore no grudges. All fulfilled their Heaven-ordained lifespans, so the dead held no resentments. The world was harmonious, and people achieved their wishes. When people rejoiced together without occasion for bestowing favors, the sages created music to harmonize and regulate them. *People* refers to the multitude. Though their hearts rejoiced together, there was a need to express their gratitude, so the sages created music to regulate them, much like a universal system.

In the governance of later ages, fields and fisheries were heavily taxed, passes and markets were strictly levied, weirs and dams were entirely prohibited, nets and traps were nowhere to be set, and plows and hoes had no place to be used. The people’s strength was exhausted by corvée labor, and their wealth was depleted by taxes and levies. *Hui* means calculation—calculating the number of people to exact their taxes. Those who stayed had no food, those who traveled had no provisions, the elderly were not cared for, the dead were not buried, wives were pledged and children sold to meet the demands of superiors, yet still they could not suffice. *Zhui* means to follow in marriage, or in some versions, to rent a wife. Foolish men and simple women all harbored thoughts of wandering and abandonment, and feelings of sorrow and distress. *Wandering* means to be scattered and neglect one’s duties; *sorrow and distress* describe a mournful appearance. *Chong* is read similarly to *zhuyi*’s *□*, a stammering utterance.

Thus, they began to strike great bells, beat resounding drums, blow reed pipes and sheng, and strum zithers and se—losing the root of music. In ancient times, the ruler’s demands were modest, and the people’s needs were met. The lord bestowed his virtue, the minister exhausted his loyalty, the father practiced his kindness, and the son fulfilled his filial piety. *Fulfilled* means to exhaust; *filial piety* means to serve one’s parents well. Each gave their utmost love, and there was no resentment among them. Without resentment, each attained their wishes.

The three-year mourning period was not forcibly imposed—it was not that one was compelled to express the emotions of a filial child, for such emotions arose naturally from within. One did not enjoy listening to music, fine food was not savory, and the heart’s longing could not be severed. The three years of mourning meant that the heart’s longing could not be cut off from sorrow. In later ages, customs declined and manners decayed. Desires multiplied, rites and righteousness were abandoned, ruler and minister deceived one another, and fathers and sons doubted each other. Resentment filled their breasts, and thoughts of loyalty and filial longing were entirely lost—all such thoughts of devotion and remembrance perished. Though they donned mourning garments and hempen girdles, they laughed and jested within them. Even if they observed the three-year period, they lost the root of mourning, which lies in sorrow.

In ancient times, the Son of Heaven had one *ji*, and the feudal lords had one *tong*—a *ji* was a thousand *li* square, and a *tong* was a hundred *li* square. Each guarded their own bounds and did not encroach upon one another. *Bounds* means borders.

As the *Book of Songs* says: *"Majestic is the Lord of Lu, at the Pond offering captives."* Earthen works were unadorned, for they were plain. Woodwork was uncarved, for it remained simple.

chunks.original_text: 有不行王道者，暴虐万民，争地侵壤，乱政犯禁，召之不至，令之不行，言不行上令者。 行，读行马之行。 禁之不止，诲之不变，诲，教也。 变，更也。 乃举兵而伐之，戮其君，易其党，封其墓，类其社，有贤者受恶君之诛，则封殖其墓。 若武王伐纣，封比干之墓是也。 祭社曰类。 以事类祭之也。 诗云，是类是褐也。 卜其子孙以代之。 卜，择立其子孙之贤也。 天子不灭国，诸侯不灭姓，古之政也。 晚世务广地侵壤，并兼无已，举不义之兵，伐无罪之国，杀不辜之民，绝先圣之后，辜，罪也。 民皆帝王之后，故曰绝先圣之后。 大国出攻，小国城守，驱人之牛马，傒人之子女，傒，系囚之系，读曰鸡。 毁人之宗庙，迁人之重宝，血流千里，暴骸满野，以赡贪主之欲，非兵之所为生也。 言兵为禁暴整乱设，不为作乱生也。 故兵者，所以讨暴，非所以为暴也。 言兵讨人之暴乱，非所以自为暴乱也。 乐者，所以致和，非所以为淫也。 乐荡人之邪志，存人之正性，致其中和而已，非所为自淫过也。 丧者，所以尽哀，非所以为伪也。 丧铺哭泣，所以尽孝子之哀情也，非所以为诈伪佯哀戚而已也。 故事亲有道矣，而爱为务； 道，孝道。 务在爱敬其亲。 朝廷有容矣，而敬为上； 朝廷之容济济也，父子主爱，君臣主敬，故以敬为上也。 处丧有礼矣，而哀为主； 处，居也。 丧礼，三年之礼也。 论语曰，丧与其易也，宁戚。 故曰以哀为主也。 用兵有术矣，而义为本。 术，数也。 阴阳天生虚实之数也。 传曰，天生五材，民并用之，废一不可，谁能去兵。 兵之所由来久矣，圣人以兴，乱人以亡，废兴存亡，昏明之术也。 故曰以义为本。 本立而道行，本伤而道废。 本立，义立也。 本伤，义丧也。 故曰道废。 淮南鸿烈解卷之十三竟 #1『其』，『芒』字之误，据集解本改。 #2『感』，『威』字之误，据集解本改。 #3『淫』，『游』字之误，据集解本改。 #4『与性』二字误入注文，据集解本改。 #5脱『不敬』二字，据集解本补。 #6『佑』，『石』字之误，据集解本改。 #7『曰』，『目』字之误，据集解本改。 #8『公』当作『馘是』，据集解本补改。 #9『而』『不』字之误，据集解本政。 #10『事』，『亡』字之误，据集解本改。 #11脱『相』字，据集解本补。 淮南鸿烈解卷之十四 太尉祭酒臣许慎记上

Those who do not follow the Kingly Way oppress the myriad people, contend for land and encroach upon territory, disrupt governance and violate prohibitions. When summoned, they do not come; when commanded, they do not obey—this refers to those who disregard the sovereign’s decrees. *Xing* (行) is read as in *xingma* (行马, "barrier"). When forbidden, they do not cease; when admonished, they do not change. *Hui* (诲) means "to teach," and *bian* (变) means "to alter."

Thus, armies are raised to punish them: their rulers are executed, their factions are replaced, their tombs are sealed, and their altars are ritually renewed. If worthy men suffer under a wicked ruler’s punishment, their tombs are honored and cultivated—such as when King Wu punished Zhou and sealed the tomb of Bi Gan. Sacrifices to the altar are called *lei* (类), meaning "to offer sacrifices by category." As the *Odes* says, *"This is the* lei*, this is the* he." Their descendants are divined to succeed them. *Bu* (卜) means to select and establish the worthiest among their descendants.

The Son of Heaven does not extinguish states; the feudal lords do not eradicate lineages—this was the governance of antiquity. In later ages, men were bent on expanding territory and encroaching upon lands, ceaselessly annexing others. They raised unrighteous armies to attack blameless states, slaughtered innocent people, and severed the posterity of former sages—for all people are descendants of emperors and kings, and thus this is called "severing the posterity of former sages." Great states launched attacks, while small states fortified their cities. They drove away others’ cattle and horses, seized others’ sons and daughters—*xi* (傒) is read as *xi* (系, "to bind"), like a prisoner. They destroyed others’ ancestral temples, carried off others’ treasures, blood flowed for a thousand *li*, and exposed corpses filled the wilderness, all to sate the desires of greedy rulers. This is not the purpose for which armies exist.

Armies are established to suppress violence and rectify disorder, not to create it. Thus, armies are for punishing the violent, not for perpetrating violence. Music is for achieving harmony, not for indulgence. Music dispels people’s wayward intentions and preserves their true nature, attaining the mean and harmony—it is not for self-indulgence or excess. Mourning is for fully expressing grief, not for pretense. Mourning rites—wailing and weeping—are for exhausting the filial child’s sorrow, not for feigning false grief.

Thus, in serving parents, there is a Way, and love is the essential duty—the *Dao* (道) being the Way of filial piety, with the duty lying in loving and respecting one’s parents. In court, there is decorum, and reverence is paramount—the court’s decorum is solemn, and while father and son prioritize love, ruler and minister prioritize reverence, hence reverence is held above all. In mourning, there are rites, and sorrow is the essence—*chu* (处) means "to dwell," and mourning rites refer to the three-year observance. As the *Analects* says, *"In mourning, rather than ease, better grief."* Thus, sorrow is the essence. In warfare, there is strategy, and righteousness is the foundation—*shu* (术) means "method," referring to the calculations of yin and yang and the natural patterns of emptiness and fullness. As the tradition states, *"Heaven generates the five materials, and the people use them all; none can be abandoned—who could do away with armies?"* Armies have existed since ancient times: the sagely use them to rise, while the disorderly use them to perish. Their decline or flourishing, survival or ruin, depend on the clarity or obscurity of their methods. Thus, righteousness is the foundation.

When the foundation stands, the Way advances; when the foundation is harmed, the Way decays. *Ben li* (本立) means "righteousness is established," and *ben shang* (本伤) means "righteousness is lost." Hence, the Way decays.

*Huainan Honglie Jie*, Scroll Thirteen, concludes.

chunks.original_text: 主术训上 主，君也。 术，道也。 君之宰国统御臣下，五帝三王以来，无不用道而兴，故曰主术也，因以题篇。 人主之术，处无为之事，而行不言之教，教，令也。 谓不言而事办也。 清静而不动，一度而不摇，因循而任下，责成而不劳。 成办而不自劳。 是故心知规而师傅谕导，规，谋也。 师者，所从取法则也。 傅，相也。 谕导以正道也。 口能言而行人称辞，足能行而相者先导，相，仪。 耳能听而执正进谏。 谏，或作谋也。 其世子时也。 是故虑无失策谋无过事过犹误也。 言为文章，行为仪表於天下，为天下人所法则也。 进退应时，动静循理，不为丑美好憎，不为赏罚喜怒，名各自名，类各自类，事犹自然，莫出於己。 故古之王者，冕而前旒所以蔽明也，冕，王者冠也。 前旒，前后垂珠饰遂筵也。 下自目，故曰蔽明也。 天子玉县十二，公侯挂珠九，卿点珠六，伯子各应随其命数也。 黈纩塞耳所以掩聪，不欲其妄闻也。 黈，读而买黈益之黈也。 天子外屏所以自障。 屏，树垣也。 尔雅曰，门内之垣谓之树。 论语曰，国君树塞门。 诸侯在内，天子在外，故曰所以自障也。 故所理者远，则所在者迩，所治者大，则所守者少。 夫目妄视则淫，耳妄听则惑，口妄言则乱。 夫三关者，不可不慎守也。 若欲规之，乃是离之； 言嗜欲有所规合，乃是离散也。 若欲饰之，乃是贼之； 饰，好也。 贼，败也。 天气为魂，地气为魄，反之玄房，各处其宅。 守而勿失，上通太一。 太一之精，通於天道。 天道玄默，无容无则，大不可极，深不可测，测，尽。 尚与人化，知不能得。 天道至大，非人智虑所能得也。 昔者神农之治天下也，神不驰於胸中，言释神安静，不躁动也。 智不出於四域，信身在中。 怀其仁成之心，怀，思。 甘雨时降，五谷蕃植蕃，茂。 植，长。 春生夏长，秋收冬藏。 月省时考，茂，成。 岁终献功，以时尝谷，尝之新谷，荐之明堂。 祀于明堂。 明堂之制，有盖而无四方，风雨不能袭，寒暑不能伤。 迁延而入之，养民以公。 迁延，犹倘佯也。 已说在本经也。 其民朴重端悫，端，直也。 悫，成也。 不忿争而财足，不劳形而功成。 因天地之资，而与之和同，是故威厉而不杀，刑错而不用，法省而不烦，省，约也。 烦，多也。 故其化如神。
chunks.translated_text:
**Governance and the Dao, Part One**

*Main* (主) means "ruler," and *shu* (术) means "Dao/Way." Since the rulers of states govern their domains and command their ministers—from the Five Emperors and Three Kings onward—none have risen without employing the Dao/Way. Thus, it is called *the ruler’s Dao/Way*, and the chapter is titled accordingly.

The ruler’s Dao/Way lies in dwelling in non-action and practicing wordless instruction. *Instruction* (教) means *command* (令), referring to the accomplishment of affairs without speech. Remaining serene and unmoving, maintaining constancy without wavering, following precedent and entrusting matters to subordinates, holding them accountable without toil—this is achieving success without personal labor.

Thus, the mind comprehends plans, and tutors and mentors provide guidance. *Plan* (规) means *strategy* (谋). A *tutor* (师) is one from whom models are drawn, while a *mentor* (傅) is an attendant. Guidance is given through the correct Dao/Way. The mouth speaks, and envoys convey words; the feet walk, and attendants lead the way. *Attendants* (相) serve as models. The ears listen, and upright officials offer remonstrance. *Remonstrance* (谏) may also mean *deliberation* (谋). This applies to the heir apparent in his youth.

Thus, deliberations avoid miscalculations, and strategies avoid errors. *Error* (过) here means *mistake* (误). Words become literary works, and conduct serves as a model for the world, a standard for all under Heaven. Advancing and retreating in accord with the seasons, moving and resting in accordance with principle—neither swayed by ugliness or beauty, nor by favor or disdain; neither rejoicing in rewards and punishments nor angered by them—names are each true to their names, categories to their categories. Affairs proceed as naturally as if nothing originated from the self.

Thus, the kings of antiquity wore the *mian* crown with its hanging strands to veil their sight. The *mian* is the crown of the Son of Heaven. The *liu* strands, adorned with hanging pearls, extend before and behind, descending to the level of the eyes—hence, *veiling sight*. The Son of Heaven’s jade chimes numbered twelve, while dukes and marquises hung nine, ministers six, and earls and viscounts each according to their rank. The *toukuang* filled the ears to block hearing, preventing reckless listening. *Tou* (黈) is read as in *maitou yi zhi tou* (买黈益之黈). The outer screen of the Son of Heaven served as a barrier. *Screen* (屏) refers to a planted wall. The *Erya* states, "The wall within the gate is called a *shu* (树)." The *Analects* says, "The ruler of a state plants a screen at his gate." For feudal lords, it is placed within; for the Son of Heaven, without—hence, *serving as a barrier*.

Thus, governing what is distant ensures presence in what is near; managing what is great ensures holding little. If the eyes recklessly gaze, they become licentious; if the ears recklessly listen, they become deluded; if the mouth recklessly speaks, it causes chaos. These three gates must be guarded with utmost care.

If one seeks to regulate them, one only estranges them. *Regulate* (规) means to align desires, yet this only leads to dispersion. If one seeks to adorn them, one only harms them. *Adorn* (饰) means to embellish; *harm* (贼) means to ruin. Heaven’s *qi* forms the *hun*, and earth’s *qi* forms the *po*. Returning them to the mysterious chamber, each resides in its proper dwelling. Guard them without loss, and they ascend to connect with the Great Unity.

The essence of the Great Unity flows through the Dao/Way of Heaven. The Dao/Way of Heaven is profoundly silent, without form or rule, vast beyond measure, deep beyond fathoming. *Fathoming* (测) means exhausting. Yet it transforms with humanity, though knowledge cannot grasp it. The Dao/Way of Heaven is supremely great—beyond the reach of human intellect.

In ancient times, when Shennong governed the world, his spirit did not race within his breast—his spirit was at peace, undisturbed. His wisdom did not extend beyond the four bounds, for his person remained centered. Embracing a heart of benevolence and completion, *embracing* (怀) means cherishing, timely sweet rains descended, and the five grains flourished. *Flourished* (蕃) means thriving; *grew* (植) means to lengthen. Spring brought life, summer growth, autumn harvest, and winter storage. Monthly inspections and seasonal assessments ensured abundance and completion. At year’s end, achievements were presented, and the new grain was tasted in due season, offered in the Hall of Light. Sacrifices were made in the Hall of Light.

The Hall of Light’s design featured a roof but no walls on four sides, shielding it from wind and rain, cold and heat. One entered with leisurely steps, nurturing the people with impartiality. *Leisurely steps* (迁延) means to wander or linger, as explained in the original text. The people were simple, weighty, upright, and sincere. *Upright* (端) means straight; *sincere* (悫) means complete. They did not contend in anger, yet their wealth sufficed; they did not toil in body, yet their works were accomplished.

Relying on the resources of Heaven and Earth, they harmonized with them. Thus, their authority was stern yet not lethal, punishments were set aside and unused, laws were few yet not burdensome. *Few* (省) means concise; *burdensome* (烦) means excessive. Therefore, their transformation was like that of spirits.

chunks.original_text: 其地南至交址，北至幽都，幽冥之都。 东至旸谷，日所出也。 西至三危，三危，西极之山。 莫不听从。 当此之时，法宽刑缓，囹圄空虚，而天下一俗，一同其俗。 莫怀奸心。 末世之政则不然，上好取而无量，下贪狼而无让，民贫苦而忿争，事力劳而无功，智诈萌兴，盗贼滋彰，上下相怨，号令不行。 执政有司，不务反道矫拂其本，而事修其末，事，治。 削薄其德，曾累其刑，而欲以为治，无以异於执弹而来鸟，□棁而狎犬也，乱乃逾甚。 逾，益。 夫水浊则鱼噞，鱼短气，出口於水，喘息之谕也。 政苛则民乱。 言聊也。
chunks.translated_text:
The land extended south to Jiaozhi, north to Youdu—the capital of darkness—east to Yanggu, where the sun rises, and west to Sanwei, the mountain at the westernmost extremity. None failed to heed and obey.

In that era, laws were lenient and punishments mild; prisons stood empty. The world shared a single custom, unified in its ways. No one harbored deceitful intentions.

In the degenerate age that followed, governance was otherwise: rulers coveted without measure, while the people, greedy as wolves, yielded nothing. The people suffered in poverty and contended in anger; their toil bore no fruit. Cunning and deceit sprouted, banditry flourished, and resentment grew between high and low. Decrees went unheeded.

Those in power, rather than returning to the Dao to correct the root, busied themselves with trifles—*busied* (事) meaning to govern. They pared away virtue, heaped up punishments, yet sought order, no different from luring birds with a slingshot or taming dogs with a stick. Chaos only worsened—*worsened* (逾) meaning to increase.

When water grows turbid, fish gasp, their breath short, mouths breaking the surface—a metaphor for panting. When governance turns harsh, the people descend into disorder. Such is the way of things.
