chunks.original_text: 大路，上路也。 王者功成作乐，故撞钟击鼓。 咸池，黄帝乐也。 干，楯也。 戚，斧也。 春夏舞者所执。 当此之时，有立武者见疑。 疑，怪也。 一世之问，而文武代为雌雄，有时而用也。 今世之为武者则非文也，为文者则非武也，文武更相非，而不知时世之用也。 此见隅曲之一指，而不知八极之广大也。 隅曲，室中之区隅，言狭小。 八极，八方之极言广大也。 故东面而望，不见西墙，南面而视，不睹北方，唯无所向者，则无所不通。 无所向，则可以见四方，故曰无所不通。 国之所以存者，道德也，道德施行，民说其化，故国存也。 家之所以亡者，理塞也。 理，道。 尧无百户之郭，舜无置锥之地，以有天下。 禹无十人之众，汤无七里之分，以王诸侯。 文王处岐周之间也，地方不过百里，而立为天子者，有王道也。 尧、舜、禹、汤、文王，皆王有天下，孟子曰，以德行仁者，身王不待，亦是也。 夏桀、殷纣之盛也，人迹所至、舟车所通，莫不为郡县，然而身死人手，而为天下笑者，有亡形也。 孟子曰，恶死亡，乐不仁，不仁必死亡，故曰有亡形也。 故圣人见化以观其征，征，成。 德有盛衰，风先萌焉。 风，气也。 萌，见也。 有盛德者，谓文王也。 伯夷、太公先见之。 有衰德者，谓桀。 太史令终古及向艺先去之也。 故得王道者，虽小必大； 汤武是也。 有亡形者，虽成必败。 桀纣是也。 夫夏之将亡，太史令终古先奔於商，三年而桀乃亡。 汤灭之也。 殷之将败也，太史令向艺先归文王，期年而纣乃亡。 武王灭之。 故圣人之见存亡之迹，成败之际也，非乃鸣条之野，甲子之日也。 汤伐桀，禽於鸣条。 武王诛纣，以甲子克之。 今谓强者胜则度地计众，富者利则量粟称金，若此，则千乘之君无不霸王者，而万乘之国无不破亡者矣。 存亡之迹，若此其易知也，愚夫意妇皆能论之。 憃亦愚，无智之貌也。 赵襄子以晋阳之城霸，智伯以三晋之地擒； 智伯，智县。 襄子，无恤也。 三晋，智氏兼有韩，魏，智伯帅韩魏之君围赵襄子於晋阳，赵襄子使张孟谈与韩魏通谋，韩魏反而击之，大破智伯之军，获其首，以为饮器。 故曰以三晋之地擒也。 愍王以大齐亡，为淳齿所杀也。 田单以即墨有功。 燕伐齐而（代）［灭］#12之，得七十城，唯即墨未下。 田单以市吏率即墨市民以击燕师，破之，故能有功也。 故国之亡也，虽大不足恃，大犹亡，智伯是。 道之行也，虽小不可轻。 汤以七十里，文王以百里，皆有天下，故虽小不可轻也。 由此观之，存在得道而不在於大也，得道之君，虽小，为善而能王天下，故曰不在於大也。 亡在失道而不在於小也。 无道之君，虽小，以为恶无伤而弗革，积必亡，故曰不在於小也。 诗云，乃眷西顾，此惟与宅。 言去殷而迁于周也。 纣治朝歌，在东。 文王国於岐周，在西。 天乃眷然顾西土，此唯居周言我宅也。 故曰去殷而迁于周也。 故乱国之君，务广其地而不务仁义，务高其位而不务道德，是释其所以存，而造其所以亡也。 故桀囚於焦门，而不能自非其所行，不自非行之恶。 而悔不杀汤於夏台，台，或作宫。 纣拘於宣室，而不反其过，反，悔。 而悔不诛文王於羑里。 悔，恨也。 羑里，今河内汤阴是也。
chunks.translated_text:
The *Great Chariot* is the supreme chariot. When a king’s achievements are complete, he creates music, hence the striking of bells and beating of drums. *Xianchi* is the music of the Yellow Emperor. *Gan* refers to shields, and *qi* to axes—these are the implements held by dancers in spring and summer.

At this time, those who established martial rule were viewed with suspicion. *Suspicion* here means doubt. Within a single generation, civil and martial governance alternated in dominance, each employed as the times required. Yet in the present age, those who practice martial rule dismiss civil governance, while those who uphold civil governance dismiss martial rule. They mutually condemn one another, unaware of the demands of their era. This is like seeing only a corner of a room and remaining ignorant of the vastness of the eight directions. *A corner of a room* refers to a confined space, narrow and small; *the eight directions* signify the boundless expanse of the eight cardinal points. Thus, one who faces east cannot see the western wall, and one who looks south cannot perceive the north—only one who turns toward nothingness can comprehend all directions. *Turning toward nothingness* means perceiving the four quarters, hence the saying: "There is nothing it does not penetrate."

A state endures through virtue and power; when virtue and power are enacted, the people delight in their transformation, and so the state endures. A household perishes through the obstruction of principle. *Principle* is the Way. Yao ruled without a walled city of a hundred households, and Shun possessed not even land enough to plant an awl, yet they held all under Heaven. Yu had no following of ten men, and Tang no domain of seven *li*, yet they reigned over the feudal lords. King Wen dwelled between Qi and Zhou with a territory no larger than a hundred *li*, yet he rose to become the Son of Heaven—this was because he possessed the kingly Way. Yao, Shun, Yu, Tang, and King Wen all ruled all under Heaven. As Mencius said, "Those who practice virtue and benevolence become kings without waiting"—this is the same principle.

In their heyday, the might of Jie of Xia and Zhou of Yin extended wherever human footsteps reached, wherever boats and chariots traveled, all made into commanderies and counties. Yet they died at the hands of others and became laughingstocks of the world—this was because they bore the signs of ruin. As Mencius said, "They loathed death and delighted in unrighteousness; unrighteousness must lead to death," hence the saying: "They bore the signs of ruin."

Thus, the sage observes transformations to discern their omens. *Omens* signify fulfillment. When virtue waxes or wanes, the winds of change first appear. *Winds* refer to *qi*; *appear* means to manifest. Those of abundant virtue—such as King Wen—were foreseen by Boyi and the Grand Duke. Those of declining virtue—such as Jie—were first abandoned by the Grand Scribe Zhong Gu and Xiang Yi.

Therefore, those who attain the kingly Way, though small, will surely grow great—Tang and Wu are examples. Those who bear the signs of ruin, though established, will surely fall—Jie and Zhou are examples. When Xia was about to perish, the Grand Scribe Zhong Gu first fled to Shang; three years later, Jie was destroyed—Tang overthrew him. When Yin was about to collapse, the Grand Scribe Xiang Yi first submitted to King Wen; a year later, Zhou was annihilated—King Wu destroyed him. Thus, the sage perceives the traces of survival and ruin, the junctures of success and failure, not merely at the wilds of Mingtiao or on the day of Jiazi. Tang vanquished Jie and captured him at Mingtiao; King Wu punished Zhou and triumphed on the day of Jiazi.

Now, if the strong prevail by measuring land and counting multitudes, and the wealthy profit by weighing grain and gold, then every lord of a thousand chariots would become a hegemon or king, and every state of ten thousand chariots would face destruction. The traces of survival and ruin would be so easily discerned that even fools and simple women could discuss them. *Fools* here means dull-witted, lacking intelligence.

Zhao Xiangzi made Jinyang his bastion of hegemony, while Zhi Bo was captured with the lands of the Three Jin. *Zhi Bo* refers to Zhi Xian; *Xiangzi* is Wuxu. The Three Jin—Zhi, Han, and Wei—were united under Zhi Bo, who led the lords of Han and Wei to besiege Zhao Xiangzi at Jinyang. Zhao Xiangzi sent Zhang Mengtan to negotiate with Han and Wei, who then turned against Zhi Bo, crushing his army and taking his head to fashion a drinking vessel—hence the saying: "captured with the lands of the Three Jin." King Min of Qi perished with his great state, slain by Chunshen. Tian Dan achieved merit at Jimo. When Yan invaded Qi and conquered it, seizing seventy cities, only Jimo remained unconquered. Tian Dan, a market officer, led the people of Jimo to strike the Yan forces and defeated them—thus he was able to achieve merit.

Therefore, the fall of a state, though vast, is not to be relied upon—even the great may perish, as Zhi Bo did. The practice of the Way, though small, must not be taken lightly. Tang ruled with seventy *li*, and King Wen with a hundred *li*, yet both held all under Heaven—thus, though small, it must not be taken lightly.

From this, we see that survival lies in attaining the Way, not in greatness. A lord who attains the Way, though small, can do good and rule all under Heaven—hence it is said: "not in greatness." Ruin lies in losing the Way, not in smallness. A lord without the Way, though small, persists in evil without reform, and accumulation leads to ruin—hence it is said: "not in smallness."

The *Book of Songs* says:
*"Then gazing westward, he turned his regard,
This alone shall be our dwelling."*
This speaks of departing Yin and moving to Zhou. Zhou ruled from Chaoge in the east, while King Wen’s state lay in Qi and Zhou in the west. Heaven then turned its regard to the western lands, saying, "This alone shall be our dwelling"—hence the saying: "departing Yin and moving to Zhou."

Thus, the rulers of disordered states strive to expand their territories but neglect benevolence and righteousness; they seek to elevate their positions but disregard virtue and power. In doing so, they abandon what sustains them and create the conditions for their own ruin.

Jie was imprisoned at Jiaomen yet did not reproach his own conduct—he did not condemn the evil of his actions—but only regretted not killing Tang at the Summer Terrace. *Terrace* is sometimes written as *Palace*. Zhou was confined at Xuan Hall yet did not repent his faults—*repent* means to feel remorse—but only regretted not executing King Wen at Youli. *Regret* here means resentment. Youli is present-day Tangyin in Henan.

The scholars of Zou and Lu, the Ru and Mo, were gathered, and the teachings of the former sages were transmitted. The Son of Heaven’s banner was raised, the grand chariot mounted, the nine streamers unfurled, the great bells struck, the sounding drums beaten, the *Xianchi* performed, and the *Ganqi* dance enacted, as recorded in the *Rites of Zhou*.

chunks.original_text: 羑，古牖守。 二君处强大势位，修仁义之道，汤、武救罪之不给，何谋之敢当。 二君，桀、纣也。 当其君也，强大之势，不能自知所行之非也。 假令能修仁义之道，则汤武不敢生诛之谋也。 若上乱三光之明，下失万民之心，三光，日、月、星辰也。 失万民心，施民所恶也。 虽微汤、武，孰弗能夺也。 言遭人能夺之，不必汤武也。 今不审其在己者，而反备之于人，言不慎行己之德，而乃反备天下之人来诛也。 天下非一汤、武也，杀一人，则必有继之者也。 且汤武之所以处小弱而能以王者，以其有道也。 桀、纣之所以处强大而见夺者，以其无道也。 今不行人之所以王者，而反益己之所以夺，是趋亡之道也。 武王克殷，欲筑宫於五行之山。 五行山，今太行山也。 在何内野王县北上党关也。 周公曰，不可。 夫五行之山，固塞险阻之地也。 使我德能覆之，则天下纳其贡职者回也。 回，迂难也。 回，或作固。 固，必也。 使我有暴乱之行，则天下之伐我难矣。 周公言我有暴乱之行，则天下当来伐我，无为於五行之山，使天下来伐我者难也。 言其依德，不侍险也。 此所以三十六世而不夺也。 周公可谓能持满矣。 满，满而不溢也。 故曰能持满也。 昔者，周书有言曰，周史之书。 上言者，下用也； 下言者，上用也。 可否相济。 上言者，常也； 为君常也。 下言者，权也。 此存亡之术也。 权，谋也。 谋度事宜，不失其道也。 唯圣人为能知权。 言而必信，期而必当，天下之高行也。 直躬其父攘羊而子证之，直躬，楚叶县人也。 叶公子高谓孔子曰，吾党有直躬者，其父攘羊而子证之。 孔子曰，吾党之直者异於是，父为子隐，子为父隐，直在其中矣。 凡六畜自来，而取之曰攘之。 尾生与妇人期而死之。 尾生，鲁人，与妇人期於梁下，水至溺死也。 直而证父，信而溺死，虽有直信，孰能贵之。 夫三军矫命，过之大者也。 秦穆公兴兵袭郑，过周而东。 以兵伐国，不击鼓，密声，曰袭。 周者，王城也。 公羊传曰，王城者，河西周也。 今河南县也。 郑贾人弦高将西贩牛，道遇秦师於周郑之间，乃矫郑伯之命，犒以十二牛，宾秦师而却之，非君命也，而称君命，曰矫。 酒肉曰向，牛羊曰犒，芬其枯槁也。 秦师曰行千里而袭之，远主有备而师无继，不如还，遂还师而去也，故曰却之。 以存郑国。 故事有所至，信反为过，诞反为功。 信为过者，尾生是。 诞为功者，弦高是也。 何谓失礼而有大功，昔楚恭王战於阴陵，恭王与晋厉战於阴陵，吕锜射於恭王，中（厥）〔目〕#13因而擒之。 过而能改，故曰恭也。 潘尪、养由基、黄衰微、公孙丙相与篡之，四子，楚大夫，篡晋取恭王。 衰，读绳之维。 微读抆诚之抆也。 恭王惧而失体，威仪不如常，坐不能起也。 黄衰微举足蹴其体，恭王乃觉。 怒其失礼，奋体而起，四大夫载而行。 失礼，谓举足蹴君也。 昔苍吾绕娶妻而美，以让兄，此所谓忠爱而不可行者也。 苍吾绕，孔子时人。 以妻美好，推与其兄。 於兄则爱矣，而违亲近曲顾之义，故曰不可行也。 是故圣人论事之扃曲直，与之屈伸偃仰，无常仪表，时屈时伸。 卑弱柔如蒲韦，非摄夺也； 刚强猛毅，志厉青云，非本矜也； 以乘时应变也。

"Yǒu" is an ancient term for "prison warden." When these two rulers held overwhelming power and authority, had they cultivated the Dao of benevolence and righteousness, Tang and Wu would not have had the means to execute their punitive campaigns—how could any plot against them have succeeded? These two rulers refer to Jie and Zhou. While they reigned, their might and dominance blinded them to the wrongness of their own conduct. Had they but practiced the Dao of benevolence and righteousness, Tang and Wu would not have dared devise schemes to execute them.

Yet when they threw into chaos the brilliance of the Three Luminaries above and lost the hearts of the myriad people below—the Three Luminaries being the sun, moon, and stars—even without Tang and Wu, who could not have seized their thrones? This means that any capable person could have overthrown them; it need not have been Tang or Wu. Now, instead of examining their own conduct, they turned to guard against others. They failed to cultivate their own virtue and power, yet sought to defend against the world’s condemnation. The world does not have only one Tang or Wu—kill one, and another will surely follow.

Moreover, Tang and Wu, though small and weak, could attain kingship because they possessed the Dao. Jie and Zhou, though strong and dominant, were overthrown because they lacked the Dao. Now, instead of practicing what leads to kingship, they only compounded what leads to their own downfall—this is the path to ruin.

When King Wu conquered Yin, he wished to build a palace on the Mountain of the Five Phases. This Mountain of the Five Phases is present-day Mount Taihang, located north of Heyang County in Henan, at the Shangdang Pass. The Duke of Zhou said, "This cannot be done. The Mountain of the Five Phases is a place of solid barriers and perilous terrain. If our virtue can encompass it, the world will submit its tribute and service, though the journey be circuitous and difficult. *Circuitous* is sometimes written as *certain*. *Certain* means *inevitable*. But if we act with violence and disorder, the world will find it difficult to attack us." The Duke of Zhou meant that if they acted with violence and disorder, the world would come to punish them, and there would be no need to rely on the Mountain of the Five Phases to make their attackers’ task difficult. This is to say, they should rely on virtue, not on terrain. This is why the Zhou dynasty endured for thirty-six generations without being overthrown. The Duke of Zhou could truly be called one who "held fullness." *Fullness* means being full yet not overflowing. Hence the saying: "able to hold fullness."

Formerly, the *Book of Zhou* stated: "The words of superiors are put into practice by inferiors; the words of inferiors are put into practice by superiors. Approval and disapproval complement one another. The words of superiors are the constant; they are the constant of the ruler. The words of inferiors are the expedient; this is the art of survival and ruin. *Expedient* means *strategy*—weighing circumstances and acting without losing the Dao. Only the sage can master the expedient."

To speak and be invariably trustworthy, to set a time and invariably meet it—these are the highest conduct in the world. Yet when the upright man of She, whose father had stolen a sheep, bore witness against him—the upright man was a native of Ye County in Chu—Zigao, the Viscount of Ye, said to Confucius, "In my village there is an upright man: when his father stole a sheep, his son bore witness against him." Confucius replied, "The upright in my village differ from this. Fathers cover for their sons, and sons cover for their fathers—uprightness lies therein." *Stealing* refers to taking livestock that comes of its own accord. Weisheng made an appointment with a woman and died for it. Weisheng was a man of Lu who had arranged to meet a woman beneath a bridge; when the waters rose, he drowned. To be upright and testify against one’s father, to be trustworthy and drown for an appointment—though one may possess uprightness and trustworthiness, who could esteem such conduct?

To falsify orders in the Three Armies is a grave transgression. When Duke Mu of Qin raised troops to raid Zheng, he passed through Zhou on his eastward march. To attack a state with troops without sounding the drums—stealthily—is called *raiding*. Zhou was the royal capital. The *Gongyang Commentary* states: "The royal capital is Zhou west of the River," referring to present-day Henan County. The Zheng merchant Xian Gao was driving cattle westward to sell when he encountered the Qin army between Zhou and Zheng. He then falsified the orders of the Earl of Zheng, presenting twelve cattle to provision the Qin troops and hosting them as guests, thereby turning them back. *Falsifying* means claiming an order that was not given. *Provisioning* with wine and meat is called *xiang*; with cattle and sheep, *kao*—reviving what is withered. The Qin army said, "We have marched a thousand *li* to raid them, but the distant lord is prepared and our forces have no reinforcements. It would be better to return." They then withdrew their troops and departed, hence the saying "turned them back." Thus, he preserved the state of Zheng.

Therefore, in some matters, trustworthiness becomes transgression, and falsehood becomes merit. *Trustworthiness becoming transgression* refers to Weisheng; *falsehood becoming merit* refers to Xian Gao. What is meant by "acting contrary to ritual yet achieving great merit"? Formerly, when King Gong of Chu fought at Yinling—King Gong battled Duke Li of Jin at Yinling—Lü Qi shot King Gong in the eye and captured him. Because he later mended his ways, he was called *Gong* (Respectful). Pan Wang, Yang Youji, Huang Shuaiwei, and Gongsun Bing conspired to rescue him. These four were ministers of Chu. *Shuai* is read like *sheng* in *shengwei* (rope’s end); *wei* is read like *wen* in *wencao* (to wipe sincerely). King Gong, terrified, lost his composure; his dignity and bearing were not as usual, and he could not rise from his seat. Huang Shuaiwei lifted his foot and kicked the king’s body, whereupon King Gong awoke. Enraged by this breach of ritual, he roused himself and stood, and the four ministers carried him away. *Breach of ritual* refers to lifting one’s foot and kicking the ruler.

Formerly, Cangwu Rao took a wife of surpassing beauty and yielded her to his elder brother—this is what is called "loyal and loving yet impracticable." Cangwu Rao was a contemporary of Confucius. Because his wife was beautiful, he offered her to his elder brother. Though this was loving toward his brother, it violated the principle of honoring close kin and observing proper order, hence the saying "impracticable."

Thus, the sage, in judging the twists and turns of affairs, adapts to them with flexibility, bending and rising without fixed form. At times, he is lowly, weak, and pliant as rushes and leather—not from cowardice or submission. At others, he is firm, strong, and fiercely resolute, his aspirations soaring to the blue clouds—not from innate arrogance. This is to seize the moment and respond to change.

chunks.original_text: 夫君臣之接，屈膝卑拜，以相尊礼也； 至其迫於患也，则举足蹙其体，天下莫能非也。 是故忠之所在，礼不足以难之也。 孝子之事亲，和颜卑体，奉带运履，运，正回也。 至其溺也，则捽其发而拯，拯，升也。 出溺曰拯也。 非敢骄侮，以救其死也。 故溺则捽父，祝则名君，孟子曰，嫂溺而不拯，是豺狼也。 而况父兄乎。 故溺则拯之。 祝则名君，周人以讳事神敬至也。 势不得不然也，此权之所设也。 故孔子曰，可以共学矣，而未可以适道也。 适，之。 道，仁义之善道。 可与适道，未可以立也。 立德、立功、立言。 可以立，未可与权。 权者，圣人之所独见也。 故忤而后合者，谓之知权。 忤，逆不合也。 权，因事制宜，权量轻重，无常形势，能（合）〔令〕#14丑反善，合於宜适，故圣人独见之也。 合而后舛者，谓之不知权。 不知权者，善反丑矣。 故礼者，实之华而伪之文也，方於卒迫穷遽之中也，则无所用矣。 无所用於礼也。 是故圣人以文交於世，而以实从事於宜，不结於一迹之涂，凝滞而不化，是故败事少而成事多，号令行于天下而莫之能非矣。 结，犹众也。 猩猩知往而不知来，猩猩，北方兽名，人面兽身，黄色。 礼记曰，猩猩能言，不离走兽。 见人往走，则知人姓字。 此知往也。
chunks.translated_text:
In the intercourse between ruler and minister, bowing the knee and lowering the body serve to express mutual respect and propriety. Yet when peril presses, one may raise a foot to trample the ruler’s person—none in the world would condemn this. Thus, where loyalty resides, ritual propriety cannot constrain it.

When a filial son serves his parents, he softens his countenance and humbles his posture, bearing their sash and adjusting their shoes—*yun* means to turn or adjust. But if they fall into the water, he seizes their hair to pull them out—*zheng* means to lift or rescue, for one rescues from drowning. He does not dare arrogance or disrespect; he acts to save their lives. Thus, when a father drowns, one seizes his hair; when praying, one names the ruler. Mencius said, "If one’s sister-in-law drowns and one does not rescue her, one is a jackal or wolf—how much more so for father or elder brother?" Hence, when drowning occurs, one rescues; when praying, one names the ruler. The Zhou people, in their reverence for the divine, avoided naming the ruler in prayers—yet circumstances leave no alternative. This is where expediency is applied.

Thus Confucius said, "One may study together, yet not be fit to follow the Way." *Shi* means to go; the Way is the virtuous path of benevolence and righteousness. "One may follow the Way, yet not be fit to stand." To stand is to establish virtue, merit, and teachings. "One may stand, yet not be fit to exercise expediency." Expediency is what only the sage perceives.

Thus, one who first resists and later conforms is said to understand expediency. *Wu* means to oppose or diverge; expediency adapts to circumstances, weighing light and heavy without fixed form, transforming the ugly into the good and aligning with what is fitting. Only the sage perceives this. One who conforms first and later errs is said not to understand expediency. Those who do not understand it turn good into ugliness.

Thus ritual is the flower of substance and the ornament of pretense. When pressed by sudden peril or dire straits, it has no use—ritual is of no avail. Therefore, the sage engages the world with formality but acts in accordance with what is fitting. He does not cling to a single path, rigid and unyielding. Thus he fails little and succeeds much; his commands are obeyed throughout the world, and none can condemn them.

To cling is to be bound. The *xingxing*—a beast of the northern lands, with a human face and animal body, yellow in color—knows what has passed but not what is to come. As the *Records of Ritual* says, "The *xingxing* can speak, yet remains a beast of the wild. Seeing people pass, it learns their names—this is knowing what has passed."

Thus, the sage, in judging the twists and turns of affairs, adapts to them with flexibility, bending and rising without fixed form. At times, he is lowly, weak, and pliant as rushes and leather—not from cowardice or submission. At others, he is firm, strong, and fiercely resolute, his aspirations soaring to the blue clouds—not from innate arrogance. This is to seize the moment and respond to change.

chunks.original_text: 又嗜酒，人以酒搏之，饮而不能息，不知当醉，以擒其身，故曰不能知来也。 乾鹄知来而不知往，乾鹄，鹊也，人将有来事忧喜之征，则鸣，此知来也。 知岁多风，多巢於木枝，人皆探其卵，故曰不知往也。 乾，读乾燥之乾。 鹄读告退之告。 此修短之分也。 昔者苌弘，周室之执数者也，苌弘，周景王之大夫也。 数，历术。 天地之气，日月之行，风两之变，律历之数，无所不通，然而不能自知，车裂而死。 晋范、中行氏之难，以畔其君也。 周刘氏与晋范氏世为婚姻，苌弘事刘文公，故周人助范氏。 至敬王二十八年，晋人让周，周为杀苌弘以释之，故曰而不能自知，车裂而死也。 苏秦，匹夫徒步之人也，靻矫嬴盖，经营万乘之主，服诺诸侯，然不自免於车裂之患。 苏秦，洛阳人也。 嬴，嬴囊也。 盖，步盖也。 苏秦相赵，赵封之为武安君。 初带籯囊，襜步盖，历说万乘之君，合东山之从，利病之势，无所不下，使诸侯服从，无有不服诺者。 故曰服诺诸侯，不自免於车裂之患。 说在诠言之篇。 淮南鸿烈解卷之十九竟
chunks.translated_text:
The *xingxing* also has a fondness for wine. People use wine to trap it, and once it drinks, it cannot stop—unaware of when it will become drunk, it is thus captured. Hence it is said to be unable to know what is to come.

The *ganhu*—the magpie—knows what is to come but not what has passed. When a person is about to encounter an omen of sorrow or joy, the *ganhu* cries out; this is knowing what is to come. It knows that years with frequent winds will lead it to build nests on the branches of trees, where people will steal its eggs. Hence it is said to be unable to know what has passed. *Gan* is read as in "dry" (*ganzao*); *hu* is read as in "retreat" (*gaotui*).

Such is the distinction between long and short foresight.

In ancient times, Chang Hong was the master of calculations in the Zhou court. Chang Hong was a minister of King Jing of Zhou. He was versed in the *shu*—the arts of the calendar. The qi of Heaven and Earth, the movements of the sun and moon, the changes of wind and rain, and the numbers of pitch-pipes and calendars—there was nothing he did not comprehend. Yet he could not foresee his own fate, and died by dismemberment. During the rebellion of Fan and Zhonghang clans in Jin, he had betrayed his lord. The Liu clan of Zhou had long been intermarried with the Fan clan of Jin, and Chang Hong served Duke Wen of Liu, so the people of Zhou aided the Fan clan. In the twenty-eighth year of King Jing, the people of Jin reproached Zhou, and Zhou executed Chang Hong to appease them. Thus it is said he could not foresee his own fate and died by dismemberment.

Su Qin was a commoner who traveled on foot. With a leather satchel and a humble canopy, he managed the affairs of rulers of ten thousand chariots and secured the compliance of the feudal lords. Yet he could not escape the disaster of dismemberment. Su Qin was a man of Luoyang. *Ying* refers to a leather satchel; *gai* refers to a walking canopy. Su Qin became chief minister of Zhao, which enfeoffed him as Lord Wu’an. Initially, he carried a satchel and a canopy, traveling to persuade the rulers of ten thousand chariots. He formed the Vertical Alliance of the eastern mountains, analyzing the advantages and disadvantages of the situation, and none could resist him. He made the feudal lords submit, and none dared refuse. Thus it is said he secured the compliance of the feudal lords but could not escape the disaster of dismemberment. This is discussed in the chapter on persuasive speech.

Here ends the nineteenth scroll of the *Huainan Honglie Jie*.

chunks.original_text: 泛论训下 徐偃王被服慈惠，身行仁义，陆地之朝者三十二国，然而身死国亡，子孙无类。 偃王於衰乱之世，修行仁义，不设武备，楚王灭之，故身死国亡也。 七谏篇曰，荆文误而徐亡是也。 大夫种辅翼越王句践，而为之报怨雪耻，擒夫差之身，开地数千里，然而身伏属镂而死。 句践奋计，报怨於吴王夫差，获千里之地，而越王终已疑之，赐其属镂以死也。 属镂，利剑也。 一曰，长剑摽施鹿卢，锋曳地，属录而行之也。 此皆达於治乱之机，机，要也。 而未知全性之具者。 故苌弘知天道而不知人事，苏秦知权谋而不知祸福，徐偃王知仁义而不知时，大夫种知忠而不知谋。 不自知为身谋。 圣人则不然，论世而为之事，权事而为之谋，是以舒之天下而不窕，内之寻常而不塞。 不窕，在大能大也。 八尺曰寻，倍寻曰常。 在小能小，不塞急也。 使天下荒乱，礼义绝，纲纪废，强弱相乘，力征相攘，臣主无差，贵贱无序，甲胃生蜡虱，乘，加也。 攘，平除。 生蜡虱，不离体也。 燕雀处帷幄，幄，幕也。 处，犹巢也。 而兵不休息，而乃始服属臾之貌，谨也。 恭俭之礼，则必灭抑而不能兴矣。 天下安宁，政教和平，百姓肃睦，上下相亲，而乃始立气矜，矜，自大也。 奋勇力，则必不免於有司之法矣。 是故圣人者，能阴能阳，能弱能强，随时而动静，因资而立功，物动而知其反，事萌而察其变，化则为之象，运则为之应，是以终身行而无所困。 故事有可行而不可言者，有可（战）〔言〕#1而不可行者，有易为而难成者，有难成而易败者。 所谓可行而不可言者，趋舍也； 可言而不可行者，伪诈也； 易为而难成者，事也； 难成而易败者，名也，此四策者，圣人之所独见而留意也。 掘寸而伸尺，圣人为之； 寸小，尺大。 小枉而大直，君子行之。 枉； 曲也。 直，直其道也。 周公有杀弟之累，诛管蔡也。 斋桓有争国之名，自莒先入，杀子纠也。 然而周公以义补缺，谓翼成王以致太平，七年归政，北面为臣，故曰以义补缺也。 桓公以功灭丑，立九合一匡之功，以灭争国之恶。 而皆为贤。 今以人之小过揜其大美，则天下无圣王贤相矣。 故目中有疵，不害於视，不可灼也； 疵，赘。 灼，燃。 喉中有病，无害於息，不可凿也。 凿，穿。 河上之丘冢，不可胜数，犹之为易也。 言河上本非丘垄之处，有易之地犹多，以大言之也，以谕万事多覆於少。 水激兴波，高下相临，差以寻常，犹之为平。 虽有激波，犹以为平，平者多也。 犹橘柚冬生，人曰冬死，〔死〕#2者众也，荠麦夏死，人曰夏生，〔生〕#3者多也。 昔者曹子为鲁将兵，三战不胜，亡地千里。 使曹子计不顾后，足不旋踵，刎刭於陈中，则终身为破军擒将矣。 然而曹子不羞其败，耻死而无功。 柯之盟，榆三尺之刃，造桓公之胸，三战所亡，一朝而反之，勇闻于天下，功立於鲁国。 复汶阳之田也。 管仲辅公子纠而不能遂，遂，成。 不可谓智； 遁逃奔走，不死其难，不死子纠之难也。 不可谓勇； 束缚桎梏，不讳其耻，不可谓贞。 当此三行者，布衣弗友，人君弗臣。 布衣之士不以为益友也，人君不以为义臣也。 然而管仲兔於累绁之中，立齐国之政，九合诸侯，一匡天下。
chunks.translated_text:
Here begins a general discourse on instruction:

King Xu of Xu clothed himself in kindness and benevolence, conducting himself with humanity and justice. Thirty-two states on land came to pay court to him. Yet he perished, his state was destroyed, and his descendants were wiped out. In an age of decline and chaos, King Xu cultivated humanity and justice, yet made no military preparations. The King of Chu annihilated him, and thus he perished along with his state. As the *Seven Admonitions* states: "King Wen of Jing erred, and Xu perished"—this is the case.

Minister Zhong assisted and guided King Goujian of Yue, aiding him in avenging grievances and wiping away shame. He captured the person of Fuchai, expanding territory by thousands of *li*. Yet in the end, he was forced to take his own life with the *shulou* sword. Goujian, deploying his stratagems, exacted vengeance upon King Fuchai of Wu, gaining a thousand *li* of land. Yet in the end, the King of Yue grew suspicious of him and presented him with the *shulou* to die. The *shulou* is a sharp sword. Another account says: a long sword with a deer-horn-shaped pommel, its tip dragging on the ground, trailing as one walks.

These men all grasped the mechanisms of order and chaos—*ji* meaning the essential point—yet did not know the means to preserve their nature. Thus, Chang Hong understood the Way of Heaven but not human affairs; Su Qin knew stratagems but not fortune and misfortune; King Xu of Xu knew humanity and justice but not timing; Minister Zhong knew loyalty but not planning. They did not know how to plan for themselves.

The sage is not thus. He assesses the age and acts accordingly, weighing matters and devising plans. Thus, he can extend his influence across the world without constraint, and apply it in the smallest matters without obstruction. *Not constrained* means that in great matters, he can act greatly. Eight *chi* make a *xun*; twice a *xun* makes a *chang*. In small matters, he can act small, without causing urgency or blockage.

If the world falls into desolation and chaos, ritual and justice are severed, the web of governance collapses, the strong oppress the weak, force is used to seize and plunder, minister and lord are indistinguishable, noble and base lack order, armor breeds wax-moths and lice—*cheng* meaning to ride upon, *rang* meaning to level—*breeding wax-moths and lice* means they never leave the body. Swallows and sparrows nest in tents and curtains—*wo* meaning a tent, *chu* meaning to dwell like a bird in its nest. Yet if warfare does not cease, and only then does one begin to adopt the demeanor of reverent restraint—*shuyu* describing a respectful and cautious appearance—and practice the rites of humility and frugality, one will surely be suppressed and unable to rise.

If the world is at peace, governance and education are harmonious, the hundred clans are respectful and harmonious, superiors and inferiors are affectionate toward one another, and only then does one begin to display arrogance and self-importance—*jin* meaning self-aggrandizement—and exert one’s strength and courage, one will surely not escape the laws of the authorities.

Thus, the sage is capable of both yin and yang, both weakness and strength. He moves or remains still according to the times, establishes merit based on available resources, perceives the return of things when they move, and discerns change when matters first sprout. When transformation occurs, he provides its image; when the course shifts, he responds accordingly. Thus, he acts throughout his life without ever encountering difficulty.

Therefore, there are matters that can be done but cannot be spoken of, matters that can be spoken of but cannot be done, matters that are easy to undertake but difficult to complete, and matters that are difficult to complete but easy to ruin.

What can be done but cannot be spoken of is the choice between advancing and retreating. What can be spoken of but cannot be done is deceit and falsehood. What is easy to undertake but difficult to complete is affairs. What is difficult to complete but easy to ruin is reputation. These four strategies are what the sage alone perceives and pays heed to.

To dig an inch to extend a foot—the sage does this. An inch is small, a foot is large. To bend slightly to achieve great straightness—the noble person practices this. *Bent* means crooked; *straight* means aligning with the Way.

The Duke of Zhou bore the burden of killing his younger brother—he executed Guan and Cai. Duke Huan bore the reputation of contending for the state—he entered first from Ju and killed Prince Jiu. Yet the Duke of Zhou mended the breach with righteousness, aiding King Cheng to bring about great peace, returning governance after seven years and facing north as a minister. Thus it is said he mended the breach with righteousness. Duke Huan obliterated disgrace with merit, establishing the achievement of uniting the feudal lords nine times and correcting the world, erasing the evil of contending for the state. Both were deemed worthy.

If one were to obscure a person’s great virtues because of minor faults, then the world would have no sage-kings or worthy ministers. Thus, a blemish in the eye does not impair vision—it cannot be burned away. *Blemish* means a growth; *burn* means to cauterize. An ailment in the throat does not obstruct breathing—it cannot be chiseled away. *Chisel* means to bore through. The burial mounds along the Yellow River are innumerable, yet the land remains easy to cultivate. This means that though the land along the river is not naturally suited for burial mounds, there is still much land that is easy to cultivate. Speaking broadly, this illustrates that in all things, the many often obscure the few.

When water is stirred, waves arise, with high and low points facing one another. Though they differ by a *xun* or a *chang*, it is still considered level. Even with surging waves, it is still deemed level because levelness is the norm. Just as oranges and pomelos grow in winter, people say they die in winter—because the dead are many. Shepherd’s purse and wheat die in summer, yet people say they grow in summer—because the living are many.

Formerly, Caozi led the troops of Lu into battle three times without victory, losing a thousand *li* of land. Had Caozi not considered the consequences, not turned his heels, and cut his throat in the ranks, he would have spent his life as a defeated general and captured commander. Yet Caozi was not ashamed of his defeat; he was ashamed to die without merit. At the Alliance of Ke, he brandished a three-*chi* blade, pressing it against Duke Huan’s chest. The land lost in three battles was recovered in a single morning. His courage was renowned throughout the world, and his merit was established in the state of Lu—restoring the fields of Wenyang.

Guan Zhong assisted Prince Jiu but could not bring his cause to fruition—*sui* meaning to succeed. He cannot be called wise. He fled and fled, yet did not die for his lord’s peril—not dying for Prince Jiu’s crisis. He cannot be called brave. Bound in fetters and shackles, he did not conceal his shame. He cannot be called steadfast. Possessing these three qualities, even a commoner would not befriend him, and a ruler would not employ him. A scholar would not consider him a worthy friend, and a ruler would not deem him a righteous minister. Yet Guan Zhong emerged from his bonds and fetters to establish the governance of the state of Qi, uniting the feudal lords nine times and correcting the world.

chunks.original_text: 使管仲出死损躯，不顾后图，岂有此霸功哉。 今人君论其臣也，不计其大功，总其略行，而求小善，则失贤之数也。 略，大也。 小善，忠也。 数，术也。 故人有厚德，无问其小节； 而有大誉，无疵其小故。 夫牛蹄之涔不能生鳣鲔，涔，雨水也，满牛蹄迹中，言其小也，故不能生鳣鲔也。 鳣，大鱼，长丈余，细鳞，黄首，白身，短头，口在腹下。 鲔，大鱼，亦长丈余，仲春二月从河西上，得过龙门，便为龙。 先师说云也。 而蜂房不容鹄卵，房，巢。 小形不足以包大体也。 夫人之情，莫不有所短，诚其大略是也，虽有小过，不足以为累。 诚其实，略其行。 若其大略非也，虽有闾里之行，未足大举。 举，用。 夫颜喙聚，梁父之大盗也，梁父，齐邑。 今属太山。 而为齐忠臣。 段干木，晋国之大驵也，而为文侯师。 驵，骄怚。 一曰，驵，市侩也。 言魏国之大侩也。 孟卯妻其嫂，有五子焉，然而相魏，宁其危，解其患。 孟卯，一齐人也。 及为魏，能安其危国，类其勋也。 战国策曰芒卯也。 景阳淫酒，被发而御於妇人，威服诸侯。 景阳楚将。 此四人者，皆有所短，然而功名不灭者，其略得也。 略，犹道也。 季襄、陈仲子立节抗行，不入洿君之朝，不食乱世之食，遂饿而死。 季襄，鲁人，孔子弟子。 陈仲子，齐人，孟子弟子，居於陵也。 不能存亡接绝者何？ 小节伸而大略屈。 伸，用。 屈，废。 故小谨者无成功，訾行者不容於众，好揜人之善，扬人之短，訾毁人行，自独卑藏，众人所疾而不容之也。 一说，訾，毁也。 行有毁缺者，不为众人所容。 体大者节疏，跖距者举远。 疏，长也。 跖，足也。 距，大也。 自古及今，五帝三王，未有能全其行者也。 〔故〕#4易曰，小过亨，利贞。 言人莫不有过，而不欲其大也。 夫尧、舜、汤、武，世主之隆也； 隆，盛。 齐桓晋文，五霸之豪英也。 然尧有不慈之名，谓天下不以予子丹朱也。 舜有卑父之谤，谓瞽叟降在庶人也。 汤武有放弒之事，殷汤放桀南巢，周武弒纣宣室也。 五伯有暴乱之谋。 齐桓、晋文、宋襄、楚庄、秦穆，德末能纯，皆有争夺之验，故曰有暴乱之谋也。 是故君子不责备於一人，方正而不以割，廉直而不以切，博通而不以訾，文武而不以责。 文武以备具，不责备於人。 求於一人则任以人力，任其力所能任也。 自修则以道德。 责人以人力，易偿也； 自修以道德，难为也。 难为则行高矣，易偿则求赡矣。 夫夏后氏之璜不能无考，半圭曰章，夏后氏之珍玉也。 考，瑕衅也。 明月之珠不能无类，夜光之珠，有似月光，故曰明月。 颜，盘，若丝之结颣也。 然而天下宝之者，何也？ 其小恶不足妨大美也。 今志人之所短，而志人之所修，而求得其贤乎天下，则难矣。 夫百里奚之饭牛，伊尹之负鼎，伊尹负鼎俎，调五味，以干汤，卒为贤相。 太公之鼓刀，太公，河内汲人。 有屠、钩之困，卒为文王佐，翼武王伐纣也。 宁戚之商歌，宁戚，卫人也，商旅於齐，宿郭门外，疾世商歌，以干桓公。 〔桓公〕#5夜出迎客，闻之举以为大田。 （其歌曲）［事〕#6在道应（说）〔训〕#7也。 其美有存焉者矣。 众人见其位之卑贱，事之洿辱，而不知其大略，以为不肖。
chunks.translated_text:
Had Guan Zhong chosen to die, sacrificing his life without regard for future plans, how could he have achieved such hegemonic merit? Now, when rulers assess their ministers, if they do not weigh their great accomplishments but instead tally their minor conduct and demand petty virtues, they will lose the method for recognizing worthies. *Lüe* means "great"; *small goodness* refers to loyalty; *shu* means "method." Thus, one who possesses profound virtue should not be questioned for minor flaws, and one who enjoys great renown should not be faulted for trivial faults.

A puddle in an ox’s hoofprint cannot nurture sturgeon or *wei*-fish. *Cen* refers to rainwater that collects in the imprint of an ox’s hoof—so small it cannot sustain sturgeon or *wei*. The sturgeon is a great fish, over a *zhang* in length, with fine scales, a yellow head, white body, and a short snout, its mouth beneath its belly. The *wei* is also a great fish, over a *zhang* long, which in the second month of spring swims upstream from the western river; if it passes through the Dragon Gate, it transforms into a dragon. This is according to the teachings of the former masters. A wasp’s nest cannot contain a swan’s egg—its chamber is too small to hold such a large body.

In human nature, none are without shortcomings. If one’s great strategy is sound, even with minor faults, they are not enough to be a hindrance. Assess their true substance, overlook their conduct. If their great strategy is flawed, even with the conduct of a village worthy, it is not enough for grand employment. *Ju* means "to employ."

Yan Hui Ju was a great bandit of Liangfu—Liangfu being a town in Qi, now part of Mount Tai—and yet he became a loyal minister to Qi. Duan Ganmu was a great broker of Jin, yet he became the teacher of Marquis Wen. *Zang* means "arrogant and haughty"; another saying holds that *zang* refers to a market broker, meaning he was a great broker of the state of Wei. Meng Mao married his sister-in-law and had five sons with her, yet he served as minister to Wei, securing its peril and resolving its crises. Meng Mao was originally a man of Qi. When he served Wei, he stabilized its endangered state, a feat of great merit. The *Strategies of the Warring States* refers to him as Mang Mao. Jing Yang indulged in wine, letting his hair loose as he rode in a carriage with women, yet his might subdued the feudal lords. Jing Yang was a general of Chu.

These four men all had their shortcomings, yet their fame and merit did not fade because their great strategies succeeded. *Lüe* here means "the Way." Ji Xiang and Chen Zhongzi upheld their principles and maintained unyielding conduct, refusing to enter the courts of corrupt rulers or consume the food of a disordered age, and so they starved to death. Ji Xiang was a man of Lu and a disciple of Confucius; Chen Zhongzi was a man of Qi and a disciple of Mencius, who lived in Julu. Why could they not preserve what was perishing or revive what was broken? Their minor virtues were upheld, but their great strategies were abandoned. *Shen* means "to employ"; *qu* means "to discard."

Thus, those who are overly cautious achieve no great success, and those who slander others’ conduct are not tolerated by the multitude. Those who delight in concealing others’ virtues and broadcasting their faults, who disparage others’ conduct and hide in self-imposed humility, are detested by the people and not accepted. Another interpretation holds that *zi* means "to slander"; those whose conduct is flawed are not tolerated by the multitude.

One of great stature has loose joints; one with large feet strides far. *Shu* means "long"; *zhi* means "foot"; *ju* means "large." From ancient times to the present, the Five Emperors and Three Kings have never been without imperfections in their conduct. Thus, the *Book of Changes* says, "Minor faults bring prosperity; it is favorable to be steadfast." It means that no one is without faults, but one should not allow them to become great.

Yao, Shun, Tang, and Wu were the most eminent rulers of their ages; Qi Huan and Jin Wen were the finest heroes among the Five Hegemons. Yet Yao bore the reputation of being unfilial—meaning he did not pass the throne to his son Dan Zhu. Shun was slandered for humiliating his father—meaning Gusou was reduced to the status of a commoner. Tang and Wu were involved in the exile and regicide of their sovereigns—Tang exiled Jie to Nanchao, and Wu killed Zhou in the Hall of Audience. The Five Hegemons harbored violent and disorderly schemes. Qi Huan, Jin Wen, Song Xiang, Chu Zhuang, and Qin Mu—though their virtue was not pure, all showed signs of contention and usurpation, hence it is said they harbored violent and disorderly schemes.

Therefore, the noble person does not demand perfection from any one individual. They are upright but do not cut, honest but not harsh, broadly learned but not disparaging, both civil and martial but not demanding. Civil and martial virtues should be complete, but one should not demand perfection from others. When seeking from one person, employ them according to their abilities—assign tasks within their capacity. In self-cultivation, rely on the Dao and virtue.

To demand of others according to their abilities is easy to repay; to cultivate oneself with the Dao and virtue is difficult to achieve. What is difficult to achieve elevates one’s conduct; what is easy to repay satisfies one’s demands. The jade tablet of the Xia dynasty cannot be without flaws—*zhang* refers to a half-*gui*, a precious jade of the Xia. *Kao* means "blemish." The luminous pearl cannot be without knots—*mingyue* refers to a pearl that shines like moonlight. *Chan* means "knot," like the tangles in silk thread. Yet the world treasures them—why? Their minor flaws do not detract from their great beauty.

If one records only the shortcomings of the worthy and ignores their cultivated virtues, seeking to find the most capable under heaven, it will be difficult indeed. Bai Li Xi herded cattle, Yi Yin carried the cauldron—Yi Yin carried the cutting board and cauldron, preparing the five flavors to present to Tang, and ultimately became a worthy minister. Taigong plied his knife—Taigong was a man of Ji in Henan. He endured the hardships of butchery and fishing, yet ultimately became an assistant to King Wen and aided King Wu in overthrowing Zhou. Ning Qi sang his merchant’s song—Ning Qi was a man of Wei who traveled as a merchant to Qi. He lodged outside the outer gate of the capital and, lamenting the age, sang a merchant’s song to present himself to Duke Huan. Duke Huan welcomed him in the night and, upon hearing his song, appointed him Grand Minister of Agriculture. The details of his song are recorded in the *Daoist Responses* and *Explanations*. His virtues were preserved therein.

The multitude sees only their lowly positions and base occupations and, not recognizing their great strategies, deems them unworthy.

chunks.original_text: 及其为天子三公，而立为诸侯贤相，乃始信於异众也。 信，知。 夫发于鼎俎之间，伊尹。 出于屠酤之肆，肆，列也。 谓太公吕尚也。 解于累绁之中，累绁，所以束缚人，谓管仲。 兴于牛颔之下，兴，起也。 谓百里奚也。 颔，读合索之合。 洗之以汤沐，祓之以爟火，立之于本朝之上，倚之于三公之位，爟火，取火於日之官也。 周礼司爟掌行火之正令。 火，所以祓除祥也。 立，置也。 本朝，国朝也。 内不惭於国家，外不愧於诸侯，符势有以内合。 内合於君。 故未有功而知其贤者，尧之知舜； 功成事立而知其贤者，市人之知舜也。 为是释度数而求之於朝肆草莽之中，其失人也必多矣。 为上自任耳目聪明以得贤人之故，不复用度量之术取人，而亟求贤於朝肆之列，草莽之中，失贤人必多矣，何言求贤。 何则？ 能效其求，而不知其所以取人也。 夫物之相类者，世主之所乱惑也； 嫌疑肖象者，众人之所眩耀。 （床似象）〔肖象，似〕#8也嫌疑，谓白骨之肖象牙也，碧卢似玉，蛇床似麋芜也。 故狠者类知而非知，狠者自用，像有知，非真知。 愚者类仁而非仁，愚者不能断割，有似於仁，非真仁也。 戆者类勇而非勇，戆者，不知畏危难，有似於勇，非真勇。 使人之相去也，若玉之与石，美之与恶，则论人易矣。 夫乱人者，芎藭之与稿本也、蛇床之与麋芜也，此皆相似。 言其相类，但其芳臭不同，犹小人类君子，但其仁与不仁异也。 故剑工或剑之似莫邪者，唯欧冶能名其种； 欧冶，良工。 玉工眩玉之似碧卢者，唯琦顿不失其情； 碧卢，或云珷玞。 猗顿，鲁之富人，能知玉理，不失其情也。 暗主乱于奸臣小人之疑君子者，唯圣人能见微以知明。 故蛇举首尺，而修短可知也； 象见其牙，而大小可论也。 薜烛庸子，见若狐甲於剑而利钝识 矣； 薜，齐邑也。 烛庸氏子，通利剑。 臾儿、易牙、淄、渑之。 水合者，尝一哈水（如）［而〕#9甘苦知矣。 叟儿、易牙，皆齐之知味遗也。 哈，口也。 故圣人之论贤也，见其一行而贤不肖分矣。 孔子辞廪丘，中不盗刀钩； 禀丘，齐（已）［邑］#10，今属济阴，齐景公养孔子，以言未见从，道未得行，不欲虚禄，辞而不受，故不复利人刀钩也。 许由让天子，终不利封侯。 许由，罗者，阳成人。 尧欲以天下与之，洗耳而不就，故曰不利於封侯也。 故未尝灼而不敢握火者，见其有所烧也； 未尝伤而不敢握刃者，见其有所害也。 由此观之，见者可以论未发也，而观小节足以知大体矣。 故论人之道，贵则观其所举，富则观其所施，穷则观其所不受，贱则观其所不为，贫则观其所不取。 视其更难，以知其勇； 动以喜乐，以观其守； 委以财货，以论其人； 振以恐惧，以知其节； 则人情备矣。 古之善赏者，费少而劝众； 赵襄二行之是。 善罚者，刑省而奸禁； 齐威王行之是也。 善予者，用约而为德，秦穆公行之是。 善取者，入多而无怨。 齐桓公行之也。 赵襄子围於晋阳，罢围而赏有功者五人，高赫为赏首。 左右曰，晋阳之难，赫无大功，今为赏首，何也。 智伯求地於赵襄子，不与，智伯率韩、魏以围之，三月不克，赵氏之臣张孟谈，潜与韩、魏通谋，反智伯而杀之，张孟谈之力也。
chunks.translated_text:
When they became Son of Heaven, the Three Dukes, or were established as worthy ministers and lords of the feudal states, only then did the multitude come to believe in their distinction. *Believe* here means *to know*.

Some emerged from among the cauldrons and chopping blocks—this was Yi Yin. Others came forth from the shops of butchers and wine-sellers—*shops* meaning market stalls—this was Lü Shang, the Grand Duke. Some were freed from bonds and fetters—*bonds and fetters* being the means to restrain men—this was Guan Zhong. Others rose from beneath the jaws of oxen—*rose* meaning *to arise*—this was Bai Li Xi. *Jaws* is read as the *he* in *hesuo*. They were bathed in scalding waters and purified with the sacred flame, then established at the forefront of the royal court and entrusted with the rank of the Three Dukes. *Sacred flame* refers to the fire-official who kindles flame from the sun. According to the *Rites of Zhou*, the *Director of Sacred Fire* oversees the proper use of fire. Fire is employed to dispel inauspicious influences. *Established* means *to place*. *Royal court* refers to the court of the state. Within, they felt no shame before their nation; without, they bore no disgrace before the feudal lords. Their authority aligned with their inner harmony, for their inner harmony accorded with their lord.

Thus, some recognized worthiness before any merit was shown—Yao’s recognition of Shun. Others knew worthiness only after deeds were accomplished and affairs established—the commoners’ recognition of Shun. If one were to abandon standards and measures and seek worthies among the courts, markets, and wilds, the loss of true talent would surely be great. If a ruler, relying solely on his own ears and eyes and keen discernment to find worthy men, ceased to employ the art of measurement in selecting people and instead hastily sought worthies among the ranks of courts and markets or in the untamed wilds, he would inevitably miss many worthy men—how could he claim to be seeking worthies?

Why is this so? He may imitate the act of seeking, yet he does not understand the principles of selection. For things that resemble one another are what confuse the rulers of the age, and those that are ambiguous or bear a likeness dazzle the multitude. *Resemblance* and *likeness* refer to things that appear similar yet differ in substance, such as white bones resembling ivory, green jasper resembling jade, or snake bed resembling *miwu* herb.

Thus, the cunning may resemble the wise yet not be wise—the cunning rely on their own devices, appearing knowledgeable but lacking true wisdom. The foolish may resemble the benevolent yet not be benevolent—the foolish, unable to make decisive judgments, may seem kind but lack true benevolence. The dull-witted may resemble the brave yet not be brave—the dull-witted, unaware of danger, may seem courageous but lack true bravery.

If people were as distinct as jade from stone, beauty from ugliness, then judging them would be easy. But those who confuse others are like *xiongqiong* and *gaoben*, or snake bed and *miwu*—all appear similar. Though they resemble one another, their fragrance and stench differ, just as petty men may resemble gentlemen, yet their benevolence—or lack thereof—sets them apart.

Thus, a swordsmith may forge a blade resembling *Moye*, yet only Ou Ye could name its true nature. *Ou Ye* was a master smith. A jade-worker may be dazzled by jade resembling *bilu*, yet only Qi Dun could discern its true quality. *Bilu* is sometimes said to be *wufen*. *Qi Dun* was a wealthy man of Lu who understood the principles of jade and never erred in his judgments. A benighted ruler, confused by treacherous ministers and petty men who cast doubt on the gentleman, can only be enlightened by a sage who perceives the subtle and knows the manifest.

Thus, when a snake raises its head a foot, its full length can be known. When an elephant bares its tusk, its size can be judged. The son of Zhu Yong from Biju, seeing the scales of a fox on a sword, could discern its sharpness or dullness. *Biju* was a town in Qi. The son of the Zhu Yong family was skilled in recognizing fine swords. Yu’er, Yi Ya, and the waters of Zhi and Mian—when these converge, one sip reveals their sweetness or bitterness. *Yu’er* and *Yi Ya* were connoisseurs of taste from Qi. *Sip* means *to taste with the mouth*.

Therefore, when a sage judges worthiness, observing a single action suffices to distinguish the worthy from the unworthy. Confucius declined the fief of Linqiu, refusing even a thief’s hook. *Linqiu* was a town in Qi—now part of Jiyin—where Duke Jing of Qi supported Confucius. Because his words went unheeded and his Way remained unrealized, Confucius declined the stipend, refusing even to profit from a thief’s hook. Xu You declined the throne, never coveting a marquisate. *Xu You* was a recluse from Yangcheng. Yao wished to yield the world to him, but he washed his ears and refused, hence his disdain for a marquisate.

Thus, one who has never been burned dares not grasp fire, for he sees its burning power. One who has never been cut dares not seize a blade, for he sees its harmful edge. From this, we see that observation can judge what has not yet occurred, and examining small details suffices to know the greater whole.

Therefore, the way to judge a person is this: when noble, observe whom he promotes; when wealthy, observe whom he aids; when impoverished, observe what he refuses; when base, observe what he will not do; when poor, observe what he will not take. Test him in adversity to know his courage; observe his conduct in joy to gauge his steadfastness; entrust him with wealth to assess his character; shake him with fear to know his discipline. Thus, the full range of human nature is revealed.

The ancients who were skilled in reward spent little yet encouraged many—this was the way of the two actions of Zhao Xiang. Those skilled in punishment used few penalties yet suppressed villainy—this was the way of King Wei of Qi. Those skilled in giving bestowed sparingly yet conferred great virtue—this was the way of Duke Mu of Qin. Those skilled in taking received much yet incurred no resentment—this was the way of Duke Huan of Qi.

When Zhao Xiangzi was besieged in Jinyang, upon lifting the siege, he rewarded five men for their merit, with Gao He ranked first. His attendants asked, “During the siege of Jinyang, Gao He performed no great deed. Why is he now first in reward?” Before this, the Viscount of Zhi had demanded land from Zhao Xiangzi, who refused. The Viscount then led Han and Wei to besiege him. After three months without success, Zhao’s minister Zhang Mengtan secretly conspired with Han and Wei, turning against the Viscount of Zhi and killing him—this was the work of Zhang Mengtan.

chunks.original_text: 故曰，高赫无大功也。 襄子曰，晋阳之园，寡人社稷危，国家殆，群臣无不有骄侮之心、唯赫不失君臣之礼。 故赏一人，而天下为忠之臣者莫不终忠於其君。 此赏少而劝善者众也。 齐威王设大鼎於庭中，而数无盐令曰，子之誉，日闻吾耳。 察子之事，田野芜，仓廪虚，囹圄实，子以奸事我者也。 乃烹之。 齐以此三十二岁道路不拾遣。 此刑省奸禁者也。 秦穆公出游而车败，右服失马，服，中失马。 野人得之。 穆公追而及之岐山之阳，野人方屠而食之。 穆公曰，夫食骏马之肉，而不还饮酒者，伤人。 吾恐其伤汝等。 徧饮而去之，处一年，与晋惠公为韩之战，处一年者，谓饮食肉人酒之明年也。 晋惠公，夷吾倍秦纳己之赂，秦兴兵伐晋，战於晋地韩原也。 晋师围穆公之车，梁由靡扣穆公之骖，获之。 梁由靡，晋大夫。 扣，犹牵也。 将获穆公。 食马肉者，三百余人，皆出死为穆公战於车下，遂克晋，虏惠公以归。 此用约而为得者也。 齐桓公将欲征伐，甲兵不足，令有重罪者出犀甲一戟，犀甲，取其坚也。 戟，车戟也，长丈六尺。 犀或作三，直出三甲也。 有轻罪者赎以金分，轻，小。 以金分，出金随罪轻重，有分两。 讼而不胜者出一束箭。 不胜，犹不直也。 箭十二为束也。 百姓皆说，乃矫箭为矢，治箭之笄好者也。 铸金而为刃，刃，五刃也，刀、剑、矛、戟、矢也。 以伐不义而征无道，遂霸天下。 此入多而无怨者也。 故圣人因民之所喜而劝善，因民之所恶以禁奸，故赏一人而天下誉之，罚一人而天下畏之。 故至赏不费，赏当赏，不虚费。 至刑不滥。 刑当刑，不伤善。 滥，读收敛之敛也。 孔子诛少正卯而鲁国之邪塞，少正，官，卯，其名也。 鲁之谄人。 孔子相鲁七日，诛之於东观之下，刑不滥也。 子产诛邓析，而郑国之奸禁，邓析，诡辩奸人之雄也。 子产诛之，故奸止也。 传曰，郑驷遄杀邓析而用其竹刑。 邓析制刑，书之於竹，郑国用，不以人废言也。 以近谕远，以小知大也。 故圣人守约而治广者，此之谓。 天下莫易於为善，而莫难於为不善也。 为善，静身无欲，信仁而已，（慎）〔顺〕#11其天性，故易。 为不善，贪欲无厌，毁人自成，戾其天性，（欲）〔故〕#12难也。 所谓为善者，静而无为也； 所谓为不善者，躁而多欲也。 适情辞，无所诱，或循性保真，无变於己，故曰为善易。 越城郭，踰险塞，奸符节，盗管金，篡弒矫诬，非人之性也。 奸，私，亦盗也。 符节成信也，而盗取之。 管，壮钥也。 金，印封，亦所以为信也。 固，闭藏也。 篡弒，下谋上也。 矫，擅作君命。 诬，以恶覆人也。 皆非人本所受天之善性也。 故曰为不善难。 今人所以犯囹圄之罪，而陷於刑戮之患者，由嗜欲无厌，不循度量之故也。 何以知其然？ 天下县官法曰，发墓者诛，窃盗者刑，此执政之所司也。 夫法令者罔其奸邪，勤率随其踪迹，勤者，问吏。 率，大任也。 无愚夫憃妇，皆知为奸之无脱也，犯禁之不得免也。 然而不材子不胜其欲，蒙死亡之罪，而被刑戮之羞。 蒙，冒。 然而立秋之后，司寇之徒继踵於门，而死市之人血流於路。 何则？ 惑於财利之得，而蔽於死亡之患也。 夫今陈卒设兵，两军相当，将施令曰，斩首拜爵，而屈挠者要斩。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus it is said, Gao He performed no great deed. Xiangzi declared, “During the siege of Jinyang, when my altars of soil and grain were imperiled and the state stood on the brink of ruin, all my ministers harbored thoughts of arrogance and disrespect—only Gao He did not lose the rites of lord and minister. Therefore, by rewarding one man, all under heaven who would be loyal ministers were moved to remain steadfast in their loyalty to their lords. This is how a small reward spurred many to goodness.”

King Wei of Qi placed a great cauldron in his courtyard and summoned the magistrate of Wuyan, saying, “Your praises reach my ears daily.” Yet when he examined your governance, the fields lay fallow, granaries stood empty, and prisons were full—you have served me with deceit.” He then boiled him alive. For thirty-two years thereafter, none in Qi abandoned lost items on the roads. This was how minimal punishment suppressed treachery.

Duke Mu of Qin went on an outing when his chariot broke down; the right-hand horse of the inner pair was lost. Rustics found it, and when the duke pursued them to the southern slopes of Mount Qi, they were butchering and eating it. The duke said, “To eat the flesh of a fine steed without drinking wine afterward harms a man. I fear it may injure you.” He gave them wine to drink all around before departing. A year later, he fought the Battle of Han against Duke Hui of Jin. (This “year later” refers to the year following the feast of horse meat and wine.) Duke Hui of Jin, Yiwu, had betrayed the gifts Qin used to secure his return, so Qin raised an army to attack Jin, clashing with them at Hanyuan in Jin territory. The Jin forces surrounded the duke’s chariot; Liang Youmi seized the duke’s trace horse and captured him. (Liang Youmi was a Jin grandee; *kou* means to lead or pull.) They were about to take the duke prisoner when over three hundred of those who had eaten the horse meat emerged to fight to the death beneath his chariot, enabling him to defeat Jin and capture Duke Hui. This was how sparing use brought great virtue.

Duke Huan of Qi, preparing for a campaign, found his armor and weapons insufficient. He decreed that those guilty of serious crimes could redeem themselves by providing a rhinoceros-hide cuirass and one halberd (the cuirass for its strength; the halberd, a chariot weapon, was sixteen feet long—*xi* may also mean three, referring to three layers of armor). Those guilty of minor offenses could ransom themselves with measured amounts of gold (the amount varying with the severity of the crime). Those who lost lawsuits were to provide a bundle of arrows (twelve arrows to a bundle). The people rejoiced, then straightened arrow shafts into arrows and refined the fletching and points. They smelted metal into blades (the five weapons: sword, knife, spear, halberd, and arrow). With these, he attacked the unjust and punished the lawless, ultimately becoming hegemon of the realm. This was how he received much yet incurred no resentment.

Thus the sage, leveraging what the people love, encourages goodness, and using what they hate, suppresses treachery. Therefore, rewarding one man earns the acclaim of all under heaven, while punishing one man instills fear in all. Thus the ultimate reward is not wasteful (it is given where deserved, not squandered), and the ultimate punishment is not excessive (it is meted out where due, not harming the good). (The character *lan* is read like *lian*, meaning “to restrain.”)

When Confucius executed Shaozheng Mao, the perversity of Lu was blocked. (Shao was an office; Zheng Mao was his name—a flatterer in Lu. Seven days after Confucius became chief minister of Lu, he executed him beneath the eastern gallery—this was punishment without excess.) When Zichan executed Deng Xi, the treachery of Zheng was suppressed. (Deng Xi was the foremost of cunning sophists; when Zichan killed him, treachery ceased. As the tradition states, “Duke Chuan of Zheng executed Deng Xi but adopted his bamboo penal code.” Deng Xi had inscribed his laws on bamboo, and Zheng used them, not discarding the words because of the man.) This illustrates how the near elucidates the far, and the small reveals the great. Thus the sage governs broadly through restraint—this is what it means.

Nothing under heaven is easier than doing good, and nothing harder than doing evil. To do good, one stills the self, eliminates desires, and embraces trust and benevolence, following one’s natural endowment—hence it is easy. To do evil, one is insatiably greedy, harms others to benefit oneself, and violates one’s natural endowment—hence it is difficult. What is called doing good is stillness and non-action; what is called doing evil is restlessness and excessive desire. When one accords with one’s nature, rejects temptation, and preserves one’s true self without alteration, this is why doing good is easy.

To scale city walls, cross perilous passes, forge tallies and seals, steal keys and seals, usurp and assassinate, falsify and slander—these are not the nature of man. (To *jian* is to act in secret, to steal; tallies and seals are tokens of trust, yet one steals them. *Guan* are bolts and locks; *jin* are seals and fastenings, also used for trust. *Cuan* and *shi* mean to plot against one’s superiors. *Jiao* is to falsely issue a lord’s command; *wu* is to cover someone with evil. None of these are the good nature bestowed by Heaven.) Thus it is said that doing evil is difficult.

Now, why do men commit crimes that land them in prison and bring them to the disaster of execution? It is because their cravings are insatiable and they do not follow the measures of propriety. How do we know this? The laws of the realm’s courts state: “Those who rob graves are executed; those who steal are punished.” This is what the authorities oversee. For laws and decrees are nets that catch the treacherous and wicked, while diligent officials track their traces. (The *qin* are the officials who inquire; *shuai* is the great responsibility.) Even the dullest men and women know that treachery cannot escape and that violating prohibitions cannot go unpunished. Yet the worthless, unable to conquer their desires, recklessly incur the crime of death and suffer the shame of execution. (To *meng* is to cover or risk.) Yet after the autumn assizes, the followers of the Minister of Justice tread upon each other’s heels at the gates, and the blood of those executed in the marketplace flows in the streets. Why? They are deluded by the prospect of gain and blinded to the peril of death.

Now, when armies are arrayed and the two sides face each other, the general issues his command: “Those who take heads will be enfeoffed with noble rank, while the cowardly and wavering will be beheaded.”

chunks.original_text: 然而队阶之卒皆不能前遂斩首之功，遂，成。 而后被要斩之罪，是去恐死而就必死也。 故利害之反，祸福之接，不可不审也。 事或欲之，适足以失之，或避之，适足以就之。 楚人有乘船而遇大风者，波至而自投於水，非不贪生，而畏死也，或於恐死而反忘生也。 故人之嗜欲，亦犹此也。 齐人有盗金者，当市繁之时，至掇而走，勒问其故曰，而盗金於市中，何也？ 繁，众也。 勒，主问吏。 故，犹意也。 而，汝也。 对曰，吾不见人，徒见金耳。 志所欲，则忘其为矣。 是故圣人审动静之变，而适受与之度，理好憎之情，和喜怒之节。 夫动静得则患弗过也，受与适则罪弗累也，好憎理则忧弗近也，喜怒节则怨弗犯也。 故达道之人，不苟得，不让福，其有弗弃，非其有弗索，常满而不溢，恒虚而易足。 虚，无欲也。 今夫溜水足以缢壶榼，而江河不能实漏卮，故人心犹是也。 自当以道术度量，食充虚，衣御寒，则足以养七尺之形矣。 若无道术度量而以自俭约，则万乘之势不足以为尊，天下之富不足以为乐矣。 谕若桀与纣，无道术度量，不得为匹夫，何尊乐之有乎。 孙叔敖三去令尹而无忧色，爵禄不能累也。 不以爵禄累其身也。 荆佽非两蛟夹绕其船而志不动，怪物不能惊也。 勇而不惑。 圣人心平志易，精神内守，物莫足以惑之。 夫醉者，俛入城门，以为七尺之闺也； 超江、淮，以为寻常之沟也； 酒浊其神也。 怯者夜见立表以为鬼也，见寝石以为虎也，惧揜其气也。 掩，夺。 又况无天地之怪物乎。 夫雌雄相接，阴阳相薄，羽者为雏鷇，毛者为驹犊，柔者为皮肉，坚者为齿角，人弗怪也； 水生蠬蜃，山生金玉，人弗怪也； 老槐生火，久血为磷，人弗怪也。 血精在地，暴露百日则为磷，遥望炯炯，若燃火也。 山出嘄阳，嘄阳，山精也。 人形，长大，面黑色，身有毛，若反踵，见人而笑。 水生罔象，水之精也，国语曰，龙，罔象也。 木生毕方，木之精也。 状如乌，青色，赤脚，一足，不食五谷也。 井生坟羊，土之精也，鲁季子穿井，获土缶，其中有羊也。 人怪之，闻见鲜而识物浅也。 天下之怪物，圣人之所独见； 利害之反覆，知者之所独明达也。 同异嫌疑者，世俗之所眩惑也。 夫见不可布於海内，闻不可明於百姓，是故因鬼神机祥而为之立禁，机祥，吉凶。 禁，戒。 总形推类而为之变象。 何以知其然也？
chunks.translated_text:
Yet the soldiers at the front ranks cannot advance to achieve the merit of beheading, for *suì* is to accomplish. Instead, they incur the certain punishment of decapitation—this is to flee from the fear of death only to embrace certain death. Thus the reversal of profit and harm, the proximity of fortune and misfortune, cannot but be examined with care.

Some matters, when pursued, only lead to their loss; others, when avoided, only bring them closer. A man of Chu, caught in a great wind while sailing, threw himself into the waves as the swells rose—not that he did not cherish life or fear death, but that in his terror of death he forgot all about living. Thus are men’s cravings and desires.

A man of Qi stole gold during the bustling market hour, snatched it, and fled. When seized and questioned, he was asked, “Why steal gold in the midst of the crowd?” *Fán* means throng; *lè* refers to the interrogating officer; *gù* means intent; *ér* means you. He replied, “I saw no one—only the gold.” When the mind is fixed on desire, it forgets all else.

Therefore the sage examines the shifts between motion and stillness, adapting to the measure of giving and receiving; he orders the passions of love and hate, harmonizing the bounds of joy and anger. When motion and stillness are balanced, calamity does not exceed; when giving and receiving are fitting, guilt does not accumulate; when love and hate are ordered, sorrow does not draw near; when joy and anger are moderated, resentment does not arise.

Thus the man who has mastered the Way does not grasp at gain, nor decline fortune; what is his he does not cast away, what is not his he does not seek. He is ever full yet never overflows, ever empty yet easily content. *Xū* means desireless.

Now, a trickle of water suffices to fill a gourd or flask, yet the Yangtze and Yellow River cannot fill a leaking goblet—so too is the human heart. One ought to measure by the arts of the Way: eat to fill hunger, clothe to ward off cold, and this suffices to nourish the seven-foot frame. Without the measure of the Way, even the most frugal restraint leaves the might of a thousand chariots insufficient for honor, the wealth of the world insufficient for joy. Witness Jie and Zhou: lacking the measure of the Way, they could not even be common men—what honor or joy did they possess?

Sunshu Ao thrice resigned the post of prime minister without a trace of sorrow, for rank and emolument could not burden him—not allowing them to encumber his person. Jing Ci Fei, with two dragons coiling about his boat, remained unmoved in spirit, for strange phenomena could not startle him—his courage unshaken by confusion.

The sage’s mind is level, his will at ease, his spirit inwardly guarded; no thing can delude him. The drunkard, stooping to enter the city gate, takes it for a seven-foot doorway; leaping the Yangtze or Huai, he mistakes them for a common ditch—wine has muddled his spirit. The coward, seeing a roadside marker at night, takes it for a ghost; seeing a recumbent stone, he takes it for a tiger—fear has stolen his breath. *Yǎn* means to seize. How much less, then, can he face the monstrous things of heaven and earth?

Male and female unite, yin and yang commingle; birds hatch fledglings, beasts bear calves, the soft becomes flesh, the hard becomes teeth and horns—none find this strange. Water gives rise to conches and clams, mountains produce gold and jade—none find this strange. Old locust trees burst into flame, long-buried blood turns to phosphorescence—none find this strange. When the essence of blood lies in the earth, exposed for a hundred days, it becomes phosphorescence, glowing faintly from afar like kindled fire. Mountains bring forth *jiào yáng*, the mountain spirit—human in form, tall and large, black-faced, hairy-bodied, with reversed heels, laughing at the sight of men. Water gives birth to *wǎng xiàng*, the water spirit (as the *Guoyu* says, “The dragon is *wǎng xiàng*”). Trees give rise to *bì fāng*, the tree spirit—shaped like a crow, blue-green, red-footed, one-legged, eating no grain. Wells produce *fén yáng*, the earth spirit (when Lu Ji Zi dug a well, he unearthed an earthen jar containing a sheep). People find these strange only because their experience is shallow and their knowledge of things limited.

The monstrous things of the world are seen only by the sage; the reversals of profit and harm are understood only by the wise. As for similarities, differences, and doubtful matters, these are what confound the common world. What cannot be made known throughout the land, what cannot be clarified for the people—this is why prohibitions are established in response to omens and portents (*jī xiáng* refers to fortune and misfortune; *jìn* means warning), and why symbolic transformations are devised by analogy to physical forms. How do we know this is so?

chunks.original_text: 世俗言曰：飨大高者而彘为上牲，大高，祖。 一曰上帝。 葬死人者裘不可以藏，相戏以刃者太祖軵其肘，軵，挤也。 读近茸，急察言之。 枕户橉而卧者鬼神蟅其首。 此皆不着於法令而圣人之所不口传也。 夫飨大高而氦为上牲者，非彘能贤於野兽麋鹿也，而神明独飨之，何也？ 以为彘者，家人所常畜而易得之物也，故因其便以尊之。 裘不可以藏者，非能其绨绵曼帛温暖於身也，世以为裘者，难得贵贾之物也，曼帛，细帛也。 裘狐之属也。 故曰贵贾之物。 而可传於后世，无益於死者，而足以养生，故因其资以詟之。 资，用也。 詟，忌恐。 相戏以刃太祖軵其肘者，夫以刃相戏必为过失，过失相伤，其患必大，无涉血之仇争忿斗，而以小事自内於刑戮，愚者所不知忌也，故因太祖以累其心。 累，恐。 枕户橉而卧鬼神履其首者，使鬼神能玄化，则不待户牖之行，若循虚而出入，则亦无能履也，虚，孔窍也。 夫户牖者，风气之所从往来，而风气者，阴阳粗捔者也。 离者必病，离，遭。 故托鬼神以伸诫之也。 凡此之属，皆不可胜着於书策竹帛而藏於官府者也，故以机祥明之。 为愚者之不知其害，乃借鬼神之威以声其教，所由来者远矣。 而愚者以为机祥，而狠者以为非，唯有道者能通其志。 今世之祭井灶、门户，箕帚、臼杵者，非以其神为能飨之也，恃赖其德，烦苦之无已也。 是故以时见其德，所以不忘其功也。 触石而出，肤寸而合，不崇朝而雨天下者，唯太山。 崇，终也。 日旦至食时为终朝也。 赤地三年而不绝流，泽及百里而润草木者，唯江河也。 是以天子秩而祭之。 故马免人於难者，其死也葬之，牛，其死也，葬以大车为荐。 牛马有功犹不可忘，又死人乎。 此圣人所以重仁袭恩。 袭，亦重累。 故炎帝於火，死而为灶； 炎帝，神农以火德王天下，死托祀於灶神。 禹劳天下，死为社； 劳力，谓天下治水之功也，托祀於后土之神。 后稷作稼穑，而死为稷； 稷，周弃也。 羿除天下之害，死而为宗布。 此鬼神之所以立。 羿，古之诸侯。 河伯溺杀人，羿射其左目。 风伯坏人屋室，羿射中其膝。 又课九婴，窫寙之属，有功於天下，故死托於宗布。 祭田为宗布，谓出也。 一曰，今人室中所祀之宗布是也。 或曰，司命傍布也。 此尧时羿。 非有穷后羿。 北楚有任侠者，其子孙数谏而止之，不听也。 县有贼，大搜其庐，事果发觉，夜惊而走，追，道及之，其所施德者皆为之战，得兔而遂反，语其子曰，汝数止吾为侠，今有难，果赖而兔身。 而谏我，不可用也。 所以知免於难，而不知所以无难。
chunks.translated_text:
Common folk say: When offering sacrifice to the Great High One, the pig is the foremost sacrificial beast—the Great High One being the Ancestor, also called the Supreme Lord. When burying the dead, fur garments must not be interred. Those who jest with blades will have their elbows restrained by the Great Ancestor. Those who sleep with their heads resting against a door or threshold will have their heads trampled by ghosts and spirits. None of these are recorded in laws or decrees, nor are they spoken of by the sage.

Why, when sacrificing to the Great High One, is the pig the foremost sacrificial beast? It is not that the pig surpasses wild beasts like elk and deer in worth, yet the numinous spirits partake of it alone. The reason is this: the pig is a creature commonly raised in households and easily obtained, so it is used for its convenience to honor the spirits. Why must fur garments not be buried? It is not that silk and fine cloth are warmer than fur. Rather, fur is a rare and costly commodity—fine cloth being delicate fabric, and fur belonging to creatures like the fox. Thus it is called a costly good. It may be passed down to later generations, bringing no benefit to the dead but sufficing to nurture the living, so it is used for its value to inspire reverence.

Why are those who jest with blades restrained by the Great Ancestor? For those who jest with blades will inevitably make mistakes; mistakes that cause injury bring great harm. Without blood feuds or quarrels, one may yet bring upon oneself punishment and execution through trivial matters—this is what fools fail to avoid. Thus the Great Ancestor is invoked to weigh upon their hearts. Why do ghosts and spirits trample the heads of those who sleep with their heads against doors or thresholds? If ghosts and spirits could work mysterious transformations, they would not wait for doors or windows to pass through. If they followed emptiness to enter and exit, they would be unable to tread upon anything—emptiness meaning apertures. Doors and windows are where wind and qi come and go, and wind and qi are the coarse manifestations of yin and yang. Those who encounter them will surely fall ill. Thus ghosts and spirits are invoked to extend the warning.

All such matters cannot be exhaustively recorded in books or inscribed on bamboo and silk to be stored in government offices. Therefore, they are made clear through omens and portents. For fools who do not recognize harm, the authority of ghosts and spirits is borrowed to amplify the teaching, a practice whose origins are ancient. Yet fools take these as mere omens, while the obstinate dismiss them as false. Only those who possess the Dao can fathom their intent.

In the present age, people sacrifice to wells and hearths, doors and thresholds, dustpans and brooms, mortars and pestles—not because they believe these spirits can partake of the offerings, but because they rely upon their power and are endlessly troubled by their demands. Thus they show gratitude in due season to avoid forgetting their merit.

When struck, a stone yields clouds; when gathered to the breadth of a *cun*, they coalesce, and within a single morning, rain falls across the land—only Mount Tai can do this. Though the land be parched for three years, its streams never cease to flow; though its moisture reaches a hundred *li* to nourish grasses and trees—only the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers can do this. Thus the Son of Heaven ranks them and offers sacrifice to them.

When a horse saves a person from peril, upon its death it is buried. When an ox dies, it is buried with a great cart as an offering. If the merits of oxen and horses cannot be forgotten, how much more so those of the dead? This is why the sage values benevolence and accumulates kindness.

Thus the Flame Emperor, master of fire, upon his death became the hearth god. The Flame Emperor—Shennong, who ruled the world through the power of fire—entrusted his sacrifices to the hearth spirit. Yu toiled for the world and, upon his death, became the earth god, his labor referring to his merit in controlling the floods, entrusting his sacrifices to the spirit of the earth. Hou Ji invented agriculture and, upon his death, became the grain god—Hou Ji being Qi of Zhou. Yi eliminated the world’s harms and, upon his death, became the ancestral spirit of the door. These are the origins of ghosts and spirits.

Yi, an ancient lord, drowned the River Earl who killed people, shooting out his left eye. The Earl of Wind destroyed people’s homes, and Yi shot him through the knee. He also subdued the Nine Serpents, the Devourer, and others, rendering great service to the world. Thus, upon his death, he was entrusted to the ancestral spirit of the door. Sacrifices to fields invoke the ancestral spirit of the door, referring to its emergence. Some say this is the spirit worshipped within the household. Others say it is the Controller of Fate, the one who spreads beside. This refers to Yi of Yao’s time, not the later Yi of the Youqiong clan.

In the northern regions of Chu, there was a knight-errant whose sons and grandsons repeatedly admonished him to cease, but he would not listen. When bandits raided the county and thoroughly searched his home, his crimes were exposed. He fled in terror that night, pursued and overtaken on the road. Those to whom he had shown kindness fought for him, allowing him to escape and return. He said to his sons, “You repeatedly urged me to abandon my knight-errantry. Now in my peril, I relied upon it to save myself. Your admonitions were of no use.” He knew how to escape peril but not how to avoid it in the first place.

What cannot be made known throughout the land, what cannot be clarified for the people—this is why prohibitions are established in response to omens and portents (*jī xiáng* refers to fortune and misfortune; *jìn* means warning), and why symbolic transformations are devised by analogy to physical forms. How do we know this is so?

chunks.original_text: 论事如此，岂不惑哉。 宋人有嫁子者，告其子曰，嫁未必成也，有如出，不可不私藏。 私藏而富，其於以复嫁易。 其子听父之计，窃而藏之。 君公之其盗也，逐而去之。 其父不自非也，而反得其计。 知为出藏财，而不知藏财所以出也。 为论如此，岂不勃哉。 今夫僦载者，救车之任，极一牛之力，为轴之折也，有如辕轴其上以为造，不知轴辕之趣轴折也。 楚王之佩玦而遂菟，为走而破其玦也，因佩两玦以为之豫，两玦相触，破乃逾疾。 乱国之治，有似於此。 夫鸱目大而睡不若鼠，蚈足众而走不若蛇，物固有大不若小，众不若少者。 及至夫强之弱，弱之强，危之安，存之亡也，非圣人，孰能观之。 大小尊卑，未足以论也，唯道之在者为贵。 何以明之？ 天子处於郊亭，则九卿趋，大夫走，坐者伏，倚者齐。 当此之时，明堂太庙，悬冠解剑，缓带而寝。 非郊亭大而庙堂狭小也，至尊居之也。 天道之贵也，非特天子之为尊也，所在而众仰之。 夫蛰虫鹊巢，皆向天一者，至和在焉尔。 帝者诚能包禀道，合至和，则禽兽草木莫不被其泽矣，而说兆民乎。 淮南鸿烈解卷之二十竟 #1『战』，『言』字之误，据集解本改。 #2『死』字脱，据集解本补。 #3『生』字脱，据集解本补。 #4『故』字脱，据集解本补。 #5『桓公』二字脱，据集解本补。 #6『其歌曲』庄本作，『事』字，集解从之。 #7『说』庄本及集解作，『训』字。 #8『床似象』当作『肖象，似』，据集解本改。 #9『如』，『而』字之误。 据集解本改。 #10『已』，『邑』字之误，据集解本改。 #11『慎』，『顺』字之误，据集解本改。 #12『欲』，『故』字之误，据集解本改。 淮南鸿烈解卷之二十一 太尉祭酒臣许慎记上
chunks.translated_text:
To argue thus is truly deluded. There was a man of Song who, when marrying off his daughter, said to her, "The marriage may not be settled. If you are sent away, you must secretly hoard something. If you hoard and grow rich, it will be easier to remarry." His daughter heeded her father’s plan and stole away to hide her possessions. When the lord of the state learned of her theft, he drove her out. Her father did not reproach himself but instead considered his plan successful. He knew how to hide wealth for the possibility of being cast out but did not understand that hiding wealth was the very reason for her expulsion. To argue in this way—is it not perverse?

Now consider the one who hires out oxen for transport. His task is to spare the cart’s burden, exhausting a single ox’s strength. Yet if the axle breaks, he piles more upon the shafts, not realizing that the weight on the shafts is what causes the axle to snap. The King of Chu wore a jade *jue* while hunting hares. When he ran and broke it, he then wore two *jue* as a precaution. But when the two struck together, they broke even faster. Governing a disordered state is much the same.

The owl’s eyes are large, yet it cannot see as well as the mouse in the dark. The centipede has many legs, yet it cannot outrun the snake. Some things are naturally such that the great are not as good as the small, the many not as good as the few. As for the strong becoming weak, the weak becoming strong, the perilous becoming secure, and the doomed enduring—who but the sage can perceive these truths? Great and small, noble and base are not sufficient grounds for judgment. Only that which embodies the Dao is truly precious.

How can this be illustrated? When the Son of Heaven resides in a suburban pavilion, the Nine Ministers hasten, the great officers run, those seated prostrate themselves, and those leaning stand upright. At such a time, even in the Bright Hall or the ancestral temple, where caps are hung and swords removed, belts are loosened and one reclines. It is not that the suburban pavilion is grand and the temple hall cramped, but that the most exalted dwells there. The nobility of the Dao of Heaven is not merely the honor due to the Son of Heaven—wherever it resides, the multitude looks up to it. Even the hibernating insects and magpies’ nests all turn toward the One Heaven, for the supreme harmony dwells there.

If the emperor truly embraces and embodies the Dao, uniting with supreme harmony, then the birds and beasts, the grasses and trees—none will fail to receive his beneficence, let alone the countless people. *Huainan Honglie Jie*, Scroll 20 concludes.
