chunks.original_text: 诠言训 诠，就也。 就万物之指以言其微，事之所谓，道之所依也。 洞同天地，浑沌为朴，未造而成物，谓之太一。 太一，元神，总万物者。 同出於一，所为各异，有鸟、有鱼、有兽，谓之分物。 方以类别，物以群分，性命不同，皆形於有。 隔而不通，分而为万物，莫能及宗，谓及己之性宗，同於洞同。 故动而为之生，死而谓之穷。 皆为物矣，非不物而物物者也，不物之物，恍惚虚无。 物物者亡乎万物之中。 物物者，造万物者也。 此不在万物之中也。 稽古太初，人生於无，形於有，有形而制於物。 能反其所生，若未有形，谓之真人。 真人者，未始分於太一者也。 圣人不以名尸，尸，主。 不为谋府，不为事任，不为智主，藏无形，行无迹，游无朕。 朕，兆。 不为福先，不为祸始。 保於虚无，动於不得已。 欲福者或为祸，欲利者或离害。 故无为而宁者，失其所以宁则危； 无事而治者，失其所以治则乱。 星列於天而明，故人指之； 义列於德而见，故人视之。 人之所指，动则有章； 人之所视，行则有迹。 动有章财词，行有迹则议，故圣人揜明於不刑，藏迹於无为。 王子庆忌死於剑，王子庆忌者，吴王僚之弟子。 阖闾弒僚，庆忌勇健，亡在郑。 阖闾畏之，使要离刺庆忌也。 羿死於桃棓，棓，大杖，以桃木为之，以击杀羿。 犹是已来，鬼畏桃也。 子路菹於卫，苏秦死於口。 苏秦好说，为齐所杀。 人莫不贵其所有，而贱其所短，然而皆溺其所贵，而极其所贱，所贵者有形，所贱者无朕也。 故虎豹之强来射，猿狖之捷来措。 人能贵其所贱，贱其所贵，可与言至论矣。 自信者不可以诽誉迁也，知足者不可以势利诱也，故通性之情者，不务性之所无以为； 人性之无以为者，不务也。 通命之情者，不忧命之所无奈何； 通於道者，物莫不足滑其调。 詹何曰，未尝闻身治而国乱者也，未尝闻身乱而国治者也。 矩不正，不可以为方，规不正，不可以为员。 身者，事之规矩也，未闻枉己而能正人者也。 原天命，治心术，理好憎，适情性，则治道通矣。 原天命则不惑祸福，治心术则不妄喜怒，理好憎则不贪无用，适情性则欲不过节。 不惑祸福则动静循理，不妄喜怒则赏罚不阿，不贪无用则不以欲用害性，欲不过节则养性知足。 凡此四者，弗求於外，弗假於人，反己而得矣。 天下不可以智为也，不可以慧识也，不可以事治也，不可以仁附也，不可以强胜也。 五者，皆人才也，德不盛，不能成一焉。 德立则五无殆，五见则德无位矣。 五事皆见，而德无所立位。 故得道则愚者有余，失道则智者不足。 度水而无游数，虽强必沉； 有游数，虽赢必遂； 又况托於舟航之上乎。 为治之本，务在於安民。 安民之本，在於足用。 足用之本，在於勿夺时。 勿夺时之本，在於省事。 省事之本，在於节欲。 节欲之本，在於反性。 反性之本，在於去载。 去浮华，载於亡者也。 去载则虚，虚则平。 平者，道之素也； 虚者，道之舍也。 能有天下者，必不失其国； 能有其国者，必不丧其家； 能治其家者，必不遗其身； 能修其身者，必不忘其心； 能原其心者，必不亏其性； 能全其性者，必不惑於道。 故广成子曰，慎守而内，周闭而外，广成子，黄帝时人也。
chunks.translated_text:
**Explanation of Terms**

*Explanation*: "Explanation" means "to approach." Approaching the subtleties of the myriad things by speaking of their essence—this is what affairs signify and what the Dao depends upon. Penetratingly identical with Heaven and Earth, undifferentiated as uncarved simplicity, it forms things before their creation—this is called the Great One. The Great One is the primordial spirit, the unifier of the myriad things. Though all emerge from the One, their functions differ: there are birds, fish, and beasts—these are called the division of things. By their categories they are distinguished; by their groups they are divided. Nature and destiny differ, yet all take form in being. Separated and uncommunicating, divided into the ten thousand things, none can reach the ancestral origin—meaning the origin of one’s own nature, identical with the penetrating unity. Thus, movement gives rise to life, and death is called exhaustion. All are things, yet not the non-thing that things things. The non-thing that things is indistinct and void. The one who things things does not reside within the ten thousand things. The one who things things is the creator of the ten thousand things—this one does not dwell within the ten thousand things.

Tracing back to the Great Beginning of antiquity, humans are born from non-being and take form in being. Once formed, they are constrained by things. Those who can return to their origin, as if they had never taken form, are called Perfected Persons. The Perfected Person is one who has never been separated from the Great One. The sage does not occupy the position of names—*occupy* means to preside. He is not a repository of schemes, not burdened with tasks, not the master of wisdom. Concealing his formlessness, moving without trace, wandering without sign—*sign* means omen. He does not precede fortune nor initiate misfortune. Abiding in emptiness, he acts only when unavoidable. Those who seek fortune may incur misfortune; those who seek profit may encounter harm. Thus, one who attains tranquility through non-action will face peril if he loses the source of his tranquility; one who governs through non-affair will fall into chaos if he loses the source of his governance.

Stars arrayed in the heavens shine, so people point to them; righteousness arrayed in virtue is manifest, so people observe it. What people point to, when moved, leaves a pattern; what people observe, when acted upon, leaves a trace. Movement with pattern invites judgment; action with trace invites discussion. Therefore, the sage conceals his brightness in non-action and hides his traces in non-doing.

Prince Qingji of Wu died by the sword. Prince Qingji was the nephew of King Liao of Wu. When Helü assassinated Liao, Qingji, brave and strong, fled to Zheng. Helü, fearing him, sent Yao Li to assassinate Qingji. Yi died by the peach-wood club—*club* means a large staff, made of peach wood, used to strike and kill Yi. Since then, ghosts have feared peach wood. Zilu was pickled in Wei; Su Qin died by the mouth. Su Qin, fond of persuasion, was killed by Qi. People all value what they possess and despise what they lack, yet they drown in what they value and exhaust what they despise. What they value has form; what they despise has no sign. Thus, the strength of tigers and leopards invites arrows; the agility of gibbons and monkeys invites capture.

One who can value what he despises and despise what he values may be spoken to of the ultimate discourse. The self-assured cannot be swayed by slander or praise; the content cannot be tempted by power or profit. Thus, one who understands the essence of human nature does not pursue what nature lacks the means to achieve. One who understands the essence of destiny does not worry over what destiny has no way to alter. One who penetrates the Dao finds nothing sufficient to disturb his harmony.

Zhan He said: "Never have I heard of one whose person was well-ordered yet whose state was in chaos; never have I heard of one whose person was in chaos yet whose state was well-ordered." If the carpenter’s square is not true, it cannot make a square; if the compass is not true, it cannot make a circle. The person is the compass and square of affairs—never have I heard of one who, being crooked himself, could make others straight.

Tracing back to the Mandate of Heaven, ordering the mind’s workings, regulating likes and dislikes, and harmonizing the passions and nature—thus the Way of governance is opened. Tracing back to the Mandate of Heaven prevents confusion over fortune and misfortune; ordering the mind’s workings prevents reckless joy and anger; regulating likes and dislikes prevents greed for the useless; harmonizing the passions and nature prevents desires from exceeding moderation. Unconfused by fortune and misfortune, one’s movement and stillness follow principle; without reckless joy and anger, rewards and punishments are not biased; without greed for the useless, one does not harm one’s nature through desire; without desires exceeding moderation, one nurtures one’s nature and knows contentment. These four matters are not sought from without, nor borrowed from others—they are obtained by turning back to oneself.

The world cannot be governed by wisdom, nor by clever discernment, nor by managing affairs, nor by clinging to benevolence, nor by forceful domination. These five are all human talents, yet without abundant virtue, not one of them can be accomplished. When virtue is established, the five are not endangered; when the five appear, virtue has no place. If all five are manifest, virtue has no position to stand. Thus, one who attains the Dao finds even the foolish sufficient; one who loses the Dao finds even the wise inadequate.

Crossing water without knowing how to swim, even the strong will sink; knowing how to swim, even the weak will succeed—how much more so when relying on a boat! The foundation of governance lies in pacifying the people. The foundation of pacifying the people lies in sufficiency of use. The foundation of sufficiency of use lies in not seizing the seasons. The foundation of not seizing the seasons lies in reducing affairs. The foundation of reducing affairs lies in moderating desires. The foundation of moderating desires lies in returning to one’s nature. The foundation of returning to one’s nature lies in shedding burdens—shedding superficial adornments, burdens of what is already lost. Shedding burdens leads to emptiness; emptiness leads to equilibrium. Equilibrium is the plainness of the Dao; emptiness is the abode of the Dao.

One who can possess the world must not lose his state; one who can possess his state must not lose his family; one who can govern his family must not neglect his person; one who can cultivate his person must not forget his mind; one who can trace back to his mind must not harm his nature; one who can preserve his nature must not be deluded by the Dao.

Thus, Guangchengzi said: "Guard carefully within; seal completely without." Guangchengzi was a man of the time of the Yellow Emperor.

chunks.original_text: 多知为败，毋视毋听。 抱神以静，形将自正。 不得之己而能知彼者，未之有也。 故易曰，括囊，无咎无誉。 能成霸王者，必得胜者也； 能胜敌者，必强者也； 能强者，必用人力者也； 能用人力者，必得人心也； 能得人心者，必自得者也； 能自得者，必柔弱也。 强胜不若己者，至於与同则格； 言人力能与己力一也，己以强加之，则战格也。 柔胜出於己者，其力不可度。 故能以众不胜成大胜者，唯圣人能之。 善游者，不学刺舟而便用之； 劲筋者，不学骑马而便居之。 轻天下者，身不累於物，故能处之。 泰王亶父处邠，狄人攻之，事之以皮币珠玉而不听，乃谢耆老而徙岐周，百姓携幼扶老而从之，遂成国焉。 推此意，四世而有天下，不亦宜乎。 四世，太王、王季、文王、武王。 无以天下为者，必能治天下者。 霜雪雨露，生杀万物，天无为焉，犹之贵天也，厌文搔法，厌，持也。 搔，劳也。 治官理民者，有司也，君无事焉，犹尊君也。 辟地垦草者，后稷也； 决河浚江者，禹也； 听狱制中者，皋陶也； 有圣名者，尧也。 故得道以御者，身虽无能，必使能者为己用。 不得其道，伎艺虽多，未有益也。 方船济乎江，有虚船从一方来，触而覆之，虽有忮心，必无怨色。 有一人在其中，一张之，一谓歙之。 持舟楫者为近岸为敛，远岸为张也。 再三呼而不应，必以丑声随其后。 向不怒而今怒，向虚而今实也。 人能虚己以游於世，孰能訾之。 释道而任智者必危，弃数而用才者必困。 有以欲多而亡者，未有以无欲而危者也。 有以欲治而乱者，未有以守常而失者也。 故智不足免患，愚不足以至於失宁。 守其分，循其理，失之不忧，得之不喜，故成者非所为也，得者非所求也。 入者有受而无取，出者有授而无予，因春而生，因秋而杀，所生者弗德，所杀者非怨，则几於道也。 圣人不为可非之行，不憎人之非己也。 修足誉之德，不求人之誉己也。 不能使祸不至，信己之不迎也。 不能使福必来，信己之不攘也。 攘，却。 祸之至也，非其求所生，故穷而不忧。 福之至，非其求所成，故通而弗矜。 矜，自伐其功也。 知祸福之制不在於己也，故闲居而乐，无为而治。 圣人守其所以有，不求其所未得。 求其所无，则所有者亡矣。 修其所有，则所欲者至。 故用兵者，先为不可胜，以待敌之可胜也； 治国者，先为不可夺，以待敌之可夺也。 舜修之历山而海内从化，文王修之岐周而天下移风。 使舜趋天下之利，而忘修己之道，身犹弗能保，何尺地之有。 故治未固於不乱，治不乱之道尚未牢固也。 而事为治者，必危； 行未固於无非，而急求名者，必锉也。 福莫大无祸，利莫美不丧。 动之为物，不损则益，动，有为也。 不成则毁，不利则病，皆险也，险，言危难险不可行。 道之者危。 故秦胜乎戎而败乎殽，秦穆公胜西戎，为晋所败於殽。 楚胜乎诸夏而败乎栢莒。 楚昭王服诸夏，而吴败之栢莒。 故道不可以劝而就利者，而可以宁避害者。 故常无祸，不常有福，常无罪，不常有功。 圣人无思虑，无设储，来者弗迎，去者弗将，将，送。 人虽东西南北，独立中央。 故处众枉之中，不失其直； 天下皆流，独不离其坛城。 故不为善，不避丑，遵天之道；
chunks.translated_text:
Excessive knowledge leads to ruin; neither see nor hear. Embrace the spirit in stillness, and the form will right itself. One who has not mastered himself yet claims to know others—such a thing has never existed. Thus, the *Yi* says: "Tie up the sack—neither blame nor praise." Those who would become overlords must first be victors; those who would be victors must be strong; those who would be strong must employ the strength of others; those who would employ the strength of others must win their hearts; those who would win their hearts must first master themselves; those who would master themselves must be yielding and weak.

Strength prevails over what is weaker than oneself, but when matched with its equal, it meets resistance. When human strength equals one’s own, and one imposes force upon it, conflict arises. Yet yielding prevails over what is stronger than oneself—its power cannot be measured. Thus, only the sage can turn many defeats into a great victory.

A skilled swimmer need not learn to pole a boat yet masters it with ease; one with strong sinews need not learn to ride a horse yet sits astride effortlessly. He who holds the world lightly is not burdened by things, and so can abide in them.

King Tai of ancient times dwelt in Bin when the Di tribes attacked. He offered them furs, silk, pearls, and jade, yet they would not desist. He then took leave of the elders and removed to Qizhou, where the people, carrying their young and supporting their old, followed him. There he established his state. Extending this principle, four generations later, his line came to rule all under Heaven—was this not fitting? Those four generations were Tai Wang, Wang Ji, King Wen, and King Wu.

He who does not treat the world as his possession is the one who can govern it. Frost, snow, rain, and dew give life and take it, yet Heaven acts not—still we honor Heaven. To grasp at patterns and exhaust oneself with laws is to hold fast to toil. Those who administer offices and govern the people are the functionaries; the ruler has no business here—yet we revere the ruler.

Those who cleared the land and tilled the soil were Hou Ji; those who dredged the rivers and deepened the streams were Yu; those who heard cases and judged with equity were Gao Yao; those who bore the name of sage were Yao. Thus, one who attains the Dao to govern employs others: though personally inept, he ensures the capable serve him. Without the Dao, even many skills bring no benefit.

A square boat crosses the river; an empty boat drifts from one side and collides, overturning it. Though one may harbor resentment, no anger shows. But if a man were aboard, he would first pull in the oars, then call out to draw them back—near shore he gathers, far shore he extends. If he shouts once, twice, and receives no answer, he will surely follow with harsh words. Where before there was no anger, now there is anger; where before it was empty, now it is full.

If one can empty oneself and move through the world, who can revile him? To abandon the Dao and rely on cunning is to court danger; to discard method and employ talent is to invite distress. There are those who perish through many desires, but none who are imperiled by having none. There are those who bring chaos through seeking order, but none who lose by holding to constancy.

Thus, wisdom is not enough to avoid calamity, nor is folly enough to bring about loss and restlessness. Guard your allotted portion, follow principle—lose without sorrow, gain without joy. Thus, achievement is not what one does, and attainment is not what one seeks. In receiving, there is acceptance without taking; in giving, there is bestowal without offering. Things grow in spring, wither in autumn—what lives is not credited with virtue, what dies is not blamed with resentment. This is near to the Dao.

The sage does not act in ways that invite reproach, nor does he resent others’ reproaches of him. He cultivates virtue that brings praise, yet does not seek others’ praise. He cannot prevent misfortune from arriving, but trusts in not inviting it. He cannot ensure blessings will come, but trusts in not warding them off. Misfortune arrives not from what one seeks, so one remains untroubled in adversity. Blessings come not from what one pursues, so one remains unassuming in success.

Knowing that the control of fortune and misfortune lies not with oneself, one dwells in leisure and joy, governs through non-action. The sage guards what he possesses and does not seek what he lacks. To seek what one does not have is to lose what one does have. To cultivate what one possesses is to have one’s desires fulfilled.

Thus, in warfare, first ensure invincibility to await the enemy’s vulnerability; in governance, first ensure unassailability to await the enemy’s vulnerability. Shun cultivated the fields of Lishan, and all within the seas followed his transformation; King Wen cultivated Qizhou, and all under Heaven shifted their customs. Had Shun pursued the world’s profit and forgotten the cultivation of his own Way, he could not have preserved himself—how then could he have possessed even a foot of land?

Thus, if governance is not yet firmly established against disorder, those who act to govern will surely be imperiled. If conduct is not yet firmly established in blamelessness, those who rush to seek fame will surely be worn down. No blessing is greater than the absence of misfortune; no profit is finer than not losing what one has.

Action, as a thing, either diminishes or augments—action is having purpose. What does not succeed is destroyed; what does not profit brings harm. All is perilous—perilous means danger and difficulty, paths one cannot tread. To follow such paths is to court peril.

Thus, Qin triumphed over the Rong yet was defeated at Yao; Duke Mu of Qin conquered the Western Rong but was routed by Jin at Yao. Chu triumphed over the Central States yet was defeated at Boju; King Zhao of Chu subdued the Central States but was vanquished by Wu at Boju. Thus, the Dao cannot be urged toward profit, but it can be relied upon to peacefully avoid harm.

Therefore, one may constantly be without misfortune, but not constantly have blessings; one may constantly be without guilt, but not constantly have merit. The sage has no thoughts, no plans laid by. What comes is not welcomed; what goes is not sent off. Though men move east, west, south, or north, he stands alone at the center.

Thus, amid a multitude of crookedness, he does not lose his straightness; though all under Heaven flow away, he alone does not depart from his sacred precinct. Therefore, he does not do good, nor does he shun the shameful—he follows the Dao of Heaven.

f the Dao.

One who can possess the world must not lose his state; one who can possess his state must not lose his family; one who can govern his family must not neglect his person; one who can cultivate his person must not forget his mind; one who can trace back to his mind must not harm his nature; one who can preserve his nature must not be deluded by the Dao.

Thus, Guangchengzi said: "Guard carefully within; seal completely without." Guangchengzi was a man of the time of the Yellow Emperor.

chunks.original_text: 不为始，不专己、修天之理。 不豫谋，不弃时，与天为期。 不求得，不辞福，从天之则。 不求所无，不失所得，内无旁祸，外无旁福。 祸福不生，安有人贼。 为善则观，众人之所观也。 为不善则议。 观则生贵，议则生患。 故道术不可以进而求名，而可以退而修身。 不可以得利，而可以离害。 故圣人不以行求名，不以智见誉，法修自然，己无所与。 虑不胜数，行不胜德，事不胜道。 为者有不成，求者有不得。 人有穷，而道无不通，与道争则凶。 故诗曰，弗识弗知，顺帝之则。 有智而无为，与无智者同道； 有能而无事，与无能者同德。 其智也，告之者至，然后觉其动也，使之者至，然后觉其为也。 有智若无智，有能若无能，道理为正也。 故功盖天下，不施其美； 泽及后世，不有其名； 道理通而人伪灭也。 名与道不两明，人受名则道不用，道胜人则名息矣。 道与人竞长。 章人者，息道者也。 章，明也。 息，止也。 人章道息，则危不远矣。 故世有圣名，则衰之日至矣。 欲尸名者必为善，欲为善者必生事，事生则释公而就私，货数而任己。 欲见誉於为善，而立名於为质，则治不修故，而事不须时。 治不修故，则多责； 事不须时，则无功。 责多功鲜，无以塞之，则妄发而邀当，妄为而要中。 功之成也，不足更责； 更，偿。 事之败也，不足以弊身。 故重为善若重为非，而几於道矣。 天下非无信士也，临货分财必探筹而定分，捉筹。 以为有心者之於平，不若无心者。 天下非无廉士也，然而守重宝者，必关户而全封，以为有欲者之於廉，不若无欲者也。 人举其疵则怨人，举说己之疵，则怨之。 鉴见其丑则善鉴。 鉴，镜也。 镜见人之好丑，以为善镜也。 人能接物而不与己焉，则免於累矣。 而不与己，若镜人形而不有好憎也。 公孙龙柴於辞而货名，公孙龙，以白马非马，冰不寒，炭不热〔为论〕#1，故曰货也。 邓析巧辩而乱法，邓析教郑人以讼，讼不俱回，子产诛之也。 苏秦善说而亡苏秦死於齐也。 国。 由其道则善无章，修其理则巧无名。 故以巧斗力者，始於阳，常卒於阴； 言知巧之所施，始之於阳，善终於阴恶也。 以慧治国者，始於治，常卒於乱。 使水流下，孰弗能治； 激而上之，非巧不能。 故文胜则质揜，邪巧则正塞之也。 德可以自修，而不可以使人暴； 道可以自治，而不可以使人乱。 虽有贤圣之宝，不遇暴乱之世、可以全身，（未而）〔而未〕#2可以霸王也。 汤武之王也，遇桀、纣之暴也。 桀、纣非以汤、武之贤暴也，汤、武遭桀、纣之暴而王也。 故虽贤王，必待遇。 遇者，能遭於时而得之也，非知能所求而成也。 君子修行而使善无名，布施而使仁无章，故士行善而不知善之所由来。 民瞻利而不知利之所由出，故无为而自治。 善有章则士争名，利有本则民争功，二争者生，虽有贤者，弗能治。 故圣人揜迹於为善，而息名於为仁也。 外交而为援，事大而为安，不若内治而待时。 凡事人者，非以宝币，必以卑辞。 事以玉帛，则货殚而欲不餍； 卑体婉辞，则谕说而交不结；
chunks.translated_text:
Do not take the lead, nor monopolize the self—cultivate the principles of Heaven. Do not premeditate, nor forsake the times—keep tryst with Heaven. Do not seek gain, nor decline blessings—follow Heaven’s norms. Do not pursue what is absent, nor lose what is attained; within, there is no collateral misfortune; without, there is no collateral blessing. When misfortune and blessing do not arise, how can there be harm from others?

To do good is to be observed—what the multitude observes. To do ill is to be discussed. Observation breeds esteem; discussion breeds trouble. Thus, the arts of the Dao cannot be advanced to seek fame, but may be withdrawn to cultivate the self. They cannot be used to obtain profit, but may be employed to avoid harm. Therefore, the sage does not seek fame through conduct, nor reputation through wisdom; he models himself on the natural, and has no part in it.

Thoughts cannot surpass their measure; actions cannot surpass virtue; affairs cannot surpass the Dao. Those who act may not succeed; those who seek may not obtain. Men may reach their limit, but the Dao is never obstructed—contending with the Dao brings misfortune.

Thus the *Odes* says:
*"Unknowing, unperceiving,
They follow the Emperor’s norms."*
One with wisdom yet without action shares the Dao of the unwise; one with ability yet without affairs shares the virtue of the incapable. In wisdom, one is as if without wisdom; in ability, one is as if without ability—this is the rectitude of the Dao.

Thus, though one’s merit covers all under Heaven, one does not display its beauty; though one’s beneficence extends to later generations, one does not claim its name. When the Dao prevails, human artifice vanishes. Fame and the Dao cannot both shine forth: when men receive fame, the Dao is unused; when the Dao prevails over men, fame ceases.

The Dao and men vie for ascendancy. Those who exalt men suppress the Dao. *Exalt* means to make manifest; *suppress* means to halt. When men are exalted and the Dao is suppressed, peril is not far off. Thus, when an age has a sage’s fame, the day of its decline has arrived.

Those who covet fame must do good; those who would do good must create affairs. Affairs arise, then one abandons the public and pursues the private, discards moderation and relies on the self. Desiring praise for doing good and establishing a name for integrity, one neglects the cultivation of governance and does not await the proper time. Neglecting governance brings many reproaches; acting without regard for timing yields no merit. Many reproaches and little merit—unable to meet these, one acts recklessly to seek validation, acts rashly to hit the mark.

When merit is achieved, it is not enough to repay reproaches; *repay* means to compensate. When affairs fail, it is not enough to ruin the self. Thus, to value doing good as one values doing ill is to draw near the Dao.

All under Heaven is not without trustworthy men, yet when dividing goods and wealth, they must draw lots to determine shares—*drawing lots* means to hold the tally. They believe that those with intention cannot be as impartial as those without. All under Heaven is not without incorruptible men, yet those who guard precious treasures must lock their doors and seal them completely. They believe that those with desire cannot be as incorruptible as those without.

When men point out one’s flaws, one resents them; when a mirror reveals one’s ugliness, it is a good mirror. *Mirror* means looking glass. A mirror shows a person’s beauty or ugliness—thus it is a good mirror. One who engages with things yet does not involve the self is free from entanglement—*not involving the self* is like a mirror reflecting forms without possessing likes or dislikes.

Gongsun Long traded in words to sell fame—Gongsun Long, with his arguments that a white horse is not a horse, that ice is not cold, and charcoal is not hot, thus is said to *sell*. Deng Xi was clever in debate but disrupted the law—Deng Xi taught the people of Zheng to litigate; when litigation did not end in mutual withdrawal, Zichan executed him. Su Qin was skilled in persuasion but perished—Su Qin died in Qi.

Following the Dao, goodness leaves no trace; cultivating its principles, skill leaves no name. Thus, those who contend with skill and strength begin with yang but invariably end in yin—*yang* refers to the outset of cunning’s application, which ends in yin, or evil. Those who govern the state with cleverness begin with order but invariably end in chaos.

Who cannot guide water to flow downward? But to force it upward requires skill. Thus, when ornament prevails, substance is obscured; when deceitful cunning arises, rectitude is blocked.

Virtue can be cultivated by the self but cannot be used to make others violent; the Dao can govern the self but cannot be used to make others chaotic. Though one possesses the treasure of the worthy and sage, in an age of violence and disorder, one may preserve the self, but cannot become a hegemon or king.

Tang and Wu became kings because they encountered the violence of Jie and Zhou. Jie and Zhou were not violent because of Tang and Wu’s worthiness—Tang and Wu encountered the violence of Jie and Zhou and thus became kings. Therefore, even a worthy king must await the encounter. *Encounter* means to meet the times and obtain it, not to achieve it through knowledge or ability.

The noble person cultivates conduct so that goodness leaves no name; bestows generosity so that benevolence leaves no trace. Thus, the scholar practices goodness yet does not know whence goodness arises. The people seek profit yet do not know whence profit comes—thus, without action, there is self-governance.

When goodness is manifest, scholars contend for fame; when profit has a source, the people contend for merit. When these two contentions arise, even the worthy cannot govern. Therefore, the sage conceals his traces in doing good and silences his name in practicing benevolence.

Seeking external alliances for support and serving the great for security is not as good as internal governance awaiting the proper time. In all matters of serving others, if not with treasures and gifts, then with humble words. Serving with jade and silk exhausts wealth yet leaves desires unfulfilled; using submissive posture and gentle words exhausts persuasion yet fails to forge bonds.

Thus, amid a multitude of crookedness, he does not lose his straightness; though all under Heaven flow away, he alone does not depart from his sacred precinct. Therefore, he does not do good, nor does he shun the shameful—he follows the Dao of Heaven.

chunks.original_text: 约束誓盟，则约定而反无日，反，（皆）［背］#3叛也。 虽割国之锱锤以事人，六两曰锱，倍锱曰锤。 而无自恃之道，不足以为全。 若诚外释交之策，而慎修其境内之事，尽其地力以多其积，厉其民死以牢其城，上下一心，君臣同志，与之守社稷，敦死而民弗离，则为民者不伐无罪，而为利者不攻难胜，此必全之道也。 民有道所同道，有法所同守，民凡所道行者同道，而法度有所共守也。 为义之不能相固，威之不能相必也，故立君以一民。 君执一则治，无常则乱。 君道者，非所以为也，所以无为也。 何谓无为？ 智者不以位为事，勇者不以位为暴，仁者不以位为患，可谓无为矣。 夫无为，则得於一也。 一也者，万物之本也，无敌之道也。 凡人之性，少则猖狂，壮则暴强，老则好利。 一身之身既数既变矣，又况君数易法，国数易君。 人以其位通其好憎，下之径衢不可胜理，故君失一则乱，甚於无君之时。 故诗曰，不愆不忘，率由旧章。 此之谓也。 君好智，则倍时而任己，弃数而用虑。 天下之物博而智浅，以浅澹博，未有能者也。 独任其智，失必多矣。 故好智，穷术也； 好勇，则轻敌而简备，自偩而辞助。 自负，自恃。 辞助，不受傍人之助。 一人之力以围强敌，不杖众多而专用身才，必不堪也。 故好勇，危术也。 好与，则无定分。 上之分不定，则下之望无止。 若多赋敛，实府库，则与民为雠。 少取多与，数未之有也。 故好与，来怨之道也。 仁智勇力，人之美才也，而莫足以治天下。 由此观之，贤能之不足任也，而道术之可修明矣。 圣人胜心。 心者，欲之所生也。 圣人止欲，故胜其心，而以百姓为心也。 众人胜欲。 心欲之，而能胜止也。 君子行正气，小人行邪气，内便於性，外合於义，循理而动，不击於物者，正气也。 推於滋味，淫於声色，发於喜怒，不顾后患者，邪气也。 邪与正相伤，欲与性相害，不可两立。 一值一废，故圣人损欲而从事於性。 目好色，耳好声，口好味，接而说之。 不知利害嗜欲也，食之不宁於体，听之不合於道，视而不便於性，三宫交争，三宫，三关，谓食、视、听。 以义为制者，心也。 割痤疽非不痛也，饮毒药非不苦也，然而为之者，便於身也。 渴而饮水，非不快也，饥而大飧，非不瞻也，然而弗为者，害於性也。 此四者，耳目鼻口不知所取去，心为之制，各得其所。 由是观之，欲之不可胜，明矣。 凡治身养性，节寝处，适饮食，和喜怒，便动静，内在己者得，而邪气因而不生，岂若忧瘕疵之与痤疽之发，而豫备之哉。 夫函牛之鼎沸而蝇蚋弗敢入，函牛，受一牛之鼎也。 昆山之玉瑱昆山，昆仑也。 瑱，式也。 而尘垢弗能污也。
chunks.translated_text:
When covenants and sworn alliances are made, the agreements are set yet soon betrayed—*fan* means to turn against and rebel. Even if one were to cede the state’s every *zi* and *chui* in service to others—six *liang* make a *zi*, twice a *zi* makes a *chui*—without a way to rely on oneself, it is insufficient for preservation. If one truly abandons the strategy of external alliances and instead diligently attends to affairs within the borders, exhausts the land’s potential to increase stores, sharpens the people’s resolve unto death to fortify the city, unites ruler and subject in a single purpose, and guards the altars of soil and grain with unwavering resolve so the people do not flee, then those who would attack will not strike the innocent, and those who seek advantage will not assault the invincible. This is surely the way to preservation.

The people have a Dao they all follow and laws they all uphold—ordinary conduct aligns with the shared Dao, while statutes are jointly observed. Since righteousness cannot bind them together nor might guarantee their loyalty, a ruler is established to unify the people. When the ruler holds to the One, there is order; without constancy, there is chaos. The ruler’s Dao is not for action but for non-action. What is non-action? The wise do not use their position to meddle, the brave do not use their position to oppress, the benevolent do not use their position to indulge—this is called non-action. Through non-action, one attains the One. The One is the root of the myriad things, the way of invincibility.

By nature, people in youth are reckless, in maturity violent and overbearing, in old age covetous. A single body undergoes many changes—how much more so when rulers frequently alter laws and states frequently change rulers? People use their positions to pursue their likes and dislikes, and the paths below become impossible to govern. Thus, when a ruler loses the One, chaos exceeds even that of a rulerless time. As the *Odes* says: "Without error, without forgetfulness, follow the old statutes." This is what it means.

If a ruler favors wisdom, he will defy the times and rely on himself, discard methods and employ deliberation. The world’s affairs are vast, yet wisdom is shallow—using the shallow to fathom the vast, none have succeeded. Relying solely on one’s own wisdom, losses will be many. Thus, favoring wisdom is a path to exhaustion. Favoring bravery leads to underestimating enemies and neglecting defenses, to self-reliance and rejecting aid. Relying on one’s own strength to encircle a formidable foe, without depending on the multitude and instead using only personal ability, will surely fail. Thus, favoring bravery is a perilous path. Favoring generosity results in no fixed allotments. If the ruler’s distributions are unstable, the people’s expectations will know no end. If heavy taxes fill the treasuries, it makes enemies of the people. To take little and give much—such a thing has never existed. Thus, favoring generosity is the way to invite resentment.

Benevolence, wisdom, courage, and strength are human excellences, yet none suffice to govern the world. From this, we see that worthiness and ability are inadequate for the task, and the cultivation of the Dao and its arts becomes clear.

The sage conquers the heart. The heart is where desires arise. The sage restrains desire, thus conquering the heart and making the people’s hearts his own. The common people conquer desire—they desire it yet can restrain themselves. The noble person embodies upright *qi*, the petty person embodies perverse *qi*. That which inwardly accords with nature and outwardly aligns with righteousness, moving in accordance with principle without clashing with things, is upright *qi*. That which indulges in rich flavors, luxuriates in sounds and sights, gives free rein to joy and anger, and disregards future harm is perverse *qi*. The perverse and the upright injure one another, desire and nature harm each other—they cannot coexist. One rises as the other falls, so the sage curbs desire and attends to nature.

The eyes delight in beauty, the ears in sound, the mouth in flavor—they encounter and take pleasure in these. Unaware of the harm in indulging desires, eating brings no peace to the body, listening does not accord with the Dao, seeing does not benefit nature. The three palaces contend—the three palaces being the three gates of eating, seeing, and hearing. The heart governs with righteousness. Cutting away an abscess is not painless, drinking poison is not without bitterness, yet one does so because it benefits the body. Drinking water when thirsty is not unpleasant, feasting when hungry is not unsatisfying, yet one refrains because it harms nature. These four cases show that the ears, eyes, nose, and mouth do not know what to accept or reject—the heart governs, and each finds its proper place. From this, it is clear that desires cannot be overcome.

In all matters of cultivating the body and nurturing nature, regulating rest and activity, moderating food and drink, harmonizing joy and anger, and adapting movement and stillness, what lies within oneself is attained, and perverse *qi* does not arise. How could this compare to the anxiety of tumors and sores erupting and preparing remedies in advance? The cauldron that holds an ox boils, yet flies and gnats dare not enter. The jade *tian* of Kunlun—*tian* means a standard—cannot be sullied by dust and grime.

ern. Therefore, the sage conceals his traces in doing good and silences his name in practicing benevolence.

Seeking external alliances for support and serving the great for security is not as good as internal governance awaiting the proper time. In all matters of serving others, if not with treasures and gifts, then with humble words. Serving with jade and silk exhausts wealth yet leaves desires unfulfilled; using submissive posture and gentle words exhausts persuasion yet fails to forge bonds.

chunks.original_text: 圣人无去之心而心无丑，无取之美而美不失。 故祭祀思亲不求福，飨宾修敬不思德，唯弗求者能有之。 言不求而所求至也。 处尊位者，以有公道而无私说，故称尊焉，不称贤也； 有大地者，以有常术而无钤谋，故称平焉，不称智也。 内无暴事以离怨於百姓，外无贤行以见忌於诸侯，上下之礼，袭而不离，而为论者莫然不见所观焉，此所谓藏无形者。 非藏无形，孰能形。 形，形而言之，筮见也。 三代之所道者，因也。 故禹决江河，因水也，后稷播种树谷，因地也； 汤武平暴乱，因时也。 故天下可得而不可取也，不可强取。 霸王可受而不可求也。 在智则人与之讼，在力则人与之争。 未有使人无智者，言己不能使适国遇而无智也。 有使人不能用其智於己者。 使人之智不能於己。 未有使人无力者也，有使人不能施其力於己者也。 此两者，常在久见。 故君贤不见，诸侯不备，不肖不见，则百姓不怨。 百姓不怨，则民用可得； 诸侯弗备，则天下之时可承。 若汤、武承桀，纣而起。 事所与众同也，功所与时成也，圣人无焉。 故老子曰，虎无所措其爪，兕无所措其角。 盖谓此也。 鼓不灭於声，故能有声； 镜不没於形，故能有形。 金石有声，弗叩弗鸣； 管萧有音，弗吹无声。 圣人内藏，不为物先倡，事来而制，物至而应。 饰其外者伤其内，失其情者害其神，见其文者蔽其质。 无须臾忘为质者，必困於性。 常思为质，不修自然，则性困也。 百步之中不忘其容者，必累其形。 故羽翼美者伤骨骸，鹄应一举千里，则形如尘芳，以其翮美也。 枝叶美者害根茎，能两美者，天下无之也。 天有明，不忧民之晦也，百姓穿户凿牖，自取照焉。 地有财，不忧民之贫也，百姓伐木芟草，自取富焉。 至德道者若丘山，块然不动，行者以为期也。 行道之人，指以为期，趋至。 直己而足物，己，己山也。 言山特自生万物以足百姓，不为百姓故生之。 不为赣，用之者尔不受其德，故宁而能（文）〔 久〕#4。 天地无予也，故无夺也； 日月无德也，故无怨也。 喜得者必多怨，喜予者必喜夺。 唯灭迹於无为，而随天地自然者，唯能胜理理，事理，情欲也。 胜理去之。 而为受名，名兴则道行，道行则人无位矣。 故誉生则毁随之，善见则怨从之。 利则为害始，福则为祸先。 唯不求利者为无害，唯不求福者为无祸。 侯而求霸者必失其侯，霸而求王者必丧其霸。 故国以全为常，霸王其寄也； 身以生为常，富贵其寄也。 能不以天下伤其国，而不以国害其身者，焉可以托天下也。 言不贪天下之利，故可以天下托也。 不知道者，释其所已有，而求其所未得也。 苦心愁虑以行曲，故福至则喜，祸至则怖，神劳於谋，智遽於事，祸福萌生，终身不悔，己之所生，乃反愁人。 祸福皆生於己，非旁人也。 不喜则忧，中未尝平，持无所监，谓之狂生。 时无所监，所监者非玄德，故为狂生。 人主好仁，则无功者赏，有罪者释。 好刑，则有功者废，无罪者诛。 及无好者，诛而无怨，施而不德，放准循绳，身无与事，若天若地，何不覆载。 故合而舍之者君也，制而诛之者法也，民已受诛，怨无所灭，谓之道。 道胜，则人无事矣。 圣人、无屈奇之服，屈，短。
chunks.translated_text:
The sage has no mind to reject yet the heart knows no ugliness; has no mind to select beauty yet beauty is not lost. Thus, in ancestral rites, one thinks of kin without seeking blessing; in hosting guests, one cultivates reverence without expecting virtue—only those who do not seek can possess. This means that what is not sought arrives of itself.

Those in exalted positions are so called because they uphold public principle without private delight, not because they are deemed worthy. Those who possess the great earth are so called because they follow constant methods without cunning schemes, not because they are deemed wise. Within, they harbor no violent affairs to incur the resentment of the people; without, they display no worthy conduct to provoke the envy of feudal lords. The rites between superior and inferior are observed without deviation, yet in the eyes of critics, nothing is seen to admire—this is what is meant by "concealing without form." If not concealing without form, who could manifest form? Form, when spoken of, appears as divination reveals.

What the Three Dynasties followed was *yin*—accord. Thus, Yu dredged the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers, following water; Hou Ji sowed and planted grains, following earth; Tang and Wu pacified tyranny and chaos, following the times. Therefore, the world may be obtained but not seized—it cannot be forcibly taken. Hegemony and kingship may be received but not sought. If sought through cunning, others will contend; if sought through force, others will resist. There has never been one who could make others devoid of wisdom—this means one cannot ensure that the state one encounters will lack wisdom. There has only been one who could prevent others from employing their wisdom against oneself. There has never been one who could make others devoid of strength; there has only been one who could prevent others from applying their strength against oneself. These two principles endure through long observation.

Thus, when the worthy ruler is not seen, feudal lords do not prepare; when the unworthy is not seen, the people do not resent. When the people do not resent, their service may be obtained; when feudal lords do not prepare, the opportunity of the world may be seized—as when Tang and Wu rose to overthrow Jie and Zhou. Their undertakings aligned with the multitude, their achievements aligned with the times—yet the sage had no part in them. Thus, Laozi said, "The tiger has no place to set its claws; the rhinoceros has no place to set its horn." This is what he meant.

The drum is not extinguished in sound, thus it can produce sound; the mirror is not obscured by form, thus it can reflect form. Metal and stone have voices, yet without striking, they do not ring; pipes and flutes have tones, yet without blowing, they make no sound. The sage conceals within, does not take the lead in matters, responds when affairs arise, and answers when things arrive.

Adorning the exterior harms the interior; losing one’s true nature harms the spirit; displaying ornament obscures substance. One who never forgets substance for even a moment will surely strain their nature. Constantly thinking of substance without cultivating naturalness strains the nature. One who does not forget their bearing within a hundred paces will surely burden their form. Thus, those with beautiful plumage harm their bones and frame; the swan, though it soars a thousand *li* in a single flight, leaves its form like drifting dust—because its wings are too fine. Those with beautiful branches and leaves harm their roots and stems. One who can perfect both is nowhere to be found in the world.

Heaven has brightness yet does not worry that the people are benighted—the people bore windows and doors to seek light for themselves. Earth has wealth yet does not worry that the people are poor—the people fell trees and clear grass to enrich themselves. The one of utmost virtue and Dao is like a mountain, solid and unmoving, yet travelers take it as their mark. Those who walk the Way point to it as their destination.

Straightening oneself suffices for others—like a mountain, it naturally produces all things to sustain the people, not for the people’s sake that it produces them. It does not bestow, yet those who use it do not receive its virtue, thus it remains tranquil and enduring. Heaven and earth do not grant, thus they do not take away; the sun and moon do not claim virtue, thus they incur no resentment. Those who delight in gaining will surely incur much resentment; those who delight in giving will surely delight in taking. Only by erasing traces in non-action and following the naturalness of heaven and earth can one overcome principle—principle meaning the patterns of human desires. Overcoming principle means eliminating it.

To act is to invite reputation; when reputation arises, the Dao is practiced; when the Dao is practiced, people lose their place. Thus, praise gives rise to slander, goodness invites resentment. Profit is the beginning of harm; blessing is the forerunner of misfortune. Only those who do not seek profit are free from harm; only those who do not seek blessing are free from misfortune. A lord who seeks hegemony will surely lose his lordship; a hegemon who seeks kingship will surely forfeit his hegemony. Thus, the state’s constancy lies in wholeness, while hegemony and kingship are but temporary lodgings; the body’s constancy lies in life, while wealth and nobility are but temporary lodgings. One who can avoid harming their state for the sake of the world and avoid harming their body for the sake of their state—such a one may be entrusted with the world. This means one who does not covet the world’s profit may be entrusted with the world.

Those who do not understand the Dao abandon what they already possess to seek what they have not obtained. They toil their minds with anxious thoughts to follow crooked paths, thus when fortune comes, they rejoice; when misfortune comes, they fear. Their spirits labor in scheming, their wisdom is frantic in affairs; misfortune and fortune sprout, yet they never repent throughout their lives. What they themselves have generated, they instead resent in others. Misfortune and fortune both arise from oneself, not from others. Without joy, there is worry; the heart is never at peace. Holding nothing to observe is called a mad life. Having no standard to observe, what is observed is not dark virtue—thus it is called a mad life.

When a ruler favors benevolence, the undeserving are rewarded and the guilty are released. When a ruler favors punishment, the meritorious are discarded and the innocent are executed. Only one who favors neither: executing without resentment, bestowing without claiming virtue, following the level and adhering to the plumb line, remaining uninvolved in affairs—like heaven and earth, what does it not cover and bear? Thus, the one who assembles and dismisses is the ruler; the one who controls and executes is the law. When the people have received punishment, yet resentment has nowhere to vanish—this is called the Dao. When the Dao prevails, people have no affairs.

The sage wears no extraordinary attire—short or long.

The jade *tian* of Kunlun—*tian* means a standard—cannot be sullied by dust and grime.

chunks.original_text: 奇，长也。 服之不中，身之灾也。 无瑰异之行，服不视，其所服，众不观视也。 行不观，言不议，通而不华，穷而不慑，荣而不显，隐而不穷，异而不见怪，容不与众同，无以名之，此之谓大通。 升降揖让，趋翔周游，不得已而为也，非性所有於身，情无符检，情无符检，非所乐也。 行所不得已之事，揖让者，不得已而为。 而不解构耳，岂加故焉哉。 岂故者，遭时宜而制礼，非故为。 故不得已而歌者，不事为悲； 不得已而舞者，不矜为丽。 歌舞而不事为悲丽者，皆无有根心者。 中无根心，强为悲丽。 善博者不欲牟，博其棋，不伤为谋也。 不恐不胜，平心定意，捉得其齐，齐，得其适。 行由其理，虽不必胜，得筹必多。 何则？ 胜在於数，不在於欲。 欲胜也。 駎者不贪最先，駎，竞骊也。 不恐独后，缓急调乎手，御心调乎马，虽不能必先哉，马力必尽矣。 何则？ 先在於数，而不在於欲也。 是故灭欲则数胜，弃智则道立矣。 贾多端则贫，工多技则穷，心不一也。 故木之大者害其条，水之大者害其深。 有智而无术，虽钻之不通； 虽有智慧，钻之弥牢，无术，不能达也。 有百枝而无一道，虽得之弗能守。 故诗曰，淑人君子，其仪一也，心如结也。 君子其结於一乎。 舜弹五弦之琴，古琴五弦，至周有七律，增为七弦也。 而歌南风之诗，南风，恺乐之风。 以治天下。 周公散臑不收於前，臑，前肩之美也。 钟鼓不解於县，以辅成王而海内平。 匹夫百亩一守，百亩之田，一夫一妇守也。 不遑启处，遑，暇。 启，开。 无所移之也。 以一人兼听天下，日有余而治不足，使人为之也。 处尊位者如尸，守官者如祝宰。 尸虽能剥狗烧彘，弗为也，弗能亏； 尸不能治狗事，不亏也。 俎豆之列次，黍稷之先后，虽知弗教也，弗能无害也。 不能祝者，不可以为祝，无害於为尸； 无害者，可以为尸也。 不能御者，不以为仆，无害於为佐。 佐，君位也。 故位愈尊而身愈佚，身愈大而事愈少。 譬如张琴，小弦虽急，大弦必缓。 无为者，道之体也，执后者，道之容也。 无为制有为，术也。 执后之制先，数也。 放於术则强，审於数则宁。 今与人弁氏之（譬）［璧〕#5未受者，先也； 求而致之，虽怨不逆者，后也。 三人同舍，二人相争，争者各自以为直，不能相听，一人虽愚，必从旁而决之，非以智，不争也。 两人相斗，一羸在侧，羸，劣人也。 助一人则胜，救一人则免，斗者虽强，必制一骡，非以勇也，以不斗也。 由此观之，后之制先，静之胜躁，数也。 倍道弃数，以求苟遇，变常易故，以知要庶，遇则自非，中则以为候，暗行缪改，终身不寤，此之谓狂。 有滑则诎，有福则羸，有过则悔，有功则矜，遂不知反，此谓狂人。 员之中规； 方之中矩，行成兽，有谓古礼执羔麋鹿，取其跪乳，群而不党。 止成文，文谓威仪文采。 可以将少，而不可以将众。 蓼菜成行，蓼菜小，皆有行列也。 瓶瓯有堤，堤，瓶瓯下安也。 量粟而舂，数米而炊，可以治家，而不可以治国。 涤杯而食，洗爵而饮，院而后馈，馈，进食也。 可以养家老，而不可以飨三军。 非易不可以治大，非简不可以合众。 大乐必易，大礼必简。 易故能天，简故能地。 大乐无怨，大礼不责，四海之内，莫不系统，故能帝也。
chunks.translated_text:
Long and short refer to attire. Wearing garments that do not fit brings disaster upon oneself. Without extraordinary conduct, one’s clothing goes unnoticed—what one wears, the multitude does not observe. Conduct unobserved, words undiscussed, unobstructed yet unadorned, impoverished yet unafraid, honored yet unassuming, secluded yet unbounded, different yet unremarkable—such bearing does not conform to the crowd. Nameless, this is called the Great Unobstruction.

Rising and bowing, advancing and retiring, pacing and circling—these are done out of necessity, not innate to one’s nature. When emotions bear no seal of restraint, they are not what one delights in. Acting from necessity, bowing and yielding are done not by choice. Yet one does not shirk them—how could they be done deliberately? Deliberation arises from adapting to the times, not from contrivance.

Thus, one who sings out of necessity does not perform sorrow; one who dances out of necessity does not flaunt beauty. Those who sing and dance without performing sorrow or beauty possess no rooted intent. Without rooted intent, sorrow and beauty are forced.

A skilled gambler does not crave gain; playing the game, they do not scheme to harm. Unafraid of defeat, their mind is calm, their intent steady. Grasping the balance, they find the proper measure. Acting according to principle, though victory is not assured, they will surely gain more. Why? Success lies in method, not in desire. Desire seeks victory.

A charioteer does not covet the lead; racing steeds, they do not fear falling behind. Rein and hand move in harmony, the mind in tune with the horses. Though they may not always prevail, the horses’ strength is fully spent. Why? The lead lies in method, not in desire.

Thus, extinguishing desire allows method to prevail; abandoning cunning allows the Dao to stand. A merchant with many schemes grows poor; a craftsman with many skills falls into want—their heart is not single. A great tree harms its branches; deep water harms its depths.

With wisdom but no technique, drilling will not penetrate; though one possesses intelligence, the deeper one drills, the more impenetrable it becomes—without technique, nothing is achieved. With a hundred branches but no single path, though one gains, one cannot hold.

Thus the *Poetry* says: “The noble person, their demeanor is one—like a knot, their heart is bound.” The noble one is knotted in unity.

Shun plucked the five-stringed zither and sang the *South Wind*, using its joyful harmony to govern the world. The Duke of Zhou left the roasted meat uneaten before him, the bells and drums unsilenced upon their stands, to assist King Cheng and bring peace to the realm.

A commoner tending a hundred *mu* of land has no leisure to rise or rest, nowhere to divert their labor. Yet one who listens to the affairs of all under heaven finds the day too long and governance insufficient—this is because others act on their behalf.

One in exalted position is like the ancestral spirit: though capable of butchering dogs or roasting pigs, they do not do so—yet their inability does not diminish them. The arrangement of sacrificial vessels, the order of millet and grain, though they know it, they do not instruct—yet their ignorance does not harm.

One who cannot perform the rites of the invocator cannot serve as invocator, but this does not prevent them from serving as the ancestral spirit. One who cannot drive a chariot cannot be a driver, but this does not prevent them from being an attendant. The attendant holds the lord’s position.

Thus, the higher the rank, the more the body is at ease; the greater the stature, the fewer the affairs. Like tuning a zither: though the small strings are taut, the great strings must be slack.

Non-action is the essence of the Dao; holding to the rear is its bearing. Non-action governs action—this is technique. Holding to the rear governs the front—this is method. Following technique brings strength; scrutinizing method brings tranquility.

Now, offering a Bian-shi jade to one who has not yet received it is to act first; seeking and presenting it, though resentment arises, is not refused—this is to act last. Three people sharing a dwelling, two quarrel: each claims rightness, neither listens. Though the third is foolish, they must decide from the side—not through wisdom, but through non-contention.

Two people brawl, a weakling stands by. Aiding one brings victory; rescuing the other brings escape. Though the fighters are strong, they are restrained by the one who does not fight—not through courage, but through non-engagement.

From this we see: the rear governs the front, stillness overcomes restlessness—this is method. Doubling the Dao and abandoning method to seek fleeting encounters, altering constants and discarding the old to grasp at trifles—if one meets success, they deem themselves right; if they hit the mark, they take it as a sign. Acting in darkness, erring and changing, they pass their lives unenlightened—this is called madness.

With obstruction comes defeat; with fortune comes weakness; with error comes regret; with merit comes pride. Proceeding without turning back—this is the madman.

A circle fits the compass; a square fits the carpenter’s square. Conduct forms the beast—ancient rites held lambs and fawns, taking their kneeling to nurse, their herding without faction. Stillness forms pattern—pattern refers to dignified bearing and adornment. This can lead the few, but not the many.

Smartweed grows in rows—smartweed is small, yet all have their order. Jars and urns have their bases—the base secures what lies beneath. Measuring grain before hulling, counting rice before cooking—this can govern a household, but not a state.

Washing cups before eating, rinsing goblets before drinking, sweeping the courtyard before serving food—this can nourish a family elder, but not feast an army. Without ease, one cannot govern the great; without simplicity, one cannot unite the multitude.

Great music must be easy; great ritual must be simple. Ease allows it to be heavenly; simplicity allows it to be earthly. Great music bears no resentment; great ritual makes no demands. Within the four seas, none are not bound to its order—thus it can be imperial.

The *South Wind* is the wind of joyful harmony. The five-stringed zither was ancient; by the Zhou, it had seven strings. The Duke of Zhou left the roasted meat (the choicest cut of the shoulder) uneaten before him. The bells and drums remained suspended, unplayed, as he assisted King Cheng and pacified the realm.

A single man and woman tend a hundred *mu* of land, with no leisure to rise or rest—nowhere to divert their labor. Yet one who listens to all under heaven finds the day too long and governance insufficient—this is because others act on their behalf.

One in exalted position is like the ancestral spirit: though capable of skinning dogs or roasting pigs, they do not do so—yet their inability does not diminish them. The arrangement of sacrificial vessels, the order of millet and grain—though they know it, they do not instruct, yet their ignorance does not harm.

One who cannot perform the rites of the invocator cannot serve as invocator, but this does not prevent them from serving as the ancestral spirit. One who cannot drive a chariot cannot be a driver, but this does not prevent them from being an attendant. The attendant holds the lord’s position.

Thus, the higher the rank, the more the body is at ease; the greater the stature, the fewer the affairs. Like tuning a zither: though the small strings are taut, the great strings must be slack.

Thus, the one who assembles and dismisses is the ruler; the one who controls and executes is the law. chunks.original_text: 心有忧者，筐床衽席弗能安也，衽，柔弱也。 菰饭犓牛弗能甘也，菰，凋胡也。 琴瑟鸣竽弗能乐也。 患解忧除，然后食甘寝宁，居安游乐。 由是观之，（性）〔生〕#6有以乐也，死有以哀也。 今务益性之所不能乐，而以害性之所以乐，故虽富有天下，贵为天子，而不免为哀之人。 凡人之性，乐恬而憎悯，悯，忧有所在也。 乐佚而憎劳。 心常无欲，可谓恬矣； 形常无事，可谓佚矣。 游心於恬，舍形放佚，以俟天命，自乐於内，无急於外，虽天下之大，不足以易其一槩，日月庾而无溉於志，庾，隐也。 溉，灌也。 己自隐藏，不以他欲灌其志也。 故虽贱如贵，虽贫如富，大道无形，大仁无亲，大辩无声，大廉不嗛，大勇不矜，五者无弃，而几乡方矣。 方，道也。 庶几乡於道。 军多令则乱，酒多约则辩。 乱则降北，辩则相贼。 故始於都者常大於鄙，始於乐者常大於悲，其作始简者，其终本必调。 今有美酒嘉肴以相飨，卑体婉辞以接之，欲以合欢，争盈爵之间爵所以饮，争满不满之间。 反生斗。 斗而相伤，三族结怨，反其所憎，此酒之败也。 诗之失僻，诗者，衰世之风也，故邪而以之正。 人失其正，则入於邪。 乐之失刺，乡饮酒之乐歌鹿鸣，鹿鸣之作，君有酒肴，不召其臣，臣怨而刺上者非也。 礼之失责，礼无往不复，有施於人则责之。 征音非无羽声也，羽音非无征声也，五音莫不有声，而以征羽定名者，以胜者也。 征音之中有羽声，而以征音名之者，羽音征以着言者也。 故仁义智勇，圣人之所备有也，然而皆立一名者，亡一名，谓仁义智勇兼以圣人之言。 言其大者也。 阳气起於东北，尽於西南； 阴气起於西南，尽於东北。 阴阳之始，皆调适相似，日长其类，以侵相远，言阳气自大寒日月长温，以致大热，与大寒相远也。 或热焦沙，或寒凝水，故圣人谨慎其所积。 水出於山而入於海，稼生於野而藏於廪，见所始则知终矣。 席之先雚蕈，席之先所从生，出於雚与蕈苇也。 樽之上玄（樽）〔酒〕#7，樽，酒器，所尊者玄水。 俎之先生鱼，祭俎上肴以生鱼也。 豆之行泰羹，木豆，谓之豆，所盛大羹，不调五味。 此皆不快於耳目，不适於口腹，而先王贵之，贵之，所祭宗庙。 先本而后末。 圣人之接物，千变万轸，必有不化而应化者。 夫寒之与暖相反，大寒地坼水凝，火弗为衰其暑； 大热铄石流金，火弗为益其烈。 寒暑之变，无损益於己，质有之也。 言人质不可变於火。 圣常后而不先，常应而不唱； 不进而求，不退而让； 随时三年，时去我先； 去时三年，时在我后； 无去无就，中立其所。 天道无亲，唯德是与。 有道者，不失时与人； 失时，失其时。 非失其时以与人。 无道者，失於时而取人。 直己而待命，〔时〕#8之（去）〔至〕#9不可迎而反也，要遮而求合，时之去不可追而援也。 故不曰我无以为而天下远，不曰我不欲而天下不至。 古之存己者，乐德而忘贱，故名不动志； 不以名移志也。 乐道而忘贫，故利不动心，名利充天下，〔不〕#10足以概志，故兼而能乐，静而能澹。 故其身治者，可与言道矣。 自身以上於荒芒尔远矣。 身以上，从己生以前至於荒芒。 荒芒，上古时也，故远矣。
chunks.translated_text:
One whose heart bears sorrow finds no rest upon woven mats or soft cushions—*ren* means gentle yielding. Even wild-rice gruel and beef from stall-fed cattle taste bitter; zither, lute, and reed pipes bring no joy. Only when cares dissolve and sorrows vanish do food become sweet, sleep peaceful, dwelling secure, and wanderings delightful.

From this we see: life has its joys, death its sorrows. Yet now men strive for what their nature cannot enjoy, harming what brings it joy. Thus, though they possess all under heaven and rank as Son of Heaven, they cannot escape becoming men of sorrow.

By nature, all delight in tranquility and detest anxiety—*min* means worry fixed upon something. They delight in ease and detest toil. A heart ever free of desire may be called tranquil; a body ever free of affairs may be called at ease. Let the mind wander in tranquility, the form roam in ease, awaiting Heaven’s decree. Rejoice within, seek nothing without. Though all under heaven be vast, it cannot exchange for even a moment’s peace. Sun and moon may wane, yet they do not irrigate the will—*yu* means hidden; *gai* means to pour. The self remains concealed, no foreign desire flooding the will.

Thus, though lowly, one may be as noble; though poor, as rich. The great Dao has no form; great benevolence no favorites; great eloquence no sound; great integrity no humility; great courage no pride. Master these five, and one nears the direction of the Way—*fang* means the Dao. One nearly turns toward the Dao.

Where commands multiply, armies fall into chaos; where wine flows freely, disputes arise. Chaos leads to defeat; disputes to mutual harm. Thus, what begins in order ever surpasses what begins in disorder; what begins in joy ever surpasses what begins in sorrow. What starts simply must end in fundamental harmony.

Now, offering fine wine and choice delicacies to feast another, bowing humbly with gentle words to welcome them, one seeks to foster joy—yet they vie over filling goblets, quarreling over whether they are full or not. This instead breeds strife. Strife leads to injury, entangling the three clans in enmity, turning to what they detest. Such is the ruin wrought by wine.

The *Odes* err through perversity—the *Odes* reflect the customs of a declining age, thus they are crooked yet used to correct. When men lose their proper way, they fall into crookedness.

Music errs through satire. In the village drinking song, the *Lu Ming* was composed when the lord had wine and delicacies yet did not summon his ministers—thus their resentment and satire of their superior were wrong.

Rites err through demanding reciprocity. In rites, nothing goes forth without return; what one bestows upon another, one expects in kind.

The *zhi* note is not without the *yu* sound; the *yu* sound is not without the *zhi* note. All five notes contain sound, yet they are named by *zhi* or *yu* because of what prevails. Within the *zhi* note lies the *yu* sound, yet it is named the *zhi* note because the *yu* sound is subsumed within it.

Thus, benevolence, righteousness, wisdom, and courage—though the sage possesses them all—each bears a single name. Were one lacking, it would be called by the sage’s name, speaking of the greater.

Yang qi arises in the northeast and ends in the southwest; yin qi arises in the southwest and ends in the northeast. At the beginning of yin and yang, all is balanced and alike. As days lengthen, their kind grows, each encroaching and distancing itself from the other. Yang qi, from the Great Cold, grows warmer day by day until the Great Heat, far removed from the Great Cold. Some days scorch the sand; others freeze the water. Thus, the sage is cautious in what he accumulates.

Water flows from mountains to the sea; grain grows in the fields and is stored in granaries. Seeing the beginning, one knows the end.

Mats first come from reeds and rushes; the first offering in the goblet is dark wine—*zun* is a wine vessel, and what is revered is dark water. The first offering on the sacrificial platter is raw fish. The first dish in the wooden bowl is plain broth—*dou* refers to the wooden vessel, and what it holds is the great broth, unseasoned with the five flavors. Though none of these please the ear or eye, nor suit the mouth or belly, the former kings prized them, for they honored what was offered in ancestral temples. They put first things first and last things last.

In the sage’s dealings with things, though they shift a thousand ways and turn ten thousand times, there must be that which remains unchanged yet responds to change.

Cold and warmth are opposites. In the Great Cold, the earth splits and water congeals, yet fire does not diminish its heat. In the Great Heat, stones melt and metal flows, yet fire does not increase its intensity. The changes of cold and heat bring no gain or loss to its essence, for its nature is fixed. This speaks of the human nature that cannot be altered by fire.

The sage always follows and never leads, always responds and never initiates. He does not advance to seek, nor retreat to yield. For three years, he follows the times; when the time departs, it goes before him. For three years after it departs, the time remains behind him. Neither departing nor approaching, he stands at the center of his place.

The Way of Heaven shows no favoritism; it befriends only virtue. One who possesses the Dao does not miss the time or the person—missing the time means losing the moment, not losing the moment to give to another. One who lacks the Dao loses the time and takes from others.

Standing straight and awaiting fate, the moment’s arrival cannot be met by turning back; seeking agreement by blocking and intercepting, the moment’s departure cannot be grasped by pulling. Thus, one does not say, “I have nothing to offer, so all under heaven keeps its distance,” nor “I do not desire it, so all under heaven does not come.”

The ancients who preserved themselves delighted in virtue and forgot lowliness, so their fame did not sway their will. They delighted in the Dao and forgot poverty, so profit did not move their hearts. Though fame and profit filled all under heaven, they were not enough to sway their will. Thus, they could delight in both and remain tranquil and serene. Therefore, those who govern themselves may be spoken to of the Dao.

From the self upward to the distant past is immeasurably far—“from the self upward” means from one’s own birth back to the distant past. *Huang mang* refers to the age of remote antiquity, thus it is far indeed.

Thus, the higher the rank, the more the body is at ease; the greater the stature, the fewer the affairs. Like tuning a zither: though the small strings are taut, the great strings must be slack.

chunks.original_text: 自死而天地无穷尔滔矣，从己身死之后，至天地无穷。 滔，曼长也。 以数杂之寿，杂，匝也。 人生子，从子至亥为一匝。 忧天下之乱，犹忧河水之少，泣而益之也。 龟三千岁，龟吐故纳新，故寿三千岁。 浮游不过三日，浮游，渠略也。 生三日死也。 以浮游而为龟忧养生之具，人必笑之矣。 故不忧天下之乱，而乐其身之治也，可与言道矣。 君子为善不能使富必来，不为非而不能使祸无至。 福之至也，非其所求，故不伐其功。 祸之来也，非其所生，故不悔其行。 内修极极，中。 而横祸至者，皆天也，非人也。 故中心常恬漠，累积其德； 狗吠而不惊，自信其情。 故知道者不惑，知命者不忧。 万乘之主卒，葬其骸於旷野之中，祀其鬼神於明堂之上，庙之中，谓之明堂也。 神贵於形也。 以人神在堂，而形骸在野。 故神制则形从，神制，谓情也。 情欲使不作也，而形体从心以合。 形胜则神穷。 形胜，谓人体躁动胜其精神，神穷而去也。 聪明虽用，必反诸神，聪明虽用，於内以守。 明神安而身全。 谓之太冲。 冲，调也。 淮南鸿烈解卷之二十一竟 #1『为论』二字脱，据集解本补。 『货』他本并作『贸』。 #2『未而』，当为『而未』，据集解本改。 #3『皆』，『背』字之误，据集解本改。 #4『文』，集解本作『久』。 #5『氏』义本原误『民』，『譬』，『璧』字之误，并据集解本改。 #6『性』，集解本作『生』。 #7『樽』，集解本作『酒』。 #8『时』字脱，据集解本补。 #9『去』，『至』字之误。 据集解本改。 #10『不』字脱，据集解本补。 淮南鸿烈解卷之二十二 太尉祭酒臣许慎记上
chunks.translated_text:
From death onward to the endlessness of heaven and earth is immeasurably vast—"from death onward" means from the time after one’s own death to the boundless end of heaven and earth. *Taotao* means long and unbroken. As for the span of mortal life, *za* means a full cycle. When a person has a child, from *zi* to *hai* marks one cycle. To worry over the world’s chaos is like weeping over the scarcity of river water, trying to add to it with tears. The tortoise lives three thousand years, for it expels the old and takes in the new, thus attaining such longevity. The mayfly does not last beyond three days—*fuyou* refers to its fleeting existence, living but three days before dying. To fret over the mayfly’s means of nurturing life as one would for the tortoise would surely invite ridicule. Thus, one who does not worry over the world’s chaos but delights in the governance of the self may be spoken to of the Dao.

The noble person, though he does good, cannot ensure that wealth will come; though he refrains from wrongdoing, cannot ensure that misfortune will not arrive. When fortune comes, it is not what he sought, so he does not boast of his merit. When misfortune arrives, it is not of his making, so he does not regret his conduct. Cultivating the utmost within—*ji* means the center—yet if calamity strikes from without, it is the work of heaven, not man. Thus, the heart remains ever tranquil and detached, accumulating virtue; the dog barks, yet one is not startled, trusting in one’s true nature. Therefore, those who know the Dao are not deluded, and those who understand fate are not anxious.

When the lord of ten thousand chariots dies, his bones are buried in the open wilderness, while his spirit is venerated in the *Mingtang*—the temple is called the *Mingtang*. The spirit is prized above the form. Thus, the spirit dwells in the hall while the body lies in the wild. When the spirit governs, the form follows—*shenzhi* refers to the emotions, meaning desires are not stirred, and the body complies with the heart’s harmony. When the form prevails, the spirit is exhausted—*xingsheng* means the body’s restlessness overpowers the spirit, and the spirit, depleted, departs. Though hearing and sight are employed, they must return to the spirit; though hearing and sight are used, they guard within. When the spirit is at peace, the self is whole. This is called *Taichong*—*chong* means harmony.

From the self upward to the distant past is immeasurably far—“from the self upward” means from one’s own birth back to the distant past. *Huang mang* refers to the age of remote antiquity, thus it is far indeed.

chunks.original_text: 兵略训 兵，防也，防乱之萌，皆在略谋，解喻至论用师之意也。 古之用兵者，非利土壤之广而贪金玉之略，略，获得也。 将以存亡继绝，平天下之乱，而除万民之害也。 凡有血气之虫，含牙带角，前爪后距，有角者触，有齿者噬，有毒者螫，有蹄者趹，喜而相戏，怒而相害，天之性也。 人有衣食之情，而物弗能足也，故群居杂处，分不均，求不赡，则争。 争则强胁弱而勇侵怯，人无筋骨之强，爪牙之利，故割革而为甲，烁铁而为刃，贪昧饕餮之人，残贼天下，万人搔动，莫宁其所有。 圣人勃然而起，乃讨强暴，平乱世，夷险除秽，以浊为清，以危为宁，故不得不中绝。 中绝，谓若殷王中相绝灭。 兵之所由来者远矣。 黄帝尝与炎帝战矣，炎帝，神农之末世也。 与黄帝战於阪泉，黄帝灭之。 颛顼尝与共工争矣。 共工与颛顼争为帝，触不周山。 故黄帝战於涿鹿之野，黄帝与蚩尤战於涿鹿，涿鹿在上谷。 尧战於丹水之浦，尧以楚伯受命，灭不义於丹水。 丹水在南阳。 舜伐有苗，有苗，三苗。 启攻有扈。 禹之子启伐有扈於甘。 甘在右扶风郡。 自五帝而弗能偃也，又况衰世乎。 夫兵者，所以禁暴讨乱也。 炎帝为火灾，故黄帝擒之； 共工为水害，故颛顼诛之。 教之以道，导之以德，而不听，则临之以威武。 临之威武而不从，则制之以兵革。 故圣人之用兵也，若栉发耨苗，所去者少，而所利者多。 杀无罪之民，而养无义之君，害莫大焉。 殚天下之财，而赡一人之欲，祸莫深焉。 使夏桀、殷纣有害於民而立被其患，不至於为炮烙。 晋厉、宋康行一不义而身死国亡，不至於侵夺为暴。 此四君者，皆有小过而莫之（计）〔讨〕#1也，故至於攘天下，攘，乱。 害百姓，肆一人之邪，而长海内之祸，此大论之所不取也。 所为立君者，以禁暴讨乱也。
chunks.translated_text:
**Military Strategy**

War is defense—defense against the sprouts of chaos, all of which lie in strategic planning. This treatise elucidates the profound principles of employing troops.

Those who wielded arms in antiquity did not covet vast lands or plunder gold and jade—*lüe* means "to obtain." Rather, they sought to preserve what was perishing, restore what was severed, pacify the world’s turmoil, and eradicate the suffering of the people.

All creatures with blood and *qi*—those bearing fangs and horns, claws and spurs—gore with their horns, bite with their teeth, sting with their venom, and kick with their hooves. When joyful, they play together; when enraged, they harm one another. Such is the nature of Heaven.

Humans possess desires for clothing and food, yet resources cannot suffice. Thus, they gather in mixed communities. When distribution is unequal and needs go unmet, strife arises. In strife, the strong coerce the weak, and the bold invade the timid. Lacking the strength of sinew and bone or the sharpness of claws and fangs, humans flay hides to fashion armor and smelt iron to forge blades. The greedy and rapacious among them ravage the world, stirring the masses into turmoil, leaving none in peace with what they possess.

The sage arises in indignation, punishing the violent, quelling chaos, leveling peril, purging filth, transforming turbidity into clarity, and turning danger into tranquility—thus, there is no choice but to sever the line. *Zhongjue* refers to the annihilation of the Shang kings’ middle lineage.

The origins of warfare stretch far into the past. The Yellow Emperor once battled the Flame Emperor—the Flame Emperor being the final sovereign of the Divine Farmer’s line. They clashed at Banquan, where the Yellow Emperor vanquished him. Zhuanxu once contended with Gonggong. Gonggong vied with Zhuanxu for supremacy, striking Mount Buzhou. Thus, the Yellow Emperor fought on the fields of Zhuolu—the Yellow Emperor’s battle against Chi You at Zhuolu, which lies in Shanggu. Yao waged war at the banks of the Dan River, where he, as the Lord of Chu, executed the mandate to destroy the unjust at Dan River. The Dan River flows through Nanyang. Shun campaigned against the Three Miao. The Three Miao were the Sanmiao. Qi, son of Yu, attacked Youhu. Qi, son of Yu, struck Youhu at Gan. Gan lies in the Right Fengyi Commandery.

Even the Five Emperors could not lay down arms—how much less could a degenerate age? Warfare exists to suppress violence and punish disorder. The Flame Emperor brought fire disasters, so the Yellow Emperor captured him. Gonggong caused water calamities, so Zhuanxu executed him. When instruction in the Dao and guidance by virtue go unheeded, authority and might are brought to bear. If authority and might are defied, then arms and armor are employed to restrain them.

Thus, the sage’s use of arms is like combing hair or weeding seedlings: what is removed is little, while what benefits is great. To slay innocent people while sustaining an unrighteous ruler is the greatest harm. To exhaust the world’s wealth to sate one man’s desires is the deepest calamity.

Had Jie of Xia and Zhou of Yin inflicted harm upon the people but faced consequences before their reigns, they would not have resorted to the *paoluo* torture. Had Li of Jin and Kang of Song committed a single act of injustice but perished before their states fell, they would not have turned to plunder and violence. These four rulers each committed minor transgressions, yet none were *punished*—thus, they plunged the world into chaos, harmed the common folk, indulged their own wickedness, and prolonged the realm’s suffering. Such is the great discourse that rejects this course.

The purpose of establishing rulers is to suppress violence and punish disorder.

chunks.original_text: 今乘万民之力，而反为残贱，是为虎傅翼，曷为弗除。 夫畜池鱼者必去猵獭，猵獭之类。 养禽兽者也必去豺狼，又凡治人乎。 故霸王之兵，以论虑之，以策图之，以义扶之，非以亡存也，将以存亡也。 故闻敌国之君有加虐於民者，则举兵而临其境，责之以不义，刺之以过行。 兵至其郊，乃令军师曰，无伐树木，毋扣坟墓，毋塾五谷，爇，烧。 毋焚积聚，毋捕民虏，毋收六畜。 乃发号施令〔曰〕#2，其国之君傲天侮鬼，决狱不辜，杀戮无罪，此天之所以诛也，民之所以仇也。 兵之来也，以废不义而复有德也。 有逆天之道，帅民之贼者，身死族灭。 以家听者，禄以家。 以里听者，赏以里。 以乡听者，封以乡。 以县听者，侯以县。 克国不及其民，废其君而易其政，尊其秀士而显其贤良，振其孤寡，恤其贫穷，出其囹圄，赏其有功。 百姓开门而待之，淅米而储之，淅，渍。 恐其不来也。 此汤、武之所以致王，而齐桓、晋文之所以成霸也。 故君为无道，民之思兵也，若旱而望雨，渴而求饮，夫有谁与交兵接刃乎。 故义兵之至也，至於不战而止。 晚世之兵，君虽无道，莫不设渠堑，传堞而守，传，守也。 堞，城上女墙。 攻者非以禁暴除害也，欲以侵地广壤也。 是故至於伏尸流血，相支以日，而霸王之功不世出者，自为之故也。 夫为地战者不能成其王，为身战者不能立其功。 举事以为人者众助之，举事以自为者众去之。 众之所助，虽弱必强； 众之所去，虽大必亡。 兵失道而弱，得道而强； 将失道而拙，得道而工； 国得道而存，失道而亡。 所谓道者，体圆而法方，背阴而抱阳，左柔而右刚，履幽而戴明，变化无常，得一之原，以应无方，是谓神明。 夫圆者，天也； 方者，地也。 天圆而无端，故不可得而观； 地方而无垠，故莫能窥其门。 天化育而无形象，地出长而无计量，浑浑沉沉，孰知其藏，凡物有朕，唯道无朕。 言万物可朕也，而道不可朕也。 所以无朕者，以其无常形势也。 轮转而无穷，象日月之行，若春秋有代谢，若日月有昼夜终而复始，明而复晦，莫能得其纪。 制刑而无刑，故功可成； 物物而不物，故胜而不屈。 刑，兵之极也，至於无刑，可谓极之矣。 是故大兵无创，与鬼神通，五兵不厉，天下莫之败当。 建鼓不出库，诸侯莫不慑□沮胆其处。 故庙战者帝，神化者王。 所谓庙战者，法天道也； 神化者，法四时也。 修政於境内而远方慕其德； 制胜於未战而诸侯服其威，内政治也。 古得道者，静而法天地，动而顺日月，喜怒而合四时，叫呼而比雷霆，音气不戾八风，诎伸不获五度。 获，误也。 五度，五行也。 下至介鳞，上及毛羽，修修叶贯，万物百族，由本至末，莫不有序。 是故入小而不偪，偪，迫。 处大而不窕，浸乎金石，润乎草木，宇中六合，振毫之末，或曰，宇中，四宇也。 六合，六合内。 莫不顺比。 道之浸洽，滒淖纤微，无所不在，是以胜权多也。 夫射，仪度不得，则格的不中。 格，射之椹质也。 的，射准也。 骥，一节不用，而千里不至。 夫战而不胜者，非鼓之日也。 鼓之日，谓陈兵击鼓闻之日。 素行无刑久矣。 故得道之兵，车不发轫，轫，车不支。 骑不被鞍，鼓不振尘，旗不解卷，卷，束也。
chunks.translated_text:
Now, riding the strength of the myriad people yet turning to cruelty and degradation—this is like adding wings to a tiger. Why should it not be eradicated?

Those who keep pond fish must remove otters and their kin; those who raise birds and beasts must drive out jackals and wolves. How much more so for governing people?

Thus, the armies of hegemons and kings are deliberated with foresight, plotted with strategy, and upheld by righteousness—not for destruction, but to preserve what would otherwise perish. When they hear of a ruler in a rival state who inflicts cruelty upon the people, they lead their troops to its borders, reproaching him for his unrighteousness and condemning his transgressions. Upon reaching its outskirts, the commander issues orders: "Do not fell trees, do not disturb tombs, do not trample the five grains, do not set fires, do not burn stored provisions, do not seize the people as captives, do not take livestock."

Then, a proclamation is issued: "This state’s ruler defies Heaven and insults the spirits, condemns the innocent in judgment, and slaughters the blameless—this is why Heaven punishes him, why the people revile him. Our army has come to abolish unrighteousness and restore virtue. Those who oppose Heaven’s Way and lead the people to ruin shall perish with their clans. Those who submit by household shall be rewarded with households; those who submit by village shall be rewarded with villages; those who submit by township shall be enfeoffed with townships; those who submit by county shall be enfeoffed with counties."

When a state is conquered, its people are spared. Its ruler is deposed, its governance reformed, its scholars honored, its worthy and good elevated, its orphans and widows relieved, its poor and destitute succored, its prisoners released, and its meritorious rewarded. The common folk open their gates in welcome, wash their rice in preparation, and fear only that the army will not come. This is how Tang and Wu attained kingship, and how Duke Huan of Qi and Duke Wen of Jin achieved hegemony.

Thus, when a ruler is without the Way, the people’s longing for righteous troops is like the parched yearning for rain or the thirsty craving for drink. Who would dare to meet them in battle? Therefore, when righteous armies arrive, they often prevail without fighting.

In later ages, even when rulers were without the Way, they would fortify moats and ramparts, man the battlements, and stand guard. Yet their attackers did not come to suppress violence or eliminate harm, but to seize land and expand territory. Thus, battles led to heaps of corpses and rivers of blood, dragging on day after day, and the achievements

chunks.original_text: 甲不离矢，刃不尝血，朝不易位，贾不去肆，农不离野，招义而责之，大国必朝，小城必下。 因民之欲，乘民之力而为之，去残除贼也。 故同利相死，同情相成，同欲相助。 顺道而动，天下为向； 因民而虑，天下为斗。 猎者逐禽，车驰人趋，各尽其力，无刑罚之威，而相为斥闉要遮者，斥，候也。 闉，塞也。 同所利也。 同舟而济於江，卒遇风波，百族之子，捷梓招杼船，捷，疾取也。 若左右手，不以相得，其忧同也。 故明王之用兵也，为天下除害，而与万民共享其利，民之为用，犹子之为父，弟之为兄，威之所加，若崩山决塘，敌孰敢当。 故善用兵者，用其自为用也； 不能用兵者，用其为己用也。 用其自为用，则天下莫不可用也； 用其为己用，所得者鲜矣。 兵有三诋，为，大。 诋，要事也。 治国家，理境内，行仁义，布德惠，立正法，塞邪隧，群臣亲附，百姓和辑，上下一心，君臣同力，诸侯服其威，而四方怀其德，修政庙堂之上，而折冲千里之外，拱揖指撝而天下响应，此用兵之上也。 地广民众，主贤将忠，国富兵强，约束信，号令明，两军相当，鼓錞相望，錞，錞于，太钟也。 未至兵交接刃而敌人奔亡，此用兵之次也。 知土地之宜，习险隘之利，明奇政之变，察行陈解赎之数，维抱绾而鼓之，绾，贯。 抱系於臂，以击鼓也。 白刃合，流矢接，涉血属肠，舆死扶伤，流血千里，暴骸盈场，乃以决胜，此用兵之下也。 今夫天下皆知事治其末，而莫知务修其本，释其根而树其枝也。 夫兵之所以佐胜者众，而所以必胜者寡。 甲坚兵利，车固马良，畜积给足，士卒殷轸，殷，众。 轸，乘轮多盛貌。 此军之大资也，而胜亡焉。 明於星辰日月之运，刑德奇赅之数，奇赅，阴阳奇秘之要，非常之术。 背乡左右之便，此战之助也，而全亡焉。 良将之所以必胜者，恒有不原之智，不道之道，难以众同也。 夫论除谨，论除，为贤除吏。 谨，慎也。 动静时，吏卒辨，兵甲治，正行五，连什伯，明鼓旗，此尉之官。 军尉，所以尉镇众也。 前后知险易，见敌知难易，发斥不忘遗，发，有所见。 斥，斥度，使视也。 此侯之官也。 军侯，侯望者也。 隧路亟，隧，道也。 亟，言治军遂道疾。 行辎治，行辎，道路辎重。 赋丈均，赋治军垒，尺丈均平。 处军辑，井灶通，此司空之官也。 军司空，补空修缮者。 收藏於后，迁舍不离，无淫舆，无遗辎，此舆之官也。 舆，众也。 候领舆众在军之后者。 凡此五官之於将也，犹身之有股肱手足也，必择其人，（枝）〔技〕#3能其才，使官胜其任，人能其事。 告之以政，申之以令，使之若虎豹之有爪牙，飞鸟之有六翮，莫不为用。 然皆佐胜之具也，非所以必胜也。 兵之胜败，本在於政。 政胜其民，下附其上，则兵强矣。 民胜其政，下畔其上，则兵弱矣。 故德义足以怀天下之民，事业足以当天下之急，选举足以得贤士之心，谋虑足以知强弱之势，此必胜之本也。 地广人众，不足以为强； 坚甲利兵，不足以为胜； 高城深池，不足以为固； 严令繁刑，不足以为威。 为存政者，虽小必存； 为亡政者，虽大必亡。
chunks.translated_text:
The armor remains unscathed, blades untasted by blood; court officials hold their posts unchanged, merchants keep to their stalls, and farmers stay in their fields. Summoning righteousness and demanding allegiance, great states must pay homage, and small cities must submit. Riding the people’s desires and harnessing their strength, one removes the cruel and eliminates the bandits.

Thus, those who share a common benefit will die for one another; those who share a common sentiment will unite; those who share a common desire will aid each other. Moving in accord with the Dao, the world turns toward you; acting in accordance with the people’s will, the world becomes your weapon. Hunters pursue game, chariots speed, and men rush forward, each exerting their utmost strength. Without the threat of punishment, they yet scout and block key passes—scouts observe, and barriers seal—all for a shared benefit. When crossing a river in the same boat and suddenly encountering wind and waves, men of all clans swiftly grasp oars and poles, working together like left and right hands, not out of mutual affection but from shared peril.

Therefore, when a sagely king employs troops, it is to eliminate harm for the world and share its benefits with all people. The people’s service is like a son’s to his father or a younger brother’s to his elder. Where his might falls, it is like a mountain collapsing or a dam bursting—what enemy could withstand it? Thus, those skilled in warfare employ others as if for their own sake, while the unskilled employ them as if for their own use. Employing others as if for their own sake, there is none in the world who cannot be used; employing them for one’s own use, little is gained.

Warfare has three levels of urgency. The highest: governing the state, ordering the realm, practicing benevolence and righteousness, spreading virtue and kindness, establishing just laws, blocking the paths of evil, so that ministers draw near, the people harmonize, superiors and inferiors unite as one, and ruler and ministers join forces. The feudal lords submit to his might, and the four quarters cherish his virtue. Cultivating governance in the ancestral temple, he yet strikes down enemies a thousand *li* away. With a mere gesture or signal, the world responds—this is the highest use of arms. The next: lands are vast, the people numerous, the ruler worthy, and the generals loyal; the state is rich, the troops strong, discipline reliable, and commands clear. When two armies face each other, drums and bells resound in sight, yet before blades clash, the enemy flees—this is the second use of arms. The lowest: knowing the suitability of terrain, mastering the advantages of perilous passes, understanding the shifts of extraordinary tactics, and discerning the calculations of formations and maneuvers. Binding the drumsticks and sounding the drums, blades meet, arrows fly, blood flows and entrails spill, the dead are borne away and the wounded supported. Blood streams for a thousand *li*, corpses litter the field, and only then is victory decided—this is the lowest use of arms.

Now, the world knows only how to manage the branches but not how to cultivate the root, abandoning the trunk to tend the twigs. The means by which armies aid victory are many, but the means by which they secure certain triumph are few. Armor is sturdy, weapons sharp, chariots sturdy, horses fine, supplies abundant, and soldiers numerous—this is the great resource of an army, yet victory or defeat still hangs in the balance. Mastery of the movements of stars, sun, and moon, the calculations of *xing* and *de*, and the secrets of yin and yang—these are the aids to battle, yet survival or ruin still remains uncertain. The reason a great general always prevails lies in his unfathomable wisdom and the Dao that cannot be spoken, which the multitude cannot grasp.

When selecting and appointing officials, he is cautious; when moving or halting, he is timely. Officers and soldiers are discerning, weapons and armor well-maintained. He rectifies the Five Ranks, links squads and platoons, and clarifies drum and banner signals—this is the duty of the military commandant, who steadies the troops. He knows the dangers and ease of the terrain ahead and behind, assesses the enemy’s strength or weakness, and ensures no scout is left behind—this is the duty of the military scout. Roads are swiftly prepared, baggage trains ordered, encampments leveled, and wells and stoves connected—this is the duty of the military engineer. Supplies are gathered at the rear, and when the army moves, none are left behind; no excess baggage is carried, no equipment abandoned—this is the duty of the logistics officer. These five officers serve the general like limbs serve the body. He must choose men of ability, assign them to roles they can fulfill, and ensure each can perform his task. Instructing them in governance and reinforcing commands, he makes them like tigers and leopards with claws and fangs, or birds with six wings—none fail to serve.

Yet these are merely tools to aid victory, not the means to ensure it. The outcome of war lies fundamentally in governance. When governance prevails over the people, the lower ranks submit to the upper, and the army is strong. When the people prevail over governance, the lower ranks rebel against the upper, and the army is weak. Thus, virtue and righteousness sufficient to win the hearts of the world’s people, undertakings sufficient to meet the world’s crises, appointments sufficient to gain the hearts of worthy scholars, and planning sufficient to know the balance of strength and weakness—these are the roots of certain victory.

Vast lands and numerous people do not make one strong; sturdy armor and sharp weapons do not ensure victory; high walls and deep moats do not guarantee security; harsh commands and severe punishments do not inspire awe. A state with sound governance, though small, will endure; a state with failing governance, though large, will perish.
